title: Corrections
description: The New DVD's column on Tuesday misidentified the distributor of ''House of Sand and Fog.'' It is DreamWorks, not Warner.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the role of the Connecticut legislative committee that is to decide whether to impeach Gov. John G. Rowland misidentified the post once held by George Jepsen, the state Democratic committee chairman, who commented on the inquiry. He was majority leader of the State Senate, not the House.

title: Ballet: Fond Farewell
description: Ballet stars of yesterday, today and (presumably) tomorrow came together at the Palais Garnier, the venerable opera house, in Paris on Tuesday evening for a glittering homage to Claude Bessy, 71, the former Paris Opera Ballet principal who is stepping down after 31 years as director of the company's prestigious dance school. Opening with a grand dfil, a 20-minute procession of 230 dancers of all ages, the show highlighted many of Ms. Bessy's former pupils, including Sylvie Guillem, Agns Letestu, Laurent Hilaire, Nicolas Le Riche and even Patrick Dupond, who is now retired. Today's students, some as young as 10, also performed. At the end of the evening, Ms. Bessy was given a 15-minute standing ovation. Elisabeth Platel, a former principal dancer here who also studied with Ms. Bessy, has been named her successor. ALAN RIDING

title: To Portray The Horror, News Media Agonize
description: As photographs and videotaped images of the attack on four private security workers in Falluja arrived at news organizations yesterday, editors and producers faced an immediate challenge: how to show what happened without offending viewers and readers?

title: Day After Grisly Killings, Iraqi Newspapers Look Elsewhere
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 1  Graphic coverage of the killing of four Americans in Falluja was splashed on television screens by Arabic news channels today. But on newsstands, Iraqis saw fewer displays of the attacks, which took place in a town known for its hostility to Americans.

title: Glass Recycling and Weekly Pickups Will Resume Today
description: Full recycling of glass, plastic, metal and paper in New York City will resume this morning after a disruption of almost two years, and if that comes as a surprise, do not be alarmed. Plenty of New Yorkers are unprepared.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bid For Retailer
description: A consortium of American, British and Dutch investors has made a 1.43 billion euro ($1.75 billion) bid to buy the Dutch retail group Royal Vendex, which owns many of the leading Dutch department stores including Vroom & Dreesmann, Hema and de Bijenkorf. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, along with private equity companies in Britain and the Netherlands, are expected to make a definitive offer for Vendex in several weeks. The company reported net sales in its last fiscal year of about 4.7 billion euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Hong Kong Protest Opposes Potential Curbs on Democracy
description: HONG KONG, Friday, April 2 — Dressed mostly in black and holding white candles, a couple of thousand people held a vigil here on Thursday night to protest Beijing's plans to restrict Hong Kong's movement toward greater democracy.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ATI Posts 2nd-Quarter Profit
description: ATI Technologies Inc., the maker of computer-graphics chips, had a second-quarter profit of $47.6 million. The company's founder, Kwok Yuen Ho, will also step down as chief executive. Net income was 19 cents a share, compared with a restated net loss of $9.4 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier, the company, based in Markham, Ontario, said yesterday. Sales in the quarter that ended Feb. 29 rose 48 percent, to $463.3 million, from a restated $313.5 million.

title: Looking Back Across a Decade, With Bloody Regret
description: Consensus is in evidence in ''Ghosts of Rwanda,'' an enlightening two-hour ''Frontline'' chronicle of the Rwandan genocide on PBS tonight. Ten years later, almost everyone seems to regret that the United States didn't act to prevent it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, GEORGE HEARD
description: HAMILTON--George Heard. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of our Life Trustee George Heard Hamilton. His scholarship was unparalleled, and the art historians whom he trained and influenced are innumerable. As Chairman of the Committee on Painting and Sculpture, he deeply influenced the shape of the Museum's collection. His relationship with the Museum began in 1929, when, as a sophomore at Yale, he visited the first exhibition we mounted. Since then, his love for and knowledge of the Museum--and for the artists and staff who have shaped it--grew and buoyed us all. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his wife, Polly, and to their family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Leon D. Black, Chairman, the Trustee Committee on Painting and Sculpture Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: National Briefing | Washington: Ashcroft Back In Office
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft returned to work at the Justice Department, four weeks after he was hospitalized with a severe case of gallstone pancreatitis. Mr. Ashcroft, hospitalized March 4 with what he thought was a stomach flu, had his gallbladder removed five days later and had been recuperating at home for the last several weeks. In a statement, he thanked the doctors at George Washington University Hospital, Deputy Attorney General James Comey, who has run the department in his absence, and ''everyone for the prayers and expressions of support for my family and me over the past few weeks.'' Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Frozen in Fear? Mighty Mouse To the Rescue
description: PC gamers must often contend with a real-life problem in their fantasy worlds: the mouse. What if your trigger locks as you face down a squadron of zombies?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEARD, CHARLES J. II.
description: BEARD--Charles J. II. The Board of Trustees and the entire Phillips Academy community in Andover, MA express deepest sympathy at the death of Charles J. Beard II. A member of the Class of 1962, he had been a Charter Trustee since 1997.

title: What's That Sound?
description: I hadn't been to Mexico since 1996, so it definitely caught my ear when I started to hear two non-Spanish words on this trip that I'd never heard here before: ''China'' and ''India.'' Mexicans are increasingly aware that these two countries are running off with jobs and markets that Mexicans once thought they owned. You have to feel sorry for the Mexicans: they are hearing ''the giant sucking sound'' in stereo these days -- from China in one ear and India in the other. Worse, they seem stuck, unable to forge a coherent strategic response.

title: Bloomberg's Plan for Utopia in Early Education May Be Just That
description: On its face, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's detailed plans for spending $5.3 billion a year in additional state education aid is a dreamy blueprint for an ideal urban school system that would meet the needs of the city's 1.1 million students, providing everything from a new prekindergarten program for 3-year-olds to enhanced college counseling for high school students.

title: There's Saying and Then There's Saying
description: John Kerry is trying to turn administration comments on the economic benefits of moving jobs overseas into a weapon against President Bush, but a new television ad on the issue may leave Mr. Bush wondering just when he said what the commercial has him saying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRISTT, MILTON
description: KRISTT--Milton. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Milton Kristt, beloved father of our devoted member Abigail Kristt. Deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President

title: Europeans Criticize Iran's Plan To Start Up Enrichment Plant
description: The foreign ministries of Germany, France and Britain Wednesday criticized Iran's decision, announced last week, to start up a uranium conversion plant in Isfahan.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Cleric Condemns TV Show
description: The country's top cleric, Grand Mufti Sheik Abdulaziz bin Abdullah al-Sheik, issued an edict against the Arabic version of the reality television show ''Star Academy,'' saying it was against Islam to broadcast, finance, participate in, watch or even admire the popular talent contest, according to the London-based pan-Arab newspaper Al Hayat. He objects to the show's ''mixing between sexes, facilitating debauchery,'' adding that ''it is obvious that this program is one of the reasons for bringing plague and disasters on Islam and Muslims. Protests in Bahrain forced the producer of another popular reality show, ''Big Brother,'' to take it off the air there a month ago. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Photo Sharing, Desktop to Desktop
description: DIGITAL photos are glorious, brilliant, liberating, flexible and free. They can also be a royal pain.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: ASHCROFT BACK IN OFFICE Attorney General John Ashcroft returned to work at the Justice Department, four weeks after he was hospitalized with a severe case of gallstone pancreatitis. Mr. Ashcroft, hospitalized March 4 with what he thought was a stomach flu, had his gallbladder removed five days later and had been recuperating at home for the last several weeks. In a statement, he thanked the doctors at George Washington University Hospital, Deputy Attorney General James Comey, who has run the department in his absence, and "everyone for the prayers and expressions of support for my family and me over the past few weeks."    Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Life's Astringent Taste Can Go Down Smooth
description: ''Vodka Lemon'' just might be the world's iciest postcard film: you will never be so happy to sit inside a cozy, theater as when you watch the actors exhaling clouds of warm breath over the blindingly white expanse.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Raises Forecast
description: The All Nippon Airways Company raised its forecast for net profit for the fiscal year just ended, citing an increase in overseas travel and cost cuts. All Nippon said it expected net profit of 21.5 billion yen ($206 million) for the year ended yesterday compared with an earlier forecast of 17.5 billion yen and a net loss of 28.26 billion yen in the previous year when the airline was hit by a drop in air travel after the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome. All Nippon said demand was strong over the last year for business-class seats on flights to the United States and Europe. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Explorations In Tie-Dye And Titanium
description: ''I'd like to dream on,'' said the Japanese textiles designer Jun-ichi Arai, above. Though in frail health, Mr. Arai, 72, is still dreaming up new materials. ''We can look forward to many things never seen before,'' he said. His fabrics, including tie-dyed aluminum or titanium blends, are in a retrospective at Gallery Gen. Textiles like ''Beyond the Rainbow,'' right, and ''Celestial Sea,'' above right, start at $600 for a 72-by-65-inch piece. Silky stainless steel thread bracelets are $35. Gallery Gen is at 158 Franklin Street (Hudson Street); www.gallerygen.com or (212) 226-7717. Mr. Arai will give a free lecture today at 6 p.m. in the Murphy Amphitheater of the Fashion Institute of Technology, Building D, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street; (212) 217-5772. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMALLEN, PAUL
description: SMALLEN--Paul, age 91, passed away on March 28th in Lantana, Florida. Devoted husband of the late Sylvia. Beloved father of Diane and Werner Grob, and the late Suzanne Morrell. Grandfather of Andrew (Michelle Bolek) Morrell, Lee (LeeAnn) Morrell. Great-grandfather of Sydney Rose. You made everyone's day that much brighter.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GLICKSMAN, JACK
description: GLICKSMAN--Jack. 12/9/1915--4/2/2003 First Lieutenant, U.S. Army Air Force, World War II (Europe); Insurance Broker for 55 years; owner of Aster Agency (insurance brokerage) from 1978 to 1992; married to his beloved Lettie (nee Berger) for 60 years. You filled our world with your love, your humor, your unquenchable zest and wonder at the world, your mighty efforts to make things right for us, your goodness. We take comfort from one of your many poems: ''I have had more than the allotted time for man--so mourn not for me today... I enjoyed the wonders of youth A great enduring love Much loved father Patriot soldier And to the end Joyous in the wonders Of each new day.'' Lettie Glicksman, Jane Glicksman, Hallie Schmidt, Dede, Stephen and Carla Kessler

title: Connecticut Seeks to Shut Off Cross-Sound Cable (Again)
description: Skirmishing over an underwater electrical wire is fast becoming a rite of spring between Long Island and Connecticut.

title: Americans Are Jolted By Gruesome Reminders Of the Day in Mogadishu
description: The grisly television news images from Iraq left David J. Rogers shaking his head in sadness on Wednesday evening and turning away. In a quiet bar here, Mr. Rogers learned of American bodies, beaten and dragged through streets in Iraq, body parts hanging from a bridge, crowds cheering and taunting.

title: Tunisian Named as Leader Behind Madrid Bombings
description: MADRID, April 1  Investigators have identified a Tunisian man as the coordinator of the March 11 attacks on commuter trains in Madrid, according to court documents.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Aristide Files Suit Contending Kidnapping
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the exiled president of Haiti, filed a lawsuit in Paris against unnamed French officials, accusing them of ''death threats, kidnapping and sequestration,'' his lawyer said. The lawyer, Gilbert Collard, said American lawyers would file a similar lawsuit in the United States. Mr. Aristide has repeatedly said that he was forced into leaving Haiti and his presidency in February. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly Passes Stray Voltage Bill
description: The Assembly approved a bill 143 to 2 ordering the Public Service Commission to require gas and electric utilities to report all incidents in which people or animals come in contact with stray voltage. The bill comes after a Manhattan woman, Jodie S. Lane, above, was killed on Jan. 16 while walking her dogs in the East Village when she stepped on a metal plate that had been electrified by a faulty underground cable. The bill also requires the commission to suggest corrections when inspections reveal problems. A similar Senate bill may be considered as early as this summer. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUSHNER, RAE
description: KUSHNER--Rae. The worldwide Shaare Zedek family mourns the loss of a cherished friend and a beloved matriarch. She was a gentle person who personified joy, humility, integrity and a deep sense of compassion. Rising from the indescribable horrors of the Holocaust, Mrs. Kushner with her late husband Joseph, of blessed memory, devoted their lives to ensuring the physical survival and spiritual needs of the Jewish people. A past recipient of our ''Woman of Achievement Award'', we will always be grateful for Mrs. Kushner's quick acceptance to become one of the founding members of the Women's Board and for her service as one of its Honorary Board members. Through her son Charles' service on our International Board of Directors, her daughter-in-law Seryl's participation as a member of the American Committee's National Board and the National Women's Division Board, and their status as Benefactors of the new Department of Emergency Medicine, they so meaningfully carry on Mrs. Kushner's deep devotion and commitment to providing for the medical needs of the people of Jerusalem. May the beautiful memories of the times spent together provide Charlie and members of the family with consolation, and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Dr. Jonathan Halevy Director-General Lee Weinbach, Pres Nat'l Women's Div

title: When a Phone Isnt Simply a Phone
description: NOT so long ago, cellphone accessories mostly meant swivel belt clips, leather-look carrying cases or, perhaps for the more adventuresome, flashy snap-on face plates. But as wireless phones have evolved, so have the extras that manufacturers promise will help make cellphones more useful, fun and cool.

title: Dream-Filled Missile Silos
description: The Pentagon is foolishly racing to deliver on President Bush's grandiose 2000 campaign promise to have a still unproven, money-munching missile defense system deployed in time for the November election. It's supposed to provide protection against incoming ballistic missiles. But, so far, the rush into the old ''Star Wars'' dream amounts to an extravagant political shield.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Journalist Gets Bail
description: Khawar Mehdi Rizvi, the Pakistani journalist arrested in December along with two French journalists for traveling to the southwestern city of Quetta without government permission, has been released on bail. The Frenchmen were freed and deported soon after their arrests, but Mr. Rizvi was charged with sedition and conspiracy and faces a possible life sentence. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Steps to Change State Deadline For Budget
description: With just hours left until New York was officially overdue to adopt a state budget, lawmakers here agreed Wednesday night to changes they said would help end the chronic lateness.

title: India's Economy Soared by 10% in Last Quarter of 2003
description: India's economy soared 10.4 percent in the final quarter of 2003, making it one of the fastest growing in the world, even ahead of China.

title: Nascar Penalizes Earnhardt For Rules Violation in Race
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr. admitted Sunday that he deliberately spun out his car late in the Food City 500 Nascar Nextel Cup race at Bristol Motor Speedway to force a caution flag and avoid falling a lap behind the leader and eventual winner, Kurt Busch.

title: A Combination Peanut Gallery, Violin Garage, Closet and Cat Gym
description: What do you call a combination loft bedroom, amphitheater, staircase and dresser? ''It's either a huge piece of furniture or a little piece of wall-floor-room,'' said Christian Volkmann, above with Lynnette Widder. They are partners in aardvarchitecture, which created the unnameable 180-square-foot object shown here for a loft in Midtown Manhattan. (The structure may remind some of the artist Andrea Zittel's built-in fiberboard bleachers-cum-room called Prototype for Raw Desk No. 2.)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: F.B.I. Arrests 17 In Odometer Fraud
description: A crime ring that bought cheap cars at auction, rolled back each of their odometers by thousands of miles and then sold the vehicles for far more than they were worth was dismantled after a 15-month investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, officials announced yesterday. Seventeen men were arrested. More than 1,000 used cars were bought and subsequent buyers were overcharged by more than $7.5 million, officials said. The ring also changed the titles and other documentation for the vehicles to match the lower mileage. Sherri Evanina, a spokeswoman with the F.B.I.'s Newark division, said Robert Fiorello, 54, of Jackson, was the group's leader. Mr. Fiorello's lawyer could not be reached. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: After Opener, Matsui Shows Yankees How to Save Face
description: Out on the field, stadium workers scrubbed the Major League Baseball logo from the turf behind home plate. Most of the Yankees had taken their seats on the team bus, bound for the airport and the United States. Hideki Matsui would soon join them, but he had to play the hero a few last moments.

title: Woman Linked To Mobster Found Dead At L.I. Hotel
description: A woman who had been linked to Peter Gotti, the married leader of the Gambino crime family, was found dead yesterday at a Red Roof Inn in Nassau County in what was believed to be a suicide, law enforcement officials said.

description: WASHINGTON, March 20

title: Governors Ask for Extension of Welfare Law
description: Governors of both parties appealed to Congress on Wednesday to pass a five-year extension of the 1996 welfare law, even as the Senate was caught up in growing partisan conflict over Democrats' demands that the measure include an increase in the minimum wage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEWERTZ, SID
description: GEWERTZ--Sid. 86, died March 13. An electro-plater for 55 years, owner of Techem, avid handball-player, photographer, a man of unflagging good-humor, Sid will be missed by his wife of 61 years, Adrienne, and sons Ken and Dan. Information on service April 3, 617-868-4867.

title: Havas plans to unveil a new network to manage various services and agencies under one roof.
description: HAVAS, the French advertising conglomerate, plans today to announce a marketing services network called Euro RSCG 4D.

title: SONY ACCUSES EASTMAN KODAK OF PATENT INFRINGEMENT
description: Sony yesterday accused Eastman Kodak of illegally using technology it developed for its digital cameras. In a suit filed in federal court in New Jersey, Sony said that Kodak infringed 10 patents dating to the early 1980's, including those for imaging devices that use clock settings and electronic shutters capable of multiple exposure time settings. Sony said it had been unable to reach an out-of-court settlement with Kodak over the use of the patents. The company, based in Tokyo, has not specified the damages it is seeking. The suit comes three weeks after Kodak brought its own suit contending that Sony infringed 10 patents that Kodak issued between 1987 and 2003. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mayor Wants $5.3 Billion From State For Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made an audacious play yesterday for billions of dollars in state money that he proclaimed is owed to New York City to pay for the improvement of its public schools, laying out exactly how much he expects and precisely what he would do with the money.

title: Judge Says Racketeering Suit Can Proceed Against Block and Household International
description: A class-action racketeering lawsuit that accuses H&R Block, the big tax preparation company, and Household International, a consumer lender, of conspiring to trick poor customers into taking out high-interest loans will proceed toward trial, a federal judge in Chicago ruled on Tuesday.

title: A Tool That Puts All Your Passwords At Your Fingertip
description: Fingerprint scanners are nothing new, but high prices have made them a tough sell for many technology buffs. A new scanner that costs $50 may persuade consumers to give biometric technology another look.

title: Better Late Than Never
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Furniture Fair Spreads Its Wings Across the City
description: During the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in May, New York will emulate the Salone Internazionale del Mobile in Milan, where satellite events for big names and emerging talent draw huge crowds. Away-from-the-Javits events will include ''Triptych,'' an exhibition by two established artists, the designer-ceramist Bodo Sperlein and the textile and wallpaper designer Neisha Crosland, along with works by Alex Taylor, making his New York debut (his cabinet is at left). The show is May 15 to May 19 at Salon Moderne, 281 Lafayette Street (Prince Street).

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Oil Exploration Near Refuge
description: Alaska will allow oil and gas exploration in the Beaufort Sea next to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge starting in October, Gov. Frank H. Murkowski said. ''The offshore area is the state sovereign area so we have the flexibility of leasing along that coastline,'' Mr. Murkowski said. Environmentalists contended that the action was intended to pressure the federal government to open the refuge's coastal plain for drilling. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 22 about the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference in Austin, Tex., gave an outdated affiliation for Jay Broberg, a panelist. He is no longer president of MCA Records; the company has been folded into Geffen Records, and its co-presidents are Jordan Schur and Polly Anthony.

title: Sept. 11 Panel Scrutinizing Past Testimony
description: The staff of the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks is conducting a detailed review of all discrepancies found in public and private statements by Condoleezza Rice and Richard A. Clarke in drawing up questions for Ms. Rice when she testifies before the panel, probably next week, commission officials said Wednesday.

title: Collapsible Comfort in a Backyard Eden
description: WHAT kind of a person bypasses drugstore aisles chock full of inexpensive folding camp chairs to go online and obsessively research such traits as ''resin feet'' and ''chair back imprint areas?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUGUST, JOAN (NEE FRIEDMAN)
description: AUGUST--Joan (nee Friedman), in West Palm Beach, Florida, on March 30, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Neil August. Devoted mother of Edythe Parker, Karen and Debra August. Loving grandmother of Michelle, Allison, Jeremy and Lindsay. Beloved sister of Lucy Peck and adored aunt and great-aunt. Graveside service Sunday, April 4, 1:30 PM, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, family requests contributions to Marcia August Scholarship Fund, Ossining High School, NY.

title: International Panel Issues Accounting Rules
description: The International Accounting Standards Board on Wednesday issued what are supposed to be its final rules before Europe adopts international accounting standards in 2005, but the final shape of an important rule on derivatives, unpopular with many financial institutions, could change.

title: In Britain, to the Bauhaus Born
description: ''WHEN the British modernize, they aren't very clever,'' wrote Ruby Ross Wood, an American decorator traveling through England in the 1930's. ''Nasty modern bedspreads of blue and silver moire, and curtains of pink and silver brocade.'' Too bad her itinerary didn't include this village in Surrey, about 15 miles southwest of London. Amid red brick suburban houses not far from the palace of Hampton Court stands the Homewood, one of the country's architectural rarities: a high-style Modernist house built in 1938, its original furnishings largely intact, right down to Bruno Mathsson chaise longues upholstered in fluffy sheepskin.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Court Rules Against President
description: The country's highest court ruled that President Rolandas Paksas violated the Constitution by granting citizenship to a Russian businessman and campaign supporter. The decision cleared the way for Parliament to vote on his impeachment as early as next week. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: VETO THREATENED ON HIGHWAY BILL
description: Taking a cue from Ronald Reagan, President Bush is threatening to cast his first veto on a popular highway bill filled with pet projects of Congress members eager before the election to win highway money for constituents stuck in traffic back home.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Voting Software To Be Demonstrated
description: A group that criticizes the current crop of privately developed electronic voting machines as hacker prone and mysterious will demonstrate free software today in San Jose, Calif., that it says will make elections more secure and accountable. The Open Voting Consortium produced the software, which runs on most computers of recent vintage and incorporates a system that allows voters to verify their choices on a paper ballot after casting their votes -- a feature not found in most touch-screen voting systems on the market. A simulation of the system is at www.openvotingconsortium.org. ''It's the open alternative to the 'black box''' systems currently in use, said Alan Dechert, president of the group of volunteer computer engineers and scientists from around the world who contributed to the effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATELSON, DANIEL ANDREW
description: PATELSON--Daniel Andrew. Beloved husband of Marsha. Devoted father of Michael Aaron. Cherished friend to many. Services today, 11AM, ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: The Clock Ticks, but There's Little Concern
description: There was a time, as quaint as it now seems, when New York's leaders were so concerned about meeting the April 1 deadline for passing the state budget that they would literally stop the clocks at midnight in the Capitol.

title: Agreement Is Near On Drug-Testing Plan
description: Major League Baseball and the players association will soon agree on a drug-testing policy for a proposed World Cup, said Rob Manfred, baseball's executive vice president for labor relations.

title: Entr'acte : Islamic art as a bridge to understanding in West
description: PARIS  Given the disturbing level of animosity between the West and much of the Islamic world, can increased appreciation of Islamic art in the West help bridge the cultural divide? Optimistic? Perhaps. But encouragingly, since the shock of Sept. 11, 2001, interest in understanding the Islamic world through its art has been growing.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer May Sell Shares
description: The Standard Life Assurance Company, Europe's largest customer-owned insurer, may sell shares in an initial public offering, making it easier to raise money and meet stricter capital requirements. The insurer will propose a plan to change its ownership structure by the annual general meeting in 2006, the chief executive, Sandy Crombie, said in a conference call.

title: 3 Are Finalists for the Hobey Baker Award
description: Zach Parise, who signed with the Devils earlier this week, was named yesterday as one of three finalists for the Hobey Baker Award, college hockey's equivalent to the Heisman Trophy.

title: German Court Sees No Basis To Convict Bank Chief
description: In a legal reprieve for Germany's most prominent banker, a court here declared on Wednesday that it had no grounds to convict Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Deutsche Bank, or three others on criminal charges in handing out rich bonuses.

title: Hey, Wanna See Me Onstage? Buy a Ticket!

description: For the first time in more than a year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's popularity has improved to the point that his approval ratings now outweigh his disapproval ratings, according to a poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac University.

title: Blog-Bleary? Try (What Else?) a Blog
description: BY pointing readers to the Web's newest and best bits, Web logs offer a way to cut through online clutter. But now that there are millions of blogs, what was once a solution to the information glut has started to become part of the problem. So perhaps inevitably, sites and services have popped up that add another level to the information food chain by digesting the Web digests.

title: Asia Society Selects Art Historian As President
description: The Asia Society, founded in 1956 by John D. Rockefeller III to foster understanding of Asia, has a new president, Vishakha N. Desai, the first woman and the first Asian-American to head the organization.

title: Morality for Sale
description: The United Nations Commission on Human Rights, the world's most important political body devoted to human rights concerns, is halfway through its deliberations here. Each year delegates from the 53 member states meet for six weeks to name the worst offending countries and adopt resolutions condemning their abuses. For years, however, the commission instead has been a haven for rogue governments -- who get elected to the body in order to shield themselves from international scrutiny and criticism. The failure of international leadership has become increasingly intolerable, especially in an age when terrorism and repressive regimes go hand in hand.

title: Corrections

title: In the West Bank and Gaza, Getting From Place to Place Is More Stop Than Go
description: ''Checkpoint,'' a grueling Israeli documentary filmed in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, home to three million Palestinians, is a movie that operates on the principle that the most powerful film to be made about a traffic jam is one that sticks you in the middle of gridlock without an explanation and keeps you there for 80 minutes. Its notion of making this frustrating experience as firsthand as possible works to a degree.

description: HILL--George B., Sr. The Board of Trustees, Administration, and Staff of Wyckoff Heights Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and esteemed Hospital Trustee, George B. Hill, Sr. Mr. Hill joined the Board of Trustees in 1985 and served as Treasurer since 1998. His commitment to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center and the Community was demonstrated by his many years of devoted service. Mr. Hill was a dynamic business leader and a man of great personal warmth. Mr. Hill received the Citizen of the Year Award in 1984 from the Bedford-Stuyvesant Lions Club and was a recipient of the United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Trustee Award. Mr. Hill will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Emil J. Rucigay, Esq. Chairman-Board of Trustees Wyckoff Heights Medical Center Dominick J. Gio President & CEO Wyckoff Heights Medical Center

title: To Thwart A Thief, Not Airport Security
description: Because of increased security concern, old-fashioned locks are not permitted on checked baggage on airplanes. In fact, airport security inspectors have the right to cut locks or even the suitcase. But the Transportation Security Administration does allow locks like EasyCheck, which inspectors can open with a special code and a tool. The locks, which can then be reclosed, come in bright colors and in two sizes, standard and compact; $20 for two at Brookstone, www.brookstone.com or (866) 576-7337. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Shrinks
description: Canada's gross domestic product shrank 0.1 percent, adjusted for inflation, in January in contrast to a 0.5 percent gain in December, Statistics Canada said, raising the prospect that the Bank of Canada will cut its main interest rate for a third time this year. The bank's next monetary policy review is scheduled for April 13. The contraction in January resulted chiefly from weak vehicle sales, weak oil and gas output and a softening housing market. Analysts expect that first-quarter growth will be about 2 percent at an annualized rate, down from the 3.8 percent posted in the final three months of 2003. Bernard Simon (NYT)

description: A man who was convicted of fatally shooting a high school student was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison, District Attorney Richard A. Brown announced yesterday. Last month, a jury convicted the man, Charles Sealey, 23, of Far Rockaway, of murder. In 2001, he and several friends confronted a cousin of the victim, the district attorney's office said. The victim, Thomas Johnson, 17, of Far Rockaway, intervened. As he walked away, seven bullets were fired, one of which killed him, prosecutors said. Mr. Sealey turned himself in to authorities several days later. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Europe Backs Tax Challenge
description: The European Union has offered its support to the America's efforts to persuade China to scrap tax breaks for domestic computer chip makers, a European Commission spokeswoman said. The Chinese government waives a large part of the value added tax on chips produced in China, putting importers like Intel at a competitive disadvantage. The main chip maker in the European Union, Infineon of Germany, benefits from the Chinese tax break because it is based in China. The spokeswoman, Arancha Gonzlez, said the union was offering to be a third party to the American complaint to the World Trade Organization because ''we have a systemic interest in that it may be chips today but tomorrow apply to other products where we do have an interest.'' Paul Meller (NYT)

Mr. Fox said he had been in a relationship with a man for six years and did not plan to make the announcement, but felt it was appropriate. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, EDWARD
description: LEVY--Edward. 96 years old, March 29th, 2004. Adored loving husband of 68 years of Helen (Friedman), children Leslie and Jim Levy, Jane and Andrew Dolkart, grandchildren Caren and Jonathan Greenhouse, Laurie Levy, Judith and Peter Dolkart and great-grandchildren Sophie and Caroline Greenhouse. Survived by the youngest of seven siblings, Miriam Horowitz. Brother of the late Sally Rogatz, Hannah Herman, A. Morris Levy, Celia Starkman, Fan Lang Weiss and Marcy Sallick. He was a man of style and elegance whose ethics and moral character were above reproach. Most of all, he was a dedicated family man who worshipped his wife. A wonderful role model for all to follow. A real estate developer, manager and appraiser who loved his work and came to the office through his 95th year. He will be forever missed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Rights Sold
description: The Irish drug maker Elan, which has been shedding assets to simplify its balance sheet and pay down debt, sold the rights to two drugs in deals worth $185 million. A British biotechnology company, Vernalis, will buy the North American rights to Frova, a migraine treatment, for $55 million over the next two years. The Japanese drug maker Eisai will buy the epilepsy drug Zonegran for $130 million, with additional payments if generic versions of the drug are delayed. In a statement, Elan's chief executive, Kelly Martin, said that selling the drugs ''sharpens our focus in neurology,'' and that the money would further the development of Antegren, a treatment for multiple sclerosis and Crohn's disease, and Prialt, for chronic pain, which are in the final stages of testing. title: F.T.C. PLANS TO CHALLENGE ARCH COAL'S PURCHASE OF RIVAL
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would challenge Arch Coal's plans to buy the assets of a rival, Triton Coal, rejecting a company offer intended to assuage competition concerns. The commission said it would seek a federal court order blocking the deal, valued at $364 million, because it would hurt competition among coal producers in the Southern Powder River Basin of Wyoming. Arch issued a statement saying that company executives ''respectfully disagree'' with the agency's decision. According to the complaint, the deal would leave the top three competitors controlling 86 percent of 2003 coal production in the Powder River Basin.

title: TIERONE AGREES TO BUY RIVAL BANK FOR $97.3 MILLION
description: The TierOne Corporation, parent of TierOne Bank, said yesterday that it planned to buy a rival bank, United Nebraska Financial, for $97.3 million in cash. The combined bank will have assets of about $2.7 billion, said TierOne, which is based in Lincoln, Neb. It is paying about 1.9 times United Nebraska's book value of $51.8 million. United Nebraska, which is closely held, is based in Grand Island, Neb. It has 15 banking offices and had total assets of $513.6 million and total deposits of $422.5 million as of Dec. 31.

title: BEST BUY AND CIRCUIT CITY REPORT STRONGER PROFITS
description: The nation's two largest electronics retailers, Best Buy and Circuit City, reported increases in quarterly profit yesterday, with Best Buy citing increased sales over the holiday season and Circuit City citing lower payroll expenses. Best Buy said it earned $469 million, or $1.42 a share, on a 21 percent increase in sales. Circuit City said it earned $89.6 million, or 43 cents a share, on a 1.8 percent increase in sales. The period was the fourth quarter for both companies. Best Buy said sales at stores open at least 14 months increased 9.7 percent, and Circuit City said sales at comparable stores increased 1 percent. Separately, Circuit City said it had agreed to buy InterTan, which operates 980 electronics retail stores in Canada, for about $284 million, and MusicNow, a privately held company that sells music downloads, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Kerry Has Shoulder Surgery
description: Senator John Kerry's doctor said that he found small tears on two torn tendons during surgery on Mr. Kerry's right shoulder on Wednesday but that the 45-minute procedure was completed without complications and the patient awoke from his time under general anesthesia lucid and laughing.

title: COURT APPROVES BERKSHIRE PURCHASE OF OAKWOOD HOMES
description: Berkshire Hathaway's $373 million purchase of Oakwood Homes won final court approval yesterday as part of Oakwood's bankruptcy reorganization plan. Judge Peter J. Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., approved the plan. He first approved the offer in January after no other bids were made for Oakwood, a builder of mobile homes. Warren E. Buffett, who controls Berkshire, plans to create the biggest mobile-home maker in the nation by merging Oakwood with Clayton Homes. Berkshire acquired Clayton in August for $1.7 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORNBLOWER, MARNE LLOYD, SMITH
description: HORNBLOWER -- Marne Lloyd-Smith, 85, born in New York City, died in Washington, DC, on March 30, 2004. Survived by her husband, George Marshall Hornblower, of Washington, her daughters, Marjorie Johnson of Golden, Colorado, Virginia Lawrence of New York City, and Nancy Rice of Coronado, California, her son, Jonathan Hornblower of Corpus Christi, TX, eleven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Huron Mountain Wildlife Foundation, Big Bay, MI. 49808, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOKE, ALISTAIR
description: COOKE--Alistair. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of 1150 Fifth Avenue Owners Corp. express their heartfelt sympathies to the family of Alistair Cooke. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

title: With Giambi as D.H., Ripples Go Through Roster
description: Jason Giambi had surgery on his left knee in November, but it is still not at full strength. After starting three games (including two exhibitions) on the artificial surface of the Tokyo Dome, he switched to designated hitter on Wednesday.

title: Irish Banks Accused of Profiting at Economy's Expense
description: When Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, hinted to a German newspaper last week about a possible cut in interest rates for the single-currency euro zone, banks and borrowers paid attention. A cut, which Mr. Trichet has avoided recently, would probably bring the central bank's main lending rate down to 1.75 percent from 2 percent -- already a 60-year low.

title: 4 FROM U.S. KILLED IN AMBUSH IN IRAQ; MOB DRAGS BODIES
description: Four Americans working for a security company were ambushed and killed Wednesday, and an enraged mob then jubilantly dragged the burned bodies through the streets of downtown Falluja, hanging at least two corpses from a bridge over the Euphrates River.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: NEW YORK

title: National Briefing | Washington: Presidential Papers Suit Called Moot
description: A case involving the release of papers of former presidents has ended with no clear result. Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of Federal District Court in Washington dismissed a lawsuit brought by historians challenging a Bush administration executive order that expands a president's power to keep secret a former president's papers, saying that the case was moot. The judge noted that almost all the papers from the most recent term at issue, President Ronald Reagan's, had been released since the suit was filed. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Suit Takes on Mississippi's Short-of-Resources Child Protection System
description: The start of Child Abuse Prevention Month on Thursday will be especially grim in Hancock County, where child welfare advocates have long gotten used to making do with less.

title: I.B.M. Will Collaborate Somewhat More on Chip Design
description: I.B.M. announced yesterday that it planned to adopt a more open strategy in its microprocessor business, borrowing a page from successful collaborative software projects like Linux.

title: Proving Age Discrimination
description: The Age Discrimination in Employment Act was intended to protect older workers from bias. Federal courts, however, have frequently given the law an unduly narrow interpretation, leaving older Americans vulnerable to unfair treatment. This week, the Supreme Court accepted a case that can rectify this problem -- if it decides that older workers can rely on the same burden of proof as plaintiffs in cases of race and sex bias. Doing otherwise would leave millions of working Americans who are 40 or older vulnerable to mistreatment.

title: Corrections
description: A film listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for ''The Middle of the World'' included an outdated reference to its opening, and an erroneous reference from the publicist to the location in Manhattan. Originally scheduled for April 9, the opening has been scheduled for tomorrow -- at the Quad Theater, not Cinema Village.

title: George Heard Hamilton, 93, Museum Director and Author
description: George Heard Hamilton, an authority on modern art who trained art historians and museum curators, died on Monday at a nursing home in Williamstown, Mass., his son, Richard, said. He was 93.

title: A Major Step Forward For Lincoln Center Plan
description: The first step in an ambitious redevelopment of Lincoln Center received approval yesterday from most of the organizations that comprise that New York showcase for the performing arts. The vote enables Lincoln Center to begin fund-raising and construction on a $325 million overhaul of the campus's main artery along West 65th Street.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Drivers Fined For Phone Use
description: More than 1,300 drivers were caught talking on cellphones and issued tickets last week in a crackdown throughout Westchester County. The fine for a first offense is $100, with a second infraction at $200. The action enforced a three-year-old state law banning drivers from using a cellphone without a hands-free device. Thirty-two police departments participated in the crackdown, which began March 19. By the end of the week, the police had issued 1,331 summons, which is equal to about 16 percent of the 8,384 tickets issued in the county last year. County Executive Andrew J. Spano called the initiative a success and said a second one would soon follow. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Reviving the Range Finder, With Some Digital Twists
description: A new digital camera from Epson has an unusual feature: a mechanical film advance lever. It does not, of course, move film. But it does reset the shutter, which is entirely mechanical.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Exports Rise
description: Despite concerns over the bird flu outbreak and a resurgent Muslim rebellion in Thailand's southernmost provinces, exports rose 22.3 percent in February compared with the month a year ago, to $7.22 billion, according to data released by the central bank. Industrial production in February rose 16.3 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Federal and Canadian Agencies Join in Arresting 140 Said to Supply 15% of U.S. Ecstasy Pills
description: American and Canadian officials arrested more than 140 people in 18 cities on Wednesday in connection with a drug ring that the authorities said supplied 15 percent of the Ecstasy pills in the United States.

title: Peace Gestures By Palestinians And the Israelis
description: With three United States envoys coming to assess the state of the Middle East conflict, Israelis and Palestinians both made gestures on Wednesday intended to show good faith in the stalled peace process.

description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it was proposing a measure that would overhaul its existing stock-option plan without having to record the options as an expense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, MALCOLM
description: GOLDMAN--Malcolm, mathematician, died on March 18, 2004. He was the husband of Ruby; brother of Alvin Goldman and Sybil Robins, brother-in-law of Holly Smith and Gene Robins. For him doing mathematics was life giving. He received a doctorate from the University of Chicago. In his long career, he worked at Bell Labs, and taught at Berkeley, University of Michigan (Ann Arbor), Reed Collge, and NYU (Courant). A hallmark of his career was his interest in and work toward improving undergraduate education.

title: Poll Picks McCain as Kerry's Vice President
description: Anew poll asked people of voting age which Democratic vice presidential candidate would be most qualified to become president if something should happen to President John Kerry. The answer? A Republican: Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Nets Win, But Martin Takes Seat
description: ''Who's the new guy?'' Richard Jefferson shouted as Kenyon Martin took jumpers before Wednesday night's game with the Wizards at the MCI Center. For a moment, the Nets' players and coaches could share a laugh. But it was only a moment.

title: Actors Switch Horses After Act I, Giving a New Twist to a Theme
description: Some plays have the single-mindedness of a short story. Everything turns on one event, one moment; everything is driven by what Flannery O'Connor called the mystery of personality. As she put it: ''If you start with a real personality, a real event, then something is bound to happen.'' A story is a complete dramatic action. The risk is always that the action will feel like the writer's invention, more calculated than inevitable.

description: At Jane Addams High School in the South Bronx yesterday, the makeup maven Bobbi Brown was as comfortable playing on the floor with toddlers in the school's nursery as she was lecturing cosmetology students on her 10 rules for success.

description: Correction Appended

title: Kerry and Democratic Groups Accused of Finance Violations
description: President Bush's campaign and the Republican Party accused Senator John Kerry and several Democratic organizations on Wednesday of violating campaign finance laws, contending that the groups are improperly buying television advertisements to support Mr. Kerry and illegally coordinating these commercials with his campaign.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: L-3 And I.B.M. Start Chip Venture
description: L-3 Communications Holdings, a maker of military electronics, has entered a technology services agreement with I.B.M. to customize computer chips for security and military applications. The five-year agreement has a total expected value of about $80 million for I.B.M., L-3 said. L-3 shares rose 27 cents, to $59.48.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Children Steal To Feed Friends
description: Two Harare street children stole Zimbabwean currency worth $23,000, then bought food and clothes for scores of other homeless children, The Herald, a state-controlled newspaper, reported. They also bought household goods and booked a hotel room before being arrested, the paper said. It quoted police officials as saying that the two were aided by a store accountant who agreed to leave the money -- 100 million Zimbabwe dollars -- on a table next to an open window. Two-thirds of Zimbabweans are said to be short of food in the fourth year of an economic collapse widely attributed to government fiscal and land policies. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Russian Parliament Moves Toward Ban on Public Demonstrations
description: The Russian Parliament took the first step on Wednesday toward passing a law that would ban demonstrations in most public places, narrowing one of the crucial freedoms won as the Soviet Union came to an end.

title: White House Memo; Trusted Adviser's Memoir Lifts Curtain a Bit
description: Karen P. Hughes has always been the personification of the good-news Bush White House, the presidential adviser who tried to turn every loss into political gold. In Ms. Hughes's world, George Bush's trouncing by Senator John McCain in the New Hampshire primary in 2000 showed his graciousness in defeat.

description: The New York Stock Exchange intends to expand its product range, including a possible move into derivatives trading, as part of a broad review to boost revenues and growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODSTONE, BERTRAM K.
description: GOODSTONE -- Bertram K. 87, of New York and Miami Shores passed away March 30, 2004 after a brief illness. He had a great love of life and lived every day to its fullest. Predeceased by his beloved wife Ellen, he is survived by his daughters Geraldine Goodstone, Felice Zensius, Peggy Katz and Andrew Goldstein. Funeral Services at 1p.m. on April 2, 2004, Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, Miami Beach, FL.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Emily Morison Beck, editor of three editions of Bartlett's Familiar Quotations, misspelled the surname of the poet who wrote ''Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard.'' (Its title had been misstated in Bartlett's, and Mrs. Beck corrected it on advice from the organist at her church.) The poet was Thomas Gray, not Grey.

title: Led by U.S., Nations Pledge Billions to Revive Afghanistan
description: Nations from around the world have pledged $4.4 billion in aid and low-cost loans to help stabilize and rebuild Afghanistan next year, with the United States accounting for about half of the contributions so far, American officials said Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURRET, RITA
description: TURRET--Rita. Beloved wife of Jack for 60 years, Devoted mother of Ira and David, loving mother-in-law of Josette and Nancy, grandmother of Jonathan, Daniel and Jason, sister of Barnet (Bud) Apfel. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City, on Friday, April 2, 11:45 AM.

title: MUTUAL FUND MANAGER TO PAY $50 MILLION FINE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that Massachusetts Financial Services, manager of the oldest mutual fund in the nation, had agreed to pay a $50 million penalty to settle allegations that it improperly disclosed brokerage arrangements. The S.E.C. said the investment company, a unit of Sun Life Financial of Canada, made arrangements with about 100 brokers to direct commissions on portfolio transactions toward them if the brokers would highlight their funds to clients. ''A mutual fund manager's use of fund brokerage commissions to pay for the marketing and distribution of the fund creates a conflict of interest that must be fully and fairly disclosed,'' said Stephen M. Cutler, director of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division.

title: Israelites Leave Egypt; a Choral Director Leaves New York
description: The choir at St. Thomas Church is composed of adult tenors, basses and countertenors and of boy sopranos who study at the church's own choir school. It produces a polished, powerful and beautifully balanced sound that for sacred music -- particularly that of the Renaissance and Baroque, historically sung by all-male choirs -- is about the best that New York has to offer.

title: Martha Stewart Seeks New Trial, Saying a Juror Lied
description: Lawyers for Martha Stewart sought a new trial yesterday, saying a juror failed to disclose that he had been arrested on an accusation of assault and provided other false information about his background.

title: All the World's a Soundstage as Audio Formats Evolve
description: DESPITE the ultramodern aura of devices that play compressed digital music files, from the Apple iPod player to the Rio Karma, they all share one anachronistic trait: they only have two audio channels. The basic stereo format used on vinyl records since the 1950's and carried over to CD's in the 1980's still defines most recorded music.

description: A measure of mortgage applications fell for a second week after reaching an eight-month high at midmonth, an industry group said yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; Left Back Or Promoted, Students Say Schools Failed
description: SOME were left back in their day and some were not. Some dropped out and others graduated from high school not knowing how to read a children's book. Now they are students again, at the Adult Learning Center of Lehman College in the Bronx, and they have a few things to say about the latest debate over social promotion in New York City.

title: Illumination for Tiny Places (Inside Flowers, Perhaps?)
description: FloraLytes will glow from within a napkin stuffed into a wine glass, stand in for candle flames inside a votive on a picnic table and provide points of light in flower vases. The battery-operated L.E.D.'s are cool enough to be sealed inside a balloon. They last for days (one day under water). Single-color sacks of 10 FloraLytes cost $20 and are available in white, red, amber, green, blue, teal, purple and pink at Jamali Garden Supplies, 149 West 28th Street; (212) 244-4025; jamaligarden.com. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Vancouver Journal; Chinese Prosper in Canada, and Eagerly Read About It
description: Raymond Chan, waging a hot race to win back his seat in Parliament, called a news conference here recently and invited only the four newspapers, three radio stations and two television stations that operate in Chinese.

title: Act of Hatred, Hints of Doubt
description: Hours after the deaths of the four American civilians who were dragged from their vehicle and mutilated in Falluja on Wednesday, an American general went before reporters in Baghdad with the air of measured assurance that has characterized every daily briefing on the military situation across Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Berlin Bans Scarves For Public Servants
description: The regional government of Berlin decided to ban the wearing of visible religious symbols by civil servants. Under the decision, to go into effect this summer, police officers, firefighters, judges, court officers and public school teachers are prohibited from wearing Muslim head scarves, Jewish skullcaps and large Christian crosses on the job. Berlin is the sixth of Germany's 16 states to ban the wearing of such symbols by civil servants. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: Testing 1, 2, 3; Critics Agree: Good Things Come in Small, Powerful Packages
description: IF a computer can have sex appeal, it is probably demonstrated most clearly in high-end gaming laptops. While young men in decades past might have lusted after the latest automotive hardware, the players (almost all young men) who gathered at a gaming party near Buffalo last month have a different passion. It made them enthusiastic road-testers of three roughly comparable laptops -- from Alienware, Dell and VoodooPC -- that a reporter asked them to size up.

title: Report Shows Slowing Pace Of Production In Midwest
description: Manufacturing in the Chicago area expanded at a slower pace in March, and orders placed with factories increased less than expected in February, government and private reports released yesterday showed.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: RHODE ISLAND: LAWMAKER DECLARES HE IS GAY The state House majority leader, Gordon Fox, announced that he is gay at a rally supporting gay marriage and at a hearing about bills on the issue. It was the first time Mr. Fox, a lawyer who has served in the Legislature since 1992, had publicly discussed his sexual orientation. Mr. Fox said he had been in a relationship with a man for six years and did not plan to make the announcement, but felt it was appropriate. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: A Deadline That Must Be Met
description: Today marks the 20th anniversary of overdue budgets for the State of New York. It's hard to imagine how to commemorate such a moment -- gift-wrapped clocks for the State Senate and Assembly? A sundial for the governor? This year, the normal crisis that comes from an ossified political system and degraded political culture has a new policy overlay. Besides coming up with the regular spending plan, Gov. George Pataki and the State Legislature must figure out a way to finance court-ordered improvements in public school education for needy children.

title: Officer Testifies of Her Two Sexual Assaults in the Army
description: For the first time since the Department of Defense ordered a senior-level investigation into reports of sexual assaults against servicewomen stationed in the Central Command area surrounding Iraq, an officer who said she had been sexually abused told her story on Wednesday at an open hearing before Congress.

title: Op-Art; Surprise!
description: It all began in 1906 when a former dye salesman named Sam Sorenson set himself up in a one-room office in Plainfield, N.J., and began funneling a powdered coal-tar derivative into bottles affixed with the label ''Cachoo.'' Thus was born sneezing powder, and, with its success, the modern joke and novelty industry. Sorenson later changed his name to S. S. Adams and, in 1909, invented that other staple of the cheap laugh: the Joy Buzzer.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: UKRAINE: MAYO ATTACK ON SOROS Protesters daubed the billionaire financier and philanthropist George Soros with what appeared to be mayonnaise during a rights conference in Kiev to object to his visit to Ukraine. Mr. Soros's Open Society Institute gives large amounts of money and training to pro-democracy groups, and his aid played a significant role in the ouster of Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Georgia last November. A Ukrainian group called Bratsvo took responsibility for the attack on Mr. Soros, saying they did not want him to prompt a similar uprising in Ukraine. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: A Loud Silence in Tunis
description: The abrupt and indefinite postponement of the Arab League summit meeting that was to have been held in Tunis last weekend was a more eloquent statement about Arab politics than any proclamation that might have come from the gathering. The rulers-for-life who gather at these extravaganzas usually produce grand declarations that are quickly forgotten, or buried under the rubble of the Middle East. Two years ago, the Beirut declaration, based on the Saudi peace initiative, was killed, in part, by a suicide bombing in Israel aimed at torpedoing any hope of a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian standoff. This time, under pressure from the Bush administration and from domestic dissidents to get serious about democracy, the Arab potentates were unable to agree even on a way to mark time.

title: Panel Is Split on Ways to Retest Air in Homes Near Ground Zero
description: A panel of experts began its critical review yesterday of the federal government's cleanup of Lower Manhattan after the collapse of the World Trade Center, and immediately found itself torn between the needs of science and the health concerns of residents.

title: Messier All but Says Goodbye to the Garden as a Player
description: If this was not Mark Messier's last game at Madison Square Garden, it sure felt that way. It also seemed similar to Wayne Gretzky's last game five years ago.

description: HUNCHED over his keyboard, eyes flicking intently over the digital animations dancing before him, Victor J. Group looked just like the other pale young gamers in the basement of a house on a nondescript side street in this Buffalo suburb. With his black T-shirt and blue jeans, he was even wearing the all-but-required uniform.

title: After Negotiations on Unity Fail, Cypriots to Decide on Plan
description: Three days of intense negotiations on proposals by Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations to heal the 30-year ethnic division of Cyprus ended without a formal agreement early Thursday, with Greece insisting that no deal was possible.

description: In ruling yesterday that the United States must provide Mexicans on death row with a fresh opportunity to argue that their convictions should be overturned, the World Court set itself on a collision course with American courts and officials.

description: ROSENBERG--Herman. April 21, 1902 to April 1, 1998. Missing you today, and every day. Carl

description: Before they were college basketball stars, they were perhaps the two tallest bodyguards to appear in a production of ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.'' Before they began answering questions about their N.B.A. dreams, they pedaled Blair Academy's 315 acres on bicycles that had once belonged to the headmaster's daughter.

title: UNION PACIFIC TO SHIFT SOME U.P.S. CARGO TO TRUCKS
description: Union Pacific said yesterday that it would try to ease delays starting next week by shifting a portion of cargo it carries for the United Parcel Service onto trucks. A spokesman for the railroad, Norman Black, said Union Pacific would pay truckers to carry United Parcel packages between Los Angeles and Chicago, and Dallas and Memphis for four weeks. Union Pacific won United Parcel's business in 2003, offering to deliver freight within 60 hours on a coast-to-coast train once a week in each direction, in conjunction with the CSX Corporation. The railroad is seeking to recover from a round of delays that began last year, costing as much as $50 million.

title: Defense Rests as Williams Declines to Testify in Manslaughter Case
description: Despite an earlier statement from his lawyer that he would take the stand, Jayson Williams said in court on Wednesday that he would not testify in his own defense at his aggravated manslaughter trial here. Minutes later, lawyers for Mr. Williams, the former basketball star, rested their case after calling five witnesses in four days of testimony.

title: Bush Signs Measure Outlawing Injury to Fetus During Crime
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  President Bush signed a law today making it a separate offense to harm the fetus in a federal crime committed against a pregnant woman, a law he said shows that "the United States of America is building a culture of life."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, JEAN
description: GREENE--Jean. Died Saturday, March 27th. Born April 15, 1910. Loving, kind, generous, funny. A true New Yorker born and bred. Lived in every neighborhood of Manhattan. From the Model T to the digital age she always kept up with the times. A most generaous spirit who loved her family and was able to share family wisdom, love and humor with her daughter Jenny, son-in-law Bill, grandchildren Cody and Rachel, sister Muriel, her not forgotten brother Bernie, nephews Cliff and Roger and niece Vicki and stepson Andy and numerous friends and neighbors. She will live in our spirits and we will miss her. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Plans Move
description: Gateway, a personal computer maker that has lost $1.84 billion in the last three years, will move its headquarters to Orange County, Calif., after buying eMachines. The company, based in Poway, a San Diego suburb, will pick a location within two weeks and may move as early as July, a spokesman, Robert Sherbin, said. The Los Angeles Times reported the move yesterday. Gateway this month purchased eMachines, based in Irvine, Calif. Gateway moved from South Dakota in 1998 to San Diego and in 2001 moved to its Poway headquarters.

title: Yes, We Have No Bananas, Yet
description: THERE is a huge saucer magnolia on my property in New Jersey. In eight years I have seen it bloom perfectly only once. I call it the brown tissue tree, because each year, around April 22, a hard frost turns the budding pink flowers to mush.

title: Flamenco: Farruquito's Future
description: The Flamenco dancer Farruquito, 22, right, has been released on $48,000 bail in Seville, Spain, after his arrest for a hit-and-run accident that killed a 35-year-old pedestrian, the Spanish daily El Mundo said. Originally it was believed that his 15-year-old brother was driving. Minors in Spain are not taken into police custody. Farruquito has already returned to the stage and will be able to perform in October at the Seville flamenco festival, where he has top billing. The judge in the case has revoked his passport, however, a move that will compel him to forgo a scheduled show in Japan. He was charged with negligent homicide, obstructing justice and failure to come to the aid of his victim. He is expected to go to trial next year. DALE FUCHS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PECK, STEPHEN M.
description: PECK--Stephen M. Most beloved and loving husband of Judith. Devoted father of Bradford, Kate, Jennifer and Suzanne Peck; father-in-law Craig Barne. Devoted stepfather of Emanuel, Liz, Edward, Stephanie and Andrea Stern. Adored and adoring grandfather of Josie, Ben, Maxine, Gabriel, Avery, Simon, Eliana, Ezra and Oliver. Beloved brother of Alice Soll, Joan Betty Schwarz. Devoted son-in-law of Charlotte Falk. Loved by his nephews, nieces, their children, his friends, and his extended inlaw family. title: Without Blinders, the Anatomy of an Illness
description: At the beginning of the classic essay ''Illness as Metaphor,'' Susan Sontag wrote, ''My point is that illness is not a metaphor, and that the most truthful way of regarding illness -- and the healthiest way of being ill -- is the one most purified of, most resistant to, metaphorical thinking.'' A similar idea seems to inform ''Son Frre,'' a wrenching new movie by Patrice Chreau, opening today in New York.

title: Wages of Bad Accounting: Bosses Got Rich While Companies Borrowed
description: THE stock market bubble might have been less severe. The wild swings in federal budget deficits might have been reduced. Companies would owe a lot less money. Less wealth would have been transferred from shareholders to managers, but then perhaps less paper wealth would have been created. Richard A. Grasso might still be running the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, RICHARD JAMES, JR.
description: LEWIS--Richard James, Jr. March 31, Springfield, VT, age 77. Born in Brooklyn, graduated from Brooklyn Tech H.S., received law degree from St. John's University, served in the U.S. Air Force World War II. Son of Annette and Richard J. Lewis, Sr. Brother of Gilbert, Jane (nee Dunbar), John, Cathy. Predeceased by wife Ruth (nee Chatfield). Survived by five children, Richard III, Harold, Keith, Gail, Beth and Moody. description: Interest rates shot sharply higher this afternoon after a surprisingly strong employment report for March suggested that all the facets of a steady economic recovery, including job growth, were finally in place.

description: The campaigns of Senator John Kerry and President Bush said yesterday that they were introducing new confrontational television commercials in swing states, with Mr. Kerry's spot criticizing Mr. Bush on job losses and Mr. Bush's criticizing Mr. Kerry on support of tax increases.

title: The Candidates Are Mortal
description: Politically, it sounds crippling -- the doctor's order that Senator John Kerry shake no hands on the campaign trail for the next few weeks, and hoist no babies into the air until mid-May. But realistically, there are other ways to work campaign crowds, and the senator wisely figures that the minor surgical repair of two torn shoulder tendons will leave him in better shape for the rest of the presidential marathon. The brief operation presented no problems, according to Mr. Kerry's doctors. But the intensely covered, four-day sidetracking of Mr. Kerry's public campaign is a further reminder that the nation needs to know the state of the major candidates' health in up-to-the-minute detail.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Teachers' Union President Re-Elected
description: Randi Weingarten, the president of the union that represents the city's 80,000 public school teachers, has been re-elected by a wide margin to a three-year term that begins July 1, union officials said yesterday. Ms. Weingarten has been president of the union, the United Federation of Teachers, since 1998. Ms. Weingarten defeated two opposition candidates, receiving 88.6 percent of nearly 47,000 votes cast. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Rate Left Unchanged Amid Mixed Signs in Europe
description: Europe's central bank stood its ground on Thursday in the face of conflicting evidence about the state of the Continent's economy, leaving its key interest rate unchanged at 2 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Exports Rise
description: South Korean exports rose more than a third for a second month in March, reaching a record as consumer spending picked up in its three biggest overseas markets -- China, Japan and the United States. Shipments rose 40 percent from a year earlier to $21.5 billion after climbing 45 percent in February, the commerce ministry said. Exports to China rose 54 percent in the first 20 days of March; sales to the United States increased 41 percent; and shipments to Japan climbed 52 percent.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Antidepressant Use Growing In Children
description: Antidepressant use among preschoolers is growing faster than among any other segment of the population, while use of the drugs among all children and adolescents grew 49 percent from 1998 to 2002, according to a study by Express Scripts, a managed-care pharmacy company. It found that the use of antidepressants among a sample of insurance clients younger than 18 grew to 2.4 percent in 2002 from 1.6 percent in 1998. The fastest-growing segment was those younger than 5, with use among preschool girls doubling and among preschool boys surging 64 percent. Gardiner Harris (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: THOUSANDS PROTEST AGAINST KING About 50,000 demonstrators demanding the restoration of democratic politics marched through the streets of Katmandu, the capital, in a peaceful protest against King Gyanendra. It was the biggest demonstration since 2002, when the king dissolved Parliament and later dismissed the prime minister, assumed executive powers and replaced the government with pro-monarchy politicians. The protest was organized by the country's six largest political parties. (AP)

description: BENNETT -- Robert Porter. On Friday, March 19, 2004 in Los Angeles, CA. Age 44. He was a cinematographer. Born in New York City, he received degrees from Colorado College and The American Film Institute. He is survived by his wife Cynthia Johnson Bennett of Los Angeles, his parents Robert and Elizabeth Bennett of Washington, D.C. and his brother Bruce of New York City and his brother and sister-in-law Andrew and JoAnn Bennett of San Francisco, CA. description: In just the past four years, 25-year-old Thabo James has lost both his brothers to AIDS. Sitting Thursday in his wheelchair at the Johannesburg General Hospital H.I.V. clinic, his eyes glazed, his frame stick-thin, he looked to be not far behind them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PECK, STEPHEN
description: PECK -- Stephen. We are deeply saddened by the tragic and untimely passing of Stephen Peck, a person whose vision of Jewish community had an enormous impact in creating the JCC in Manhattan. Stephen's wisdom, advice, guidance and friendship over the past 14 years has been invaluable, and will be forever remembered and cherished. He was the embodiment of a mensch, and his dedication to making the world a better place is the purest reflection of ''tikkun olam.'' On behalf of the Board of Directors and staff of the JCC, we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Judy, one of our founding spirits, as well as to his children Jennifer, Suzanne, Brad and Kate. We also send our deep sympathy to his stepchildren--Andrea, our fellow Board members Emanuel and Liz and Stephanie and Eddie--and to all his beloved grandchildren. We mourn this profound loss to his family and the entire community. Elizabeth Scheuer and Peter Joseph, Co-Chairs Nick Bunzl, President The JCC in Manhattan

description: Thomas F. Willers, a former top executive of Hooker Chemical and Occidental Petroleum and of Champion International, the paper company, died on March 24 at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 84.

description: Leading stock gauges rose for a third day in four yesterday after an index of manufacturing increased last month. The report from the Institute for Supply Management also showed that more factories added workers than at any time since 1987.

title: The Bronx Discovers Its Own Inner Mexico
description: The sight could dismay the average downtown restaurateur: a roomful of empty tables at 8 on a Saturday night. But the owners of modest Mexican restaurants scattered around the Bronx know better. At that hour, much of their immigrant clientele is still working -- some at those very same downtown restaurants. By midnight the tables will be filling up, the kitchen bustling and the Corona flowing. And of course, the music playing.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Computer Associates Names New Financial Officer
description: Computer Associates International said yesterday that it had hired Jeffrey J. Clarke, a former top executive at the Hewlett-Packard Company, as its chief financial officer. Mr. Clarke, 42, who was finance chief at Compaq Computer before its acquisition by Hewlett, fills a post left vacant after the board at Computer Associates dismissed several top finance executives in October amid a criminal inquiry into the software maker's accounting. He was widely viewed as a rising star at Hewlett before he left in November.

title: Inquiry at Bank Looks at Accounts Of Diplomats
description: As the F.B.I., banking regulators and a Congressional committee look more deeply into Saudi Arabian transactions at a Washington bank used widely by diplomats, a host of accounts controlled by representatives of several Mideast countries have also come under scrutiny, according to a person briefed on the investigations.

Like most get-togethers at the club, this one involved spirited drinking and boat talk, but there was a sense of occasion in the air, too.

title: An Evolution Runs Backward
description: Van Morrison was a consummate 1960's songwriter. He followed a path from pop and garage-rock with Them to thoroughly idiosyncratic fusions of soul, folk, jazz, rock and Celtic music in songs about earthly love and spiritual quests, the product of his instincts and an era of psychedelic openness. Long rock careers have a way of taking unlikely turns, though, and lately Mr. Morrison has pushed back into his own prehistory.

title: Saving German Moderns From Their Tortured Past
description: It is worth remembering that modern art was one of the forms of civilization that Hitler's Germany set out to destroy. In July 1937, Nazi officials, cracking down on what they viewed as a decadent misrepresentation of Nordic culture, seized 148 paintings, 27 sculptures and 319 drawings -- declaring all of them degenerate -- from the Kronprinzen Palace, the branch of Berlin's Nationalgalerie that was Germany's first museum of contemporary art.
