Pataki used the opening day of trout season in New York yesterday to announce the purchase of 239 acres along Sullivan County's Willowemoc Creek, a world-class trout stream in the Catskills that has drawn presidents and princes over the last century. The state will use $538,000 from the New York State Environmental Protection Fund to buy the land, which is part of what has been known for many years as the Van Norden property. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINSTON, CHARLES C., JR.
description: WINSTON--Charles C., Jr. of Rye, New York passed away on March 29, 2004. He was 96 years old. Charles was born in New York, New York on April 26, 1907 to Charles and Edna (Reitmeyer) Winston. Charles attended New York University and enjoyed a life long career in the insurance industry. Many years of which were spent as a principal in his own firm, Goestch, Steimetz and Winston. On June 4, 1932 he married Margaret Joerissen in Harrison New York. She died in June of 1993. He is also predeceased by a son, Major Charles C. Winston III, United States Air Force. Charles raised his family in Scarsdale New York before moving to White Plains in the 1960s. For the past three years he has resided at the Osborne Home in Rye New York in the company of his cherished companion Ruth Grimsey. Charles served in the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, Third Naval Division during World War II. He was a member of the United States Power Squadron and the N Club. He was also a long standing member of Westchester Hills Golf Club. In addition to Mrs. Grimsey, he is survived by a daughter, Marcia Balzac and her husband John of Scarsdale, NY and a daughter in law Elizabeth Yaffa and her husband Earl of Armonk, NY. He is also survived by five grandchildren: Kathleen Ramsey (Craig) of Pleasantville, NY, Patricia O'Reilly (Kevin) of Mount Pleasant, SC, Kimberly Hartman (Alan) of New York, NY, Charles C. Winston IV (Julia) of Greenwich, CT, and Nancy LeRoux (Pieter) of London, England. And nine great grandchildren Elizabeth, Kristina, James, Christopher, Katie, Kyle, Max, Michael and Andy. A memorial service will be held at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home in White Plains, NY on Wednesday, April 7, 2004 at 11:00am. Following will be a luncheon at the Westchester Hills Golf Club. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 60 East 42nd Street, Suite 1563, New York, NY 10165 or to the Westchester/Putnam Special Olympics, P.O. Box 744, Holmes, New York 12531, Attn: Jerry Peters.

description: ''Truth ultimately finds its way to people's eyes and ears and hearts.'' This sentence, uttered by Secretary of Defense Donald H. You can only hope that Mr. Rumsfeld is right, though his words inevitably call to mind the adage that in war, truth is the first casualty.

Upon graduation from Julia Richmond High School, she worked at Macy's Herald Square, where whe was named Miss Macy. She is survived by her husband Patrick J. Hughes, of Greenwich, her son Thomas J. Hughes, of Greenwich, her daughter Kathleen M. Chiaravalle, of Bronxville, NY, two sisters, Jeanette Grisoli of Baywater, NY, and Esther Ward of Brooklyn, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, 178 Greenwich Ave, on Saturday, April 3, 2004, at 10 AM. Burial will be held privately. description: LEVY--Edward. 96 years old, March 29th, 2004. Adored loving husband of 68 years of Helen (Friedman), children Leslie and Jim Levy, Jane and Andrew Dolkart, grandchildren Caren and Jonathan Greenhouse, Laurie Levy, Judith and Peter Dolkart and great-grandchildren Sophie and Caroline Greenhouse. Survived by the youngest of seven siblings, Miriam Horowitz. Brother of the late Sally Rogatz, Hannah Herman, A. Morris Levy, Celia Starkman, Fan Lang Weiss and Marcy Sallick. A real estate developer, manager and appraiser who loved his work and came to the office through his 95th year. He will be forever missed.

title: One Shot Is What Roddick Needed
description: The screaming forehand came in low and hard, the angle so acute that Carlos Moya could only whip his head around to watch it -- and any real hope of beating Andy Roddick -- sail by. Roddick saved a break point with that cross-court shot, struck while he was on a dead run along the baseline, and with it saved his chance to advance to the semifinals with a 5-7, 6-2, 7-5 victory over Moya at the Nasdaq-100 Open.

title: Classic Fairy-Tale Speech, Spiced With Today's Slang
description: There are several ways to approach Eugne Green's ''Monde Vivant,'' an enigmatic film that puts stock fairy-tale characters, including a pallid knight (Alexis Loret) and an ogre (Arnold Pasquier) through their usual paces but has its own whimsical point of view. At the simplest level, this lighthearted French film takes the ingredients of classic children's fantasy and replays them with contemporary actors. Speaking in stilted fairy-tale language infused with contemporary slang, the cast maintains a poker-faced sobriety that enhances the dialogue's mythic aspirations while seeming glaringly artificial.

In addition to locating files by name, type or date modified, Windows can do a search based on the files' text; recent versions, including Windows 2000 and XP, do so with a feature called Indexing Service, which can create a database of documents for searching by keywords, phrases or properties.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: ISRAEL: SHARON SAID TO THREATEN ARAFAT Prime Minister Ariel Sharon reportedly said that it was possible Israel could act at some point against Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who has not left his battered West Bank compound for nearly two years. But an Israeli official said there was no change in the government's policy toward Mr. Arafat. Mr. Sharon has promised the United States that Israel will not harm Mr. Arafat, though the Israeli cabinet voted in principle last year to remove the Palestinian leader. Israel's Channel 1 television reported that Mr. Sharon said it was not certain that Mr. Arafat could remain forever in his current position. In another development, three American envoys  Stephen Hadley, Elliott Abrams and William J. Burns  held separate discussions with Mr. Sharon and the Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, on stalled Middle East peace efforts. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Philadelphia
description: WHAT makes a great walking city? The American Podiatric Medical Association and Prevention magazine ranked Philadelphia one of its top 12 nationwide, in part because it has the highest podiatrist-per-capita ratio in the United States. But a more realistic definition might be that it is a place where you can easily and quickly get from one attraction to another -- but you don't really want to. Potential detours and pleasant interruptions abound in this city, from horse-headed hitching posts to 19th-century row houses to a tiny bakery-cafe with one two-person table that clears out just in time for you. SETH KUGEL

title: 1954:Photos of H-Bomb : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.: The world's first photographs and movies showing the catastrophic power of a thermonuclear, or "hydrogen," explosion appeared in newspapers and on television networks today [April 1] after distribution by the Civil Defense Administration. The first photographs of an H-bomb explosion, that show total destruction of the South Pacific island and its replacement by a crater a mile wide in diameter and filled with strangely dark seawater, were taken in November 1952. That was when scientists unleashed the prototype of the much more powerful "hydrogen" devices. In an official accounting, Rear Adm. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday [March 31] that H-Bombs can be made with sufficient force to cripple an area as large as metropolitan New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Gucci Struggles
description: The Gucci Group, the luxury goods maker, said fourth-quarter profit climbed 2 percent, less than analysts had forecast, as the company's Yves Saint Laurent brand posted a loss. Net income rose to 97.3 million euros ($119.7 million) from 95.4 million euros a year earlier, Gucci said. Sales in the period, which ended Jan. 31, increased 3.8 percent, to 741.7 million euros. The creative director, Tom Ford, who has struggled to revive Yves Saint Laurent, and the chief executive, Domenico De Sole, above, are quitting this month, leaving the new owner, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, to keep the momentum at Gucci and stem losses at Saint Laurent and other labels. ''My advice to Pinault is to stay the course,'' Mr. De Sole said in a telephone interview from Amsterdam, where Gucci is based. Pinault, based in Paris, plans to buy the third of Gucci it does not own this month and has named four of Ford's former assistants to succeed him.

He has been charged with two counts each of reckless endangerment and endangering the welfare of a child. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tabloid Photos Dismay Royals
description: Prince Charles reacted furiously when The Sun printed photographs of his oldest son, Prince William, and Kate Middleton, a young woman it said was William's girlfriend, on the cover and across five inside pages, The Associated Press reported. British newspapers, longing to publish interesting pictures of William and his brother, Harry, have until now kept to an agreement to use only photographs taken at officially sanctioned photo opportunities. But The Sun tried to take the high road in arguing that the new photographs, taken on the Swiss ski slopes, were too good to pass up. ''One of William's girlfriends could become queen one day,'' it said. ''Her subjects will be entitled to know all about her.'' News agencies also reported that Charles's office has banned The Sun from appearing at official photo opportunities until further notice. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAGER, FREDERICK A. JR
description: RAGER--Frederick A. Jr, died at home in NYC on January 14th, 2004. He was born in Vienna, Austria in 1928. His father, Frederick Sr, a Nazi resister, was Secretary of the Chamber of Labor of Austria, and moved the family to London in 1939 and then to the US in 1940. Fred graduated from The Peddie School in Hightstown, NJ and earned his degree from Wesleyan University in 1948. At Wesleyan, he was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity, and later was president of the Wesleyan Psi Upsilon Alumni Association. Upon graduation he worked briefly at the Emhart Manufacturing Co, and in 1949 joined The Hanover Bank in NYC. From 1950 to 1952, he served in Korea as a corporal in the US Army, and subsequently rejoined the bank. He built an impeccable 37-year career in corporate banking as successive mergers led to the formation of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, a predecessor of today's JP Morgan Chase. At the time of his retirement from Manufacturers Hanover in 1986, he was Senior VP of the bank's National Division and one of its most respected credit officers. He also distinguished himself during his long career by recruiting and mentoring scores of young bankers; they and Fred's many friends and former colleagues will remember him with great affection. He is survived by an elder brother, Peter, and a niece and nephew.

title: The City Life; Proud Borough Needs Bard
description: Word that the city's benignly overlooked borough of Queens was urgently scratching about for a new poet laureate seemed counterintuitive. What could be more challenging as the theme for a true poet than the borough's defining spirit of restlessness? Its horizon swatchwork of grays and lack of pretension in the face of mortality begs a surfeit of lyricists. Anyone who wanders Queens -- or sleepily commutes through it -- can sense what a perch it offers a poet groping for life's meaning. As a onetime resident, I cherish it as a land rich with life's strivers, caught in what Allen Ginsberg called ''the dearness of the vanishing moment.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Group Wants Rules On Food Supplements

title: Our Sprawling, Supersize Utopia
description: We're living in the age of the great dispersal. Americans continue to move from the Northeast and Midwest to the South and West. But the truly historic migration is from the inner suburbs to the outer suburbs, to the suburbs of suburbia. From New Hampshire down to Georgia, across Texas to Arizona and up through California, you now have the booming exurban sprawls that have broken free of the gravitational pull of the cities and now float in a new space far beyond them. For example, the population of metropolitan Pittsburgh has declined by 8 percent since 1980, but as people spread out, the amount of developed land in the Pittsburgh area increased by nearly 43 percent. The population of Atlanta increased by 22,000 during the 90's, but the expanding suburbs grew by 2.1 million.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: U.S. DISTURBED BY MILITIAS The United States said it was deeply disturbed by reports of summary executions in Ivory Coast and urged the government to end impunity enjoyed by militias. Security forces clashed last week with opposition supporters trying to hold a march in Abidjan despite an official ban. The opposition and rights groups say armed civilians, mostly loyal to President Laurent Gbagbo, were involved in killings and kidnappings during and after the attempted rally. Tallies from morgues indicate more than 100 people were killed on March 25, the day of the protest, and in the two following days. The government has put the death toll at 37, the opposition at several hundred. (Reuters)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Inmate Wants Right To Grow Hair
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California has filed a federal suit on behalf of Billy Soza Warsoldier, an American Indian prisoner. State prison authorities say Mr. Warsoldier is violating a policy that bars male inmates from having hair longer than three inches. Mr. Warsoldier, whose hair extends past his lower back, is a Cahuilla Indian who says his religious beliefs allow a haircut only when a relative dies. His last haircut was after his father's death in 1980, the suit states. According to the suit, Mr. Warsoldier has been denied privileges, including visits and vocational training, because he refuses haircuts. Ben Bergman (NYT)

But Mr. del Toro lets loose with an all-American, vaudevillian rambunctiousness that makes the movie daffy, loose and lovable.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: EX-MARINE GETS PRISON IN ABDUCTION A Michigan man who pleaded guilty to abducting a 12-year-old British girl he met in an Internet chat room was sentenced to four and a half years in prison by a Manchester court. The man, Toby Studabaker, 32, a former marine from Constantine, Mich., pleaded guilty in February, admitting charges of abduction and incitement to gross indecency. Prosecutors said he traveled to France and Germany with the girl. He was extradited to Britain in August from Germany, where he was arrested on July 16. He has maintained that he thought the girl was 18. He has also been indicted by a federal grand jury in Michigan. The indictment accuses him of sexually assaulting the girl. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Phone Concern Raises Outlook
description: Ericsson, the world's largest maker of mobile phone networks, said 53,000 job cuts since 2000 helped first-quarter profitability more than it had previously forecast. The gross margin, a yardstick of profitability, widened from 41.6 percent in the fourth quarter, an Ericsson spokeswoman, Aase Lindskog, said. Ericsson had predicted earlier that the margin, which measures profit against expenses, would decline. It left unchanged a first-quarter forecast of sales rising 5 percent to 9 percent from a year earlier, without giving any revenue or net income figures. Ericsson, based in Stockholm, reported its first profit in almost three years in the fourth quarter. The company has cut more than half its work force and is benefiting from resumed spending on base stations and switches by phone companies.

title: On the Road To Modern America
description: A DRIVING tour of modernist landmarks in the United States could in theory begin on almost any page of the road atlas. The Shaker communities of New England, in rejecting 19th-century pomp in favor of a minimalist aesthetic, qualify as modern. New York has long seen itself as the nation's capital of progressive art and thought. And Los Angeles, magnet for European architects and composers in the 1920's and 30's, has turned into the paradise where modernism -- in the sense of perpetual novelty -- never grows old.

Visteon, based in Dearborn, Mich., has been searching for a finance chief since Nov. 26, when George Strickler, a BorgWarner Inc. executive, decided not to take the position five days before he was scheduled to start work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, GEORGE HEARD
description: HAMILTON--George Heard. The trustees and staff of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute note with sorrow the passing of George Heard Hamilton, director of the Clark from 1966-1977. As one of the foremost historians, critics and scholars of the twentieth century, he left an indelible impact on the Clark and the museum world. He established the research and academic foundation for the Clark through the founding of the Clark's art history library and the establishment of the Williams College/Clark Art Institute Graduate Program in the History of Art, which too has become one of the leading programs of its kind in the United States. Professor Hamilton also initiated the Clark's full scale exhibition program in 1976; and oversaw an important building addition in 1973. His noteworthy acquisitions include Monet's ''Rouen Cathedral.'' We are grateful for the strong foundation George built for us, and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Polly, and their family. Michael Conforti, Director Francis Oakley, President Board of Trustees, Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon Said To Threaten Arafat
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon reportedly said that it was possible Israel could act at some point against Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who has not left his battered West Bank compound for nearly two years. But an Israeli official said there was no change in the government's policy toward Mr. Arafat. Mr. Sharon has promised the United States that Israel will not harm Mr. Arafat, though the Israeli cabinet voted in principle last year to remove the Palestinian leader. Israel's Channel 1 television reported that Mr. Sharon said it was not certain that Mr. Arafat could remain forever in his current position. In another development, three American envoys -- Stephen Hadley, Elliott Abrams and William J. Burns -- held separate discussions with Mr. Sharon and the Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, on stalled Middle East peace efforts. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC WINS RULING ON STENT PATENTS
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation has won a court ruling that found a rival patent on stents invalid and allows the company to resume stent sales in the Netherlands. The European Patent Office reversed a December decision that forced Boston Scientific to stop Dutch sales of the Express and Taxus brand stents. The latest ruling, which invalidated a patent belonging to Medinol Ltd. of Israel, is final and cannot be appealed, Boston Scientific said. The finding is a blow to Medinol, which said last year that it was trying to stop Boston Scientific from selling stents around the world. Boston Scientific marketed Medinol's Nir brand stents after the Israeli company, which is closely held, won approval to sell them in Europe in 1996 and the United States in 1998. The marketing agreement ended in 2001. The ruling does not affect a German patent infringement case that Boston Scientific is still appealing.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Questions About Death Sentencings
description: Expert testimony that a murder defendant was likely to prove dangerous in prison if spared the death penalty was wrong 95 percent of the time, the Texas Defender Service, a nonprofit law firm, said in a new study. Texas and Oregon are the only states that allow testimony on future dangerousness as a factor in imposing the death penalty. The Defender Service said that of 155 inmates who received death sentences after such testimony ''only 8 later engaged in serious assaultive behavior which resulted in injury requiring treatment more than first aid.'' Ralph Blumenthal (NYT)

title: On Opening Day, Fishing for Trout and Then Beating the Traffic

title: Pictures of the Picturesque, Not Necessarily of the Truth

title: National Briefing | Washington: Tougher Air-Conditioner Standard Stands
description: The Energy Department gave up its three-year effort to weaken an efficiency standard for central air-conditioners. The standard, requiring a 30 percent increase in efficiency beginning in 2006, was approved by the Clinton administration in its last days in office and suspended by the Bush administration, which favored a 20 percent increase instead. Environmentalists and seven states sued to maintain the Clinton standard, and this year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled against the department. Last month the air-conditioner industry, which favored the 20 percent standard, announced that it would not pursue further court challenges. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tiananmen Relatives Freed
description: Three women, members of a protest group called Tiananmen Mothers, were released from custody after domestic and international appeals for their freedom, family members said. The women, who had relatives who were killed in the crackdown on democracy protests in 1989, were taken from their homes on Sunday, possibly in connection with videotaped testimony they had made that rights advocates planned to present at a United Nations conference in Geneva. It is also possible the women were brought in for questioning as the police seek to prevent any protests connected with the 15th anniversary of the crackdown. As part of Tiananmen Mothers, the women -- Zhang Xianling, Ding Zilin and Huang Jinping -- have pressed Chinese leaders to reconsider the 1989 army crackdown and ''rehabilitate'' their dead relatives. Ms. Zhang and Ms. Ding both lost sons and Ms. Huang's husband was killed when army troops stormed Beijing on June 4, 1989, to crush a long-running but peaceful student-led demonstration. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: The Mayor Strikes a Blow for Everydriver

In the letter, published in the newspaper Vedomosti this week, Mr. Khodorkovsky chastises Russia's liberals (himself included) for their isolation from the people; he castigates the oligarchs (himself included) for not contributing enough to Russia; he acknowledges that Russia's piratical privatization (which left him worth $15 billion) was unfair; and he declares President Vladimir Putin (who threw him in jail without charges) to be ''more liberal and democratic'' than most of the people he leads.

title: MAKER OF ARTIFICIAL JOINTS DOUBLED SALES IN QUARTER
description: Zimmer Holdings Inc., the world's largest maker of artificial hips and knees, said first-quarter sales almost doubled after the purchase of Centerpulse, and that earnings exceeded analysts' forecasts. Sales rose to $740 million from $390.1 million a year ago, Zimmer said. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial was $704 million in sales. Zimmer, which is based in Warsaw, Ind., is benefiting from the $3.2 billion purchase of Centerpulse, which allowed it to surpass Johnson & Johnson and the Stryker Corporation in the $7 billion artificial-joint market. It is also being aided by rising demand for replacement hips and knees as global populations age. Zimmer said it would add 400 jobs at its headquarters by 2007 and gain about $10 million in tax and other incentives from the state.

title: Beholding Byzantium
description: The galleries of a major exhibition like ''Byzantium: Faith and Power (1261-1557),'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, are nearly always filled with formulaic poses. One viewer clasps his hands behind his back, which allows him to lean in closer to the objects without alarming the guards. One viewer lets her head settle back between her shoulder blades as though looking up in a stand of redwoods, while another peers intently from the side of a painted panel, as if hoping to see between its layers. Then there are the hordes of the disembodied, wearing headphones, staggering limply from one numbered object to the next, as if the voices they were hearing were more than curatorial.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Cellphone Company Sold
description: The New World Development Company will sell its Hong Kong cellphone business for 1.25 billion Hong Kong dollars ($161 million) to a company in which it owns a stake, after trying for four years to find an overseas buyer. The business, New World PCS Holdings, will be acquired by Asia Logistics Technologies, which is controlled by a Hong Kong businessman, Simon Lo. Asia Logistics will issue shares and bonds convertible into its stock to acquire New World PCS, which runs a cellular network in Hong Kong with one million customers. New World Development, which is controlled by Cheng Yu-tung, a Hong Kong billionaire, will have a 55 percent stake in the new company, which will be called New World Mobile Holdings. Potential overseas buyers have been deterred by the fact that Hong Kong has fewer than a tenth the number of subscribers as Japan but has twice as many mobile phone operations.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Charge Against Sheriff Is Thrown Out
description: An indictment accusing Sheriff Jim Bowles of Dallas County of diverting political contributions to his personal account was quashed. In dismissing the charges, Judge Karen Greene of State District Court said they were subject to administrative review by election officials and were not governed by the criminal code. Mr. Bowles, who was defeated for renomination in a Republican primary before his indictment last month, was charged with transferring more than $100,000 in political contributions for his private use. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: FITCH RATINGS UPGRADES OUTLOOK FOR INTERPUBLIC GROUP
description: Fitch Ratings in New York has upgraded its rating outlook for a large advertising agency company, the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, to stable from negative. The change, Fitch said yesterday, reflected an expectation that Interpublic's ''turnaround efforts have begun to steady operating earnings and cash flow generation'' after two years of financial and operational difficulties. Fitch affirmed Interpublic's debt ratings, including the senior unsecured debt at BB+ and the convertible subordinated notes at BB-. On March 25, Moody's Investors Service concluded a lengthy review of the Interpublic debt with a decision to confirm rather than reduce its ratings. Nat Ives (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEDER, MARIA, M.D.
description: FEDER--Maria, M.D. Died peacefully on Friday, April 2nd, 2004. Beloved wife of the (recently) late Ted, devoted mother of Gene, Ann and Joan, loving grandmother of Ellie, Ben, Josh, Jojo, Lizzie, Jake and Sammy and aunt of Beverly, June, Allan and Lami. Born on the shores of Lake Balaton, she survived the Holocaust, met the love of her life and lived in Austria, Germany, Iran, Israel, Switzerland, before retiring in New York. She combined raising her family with a distinguished career in geriatric psychiatry, setting up the first day hospital in Switzerland. We loved everything about her. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Burden Center/C.V. Starr, 1484 1st Avenue, New York NY 10021. Funeral will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, corner of 91st St on Sunday, April 4th, 2004 at 10AM.

title: Taking the Liberalism Out of Liberal Arts
description: City halls where gay marriage vows are uttered, the Superbowl half-time show and movie theaters showing ''The Passion of the Christ'' would seem to be prime battlegrounds in the latest culture wars. But to conservative crusaders like David Horowitz, the main action is still on college campuses, which he insists have been colonized by ''tenured leftists'' and turned into ''their political base.''

title: Final Four Matchups
Paid Notice: Deaths   HUGHES, MARY E.
description: HUGHES--Mary E. A Greenwich resident passed away at Greenwich Hospital on Thursday, April 1, 2004, due to heart failure, she was 84. Born in NYC on February 14, 1920, she was the daughter of the late James and Catherine O'Neil Ward. Upon graduation from Julia Richmond High School, she worked at Macy's Herald Square, where whe was named Miss Macy. She is survived by her husband Patrick J. Hughes, of Greenwich, her son Thomas J. Hughes, of Greenwich, her daughter Kathleen M. Chiaravalle, of Bronxville, NY, two sisters, Jeanette Grisoli of Baywater, NY, and Esther Ward of Brooklyn, NY. Additionally, six grandchildren, one great-granddaughter and several nieces and nephews survive her. Her two brothers and two sisters predeceased her, as well as her daughter Patricia Ann Hughes, who passed away in 1971. Calling hours will be held at the Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich, on Friday, April 2, 2004, from 2 PM to 4 PM, and from 6 PM to 9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, 178 Greenwich Ave, on Saturday, April 3, 2004, at 10 AM. Burial will be held privately. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, C/O Doris Tulcin, 245 Main St, Suite 520, White Plains, New York 10606.

title: Japan Support of Missile Shield Could Tilt Asia Power Balance
description: As the United States races to erect a ballistic missile defense system by the end of the year, it is quietly enlisting Japan and other allies in Asia to take part in the network, which could reshape the balance of power in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOCKHART, EPPIE (ETSUKO)
description: LOCKHART--Eppie (Etsuko). The Trustees, staff and entire Corlears School community express our deep condolences to the family and dear friends of Eppie Lockhart, on the day of her death, April 1, 2004. We have been moved by her quiet strength; Touched by her sweet humility; Enriched by her loyal friendship; Steadied by her right-on bass beat. Her spirit lives on in the hearts and minds of each child, parent, and teacher whom she touched.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE ACQUIRES MORE FORD MOTOR SHARES
description: The Ford Motor Company's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., acquired 1.44 million company shares, increasing his holdings by 53 percent, the company said yesterday. Mr. Ford, 46, received 27,624 restricted shares as salary for this year's first quarter and must hold them for at least a year, a spokeswoman, Becky Bach, said. He also exercised options for 1.41 million shares that he will keep, she said. The stock acquisition increased his shares of Ford common stock to 4.15 million, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, under intense pressure to meet or exceed market expectations after its large reserve write-down in January, is running over budget at a large Russian development and will not draw oil from its Nigerian offshore project as soon as expected.

title: Schenscher Is Georgia Tech's Added Dimension
description: At age 16, Luke Schenscher was a tall student in the rural town of Hope Forest in South Australia who was trying to adjust to a growth spurt that would make him taller than seven feet. His education improved when he moved into the Australian Institute of Sport in Canberra.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of former New York State Senator Mary B. Goodhue on March 26 misstated the name of the her law firm at its founding; it was Goodhue & Lange. (It later became Goodhue, Arons & Neary; it is now Arons & Neary.)

title: Numbers a Relief To Republicans, But Fears Remain
description: For months, President Bush has premised his re-election campaign on the argument that the economy was back on track, citing rapid economic growth, low inflation, low interest rates and near-record home sales.

title: Conservative Takes On Moderate G.O.P. Senator in Pennsylvania
description: Representative Patrick J. Toomey, Republican candidate for Senate in Pennsylvania, has been ripping his opponent for being a ''Ted Kennedy'' liberal, too fond of taxes and spending, too close to activist judges and trial lawyers, too supportive of abortion rights and the United Nations.

description: Work on Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's $500 million high-rise research center can proceed, a judge has ruled, as he turned aside the objections of neighbors who say the project violates the city's zoning rules.

title: State Panel Rejects Brooklyn Power Plant
description: State examiners have recommended rejecting a private developer's efforts to build an electric power plant in Williamsburg on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Partly Made Bomb Is Found Under a Rail Line in Spain
description: A partly assembled bomb containing 26 pounds of explosives was discovered Friday during a routine track check on a high-speed rail line linking the Spanish capital to Seville. The explosives were thought to be the same type as those used in the March 11 terror attacks in Madrid, officials said.

title: Expansion Planned for Science Center in Liberty State Park
description: Noting that the Liberty Science Center has outgrown its current building in Liberty State Park, the center's board said Friday that it would restructure the existing space and add a wing that would expand the center by about 50 percent.

title: With Influences From Beethoven to Bartok
description: It's always good to see a new work growing legs, even if it seems unlikely to become a distance runner. Krzysztof Penderecki's ''Metamorphosen,'' his second violin concerto, was composed for Anne-Sophie Mutter, who gave its world premiere in 1995, recorded it with the composer conducting, and presented it with the New York Philharmonic four years ago, also under the composer's baton. Now ''Metamorphosen'' has been taken up by Julian Rachlin, who brought it back to the New York Philharmonic on Thursday, this time under Lorin Maazel's direction.

description: He might have grown up in this sleepy, woodsy part of Central Florida, but after Scott Helvenston left as an adventure-hungry teenager, he made sure his life was never dull.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about testimony by the new chief weapons inspector for Iraq, Charles A. Duelfer, who said the American search for unconventional weapons remained a tangle of mysteries, referred incorrectly to a comment by his predecessor, David Kay, at the time of his resignation. Referring to a number of countries, Mr. Kay said that in believing before the war that Iraq possessed illicit weapons, ''we were all wrong, probably.'' He did not say all American officials were wrong.

title: Informants in Seton Hall Fire Were Offered $60,000 Each
description: Early in the investigation into the fatal Seton Hall dormitory fire in January 2000, the Essex County prosecutor's office agreed to pay two members of organized crime $60,000 apiece to help detectives obtain evidence, according to court documents.

description: Nowadays cosmopolitan teams that include players from both sides of the Atlantic are common at major competitions in the United States, but within these teams cross-Atlantic partnerships are rare.

title: Scanning For Success
description: The scanners are the least impressive things at the FedEx global distribution hub here in Memphis. The first thing you notice during the overnight sort is the endless parade of planes stacked up in the night sky. Then there are the swarms of workers who descend upon the planes once they land and strip them of their cargo. Then begins the scramble of the caterpillars -- little motorized tugs towing strings of cargo containers pell-mell around the complex and honking out warnings at every intersection.

title: Inventory Shows an Uneven Distribution of School Computers
description: Computers are distributed among the New York City schools in a wildly uneven manner, a Department of Education inventory released yesterday found. In the Bronx alone, for example, Community School 234 has 40 computers for its 576 students, while Middle School/High School 368, which has a special emphasis on technology, has 543 computers for its 720 students.

description: After a long period of stagnation, job creation finally surged ahead in March, the government reported yesterday. title: ABER DIAMOND OF CANADA BUYS CONTROL OF HARRY WINSTON
description: The Aber Diamond Corporation of Toronto, part owner of the Diavik diamond mine in the Northwest Territories of Canada, said that it had bought a 51 percent stake in Harry Winston Inc., the jewelry retailer based in New York. The purchase price is $85 million, with $20 million of that as working capital. Aber has an option to buy the remaining 49 percent of Harry Winston, which is currently owned by Fenway Partners, a New York investment firm. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: ROLES IN DISASTER CAUSE RIFT IN CITY
description: More than two and a half years after the World Trade Center attacks exposed weaknesses in New York City's emergency response system, the city still lacks what many experts say is the most basic and essential tool for handling disasters: a formal agreement governing which city agency would lead the response at the scene of any catastrophic accident or terrorist strike.

title: White House Agrees to Let Panel Review Clinton-Era Files
description: The White House has agreed to allow the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks to review thousands of Clinton administration national-security documents that the White House acknowledged this week it had withheld from the panel, the commission said Friday.

title: Yanks Tackle Jet Lag Before Finishing Spring
description: Derek Jeter went to bed at 11 Thursday night but woke up three hours later and could not fall back to sleep. So Jeter, the Yankees' shortstop and captain, rose, had some food and watched television before nodding off.

description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the city should pay special disability benefits to a former police officer who had helped uncover corruption in the Police Department. The city said it would appeal.

description: NATO formally welcomed seven new members into the alliance on Friday, stretching its security umbrella to the borders of Russia and prompting Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to reassure Moscow that it should not feel threatened.

title: Treasured Churches in a Cycle of Revenge
description: ''Kishe kaput; very good,'' said the smiling boy, using an incongruous mix of Albanian, German and English to describe the remains of St. Nicholas, Pristina's only working Serbian Orthodox church. Next to him the four walls of the church were smoldering.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Thursday about the formation of a dance company in Germany by the American choreographer William Forsythe reversed the state identifications for the two cities involved in supporting it. Frankfurt is in Hesse; Dresden is in Saxony.

Dear sister of the late Miriam Lennon, Harold and Milton. Services at I.J. Morris, 10:15 AM Sunday. In repose: I.J. Morris Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUSHNER, RAE
description: KUSHNER--Rae. We mourn the passing of Rae Kushner, an ashet chayil, Holocaust survivor, benefactor of Torah institutions, philanthropist, business leader and true friend. Together with her late husband, Joseph Kushner, z''l, emerged from the ashes of the Holocaust and created a life of Torah and Mitzvot that will continue to thrive through the deeds of her children. Her memory will always be an inspiration for all of us. To her sister, Lisa Reibel, the Kushner children, Linda and Murray, Lee and Murray, Seryl and Charles, and Esther and William, her grandchildren and greatgrandchildren we extend our deepest condolences and sympathies. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Cecile and Edward Mosberg, Beatrice Mosberg, Louise and Stuart Levine, Caroline and Darren Karger, and Families

title: Ailing L.S.U. Coach Watches Her Team From Afar
description: Her peers can only imagine Louisiana State Coach Sue Gunter's feelings, how she sits in her living room in front of the television, watching the basketball team she built, watching the program she has poured her heart into for 22 years.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Thursday about the premiere of the liberal radio network Air America omitted the stations on which its programs are heard. They are WLIB-AM (1190) in New York, WNTD-AM (950) in Chicago, KBLA-AM (1580) in Los Angeles, KCAA-AM (1050) in Riverside and San Bernardino, Calif., KPOJ-AM (620) in Portland, Ore., and Channel 167 on XM Satellite Radio.

title: TYCO TRIAL ENDED AS A JUROR CITES OUTSIDE PRESSURE
description: The judge in the six-month trial of two former Tyco International executives declared a mistrial yesterday after a juror said she had received a letter pressuring her to convict the defendants. The mistrial came just as some jurors said the group was on the verge of convicting the defendants of some of the most serious criminal charges while acquitting them of others.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 17 Years For Bosnian Serb Policeman
description: Darko Mrdja, a former Bosnian Serb policeman who pleaded guilty last July to charges of murder and inhumane acts at the United Nations war crimes tribunal, has been sentenced to 17 years in prison. Mr. Mrdja, who confessed to taking part in the killing of more than 200 prisoners of war in Bosnia in 1992, became the 16th person to enter into a plea agreement at the tribunal. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: MARRIOTT SELLS ITS STAKE IN 2 HOTEL CHAINS TO CENDANT
description: Marriott International Inc., the hotel operator, agreed to sell a stake in the Ramada and Days Inn hotel brands to a partner, the Cendant Corporation, for about $200 million, ending a two-year-old venture. Marriott, which is based in Bethesda, Md., said the sale enabled it to shed an asset that was not part of its strategy of owning and managing hotels under names including Marriott, Renaissance and Ritz-Carlton. The company will receive the proceeds on Sept. 1, increasing third-quarter profit by $13 million before taxes.

title: Large Raise For Executive At Hospital Stirs Criticism
description: Westchester Medical Center has provoked employees and union representatives by giving a top administrator a large raise in the midst of a financial crisis that has involved laying off scores of workers in the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISER, IRA
description: WEISER--Ira. 85, of Tamarac, FL passed away April 1, 2004. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Cherished father of Sherri (Richard) and the late Maureen (Stewart). Adored Poppy of Tracy, Gregory, Lauren, Jill and Brian. Brother of Horace. Chapel service Monday, April 5, 10:30AM at Star of David Memorial Chapel, North Lauderdale, FL 800-456-5252

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Some Extension For Abuse Prevention Centers
description: Half of the state centers that work to prevent child abuse will remain open for at least another six months, said Attorney General Jim Hood, who said he would provide $3.4 million from the state's tobacco litigation settlement. Last month, the Department of Human Services announced that the previous administration had miscalculated the amount of federal grants available by $20 million and that 34 of the state's Family First Resource Centers would have to close within weeks. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Descending Into the Soul With an Intense Lyricism
description: The Ailey II company is in part a proving ground for young dancers who dream of performing with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. To judge from its program on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater in a shared engagement with the ABT Studio Company that runs through tomorrow night, the senior Ailey troupe had better add slots immediately for all 12 junior dancers.

title: Get With It, Bar Hoppers, The Berlin Wall Is Falling
description: ''Berlin Blues,'' a ragged and occasionally charming new film by Leander Haussmann, takes place in the autumn of 1989, at the moment when the divided city of the movie's title was about to become the scene of an unforgettable historical event. That moment was recently the subject of Wolfgang Becker's ''Goodbye, Lenin!,'' which offers an interesting contrast to the story Mr. Haussmann has to tell. Mr. Becker's film concerns a young East German man who tries to protect his true-believing Communist mother from discovering that the world she knew had changed utterly.

title: The Mystery Deepens
description: The Bush administration's handling of the bipartisan commission investigating the 9/11 tragedy grows worse -- and more oddly self-destructive -- with each passing day. Following its earlier attempts to withhold documents from the panel and then to deny its members vital testimony, we now learn that President Bush's staff has been withholding thousands of pages of Clinton administration papers as well.

title: Labor Board Dismisses Virtual Music Charge
description: The National Labor Relations Board has dismissed a charge made against the Broadway musicians' union by a Manhattan company that sells the so-called virtual orchestra machine.

title: Dispute Halts Tree Planting In Three Parts Of the City
description: Like many New Yorkers, Mary-Lynne Peluso waited for years for the city to replace a tree felled by delivery truck damage in her neighborhood near Gramercy Park. Finally, the empty pit where it once stood came up on the list and, after a site visit from a Parks Department employee, a sephora sapling was due to arrive at the beginning of spring.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

description: Pat Summerall was in stable condition yesterday at the Mayo Clinic's St. Luke's Hospital in Jacksonville, Fla., awaiting a liver transplant, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Election Is Turning Novices Into Political Advocates
description: For 20 years, Al Puchala was in political hibernation. So was his sometime investment partner, Douglas Korn. They were busy with other things: career, marriage, children, charities. Sure, they voted as a civic duty, but in their world of high finance, politics was considered a private thing -- rude if openly displayed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOHSE, AUSTIN W.
description: LOHSE--Austin W. died on April 1, 2004 at his home, he was 78 years old. Born in NYC, NY, he was a lifelong resident of Short Hills. He is predeceased by his wife, Virginia Lohse (nee Butler) and his brother, Robert V. Lohse. Surviving are his daughter, Connie Lohse and her husband, Robby Brewer of Chevy Chase, MD, his son, Dan Lohse and his wife, Sarah of Branchburg, NJ, and his grandchildren, Robert Scott and Laura Elizabeth Brewer, and Jonathan Watts and Andrew Butler Lohse. Received his BA from Dartmouth University in 1947. From 1947 to 1952, he worked as a credit analyst for Irving Trust Co. in NYC. From 1952 to 1973, he worked for American Express International Banking Corp. in NYC where he was Assistant Vice President from 1958 to 1961, Vice President from 1961 to 1968, and Senior Vice President from 1968 to 1973. He worked for Charterhouse Group International, Inc. in NYC from 1973 to 1978. From 1978 to 1981 he worked at RT Madden & Co, Inc, NYC. From 1981 until his retirement, he was President of his own investment banking corporation, the AW, Lohse & Company, Inc. He was also the former director of American Express Bank GMBH, Frankfurt, Germany, American Express Bank SPA, Rome, Italy, American Express Securities SA, Paris, France, and LB/Amex Ltd, London, England. He was a member of Casque and Gauntlet Society and Beta Theta Pi both in NYC. He belonged to the Short Hills Club and the Knickerbocker Club, NYC. Funeral services and interment will be private. Relatives and friends may visit from 2-5 on Sunday, April 4th at the Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home, 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ.

title: High Times
description: ''Get drunk!'' Charles Baudelaire exhorted in one of his best-known poems, but given what a mess he made of his own life, he's hardly the man to turn to for advice. A new biography, ''Baudelaire in Chains,'' insists that intoxication, far from being the wellspring of the poet's spirit, was ''the root of all his problems.'' And that's a lot of problems, observes the author, Frank Hilton, including Baudelaire's ''inability to manage his financial affairs, his unsatisfactory relationships, his bad health, his guignon'' -- the demonic misfortune he believed plagued him -- and, most important, his ''chronic difficulty in getting down to any prolonged creative work.'' All of this Hilton attributes to Baudelaire's opium addiction, which, he argues, other biographers have underestimated. Instead, they have blamed syphilis (a diagnosis that Hilton doubts) and other illnesses for his physical sufferings, the heartlessness of his intimates and the stupidity of the public for the rest.

title: Why It's Painful At the Pump

Iraq's exports are constrained by domestic violence and insecurity along its northern export pipeline route. More broadly, conflict in the Middle East and anxiety about terrorism are pushing up prices. Then there's OPEC, which last week announced a new production cut. Meanwhile, demand is growing more strongly than it has for several years. The No.1 reason is China, which is experiencing rapid economic growth.

Wild oats once sown come back to haunt you in the haggard shadows under your eyes, the fine lines in the sunlight, the dun-colored aura of stress. It's pretty scary. As we age, our faces and necks succumb to gravity; worse, your chins hang low and they wobble to and fro. You can tie them in a knot, you can tie them in a bow.

title: TETERBORO STUDY
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has agreed in principle with a bipartisan coalition of elected officials from a dozen towns surrounding Teterboro Airport to do a thorough study of pollution at the 827-acre site. The Coalition for Public Health and Safety, concerned that a $92.4 million improvement plan for the airport actually means to expand it, argued that an independent air pollution study was needed for the airport. The coalition sued the Port Authority in 2002 to force the agency to pay for a study and to allow the coalition a voice in picking the company to conduct it. A Port Authority spokeswoman said the suit had no bearing on the tentative agreement, which stipulates that the Port Authority will pay $300,000 and the state $150,000 for an 18-month study with four monitoring stations on the airport perimeter. title: For Japanese Girls, Black Is Beautiful
description: IONA ROZEAL BROWN is obsessed with hip-hop. When she is not home spinning discs, out haunting music stores or cruising clubs, she makes paintings about fashion-conscious Japanese teenagers who want to look cool, black and American, much like their hip-hop idols. Known as the ganguro, these teenagers dress in funky clothes, dye and weave their hair into cornrows and darken their skin at tanning salons or with makeup.

title: Pack Journalism
description: RATS

title: Hincapies Picture Tells a Story
description: PARIS, April 3  Everybody in the small world of bicycle racing has seen the photograph of George Hincapie, covered in dust, sitting slumped in a cubicle, holding his head in his hands, after the 2002 Paris-Roubaix race. In black and white, a bit grainy, the photograph sums up that fearful race over cobblestones and the toll it takes on riders.

title: Bond Issues Are Defeated in Roslyn and Mattituck
description: Voters in the Mattituck-Cutchogue School District resoundingly rejected a $39.7 million bond issue to increase the size of the junior-senior high school, while those in the Roslyn School District soundly defeated a bond issue that would have doubled the size of the Bryant Library.

title: The Game That Even Ripley Couldn't Win
description: WE last saw Tom Ripley pondering his dark new talents in the mirror, like some murderous Narcissus. Having eluded the Venetian police, who rightly suspected him of killing his wealthy friend Dickie Greenleaf, Tom fled Italy aboard a luxury yacht, his pocket full of cash from a duped Greenleaf Sr., his hands warm from the recent suffocation of yet another companion.

title: When a Man Is Left Holding the Bag
description: HE dreads the day she first pops the question. He's come to expect it. She'll lean up against him, place her hand on his chest and look deep into his eyes. Then she'll lay it on him.

title: A Triangle Of Love, Built On a Cipher
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW did not give the title character of ''Candida'' an awful lot to do or provide more than a sketchy description of what it is about her that causes two very different men to go daft. But when the daftees are as delightful as Michael Siberry and Jeffrey Carlson are in the McCarter Theater Center's current production of the classic, it hardly matters.

title: Imagining a $7-a-Gallon Future
description: NO price in America is more visible, indeed inescapable, than that of gasoline. And Americans don't like the numbers they're seeing today, and their anger has turned high prices at the pump into highly flammable political fodder. OPEC's decision last week to cut production has further fueled the fire.

title: The Socratic Shrink
description: I think Lou Marinoff is onto something. I am taking a course for my master's degree that requires reading Socrates, Plato and Aristotle. I've discovered that the sky is definitely bluer outside the cave. I have started playing the piano again, listening to music and just enjoying every aspect of my life more. If Marinoff can help people discover this very powerful aphrodisiac, all power to him.

title: The Boys of Spring
description: A PERILOUS business, seeking the poetry in stories of baseball and spring. Too much myth. Too much lore. Too much schmaltz. And yes, too much poetry -- literally, as in Maxine Kumin's ''Spring Training'':

title: FIRST LADY SUITE
description: PRESIDENTIAL wives are the focus of Michael John LaChiusa's ''First Lady Suite,'' four chamber musicals in which Eleanor Roosevelt, Mamie Eisenhower and Jacqueline Kennedy, among other historical figures, appear. The Transport Group revival of the 1993 show, which opens today at the Connelly Theater in the East Village, includes a new prologue and epilogue and stars Julia Murney, Cheryl Stern, Mary Testa, Sherry D. Boone and Mary Beth Peil. In this lyric, Ms. Stern, as Mamie, sings about the difficulties of liking Ike. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Forbidden Fur
description: The Ethicist's triangulations about the use of the inherited fur garments had him walking a tightrope. Either he advises the woman to keep the garment and wear it without compunction or, if the use of fur is so distasteful, he must tell her to destroy it. But the proposal that his correspondent find hidden uses for her great-aunt's fur coats is, no pun intended, fuzzy thinking.

title: The Neptunes' Guilty Pleasures
description: N.E.R.D. -- Everything the Neptunes leave out of their hip-hop hits goes into their songs for N.E.R.D., the band that includes the Neptunes -- Pharrell Williams and Chad Hugo -- and their friend Shay Haley. On N.E.R.D.'s second album, ''Fly or Die'' (Virgin), that includes rock guitars, melodic verses, Beatles chords, live drums and a distinct hippie streak, from light-headed optimism to antiwar sentiments. It also includes more mixed emotions than chartmaking hip-hop allows. Between the romantic come-ons and dance workouts, N.E.R.D. has sympathy for misfits and teenage runaways, and it understands that positive thinking can be hard-earned. While Mr. Williams isn't much of a singer, ''Fly or Die'' has goofy charms to spare.

title: The Island at the Center of the World
description: On a late summer's day in the year 1608, a gentleman of London made his way across that city. He was a man of ambition, intellect, arrogance, and drive-in short, a man of his age. Like our own, his was an era of expanding horizons and a rapidly shrinking world, in which the pursuit of individual dreams led to new discoveries, which in turn led to newer and bigger dreams. His complicated personality-including periodic fits of brooding passivity that all but incapacitated him-was built around an impressive self-confidence, and at this moment he was almost certainly convinced that the meeting he was headed toward would be of historic importance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARHAM, BETTY
description: BARHAM--Betty, 79, livosopher and poet, died gracefully in her sleep on Sunday, March 28, 2004. Betty will be remembered by thousands of people who received her ''55'' pin and her ''22/55'' message to ''change your point of view''. She lived in Manhattan for 27 years, savoring every minute of the energy and electricity of a city that perfectly matched her personality. Betty was loved and will be greatly missed by her friends and family: Sandy and Stu Nahan; Richard, Barbara, Whitney and Dagny Mendelsohn; Helen, Gabriel, Carole and Corky Kovacs. Donations may be made in Betty's memory to Hospice by the Bay, 1540 Market St., San Franciso, CA. 94102-6035. Betty always said, ''I want to be alive when I die''...and she was.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Janus, Once the Gambler, Is Now the Stakes
description: JANUS, the mutual fund giant, was famous for betting big on high-tech growth companies during the Internet bubble. But now the fund company itself has become a darling of investors of a different persuasion -- those who scour the landscape for battered stocks selling at bargain prices.

description: ONE sunny afternoon in late March, Wambui Bahati, a 54-year-old actress, inspirational speaker and dormant manic-depressive, sat cross-legged on her tomato red couch in her Habitat for Humanity condominium on West 134th Street and offered a hilarious aural snack, a few lines from her one-woman show. Called ''Balancing Act,'' it is an unusual musical about mental illness, and it makes its creator seem a potent combination -- part Nancy Wilson, part Joan Rivers.

description: MANY people know that if a sealed bottle of water is left out in freezing temperatures, the water expands as it freezes and sometimes cracks the bottle or pops the top. The same thing can happen to a sidewalk.

title: In Scarsdale, Wary Reactions to State Financing Report
description: IT is, in many ways, the quintessentially privileged Westchester school district, boasting a public education that attracts some of the most discerning and well-off parents in the New York metropolitan region. Scarsdale's schools are high-performing, academically ambitious and extremely rich, thanks largely to the willingness and ability of local residents to shoulder a tax burden that is among the highest in the nation.

What they got was a drama about an Iranian lesbian who goes to visit relatives in Los Angeles so she can get a sex change and return to Tehran to live with her American girlfriend as a man.

title: A 2,000-Mile Forage for Folk Art
description: EARLY on a gray winter Sunday morning, Jeanne Kronsnoble and Cathy Clayton, friends and owners of different art galleries for almost 20 years, set out from Tampa, Fla., and drove north in a minivan with the middle seat removed. The tourists were flowing south, but they were on a different mission. They carried blankets, sheets of plywood, bubble wrap and cardboard. Maps, dogeared address books, bottles of water, bags of chocolates. And sturdy clothes. They would clump through damp fields and dark spidery places and sit down to midday dinners of baked chicken, turnip greens, cornbread, peach cobbler and presweetened iced tea. There was also a checkbook, and an envelope of cash.

title: Growing Hub for All Things Salvadoran
description: IT was business as usual on a recent morning at the Consulate of El Salvador in Brentwood. The television blared in Spanish. Five different local Spanish-language newspapers were being perused in the waiting room, where dozens of Salvadorans sat quietly on plastic chairs waiting to get their passports renewed. Signs posted in Spanish listed the fees: $60 for a passport; $5 for a birth or death certificate.

Is it necessary for him to be listed as a tenant of record on the lease for him to be eligible for succession rights to the apartment? . . . Richard Bengloff, Manhattan.

Truth be told, though, Franken as a ''total jock'' with a ''butt like a cut basketball'' is not the Al I remember. title: Rats
description: WHEN I WROTE the following account of my experiences with rats, I lived in an apartment building on a block filled with other apartment buildings, amidst the approximately eight million people in New York City, and I paid rent to a landlord that I never actually met-though I did meet the superintendent, who was a very nice guy. At this moment, I am living out of the city, away from the masses, in a bucolic little village with about the same number of inhabitants as my former city block. I wouldn't normally delve into my own personal matters, except that when I mention my rat experiences to people, they sometimes think I took extraordinary measures to investigate them, and I didn't. All I did was stand in an alley-a filth-slicked little alley that is about as old as the city and secret the way alleys are secret and yet just a block or two from Wall Street, from Broadway, and from what used to be the World Trade Center. All I did was take a spot next to the trash and wait and watch, rain or no rain, night after night, and always at night, the time when, generally speaking, humans go to sleep and rats come alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOHSE, AUSTIN W.
description: LOHSE--Austin W. died on April 1, 2004 at his home, he was 78 years old. Born in NYC, NY, he was a lifelong resident of Short Hills. He is predeceased by his wife, Virginia Lohse (nee Butler) and his brother, Robert V. Lohse. Surviving are his daughter, Connie Lohse and her husband, Robby Brewer of Chevy Chase, MD, his son, Dan Lohse and his wife, Sarah of Branchburg, NJ, and his grandchildren, Robert Scott and Laura Elizabeth Brewer, and Jonathan Watts and Andrew Butler Lohse. Received his BA from Dartmouth University in 1947. From 1947 to 1952, he worked as a credit analyst for Irving Trust Co. in NYC. From 1952 to 1973, he worked for American Express International Banking Corp. in NYC where he was Assistant Vice President from 1958 to 1961, Vice President from 1961 to 1968, and Senior Vice President from 1968 to 1973. He worked for Charterhouse Group International, Inc. in NYC from 1973 to 1978. From 1978 to 1981 he worked at RT Madden & Co, Inc, NYC. From 1981 until his retirement, he was President of his own investment banking corporation, the AW, Lohse & Company, Inc. He was also the former director of American Express Bank GMBH, Frankfurt, Germany, American Express Bank SPA, Rome, Italy, American Express Securities SA, Paris, France, and LB/Amex Ltd, London, England. He was a member of Casque and Gauntlet Society and Beta Theta Pi both in NYC. He belonged to the Short Hills Club and the Knickerbocker Club, NYC. Funeral services and interment will be private. Relatives and friends may visit from 2-5 on Sunday, April 4th at the Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home, 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Amy Poehler; Live From New York
description: ON a recent Sunday evening, while countless millions were glued to their television sets for the season premiere of ''The Sopranos,'' the actress Amy Poehler was bustling around backstage at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Chelsea. Ms. Poehler's main gig is ''Saturday Night Live,'' on which she lampoons pop-culture stars like Avril Lavigne and Kelly Ripa while introducing her own indelible characters, notably Amber, the trailer park queen, to the world at large. But she also has what one might call her Sunday Night Live: the weekly improv show at the theater, which she opened five years ago with several fellow transplants from the Chicago comedy scene.

title: Detained While Young
description: Stephen Elliott's HAPPY BABY (McSweeney's with MacAdam/Cage, $21) is surely the most intelligent and beautiful book ever written about juvenile detention centers, sadomasochism and drugs. Lesser writers might be tempted to milk such material for shock value, but one of Elliott's many gifts is his light touch. Nowhere in this, his fourth novel, does Elliott either overexplain or depict gratuitous brutality. Instead, in episodic chapters told in reverse chronological order, his guiding principles are precision and realism. Theo, the narrator, experienced sexual abuse, violence and occasional camaraderie during his adolescence as a ward of the state of Illinois (Elliot himself was also a ward of the state). As an adult, Theo feels most sexually and emotionally fulfilled when he is being insulted or punished. Seeking out, for example, a prostitute who ''makes'' him wear a diaper, Theo could appear freakish; but he is so fully drawn, and so honest about himself, that he seems touchingly normal. In deft, vivid scenes, other characters also come to life -- the dialogue is both natural-sounding and surprising -- and Theo's first girlfriend, Maria, is especially smart, complicated and, like Theo himself, matter-of-factly rather than self-pityingly unhappy. Though Theo sometimes longs for clarity or peace, both he and the book accept as a given that many people struggle almost all the time -- and that such struggling doesn't preclude moments of humor and comfort. The novel's backward structure means that rather than building momentum, it offers the sense of a mystery being slowly solved. That the mystery of why Theo, or anyone, turns out as he does is essentially unsolvable makes it no less satisfying, or, in Theo's case, less heartbreaking. Curtis Sittenfeld

title: Our Sprawling, Supersize Utopia
description: We're living in the age of the great dispersal. Americans continue to move from the Northeast and Midwest to the South and West. But the truly historic migration is from the inner suburbs to the outer suburbs, to the suburbs of suburbia. From New Hampshire down to Georgia, across Texas to Arizona and up through California, you now have the booming exurban sprawls that have broken free of the gravitational pull of the cities and now float in a new space far beyond them. For example, the population of metropolitan Pittsburgh has declined by 8 percent since 1980, but as people spread out, the amount of developed land in the Pittsburgh area increased by nearly 43 percent. The population of Atlanta increased by 22,000 during the 90's, but the expanding suburbs grew by 2.1 million.

title: Ghost Wars
description: In the tattered, cargo-strewn cabin of an Ariana Afghan Airlines passenger jet streaking above Punjab toward Kabul sat a stocky, broad-faced American with short graying hair. He was a friendly man in his early fifties who spoke in a flat midwestern accent. He looked as if he might be a dentist, an acquaintance once remarked. Gary Schroen had served for twenty-six years as an officer in the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine services. He was now, in September 1996, chief of station in Islamabad, Pakistan. He spoke Persian and its cousin, Dari, one of Afghanistan's two main languages. In spy terminology, Schroen was an operator. He recruited and managed paid intelligence agents, conducted espionage operations, and supervised covert actions against foreign governments and terrorist groups. A few weeks before, with approval from CIA headquarters in Langley, Virginia, he had made contact through intermediaries with Ahmed Shah Massoud, the celebrated anti-Soviet guerrilla commander, now defense minister in a war-battered Afghan government crumbling from within. Schroen had requested a meeting, and Massoud had accepted.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: KRAKATOA. The Day the World Exploded: August 27, 1883, by Simon Winchester. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) When Krakatoa erupted in one of the biggest volcanic explosions in recorded history, it erased the whole island on which it stood, and sent out tsunamis that killed more than 36,000 people in Java and Sumatra. This ''brilliant'' account of the what, where, when and why of the event ''is thrilling, comprehensive, literate, meticulously researched and scientifically accurate,'' Richard Ellis wrote here in 2003. ''It is one of the best books ever written about the history and significance of a natural disaster.''

title: Greek Revival
description: ''Lent is a time for reflection,'' said Nick Livanos at Molyvos, the restaurant at Seventh Avenue and 54th Street that he owns with his family and that is named after a village on the island of Lesbos in Greece. ''For us, it's the time to tame your passions. So the emphasis is spiritual -- it's not just, 'Oh, let's lose weight or quit smoking.''' An array of Molyvos's Lenten specialties has been spread before us: a crunchy-soft sea scallop breaded with panko, the Japanese crumb with so little moisture it just about guarantees crispness; an octopus pie wrapped in phyllo that will change your mind about the octopod; a jumping, impeccable taramosalata -- carp roe, olive oil, potato, garlic and almond, pured and smeared on crisp pita triangles; a bracing salad with pickled pearl onions and candied beets; a vegetable moussaka that not only shuns ground beef but also the customary yogurt bchamel, replacing them with a dairy-free mixture Viagra-ed with garlic.

title: DONE

Soon after Bridgeport firefighters extinguished the flames, city and state officials were predicting that the interstate could be shut down for three weeks.

title: Author in the Court; Martin Clark, novelist
description: Martin Clark's novels have great titles. His first, ''The Many Aspects of Mobile Home Living,'' came out in 2000. It is arguably the funniest legal thriller ever written -- a book that made Clark seem like not only the thinking man's John Grisham but, maybe better, the drinking man's John Grisham. Here's how Clark introduced his hero, a pot-smoking young judge in a small Southern town: ''On the morning that Evers got his first glimpse of the albino mystery, he'd been walking into the sun, scraping down the sidewalk, burping up squalls of alcohol and 2-in-the-morning microwave lasagna.'' The legal thriller has become an uptight and moribund genre, and this is what made Clark's novel feel so winning: it cheerfully, and comprehensively, flunked its sobriety test.

title: Soul Made Flesh
description: To imagine a time and place - say, the city of Oxford on a summer day in 1662 - you have to engage not only the mind's eye and ear but also the mind's nose. The warm odor of malt and corn flour rises from the boats landing at the wharves along the Thames. The stink of cured fish hanging in fishmongers' stalls mixes with the soft smell of bread in the bakeries. The smell of manure is everywhere, in the open sewers, on the town common where cows graze, in the streets where horses haul wagons and coaches. Sometimes a coach rolls through the narrow gate of one of Oxford's colleges, to be swallowed up behind a high, windowless stone wall. The chimneys of the college kitchens relay smoke signals to the surrounding neighborhoods, carrying the smell of roasting capon and mutton or perhaps a goose stolen from a nearby village by students.

title: The Confusion Over Voter ID
description: In last month's Florida presidential primary, Fort Myers polling places had signs saying voters could not vote without photo ID, according to the American Civil Liberties Union of Florida The problem is, the signs were wrong. Florida law guarantees voters without photo ID the right to cast an ''affidavit ballot,'' which counts the same as a regular one. There is no way of knowing how many eligible voters saw the false notice and did not vote as a result.

title: The Rwanda Witness
description: For seven days in February, Romo Dallaire, the Canadian general who commanded the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Rwanda 10 years ago, sat on a witness stand in a small courtroom in Arusha, Tanzania. Dallaire had served in Rwanda during one of the worst massacres in modern history. In 100 days, some 800,000 Tutsis and Hutus viewed as sympathetic to them were murdered, and Dallaire was powerless to stop it. During those months, his waking hours were a living nightmare. The bodies were everywhere, strewn in fields and latrines and stacked in neat rows next to the road as if someone were keeping score. Countless times, Dallaire had to get out of his four-by-four and move remains from the middle of the road to avoid driving over them. Denied authority by the United Nations to intervene, Dallaire tried to broker a cease-fire, protect the innocent, prick the world's conscience through the media. But his real mission, it came to pass, was personally far more devastating -- to be a witness.

title: Plain Heathen Mischief
description: After considering the possibilities for six days and six nights, it seemed pointless to mention sex or weakness or the girl, so Joel King decided his final sermon would be pale and simple, no more and no less than the ordinary things he'd said to his congregation in the past. There were, of course, several last-stand temptations he'd contemplated while staring at his laptop, and two he'd quixotically pecked to life even though he knew all along they'd never depart his study. The first composition was a blaze of fury, defiance and "how-dare-you" indignation. Jacked on coffee and Jonathan Edwards, he wasted an afternoon creating a fiery screed that would have him going out unbowed and bare-knuckled, every syllable a conflagration, every breath a test of will, the pulpit seething with brimstone and bit- ter jabs into the air. Then, on Friday morning, his wife called him a "pissant," and by that evening, during a long, drab rain, a flamboyant collapse seemedfor an hour or so at leastlike a good choice. Midway through this one, he started to use a Pentecostal tongue, typed the word "Gawd" a lot and didn't worry about periods, just strung together sentences he could preach big-time, throwing back his head and squeezing his eyes shut, the snot and tears running on his cheeks as he finished his career with a sopping, over-the-top, tent-revival mea culpa full of biblical caterwauling and pitifully rococo pleas to the forgiving heavenly Father.

title: Searching Students For Contraband
description: Re ''Seeking Security, Schools Are Turning to the Sniff Test'' [March 21]: I am appalled by the critical, even skeptical tone of the article, which gives equal time to the carping of the American Civil Liberties Union, one of the most dangerous groups in America. The prevalent use of drugs at Melville High School in East Setauket is no secret, as attested by the disturbing images of Jimi Hendrix, doves, peace signs and multiracial groups of children holding hands that adorn its walls. In past, drug use among students has led to devil worship, sexual deviancy, Marxism and boys' lacrosse. I am glad we have a school administration that finally appreciates this problem, for there is no greater or more immediate threat to our youth than the war on drugs. The fact that the canine inspectors have not yet found any evidence of contraband does not mean that this is a sweetheart-deal boondoggle. It means that we must give the inspectors more time and all the resources they require. The school is better off than it was a year ago, and local residents are safer because teenage lawlessness is being fought in the schools and not in suburban streets. School officials will make sure that a problem that never existed does not get worse.

title: RADIO: CHATTING ABOUT 'MORNING EDITION'
description: Discontented listeners opposed to replacing Bob Edwards as the host of NPR's popular news program ''Morning Edition'' can log onto the Internet today and say so. Jay Kernis, the network's senior vice president for programming, will hold a live, hourlong Web chat at NPR.org, beginning at 1 p.m. Jeffrey Dvorkin, NPR's ombudsman, will be the host. Though Mr. Kernis, who was central in the decision to remove Mr. Edwards, has been responding to complaints through form letters and occasional phone calls, a spokeswoman for the network said it wanted to do more. ''We felt that we wanted to interact as directly as possible,'' said Jessamyn Sarmiento, NPR's director for public and media relations. ''It's not going to change the outcome of what has happened, but hopefully it will help paint the picture of why it happened in a clearer way.'' In addition to the Web chat, NPR has added a link on its Web site that synthesizes and provides answers to the flood of complaints -- more than 25,000 calls and e-mail messages, Ms. Sarmiento said -- that the network has received since announcing on March 23 that Mr. Edwards was being removed from his anchor post and reassigned as a senior correspondent. One of the most frequently asked questions was, ''Is there a chance you will change your mind and bring Bob back?'' The answer, delivered in wordy managerial speak: not likely. Mr. Edwards has negotiated and accepted a new contract and is scheduled to be host of ''Morning Edition'' for the last time on April 30. LYNETTE CLEMETSON

title: A Balladeer's Subtle Lyricism Drowns in Rock Technology

No one seemed to care that the subtlety and feeling conveyed on his lush, formal albums were crushed. Her dilemma -- her erotic impulses and moral ambiguity -- is the coil that runs through the series, twisting and turning.

If they fail, the schools become the ward of the state's highest court, the last thing most reasonable people want. So legislators and Gov. George Pataki are looking at proposals ranging from $2 billion to $6 billion a year in added education money. Since a good chunk of that money should go to New York City to serve the largest population of the state's neediest students, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has put his bill at $5.3 billion. These huge numbers raise a very basic question -- where is the state going to get the money?
