title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Dies After Pipe Bursts
description: A disabled Brooklyn woman died yesterday when a steam pipe burst beneath her first floor apartment in the Bay View Houses in Canarsie, producing a lethal level of heat, the authorities said. The woman, identified last night as Constance Wallace-Lloyd, 47, was found by emergency workers who entered the apartment shortly after 10:30 a.m., and was pronounced dead at the scene. Sheila Greene, a Housing Authority spokeswoman, said Ms. Wallace-Lloyd's apartment was directly above a basement room where heating pipes entered her building from a central heating plant in the 23- building housing complex. Ms. Greene said the pipe was immediately repaired when workers arrived, and the cause of the accident remained under investigation last night. Relatives said on televised news reports that Ms. Wallace-Lloyd had multiple sclerosis and used a wheelchair. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | People: EchoStar President To Retire
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Michael T. Dugan, would retire at the end of this month and join the company's board. Mr. Dugan, 55, will succeed Peter A. Dea on the board on May 6, according to the company, which is based in Englewood, Colo. Mr. Dugan's responsibilities will be assumed by other executives until a successor is found, the company said. He has been with EchoStar for 14 years. Mr. Dea decided to resign from the board at the end of his term for personal reasons, the company said. Shares of EchoStar fell 26 cents, to $32.73. On March 26 EchoStar reported fourth-quarter net income of $3 million after it gained subscribers by offering more local channels and free video recorders. That was in contrast to a loss of $716 million a year earlier, when it had paid $600 million to break a contract to buy the DirecTV Group.

title: A Group Perseveres After Losing Its Leader
description: The Art Ensemble of Chicago began its first set at Iridium on March 30 with the group's members facing west and bowing their heads for about 10 seconds. It was their first performance together since the death of Malachi Favors, the group's bassist, in January.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Human Remains Found In Subway
description: The authorities were trying last night to identify human remains that were found yesterday on the subway tracks north of the 116th Street station at Lenox Avenue. The police said that the body parts, which were spotted by the motorman of a No. 3 train that was about to leave the station about 4:30 p.m., were so badly mutilated that the body's gender could not be immediately determined. Northbound service was disrupted on the No. 2 and 3 lines, with all northbound No. 3 service halted north of 96th Street for several hours while the remains were removed. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Schools Fail Children, Not the Other Way Around
description: The nation's largest school system was thrown into a panic recently when the mayor of New York decreed that third graders who performed poorly on a city test just weeks away could be required to repeat the grade. Mayor Michael Bloomberg actually fired education officials who disagreed with the new policy, despite data from several cities -- including Chicago, Miami, Boston, Washington and New York itself -- showing that children held back in the early grades fare worse academically -- and are more likely to drop out -- than children with similar test scores who get extra help after being promoted.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Aznar To Teach At Georgetown
description: Jos Mara Aznar, the outgoing prime minister, will join the faculty at Georgetown University in Washington in the fall, teaching seminars on contemporary European politics and trans-Atlantic relationships, the university said. Mr. Aznar won election as prime minister in 1996 and 2000 as head the conservative Popular Party. A staunch supporter of the United States-led war in Iraq despite opposition at home, he did not seek a third term in elections last month. His new title will be distinguished scholar in the practice of global leadership. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

description: Four men have been arrested on gun charges stemming from a weekend brawl at a party at Fairleigh Dickinson University that left seven people injured and nerves frayed on the college's suburban campus.

description: The Merisant Company in Chicago said yesterday that it had named units of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York, majority owned by MDC Partners, to handle creative and media duties for the Equal brand of sweetener. Those duties had been handled by the New York office of the Wolf Group, which closed in January along with its parent, Wolf Group Integrated Communications. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

description: American officials on Monday stepped up their confrontation with Moktada al-Sadr, the militant Shiite cleric whose followers started an uprising in at least six Iraqi cities over the weekend, confirming that they had issued an arrest warrant for him but declining to say when they would execute it.

description: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether the police need a special reason to subject a car they have stopped for a traffic violation to a drug-sniffing dog.

description: In Tom Glavine's imagination, it is already late Tuesday night, he is walking out of Turner Field, and the worst season of his career is finally in the background, fading into a new year.

description: City officials announced a new set of traffic safety improvements yesterday for Queens Boulevard, the broad artery running through central Queens that has earned the nickname the Boulevard of Death because of the high number of pedestrians killed in accidents there.

description: Responding to concerns in his own party that he may have taken too long off the campaign trail, Senator John Kerry said Monday that he had plenty of time to define himself for voters despite millions of dollars worth of what he termed ''the equivalent of nuclear attacks'' on television by the Bush campaign that have cast him as a tax-and-spend liberal.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Slaughter Ordered For 19 Million Poultry
description: Agriculture Minister Bob Speller ordered the slaughter of 19 million chickens, turkeys and ducks in British Columbia in an attempt to stop the rapid spread of avian influenza. The mass cull will effectively destroy up to 80 percent of the province's poultry industry. About 400,000 birds have already been slaughtered there, but agriculture officials have not been able to halt the spread of the disease in a number of farms in the Fraser Valley. The outbreak is a milder strain that the flu that has ravaged poultry in Asia and is not considered a serious threat to human health. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: F.D.A. AGREES TO SPEED APPLICATION FOR A CANCER DRUG
description: The Bayer Group and Onyx Pharmaceuticals said Food and Drug Administration regulators had agreed to work with them to hasten approval of an experimental drug to treat kidney cancer. The F.D.A. added the medication, known as BAY 43-9006, to its fast-track program, intended to speed development of treatments for fatal diseases, the companies said. The companies said the designation meant that they could file parts of the application as study results became available, instead of waiting to complete all of the research. BAY 43-9006, which could become Onyx's first approved product, is in the third and last stage of testing usually required for approval of a medicine, the companies said. Onyx is based in Richmond, Calif., and Bayer is based in Leverkusen, Germany.

title: Family Togetherness in Sitcomland

Last month Fox issued Walter Lang's original (1950), with Clifton Webb and Myrna Loy as Frank and Lillian Gilbreth, who in the 1920's herded their brood from Rhode Island to New Jersey. In Shawn Levy's distant cousin of a remake, Tom and Kate Baker (Steve Martin and Bonnie Hunt) uproot their kids, while Tom tries to make it as a big-time football coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACHLIN, MILT
description: MACHLIN--Milt. April 3, 2004 He had more fun in his lifetime than any one person could expect. Native of New York City, decorated veteran of WWII, served in the Asian theater, graduated from Brown University and attended the Sorbonne, receiving a degree in Coeur de Civilisation. Editor of Argosy Magazine and the author of numerous books, fiction and non fiction, including ''9th Life,'' ''Libby,'' ''The Search for Michael Rockefeller,'' and ''Pipeline.'' He received an Edgar Allan Poe Special Award from the Mystery Writers of America for ''The Setup.'' He is survived by his wife, Margaret Ryan Machlin, his stepson Jason Sheckley, his brother and sister-in-law Dr. Stanley and Mikki Machlin, sister-in-law Ruth Machlin and loving nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial service to be announced.

Once the province of heartfelt sincerity or moronic humor, the T-shirt is now a showcase for an intolerance of being earnest. A past master of this advanced art form is Marc Jacobs, whose T-shirts are so aloof as to be inscrutable. Past T's have borne the legends ''Mayonnaise'' and ''2008.'' But the latest T-shirt at his Bleecker Street store has even veteran fashion-watchers scratching their heads.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Scientist Convicted Of Spying
description: A jury in Moscow convicted a nuclear arms researcher of treason in a case that has been widely seen as a measure of intellectual freedom in Russia, news agencies reported. The researcher, Igor Sutyagin, arrested in 1999 and held since then despite an inconclusive trial in 2001, was accused of passing classified information about Russia's military to the United States and Britain. He has maintained his innocence, saying his research involved only public information. A judge was expected to hand down a sentence today. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: Half hidden behind a column, Narciso Rodriguez shyly presided over the unveiling of his fall collection last week for a select circle of New Yorkers. ''Chic girls,'' he murmured, studying the crowd. And indeed, immaculate young society fixtures like Aerin Lauder, Gigi Mortimer and Lillian von Stauffenberg had all turned out in support of Mr. Rodriguez and of Jessica Seinfeld, their mutual friend, for this private trunk show. The sales were to benefit Baby Buggy, the charity Ms. Seinfeld set up to collect strollers, clothing and other articles for infants and children.

Both junior troupes serve as farm teams and incubators for choreographic talent, represented here by Laura Gorenstein Miller and Brian Reeder. But first the Ballet Theater dancers got to show what they could do in repertory classics.

Along with undercover officers and supervisors, they were dispatched as part of a state program called Operation Impact, which sends state troopers to 15 counties that account for 80 percent of crime in the state, not counting New York City. The governor's Operation Impact is not to be confused with Mayor Michael R. The 2-year-old twins, Mohamed and Ahmed Ibrahim, who were born in a small town in Egypt, will return to the hospital each weekday to continue physical therapy. More surgery is planned to repair and strengthen the boys' skulls until they can wear protective helmets. Doctors said the children could return to Egypt by the end of the year. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston has reached settlements with four men who say they were sexually abused by the Rev. Paul R. Shanley and who opted out of an $85 million agreement brokered last year with hundreds of people who say they were abused by priests.

description: It is hard to say what is the most amazing sight in Syria. The ruins that map human history in toppled stone? The church where St. Paul converted to Christianity? title: A Soprano Pays Tribute to Her Roots
description: Folk song, or at least its spirit, lies at the heart of a good deal of classical music, from Renaissance parody Masses to Mahler symphonies. In modern times, the impulse toward complication - and then the impulse toward simplicity - has pulled music in other, decidedly non-folkish directions. But some composers have kept in touch with folk roots, and on March 31 the soprano Dawn Upshaw devoted her concert at Zankel Hall to two of them, Luciano Berio and Osvaldo Golijov.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Web Site Adds Canadian Pharmacy

Craig Benson has added a section on his official Web site linking to a state-approved Canadian mail-order pharmacy and telling residents about the state's plan to import prescription drugs. Pharmacists commissioned by the state visited the Winnipeg offices of the site, canadadrugs.com, in February and found that it was safe. Mr. Benson's Web site, www.nh.gov/governor/prescription/prescription.html, also provides frequently asked questions about buying drugs from Canada, criteria used by the state to decide an online pharmacy's security, and a cost-savings analysis. A spokesman for the New Hampshire Pharmacists Association said the move put the state at risk, echoing criticism from the Food and Drug Administration. Mr. Benson, a Republican, has sought a waiver from federal law, which bans the importing of prescription drugs. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Raises Thai Stakes
description: The Nissan Motor Company will pay $190 million to gain controlling stakes in two companies that manufacture and sell Nissans in Thailand. Hoping to increase sales and profits in the fast growing Thai market, Nissan said it would raise its stakes in the Siam Nissan Automobile Company, a manufacturer and distributor of Nissan vehicles, and the Siam Motors and Nissan Company, a vehicle assembler, to 75 percent from 25 percent. Nissan's move to take control of the operations follows a year in which sales of Nissan vehicles sank 1.8 percent in Thailand while the overall vehicle sales expanded by 30 percent. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Three People Die in 4-Alarm Fire In Yonkers Apartment Building
description: Flames fanned by high winds tore through three apartment buildings in Yonkers yesterday, killing a man, a woman and a child -- possibly a teenager -- from one family and forcing as many as 80 people out into the cold, authorities said.

title: Game, Not Membership, Is Hot Topic at Masters
description: A year after being engulfed by controversy, Augusta National Golf Club was engulfed Monday by heavy traffic, bright sunshine and thousands of eager fans pouring through the gates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONSTHER, BURTON, M.D.
description: BRONSTHER--Burton, M.D. It is with sadness that we acknowledge the untimely death of our friend and colleague, Dr. Burton Bronsther. Dr. Bronsther was one of the founding pediatric surgeons on Long Island. He served with distinction as a member of the staff of Pediatric Surgery at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center for over 40 years. He played a vital role in the establishment of the Schneider Children's Hospital and it was through his vision that the Children's Hospital was established. A renowned surgeon, Dr. Bronsther was a man with many interests, a devoted husband, a loving father and grandfather. He had an outstanding ability to interact with his patients, their families, peers, members of the nursing staff and everyone with whom he came in contact. He was a man of humor and integrity and was loved by his patients the world over and respected by his peers. The faculty and staff of the Schneider Children's Hospital mourn his passing and acknowledge the loss of one of its finest doctors. Condolences to his loving wife, Ellyn, his children and grandchildren. Philip Lanzkowsky, MD Executive Director and Chief of Staff Schneider Children's Hospital

title: In Double Time, Sex and Death and Punk 'n' Roll
description: Here's a great idea for a band: a bunch of loud, fast punks, led by a roaring Australian woman who's never seen in public without blood-red lipstick and a carefully ripped T-shirt.

title: Scientists Discover Fossil From Era When Fish Did Push-Ups
description: A small arm bone fossilized in the red sandstone of a Pennsylvania road cut may hold clues to a critical transition of life on Earth, the evolution of some fish into land-dwelling animals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 6 Bosnian Croats Surrender
description: Six former fighters in the conflict between Croatia and Bosnian Muslims in 1993 surrendered to the United Nations war crimes tribunal, which has accused them of murder, rape and other abuses against Muslims. Their charges are all linked to a campaign to drive Muslims from a Croatian state formed during the war in Bosnia. One of the six, Jadranko Prlic, was briefly the prime minister of the breakaway state; another, Bruno Stojic, was its defense minister. The other four are Gen. Slobodan Praljak and Gen. Milivoij Petkovic, who both headed militia; Valentin Coric, a wartime commander of the military police; and Berislav Pusic, in charge of exchanging prisoners of war. Marlise Simons (NYT)

Loving grandfather of Zeke, Alex, Leah, Madeline, Sarah, Samara and Jeremy. Services at Clark Associates, Katonah, NY, on Thursday, April 8, at 12 noon.

title: Barely Over Last Nights Party, UConn Hopes for Another
description: The tiny town of Storrs, Connecticut, is awash in red, white and blue, and draped with flags of the UConn Huskies. As everybody here knows, unless they've been in a coma, the University of Connecticut men's basketball team won the N.C.A.A. national championship last night.

title: An Artful Wink Slyly Denies Time's Passage
description: Stephen Sondheim's declaration of show business survival, ''I'm Still Here,'' has become a kind of Rorschach test for singers of a certain age. You can pluck any emotion you want from the monologue of a trouper who has weathered several decades of personal and professional vicissitudes: triumph, bitterness and even a zany appreciation for the absurdity of it all. But no one extracts more from the song than Julie Wilson, the 79-year-old cabaret singer who returned to the nightclub stage this weekend at the Hideaway Room at Helen's, the small Chelsea cabaret that used to be Judy's.

Would any kin, or anyone knowing any next of kin please contact the Rome D.D.S.O collect at 315-336-2300 with any special funeral arrangements.

title: As Fans Cry Foul, Bonds Hits Back With His Bat
description: Barry Bonds of the Giants is long accustomed to his role as one of baseball's most disliked visiting villains. Early returns Monday night indicated that this season could be his most trying one. But in the face of a hostile Astros crowd, its booing fueled by the steroids controversy, Bonds hit his 659th career home run, a three-run shot that moved him to one behind his godfather, Willie Mays, for third place on the career list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARAS, JOHN
description: TARAS--John. Peter Martins, the Board of Directors, the dancers and staff of New York City Ballet mourn the passing of John Taras. John's long association with George Balanchine began as a student at the School of American Ballet, continued as a dancer with several of Mr. Balanchine's early companies and culminated in his position as Ballet Master for New York City Ballet, a title he shared with Mr. Balanchine and Jerome Robbins. Mr. Balanchine also encouraged John to choreograph and during his years with the company he created more than 15 works. A man of grace, sophistication and impeccable style, John will be greatly missed by the entire ballet world. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Helene Sadovska and stepdaughter Anne Stephant.

title: END OF OLDSMOBILE ALERO WILL COST 1,500 G.M. JOBS
description: General Motors plans to cut about 1,500 more jobs at a Lansing, Mich., factory on June 7 by eliminating a shift when it ends production of the Oldsmobile Alero. The factory, which has three shifts and 4,600 hourly workers, produces the Alero, Pontiac Grand Am and Chevy Classic midsize cars. Laid-off workers will be eligible for other jobs within the company, including as many as 2,600 openings at a new vehicle plant scheduled to open in 2006 in Delta Township, a Lansing suburb, a company spokesman, Dan Flores, said. General Motors, based in Detroit, has not said what it will build at the new factory.

title: Breakfast at Barneys
description: Half hidden behind a column, Narciso Rodriguez shyly presided over the unveiling of his fall collection last week for a select circle of New Yorkers. "Chic girls," he murmured, studying the crowd. And indeed, immaculate young society fixtures like Aerin Lauder, Gigi Mortimer and Lillian von Stauffenberg had all turned out in support of Mr. Rodriguez and of Jessica Seinfeld, their mutual friend, for this private trunk show. The sales were to benefit Baby Buggy, the charity Ms. Seinfeld set up to collect strollers, clothing and other articles for infants and children.

title: Obsessing About the Calendar
description: President Bush keeps clinging to his politically driven deadline of June 30 for handing over symbolic sovereignty in Iraq to an Iraqi entity. While everyone is eager for the country to be turned over to its people, simply sticking to a timetable is not the same as making real progress toward self-government. After the weekend's clashes between the American-led occupation forces and heavily armed militias loyal to a Shiite Muslim cleric, Mr. Bush presented the date as a watershed and its timing as a test of American will. In fact, neither is true.

title: LENNOX TO SELL SERVICE CENTERS IN A REVAMPING
description: Lennox International, which makes heating and air-conditioning products, said it would sell 47 of its dealer service centers and take at least $205 million in pretax charges to turn around its service business. The company will record $25 million in pretax expenses related to the divestiture and take a pretax noncash charge of at least $180 million to write down good will, Lennox said. The 47 centers will be organized under a new entity and classified as a discontinued business, Lennox said. Lennox, based in Richardson, Tex., said in February that it was evaluating options to turn around its service segment, which had an operating loss of $10 million in the fourth quarter of 2003. The 47 centers to be shed are mainly in smaller cities and focus on new construction, the company said.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: SCIENTIST CONVICTED OF SPYING A jury in Moscow convicted a nuclear arms researcher of treason in a case that has been widely seen as a measure of intellectual freedom in Russia, news agencies reported. The researcher, Igor Sutyagin, arrested in 1999 and held since then despite an inconclusive trial in 2001, was accused of passing classified information about Russia's military to the United States and Britain. He has maintained his innocence, saying his research involved only public information. A judge was expected to hand down a sentence today. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

But 20 years ago, researchers here at the California National Primate Research Center were the first to realize that an infection killing their colony of rhesus macaque monkeys mirrored the new human disorder known as AIDS.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Tobacco Smuggling Deal
description: Philip Morris International, part of the Altria Group, has agreed to pay about $1 billion over 12 years to settle European Union charges that it aids cigarette smuggling that costs governments billions in tax revenue. The preliminary deal between the company, based in New York, and the European Commission, the European Union's executive arm, will ''put past disputes behind us,'' David Davies, head of European corporate affairs at Philip Morris, said in an interview. An agreement could also help curtail the trade in counterfeits that has cost Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, about $121 million a year, Mr. Davies said. The European Union first sued Philip Morris and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings in a New York federal court in 2000, accusing them of illegally importing cigarettes into Europe. ''We are close to an agreement'' with Philip Morris, the European Union's budget commissioner Michaele Schreyer, above, said in a briefing in Brussels. She said the commission was waiting for the approval of the member countries and hoped to sign the agreement very soon. The accord would reduce conflict between the community and the company, Ms. Schreyer said. The company's payment is not a fine or a repayment demand, but it is part of an agreement to fight smuggling, she said.

description: The Walt Disney Company is considering a broad overhaul of its ABC television network in the wake of another year of lackluster ratings and is holding discussions with some executives about changing their roles, several executives said last night.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Floods Kill 25
description: At least 25 people were reported dead in flash floods that swept across the town of Piedras Negras, on the border with the United States. Another 70 people were reported missing, and local authorities evacuated 5,000 people. The floods were caused by a torrential rainfall on Sunday that broke the banks of the Escondido River. The same storm brought heavy rainfall to New Mexico and western Texas, causing at least one bridge to collapse. More rain was expected today. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Man Charged With Kidnapping
description: A Long Island man was arrested on Sunday afternoon on charges that he abducted a woman waiting for a train and, for six hours, forced her to perform sex acts with other people who paid him, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The man, Arthur Philip, 33, of Hempstead, was charged with kidnapping and promoting prostitution in the incident, which took place on March 28. The police said that the victim, 22, was waiting to take a train into New York City when Mr. Philip and an unidentified man forced her into a white van. She was then driven to different houses and was ordered to have sex with different people, who paid Mr. Philip, the police said. After six hours, the woman, who had apparently been singled out at random, was released, the police said. Patrick Healy (NYT)

description: BOTSFORD -- Ward, 76, Grammy winning record producer, died April 1 after a long illness. Considered to be the penultimate classical music maven, Botsford's work included recordings with Sir Thomas Beecham, Michael Tilson Thomas and many others. He also produced spoken arts recordings for radio, film and records with many actors such as Sir Gielgud, Sir Olivier and Henry Fonda. Friend & colleague to many in science fiction including Isaac Asimov, Robert Heinlein, Frank Herbert & Arthur C. Clarke-all whom dedicated works to him. Botsford wrote for the Star Trek: TNG episode ''Rascals.'' He is survived by his wife, Lynn, daughters Diana and Andrea and four grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIZAVI, SYED ALAY ZAMIN, M.D.
description: RIZAVI--Syed Alay Zamin, M.D. Died Wednesday, March 24, 2004 at home in New York City. A doctor to the core, his compassion, kindness and goodness knew no bounds. He showed his family and friends how to combine confidence, competence, humility and warmth. He was the son of Alay Nabi, the Mayor of Agra, India, and member of the Parliament and Moquidissa and was the youngest of six children. Dr. Rizavi was raised in Agra, and moved to Karachi, Pakistan. He attended King Edward Medical College and specialized in Cardiology and Tropical Diseases in Edinburgh, Scotland. Dr. Rizavi returned to practice medicine in Pakistan as Civil Surgeon of Karachi. He then worked at New York Hospital on a World Health Organization scholarship, and in 1976, he and his family moved to Evanston, IL, and then Winnetka, IL. Dr. Rizavi practiced medicine at Evanston Hospital from 1975 until 2003, when he moved to New York City. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, son-in-law, as well as three grandchildren, two brothers, a sister and many nieces and nephews. We cherished our moments with him and he will be with us in spirit. Memorial gifts should be directed to Evanston Northwestern Healthcare Foundation, Dr. Rizavi Memorial, 1603 Orrington, Suite 750, Evanston, IL 60201, 847-570-5601. Funds will be used to establish an annual award in Dr. Rizavi's name, to be given to the medical resident who best exemplifies his dedication and generosity of spirit.

description: The Brady Corporation, which makes safety and identification signs used in warehouses and other industrial locations, agreed to buy the EMED Company from Summit Partners for about $190 million. EMED, based in Buffalo, makes parking and traffic signs, warehouse and shipping signs and first-aid and protective clothing. EMED, which is privately held, had sales of $55 million in 2003. The transaction is expected to add slightly to Brady's per-share profit in the 12 months ending in July and to increase net income by 15 cents to 20 cents a share in the year ending in July 2005, the chief financial officer, David Mathieson, said. Brady is based in Milwaukee.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Payout In Telecom Acquisition
description: Manitoba Telecom Services Inc. will raise its annual dividend almost threefold to 2.60 Canadian dollars a share, or $1.98, after the purchase of Allstream, ending at least one investor's opposition to the acquisition. Manitoba Telecom said the dividend was 40 cents more than what was planned when the $1.53 billion Canadian purchase of Allstream, a former unit of the AT&T Corporation, was announced on March 18. The higher payout would raise the telephone company's dividend yield to more than 5 percent. Investors including Enterprise Capital Management, owner of about 5 percent of Manitoba Telecom, opposed the merger with Allstream, saying they wanted the company to transform itself into an income trust instead. Enterprise said that it was satisfied with the new dividend and would drop its opposition.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Fire Damages Clintons' Former Home
description: A small house in Hot Springs that had once been home to former President Bill Clinton and his family was extensively damaged by fire on Sunday night. The fire began in a car in the attached garage, then entered the attic and spread to the rest of the home, Fire Department officials said. The house was one of several the Clinton family occupied in Hot Springs after moving from Mr. Clinton's native Hope in 1953. On Friday, a vacation cottage owned by the family of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Lake Winola, Pa., had minor damage after a nearby home caught fire. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWRENCE, H. SHERWOOD, M.D.
description: LAWRENCE--H. Sherwood, M.D. Died Monday, April 5, St. Luke's Hospital, Manhattan, after a long illness. He was born in 1916 in Astoria, NY, son of Victor John and Agnes Brigid Whalen Lawrence. Beloved husband of sixty years of Dorothea Lawrence. Cherished father of Dorothea Lawrence Browne, Victor John Lawrence, M.D. and Geoffrey Douglas Lawrence. Dear father-in-law of Patricia and Ida Lawrence. Dearest grandfather of Alexander and Hillary Browne, Andrew Lawrence and Susannah Lawrence. Dr. Lawrence graduated from Stuyvesant High School, New York University Washington Square College and New York University School of Medicine, Class of '43D. He enlisted in the United States Navy following Pearl Harbor and served in World War II as a medical officer on several LSTs. He participated in the Normandy invasion at Omaha Beach and was part of the invasions of Southern France and Okinawa. Upon return from the War, he began his long and distinguished association with NYU School of Medicine and Bellevue Hospital. He concentrated his research in immunology, most notably in Transfer Factor. He was a member of the National Academy of Science and recipient of many other awards and honors. His long and distinguished career as a Bellevue physician, teacher, and researcher ceased only when he was in his eighties. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street Tuesday, April 6 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, April 7 at 10AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 2nd Ave and 22 Street, NY NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dr. Lawrence's memory to Michael Freedman, M.D. at the Department of Geriatrics, New York University Medical Center, 530 First Avenue, NY NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHARET, RICHARD, MD.
description: CHARET -- Richard, MD. Prominent Brooklyn Physician. Richard Charet, 97, prominent Brooklyn physician and decorated war hero, passed away on April 3, 2004. Born in Brooklyn, graduate of NYU College of Medicine, Dr. Charet practiced Internal Medicine and Cardiology in Brooklyn for 53 years. From 1941-1946, he served in the Army Medical Corps, reaching the rank of Major, participated in the battles of Saipan and Okinawa, and was awarded the Silver and Bronze Star Medals, and the Presidential Unit Citation. He served as Director of Medicine at the Madison Park Hospital of Adelphi College (and was named an honorary fellow of the college), the Prospect Heights Hospital, and the Community Hospital of Brooklyn, where he also served as Director of the Medical Staff and Chief of the ICU. He was an attending cardiologist at the Long Island College Hospital, and an Assistant Clinical Professor at SUNY Downstate Medical Center. He also served as President of the Brooklyn Society of Internal Medicine. He received a citation from Borough President Howard Golden, and was awarded the Distinguished Physician Award by the Kings County Medical Society. He authored numerous articles in national medical journals, and collaborated on a book on electrocardiology. Dr. Charet retired in 1991, and moved to Los Angeles with his family. He was loved by his many patients and considered a ''doctor's doctor'' by his colleagues. Dr. Charet is survived by his wife of 46 years, the former Annette Silver, two sons, Robert, also a physician, and Bruce, all of Los Angeles, and a sister, Dorothy Shafter, of Boca Raton, FL.

The commission found that the judge, Henry R. Bauer, left, of the Troy City Court, set extraordinarily high bail for minor offenses, did not tell defendants that the court could appoint lawyers to represent them, and coerced guilty pleas. Judge Bauer has contended that other circumstances, like being arrested in the company of known felons, justified high bails in certain cases. The judge, who contested the charges at an open hearing in January, will ask the State Court of Appeals to review the decision, his lawyer said, adding that he was confident it would be overturned. title: Technology Briefing | Services: Gtech To Buy Caribbean Lottery Operator
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation, the supplier of Internet lottery systems, has agreed to buy the Leeward Islands Lottery Holding Company for about $40 million to add contracts in the Caribbean and gain video-lottery terminals. Gtech said yesterday that it would pay cash and that it expected to complete the purchase of Leeward, which is closely held, in May. The acquisition will have no effect on earnings in the 2005 fiscal year, the company said. Gtech, which has announced three acquisitions since September, said the purchase would give it a ''strategic foothold'' in the regional Caribbean Lotto game and would help it gain video-lottery customers. Gtech already runs lotteries in Barbados, Jamaica, Puerto Rico and Trinidad and Tobago. The company said Leeward would generate $20 million to $25 million in lottery ticket sales, and net revenue of $6 million to $8 million in the fiscal year ending Feb. 26, 2005.

The company, based in Marlboro, Mass., said it misjudged the number of contracts it received in the first quarter. Its shares fell $1.79, or 13 percent, to $12.24. Concord, which makes software that helps identify problems on large computer networks, said it now expected to post a loss of 3 cents to 5 cents a share on revenue of $23.5 million to $23.8 million for the first quarter that ended March 31. Wall Street analysts were looking for earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $28 million, according to average estimates provided by Thomson Financial. In January, the company projected a profit of 6 cents to 8 cents a share on revenue of about $28 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Penalty For Trade Violation
description: Deutsche Bank, the European bank, was fined $347,000 by Britain's securities regulator for making its own trades in stocks before executing the trades for a client. The regulator, the Financial Services Authority, found that Morgan Grenfell and Company, a British unit of Deutsche Bank, in April 2002 made its own trades in seven of the securities in a client's planned program trade after receiving information about the trading plans. Morgan Grenfell did not tell the customer it might trade the securities based on the information it received and did not ensure the broker's trading would not cause the client to suffer a disadvantage, the financial authority said. Andrew Proctor, the authority's director of enforcement, said that Morgan Grenfell had disadvantaged its customer in the price it paid for the trade.

title: TV: 'SIMPSONS' SILENCE
description: Production on the new season of ''The Simpsons,'' the enduring animated show on the Fox network, has been held up over contract demands by the actors who play major voice roles in the comedy series. People close to the negotiations said that the actors whose voices portray Marge, Homer, Bart, Lisa and other characters had not appeared for several table readings and had stalled production for the fall season. Those familiar with the negotiations said that the actors were seeking $360,000 an episode, or $8 million for a 22-episode season. Currently, top actors on the show earn about $125,000 an episode. Details of the impasse in contract talks were disclosed last week in Daily Variety. Executives at 20th Century Fox Television and James L. Brooks's Gracie Films, which produces the show, declined to comment. The actors involved include Dan Catellaneta, the voice of Homer; Julie Kavner (Marge); Hank Azaria (Moe, Apu and others); Harry Shearer (Mr. Burns, Mr. Smithers and others), Yeardley Smith (Lisa) and Nancy Cartwright (Bart). The Simpsons began as a series of short vignettes on ''The Tracey Ullman Show'' in 1987, and with its off-kilter, even subversive, humor, became an enormous success two years later as a regular series. It has also proven a gold mine for its creators. The franchise itself is, according to Variety, worth more than $1 billion.

Competitive pricing responses by major carriers to incursions by low-fare carriers are a prime reason for the drop to a $276 average fare paid last year, the lowest since $256 in 1996, according to American Express. Average fares are calculated from a variety of fare types booked by business travelers, including full walkup fares, nonrefundable advance-purchase tickets and negotiated corporate discounts.

title: The Genocide Next Door
description: It wasn't surprising that the 20th century ended with Africa having a genocide of its own. The bill he is backing, the governor said, has safeguards to ensure that terrorists will not get licenses. Under the Florida bill, those seeking the licenses would be fingerprinted and required to show identification.They would also have to prove that they owned or were leasing a car. Consulates would have to provide criminal background checks. Licenses would be valid for two years and only in Florida.    (AP)

title: A Fledgling Williams Play Flies to the Stage
description: In 1937, when Tom Williams was 26, he wrote a play called ''Spring Storm,'' and the following year read it aloud in his playwriting seminar at the University of Iowa. It was greeted by ''a long and all but unendurable silence,'' he later recalled, and ''was quite finally rejected by the class.'' After failing to get the play produced, he filed it in the forgotten drawer. He soon changed his name to Tennessee Williams, and within a few years began his career as a playwright.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Internet Provider Cuts Loss
description: Tiscali, an Internet service provider, said its 2003 loss narrowed as it added clients for its fast Internet service and increased sales. The net loss was 242 million euros ($292 million), compared with a loss of 593 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 20 percent to 901 million euros ($1 billion), the company said. Tiscali, which offers Web access and services in 14 European countries and South Africa, is hoping for a profit from operations in 2005 by gaining clients for faster Internet services using asymmetric digital subscriber lines. Tiscali, based in Cagliari, Italy, plans to increase asymmetric digital clients to about 5 million by the end of 2008.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State Landmarks Plantation Site
description: A five-acre site where archaeologists unearthed evidence of a northern slave plantation that the Marquis de Lafayette and George Washington visited has been granted state landmark status, officials said yesterday. Known as the Beverwyck site, near Parsippany and Troy Hills, it was a parking lot scheduled for expansion in the late 1990's when workers came across artifacts. Archaeologists eventually found slave shackles, buttons from Revolutionary War-era uniforms and other items that tied the site to a 2,000-acre mid-18th-century plantation known as Beverwyck. The Department of Environmental Protection plans to recommend the property for federal landmark status as well. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Index Rises
description: Japan's index of leading economic indicators rose to 77.8 percent in February from 50 percent in January, suggesting that growth will continue in the coming months. The index, which is designed to predict economic conditions several months ahead, was above the level of 50 percent for a ninth consecutive month. A reading above 50 percent suggests economic expansion while a number below 50 percent suggests contraction. The figure is the latest in a string of economic data pointing to a strengthening of the two-year-old economic recovery in Japan. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Sentenced In $7 Million Fraud
description: A Jordanian fugitive, wanted on a murder charge in Israel, was sentenced yesterday to nine years in prison on a fraud charge. The man, Ali Qaraeen, 50, had pleaded guilty to leading a credit card scheme that defrauded cardholders and companies of about $6.8 million in goods and cash. Mr. Qaraeen, arrested in Fort Lee in 2002, was also ordered to repay the money and was fined an additional $200,000. Neither crime is related to terrorism. Prosecutors said that from 1995 until his arrest, Mr. Qaraeen, in the United States illegally, directed more than a dozen people to open more than 1,000 credit card accounts and get cash advances. Judge Faith S. Hochberg told prosecutors to notify the Israeli authorities about the sentencing. Extradition is possible. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Water Rate Increase Proposed
description: The New York City Water Board has proposed raising water rates 5.5 percent for the coming fiscal year beginning July 1 to help cover higher security costs for New York's water supply and a long-term rebuilding program. If the proposal is accepted, annual water and sewage charges for apartments in walk-up buildings would reach $447, an increase of $23. Rates would rise $26 a year for apartments in elevator buildings, and $28 a year for single-family homes. The board will hold public hearings on the proposed increase between now and May 7, when the final rate will be set. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

While the donors should be celebrated for their generosity, this sort of basic caretaking at a national monument should have been done by the government. The statue's reopening has turned into an embarrassment for the Interior Department, and the most troubling aspect is what it says about the chronic underfinancing of the national park system.

Ms. Correra will advise the governor and his staff on proper greetings -- no hugging dignitaries -- and seating arrangements and develop a handbook of tips. description: HAMBURG, April 7  The only man convicted in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, Mounir el-Motassadeq, was released today by a German court pending a new trial later this year.

title: Slice a Tomato Thin, It Gets All Sloppy, Right? Wrong
description: Connie's Organic Tomato Chips are a mix of skinny slices of tomatoes and tomatillos from the Rattlesnake Creek vineyard and farm in Missoula, Mont. Scatter these dried tomato slices on a pizza or in a salad, or just pile them in a bowl and serve them with drinks. Soak them and layer them on baking fish. It takes two pounds of homegrown heirloom tomatoes to make a two-ounce package of chips, which come with either basil and oregano or lemon and pepper flavorings; $5.99 a package, plus shipping, from www.rattlesnakecreekvineyard.com.

title: Peril in Sudan
description: The worsening humanitarian disaster in western Sudan, where thousands of people have been killed and almost a million driven from their homes and farms by government-backed forces, will test whether the world has learned anything from its failure to stop the genocide in Rwanda 10 years ago. The United Nations, the United States, the European Union and African states must press the Sudanese government to halt attacks on civilians and to let aid agencies in. Absent swift and determined international action, Sudan could be another case of outside neglect allowing famine and disease to consume a nation.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: New Prime Minister
description: Mahinda Rajapakse, a 58-year-old lawyer and until last week the leader of the opposition, was sworn in as prime minister by President Chandrika Kumaratunga. For now, Mr. Rajapakse leads a minority government; Mrs. Kumaratunga's United People's Freedom Alliance won 105 out of 225 parliamentary seats in elections on Friday, giving it the largest number of seats, but has yet to cobble together a coalition that will give it a majority. Mr. Rajapakse said he would pursue peace talks with Tamil separatists and told the BBC that India should play a larger role in the process. Amy Waldman (NYT)

description: BOTSFORD -- Ward, 76, Grammy winning record producer, died April 1 after a long illness. Considered to be the penultimate classical music maven, Botsford's work included recordings with Sir Thomas Beecham, Michael Tilson Thomas and many others. He also produced spoken arts recordings for radio, film and records with many actors such as Sir Gielgud, Sir Olivier and Henry Fonda. Friend & colleague to many in science fiction including Isaac Asimov, Robert Heinlein, Frank Herbert & Arthur C. Clarke-all whom dedicated works to him. Botsford wrote for the Star Trek: TNG episode ''Rascals.'' He is survived by his wife, Lynn, daughters Diana and Andrea and four grandchildren.

Authority and passion emanate from Rawia Bishara like the enticing aromas that waft from the open kitchen. Whether overseeing her cooks or striding through the dining room to greet a familiar face, Ms. Bishara, a tall woman with striking dark hair, possesses Tanoreen. It is a restaurant as undiluted self-expression.

title: 'Un Ballo' in Sweden, as Verdi Intended and Censors Forbade
description: Verdi had problems with the censors. They wouldn't allow him to depict a king in a negative light, or a regicide, forcing him to make last-minute changes playing down the political overtones of several operas. So the Collegiate Chorale was proud to offer a ''Ballo in Maschera'' last Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall that restored it to its original setting (Sweden, not Boston), its original characters (King Gustavus III, not Riccardo the count) and its original text (''Svezia,'' or Sweden, rather than ''patria,'' or fatherland).

description: SAFFRON, contrary to what I often hear, is neither overrated, tasteless, ''for color only'' nor even especially expensive, at least by today's standards. Hand-harvested stigmas of the crocus sativus, real saffron is deep red (yellow threads are either male stamens, which have no culinary value, or an even more crass imitation), with a fabulous flavor as distinctive as that of basil or cumin.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Health Study For 9/11 Workers
description: About $81 million in federal grants will be used to track the long-term health of Sept. 11 rescue workers, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta, left, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced yesterday. Eight grants from the Department of Health and Human Services National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health will finance a five-year program to track the workers, including $25 million to monitor Fire Department and Emergency Medical Services personnel. Separately, a recent study by the Smithers Institute at Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations focused on firefighters' emotional health. The survey, proposed by the Uniformed Firefighters Association, found that the number of rescue workers seeking help for emotional problems increased by 50 percent after the attacks. The survey also found that firefighters who suffer from post-traumatic stress from the attacks and their aftermath report higher levels of depression, anxiety, stress and an increased risk of alcoholism. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Leader of Russian Republic Narrowly Escapes Assassination
description: The leader of the southern Russian republic of Ingushetia narrowly escaped an assassination attempt on Tuesday when a car bomb exploded next to his motorcade, officials said. The powerful explosion killed at least one person, apparently a suicide bomber, while wounding seven others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENDIXEN, HENRIK H.
description: BENDIXEN--Henrik H. The faculty, alumni and staff of Columbia University Medical Center mourn the death of our former leader, Dr. Henrik Bendixen. He brought rare qualities to the position of vice president and dean and he made even rarer contributions while on the job. Dr. Bendixen joined the College of Physicians & Surgeons at Columbia in 1973 as professor and chairman of anesthesiology after serving in posts at the Harvard Medical School and the University of California at San Diego. He was also director of the anesthesiology service at Presbyterian Hospital. He served as acting provost and vice president for the health sciences at Columbia in 1980-81. He was named Alumni Professor for the college in 1984 and the E.M. Papper Professor of Anesthesiology in 1985. He served as vice president and dean from 1984-89 and then became senior associate vice president and senior associate dean in 1989. During his time as vice president and dean he ushered the medical center's schools into the information age. He supported creation of a medical informatics center (now a P&S department) and established the computer infrastructure that has evolved into a ubiquitous educational, clinical, research, and administrative resource. In anesthesiology he was a leader in intensive care, developed new information on the care of patients with respiratory disease, and created the medical center's first department-wide practice plan. When he was named professor emeritus of anesthesiology in 1994, a portrait was unveiled in the medical center library, where it hangs today to honor his contributions to information technology in education, clinical systems, and administration. We extend our condolences to his family and friends and pledge to continue to honor his legacy to Columbia University. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: I2 And China Unicom Form Joint Venture
description: I2 Telecom International has formed a venture with China Unicom to deliver voice-over-Internet protocol service to small businesses, the latest effort to bring cheaper phone service to China. The service, which routes phone calls digitally over the Internet, is often many times cheaper than typical analog phone calls. To reduce long-distance costs, China Unicom, the country's second-largest telecommunications provider, will open a network operating center in Guangdong Province that will allow the company to avoid paying other carriers for use of their phone networks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Speedier Nuclear Cooperation Vowed
description: After talks with Mohamed ElBaradei, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Gholamreza Aghazadeh, Iran's nuclear chief, said Iran would agree to speed its cooperation with the agency but urged it to finish its inquiry by June, when the agency's board next meets. He added that Iran would suspend making and assembling atomic parts as of Friday, as a gesture of good will. A team of inspectors is scheduled to return Monday. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Personally Political: Fallout From the 'Dirty War'
description: ''The Blonds,'' an autobiographical semidocumentary directed by Albertina Carri, which opens today at Film Forum, is the second film shown in New York in the last few weeks to deal with the aftereffects of political repression in Argentina in the 1970's. Like Gastn Biraben's ''Captive,'' which was part of the recent New Directors/New Films series, Ms. Carri's film concerns a child whose parents were among the tens of thousands of Argentines kidnapped, tortured and killed during the military junta's ''dirty war'' against leftists, and who must, years later, contend with the pain and confusion of events she barely remembers.

title: Rescuing the Triangle That Got Lost in the Midst of Times Square

The place that went from that kiss on V-J Day to all that depravity and danger. The place that then cleaned itself up in time for the party when the calendar rolled over from 1999 into 2000. The crossroads of the world.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: A Stake In Bank
description: The Absa Group, a South African bank, has agreed to sell a 10 percent stake for as much as 5.05 billion rand ($795 million) to a group of black investors led by a wealthy black investor and former political prisoner, Tokyo Sexwale. Mr. Sexwale, left, who was imprisoned with former President Nelson Mandela, is one of South Africa's wealthiest blacks. He is on the board at Absa and is the head of Mvelaphanda Resources, the biggest black-owned mining company. Mvelaphanda also is in talks to buy 15 percent of the South African assets of Gold Fields, a gold producer. Absa is the first of the largest banks in South Africa to announce a stake sale to blacks. Financial services companies agreed last year to sell a quarter of their business to blacks to help make up for discrimination during South Africa's apartheid era that lasted from 1948 to 1994.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Father Sentenced In Son's Death
description: A young father who admitted that he fatally beat his infant son was sentenced yesterday to 18 years in prison. The man, Steven Murphy, 21, of East Massapequa, was accused of fatally striking the 9-month-old baby, who was crying, while baby-sitting in 2002. Last September, he pleaded guilty to a manslaughter charge. Mr. Murphy maintained that he had struck the infant once in the stomach. But Robert Biancavilla, the deputy chief of the district attorney's major offense bureau, said there had been repeated blows. An autopsy revealed that the child's liver was severed and his intestines lacerated. Mr. Murphy worked nights and watched his son days while the child's mother worked, Mr. Biancavilla said. title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Aide Quits Over Chvez Comments

Opposition forces had charged, with little evidence, that the soldiers were set on fire last week for opposing Mr. Chvez. The president, relying on Mr. Chacn's information, then told the nation on his radio program that the fire was ''light'' and the injuries slight. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DaimlerChrysler To Install Sirius Radios

The company expects about 550,000 new subscribers by 2006 from the agreement. Chrysler factories will install the satellite radios on Chrysler, Jeep and Dodge vehicles, including the Chrysler 300 Series, Dodge Ram pickup trucks and the Jeep Liberty, Sirius said. Sirius is issuing warrants to DaimlerChrysler to buy up to 21.5 million shares of Sirius at $1.04 each. That is a 65 percent discount to warrants issued in an earlier agreement. Sirius has exclusive partnerships with DaimlerChrysler, BMW and Ford Motor. The Ford agreement has not produced any radio installations. In January 2003 DaimlerChrysler began offering Sirius's subscription-radio service as a dealer-installed option on 16 of its cars and trucks. Shares of Sirius rose 14 cents to $3.89.

description: While working with Environmental Protection Agency officials to write regulations for coal-fired power plants over several recent months, White House staff members played down the toxic effects of mercury, hundreds of pages of documents and e-mail messages show.

description: President Megawati Sukarnoputri, whose party slumped in parliamentary elections on Monday, may have difficulty regaining the presidency in July, according to a national sample of returns released Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 21 about Rabbi Ayelet S. Cohen, who has performed same-sex marriages for Congregation Beth Simchat Torah in Greenwich Village, referred imprecisely to Orthodox Judaism's position on homosexuality and same-sex marriage. While the Rabbinical Council of America and the Union of Orthodox Congregations of America say that both are a violation of Jewish tradition and law, the groups say that people who do not follow that teaching should be treated with compassion and welcomed at services, not rejected at all levels.

title: Letting Minds Flow Unfettered, As Bodies Move To Bold Rhythms
description: Nancy Meehan's latest premiere, ''Unconscious Conversations,'' has a bold rhythmic vigor that departs from her usual subtle fluency. As the first of two pieces presented by her company on Sunday night at St. Mark's Church in the East Village, ''Unconscious Conversations'' was like a darkening storm. But the other work, ''12 Feet on a Wooden Plane,'' from 2002, was like a brief April shower. The first piece startled, the second refreshed. Both cleared the mind.

title: Detained by Militiamen
description: A journalistic encounter with militiamen loyal to the cleric Moktada al-Sadr began with a supposed news conference and lasted, under jumpy armed guard, for hours. Page A8.

title: Pacers Put On Clinic For Thomas and Knicks
description: Isiah Thomas picked his moments carefully. Only during play at Conseco Fieldhouse did Thomas walk several steps forward from the tunnel leading to the Knicks' locker room Tuesday night for a closer look at the court. Thomas, the former Pacers coach and the current Knicks president of basketball operations, did not want to draw needless attention from the crowd.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Andrew Says Earnings Beat Forecasts
description: The Andrew Corporation, the third-best-performing stock in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index through March 31, said yesterday that earnings for its second quarter topped forecasts after sales more than doubled on growing demand for wireless-network gear. Net income, on a preliminary basis, was 4 cents to 6 cents a share on sales of $440 million to $450 million, said the company, based in Orland Park, Ill. A year earlier, Andrew had a net loss of 3 cents on revenue of $201 million. Andrew, which makes cable, antennas and other components for wireless-network towers, is benefiting from higher spending by carriers in the United States and Europe. Profit exceeded the company's forecast of break-even to 3 cents a share and revenue topped its forecast of $350 million to $380 million. Shares of Andrew rose $2.39, or 13 percent, to $20.58. Andrew plans to report full financial results on April 29.

title: Europe Trying to Act First Against Terrorist Networks
description: With a new threat of terrorism coursing through Europe, intelligence and police authorities say they are acting more aggressively, with greater emphasis on pre-emptive action to roll up networks of Islamic militants whose members may not have committed crimes, but who have the skills or ideological resolve for violence.

title: Motor-Vehicle-Related Deaths Will Increase, Study Predicts
description: Motor vehicle crashes kill about 1.2 million people a year worldwide, and the number will rise to more than 2 million in 2020 unless new steps are taken, according to a study being released Wednesday by the World Health Organization and the World Bank.

''I went to Dillard's this morning and found these, but nothing matches,'' Mrs. Flower said, holding up a pink silk blouse and a yellow skirt. ''I buy a skirt here, a top there, but it doesn't look pulled together.''

But Mr. Schwarz's other longstanding commitment has been to the Seattle Symphony, a group that, remarkably, had never performed in Carnegie Hall until April 1, when it made its debut as part of an East Coast tour celebrating its centenary season.

title: Yearning for Mideast Peace (With a Nod to Italian Strife)
description: When the Metropolitan Opera puts many weeks of work into mounting an ambitious new production, as the company did three years ago for Verdi's ''Nabucco,'' it is hard to maintain the same standard when it returns in a revival without the built-in extra rehearsal time. Also, some components of the performance may change: a different cast member or conductor. It is easy for things to get a little creaky.

title: A New Chef and a Fresh Start
description: THE address 208 West 70th Street has not been kind to restaurateurs. Marika, among the first restaurants to occupy the space, in 2000, began with great optimism. But after a few negative reviews and a family feud, its hopes were dashed. Then came Compass. The new owners added some Cadillac-size modern paintings and a few banquettes. But what they really needed was a new identity. Without one, it became a revolving door for chefs. It kept Jehangir Mehta, a talented young pastry chef, for almost a year, but then he departed for Aix. Neil Annis, who came from Lespinasse, ran the kitchen for more than two years -- and earned two stars from The New York Times -- but then he left, too.

title: Trading in Lies, Some Informers Build Cases For Prosecutors
description: When a federal judge in Brooklyn overturned the gang-murder conviction of a Red Hook man in February because of perjury by government witnesses, he provided a rare glimpse of the murky world of prosecutors and their criminal informers. In exchange for information, prosecutors routinely offer leniency to killers, thieves and liars.

title: Sports of The Times; Mays Is There for Bonds But Won't Step on Toes
description: WILLIE MAYS is an icon. He may not be larger than baseball, but he looks at the game at eye level. He introduced a combination of style, sophistication and performance that has not been matched. But there are players today who feel that tradition is larger than icons -- even Mays.

title: Pile in Everybody, It's Road Trip Time, As Another Family Starts an Odyssey
description: As its title suggests, ''Johnson Family Vacation,'' which opens nationwide today, could be described as a family road-trip comedy in the weary tradition of the National Lampoon Vacation movies starring Chevy Chase. Unfortunately, this rendition, with the redoubtable Cedric the Entertainer in the put-upon patriarch role, feels more like a grueling road trip in search of a family comedy. Once the destination, a reunion in a small Missouri town, is finally reached, the movie loosens up a little, but not enough to make the cramped, bumpy ride worth it. ''When are we going to be there?'' you want to cry out, ''there'' meaning either a worthwhile joke or, failing that, the end credits.

WebMD, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., agreed to pay $40 million in cash and as much as $25 million more starting in April 2005, provided certain goals are met, the company said. Dakota Imaging, based in Columbia, Md., processes claims for Medicare in 21 states.

title: MGM TO RECOMMEND TO ITS BOARD AN $8-A-SHARE DIVIDEND

MGM, which is based in Los Angeles, will make its recommendation after the company completes refinancing of its credit line, which it expects to do by the end of the month, MGM said in an e-mail statement. Mr. Kerkorian and his company, the Tracinda Corporation of Las Vegas, which together own more than 174 million MGM shares, would receive about $1.39 billion. MGM had 235.4 million shares outstanding at the end of 2003.

You can go on to make mayonnaise classics, or deviled eggs with herbs or topped with caviar. You can even try recipes for seasoning the yolks with blue cheese, avocado, spinach and bacon, smoked salmon or chocolate.

title: Friends Missing in Action
description: Americans watching the frightening escalation of combat across Iraq must be asking themselves where, exactly, are our Iraqi friends? President Bush keeps assuring the public that the militias attacking the occupation forces represent a tiny, freedom-hating fringe. But that fringe is willing to take to the streets with guns, and none of Iraq's leaders are willing to stand up to them. If they are afraid to speak against the mob now, when they are flanked by American troops, what makes us believe they will behave more forcefully in the future, when the troops are gone and the mob is rising up against other Iraqis who don't share the same religion?

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: AIRPORT EVACUATED BECAUSE OF PACKAGE A 100-foot area in the South Terminal of Atlanta's international airport was evacuated for 2 hours and 15 minutes after a small suspicious package was found in a restroom, an airport spokeswoman said. A police bomb unit was called, and the package was rendered safe, though the authorities did not confirm whether it was an explosive. No flights were canceled, but some passengers were rebooked after they missed their flights because some ticketing stations were closed. The F.B.I. is investigating. Ariel Hart (NYT)

That may seem odd, because most solid-state L.E.D.'s are not noticeably hot. But Dan Nelson, the Enlux marketing director, said that was mainly because of how they are used.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, NATHAN L.
description: HALPERN--Nathan L. died April 3 at home. A man of strong, agile intellect, life long excellence, high achievement and significant contributions to the quality of life in New York City. He was independent, original and a true American success story. Through his company, Theatre Network Television, he was the USA pioneer and successful business developer of three major areas of television--the multi-city live interactive video conference; the use of large screen TV image magnification for audiences at meetings of all types and special events; and large screen TV presentations of live sports, with replays in major arenas. A tireless, effective Trustee for the Central Park Conservancy, he was proud of being part of and seeing the renaissance of Central Park; as recognition of his efforts, he was made a Life Trustee. He was a benefactor and member of the corporation of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He was president of the International Center of Photography during an important period of its development; and because of the results, he was made an Honorary Trustee. Born in Sioux City, Iowa to Aaron and Lena Halpern, who had emigrated from Russia, his family finally settled in Los Angeles. Graduating from Theodore Roosevelt High School, he was a top student as well as the basketball scoring leader for the City of Los Angeles. Receiving a scholarship to University of Southern California, he graduated in 1936 with Phi Beta Kappa honors, as well as being a member of three Pacific Conference champion basketball teams. He then came east to Harvard Law School where he was a member and Treasurer of the Law Review. To help with the publication's finances, he developed the idea of publishing volumes of previous years' editions and selling them to interested professionals--a successful venture. Upon graduation, he went as a young lawyer to Washington, D.C. as Assistant to the Chairman of the SEC. While working with the SEC he was given an additional duty to assist in the drafting of the Lend Lease. Then served as Executive Assistant to the Director of WPB 1941-42. During WWII as a Navy Officer, he became Executive Assistant to James Forrestal. Seeking an active role overseas, he became part of the Office of Strategic Services. He participated in the planning of D-Day in London. Executive Assistant to Director of US Information Services (France), he went behind German lines in Belgium and later had duties that brought him all the way through and behind the lines of the advancing Russian troops to start negotiating repatriation of whole populations in Europe. In the course of his OSS assignments, he met William S. Paley, President of CBS and some of the people who worked for him. After the war, he went to work for CBS from 1945-49, becoming Assistant to Mr. Paley during the period. As he learned more about the new medium of television. he developed an innovative concept of closed circuit television--the ''special origination, distribution and display of television to a special audience.'' He left CBS to form his own company. His work over the next 45 years included the first pay-TV events televised live to theatre audiences; the first satellite television telecasts to Europe (Telstar), Japan and China; ten national political conventions in which he was part of changing the entire nature of the televised event through new staging of the rostrum, preparing speakers for TV and special TV presentations for the audience; providing new national private network TV marketing communication for major US companies; designing and providing the high resolution large screen TV technology which NASA used for management of its rocket launches as well as extensive application for all the images from the moon during Apollo 11; breakthrough medical television techniques with live broadcasts from hospitals into major medical meetings involving patient case histories, treatment techniques and live surgeries; many of the biggest sports events and concerts; major meetings of associations, religious denominations, corporations; flight simulator displays and air traffic control. He loved East Hampton and the beach. He became a founding member and president of the East Hampton Beach Preservation Society and, true to form, became an expert as he researched the facts on beaches and erosion/ build up patterns. He was an avid landscaper and tree planter and created a beautiful environment at his home. A voracious reader, a fine eye and appreciation for art and a collector in various categories, a punster, he swam in the ocean and shot baskets regularly until age 85. He is predeceased by Edith, his loving wife of 63 years. He is survived by his son Michael, daughter-in-law Chris Grant and two grandsons. Funeral arrangements were private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Seagate Profit Misses Forecast
description: Shares of Seagate Technology, the maker of computer disk drives, fell as much as 17 percent yesterday after the company said third-quarter profit missed an already reduced forecast. Profit, excluding some items, was 6 cents to 8 cents a share in the quarter that ended April 2, Seagate said late Tuesday. It did not estimate net income or sales. Net income was 37 cents a share on sales of $1.62 billion a year earlier. Seagate, based in the Cayman Islands and run from Scotts Valley, Calif., said lower-than-expected sales of drives for notebook computers hurt results. Seagate shares fell 61 cents, to $14.98.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Currency Reserves Grow
description: Japan's foreign currency reserves rose to a record high of $827 billion in March as the financial authorities intervened heavily in currency markets to protect the nation's exporters. Japan's foreign currency reserves grew by $50 billion in March from $777 billion at the end of February, the ministry of finance said. Japan's foreign reserves have been growing rapidly as Tokyo has bought dollars and sold yen to contain a rise in the value of the Japanese currency that could threaten profits for exporters, which are powering Japan's recovery. Todd Zaun (NYT)

A score of agents now used to treat cancer, arthritis and autoimmune diseases are directed against these molecules. Their development is his intellectual legacy. It satisfies audiences, prodding their memories by playing exquisitely chosen old jazz and theater tunes and framing them with neat arrangements; occasionally it fills them with stupendous piano improvisation.

They left the house in sad disrepair when they moved out in the early 1970's, after which it sat vacant for more than a decade. During these years of neglect, the ceilings caved in, plaster walls crumbled and part of a stairwell collapsed. A sumac tree took root in the basement and raised its scrawny branches through the broken windows, searching for light.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Prime Minister In The Witness Box
description: After months of speculation about his possible appearance, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern testified in a long-running High Court corruption inquiry about his knowledge of Dublin's urban planning in the 1980's and 90's, when real estate developers often obtained zoning permits by bribing politicians. Mr. Ahern said he could not recall a 1989 meeting with a property developer who claims that Mr. Ahern's party demanded a bribe, but he acknowledged that it was possible that ''casual chit-chats'' had taken place. Mr. Ahern has not been directly accused of any wrongdoing, but prominent members of his party have been disgraced, and even imprisoned, through revelations at the tribunal. Nearly 300 people packed into Dublin Castle to hear Mr. Ahern's testimony. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Economic Forecast Cut
description: The European Commission reduced its economic growth forecast, saying risks to the recovery are increasing and warning that 6 of the 12 countries using the euro will break budget-deficit rules in 2004. France, Germany, Greece, Italy, the Netherlands and Portugal will surpass the deficit limit of 3 percent of gross domestic product, the commission said. Governments are struggling to control their budget gaps after growth slowed to a 10-year low of 0.4 percent in 2003. The commission pared its forecast for 2004 to 1.7 percent from 1.8 percent. ''We have to acknowledge the hard truth that the E.U. economy is not participating fully in the positive global economic performance,'' said the monetary affairs commissioner, Pedro Solbes, above.

title: Are There Any Iraqis In Iraq?
description: We are at a perilous juncture in Iraq. Two things are clear, and there's only one question left to be answered. What's clear is that there are no weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and there are no Viet Cong in Iraq. The key unanswered question is: Are there any Iraqis in Iraq? Is there a critical mass ready to identify themselves -- not as Shiites, Kurds and Sunnis -- but as Iraqis, who are ready to fight for the chance of self-determination for the Iraqi people as a whole?

title: In Positive Indicator, G.E. Reports Increased Earnings
description: The General Electric Company said this morning that its first quarter earnings rose, aided by a rebound in orders at some of its industrial units as well as recent acquisitions in businesses including health care and consumer finance.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadcom Buys Sand Video For $77.5 Million
description: The Broadcom Corporation, a maker of chips for electronics and computer networks, has acquired the closely held Sand Video Inc. for $77.5 million in cash and stock to add semiconductors that increase video-transmission volumes. Shares of Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., rose 14 cents, to $42.19.

title: OIL MARKETER SAYS TEXAS IS SCRUTINIZING PIPELINE DEAL
description: Plains All American Pipeline, a marketer of crude oil, said yesterday that the Texas attorney general was investigating its purchase of Link Energy's oil pipeline operations on concern that the transaction would thwart competition. The state attorney general's office indicated that the investigation was prompted by complaints about the potential impact on competition in the Permian Basin in West Texas, Plains said in a regulatory filing. A spokesman for the attorney general declined to comment or to confirm the investigation. Plains bought 3,100 miles of crude oil pipelines from Link Energy, terminals able to store 3.4 million barrels of oil and 200 trucks for $273 million last week.

title: Cut-Rate Calling, By Way of the Net
description: EVERY time an important piece of our lives goes electronic, much is gained, but something is lost, too. Audiophiles say that compact discs don't sound as warm as vinyl records. Home theaters are neat, but don't offer the communal fun of a movie theater crowd. And no matter how efficient e-mail may be, it can't touch the joy of receiving a handwritten letter on fine stationery, thoughtfully composed and concluding with the words ''check enclosed.''

title: Push Is On to Give Legal Immigrants A Vote in the City
description: At first glance, it may seem a long shot in an era of orange alerts and stepped-up border patrols. But quietly and carefully, elected officials, labor unions and community groups are starting to push the notion of allowing legal immigrants who are not United States citizens to vote in New York City elections.

description: Electronic Arts, the world's largest maker of video games, announced late Wednesday that John Riccitiello, the company's president and chief operating officer, had resigned effective immediately.

description: BNP Paribas, the French banking giant, said yesterday that it had fired Edward V. Canale, head of its asset workout unit in New York, after the Manhattan district attorney began investigating accusations of improper banking practices.
