title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Genentech Profit Rises On Cancer Drug Sales
description: Genentech said yesterday that first-quarter net income rose 17 percent, lifted by revenue from its leading cancer medicines as sales of a new drug, Avastin, exceeded investor expectations. Net income climbed to $176.6 million, or 33 cents a share, from $151.5 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue jumped 30 percent, to $975.1 million. Shares of Genentech, which is majority owned by the Swiss drug maker Roche Holding and is based in South San Francisco, Calif., rose as much as $4.65, to $113.10, in after-hours trading. In regular trading, the shares fell $1.75, to $108.45.

description: On Tuesday, an adoring state and the University of Connecticut campus paid homage to the men's national championship basketball team.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER SAYS '04 PROFIT WILL RISE SLIGHTLY
description: DaimlerChrysler said yesterday that it still expected 2004 profit to rise slightly, held back by losses at its Mitsubishi Motors affiliate and the cost of introducing new models. Net income will grow from last year's 448 million euros ($541 million) as the Chrysler unit returns to profitability, the carmaker said at the annual shareholders' meeting in Berlin, reiterating a forecast from February. DaimlerChrysler is helping put together a reorganization of Mitsubishi Motors, in which it has a 37 percent stake. Chrysler is expected to become profitable on the strength of new models.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: White Man Accuses Agency Of Bias
description: A white man who works for the Federal Aviation Administration has accused the agency of discrimination in a federal lawsuit that is scheduled to go to trial at the end of this month. The employee, Michael C. Ryan, is a computer specialist at the agency's William J. Hughes Technical Center in Atlantic City. In his complaint, first filed in 1999, he says he was unfairly passed over for eight promotions between 1995 and 1997. In one instance, he had trained the successful candidate, a black woman who had 13 years less experience. Mr. Ryan also says that some of the promotions were made simply to fulfill affirmative action quotas for minorities and women. An F.A.A. spokesman declined to comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Kerry Says His Economic Plan Calls for Federal Spending Caps and Clinton-Era Rules
description: Laying out a sweeping economic strategy to counter the nation's rising deficits, Senator John Kerry said Wednesday that as president he would impose caps on government spending. He also said he would adopt rules that guided former President Bill Clinton in creating what Mr. Kerry called the most prosperous era in American history.

title: Rodriguez Handles the Pressure at the Hot Corner
description: He had tried to prepare himself for any situation. That was the point of all those buckets of grounders and all that instruction from coaches. Alex Rodriguez would be new to third base, but he could still be comfortable.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tax Preparers Criticized
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller, left, criticized the city's Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday, saying that it had failed to enforce legislation that requires tax-preparation services to inform their customers about hidden fees and interest charges. Speaker Miller and fellow Council members Eric Gioia and Diana Reyna, called for stronger enforcement. ''People are still being taken advantage of,'' Mr. Miller said. Dina Improta, a spokeswoman for the Department of Consumer Affairs, responded that the city had ''effectively and vigorously enforced the law to protect consumers and will continue to do so.'' Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Accord On Disabled Students
description: Just three weeks after several disabled Alaska children and their parents filed a federal class-action lawsuit charging that the state's high school exit exam discriminated against those with disabilities, Alaska has agreed to allow all students with disabilities in the class of 2004 to graduate, whether or not they have passed the exam, as long as they meet all other graduation requirements. In addition, the state agreed to negotiate with the plaintiffs in the case to find some way to keep the exit exam from being an unsurmountable barrier for disabled students in future classes. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: A Haven for the Data Pack Rat

But Xdrive, an online data storage service in Santa Monica, Calif., that started in 1999, has evolved, its officials say, offering space on its servers for secure data backup.

title: Magazine Names Editor
description: DEBORAH NEEDLEMAN, an editor at large at House & Garden magazine, has been named the editor in chief of a new home dcor magazine to be introduced next year by Cond Nast Publications, the company announced yesterday. Ms. Needleman, 40, is married to Jacob Weisberg, the editor of Slate. Cond Nast, which publishes House & Garden and Architectural Digest, created considerable interest in announcing the yet to be titled magazine, a shopping guide to decorating. It is one of several new home magazines scheduled to appear in the next year, including Happy Home, an American Media publication. ''The market is a very different place now,'' Ms. Needleman said of the influence of the Internet on shopping, and younger, newly house-proud buyers.

title: In Google We Trust? When the Subject Is E-Mail, Maybe Not
description: AT first, people thought it was an April Fool's joke last week when Google, the search-engine leader, announced plans to offer a free Web-based e-mail service.

title: Kabul Orders Troops to Quell Latest Violence
description: For the second time in two weeks, President Hamid Karzai is sending newly trained Afghan National Army troops from the capital to quell fighting in outlying regions, this time in northern Afghanistan, government officials said.

title: To Do Its Thing, a Door Needs That Swing
description: SINCE the 1970's, doors have been as popular as traffic jams. Bent on acquiring the loftlike virtues of light and air, a generation of renovators has ripped out doors and demolished halls. And what did they get in return for all that destruction?

description: Consumer borrowing rose $4.2 billion in February, less than expected and the smallest increase in three months, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, ARTHUR M.
description: SOLOMON--Arthur M., age 70. Attorney, actor and concerned citizen, on April 7 at home in Wilmette, IL. Attended James Madison High School in Brooklyn; received bachelor and law degrees from University of Chicago. Lieutenant U.S. Navy 1955-1958; 35 year partner in the Chicago firm Solomon & Behrendt. Beloved and adoring husband of Lois Adelman; cherished father of Adam Solomon and Elizabeth Hubbard; loving brother of Mimi Sheraton; devoted father-inlaw of Jeff Hubbard and proud grandfather of four; admired brother-in-law of Richard Falcone and uncle of Marc Falcone. May he sleep the sleep of the just. Memorial to be announced.

title: Waterfront Neighborhoods Seek Relief From Trash Burden
description: A group representing waterfront neighborhoods outside Manhattan urged officials yesterday to rebuild city transfer stations that ship waste by water. It wants the city to then close some of the stations that it says overburden these communities.

title: Rice Defends Administration's Performance Before 9/11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  President Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, defended the administration's performance on terrorism today, insisting that Mr. Bush understood the deadly threat posed by Al Qaeda terrorists from his first days in office.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 23 about the Bush administration's assertion that solid progress was being made in wiping out the Andean region's coca crops described the eradication efforts in Peru and Bolivia incorrectly. Only ground operations are used there; aerial spraying is limited to Colombia. ( Go to Article )

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about unusual ways some families find to bring the themes of Passover to life at seder observances misidentified maror, a traditional seder food. It is a bitter herb, not a paste typically made of apples, nuts and grape juice or wine. (That is charoset.)

title: Mortgage Index Declines
description: An index of mortgage applications fell for a third consecutive week as mortgage rates jumped the most in eight months and refinancing slowed by the most since early December, an industry group said.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a couple's quest for a quiet apartment in New York misstated the price of soundproofing windows by Cityproof. They are $2,900 each, not $3,900.

title: Australia Feeling Nervous as Its Dollar Soars
description: It is usually the brightly colored polymer bills, with their holographic markings, that make the Australian dollar stand out in a currency crowd. But the volatile ''Aussie'' has grabbed more than aesthetic attention recently after a breakneck rise against its American counterpart -- a rise that has this nation's exporters shuddering.

title: The (Space for Sale) Yankees
description: The information age uses the phrase ''dead space'' to describe surfaces -- on buildings, Web sites and elsewhere -- where no advertising has yet been posted and nothing is being sold. Americans have grown accustomed to this line of thinking, and to the corporate impulse to fill every salable space with brand names. But Major League Baseball crossed an emotional line recently when the venerable New York Yankees showed up in Japan wearing uniforms festooned with the logo of a company that makes photocopiers.

title: A Mix-and-Match Program Makes Spreadsheets Portable
description: SoftMaker, a German software company, will soon offer a full-featured spreadsheet program that bean counters can use no matter where they may be.

title: A Blacklist For Renters
description: IMAGINE finding the perfect apartment, only to learn that the landlord is denying you the place because you are on a blacklist of supposedly high-risk renters. Nothing is wrong with your credit rating, but your name showed up on the list because a private screening service found it in housing court records about a dispute you had with a previous landlord -- a dispute that was resolved in your favor.

title: Rice Questioners May Avoid Partisanship
description: The leaders of the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks urged the panel's members on Wednesday to try to avoid partisanship in their public questioning of Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, whose long-awaited sworn testimony could alter the public's view of her, the Bush administration and the commission itself, panel officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 18 about Thomas Jefferson's garden misstated his residence in 1793, when he was secretary of state and received a letter from a daughter about the condition of his garden at Monticello. He was living in Philadelphia, not Washington.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Afghan Killed As Youths Attack Foreigners
description: A mob of about 50 youths rampaged through a marketplace in Volgograd attacking dark-skinned people and killing one man from Afghanistan, the Itar-Tass news agency reported. It appeared to be the latest in a string of racist attacks that have included the killing of an African student in Voronezh, an Afghan doctor in Moscow and a 9-year-old girl from Tajikistan who was knifed to death in St. Petersburg. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Yankees Trial Is Law Lite, an Unreal Stab at Reality TV
description: It was legal silliness, to be sure, ESPN's mock trial yesterday of the Yankees on charges of tilting baseball's competitive balance, which will be shown tonight. There was no indictment -- had there been one, it would have been one charge of guilt by profligacy -- no grand jury, no voir dire of the jurors, no voluminous charge to the jury by ESPN Superior Court Judge Catherine Crier (once a real judge, now a Court TV host). No defendant sat beside Bruce Cutler, once John Gotti's lawyer, whose defense by adoration of the Yankees would have made George Steinbrenner kvell.

title: Back on Clay, Williams Swiftly Defeats Pierce
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., April 7  Serena Williams, coming off a tournament victory last week, was her typically dominating self on Wednesday night in her first match of the Bausch & Lomb Championships at Amelia Island Plantation.

title: Accounts
description: Mervyn's department stores, Hayward, Calif., owned by the Target Corporation, to Wong Doody, Los Angeles and Seattle, to create television commercials that are to start running April 19. This is the first time Wong Doody is working for Mervyn's, which works with various agencies on a project basis. Spending has not been determined.

title: John Kerry, Fiscal Conservative
description: Yesterday at Georgetown University, Senator John Kerry delivered a forceful speech on the virtues of responsible budgeting. On top of his recent nuanced proposals on corporate taxes, Mr. Kerry's performance suggested he is starting to hit his stride in thinking and talking about the economy.

title: Dozen Composers, 4 Pianists And a Contemporary Crowd
description: The Piano Mega Concert at Cooper Union on Thursday night was not mega-long, just over two hours. But it was certainly mega-intense. Four formidable pianists, all champions of contemporary music, played 12 solo works from the last 30 years. Except for a couple of works that offered timeouts from the intensity, like Eric Moe's ruminative ''When Branched Thoughts Murmur in the Wind,'' tenderly played by Marc Ponthus, the pieces performed were steely, piercingly atonal, dauntingly complex and mega-difficult.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARF, DAVID J.
description: SHARF--David J. On April 7, 2004. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Stephanie Sharf and Rhonda Pomphrey. Cherished grandfather of Brian Pomphrey. Loving brother of Irving and Arthur Sharf and Natalie Rosen. Graveside services Thursday, 2 PM, at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWNER, HENRY L.
description: DOWNER--Henry L., on April 5 after a long illness, in Morristown, NJ. A gentleman of fortitude. Devoted husband of the late Irene Biedron Downer, and father of Gregory of Manhattan and Diane of Williston, VT. Memorial service to be announced.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 2 More Suspects Held In Madrid Attacks
description: A High Court judge ordered two more Moroccan men detained on charges related to the Madrid train attacks on March 11. The detention of the men, Rachid Adli and Abdelilah Fouad, brought the number of suspects in custody to 17, 13 of them of Moroccan descent.

title: Sunni-Shiite Cooperation Grows, Worrying U.S. Officials
description: BAGHDAD, April 8  The convoy chugged into the mosque today with signature black Shiite flags flapping from the pickup trucks. Carried in back were sacks of grain, flour, sugar and rice. And gallons of tomato juice, crates of oranges, vats of cooking oil and boxes of powdered milk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHEEL, LESLEY
description: WHEEL--Lesley 75 on April 1, 2004. Ms. Wheel was a remarkable, generous, articulate, truly great aunt who cherished her nephews, grand nephews, nieces-in-law and beloved friends. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1949, trained originally in Theater Lighting and production, was the first woman to practice full time in architectural lighting design. Her career was studded with award-winning projects for hotels world wide. She was co-founder of the firm WheelGaron (later Wheel-Gertsztoff) in 1961. Ms. Wheel was a founding member, past president and Fellow of the International Association of Lighting Designers. May 2004 memorial services are planned in both New York City and Los Angeles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUROFF, DR. MELVIN
description: MUROFF--Dr. Melvin, on April 7, 2004. Longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY, dearly beloved husband, father and uncle, survived by his wife Blanche and son Ivor. He was a psychotherapist devoted to his practice over 60 years with the highest principles and utmost integrity. He completed his training at the Menninger Clinic and was a member of a number of associations including the Topeka Psychoanalytic Institute and the American Orthopsychiatric Association. He was an author, editor and teacher whose focus was on child development and group dynamics. We will never stop missing him. Services will be held at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY (914-381-1809) Friday April 9, 2004 at 10AM.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Officer Hit By Car
description: A police officer was seriously injured last night when she was hit by a car in Harlem, the authorities said. The officer, whose name was not immediately released, was struck about 9:30 p.m. while she and a sergeant were struggling with the driver of a scooter on 125th Street near St. Nicholas Avenue. A black Nissan Sentra hit the officer, breaking both her legs. The officer was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where she was later reported in serious condition. The sergeant had minor injuries. The scooter driver escaped. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Iraqi Uprising Spreads; Rumsfeld Sees It as 'Test of Will'
description: The Iraqi uprising against the American-led occupation intensified Wednesday and spread to new parts of the country, with United States forces increasing their efforts to put down Sunni and Shiite combatants.

title: For a Week In the Bronx, Not One Shot Is Reported
description: Ten years ago, at least 30 shots were fired during a single week in the Bronx, killing 12 people. On a single day in that week, 40 minutes apart, two men were shot and killed within a few miles of each other.

title: Capturing Little Dramas With a Click; Helen Levitt's Pictures Speak for Themselves
description: You might get the wrong impression about Helen Levitt from her photographs. They are dying to talk. She is not. She lives in a fifth-floor walk-up in Greenwich Village. Miss Levitt, who is 90, says she is working on ''books.'' Of what? ''Of my pictures.'' She is assembling a collection of her color photography that will probably be called ''Slide Show.'' Which does she prefer, color or black-and-white? ''Whatever roll of film I have, that's what I'll shoot.''

title: Giants Trying to Trade Up As N.F.L. Draft Approaches
description: Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi confirmed last night that he had spoken with Chargers General Manager A. J. Smith about a potential trade for San Diego's No. 1 pick in this month's N.F.L. draft, but that the talks are preliminary and the Giants have not made an offer.

title: Princeton Tries To Put a Cap On Giving A's
description: Aiming to halt widespread grade inflation afflicting Ivy League colleges, Princeton University officials are proposing to limit the number of A's that its professors award.

title: Prosecution Argues Case For No Retrial Of Stewart
description: A campaign that Martha Stewart's lawyers have started to discredit a juror in her case should not be the basis for a new trial or even for a hearing into the juror's background, prosecutors wrote in a brief filed yesterday.

title: U. S. Taiwan Expert Quits; Reason Is Disputed
description: The top American diplomat in the office responsible for relations with Taiwan resigned abruptly on Wednesday, after reports that the Chinese government had complained that she was overly sympathetic to the Taiwan government.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tycoon's Trial Is Next Week
description: Lawyers for Platon Lebedev, one of the largest shareholders in the oil giant Yukos, said his trial would begin April 15. He was arrested in July. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

description: Lea Fastow, the wife of Enron's former chief financial officer, withdrew her guilty plea on criminal tax charges yesterday after a federal judge announced that he would not abide by the terms of her agreement with the government.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CYPRUS: LEADERS REJECT UNITY PLAN Both the Greek Cypriot leader, Tassos Papadopoulos, and the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Dentkash, condemned the United Nations plan to reunify the island before it enters the European Union on May 1 and urged voters to reject it in referendums on April 24. Mr. Papadopoulos, left, said the plan would threaten the security of citizens by disbanding the Greek Cypriot army. Earlier, Mr. Denktash said he would campaign for a "no" vote in the northern Turkish third of the island, a breakaway state recognized internationally only by Turkey and occupied by 40,000 Turkish troops. He made it clear that he believed the plan would spell an end to that state. Under the plan, Cyprus would become a loose federation. If voters on either side reject the referendums, only the Greek Cypriot south will be represented in the European Union. Polls have pointed to a rejection by Greek Cypriots and approval by Turkish Cypriots by a thin majority. (Reuters)

title: OMAN'S OIL YIELD LONG IN DECLINE, SHELL DATA SHOW
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group's oil production in Oman has been declining for years, belying the company's optimistic reports and raising doubts about a vital question in the Middle East: whether new technology can extend the life of huge but mature oil fields.

title: Adelphia Witness Tells of Payouts to Founder
description: John Rigas, the founder of the Adelphia Communications Corporation, received cash advances of $50 million approved by his son Timothy, who tried to limit his father to $1 million a month, a former treasury supervisor told jurors yesterday in federal court in New York.

title: MEXICAN LINE REVIVES TALKS WITH KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN
description: Kansas City Southern said yesterday that Grupo TMM, parent of Mexico's biggest railroad, had agreed to discuss reviving a disputed transaction that would give Kansas City Southern control of the railroad. The companies temporarily halted their legal dispute to try to work out differences over the transaction, which called for TMM to sell Kansas City Southern its 43 percent stake in the railroad, Grupo TFM, for $412 million, a Kansas City Southern spokesman, Warren Erdman, said. The deal was announced in April 2003, but TMM said in August that it had terminated the deal after its shareholders rejected the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ERLANGER, MARTIN S.
description: ERLANGER--Martin S. On April 6th. Devoted husband of the late Beth Amy Posner Erlanger. Beloved father of Dr. Steven M. Erlanger, Thomas N. Erlanger and Barbara E. Kaplan. Also survived by six grandchildren, two nieces and one nephew. Dear brother of the late Benjamin F. Erlanger. Funeral services today in Stamford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FETT, HERBERT C., JR., MD
description: FETT--Herbert C., Jr., MD, on April 7, 2004, of Cutchogue, NY, Stuart, FL, and formerly of Garden City, NY. Lt. Cmdr. in WWII-USN. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth A. (Hickey). Loving father of Michael E. Clavin, Elizabeth A. Kane, Herbert C. Fett III, Robert C. Fett, Peter J. Fett, Marie A. Hill and Patricia H. D'Antonio, and father-in-law of Maia H. Clavin, Thomas Kane, Audrey M. Fett, Mary Ellen Fett, Randy Hill and Thomas D'Antonio. Cherished grandfather of 13 grandchildren and greatgrandfather of 4 great grandchildren. Dear brother of Doris Murphy, Edna Drake, Marie Louise Phillips, Philip Fett and the late Jeanne McKenna. Dr. Fett was a member of the Knights of Malta and member of the Faculty of the American College of Surgeons. He was on staff at Mercy Medical Center, Winthrop University Hospital and Nassau University Medical Center for 25 years and was Chief of Orthopedic Surgery at Mercy Medical Center for 12 years. Dr. Fett was a graduate of Williams College, Temple University School of Medicine and the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Medicine. He was an avid golfer and Long Island Lacrosse supporter. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 and 7-9pm Saturday. Mass St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10am Monday, April 12. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations to St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, NY.

title: Okayama Journal; Love Peeks Through Elder Japan's Curtain of Reserve
description: It was garbage day here in the suburbs of western Japan. The middle-aged husband prepared to walk the block between the couple's two-story house to the curb. Anything else to toss out?

description: Yet another makeover is being proposed for Long Island's electricity supply system, which for decades has been a focus of notoriety and multibillion-dollar problems that prompted interventions by Govs. Mario M. Cuomo and George E. Pataki.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENDIXEN, HENRIK H.
description: BENDIXEN--Henrik H. The faculty and staff of the Department of Anesthesiology of Columbia University Medical Center mourn the death of our beloved former chairman, Dr. Henrik H. Bendixen. He served as chair of our department from 1973 to 1985 and during that time was pivotal in building the clinical excellence of the department, especially in intensive care. In 1993, we were proud to honor Dr. Bendixen with the creation of an endowed professorship in his name. He was a source of strength and integrity to his faculty and he will be sadly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Margaret Wood, M.D. E.M. Papper Professor and Chair, Department of Anesthesiology Columbia University

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sale Of Baby Walkers Banned
description: Canada became the first country to ban the sale, importation or advertisement of baby walkers because of concerns that babies who are put in them can fall down stairs and reach dangerous objects when out of the sight of their parents or guardians. Since 1989 there has been a voluntary industry ban on the walkers -- a frame and seat on a wheeled base intended for children who are sitting up but not yet walking -- but government health officials have reported that the product has recently made a comeback. The Canadian Pediatric Society applauded the ban. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

It was 29, plus the District of Columbia, not 41.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Arrest In Smuggling Case
description: A man the authorities have described as a central figure in an immigrant smuggling case in which 19 people died last May has been arrested and charged in Mexico, possibly preventing his prosecution in the United States, officials said. The man, Victor Rodriguez, an American citizen formerly of Brownsville, is among 14 defendants in the case, in which the illegal immigrants died of heat exhaustion or suffocation when abandoned in Victoria, Tex., inside a sealed transport truck. Michael T. Shelby, the United States attorney in Houston, said he would not agree in advance to a prison sentence of less than 30 years for Mr. Rodriguez. Mr. Shelby said Mexican officials typically required such an agreement before extraditing a defendant to the United States. Steve Barnes

Robertson, said overseas lawsuits by Microsoft that challenge the company's name would force Lindows to adopt a new name for Europe and other foreign markets. description: Jason Kidd woke up Wednesday and felt no pain in his left knee. Kenyon Martin arose in his home and found no stiffness or pain in his left knee. title: For Those With Green Thumbs And Pocket-Size Apartments
description: Urban gardeners with little or no outdoor space can find suitable materials at GRDN, a brand-new store in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. GRDN came to be when Susanne Kongoy, a professional chef, moved to the area and needed accouterments for her 5-by-8-foot terrace. Finding no nearby source, she set up shop herself, stocking apartment- and pocket-garden-size topiaries, olive trees, potted bulbs and seeds that can, with proper light, be grown indoors or out. Handsome terra cotta pots from Guy Wolff and Company (above left) are $20 to $88.

title: Economic Scene; Stock options are still a gamble, but the size of the pot may soon be clearer.
description: THE Financial Accounting Standards Board published its long-anticipated statement about options accounting last week, and as expected it recommended that options grants to employees be counted as an expense in corporate financial statements. Barring any last-minute changes, this will probably become a requirement of the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2005.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Heat Death Ruled Accidental
description: Constance Wallace-Lloyd, a disabled Brooklyn woman who was found dead in her bed on Sunday after a steam pipe burst beneath her apartment, died of hyperthermia caused by the extreme heat of the steam, the authorities said yesterday. Ms. Wallace-Lloyd lived in a first-floor apartment in the Bay View Houses, a 23-building public housing complex in Canarsie. She used a wheelchair and had multiple sclerosis, a condition that also contributed to her death, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner's office, which ruled the death accidental. The Housing Authority said the steam pipe that burst was part of a 50-year-old heating system that had been scheduled, even before the accident Sunday, for replacement this summer. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

I expected, "Hey, get back to writing about palmtops"-but received instead some of the most thoughtful questions and commentary ever.

title: VERIZON WIRELESS TO MOVE 1,700 CUSTOMER-SERVICE JOBS
description: Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it planned to move 1,700 customer-service jobs in Orangeburg, N.Y., and Morristown, N.J., to two bigger call centers by the end of the year. One new call center will be in Wilmington, N.C. The location of the second will be announced this year, Verizon Wireless said. The company, owned by Verizon Communications and the Vodafone Group, is offering workers a $10,000 incentive to move. The size of the new centers will allow Verizon Wireless to add about 500 customer-service jobs and reduce the need to hire outside contractors to handle call overflow, a spokesman said. Verizon Wireless plans to close its Morristown office and spend $10 million to expand the Orangeburg office's data center operation.

title: GOODYEAR TO BUY OUT PARTNER IN SLOVENIAN TIRE VENTURE
description: Goodyear Tire and Rubber said yesterday that it was buying out its partner in a venture in Slovenia for $52 million. Goodyear said it would exercise an option to buy the remaining 20 percent stake in the venture, Sava Tires, from Sava D.D. Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, bought 60 percent of the tire company, which is based in Kranj, Slovenia, in 1998 and increased the investment to 80 percent in 2002. Sava produced about seven million tires last year for passenger and commercial vehicles, exporting more than 80 percent to customers in 70 countries, Goodyear said.

description: BOSTON, April 8 - Denver had been swept by Minnesota-Duluth during the regular season and was behind by 3-1 in the third period when it scored two goals in 34 seconds and went on to a 5-3 victory, advancing to college hockey's championship game.

description: Olmec Systems, a computer network company in Denville, N.J., was conceived in 1996 by two co-workers complaining over beers about working for somebody else.

title: F.C.C. Fines Clear Channel Over Howard Stern Broadcast
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it intended to fine Clear Channel Communications , the radio giant, nearly $500,000 for indecent statements about anal sex and other sexual activities that were broadcast on an installment of "The Howard Stern Show" last April. The fines are to be levied on six stations owned by Clear Channel that broadcast the program, and Clear Channel responded by permanently removing Mr. Stern's program from those stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLBERT, DOROTHY K. (NEE KATZ)
description: COLBERT--Dorothy K. (nee Katz), 81, of Palm Beach, FL and Cleveland, OH, died April 7, 2004. She was the beloved wife of Ralph. Devoted mother of Michael and Jan and Loving grandmother of Lauren and Marcus. title: 1929:Decimal Causes Death : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: LONDON: The strange story of how a misplaced decimal point led to the death of three young brothers was told at an inquest at Wembley today [April 8]. The boys, the eldest of who was ten, died shortly after they had been taken to the London Skin Hospital for treatment for ringworm. On their arrival at the hospital, the examining physician prescribed the rare drug thallium acetate, and he made his prescription out according to the metric system of weights. Consequently, it was necessary for the hospital pharmacist to convert the metric numbers to the apothecary system, not using metric weights but scales. In doing so she misplaced the decimal point, thus increasing the dose tenfold. Administration of the medicine had almost immediate fatal results, death occurring before the attendants realized or could determine the cause.

Preservationists and energetic officials have worked to restore buildings to their 19th-century splendor and to build a collection of attractions celebrating the city's rich history. The companies will close the transaction on April 30, DuPont said. The companies previously said they would finish by June 30. The new price includes debt assumption and certain joint venture and equity interests, DuPont said. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., announced in November the sale of the 18,000-employee Invista unit, in part to cut spending on high-priced petroleum products used to make synthetic fibers. Invista is the biggest maker of nylon, including Stainmaster carpet and Lycra brands.

title: National Briefing: West

The agreement was filed in federal court in Los Angeles after a year of negotiations between the California Transportation Department, or Caltrans, and two environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council and Santa Monica BayKeeper. Storm water runoff is the largest source of coastal water pollution, and highways serve to collect and channel pollutants, including toxic particles from tires, oil and grease. David Beckman, director of the resources council's Coastal Water Quality Project, said the agreement could ultimately cut 80 percent of the pollution. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Heading for the Chorus Line, Intertwining Fact and Fiction
description: ''Showboy,'' a clever hide-and-seek game of reality versus fiction, reveals itself as not the movie you thought it was when the final credits roll and its production notes have been consulted. Ostensibly a documentary portrait of Christian Taylor, a screenwriter and producer of the Home Box Office series ''Six Feet Under,'' the movie turns his pursuit of his childhood dream of becoming a Las Vegas dancer into documentary-style semifiction in which any notion of the truth is contaminated.

title: Security Firm Says Its Workers Were Lured Into Iraqi Ambush
description: At first, their gruesome deaths seemed the work of yet another random ambush in Iraq, this one made unforgettable by images of incensed Iraqis celebrating the sight of charred corpses swinging from a bridge over the Euphrates River.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Accenture Names New Chief Executive
description: Accenture said yesterday that it had named William D. Green to succeed Joe W. Forehand as chief executive. Mr. Green, 50, left, one of Accenture's two chief operating officers, will take over on Sept. 1, said a spokeswoman, Roxanne Taylor. Accenture, a consulting and computer-services company based in Hamilton, Bermuda, said March 30 that Mr. Forehand, 55, would step down as chief executive and remain chairman. Mr. Green steps into the role as Accenture prepares to hire 30,000 people and on the heels of a 17 percent sales increase in the second quarter. Mr. Forehand pushed the company into services like managing computer systems and call centers as growth slowed in its traditional consulting business. Shares of Accenture rose 10 cents, to $25.24. On March 30, Mr. Forehand said the company planned to hire 30,000 people worldwide this year. Mr. Green said 8,000 of those workers would be in the United States and that 15,000 of the 30,000 had been hired.

description: HERSHEY FOODS plans to announce Monday that it will soon blanket Spanish-language television, radio and magazines with ads for its chocolates and candies, becoming the latest big marketer to try spreading its reach in the fast-growing Hispanic market.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Strong economic growth pushed Australia's unemployment rate in March to its lowest in 14 years, according to new data. The Bureau of Statistics said the economy added 66,900 jobs in March, pushing seasonally adjusted unemployment down to 5.6 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Nuclear Plant Settles Fish-Kill Accusation
description: The operator of the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant has agreed to pay $1 million to settle criminal and civil allegations that the Lacey Township plant discharged lethally hot water into a neighboring creek, killing thousands of fish, officials said yesterday. In 2002, during a maintenance operation, the company, AmerGen Energy, shut down a transformer that helps cool hot water before it reaches the creek. The released water was 101 degrees Fahrenheit, or 14 degrees hotter than legally permitted. Nearly 6,000 fish and other wildlife were killed, including stripped bass, white perch and oysters. The state's Department of Environmental Protection said the settlement included an estuary-monitoring program that posts on the Internet the current temperature of nearby Barnegat Bay. Ann Mary Carley, a spokeswoman for AmerGen, said the company took ''full responsibility'' for the incident. She blamed the situation on ''miscommunications.'' Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Home Sweet Hangar
description: SHORTLY after 9:30 a.m., the first plane comes screeching in a four-seat Mooney 201 with orange and brown pinstripes. It taxis tentatively down the runway before coming to a stop in front of a large concrete berm. Then the pilot, Joe Colonna, shuts off the engine, climbs out of the cockpit and plops down $25 for brunch.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Oil Stake Sold
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it would sell its 50 percent stake in an Angola offshore project to India's largest government-run oil and gas company, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation, for about $600 million. Shell is under pressure to increase reserves after the company said in January that its proven oil and gas supplies were 20 percent lower than originally reported. A Shell spokesman characterized the sale of the stake in the Angola project, which is expected to produce oil by 2007, as routine portfolio management. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: In the days leading up to his Mets debut, Scott Erickson reminisced about all the other times he was pitching for a new team in a new season, and all the other times he was coming back from an injury that was supposed to finish him.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Canada lost 13,300 jobs in March for the biggest two-month loss in three years, strengthening expectations that the Bank of Canada will cut interest rates next week to help the economy. The unemployment rate rose to 7.5 percent from 7.4 percent in February, Statistics Canada said. Canada's economy gave up 21,200 jobs in February, the first decline since August and the biggest one-month loss since December 2001.

title: Russia Weighs Tax Shift Toward Oil Sector
description: In an effort to shift the tax burden toward big business, the government of Russia on Thursday put forward a package of proposals that would raise tax rates moderately on the oil sector and would lower payroll taxes.

title: F.C.C. to Fine Clear Channel $495,000 For Sex Talk
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that it intended to fine the radio giant Clear Channel Communications $495,000 for statements about anal sex and other sexual activities that were broadcast on Howard Stern's radio show last April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELVENSTON, STEPHEN SCOTTEN
description: HELVENSTON -- Stephen Scotten, 38, died in Iraq on Wednesday, March 31, 2004. Born in Ocala, FL, he was preceded in death by his father Harry Stephen Helvenston, grandparents Donald Root Scotten and Mary Lu McLeod, and grandparents, Harry and L'Ouida Helvenston and Everett Wettengel. Residing in San Diego, California for the past 15 years he is survived by his mother Katy Helvenston - Wettengel of Leesburg, FL, a brother Jason Helvenston with fiance Jennifer Preiss of Orlando, FL, a son Kyle Jacob, a daughter Kelsey Erin and their mother Patricia Irby of San Diego, CA. He is also survived by Sybil Cross, Sheryl Lybbert, Donald Scotten, Mary Clare Scotten, and Paul Scotten. Scott was a supportive and devoted father to his two wonderful children, Kyle and Kelsey. Scott served with the USN SEALs team for 12 years and was a World Champion Pentathlete. Scott lost his life heroically serving his country. He leaves behind many friends and family that will miss him deeply. Scott's excitement, zest, and true love for living life to the fullest overflowed onto everything and every one. We can only hope that this moment in history can make a difference in the world. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to: Kyle and Kelsey Helvenston Memorial Fund, P.O. Box #

description: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has unexpectedly suspended plans for a massive dam system on the Nu River in western China that scientists have warned could ruin one of the country's last unspoiled places, according to news reports in China and Hong Kong.

As David (David Wissack), a gaunt, sharp-featured young American, and his beautiful French-speaking Russian girlfriend, Katia (Katia Golubeva), explore the sullen landscape in and around Joshua Tree National Park, an inane little ditty, sung in Japanese, chirps annoyingly on the car's sound system.

Blended with Bruce Willis's dry, threatening assurance, Matthew Perry's neurotic, stammering pratfalls made a rosy Cosmopolitan. title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Move Seen As Leader's Power Ploy Fails
description: With much shouting and throwing of things, the opposition in Parliament won a round in pre-election jockeying by defeating a proposed constitutional amendment that would have weakened future presidents and strengthened Parliament. The change would have meant that the incumbent president, Leonid Kuchma, would retain significant power -- whether he wins or loses this fall -- through a Parliament he controls. Mr. Kuchma, who is serving his second term, won a round in December when the Constitutional Court ruled that he could evade a two-term limit and run again. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Long Prison Terms for 2 Men In Brooklyn Gang Murder
description: A federal judge yesterday gave long prison sentences to two men he said lied in their testimony in a gang murder trial last year after having won promises of leniency for cooperating with prosecutors.

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Troops Kill Militant Leader
description: Soldiers killed a top commander of the militant group Abu Sayyaf and five other rebels in a firefight on the island of Basilan, the government said. The commander was indicted in 2002 for kidnappings that led to the death of two hostages, including the Kansas missionary Martin Burnham. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Study Advises Against Drugs For Children In Depression
description: Pediatricians and family physicians should not prescribe antidepressants for depressed children and adolescents because the drugs barely work and their side effects are often significant, Australian researchers have concluded.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: 63 Die Of Hunger In Country's Second City
description: Crop failures and acute food shortages caused by Zimbabwe's collapsing economy caused 48 children and 15 adults to die of hunger-related causes last month in Bulawayo, the nation's second-largest city, a city health official told the newspaper The Zimbabwe Independent. Zimbabwe has been acutely short of food, medicine and health care workers in recent months, and the United Nations, which has asked governments to donate $100 million in emergency aid, says that two-thirds of the nation's 11.6 million citizens have no ready access to adequate meals. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Man Sues Over Strip Search
description: A Norwich man who says he was subjected to a strip search in a parking lot filed suit yesterday in United States District Court in Hartford. The man, Brian W. Beard, was sitting in his car outside a Norwich pizzeria in April 2002 when two plainclothes police officers, along with five officers in uniform, approached and asked him if he had any weapons or drugs, according to court records. Mr. Beard told them he did not, and while his car was being searched, he was asked to pull down his underwear and submit to a full body search, court records said. After the search, his belongings were returned to him and he was allowed to leave the scene, according to the records. Lt. John John of the Norwich police said yesterday, ''This is the first I've heard of it.'' Mr. Beard's lawsuit contends that the police violated his constitutional rights, used arbitrary and excessive force and created a humiliating situation. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

That said, after all the controversy that has surrounded Lorin Maazel as music director of the New York Philharmonic, I decided at the outset of this season to wipe away any preconceptions and to attend as many Maazel programs as I could. title: When Daddy Belongs to the Bad Guys

The movie, directed by Gabriele Salvatores (''Mediterraneo''), gazes at this world through the eyes of Michele (Giuseppe Cristiano), a 10-year-old boy living with his little sister and his parents in a tiny, impoverished village that is almost swallowed by its surroundings.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Nichols's Ex-Wife Tells Of Affair
description: The second wife of Terry L. Nichols, Marife Torres, testified that she had an affair with Timothy J. McVeigh, the man convicted with Mr. Nichols in the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building in 1995. She later left her husband and went back to her native country, the Philippines, but returned after he assured her that Mr. McVeigh would no longer visit their home, Ms. Torres said. The couple later divorced. Mr. Nichols, 49, is on trial in state court, where he is facing 161 counts of first-degree murder in the bombing. He is serving a life term after being convicted in a federal court. Mr. McVeigh was executed in 2001. Ms. Torres, 30, said the two men watched television coverage of the government assault on the Branch Davidian compound outside Waco, Tex., in 1993. ''They were not happy about it,'' she testified. Prosecutors contend that Mr. McVeigh and Mr. Nichols were so angered by the siege that they destroyed the Oklahoma City building as revenge. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: NCR RAISES 2004 EARNINGS ESTIMATE TO $1.10 A SHARE
description: The NCR Corporation, the world's biggest maker of automated cash machines, raised its forecast for the year to as much as $1.15 a share because of an increase in demand for automatic tellers and research software. NCR expects earnings for 2004 to rise to $1.10 to $1.15 a share from 61 cents a year earlier. The company, based in Dayton, Ohio, previously forecast net income of 85 cents to 95 cents a share. NCR's customers are spending more on research software and hardware and automated cash dispensers, which is increasing profit, a spokesman, Jeff Dafler, said.

description: A court handed a 20-year sentence to a Chechen woman who was arrested last July when she tried to carry a bomb into a downtown Moscow restaurant. A policeman was killed trying to defuse the bomb. When she was found guilty, the woman, Zarema Muzhakhoyeva, 23, shouted from the defendant's cage, ''Now I know why everyone hates Russians!'' She said that when she is released, she will ''come back and blow you all up.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rates Steady
description: The Bank of England kept interest rates unchanged at 4 percent but economists said rates were likely to rise next month to curb surging consumer spending and rising house prices. After two increases since November 2003, British rates are four times those in the United States and twice those of the 12-nation euro zone, underscoring the divergent nature of the economies of Britain and those of the Continent. Economists had been divided on whether the bank would increase rates now or wait until May. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Folksy Eccentric Who's Got a Secret
description: Now this is what it means to work a room. In the opening moments of ''Match,'' the slim and soggy new comedy by Stephen Belber that opened last night at the Plymouth Theater, Frank Langella is utterly alone onstage. This is appropriate, since aloneness is a dominant shade in Mr. Langella's portrait of his character, an aging choreographer and dance teacher named Tobi Powell. But though there's not another soul in Tobi's apartment, he fills the space with the social energy of Le Cirque 2000 during a weekday lunch hour.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Totowa: Lettuce Truck Contained Marijuana, Officials Say
description: Two California men were charged with drug trafficking when a tractor-trailer loaded with lettuce bound for the Bronx was discovered to hold more than $1.3 million worth of marijuana as well, officials said yesterday. On Tuesday, Lenox Davis, 42, of Hawthorne, Calif., and Gilbert Francis, 41, of Los Angeles, driving a truck owned by Commercial Renaissance of Sacramento, were arrested on charges of possession of marijuana with the intent to distribute, according to the state police. Investigators boarded the truck and found 16 cardboard boxes with 690 pounds of marijuana concealed in the shipment, law enforcement officials said. The two men are being held in the Union County Jail on $1 million bail. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EARLE, WALTER R.
description: EARLE--Walter R. 67, of Freehold, NJ died Tuesday, April 6, 2004 at New York Presbyterian Hospital, New York City. He was a man of humble beginnings, a self made man. Upon graduating high school he enlisted in the United States Navy and was stationed on the USS Albany, the last two years of his four years of service he earned the position of Gig Coxswain (Admiral's personal boat Captain) and reported directly to Admiral John McCain, the father of Senator John McCain. During his tenure as Gig Coxswain he received a Commendation for Outstanding Performance from Admiral McCain, The commendation read As Gig Coxswain you have shown exceptional pride in making the Albany s Gig one of the smartest boats in the Sixth Fleet. His father had died during the period he was in the service. In 1968 Walter incorporated Earle Asphalt Company with a $25,000.00 loan from a dear personal friend. With the money he then purchased a used pickup truck, small asphalt paver, and small roller. Earle Asphalt Company's first project was for Lakehurst Naval Air Station at a price of $5,800.00. In 1974 Walter then purchased an Asphalt plant in Jackson Township from Gallo Asphalt Co., Gallo family members Mario, Gene, and Vince were instrumental lending advice and guidance during the early years of the company s incorporation. Over time the construction and manufacturing companies have evolved as industry leaders in the State of New Jersey receiving numerous National and State awards, utilizing his trademark style of Quality, Cleanliness, Integrity, and Effiency. He was also a philanthropist donating, often anonymously, money and time to many charitable organizations, including the Catholic Church, St. Rose of Lima Elementary School, Borough of Freehold Police, Freehold First Aid and Emergency Squad, and those less fortunate than he. He was on the Board of Directors of the Central Jersey Bank & Trust Company during the 1970's; Executive Board of Trustees of the Associated Independent Contractors; and the Board of Directors for the New Jersey Asphalt Pavement Association. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at St. Rose of Lima Chapel, Freehold on Monday at 11:30 A.M. followed by interment at the parish cemetery. Visiting will be held at St. Rose of Lima Chapel on Monday from 9:30-11:30 A.M. Memorial donations to the St. Rose of Lima School, 51 Lincoln Place, Freehold, NJ 07728 would be appreciated. For information, contact Higgins Memorial Home, Freehold.

title: One Hearing, Two Worlds
description: How did Condoleezza Rice do in defending the Bush administration's antiterrororism policies yesterday before the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks? Better if you kept your eyes on her than if you glanced down at the CNN headlines rolling across the bottom of the TV screen.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Mars Rovers' Mission Extended
description: The two rovers on Mars, Spirit and Opportunity, have been cleared to continue exploring five months beyond the end of their three-month primary missions, NASA announced. ''Given the rovers' tremendous success, the project submitted a proposal for extending the mission, and we have approved it,'' said Orlando Figueroa, the Mars exploration program director. The extension is budgeted to cost $15 million through September. The Spirit completed its prime mission on Monday, having traveled nearly 2,000 feet in studies of a Martian crater. Opportunity is to complete its three-month mission on April 26. John Noble Wilford (NYT)

title: DeLay Takes Issue With Carter's Latest Comments on Iraq
description: In some circles, former President Jimmy Carter is thought of as a man who has made the most of his post-White House years with his international and humanitarian work.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Debt Delinquencies Rise
description: Overdue payments at South Korean credit card companies rose to a record for an eighth month in February, led by the Korea Exchange Bank Credit Service Company, the nation's financial regulator said. The ratio of card loans overdue by more than a month rose to 15.4 percent from 15.2 percent in January, the financial supervisory service said, citing preliminary figures. The total amount of overdue credit card bills rose to 9.1 trillion won, ($8 billion) up 1 trillion won from January.

title: This Development Plan, Officials Say, Will Return Asbury Park to Glory Days
description: The governor showed up, the flashbulbs flashed and the sunshine even came out in force. After two decades in which its dreams of resurgence were repeatedly doused, this deteriorating seaside resort finally got a moment in the light on Thursday.

title: The Rice Version
description: In her long-awaited public testimony yesterday, Condoleezza Rice, the most diligent of public servants, made it clear that under her direction the Bush administration touched all the proper bases in planning an antiterror program. The State Department was told to ''work with'' other countries. F.B.I. field offices were ''tasked'' to increase surveillance on known terrorists. Warnings were issued, meetings were held. But Ms. Rice was utterly unconvincing when she tried to portray Al Qaeda as anything approaching a top concern for the White House.

title: Here Today, Gone Tomorrow
description: Even by the standards of the revolving door that is sometimes the John Kerry campaign, the arrival and departure of Howard Wolfson  the high-powered political consultant from New York  had to be a record.

title: Blast Suspects In Madrid Had New Plot, Officials Say
description: The group believed to be responsible for the Madrid train bombings in March had been planning another major attack, an Interior Ministry official said Thursday.

title: Teenager Gets 10 Years in Shooting Rampage Plot
description: A South Jersey teenager who the authorities said led two other youths in a scuttled plot to go on a shooting rampage last summer was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison.

title: Colorado's Other Slopes
description: ON these slopes, there are no chalets or lifts, and that flask had better contain water, not a hot toddy. But who needs cocoa, or even snow, when you can schuss down the Great Sand Dunes in Colorado? The dunes have become a center for the growing sport of sandboarding, similar to snowboarding. Page 9.

description: JAVIER VAZQUEZ pitched at Yankee Stadium yesterday courtesy of Major League Baseball. Considering that the Yankees cause Major League Baseball officials and owners stomach-wrenching anguish, they can only dislike even more the development that allowed the Yankees to put Vazquez in their starting rotation.

title: Arabs Worry Over Extremism While Evoking Vindication
description: Some Arabs watching the escalating violence in Iraq expressed fear Thursday that the United States, rather than helping to stamp out extremism, might have created a new, toxic incubator for it, while others expressed satisfaction that the Americans were getting their nose bloodied.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Priceline Chairman Resigns
description: Priceline.com, an Internet seller of discount travel services, said yesterday that Richard S. Braddock had resigned as chairman and was leaving the company. A board member, Ralph M. Bahna, took his place. Mr. Braddock, 62, said in a statement that ''it is now time to move on.'' He was named chairman in 1998, the same year that Mr. Bahna, 61, joined the board of the company, based in Norwalk, Conn. His departure comes as analysts forecast rising profit for the company as it rebounds from weak sales of airline tickets. Mr. Braddock, who was once president of Citicorp, is one of the last of several high-profile executives recruited by the company during the Internet bubble of the late 1990's. The chief executive, Jeffery H. Boyd, 47, took over day-to-day operations from him in November 2002. Shares of Priceline.com rose 37 cents, to $27.02.

title: Senate Panel Asked to Give S.E.C. Proposals a Chance
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Senate committee yesterday that Congress should not pass any laws to correct abuses in the $7.6 trillion mutual fund industry until after his agency's proposals to fix improper trading can take hold.

title: Salaried Parent Coordinators Weighed for 60 Small Schools
description: The New York City Department of Education is debating whether to assign a full-time paid parent coordinator to each of the 60 small schools scheduled to open in September, officials said yesterday.

description: The two largest advertising industry associations are joining forces to lobby for changes in the process marketers use to buy billions of dollars in commercial time ahead of the fall television season in what is known as the upfront market.

title: As Iraq Insurgency Spreads, U.S. Finds More Foes and Fewer Friends
description: The spreading insurgency in Iraq has drastically altered the strategic equation for the United States military. One year after United States forces fought their way into Baghdad, Americans now find themselves facing more enemies, with fewer effective allies, than they had counted on.

title: European Economic Liberalization: Often Forecast but Never Done
description: ON May Day, the historic workers' holiday, the European Union will expand to 25 countries, bringing increased competition that forces economic liberalization in the comfortable countries of old Europe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Subpoenaed
description: The drug and chemical maker Bayer said the inspector general of the United States Defense Department had subpoenaed documents relating to the company's withdrawal from the market of the cholesterol drug Baycol. Preliminary conversations indicate the subpoena is related to a joint Defense Department and Food and Drug Administration inquiry, Bayer said in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, which is based in Leverkusen, said that it had not been informed of any charges or complaints in connection with the inquiry, and that it would cooperate with the government.

description: As American forces continued battling Sunni Muslims in Falluja and other troops began deploying south to challenge insurgents who have seized control of three major Shiite cities, rebels kidnapped several foreign civilians on Thursday and threatened to execute them.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Coors To Seek Senate Seat
description: Peter Coors, president of his family's brewing company, is likely to run for the Senate seat that is being vacated by Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Republican who is retiring. Although Mr. Coors, a Republican, has not formally announced his candidacy, the Republican governor, Bill Owens, made it public this week. Officials with the Colorado Republican Party said Mr. Coors, 57, was expected to make an official announcement next week. Former Congressman Bob Schaffer, a Republican, has announced his candidacy and Attorney General Ken Salazar, a Democrat, is also running. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: Senator John Kerry took some heat recently for leaving the campaign trail, to vacation in Idaho and then to undergo shoulder surgery. So now that he is back in full campaign mode, he took a jab at President Bush for taking some time off himself, at his ranch in Texas .

description: One invaluable lesson conveyed by the English musical theater star Maria Friedman is that subtraction is often more truthful than the piling on of vocal pyrotechnics. For a semi-operatic singer like Ms. Friedman, the rejection of high-powered display in favor of something deeper and subtler takes extra courage.

title: Spring Tonic: Fresh Trout
description: SINCE I was a child, opening day (in Connecticut, where I live, it is the third Saturday in April) has meant fresh trout to eat. My friend Joe Haines, a Connecticut game warden, used to whip up what he called a spring tonic; usually a fresh trout rolled in flour and fried in olive oil, with a salad of new dandelion leaves. Below is a variation on that dish from a recipe by the chef Tom Valenti (an owner of the Upper West Side restaurants Ouest and 'Cesca), a fanatic catch-and-release trout fisherman who has a summer place on the Beaverkill. JAMES PROSEK

title: World Briefing | Asia: Georgia: President Orders Province To Free Prisoner
description: President Mikhail Saakashvili seemed to set up a new confrontation with the renegade province of Adzharia when he demanded the immediate release from prison of Tengiz Asanidze, who was convicted, but then pardoned, in a 1993 assassination attempt against the provincial leader, Aslan Abashidze, the Interfax news agency reported. ''I have all the leverage to teach a lesson to shameless feudal lords,'' Mr. Saakashvili said. ''You should not test the patience of the Georgian president and people.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Industrial Output Rises
description: Malaysia's industrial production rose 11.1 percent in February from a year earlier, its slowest pace in five months, after exports did not grow as quickly as expected. Production at Malaysia's factories, mines and utilities rose a revised 18.4 percent in January, the government statistics department said. Exports and manufacturing production have surged in recent months as faster global economic growth increased demand for Malaysia's computer chips, hard disks and other goods. Production rose at the fastest rate in more than three years in the two months before February.

title: Watson Recalls Caddie's Last Reminder
description: More than an hour before his 8:44 a.m. tee time, Tom Watson was in the champions' locker room at Augusta National on Thursday when the security guard told him that his wife, Hilary, was at the door.

title: Iowa Lineman Turns Heads of All Ages
description: The first day Robert Gallery walked into the classroom, ducking his head under the doorway, dozens of eyes stared up at him, wide with awe. He still smiles at the memory, a group of fourth to sixth graders rendered silent before he could even say a word. The kids had been told an Iowa football player would be their student-teacher, but nothing could quite prepare them for Gallery.

title: TELEDYNE TO BUY MAKER OF ENVIRONMENTAL INSTRUMENTS
description: Teledyne Technologies Inc. agreed to buy Isco Inc. for $96 million in cash, its fifth acquisition of a company that makes instruments to measure environmental conditions. Teledyne, which makes engines and parts for the aerospace industry, will pay $16 a share, which is 32 percent more than Isco's closing price Wednesday of $12.10, it said. Teledyne, based in Los Angeles, said it expected the acquisition to add to earnings in fiscal 2005. Isco, based in Lincoln, Neb., makes instruments that analyze chemicals in water and measure flow. Customers include government wastewater treatment plants and scientists who measure water pollution.

title: Stoppard's Eight Lords A-Leaping
description: THEY are not, by and large, very athletic or, to be completely honest, very good. Some have pot bellies, and some have gray hair. Their fashion sense, too, is questionable: canary yellow jumpsuits, after all, shouldn't really be worn before Memorial Day. (Or after, for that matter.)

title: Excerpts From Rice's Testimony Before Commission Investigating Sept. 11
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, yesterday before the National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States, as recorded by The New York Times. A complete version is at nytimes.com/washington.

description: When the United States invaded Iraq a year ago, one of its chief concerns was preventing a civil war between Shiite Muslims, who make up a majority in the country, and Sunni Muslims, who held all the power under Saddam Hussein.

description: NOW that Jay Haas is 50, he finds an AARP application in his mailbox every so often. But he hasn't joined.

title: Nets Truly Limping Into Playoffs
description: It was a moment that the Nets have dreaded as they limp into the postseason. Late in the third quarter, Kenyon Martin started limping, moved into his defensive position and managed to block a shot. But he could not jog down to the other end of the court and struggled to make it to the bench.

title: Discount Airline and Belgians Reach Agreement on Airport
description: Ryanair , the fast-growing no-frills airline, said today that it would keep flying to an airport near Brussels that it had threatened to leave after a regulatory setback in February.

description: To the Editor:

title: From Modernism Backward: Jim Dine's Multiple Styles
description: Jim Dine, who is having a retrospective of drawings at the National Gallery of Art in Washington and a two-gallery show of new paintings, sculptures and photographs at PaceWildenstein and Pace/MacGill in Manhattan, made it in New York in the early 60's. Fresh out of Ohio State University, he arrived in 1958, a propitious moment.

title: Winner in Mock Trial
description: The Yankees were cleared by an ESPN jury of upsetting baseball's competitive balance with their free spending in a mock trial taped Wednesday and shown last night as ''Break Up the Bombers: The Yankees on Trial.'' The jury voted, 10 to 2, in the Yankees' favor.

title: New York City's Population Grew For 2nd Year, Census Data Show
description: New York City's population grew for a second straight year after 9/11, according to estimates released yesterday by the Census Bureau, dispelling theories that it might decrease because of the recession or fears of another terrorist attack.

title: Crosshatching the World's Controversies
description: ABOUT 30 years ago, two redheaded 6-year-olds got into a frightful scrape in Surrey, England. One, Andrew Murphy, had come up with a potty-humor poem about the queen. The other, Matt Davies, had illustrated it. Despite the rumpus it caused (''I found myself on the receiving end of Britain's now-defunct corporal punishment system,'' Mr. Davies recalls), even his mother thought the picture quite good.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Highways To Be Redesigned
description: The state transportation agency, in an effort to settle a decade-old lawsuit, has agreed to redesign state highways to stop polluted runoff from fouling the coastline. The agreement was filed in federal court in Los Angeles after a year of negotiations between the California Transportation Department, or Caltrans, and two environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council and Santa Monica BayKeeper. Storm water runoff is the largest source of coastal water pollution, and highways serve to collect and channel pollutants, including toxic particles from tires, oil and grease. David Beckman, director of the resources council's Coastal Water Quality Project, said the agreement could ultimately cut 80 percent of the pollution. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: U.S. Says Gasoline Prices Won't Fall Anytime Soon
description: The Energy Department predicted yesterday that the average price of gasoline this summer would rival record levels, an announcement that drove crude oil prices 2.8 percent higher, to more than $37 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINTRAUB, NORMA
description: WEINTRAUB--Norma. April 9, 1974. Beloved wife of Morris, mother of Marcia Morris. Yahrzeit 17 Nisan.

title: In the Catskills, the Ties That Bind
description: THE first time Paul Weamer visited Roscoe, N.Y., to fish the Beaverkill River, a place he had read about a dozen years earlier, when he was only 10 and just beginning to develop his passion for fly-fishing, he spent the night in his pickup truck because he was too broke to afford a motel room. But the next morning, his body still stiff from sleeping on the front seat, and with frost on the windshield (it was a cold May morning), he was casting a fly in the fabled Junction Pool, where his heroes of the sport -- Theodore Gordon, Harry Darbee and Sparse Grey Hackle -- had once stood, and any soreness was restored by the river's tonic.

title: Torre Near 3-Year Deal
description: The new contract for Manager Joe Torre could be for three years, a person familiar with the negotiations said. Torre, who met in his office with the Yankees general partner Steve Swindal before yesterday's game, is expected to sign a deal worth from $6 million to $6.5 million a season for three guaranteed years or two years with an option. The contract may include performance bonuses based on victories and championships, as his current contract does. Tyler Kepner

title: Proposal Raises Issue of Who Should Pay What for College
description: If Congress changes the rules on college loans, taking away the opportunity for students to consolidate them at low fixed rates, the average graduate will have to pay an extra $3,115 to $5,484 in interest over the life of the loans, the Congressional Research Service has found.

title: After a Drizzly 5-Hour Match, Brooklyn College Takes the Cup
description: In terms of championship games, the cricket match played in Brooklyn yesterday between computer science students from Brooklyn College and a spirited bunch of players from City College will probably not make the annals of intercollegiate sports.

title: Cairns's Errors Hurt Islanders
description: Defenseman Eric Cairns's job for the Islanders has been to do the dirty work. He harasses shot-makers, picks up penalty minutes (a team-leading 189) and jumps into the occasional scrape.

title: Rose Shoots 71 and Holds Onto 2-Stroke Lead in Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9  As a legend in golf departed the Masters, a huge opportunity awaited the many players still in contention Friday.

title: U.S. Orders Halt to Falluja Operations, but Situation Unclear
description: Ahalt to Marine operations in Falluja was announced today by the top American administrator in Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, so that talks could be held with a delegation of sheiks and the city's residents could collect their dead and wounded.

title: Upper East Side Block Closed by Main Breaks
description: Water and sewer mains ruptured early yesterday on an Upper East Side block, leaving a gigantic crater in the street, flooding the basements of several buildings and forcing the city to close the block and shut off water to the area.

title: A Decade After Massacres, Rwanda Outlaws Ethnicity
description: Although he is not a government spokesman, Ernest Twahrwa can recite Rwanda's official view toward ethnicity with great precision: ''There is no ethnicity here. We are all Rwandan.''

title: A Modernist And Innovator, Rediscovered
description: Only Modern design aficionados know that two of the most emblematic creations of the 20th century, Le Corbusier's stylish tubular steel Chaise Longue LC4 and his Grand Confort, a cube-shaped armchair whose leather cushions are held in a chrome-plated steel corset, were created in 1928 by a team of three: Le Corbusier; his cousin and colleague Pierre Jeanneret; and Charlotte Perriand, the French Modernist designer who died in 1999 at 96.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Production Falls
description: German industrial production fell 0.7 percent in February, the first decline since September, the economics and labor ministry said. Manufacturing output was down 1.1 percent, with production of durable goods down 1.7 percent and production of capital goods down 1.9 percent. Construction, which declined in January, rebounded and rose 4.6 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: A Little Light Is Shed on Intelligence Digests
description: In Washington-speak, it is the P.D.B. or President's Daily Brief. An intelligence digest prepared six mornings a week, by the Central Intelligence Agency, it is one of the most highly classified documents prepared by the government, its distribution limited under President Bush to fewer than a dozen senior administration officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, MAX CHARLES, PH.D.
description: KAUFMAN -- Max Charles, Ph.D. At 86. Beloved husband of the late Reva. Devoted father of Harley, Brian and Susan. Dear brother of Esther, Sybie and the late Jessie. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Jenna, Jeremy and Johanna. Funeral services will be today, 1PM, at the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Defense Asks For Dismissal Of Charges On Williams
description: Lawyers for Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets star, asked a judge yesterday to dismiss all charges against him, saying that the prosecutor in his manslaughter trial had committed misconduct by withholding evidence and allowing false testimony.

title: Knicks See Nets on Their Radar Now
description: The Knicks have three regular-season games to play, and their playoff opponent might as well be plucked from a bunch of Ping-Pong balls in a lottery drum. But Isiah Thomas, the team president, was asked in an interview Wednesday about just one potential foe.

title: Weekender | Greenwood Lake, N.Y.
description: WHEN Carol and Howard Kolins, who live in Brooklyn, began thinking of buying a second home, friends in Greenwood Lake invited them for a visit. ''It was autumn, and the foliage reflecting off the lake was stunning,'' said Ms. Kolins, an assistant preschool teacher and a former Rockette. ''I couldn't believe how close to the city it was.''

title: Baseball's Biggest Stage Suits Vazquez
description: They all came to Yankee Stadium with memories. Javier Vazquez was the losing pitcher the day David Cone threw his perfect game. Gary Sheffield visited with his Little League team when he was 11 years old. Alex Rodriguez faced the Yankees in the 2000 playoffs, when he realized the glory that could come to a player on baseball's grandest stage.

title: Sticking to Their Scripts
description: When Condoleezza Rice took the national stage on Thursday morning, her task was to defend President Bush against the accusation that he was inattentive to terrorism before the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, and to defuse a debate that threatens his re-election campaign. She mounted the defense vigorously, but in the hours after she returned to the White House, it was evident that she had not defused the arguments.

title: Just Past the End Zone, a Site for Art Is Seen
description: The Bloomberg administration and the Jets have held all manner of news conferences and media stunts to promote a sense of momentum for their $6.5 billion proposal to redevelop the West Side of Manhattan and build a 75,000-seat football stadium.

title: Out of Usual Spotlight, Clinton Has Long Session With Panel
description: Hours after it riveted Washington's attention with public testimony from Condoleezza Rice, the commission investigating the 9/11 attacks met in secret and hung on the words of a witness who once made much bigger headlines: Bill Clinton.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: 20 YEARS FOR FAILED SUICIDE BOMBER A court handed a 20-year sentence to a Chechen woman who was arrested last July when she tried to carry a bomb into a downtown Moscow restaurant. A policeman was killed trying to defuse the bomb. When she was found guilty, the woman, Zarema Muzhakhoyeva, 23, shouted from the defendant's cage, "Now I know why everyone hates Russians!" She said that when she is released, she will "come back and blow you all up." Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Jack Smith, 58, TV Reporter of World Events
description: Jack Smith, a former Washington-based correspondent for ABC News who covered world events before helping that network shape its technology beat, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 58 and lived in Mill Valley, Calif.

title: Bush Picks Businessman For Manufacturing Post
description: President Bush nominated a California businessman on Thursday for a senior position in the Commerce Department charged with reversing the precipitous drop in manufacturing jobs over the last three years. That decline continues to be a serious liability for Mr. Bush's re-election campaign.

title: O Square, Where Is Thy Sting?
description: ON the 100th anniversary of the moment when Long Acre Square disappeared, yielding to Times Square, wisps of the past blew in yesterday, inevitably.
