description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Empty Room
description: Condi Rice was in Washington trying to pass her oral exam before the 9/11 commission yesterday, and the president was on vacation in Texas. As usual, they were in close agreement, this time on the fact that neither they nor anyone else in this remarkably aloof and arrogant administration is responsible for the tragic mess unfolding in Iraq, and its implications for the worldwide war on terror.

title: Putin Doubts Expanded NATO Meets New Threats
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Thursday that he hoped the expansion of NATO might have a positive effect on international relations but that the expansion is not effective against terrorist threats.

title: 9/11 Panel Presses Rice on Early Warnings
description: Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, testified Thursday that Mr. Bush was warned a month before the Sept. 11 terror attacks that the F.B.I. had detected ''suspicious activity'' that suggested terrorists might be planning a domestic hijacking. She said he was also told that the bureau was conducting 70 investigations of possible terrorist cells connected to Al Qaeda operating within American borders.

title: New Sentencing Hearing for Death Row Inmate Who Hired Wife's Killer
description: Robert O. Marshall, who hired a hit man to kill his wife at a rest stop on the Garden State Parkway, was granted a new sentencing hearing Thursday after 18 years on New Jersey's death row.

title: Testimony Provides Breath Of Racial Reality for TV
description: There was absolutely nothing in Condoleezza Rice's neutral-toned suit, primly folded hands or calm demeanor to draw attention to her sex or race. Her answers, guarded, prosaic and a bit pedantic, were typical of any high-level Washington official.

title: Christo's Feat: 25 Years' Work For 16 Days
description: You might think that after more than 40 years of grand-scale achievements, like hanging a curtain between two peaks in a Colorado valley; running miles of fence through two California counties; outfitting several islands off Florida with tutus; wrapping the Pont Neuf in Paris; and swaddling the Reichstag in Berlin, the indefatigable team of Christo and his wife-collaborator, Jeanne-Claude, would at last run out of ambition.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: THE PHILIPPINES: TROOPS KILL MILITANT LEADER Soldiers killed a top commander of the militant group Abu Sayyaf and five other rebels in a firefight on the island of Basilan, the government said. The commander was indicted in 2002 for kidnappings that led to the death of two hostages, including the Kansas missionary Martin Burnham. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: A Comedy That Visited on Its First Time Around, Too
description: The director David Leveaux describes Tom Stoppard's comedy ''Jumpers'' as a play about ''philosophy and bottoms.'' It was the latter that caused much of the fuss over the original 1972 London production.

title: Names of the American Dead in the Iraq War
description: The Department of Defense has identified 634 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Rejecting Constitutional Claims, Judge Upholds Smoking Bans
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has upheld the smoking bans that the city and state enacted last year.

description: A United States Senate committee headed by John McCain, Republican of Arizona, issued a subpoena yesterday to obtain documents from the Department of Justice regarding the athletes who testified before a grand jury investigating the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative and their possible purchase and use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CROWLEY, JOHN S.
description: CROWLEY--John S. A former Senior Partner/Director at McKinsey & Co. in New York and Greenwich, CT resident, died of complications from pneumonia and Parkinson's disease on Wednesday, March 31, 2004. He was 80. Known as ''Jack'' to his friends, Mr. Crowley served as Chairman of the American Foundation for the Blind and Helen Keller International (HKI), where he pioneered international distribution of vitamin A in Indonesia to prevent nutritional blindness in millions of people. In addition, he was Chairman of the Board of the New York PBS station WNET/Channel 13 and a member of The Links in New York City. Mr. Crowley's survivors include his wife, Carol Kilby Crowley, their four children, five grandchildren, his younger brother, Harry B. Crowley, Jr., and younger sister, Dorothy Crowley Howe both of Rochester, NY. A wake will be held on Monday, April 12, 7PM9PM, at Gallagher Funeral Home, 37 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, April 13, 10AM, at St. Michael's Church, 469 North St., Greenwich, CT. Donations may be made in Mr. Crowley's memory to: Helen Keller Intl., 352 Park Ave. South, Suite 1200, New York, New York 10010.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SRI LANKA: HEAVY COMBAT BETWEEN REBEL FACTIONS Heavy fighting erupted Friday between the main Tamil Tiger rebel group and a breakaway faction, the country's first major violence since a 2002 cease-fire halted its civil war, the guerrillas and military said. A spokesman for the breakaway faction said fighters from the main group had invaded its territory by crossing the Verugal River. The Sri Lankan army has a large presence near the river, raising fears that it could be drawn into any conflict.    (AP)

title: Saxophone Improvisations Surface From Chicago's Underground
description: The tenor saxophonist Fred Anderson, a gray eminence of the jazz underground from Chicago, makes music that sounds as if it's all middle. There's not much written material beyond little motifs of a few notes, and then the band's off and running, the saxophonist riding the wave. But the beginnings sound like connector pieces.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Equipment Sales Rose 10% In 2003
description: Worldwide sales of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment rose 10 percent last year and will surge 40 percent in 2004 as chip makers upgrade plants and buy tools for new production techniques, the research firm Gartner Inc. said yesterday. Sales increased to $22.8 billion in 2003 from $20.7 billion, Gartner said. Sales at Applied Materials, the No.1 supplier, dropped 12 percent. Advantest had the fastest growth of the top companies, with sales more than doubling, Gartner said. Semiconductor makers have been adding tools that build chips with thinner wires and filling factories with gear that uses larger 300-millimeter silicon wafers. Gartner's 2004 forecast, up from an earlier 37 percent growth estimate, compares with a prediction by Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International of a 38 percent sales gain.

title: Flare-Ups in Iraq Fighting Mar Early Efforts at Cease-Fire
description: Coalition forces battled insurgents throughout Iraq today  the anniversary of the fall of Baghdad  even though the day began with the talk of a cease-fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCAHILL, ELIZABETH CAMERON
description: McCAHILL--Elizabeth Cameron, of Southold, Long Island on April 5, 2004 at the age of 85. Dame of Malta. Survived by her cousin, Cynthia Halsey of Southold and the HoustonThomas Family of Geneseo, NY. Friends may call on Thursday, April 15 from 35PM at the DeFriest-Grattan Funeral Homes, Inc., 51400 Route 25, Southold (19 miles East of LIE, Exit 73). title: The Rural Life; Hole in the Sky
description: Until a few days ago, the biggest tree on our farm was a century-old honey locust that stood at the edge of an embankment overlooking the lower pasture. There are other big trees on this place -- hemlocks and hickories and one old sugar maple that looks like something out of ''The Faerie Queene.'' But a few years ago the honey locust began dropping major limbs after wind storms, and with each limb it dropped it seemed to reach higher and higher into the sky. What kept it standing I don't know. The core of the trunk had decayed into brick-red frass. The tree leaned into the northeast, where the worst of our storms begin, and perhaps that made a difference. In the end, it was only the strength of the wood itself, a kind of cellular will.

Halpern, President of the Board of Trustees from 1977 to 1982. Nathan provided strong leadership in establishing measures to guarantee the growth and stability of the young institution. He was also an avid photographer who each year shared with us his pictures of the roses he and Edith grew. We extend our sympathies to his son, Michael, daughter-in-law, Chris Grant, and two grandsons. Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus Rita Hillman, Honorary Chair Willis Hartshorn, Ehrenkranz Director

title: Piracy and Terrorism
description: Piracy, these days, refers more often to digital miscreants who copy music and movies than to skull-and-crossbones derring-do on the high seas. But pirates of the old-fashioned variety, armed with automatic weapons, are not only a real and growing menace, they are also suspected of forging links with global terrorists. A greater effort is needed on the part of governments and private shippers worldwide to secure their harbors, ships and sea lanes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Transit Proposal
description: Thailand asked the main creditors of the Bangkok Mass Transit System to forgo half of their 38.1 billion baht debt ($974 million) as part of the government's move to take over the operator of the elevated-train network. The government wants creditors -- including the Siam Commercial Bank, the International Finance Corporation and Kreditanstalt fr Wiederaufbau -- to write off most of their debt before it starts negotiating with Tanayong, the biggest shareholder of Bangkok Mass Transit, the transport minister, Suriya Jungrungreangkit told reporters in Bangkok after meeting with creditors. Thailand's government wants to take control of Bangkok Mass Transit to expand routes and reduce fares.

title: Don't Abandon Rwandan Women Again
description: At commemorations held in Rwanda and around the world this week for the 800,000 people who were murdered in the Rwandan genocide 10 years ago, politicians and other leaders said ''never again.'' Those words, while well-intentioned, have a hollowness to them: people are still dying of the genocide in Rwanda and the world is still failing them.

description: David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader and state representative, was released on Thursday from a federal prison in Big Spring, Tex., and transferred to a halfway house in Louisiana where he is scheduled to stay until May 16, said Kathryn Tracy, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Prisons. title: China's Martha Stewart, With Reasons to Smile
description: WHEN she started out in television three years ago, stuffing a Thanksgiving turkey as she stood behind a kitchen counter on a simple set, Zhou Zhu remembers painfully, she had difficulty smiling while struggling to remember her lines. Her first self-produced pilot for a program offering tips on a Western-style middle-class lifestyle was rejected out of hand, in part because of her awkwardness. ''Those first shows were excruciating,'' said Ms. Zhou, 36, dressed in a bright fuchsia blouse and wearing her hair tied atop her head in an artful knot. ''I had no experience before the camera, and had to repeat one line 40 times. I even had to learn how to smile.''

The sale ''will improve the performance and the credibility of Hyundai Capital,'' South Korea's biggest auto financing service company, Mr. Kim said. He declined to identify the other company involved.

title: Justice Begrudged
description: The criminal justice system of Virginia has long been haunted by Earl Washington Jr., a pliable farmhand with the I.Q. of a 10-year-old who spent 17 years in prison for a murder he did not commit before being grudgingly freed. His lawyers and news organizations are now in federal court trying to force open the police records of Mr. Washington's arrest and conviction, one of the more notorious injustices in state history. Mr. Washington, retarded and black in a rural white community, was convicted on the basis of a confession in which he was painstakingly coached by police.

There were guidance counselors: Julius Rudel, and Margaret Singer, who flew in from Germany for the event. ''He actively played volleyball in his early years and these days comes to the court to watch nearly all the matches of the Dinamo team,'' said Vladimir Patkin, the federation's executive secretary. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: In Reversal, U.S. Proposes To Remove Atom Waste
description: When the federal government suggested that the easiest way to take care of tons of radioactive material at a long-closed Long Island nuclear reactor was to just leave it there and let it decay over time -- the next 87,000 years -- critics blanched.

title: Child Care in Trouble
description: The government's failure to support child care for low-income families has created an appalling situation in which only 15 percent of the children eligible for federally financed child care actually get it. More than 400,000 children will fall off the rolls over the next five years. This will mean disaster for their families unless the government puts real child care money into welfare reform bills pending in the House and Senate.

title: Where Music May Owe Stalin a Little Credit
description: Stalin was undoubtedly a man of good taste. Like the composer Dmitri Shostakovich, he was said to have so loved one Chekhov story that he practically knew it by heart. Like Shostakovich, too, he admired Pushkin. And he was an avid fan of opera and ballet. A recording of a Mozart piano concerto may even have been playing by his bed when he died.

title: When U.S. Aided Insurgents, Did It Breed Future Terrorists?
description: In the varied explanations for the 9/11 attacks and the rise in terrorism, two themes keep recurring. One is that Islamic culture itself is to blame, leading to a clash of civilizations, or, as more nuanced versions have it, a struggle between secular-minded and fundamentalist Muslims that has resulted in extremist violence against the West. The second is that terrorism is a feature of the post-cold-war landscape, belonging to an era in which international relations are no longer defined by the titanic confrontation between two superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Second-Guessing of Bush Now Extends to Convention Site
description: When the Republican Party chose New York City as the site of its 2004 nominating convention, the symbolism was apparent: the G.O.P. would be rallying around its nominee in the city that had come to embody the nation's resolve in the wake of the 9/11 attacks, a place where President Bush once stood on a pile of debris at ground zero, rallying the nation to unite in the war on terror.

title: Niedermayer Fills In the Gap
description: For the first time since joining the Devils in 1991, Scott Stevens was not in the lineup Thursday night for a playoff game, and the team missed him, losing by 3-2 to the Flyers in Game 1 of their first-round series. Stevens, who turned 40 on April 1, has not played since Jan. 7 because of post-concussion syndrome.

title: Mets' Yates Shows He's Where He Belongs
description: The last time Tyler Yates came to Puerto Rico, his parents warned him to be inside by 9 p.m. or else he could find himself in danger.

title: Iraqis Unclear About Answers, but Clearly Weary of War
description: The Happy Time restaurant sounds like an improbable place for Iraqis to discuss the turmoil and strife of a growing guerrilla war against American-led troops occupying their country.

title: In Iraq, Give Peace a Chance
description: When American marines stormed into Baghdad a year ago, Amer al-Minshidawi, a leading cleric in the Saddam City neighborhood, told worshipers that after being liberated it was the ''duty of Shiites in Iraq to teach the world that Islam is a religion of peace, tolerance and love.'' A year later, however, such gratitude has all but evaporated -- and that Shiite enclave, now called Sadr City, has given birth to an insurgency led by the young cleric Moktada al-Sadr that has spread through southern Iraq.

title: The Islanders Put Aside Cairns's Two Giveaways

title: Devotee of Soul Offers a Bow to Past Masters
description: Van Hunt brought a vulnerable streak to the fundamentals of 1970's soul -- groove, flirtation, desire, suaveness and swagger -- at Joe's Pub on Thursday night. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHIFF, FRANK
description: SCHIFF--Frank, age 83, died on April 8, after a brief illness. He is survived by Gloria Schiff, his devoted wife of 50 years, and by loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Schiff was educated at Lawrenceville School and then Hamilton College where he was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon. In 1941, he joined the Air Force and rose to the rank of Captain, working in intelligence with the 9th Air Force. His assignments took him to northern Europe, beginning in Normandy and continuing through France, Belgium and into Germany. After he was discharged from the service, he joined the family business, Schiff Terhune Inc. He served as President and later as Chairman and CEO of Schiff Terhune International. In 1982, the company merged with Alexander & Alexander where Mr. Schiff remained in the position of Vice Chairman until his retirement in 1988. Frank Schiff was Chapter Chairman of the Young Presidents Organization, a Director of the Travelers Aid Society of N.Y., and Chairman of the United Service Organization. He was an avid sportsman and member of Piping Rock Club and the Meadow Club in Southampton. Mr. Schiff will be greatly missed by his family and friends for his generous source of wit and humor. Funeral services will be private.

title: 1904:Pneumonia Takes Toll : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: NEW YORK: The appalling fatality of pneumonia during the last few months has been the subject of universal comment. In New York alone there have been over six thousand deaths since December 1. Statistics show also that the prevalence of the disease and the ratio of mortality are increasing from year to year in spite of improved sanitation and increasing attention to civic hygiene. This is in marked contrast with the conditions governing the spread of tuberculosis, inasmuch as that disease always flourishes in uncleanly and ill-ventilated quarters. There has been no end of theorizing as to the real causes of epidemic "lung fever," but as yet no definite solution of the problem has been reached. It is so fashionably scientific to match every disease with its microbe that it is no wonder we hear more of the pneumococcus than we ever did before.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Pointillist Printmaker
description: Chuck Close, the great postmodern pointillist printmaker, is a methodical perfectionist. Fittingly, Terrie Sultan, the director of the Blaffer Gallery, the art museum of the University of Houston, goes much deeper than the usual artist appreciation in CHUCK CLOSE PRINTS: Process and Collaboration (Princeton University, cloth, $49.95; paper, $35). After Sultan's introduction and an essay by Richard Shiff, an art professor at the University of Texas, Austin, whole chapters are devoted to each type of printmaking that Close has mastered. He is interviewed by his longtime collaborators about techniques both familiar (silk-screen) and less so (spitbite etching). Close has called himself ''an artist looking for trouble'' because, as Sultan writes, ''extricating himself from a technical corner becomes a catalyst for his creativity.'' Close is never sure how he will achieve the desired result; part of his talent lies in being up for anything. ''I have this nave belief in systems,'' he has said, ''that if you believe in something and follow it, you will create something.'' Ted Loos

His new album, ''Travesia'' (Sony Discos), comes with a new producer, the Latin pop svengali Emilio Estefan; it contains strong dance-floor salsa and some overly sweet ballads that suddenly unfold into complexity. title: Way Uptown
description: By the 1960's, with the pain of the Second World War and Korea still vivid and a new war festering in Asia, Manhattan, suffering one of its periodic paroxysms of self-destruction in the name of renewal, was again at war with itself. The double-decker buses, with their open tops in the spring, where romantic tourists ate their picnic lunches, were scrapped. The old Lafayette restaurant in Greenwich Village was demolished. Schrafft's, with its Irish waitresses in their black dresses, white aprons and lace tiaras, with its date-nut bread, creamed chicken with bright green peas and pineapple sundaes, was dying as if in sympathy with the afflicted cityscape itself. A developer seriously proposed tearing down Carnegie Hall and replacing it with a vertical crate the color of tomato soup. He was thwarted. But another developer got away with wrecking the glorious Pennsylvania Station and erecting in its place a grimy glass and concrete box, the mortal twitch of a dying modernism. Sprouting along Sixth and Third and Lexington, these morbid boxes were like the detritus of an intergalactic invasion. One of them, across the street from Random House, where I worked for many years, displaced Caf Chambord, Roger Chauveron's great belle poque restaurant at 3rd and 49th, where I dined when I could afford it.

title: Young Adam And His Eves
description: PLAYING what we'd now call a sex addict, Ewan McGregor finds plenty of partners in ''Young Adam,'' even though his occupation doesn't offer many prospects for womanizing: he works and lives on a coal barge with a married couple and their small son. Set in 1950's Glasgow, the film (opening on Friday) has generated publicity because of its silly NC-17 rating, a ruling based not only on Mr. McGregor's fully nude scene, but also on his fully clothed oral sex scene on a riverbank. It's not the film's sex that is startling, though. What's truly subversive and bracing is its utter lack of moral judgment, even as its hero slides into behavior most films would pillory.

title: SENATORS ASK C.D.C. TO EXAMINE DEATHS
description: Senators Frank R. Lautenberg and Jon S. Corzine have asked the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta to ''initiate a thorough investigation'' of a possible cluster of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in the deaths of at least 12 people who attended or worked at the Garden State Race Track in Cherry Hill from 1988 to 1992. Creutzfeldt-Jakob is a rare, fatal neurological disease similar to mad cow disease; it kills about one in a million people in the United States each year. The senators sent a letter last week to the agency's director, Dr. Julie L. Gerberding, urging an inquiry into the cases compiled by Janet Skarbek, an accountant and writer who decided to investigate after a friend who worked at the track died of Creutzfeldt-Jakob. New Jersey's health department has yet to release the results of its investigation into the deaths. George James

title: A HIGH-ENERGY TUNEUP IN UTAH
description: IT isn't difficult to get an appointment for a massage or a leg wrap during the day at Red Mountain Spa, a health resort nestled in the red rocks of southwestern Utah about 90 minutes from Las Vegas. But evening treatments book up quickly. True, there's not much to do at night at a midsize spa that sits at the foot of Snow Canyon State Park, a 10-minute drive from sleepy St. George, the nearest town. But as a fellow guest explained my first night, there is another reason evening treatments are so popular. A typical day can include a rigorous hike, swimming, classes in yoga, spinning and Pilates and, if you're so inclined, horseback riding, mountain biking, snowshoeing or rock climbing. ''You need a massage so you'll be able to walk the next day,'' she said.

title: Fined by a Homeowners' Association
description: Q. My wife and I own a vacation home in Columbia County in a development with a mix of year-round and vacation homeowners. All homeowners are required to be members of a homeowners' association, which collects annual dues for maintenance of the roads, lake and water supply. The association recently instituted a rule requiring each homeowner to have his septic tank pumped out and inspected once every five years. Since we use our home only about 60 days a year, I feel this requirement is excessive for us. The association is attempting to levy a fine of $250 per year for noncompliance. Does the homeowners' association have any statutory authority to collect such fines? . . . Larry Sullivan, Riverdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMENDOLA, BRITTA SWENNING
description: AMENDOLA--Britta Swenning, passed away in her New York home on April 7th. The beloved wife of the late Dr. Frederick Amendola, former Chief of Surgery at Roosevelt Hospital, Mrs. Amendola was born September 25th, 1913 in Norrkopping, Sweden and emigrated to this country in 1923. A graduate of the Lenox Hill School of Nursing, she was a registered nurse at Roosevelt Hospital in the years immediately before, during and after World War II. She is survived by her first cousins, Carl Volckmann of Westport, CT and Karin Volckmann Cusic of Sherborn, MA to whom Britta was a loving, generous and caring ''Auntie Mame,'' and who will always be remembered for her unfailing sense of humor, and first cousin, Harold Classon of Monsey, NY. Other survivors include her niece, Susan Amendola Niemi of New York, and her sister-inlaw, Susanne Amendola Kohut of New York. Interment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY on April 13th at 12 noon. Memorial donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Surviving 'Assassins'

But the studio where the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Assassins'' was ensconced last month was different, and not just because the prop table was littered with unloaded guns and academic studies of violence. More unusual was the ''wall of shame'': dozens of humiliating photos of the cast, from earlier eras of their acting lives, pinned up in a neat array like so many un-Wanted posters. The poorly retouched rsum shot. The unflattering bathing suit candid. The now-bald actor when he had way too much hair.

title: Mary Case, Stewart Mittnacht Jr.
description: Mary Shoemaker Case, a daughter of Frank C. Shoemaker of Princeton, N.J., and the late Ruth Elizabeth Shoemaker, was married yesterday to Stewart Mittnacht Jr., a son of the late Keo England Jordan and the late Stewart Mittnacht. Sallie Manzanet, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Ukrainian Institute of America in New York.

title: At Long Last, a Poet Reigns
description: THE modernist poet Wallace Stevens was said to be ahead of his time, but this is ridiculous. Stevens, who lived in relative -- but comfortably bourgeois -- obscurity in Hartford from 1916 until his death in 1955, is receiving the sort of lionizing in 2004 usually accorded young phenoms.

title: The World; So Many Voices, So Many Versions
description: IN the end, it was the books. Members of the 9/11 commission, which had sought and, last Thursday, finally received public testimony from President Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, came to the event armed with quotations and references to books by Bob Woodward of The Washington Post and Richard A. Clarke, the former National Security Council official.

title: Planet Prada
description: Miuccia Prada has stamped her name on an era by alleviating the isolation of creative people. For such sensitive types, the ultimate luxury is to feel that they are part of a community. This is the service Prada provides. She has made the world safe for people with overdeveloped inner lives.

title: Knocked Out by Rachmaninoff
description: WHEN he was preparing to record Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto with Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony Orchestra in 2000, the pianist Krystian Zimerman closely examined the original manuscript in Philadelphia. On almost every page he found additional pencil marks by Rachmaninoff showing ''where you should really let go and knock yourself out,'' as Mr. Zimerman puts it in notes to the belated Deutsche Grammophon release of that recording. It is coupled with an even older First Concerto by the same performers, recorded in 1997.

title: Diversity's False Solace
description: The university where I have taught for the last three years -- the University of Illinois, Chicago -- is a large, increasingly underfinanced public university. Our classrooms are overcrowded. Our physical plant is deteriorating. Many departments cannot afford to hire any new professors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDEL, DORA (DOROTHY)
description: FRIEDEL--Dora (Dorothy). Devoted wife of the late Irving Friedel, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt and great-aunt. She is survived by her children Celia and Charles Reiner, Walter and Dorothy Friedel, brother Bernard Fox, grandchildren Michael, Eric, Rose, Donald and Connie Reiner, Evan, Erika, Jay, Laura and Gregory Friedel, great grandchildren Daniel and Nicole Reiner and Alexander Friedel and many loving nieces and nephews. Her strength and wisdom will be missed by all who enjoyed her friendship and generosity and by the family who cherished her for all of her 94 years. Services 12 noon, Sunday, April 11, Riverside Chapels, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Coney Island Okie
description: RAMBLIN' MAN

title: 'Disarming Iraq'
description: On the afternoon of Sunday, March 16, 2003, I was in my office on the thirty-first floor of the United Nations Secretariat building in New York, the headquarters of the UN Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission for Iraq (UNMOVIC). Some of my close collaborators had joined me to put the final touches on a work program I was to submit to the Security Council.

title: 'Centennial Crisis'
description: On May 10, 1876, the Centennial Exhibition, commemorating one hundred years of American independence, opened in Philadelphia-the logical place to hold such an exhibition. It was there on July 4, 1776, that the Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence, proclaiming in Thomas Jefferson's stirring words that "these united colonies are, and of Right ought to be, Free and Independent States."

title: Gauging the Worth Of the Chief Executive
description: To the Editor: It is hard to understand why the news media get so excited about compensation of corporate executives -- who, if successful, provide employment and benefits for thousands of people -- and yet do not express dismay over the outrageous amounts paid professional athletes or entertainers (''Is C.E.O. Pay Up or Down? Both.'' April 4).

title: Personal Business; Situation Wanted for Unemployed Professional
description: AFTER a 10-month job search, Thomas Mourer Sr. of Bensalem, Pa., was at his wits' end. He had tried networking with former colleagues and scouring online job sites and newspaper ads, all to no avail. So, in January, he tried a new approach: he placed his own ad in the classified section of the local newspaper, promoting his three decades of management experience.

title: A Change of Scenery
description: MY given name is Michael. When my mother was pregnant with me, she called me Sam. The name stuck. Several months after I was born, my parents changed my birth certificate from Michael Ross to Michael Sam. I've been known as Sam ever since.

title: Vows
description: GAY MARRIAGE

title: Strictly LeWitt, From Wall to Wall, and Then Some
description: SOL LeWITT is well known as an influential minimal artist, although pure minimalism doesn't contain him. His ideas also spill over into conceptual and installation art.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BUSH, JARED WILHELM, PH.D.
description: BUSH--Jared Wilhelm, Ph.D. My Son, three years ago, on April 11, 2001, we buried your body. Your heart had stopped suddenly on the morning of April 8. Thank you for bringing your beauty, creativity, brilliance, strength and joy to our lives. You will always be with us. All our love forever.

title: A Choreograph Of Fire and Training
description: UPSTAIRS in Bridgeport fire headquarters, where framed photos of rescues, house fires and good times crowd the Wall of Flame, a photo of the 30-foot flames that raged around Interstate 95 on March 25 was added recently. It hangs below eye level, below older pictures from more tranquil days. Like the one of Big Moe and the monkey learning to operate Engine Company 1's automatic nozzle with a new remote control gadget. (Someone pasted the monkey next to Big Moe as a joke.)

title: All the Nest Eggs in One Company Basket; Corning Shows Risk of Betting Fortune on Employer
description: In the late 1990's, George Stewart used to eat at a table they called the million-dollar club. Mr. Stewart, now 61, was a machinist for Corning Inc., working the overnight shift for $18.32 an hour. But in his retirement account, composed entirely of Corning stock, he was a millionaire. In 2000, as the stock neared its peak, Mr. Stewart retired, moving his money into a secure bond fund.

title: 'Sons of Camelot'
description: On his third birthday, John F. Kennedy Jr. stood holding his mother's hand as the caisson pulled by six gray horses rolled by, bearing the body of his father. It was a cold day, and John was wearing shorts and a cloth coat. His mother, Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy, whispered to her son, and John saluted his father. This was not a little boy making a stab at a military greeting, but a young actor performing a soldier's salute. Practically everyone in America who viewed the funeral of President John F. Kennedy on television or saw the picture in the newspapers felt a poignant identity with the fatherless child. It was an indelible image, forever frozen in that moment.

title: Dean Hamer, Joseph Wilson
description: Dr. Dean Heilman Hamer and Joseph Hall Wilson were married yesterday. Johanna Hickey, a marriage commissioner in British Columbia, Canada, officiated at Stanley Park, a public park in Vancouver.

title: Coach Fitz's Management Theory
description: I hope parents heard the message: the coach is challenging their children to be the best they can be, while their parents whine and complain.

title: On Second Thought: A Castro Follow-Up
description: AS Oliver Stone completes the editing on his biographical film about Alexander the Great, a dramatic chapter in his own biography is coming to a close. The story of Mr. Stone's film chronicle of Fidel Castro, which began in 2002 with a three-day encounter that resulted in the sympathetic documentary ''Comandante,'' concludes on Wednesday, when HBO broadcasts a more critical follow-up, ''Looking for Fidel.''

title: Spring It On
description: Green is traditionally the color of spring, of growth and of promise. Even the names of the coolest shades this year read like a roster of ''American Idol'' hopefuls: kelly, sage, chartreuse. This season retailers are hopeful, too, banking on green to bring in customers while lining store shelves and racks with verdant offerings in everything from T-shirts to eye shadow. Here are some of the year's best picks.

There is no need to elaborate with my details; just change the names. Lewis's article reads true for many men.

title: Kasparov, at Reykjavik Rapid, Sprints Back to the Top Again
description: Garry Kasparov made a quick recovery from his indifferent play in the Linares Super GM Tournament in Spain by winning the Reykjavik Rapid two weeks later in Iceland. In this double-round-robin knockout format, he won games against Magnus Carlsen, Jan Timman, Peter Heine Nielsen and Nigel Short.

title: U.S. Says Libya Will Convert Missiles to Defensive Weapons
description: In keeping with its pledge to destroy its unconventional weapons, Libya has told American officials that it will convert hundreds of its Scud-B missiles into shorter-range, less powerful weapons for purely defensive purposes and end all military trade with North Korea, American officials said last week.

title: The Emerald Megacities of Southeast Asia
description: THE megacities of Southeast Asia are a dream and a nightmare cohabiting. Emperors could only dream of capitals that so prodigally display might and money; urban planners must wake screaming from visions of massed poverty in the same places. Authors of fairy tales might have dreamed up the architecture while particle physicists sank into reveries of how much energy a mere city could generate. Claustrophobes are condemned to the nightmare of midget apartments that ring with the heavy metal noise; drivers fret the hours away in pinched streets shrouded in gasoline fumes.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Audubon Terrace; An Uptown Pocket With Historic Roots
description: Correction Appended

title: A Washington Bank In a Global Mess
description: EACH January, in honor of Gen. Robert E. Lee's birthday, a group of Washington's movers and shakers gather to rub elbows at the Alfalfa Club dinner. Wizened, impressive and until recently entirely male, the Alfalfa roster includes presidents, politicians, diplomats and business impresarios, all bound together by being either formidably influential or fabulously rich.

title: What's Doin' in Storrs? Just Winning Championships
description: LEAVE it to the 20-year-olds to make fools of themselves in front of the television cameras at the University of Connecticut's Gampel Pavilion. The performance by both the men's and women's basketball teams last week, an unprecedented double national championship, gave any fan license to temporarily lose composure.

title: New Mood Around the Budget
description: HERE is an obvious point: Gov. John G. Rowland has been weakened politically by investigations into gift-giving in his administration. Here is a less obvious one: Mr. Rowland's position may mean more poor people get health care, that schools in the state have more teachers, and that the rich pay for these programs. It could affect whether some mentally retarded people get help from the state and it could change the process of creating a budget itself.

title: Fanfare for the Common Car...
description: LIKE the children in Garrison Keillor's Lake Wobegon, the auto industry's precocious offspring are all above average. The next generation of cars and trucks, on display this week at the New York auto show, are all special, gifted and talented, their manufacturers contend.

title: Editors' Note
description: Frank Rich is on vacation.

title: Tough Times on the Island? Poll and Stats Diverge
description: THE gap dividing the rich and comfortably well-off from nearly everyone else is growing wider on Long Island, and more middle- and lower-middle-income working adults are pessimistic about the region's future and their ability to make ends meet, according to a new report by the Rauch Foundation of Garden City.

title: The Story Line in Iraq
description: Vietnam analogies are deeply imperfect when discussing the war in Iraq. Still, it can't be a good sign for the Bush administration that so many people have begun talking about the Tet offensive.

title: Where a Thousand Flowers (and Disputes) Bloom
description: The shipping channel at its front door and the cemetery out back have long bounded Snug Harbor, the 83-acre swath of wetlands, young forest and overgrown fields that once housed a retirement complex for penniless sailors. Since the 1970's, the borough's Botanical Garden has flourished there among the workshops and dormitories of the former sailors' home.

title: Art That Wears $780 Shoes
description: IN the 1990's fashion photography took a sharp turn away from the glamour goddesses of the past and toward a new image: pictures that challenged our notion of physical beauty, that made clothing subservient to sensibility and narrative, that, in some cases, did away with clothing or models entirely.

Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, at Fordham University on Tuesday from 10 AM to 12 noon. Mass of Christian Burial at the Murray Weigel Hall Chapel, Tuesday 12 noon. title: Done With 'Caligula,' Ready to Play Martha
description: OVER a nearly 40-year career in theater and film, Helen Mirren has managed a tricky balance: to be almost equally well known for her talent and for her willingness to get naked. She's been a serious sexpot from ''Caligula'' (1979) through ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' (1989) to last year's ''Calendar Girls.''

title: A 1762 Fable, Set in a Theme Park

title: Taking Home A Hotel Room
description: PETER GREENBERG, the travel editor for the ''Today'' show, faced the daunting task of building a new house after his Los Angeles home was flattened by an earthquake 10 years ago. But when his architect asked him to describe an ideal surrounding, Mr. Greenberg, who visits dozens of hotels a year, had a revelation. Nearly everything he liked, from sofas to swimming pools to shower heads, hailed from hotels. With that understood, outfitting his new house proved easy. ''With very few exceptions, almost everything you see at hotels is for sale,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 21 about how the White House handles information and pointing out the thin line between spin and deception misquoted former President Bill Clinton. Early in 1998, referring to Monica Lewinsky, he said, "I did not have sexual relations with that woman,'' not "I did not have sex with that woman.''

title: Lexical Lessons; What the Good Book Says: Anti-Semitism, Loosely Defined
description: MERRIAM-WEBSTER found itself on the defensive recently over a 40-year-old definition of ''anti-Semitism'' in its Third New International Dictionary, the monumental unabridged edition originally published in 1961 and reprinted in 2002. In addition to the conventional sense of the word as ''hostility toward Jews as a racial or religious minority group,'' the dictionary included a second sense as ''opposition to Zionism: sympathy with opponents of the state of Israel.''

title: Corrections
description: Areport on the Travel Advisory page on March 14 about an Irish celebration of the admission of new members to the European Union included an outdated reference to a rock concert on May 1 in Dublin. After the section had gone to press, the concert was canceled when the city refused to grant permission to hold it on O'Connell Street and the BBC, one of two main sponsors, refused to accept another location.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HART, ANNA
description: HART--Anna. Our mother, our grandmother, our fearless leader and our great friend: Happy 100th Birthday! We are so very grateful to have enjoyed and to continue to enjoy your kinship and companionship. You are our strength, our courage and our hero. For those of us who love you so dearly, you are ''still here.'' Love Always, Helen, Elizabeth and Christopher

description: The national headquarters of the Dannon Company will be leaving its Tarrytown offices for Greenburgh this fall, allowing its more than 200 employees to remain in Westchester County, said a company spokeswoman, Anna Moses.

title: Diversify! Diversify! Well, Not So Fast
description: ONE of the more controversial beliefs of Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, is that diversification is not always good. If you are a ''know-something investor,'' he wrote in a 1993 letter to shareholders, spreading your bets among a large number of stocks is likely ''to hurt your results and increase your risk.'' A new academic study finds that Mr. Buffett may be right.

title: On Writers and Writing; I Wish I Had Said That, and I Will
description: I used to wish I could live through the words of other writers. Unpleasant questions would be parried with crisp couplets and song lyrics; strong feelings and opinions would be given third-person protection. I wouldn't have to censor myself because my own prose wasn't up to the mark. Unreliable or omniscient, I would be the narrator in control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, LORELEI
description: LEWIS--Lorelei. Died unexpectedly at St. Vincent's Hospital on April 5. Lorelei worked in radio, early television, and book publishing. For twenty years, she was a reporter for Star magazine. Passionate and positive, Lorelei was an unfailing source of support and comfort to her many friends. In her memory, those who knew her may wish to adopt or foster a homeless pet, or contribute to an animal shelter. Or they may learn to tango really well.

title: 'The Fabric of the Cosmos'
description: None of the books in my father's dusty old bookcase were forbidden. Yet while I was growing up, I never saw anyone take one down. Most were massive tomes-a comprehensive history of civilization, matching volumes of the great works of western literature, numerous others I can no longer recall-that seemed almost fused to shelves that bowed slightly from decades of steadfast support. But way up on the highest shelf was a thin little text that, every now and then, would catch my eye because it seemed so out of place, like Gulliver among the Brobdingnagians. In hindsight, I'm not quite sure why I waited so long before taking a look. Perhaps, as the years went by, the books seemed less like material you read and more like family heirlooms you admire from afar. Ultimately, such reverence gave way to teenage brashness. I reached up for the little text, dusted it off, and opened to page one. The first few lines were, to say the least, startling.

title: Secrecy at Catholic Schools Frustrates Parents and Teachers

In an odd twist on the usual Catholic school dilemma, they are collecting signatures - not money - to keep John Burke, the man who has been principal, chief fund-raiser and neighborhood advocate for more than 32 years.

title: Coach Fitz's Management Theory
description: My Coach Fitz was a tweed-suited, chain-smoking, red-pencil-wielding high-school English teacher named Margaret Tuck. She came to school an hour early, on her own time, to meet with students individually to review our written work. I went back as an adult to thank her. Now I realize I should have thanked my parents too, for letting me rise to Mrs. Tuck's challenge instead of complaining about it.

title: Painter's Deft Touch On Civil War Life
description: MORT KNSTLER always does copious research before he starts his Civil War paintings. A historian as well as an artist, Mr. Knstler incorporates as much meticulously accurate detail as possible. He uses memorabilia as models and often visits the site of an event before he lets his imagination fill in the scene.

title: The Rewards of Growing Japanese Primroses
description: IN mid-April, when most gardeners are still raking up autumn leaves, Paul Held is already surveying his suburban Connecticut garden for blossoms. By the third week in April, when his neighbors are lucky to have a few precocious daffodils and signs of life in their tulip beds, Mr. Held's one-acre front-yard garden is bristling with flowers. For the next few weeks, he will have a hard time wading through it.

title: A Drop in Price, but Not in Star Appeal
description: KATHARINE HEPBURN'S nine-bedroom house facing Long Island Sound went on the market last fall, several months after the actress died in June. Attended James Madison High School in Brooklyn; received bachelor and law degrees from University of Chicago. Lieutenant U.S. Navy 1955-1958; 35 year partner in the Chicago firm Solomon & Behrendt. Beloved and adoring husband of Lois Adelman; cherished father of Adam Solomon and Elizabeth Hubbard; loving brother of Mimi Sheraton; devoted father-inlaw of Jeff Hubbard and proud grandfather of four; admired brother-in-law of Richard Falcone and uncle of Marc Falcone. May he sleep the sleep of the just. Memorial to be announced.

title: Local Fans Tuned In For Title Experiences
description: At least half of the Hartford-New Haven television market was watching the University of Connecticut basketball teams win their national championships on Monday and Tuesday nights, according to Nielsen Media Research.

title: Can This Marriage Be Saved?
description: For many years, the Log Cabin Republicans have known the particular torment of being aligned with a cause easily lampooned as ridiculous. You are a what? they are asked in various ways. A gay Republican? A gay conservative? What does that even mean? And by the way, don't you know that your so-called allies actually despise you? ''You're attacked in social settings,'' Patrick Guerriero, Log Cabin's executive director, told me. ''You lose dates. It's not easy.'' What is even more difficult, though, is to have your loyalty thrown back in your face by the very people with whom you have united -- and to arrive at that moment of truth when you must acknowledge that those who have confronted you, or snickered behind your back, may, in fact, have a point.

title: Storms, Natural and Political, at Library
description: AT the century-old Mount Vernon Public Library, the roof is falling in, rooms are closed to the public and books have been ruined. Mildew molders, lead paint peels and asbestos remains unabated. Everybody seems to agree that the library needs help, and fast. But city and state officials are at odds over money and the method of running the library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPECTOR, CHARLES
description: SPECTOR--Charles. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Monica and Joel Greenberg, Brian and Madeline Spector, and Emily and Thomas Piovoso. Cherished grandfather of Chelsey and Melissa Greenberg, Charlotte and Suzanne Spector, and Juliette and Caroline Piovoso. Dear brother of Joel and Sunny Spector. Services were held on April 5.

title: Crime
description: How's that again? Any reader familiar with Lawrence Block's whimsical whodunits featuring Bernie Rhodenbarr, an amiable Greenwich Village bookseller who moonlights as a burglar, already knows that the shaggy dog plots rely heavily on coincidence and require absurdly complicated explanations. Being a great kidder, Block carries these quirks to hilarious extremes in his 10th series mystery, THE BURGLAR ON THE PROWL (Morrow, $24.95), with a convoluted story in which Bernie crosses paths with Russian mobsters, Latvian patriots and a shady plastic surgeon, all of them desperate to get their hands on a copy of ''The Secret Agent,'' by Joseph Conrad. Or is it ''QB VII,'' by Leon Uris?

title: Warring Militias in Congo Test U.N. Enforcement Role
description: In this scrappy frontier town in eastern Congo, the United Nations faces among the most important tests of its peacekeeping prowess.

title: Joseph J. Zimmermann Jr., 92, an Inventor, Is Dead
description: Joseph J. Zimmermann Jr., who invented one of the first commercially successful answering machines, ancestor of sleeker later generations, died March 31 in Brookfield, Wis. He was 92.

title: A Story From A to Z, With Lots of Detours
description: POPPY JOHNSON is a performance-installation artist who likes ''to set up situations that can sometimes quickly veer out of control.'' John Hawke is a businessman who collects antique typewriters because he ''likes old machines.''

title: Editors' Note; Political Points
description: John Tierney is on vacation. The Political Points column will return next Sunday.

title: Inquiry Into Attack on the Cole In 2000 Missed Clues to 9/11
description: The American investigators probing the October 2000 terrorist attack against the Navy destroyer Cole came tantalizingly close to detecting the Sept. 11 plot, F.B.I. and C.I.A. officials now say. But the government missed the significance of a series of clues because some investigators believed that the evidence fit narrowly into their case against the ship bombers and, others say, they did not have access to all the information.

title: Recycling for Profit
description: A 17-year-old relative participated in a school ecology-club event in which people dropped off computers, cellphones and TV's to be recycled. Afterward, he brought home a box full of these things, as did some other volunteers. Later, I discovered that he sold some of the stuff. I think this is a major ethical breach; he disagrees. What do you think? J.P., Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: ...Amid a Luxury Landscape
description: A VISIT to the New York International Auto Show serves as a reminder that the car business is a lot like the Indianapolis 500 -- minus the finish line.

title: To Read the Menu, Baby Boomers Turn To Eye Treatments
description: A few months ago, George Miller, 55, a computer sales manager in Lexington, S.C., had reading glasses scattered all over the house. Worse, he found it was impossible to read a menu at night in a dimly lighted restaurant or the many car magazines that came to his house. ''It really bothered me a lot because I love to read,'' Mr. Miller said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMAN, EDITH
description: SELIGMAN--Edith. Beloved friend died on March 6, 2004. Brilliant bridge teacher and mentor to so many students. You were always so full of life and generous with your time. Edith had taught bridge for 15 years at the New York City Cavendish Bridge Club, known as the bridge capitol of the world. She won several national women's bridge tournaments given by the American Contract Bridge League. Among Edith's partners have been two United States Presidents, several state's governors and many known celebrities. She was predeceased by her husband Erwin and son George. Born in Midnight, Mississippi, the former Edith learned bridge as a child. Before becoming a teacher, she was well known as a singer, appearing at Carnegie Hall, the Waldorf-Astoria and other prominent hotels. ''Bridge is a must for men, women and children claims the author of 'How to Bid your Best in Bridge', it stimulates the brain, has therepeutic value and is a social asset.'' We your students and loving friends will sadly miss you.

title: Coach Fitz's Management Theory
description: Although I played basketball under Fitz more than 20 years ago, hardly a week goes by that I do not recall the experience. My teammates with whom I keep in touch tell me they think about those days as well. Remarkably, we are not just a bunch of high-school athletes recalling our ''glory days'' but rather remembering the lessons that Fitz taught us. If educators who challenge kids to be their best, instill discipline and demand pride in their effort are becoming an anachronism, then we really are in trouble.

title: Wing Nut
description: Sometimes a new or offbeat word or phrase is used in common parlance for years before it sees print. Occasionally our computers' search engines, prowling the world of words for everything written or transcribed, can pick up an isolated usage.

title: Coach Fitz's Management Theory
description: I thoroughly enjoyed the article. We had Coach Savage (you can't make these names up) as our high-school wrestling coach. He had us for three hours each day after school. He would tape the windows so that inquiring parents (there were very few at that time) and school administrators could not interfere with his style. He was a life mentor to many of us.

description: MELLE, Belgium  Bjarne Riis knows what most people are saying about the Kelme drug scandal in Spain and what some people are thinking about his CSC team from Denmark, and he is angry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMS, ROGER B.
description: SIMS--Roger B., a retired TV producer and one of the first three African-American graduates of the United States Air Force Academy, died in his sleep on February 2 in his home in Everett, WA. He was 65. Born in Chicago and raised in Brooklyn, Mr. Sims attended Howard University for three years before entering the Academy. He flew missions throughout the Far East including Viet Nam. From 1969 until illness forced him to retire in 1991 Mr. Sims worked for NBC and CBS. He was a producer on the Evening News with Walter Cronkite and Sunday Morning with Charles Kuralt. He was nominated for two national Emmy Awards. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: U.S. Takes Davis Cup Lead As the Bryans Beat Sweden
description: The Bryan twins, Bob and Mike, are virtually inseparable. They live in the same house, drive the same car and have the same e-mail address, bank account and phone number. They are also the world's top-ranked doubles team, and on Saturday they staked the United States to a 2-1 lead over Sweden in a Davis Cup quarterfinal.

title: Coach Fitz's Management Theory
description: With pinpoint accuracy and hilarious self-knowledge, Michael Lewis nailed the queasy business of growing up. It was wonderful and awful. I snorted in appreciation as I read the article and turned back the pages to read it again.

title: Rossini, Hold the Pasta Sauce
description: TO a large segment of the public today, the music of Gioacchino Rossini evokes pasta-sauce commercials and Bugs Bunny. Even among serious operagoers, Rossini is thought of primarily as Italian and funny. Small wonder, then, that his opera ''Ermione'' isn't performed more often, since it is neither particularly Italian nor funny. In his day, Rossini was branded ''Germanic'' for his startling harmonies and lavish orchestration. And the libretto of ''Ermione'' comes from Greek tragedy by way of the great French playwright Jean Racine.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JUDY GONZLEZ has a new boyfriend but tells her best friend, ''Just think of him as bug spray.'' In Peter Sollett's RAISING VICTOR VARGAS (2002), the teenage title character (Victor Rasuk) thinks he's a ladies' man, but Judy (Judy Marte) is just using him to keep all those other obnoxious boys from bothering her. Victor's other problem is that he lives with his grandmother (Altagracia Guzman), a no-nonsense woman who does not approve of young boys having sex lives. So she decides to throw him out. Meanwhile, Victor finds out the truth about his relationship with Judy and asks, bitterly, how she kept guys away before. ''Mace,'' she says -- Tuesday at 11:20 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 2:45 a.m. on Starz.

title: Charting the Tarantino Universe
description: EVER since ''Kill Bill Vol. 1'' was released last October, Internet movie message boards have been buzzing about the numerous references that Quentin Tarantino's action revenge film makes to the rich tradition of Asian genre filmmaking -- both Hong Kong kung fu movies and the Japanese swordfight flicks. With the release on Friday of ''Kill Bill Vol. 2,'' Mr. Tarantino's grand design becomes clear: where the first part of his epic took place under the sign of the East, the second is largely devoted to the West -- that is, the American and European traditions of revenge movies, particularly the American western.

''We had no idea we were part of a historic district,'' she said. ''We had to appeal for an exception to a ruling we didn't know existed.''

If it has any hope of surviving this Hobbesian moment, we need three conversations to happen fast: George Bush needs to talk to his father, the Arab leaders need to talk to their sons -- and daughters -- and we need to talk to the Iraqi Governing Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHIFF, FRANK
description: SCHIFF--Frank, age 83, died on April 8, after a brief illness. He is survived by Gloria Schiff, his devoted wife of 50 years, and by loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Schiff was educated at Lawrenceville School and then Hamilton College where he was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon. In 1941, he joined the Air Force and rose to the rank of Captain, working in intelligence with the 9th Air Force. His assignments took him to northern Europe, beginning in Normandy and continuing through France, Belgium and into Germany. After he was discharged from the service, he joined the family business, Schiff Terhune Inc. He served as President and later as Chairman and CEO of Schiff Terhune International. In 1982, the company merged with Alexander & Alexander where Mr. Schiff remained in the position of Vice Chairman until his retirement in 1988. Frank Schiff was Chapter Chairman of the Young Presidents Organization, a Director of the Travelers Aid Society of N.Y., and Chairman of the United Service Organization. He was an avid sportsman and member of Piping Rock Club and the Meadow Club in Southampton. Mr. Schiff will be greatly missed by his family and friends for his generous source of wit and humor. Funeral services will be private.

title: 3 Killings Put South Africa on Edge as Elections Near
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 11  With South Africa's national elections only four days away, the killings of three political workers in KwaZulu Natal Province this weekend have heightened concerns that a longtime struggle for power there may bubble over into further strife.

title: BACKING DISTRICTS WITHOUT SCHOOLS
description: The legislative committee of the New Jersey School Boards Association has voted against an economy measure by the state Department of Education to eliminate 23 nonoperating school districts -- those that, because they have no schools of their own, now send students to neighboring districts. The association's board of directors is expected to take action on the committee's recommendation next month. A 90-year-old federation of the state's local boards, the association has criticized Governor McGreevey for saying in his state of the state address that he planned to eliminate nonoperating districts because ''they oversee nothing but their own existence.'' Each such district has a part-time administrator who handles tuition and transportation bills and makes $10,000 to $15,000 a year. The Department of Education plan would dissolve the districts and transfer their duties to their respective municipal governments at an estimated savings of $750,000 statewide. But representatives of the 23 districts, at a meeting April 3, argued that municipalities have no experience in school education and finance matters. George James

title: Poking Holes in Beautiful Art, and Getting Paid for It, Too
description: A few years ago, Bortolot Daybreak, a Connecticut firm that specializes in the authentication of ancient objects, was asked by a New York City African art dealer to examine some Nigerian ceramic sculptures. Victor Bortolot, a scientist and the owner of the company, found the objects to be made mostly of new materials, but the dealer blacked out the negative determination, then sold the items as antiques. Later, he was indicted, jailed and released on bail, and then skipped town.

Khabibulin had posted a shutout in Game 1 of this first-round series, and he was doing his crablike best on Saturday to keep the Lightning close in Game 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRULLY, L. VINCENT, MD, FACS
description: STRULLY--L. Vincent, MD, FACS, of Fair Lawn, NJ died April 10, 2004. He was 90. Son of Jacques M. Strully, DMD and Rebecca Waisman Strully. Dr. Strully was born on March 6, 1914 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Hamilton College, Clinton, NY in 1934 and received his medical degree in 1938 from Long Island College of Medicine (now Downstate Medical School). During WWII, he was a Lieutenant in the Navy and served in the European Theater from 1934 to 1946. For 40 years, he maintained an active medical practice at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Claire Kleinfeld Strully, his two children, L. Vincent Strully, Jr. of Cambridge, MA and Maxine R. Strully, of Fair Lawn, NJ and his former daughter-in-law, Marylou Sudders of Cambridge, MA. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday, April 13, 2004 at 1:30 PM at the Louis Suburban Chapels, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the New England Center for Children, 33 Turnpike Rd., Southborough, MA 01772.

title: The Kids and the Show Were Both Square Pegs
description: In the annals of life stress, having one's favorite show go off the air is probably not up there with, say, the death of a loved one. But for fans of shows like ''Once and Again,'' ''Firefly,'' ''The Tick,'' ''Greg the Bunny,'' ''Andy Richter Controls the Universe'' and the newly canceled ''Wonderfalls,'' theirs (let's be honest: mine) is a special pain. Particularly mourned are the one-season beauties like ''My So-Called Life,'' series that died in a state of grace. I'm personally afraid to become a fan of ''Arrested Development.'' Who needs the agita?

description: I could not disagree with Ms. DiGrazia more concerning the Valley being a great place to live. My wife and I, both artists, have been here in Shelton for six years and can't wait to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARCLAY, JOHN WILLIAMS
description: BARCLAY--John Williams. Born in New Haven, CT, August 6, 1913, the son of Albert Hampton Barclay, an attorney, and Laura Williams Barclay, who was originally from Rochester, NY. Educated at Phillips Academy, Andover, and then Yale, class of 1936, he received his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1939. He was admitted to the Connecticut bar in that year, and to the New York bar in 1940 and then joined the law firm of Barclay and Barclay with his father and brother. He joined the Navy in 1941, and served in the Pacific from 1943 to 1946 as an air combat intelligence officer on the aircraft carrier Hornet. In 1957, Barclay and Barclay joined with Thompson, Weir and MacDonald form the law firm of Thompson, Weir and Barclay. Mr. Barclay continued to practice law into his eighties, after Thompson, Weir, and Barclay merged with Murtha, Cullina, Richter and Pinney, LLP of Hartford and New Haven. Mr. Barclay s first wife, the former Alice Sturges of Providence, RI, died in 1962. He was married for thirty-six years to Eleanor Paul Barclay, who died in 2000. He leaves his wife, Stratton Nicolson Barclay of Old Lyme, a daughter Louise Rice, of Cambridge MA, a son, John Whitney Barclay, of Winston Salem, NC, a daughter, Nina Barclay, of Norwich, CT, a step daughter, Elizabeth Bohlen of Cambridge, MA, seven grandchildren and a great granddaughter. A memorial service will be held at 12:00 PM, Saturday, April 17th at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Rte 156, Old Lyme, CT. There will be no calling hours and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Ann's Episcopal Church. For information contact Swan Funeral Home, 1224 Boston Post Road, Old Saybrook, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PURDY, GORDON L.
description: PURDY--Gordon L., 89, of Speculator, NY, former Director of CAMP - of - the WOODS, died Sunday, March 21, 2004 in Melbourne, FL. Gordon, born in Canada, came to a NY summer camp job in 1933 and surrendered his heart to Jesus Christ there. This changed his life and eternity. He soon became assistant to George Tibbitts in operating the camp. In 1939 he married Ann Rask of Springfield, MA. He was Director from 1948-1986, overseeing expansive growth in the camp's development and ministry. He was a pioneer organizer of Christian Camping International and served on numerous mission and business boards. His passion was serving Christ at CAMP-of-the-WOODS, with excellence. Survived by his wife of 64 years, Ann; four married children; eight grandchildren; six greatgrandchildren. Services will be June 5th in NY. Memorial gifts only to Missions/CAMPof-the-WOODS or Speculator Ambulance Corps, Speculator, NY 12164.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATTOON, HENRY AMASA, JR.
description: MATTOON--Henry Amasa, Jr. 90, retired ad executive, died at his home in Danville, California, March 8, 2004. Mr. Mattoon or Ham as he was best known, was born January 14, 1914, in Waterbury, CT., son of Henry Amasa and Sarah Currie Hallock Mattoon. Ham's wife of 62 years, Dorothy Teeter Mattoon, preceded him in death in 1996. After graduating Yale University with a degree in Electrical Engineering in 1935, Ham started his sixty year advertising career in the mailroom at Compton Advertising in New York City. He swiftly rose to copywriter, manager, vice president, and partner at firms including Ruthrauff and Ryan, Dancer - Fitzgerald Sample, Reach Yates and Mattoon, and McCann Erickson. He will be remembered for his extraordinary vocabulary, linguistic virtuosity, and gleeful sense of humor. His M&M candies slogan, ''The Chocolate Melts in Your Mouth, Not in Your Hand,'' is an Advertising Age top 15 alltime best slogan. Ham loved organic gardening, flew Civil Air Patrol sea planes in the 1940s, and was a founder and president of the Weston Field Club in Weston, CT., his family's home for 40 years. In 1985, Ham was honored by the ecumenical Knights of Malta. Ham is survived by his children; Ann Mattoon Wofford, David Scott Mattoon, Sara Halsey Mattoon, Judith Mattoon Conn; sister Virginia Young, four grandchildren, Scott Alexander Mattoon, Elizabeth Wofford Busboom, William Halsey Mattoon, Catherine Halsey Wofford; and five great-grandchildren. Memorials to Hope Hospice, 6500 Dublin Blvd., Suite 100, Dublin, CA 94568.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIZAVI, SYED ALAY ZAMIN, M.D.
description: RIZAVI--Syed Alay Zamin, M.D. Died Wednesday, March 24, 2004 at home in New York City. A doctor to the core, his compassion, kindness and goodness knew no bounds. He showed his family and friends how to combine confidence, competence, humility and warmth. He was the son of Alay Nabi, the Mayor of Agra, India, and member of the Parliament and Moquidissa and was the youngest of six children. Dr. Rizavi was raised in Agra, and moved to Karachi, Pakistan. He attended King Edward Medical College and specialized in Cardiology and Tropical Diseases in Edinburgh, Scotland. Dr. Rizavi returned to practice medicine in Pakistan as Civil Surgeon of Karachi. He then worked at New York Hospital on a World Health Organization scholarship, and in 1976, he and his family moved to Evanston, IL, and then Winnetka, IL. Dr. Rizavi practiced medicine at Evanston Hospital from 1975 until 2003, when he moved to New York City. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, son-in-law, as well as three grandchildren, two brothers, a sister and many nieces and nephews. We cherished our moments with him and he will be with us in spirit. Memorial gifts should be directed to Evanston Northwestern Healthcare Foundation, Dr. Rizavi Memorial, 1603 Orrington, Suite 750, Evanston, IL 60201, 847-570-5601. Funds will be used to establish an annual award in Dr. Rizavi's name, to be given to the medical resident who best exemplifies his dedication and generosity of spirit.

description: SCHEIN--David. 67. Died April 6, 2004 in Ogunquit, ME. Born in Providence, RI, July 26, 1936, the son of Joseph and Ruth (Fink) Schein and husband of Anita Lauten Schein. He graduated from Classical HS, Providence, RI, in 1954 and from Harvard College in 1958 where he played varsity football. Received a Master's Degree from the Harvard Graduate School of Education and while there coached Harvard football. He had a forty - year distinguished career as a progressive educator and was the founding principal of Blind Brook HS (Rye Brook, NY), the principal of Irvington HS (NY), Sharon HS (MA), Clarkstown S. HS (NY) and Glen Rock HS (NJ) from which he retired. For many years, he ran the family business at Camps Mendota and Deertrees in Maine which engendered his love for teaching and the outdoors. He is survived by his wife of twenty-five years Anita Lauten Schein; daughters Debbie Jacobs and her husband Phil of Fairfield, CT and Margie Weston and her husband Brian of Katonah, NY; his mother Ruth Schein and brother Michael Schein both of Toronto; and five grandchildren Marc and Alec Jacobs, Betsy, Caroline and Scott Weston. title: Production Rises in China
description: China's National Bureau of Statistics announced on Friday that industrial production was 19.4 percent higher in March than a year earlier. Educated at Phillips Academy, Andover, and then Yale, class of 1936, he received his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1939. He was admitted to the Connecticut bar in that year, and to the New York bar in 1940 and then joined the law firm of Barclay and Barclay with his father and brother. He joined the Navy in 1941, and served in the Pacific from 1943 to 1946 as an air combat intelligence officer on the aircraft carrier Hornet. In 1957, Barclay and Barclay joined with Thompson, Weir and MacDonald form the law firm of Thompson, Weir and Barclay. Mr. Barclay continued to practice law into his eighties, after Thompson, Weir, and Barclay merged with Murtha, Cullina, Richter and Pinney, LLP of Hartford and New Haven. Mr. Barclay s first wife, the former Alice Sturges of Providence, RI, died in 1962. He was married for thirty-six years to Eleanor Paul Barclay, who died in 2000. He leaves his wife, Stratton Nicolson Barclay of Old Lyme, a daughter Louise Rice, of Cambridge MA, a son, John Whitney Barclay, of Winston Salem, NC, a daughter, Nina Barclay, of Norwich, CT, a step daughter, Elizabeth Bohlen of Cambridge, MA, seven grandchildren and a great granddaughter. A memorial service will be held at 12:00 PM, Saturday, April 17th at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Rte 156, Old Lyme, CT. There will be no calling hours and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Ann's Episcopal Church. For information contact Swan Funeral Home, 1224 Boston Post Road, Old Saybrook, CT.

title: The Silent President
description: President Bush was asked, during a very brief session with reporters yesterday, about the now-famous Aug. 6, 2001, memo he received on domestic terrorism. He responded with the familiar White House complaint about lack of specificity in the C.I.A.'s warnings -- although the memo mentioned a plot, possibly involving hijacked planes and New York City. The most striking thing about the president's comment, however, was his bottom line: that he did everything he could. Over the last few weeks we have heard lawmakers and officials from two administrations talk about their feelings of responsibility, about how they compulsively re-examine the events leading up to 9/ll, asking themselves whether they could have done anything to avert the terrible disaster that day. It is beginning to seem that the only person free of that kind of self-examination is the man who was chief executive when the attacks occurred.

title: C-Sections and the Real Crime
description: Prosecutors in Salt Lake City announced last week that they had dropped charges of homicide against a woman who delayed a Cesarean section despite doctors' advice that it was necessary to save the lives of her twins. It was a step in the right direction, but the decision to criminalize the woman's choice -- one of her twins was later delivered stillborn, the other survived with complications, and the mother has pleaded guilty to child endangerment -- was wrong from the start. Not because it violated a patient's general right to privacy or a woman's specific right to make her own choices about reproduction (though it did). The charge was disturbing because it implied that the medical establishment can predict with certainty the best course of action for a fetus in distress. It cannot.

Eight are reported dead near Parkin, three in Guion, six in Lorado, two in Wynne. In the latter town the bodies of two children, known to be dead, have not been recovered.

title: No Rap but Just About Everything Else for Blake Cycle

All that was missing were lighting effects and projections of Blake's engravings, suggested in the score. But they were on display in the lobby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   USLAN, SEYMOUR
description: USLAN--Seymour. June 12, 1921-April 11, 2004. Cherished father, devoted grandfather and great-grandfather, and friend to many. He is survived by his daughter Sheila Jacobs and her husband Harvey; grandchildren Ari Jacobs and his wife Melissa, and Matthew Jacobs and his wife Robin; and great-grandchildren Alex and Ethan Jacobs. He was predeceased by his devoted wife Minna. Known to all as Sy, he rallied friends and family to find love and humor in everyday living. Sy earned a degree in engineering and served his country with honor and distinction during WWII, obtaining top secret clearance to work on projects that brought an early end to the War. Sy founded AMPHOTO, a photographic book publishing company. In his retirement, he was a resident of Classic Residents by Hyatt, where his dynamic personality created an atmosphere of warmth and liveliness. Sy will be sorely missed. title: MEMO PAD
description: 15.2 MILLION FREE TRIPS -- More than 15.2 million passengers traveled during 2003 using frequent-flier awards on major domestic airlines surveyed, according to IdeaWorks, a consulting firm. IdeaWorks reviewed financial reports by various airlines to calculate the data. Comparable numbers for previous years were not available, but airlines maintain that free-trip awards have held steady in recent years as a percentage of total revenue passenger miles. In 2003, IdeaWorks estimated that frequent-flier awards trips represented an average of about 7.9 percent of revenue passenger miles on 10 airlines studied, said Jay Sorensen, the firm's president.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Taliban Say They Killed Spy Chief
description: A Taliban spokesman claimed the movement had executed the intelligence chief of Uruzgan Province and two of his bodyguards after kidnapping them several days ago, and threatened to increase attacks in southern Afghanistan. The Uruzgan governor warned that if the men had been killed, he would retaliate by killing Taliban prisoners. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Profit Rises
description: Posco, the world's third-largest steel maker, said first-quarter profit rose 54 percent as demand from China's builders and automakers drove prices higher. Net income rose to 720 billion won ($630 million), from 468.7 billion won a year earlier, the company said. Posco, which is based in Pohang, raised its forecast for 2004 sales by 3 percent, to 17.4 trillion won, and for operating profit to 3.7 trillion won, from 3.2 trillion won. First-quarter operating profit rose 30 percent, to 1 trillion won, on sales that grew 31 percent, to 4.3 trillion won. Prices almost doubled in the last year for steel sold in China, which used a third of global supply in 2003.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Balance Rises

The surplus in the account, which includes travel and financial services in addition to merchandise trade flows, was 2.15 trillion yen, slightly more than estimates by private economists. The increase was the eighth in a row and suggests that Japan's economic recovery is continuing to get a strong push from exports. Todd Zaun (NYT)
