title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Motion To Drop Bomb Charges
description: Lawyers for Terry L. Nichols have asked that state murder charges against him in the Oklahoma City bombing case be dismissed, disputing the state's contention that it has withheld no relevant evidence. In their motion, the defense lawyers said the state refused to turn over documents and a videotape showing that other people, not Mr. Nichols, helped Timothy J. McVeigh in the 1995 bombing. Mr. McVeigh was executed after being convicted on federal charges. Mr. Nichols, who was sentenced to life in prison in the federal case, faces 161 charges of first-degree murder in the state case. The state is seeking the death penalty against Mr. Nichols. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Television Acquisition
description: Chum, which owns eight television stations in Canada, has agreed to buy the closely held Craig Media for 265 million Canadian dollars ($199 million) to expand in the West. The purchase will be financed with bank debt, Chum said. Buying Craig gives Chum, whose TV assets are mainly in Ontario, TV stations in the largest cities in Alberta and Manitoba. The Craig family put its company, Canada's largest closely held broadcaster, up for sale in January as troubles selling ads cut into sales. ''The business environment in Canada was challenging to say the least in terms of the ad market,'' Craig's chief executive, Drew Craig, said. Craig is based in Calgary, Alberta, and Chum is in Toronto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERG, SR. MAJELLA, RSHM
description: BERG--Sr. Majella, RSHM. The Board of Trustees, the President, the faculty and administration of Marymount Manhattan College join our sister institution Marymount University of Arlington, VA in mourning the passing on April 5, 2004 of Sr. Magella Berg of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary. Sr. Magella served as the first registrar of Marymount Manhattan College before becoming the President of Marymount in Arlington, where she served for 33 years. The order allows employees to ask about the status only in specific situations: when such disclosure is required by law, for example, or when the resident is suspected of unlawful activity other than being in the country illegally. Mr. Baldacci, a Democrat, signed the order after meetings with social service, civil rights and community organizations. The sessions were held to help ease relations between the groups and state officials after Border Patrol agents swept through stores, restaurants and a homeless shelter in Portland in January. She graduated from the Lincoln School in 1941. During the second World War, she worked for the Red Cross and later, in Washington, DC, as Assistant to Chinese Ambassador Wellington Koo. A Greenwich resident of over 50 years, she was a former President of the Greenwich Kennel Club, founding member of L.O.S.T.S. Investment Club and secretary of the English Speaking Union. She was a realtor with Cleveland Duble & Arnold for over 30 years. Predeceased by her husband Gerard, she is survived by her beloved children, Chantal Curtis of Greenwich, CharlesEtienne Aubertin of London and granddaughter Caroline Curtis; two sisters, Mrs. John (Nancy) Keay of PA, Mrs. Cornelius (Joan) Provost of Maine and devoted in-laws Comtesse Pierre de Laguiche and M. and Mme. Michel Aubertin of Paris. A memorial service will be held at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT on April 29 at 2:00 P.M. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSBORNE, STANLEY DE J.
description: OSBORNE--Stanley de J. The Boards, Physicians, and Staff of New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Stanley de J. Osborne. Mr. Osborne became a member of the Board of Governors of The New York Hospital in 1957 and served as President of the Board from 1975 to 1980. His presidential legacy to the Hospital included the establishment of the William Randolph Hearst Burn Center, the first comprehensive burn center in New York City and the largest civilian burn care facility in the nation. Following his term as President, he continued to give distinguished service to the Board as a Life Governor. In 1998, he became a Life Trustee of New YorkPresbyterian Hospital. We extend our deepest condolences to his children, Richard de J. Osborne, Mary Osborne Witherbee, and Cynthia Osborne Hoskin. John J. Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

Mrs. Hampford was born in St. Clair, PA, on March 21, 1936, the daughter of Martin and Clare McCarthy Malarkey. She was a graduate of Pottsville Catholic High School and Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY. Tee was an active community volunteer who was primarily interested in children and education. She served on numerous local boards and commissions including 12 years as a member of the Trumbull Board of Education, six of those as Chairman. Hampford Jr., and his wife Andrea of Trumbull, Anne Hampford of Westport, Marty Hampford of Shelton and Tim Hampford and his wife Lori Carroll of Trumbull, eight grandchildren, Katy, Grace and Jimmy Donahue, Johnny and Will Hampford and Mia, Clare and Maeve Hampford. Friends may attend a Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, at 10 am, in St. Theresa Church, Trumbull, with interment to follow in Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Friends may call on Tuesday from 4 to 8 pm, in the Redgate - Hennessy Funeral Home, Main Street and Gorham Place, Trumbull. In lieu of flowers those who so desire may make contributions to the Clare M. Hampford Media Center at Trumbull High School or the Class of 1958 Scholarship Fund at Manhattanville College.

The instructor, a poet named Jan Richman, subsequently found herself out of a job. The university chose not to explain its failure to renew Ms. Richman's contract, but she intimated that she was being punished for having set the tone for the class by assigning a well-regarded if disturbing short story by the MacArthur-winning novelist David Foster Wallace, ''Girl with Curious Hair.'' Ms. Richman had been troubled enough by the student's work to report it to her superiors in the first place, in spite of the fact that it was not, according to the Chronicle, ''the first serial-killer story she had read in her six semesters on the faculty at the Academy of Art University.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: S.E.C. Investigating Quovadx Revenue
description: Quovadx, the software developer that announced a restatement last month of third-quarter 2003 results, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was formally investigating revenue recorded in the third quarter of 2002. The shares fell as much as 32 percent. The company last month also revised preliminary fourth-quarter and full-year results because it was not able to collect money from Infotech Network Group, a consortium of Indian information-technology companies. The restatement will reduce 2003 revenue by $11.3 million. Quovadx has been unable to collect on a letter of credit from Infotech, which in October signed a $7.6 million agreement to buy software, the company said. Quovadx said the contract was the largest in company history. It faces several shareholder lawsuits related to the way it recognized revenue from software sales. Quovadx, based in Englewood, Colo., said that it had hired the law firm of Hogan & Hartson to review the company's relationship with Infotech. Separately, the company said it had named Harvey Wagner, 63, as acting chief executive and president effective May 1, succeeding Lorine Sweeney, who resigned. An S.E.C. spokesman, John Heine, declined to comment on the investigation. Quovadx shares fell 98 cents, or 25 percent, to $2.90.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: World War II Mass Grave Found
description: A group that searches for the remains of Nazi victims said it had found a mass grave in Crimea that could contain as many as 2,000 bodies. The group, Poisk, said it had recovered the bodies of 50 people so far, including 10 children. Vassyl Rybka, a member of the group, told Agence France-Presse, ''Usually we find the remains of soldiers, but this time it was only old people and children, shot in the back of the head on the edge of the ravine, naked, with no documents.'' Hennadi Babenko, deputy prime minister of Crimea, said that the executions began in 1941 and that the civilians included ''members of Communist families and Soviet officials, possibly also Gypsies, Crimean Tartars and prisoners of war.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Timing of Clinton Memoir Is Everything, for Kerry
description: As Bill Clinton seeks to finish his memoirs, leading Democrats are voicing concern that the book could overshadow Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign, diverting attention to Mr. Clinton's outsize legacy of scandal and achievement.

title: Grandma Finds a Job, Looking After Junior
description: LOTS of grandparents fantasize about quitting their jobs and spending more time with their grandchildren.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Airport Briefly Loses Power
description: A 10-second power failure at Los Angeles International Airport shut down most operations in the air traffic control tower for a short time on Monday. The failure, which was traced to a bird that may have hit a transmission line, affected 80 to 100 flights, forcing some arriving flights into holding patterns, said Paul Haney, a spokesman for the airport, which processes about 1,800 flights a day. There was virtually no effect on departing flights, Mr. Haney said, and no loss of radar contact with airborne planes. Delays at some other airports were attributed to the Los Angeles power failure. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: Witness Tells Of Debt Deal At Adelphia
description: A former treasury supervisor for Adelphia Communications testified yesterday that the former finance chief, Timothy Rigas, signed a receipt that falsely showed his family used cash to buy $400 million in company debt in January 2002.

title: Pakistani Says He Saw North Korean Nuclear Devices
description: Abdul Qadeer Khan, the Pakistani scientist who sold nuclear technology around the world, has told his interrogators that during a trip to North Korea five years ago he was taken to a secret underground nuclear plant and shown what he described as three nuclear devices, according to Asian and American officials who have been briefed by the Pakistanis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, CECILE S.
description: COHN--Cecile S. Formerly of Brookline MA, New York NY, and Scarsdale NY, in Boston MA on Sunday, at the age of 93. Wife of the late Joseph Cohn of Scarsdale, NY. Mother of Robert M. Cohn of New York, NY. Aunt of five and Great Aunt of eight. She was an avid seeker of knowledge, a gracious hostess, and the glue that held our family together. Services on Wednesday, April 14 at 9:30AM at Stanetsky Chapel, Brookline MA and at 2:30PM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne NY. In lieu of flowers, send contributions in her memory to Hebrew Rehabilitation Center, 1200 Centre St, Roslindale MA 02131.

title: A Medicated Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial output rose 7.4 percent in February, up from 7 percent a year earlier, as rising farm income and low interest rates fed consumer demand. The rate slipped from 7.7 percent in January, a result of a decline in manufacturing. But the capital goods and consumer goods segments each rose more than 20 percent and economists say they expect the country's economy to have grown at a rate of more than 8 percent in the fiscal year that ended in March. The output figures were released by the government's Central Statistical Organization. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: For Failing Eyes, a Dose of Green
description: Supplements containing lutein, a pigment found in dark green vegetables, improved the vision of men with age-related macular degeneration, a study has found.

title: Voters Choosing None of the Above, and Parties Scramble
description: It is a political force measured, in effect, by what is being left out. More and more, when voters in New York are given the chance to select Democrat or Republican, they choose neither. Some register in the Independence Party. Some have earned the political shorthand ''blanks,'' for their lack of a choice.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on the Back Talk page on Sunday with an article about Shea Stadium on its 40th anniversary misidentified the league in which the New York Jets played in their first game in the stadium in 1964. It was the American Football League, not the National Football League.

title: Staff Reports Portray a Divided and Backward Pre-9/11 F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  In the years before Sept. 11, 2001, the Federal Bureau of Investigation was almost at war with itself over how to deal with the threat of terrorism, an investigative unit said today, describing the bureau as torn by internal strife and shackled by woefully outmoded computers.

title: The Uncertainty Factor
description: Twenty years ago, Secretary of State George Shultz went to the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York to give a speech about terrorism. Fighting a war on terrorism, he emphasized, means coping with uncertainty.

title: With a Hearty Victory, the Mets Begin the Healing at Home
description: The Mets opened their home schedule yesterday in a cold and steady drizzle, with four regulars out of the lineup and with their three best hitters wrapped in gauze.

title: An Introduction by Show and Tell
description: Mike Cameron coolly climbed the blue three-foot railing beside the first-base dugout, pulled himself onto the roof and plopped himself down within inches of some Mets fans. He sat with his muscular legs stretched out and looked as if he were preparing for story time with eager first-graders.

title: DUPONT LAYING OFF 3,000 AND CLOSING CANADIAN PLANT
description: The DuPont Company said yesterday that it would lay off 3,000 workers, eliminate 950 other jobs and shut a spandex plant in Canada as part of a plan to trim annual costs by $900 million. The job cuts, to be completed by Dec. 31, will reduce second-quarter earnings by 17 cents to 19 cents a share, DuPont said. About 70 percent of the job cuts will be in North America, and most of the rest will be in Western Europe, a spokesman, Clif Webb, said. About 200 jobs will be eliminated in Canada, including 85 in Maitland, Ontario, where the company will close a plant in May that makes spandex stretch fibers used in disposable diapers, said Richard Gareau, a spokesman for DuPont Canada.

title: So Others Might Survive
description: ''Transplant: From Myth to Reality,'' by Dr. Nicholas L. Tilney. Yale University Press, $30.

title: China Takes Another Step To Tighten Monetary Policy
description: China's central bank has tightened monetary policy for the second time in less than three weeks, trying to put the brakes on bank lending and property speculation as top Chinese officials voice concern that the economy may be overheating.

title: In Asia, Seaports Battle to Be King of Containers
description: On paper, Shanghai and Pusan are sister cities, the largest seaports of China and South Korea, separated by 500 miles of the Yellow Sea.

title: Golf Widows Take Up the Game But Play It in a Different Spirit
description: EVERY year, thousands of women who have moved to Florida for retirement decide to take up golf. What better way to spend more time with their husbands?

title: Scalia Apologizes for Seizure of Recordings
description: Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court has apologized to two Mississippi reporters who were required to erase recordings of a speech he gave at a high school there on Wednesday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Nuclear Inspectors Arrive
description: A team of five inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency arrived in Tehran to try to verify that all uranium enrichment activities have stopped. They are expected to be in Iran for a week. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: All Your Neighbors Are Just Like You
description: DECIDING where to retire used to be like deciding on a summer camp -- there were day camps and sleep-away camps, but the activities were pretty much the same.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Carters Inc., Atlanta, which sells childrens apparel, named Wolff Olins, New York, to handle a branding assignment for its account, which has been inactive. Spending was not disclosed. Wolff Olins is part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABDELMONEIM, OMAR
description: ABDELMONEIM--Omar. The entire Long Island College Hospital family joins with the physicians, nurses and staff in the Department of Pediatrics in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Omar Abdelmoneim, beloved son of our dear and devoted colleague, Talaat Abdelmoneim, MD. To Dr. Abdelmoneim, his family and all of his son's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Stanley Brezenoff Interim President/CEO John Byrne Interim Executive VP/COO Steven Schwarz, MD Chairman of Pediatrics Daniel Ricciardi, MD President of the Medical Staff

title: Bloomberg Plans Overhaul of Creaky 911 System
description: One summer day in 1968, Mayor John V. Lindsay, declaring that he was at ''perhaps the most important event of my administration,'' picked up a telephone at police headquarters and made a ceremonial call to a three-digit number, 911. The call did not go through, so the mayor dialed again. Then again. Finally, someone realized he was using an inside phone line, and pushed a button. With that, the mayor managed to complete the call, and officially launch the city's 911 line.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the death of a teenager whose BMW collided with a Jeep driven by a New York City firefighter in Brooklyn misstated the street name for the location in some copies. It was Ocean Parkway, not Ocean Boulevard.

title: Corrections
description: The Bensonhurst Journal article on Sunday, about opening weekend at the Nellie Bly Amusement Park in Brooklyn, gave an incorrect surname in some copies for the spokeswoman for an international amusement park association. She is Beth Robertson, not Roberston.

title: 9/11 Panel Is Said to Offer Harsh Review of Ashcroft
description: Draft reports by the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks portray Attorney General John Ashcroft as largely uninterested in counterterrorism issues before Sept. 11 despite intelligence warnings that summer that Al Qaeda was planning a large, perhaps catastrophic, terrorist attack, panel officials and others with access to the reports have said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Police Force Suspended
description: More than 500 police officers in the state of Morelos were suspended as part of a drug-trafficking investigation after the arrests of their chief, Jos Agustn Montiel, and his operations deputy. Federal investigators suspect that the police officials protected planeloads of drug shipments by the Jurez cartel. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Testing the Idea That Helping Out Is Healthy
description: FOR Erwin Sekulow, a retired fund-raiser for Johns Hopkins University, volunteering to work with fourth graders in the Baltimore city schools gives him a sense of purpose and makes him healthier.

title: An Actor Confronts A Wrenching Rite of Passage
description: Toward the end of ''The Tricky Part,'' Martin Moran's translucent memoir of a play, a man who might be called the villain of the piece is quoted to shattering effect: ''There were a lot of levels to what we shared.''

title: Tax Cuts Give New Options To Savers Playing Catch-Up
description: RETIREMENT guides routinely exhort readers to start saving while they are young, but very often nest eggs get built in a hurry by people in their 50's for whom retirement finally seems a reality.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RUSS BERRIE & CO., Oakland, N.J., a maker of teddy bears, said it had dropped plans for a possible sale of the company and that profit would fall this year because orders have declined. The company also named Andrew Gatto of Toys ''R'' Us Inc. as chief executive and president.

title: Merrill Lynch Reports Sharp Rise in First-Quarter Earnings
description: Merrill Lynch & Company , the world's largest securities firm, said its earnings almost doubled in the first quarter from the same period a year ago, helped by favorable conditions in the fixed income market and strength in its investment banking operations.

title: ABBOTT TO GIVE ITS HOLDERS SHARES IN HOSPIRA
description: Abbott Laboratories will give stockholders one share of its Hospira hospital-products unit for every 10 Abbott shares they own when the business is spun off this month. No fractional shares will be issued when Abbott sheds the business, which sells hospital products like morphine, pumps and bags for infusing drugs. Shareholders will receive cash in lieu of fractional shares, the company said. The special dividend will be paid on April 30 to shareholders of record as of April 22.

description: GERSH--Madeline. Beloved wife of Alvin. Devoted mother of Heide & Avram Rosner and Tammy Gersh. Trusted confidante to cousin Linda and Glenn Gruen. Sister of Myrna and Burt Dukoff. Will be forever loved and missed. Services 1 PM Tuesday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Admits Murder-For-Hire Plot
description: A Long Island man pleaded guilty yesterday to plotting a mutilation-for-hire and to soliciting prison inmates to murder another inmate who is a police informant in that case. Both plots were uncovered and foiled, prosecutors said. The informant had told authorities that the man, David Quinn, 37, of Rockville Centre, planned to have his girlfriend's ex-husband sexually mutilated, the Queens district attorney's office said. Authorities said Mr. Quinn had sent more than 100 solicitation letters to inmates at the Sullivan Correctional Facility, including the Son of Sam killer, David Berkowitz. Mr. Quinn's lawyer, Joseph Corozzo Jr., did not return a call for comment. Last year, the ex-husband, who had pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting his teenage daughter, was sentenced to 10 years in prison. His name has not been revealed to protect the identity of the daughter. Prosecutors said Mr. Quinn had sought revenge for the attack on the girl. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Earnings Fall At Times Co. But Increase At Gannett
description: The New York Times Company and the Gannett Company reported yesterday that the newspaper advertising climate was showing steady signs of growth so far this year. But while those improvements were enough to help propel a gain in earnings at Gannett in the first quarter, they were not enough to stave off a decline at the Times Company.

title: Discount Drug Cards Are Coming: It's Time to Do Your Homework
description: WITH new government-endorsed drug discount cards becoming available June 1, many Medicare recipients are facing a difficult task in comparison shopping.

title: To Make a Pill More Affordable, Cut It in Half
description: DR. MICHAEL MYERS, an internist in upstate New York, has all too often heard the complaints about expensive prescription drugs from elderly patients living on fixed incomes.

title: 3 More Moroccans Arrested In Madrid Train Bombings
description: A 28-year-old Moroccan aeronautical engineering student was charged Monday with involvement in the train bombings last month in Madrid, and the police announced the arrest of three more Moroccans in connection with the attacks.

title: People
description: Michael Hudes was named executive vice president for corporate development at Clear Channel Outdoor, Phoenix, where he will focus on developing technologies like digital displays, which can aim at specific consumer groups by displaying different signs at different times. Mr. Hudes, who will be based in San Francisco, had been president and chief operating officer at AdSpace Networks, Burlingame, Calif. Clear Channel Outdoor is part of Clear Channel Communications.

description: An article in World Business on Thursday about a rally in Japanese stock prices referred incorrectly to assets under management by Franklin Templeton Investments Japan, whose chief investment officer, Toru Ohara, commented on the rally. The $3 billion figure represented the total assets managed by the company, not just by Mr. Ohara.

title: Fire Dept. to Reinforce Rules on Drunken Driving
description: Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday that the department had been lax and uneven in enforcing of its own rules against firefighters caught driving drunk while off duty. But after two off-duty firefighters were charged with drunken driving over the weekend, he said the department would be more aggressive in the future.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Troops Kill 5 Civilians
description: President lvaro Uribe met with relatives of a family of five killed Saturday by an army patrol in what appeared to be an accident, the second time in three weeks the army has mistakenly killed people. The army said the family, including two children, had been killed in southern Tolima State when they ran from soldiers who had told them to halt. Relatives, though, told a local radio station that the soldiers fired on the family as they transported a sick baby to a hospital. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Plea in Movie Piracy Case
description: An Illinois man pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges related to Internet posting of copies of first-run movies supplied by an Academy Awards voter, prosecutors said.

title: Disney Seeks to Counter Analysts' Poor Reviews
description: The summer movie rush has not even begun and already Wall Street analysts, based on a cool reception to early films like ''The Alamo'' and ''Home on the Range,'' are beginning to worry that the Walt Disney Company's movie division may have a less-than-stellar year.

title: In Michigan, a Milestone For a Mouse Methuselah
description: Could the elusive secret of longevity be a diet heavy in cheese?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article last Tuesday about Hall of Fame nominees at the National Museum of Racing listed a horse incorrectly among those trained by one nominee, Shug McGaughey. And a correction in this space yesterday misspelled the name of that horse's actual trainer. Skip Away, the 1998 Horse of the Year, was trained by Sonny Hine (not Hines).

title: Experts Assess the Merits of Meditation in Motion
description: On a languid March evening, Jeff Morris, a lean, muscular man with a calm smile and shaved head, led a class of three men and two women with slow, fluid, continuous movements through the formalized postures of tai chi, the centuries-old Chinese Taoist martial art.

title: Corporate Tax Holidays
description: Here's unwelcome news for individuals scrambling this week to file their taxes: Almost two-thirds of America's corporations paid no federal income taxes during the late 1990's, when corporate profits were soaring. Nine out of 10 companies paid less than the equivalent of 5 percent of their total income. After allowable deductions, companies ostensibly face a 35 percent rate. Meanwhile, as David Cay Johnston reported in yesterday's Times, the government is doing less to enforce the law. Over the last decade, the audit rate for the largest corporations has fallen by almost half.

title: Wayport Plans to Serve McDonald's With Wi-Fi
description: Wayport Inc., based in Austin, Tex., has won a contract to become the sole provider of wireless Internet access in thousands of McDonald's restaurants, according to Wayport executives.

title: Business Trips Can Be Hazardous to Your Health
description: For a year, whenever Phillip Van Hooser traveled for speaking engagements, he ate the same item -- a turkey sandwich -- for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Mr. Van Hooser, 47, who owns a consulting firm in Princeton, Ky., did not have a food fetish; rather, he had inflammatory bowel disease, a disorder characterized by inflammation of the colon that required him to be near a bathroom during flare-ups.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Guilty Pleas In Smuggling
description: Two people pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Houston to roles in a smuggling operation in which 19 illegal immigrants died last year near Victoria. One, Fatima Holloway, 28, of Cleveland, admitted accompanying the driver of a truck transporting the immigrants and of lying to Border Patrol agents who asked if the truck was empty. The other defendant, Abelardo Flores Jr. of Harlingen, acknowledged recruiting and paying the driver. The immigrants died of heat exhaustion or suffocation. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Executive Quits as Turmoil Continues at Coke
description: In a development that analysts said reflected continuing political turmoil and infighting at the Coca-Cola Company, Deval L. Patrick, the general counsel for three years, has resigned, the company said.

title: Judge Weighs Motion on Manslaughter Charges Against Williams
description: Lawyers for Jayson Williams told a State Superior Court judge Monday that manslaughter charges against their client should be thrown out because prosecutors failed to turn over photographs and notes from an expert witness before his trial began.

title: A Home Away From Home Keeps Old Scholars Happy
description: IN the 10 years since the federal law eliminating mandatory retirement took effect, universities have faced a conundrum: namely, how to encourage senior professors to step aside to make room for younger instructors.

Beloved wife, mother and friend, she is survived by her husband, Gerry, her daughter & son-in-law Betsy and Nik Taylor, her son David Cameron and his fiancee Pam Burke, her son Ben Cameron, her granddaughter Grace Taylor, her stepmother Adele Mairs, her sister Mary Chapot, her stepsister Valerie McDermott, her stepbrother Brian McDermott, and her best friend Madelon Peck. Her life was defined by her dignity, determination, enormous capacity for friendship and extraordinary grace. A celebration of her life will be held at 11:00AM on Wednesday, May 12, 2004 at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd, Darien CT. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Island Health Project, Inc., P.O. Box 344, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

On opening day in New York's other ballpark, there were no pennants raised, no military jets flown overhead, no contrived attempts to rally the troops and send the not-so-subtle message that it's win or off to the brig.

Rowland in the past and two people who provided improvements for his Litchfield cottage are the first witnesses to be asked to testify privately before a Connecticut House committee considering whether to recommend his impeachment, the committee said Monday.

He will continue to be remembered for his contributions to medical education.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Petroleum Use Rises
description: Rapid economic growth increased Thailand's demand for petroleum products by 6.3 percent in the first two months of the year, led by a 22.5 percent rise in consumption of fuel oil, according to data released by the government-run oil company, PTT. Thai utilities are burning more fuel oil as power demand outstrips the country's capacity to pipe natural gas to generators. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Group Claims It Made Attacks
description: Militant Islamic Web sites published a claim of responsibility for an outbreak of violence since March 29 that has taken the lives of 47 people. The statement was signed Jihad Islamic Group -- a previously unknown name -- and claimed that the bombings and shootings were a response to repression of Muslims who worshiped outside officially approved congregations. Rights groups say that 7,000 people are in prison for their beliefs and that torture is systematic. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCHHOLTZ, SAMUEL SIDNEY
description: BUCHHOLTZ--Samuel Sidney. Passed away on April 11, 2004, after a valiant struggle. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Norma and is survived by his children Michael (Mary Uricchio) Buchholtz, Sheryl B. Rosenfield and Sheila B. Scharfman. Adored by his grandchildren Melissa, Daniel, Jessica, Charles, Alex, Emily, Warren and Nora. Loving brother of Stanley and Pearl. A brilliant legal scholar and teacher to many. His legacy of high moral character, scholarship, love of Judaism and kindness to all will endure forever. Services will be held Tuesday, April 13, 12:30 pm, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund.

title: Gaza First, but Not Last
description: When Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel arrives in Washington tomorrow, he is likely to present President Bush with what is, on the face of it, an excellent idea -- the unilateral withdrawal of all Jewish settlements from the Gaza Strip. But Mr. Sharon is likely to want to extract a price for that necessary move, and Mr. Bush did exactly the right thing yesterday by giving advance notice that he's not willing to pay it.

title: Twisting the Piano tude Into New 12-Tone Shapes
description: Brain power is as important to virtuosic piano playing as physical agility of the fingers and arms. With the young American pianist Christopher Taylor, though, the balance seems tipped toward the brain.

title: Ashcroft Faults Clinton Era at 9/11 Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Attorney General John Ashcroft strongly defended the Bush administration and himself today before the 9/11 commission, laying the blame for intelligence failures prior to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks squarely on the presidency of Bill Clinton.

title: Age May Trump Regionalism for Voters in South Korea
description: In South Korea, regionalism has traditionally been the deciding factor in elections. People here in the southeast, used to sending military and civilian rulers to Seoul, backed the Grand National Party or other conservative parties. Voters in the southwest have supported the opposition parties.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Traffic Dispute Leads To Killing
description: A Manhattan man was fatally stabbed last night, after a traffic dispute with another driver, the police said. The man, identified as Wilfredo Jimenez, 25, began a car chase with the other man, Victor White, 48, of Harlem, about 1 p.m. on 149th Street in the Bronx, the authorities said. One of the men cut the other off, a police official said, a move that led to several miles of chasing one another at high speeds. The chase ended in Harlem, the police said, where Mr. Jimenez threw an empty bottle at Mr. White. Mr. White then stabbed Mr. Jimenez in the stomach, the police said. He died at Harlem Hospital Center. The police arrested Mr. White last night. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT).

title: Missing Workers Point Up Halliburton Danger
description: The families of six civilian contractors who have been missing since an ambush last week in Iraq were waiting in anticipation of information about their loved ones, with company representatives by their sides, the Halliburton Company said Monday.

title: New York and FEMA End Dispute Over 9/11 Medical Claims
description: New York will not be held liable for up to $350 million in medical claims arising from the cleanup of the World Trade Center site, since city and federal officials said yesterday that they had resolved a dispute over the matter.

title: Cheney Praises Japan's Stand Against Abductors in Iraq
description: On the first stop of an Asian tour that has been clouded by a series of kidnappings in Iraq, Vice President Dick Cheney on Tuesday praised Japan's policy of not bending to the abductors' demands that Tokyo remove its troops from Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Comments On Vote Issue
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he favored streamlining applications for citizenship by reducing red tape, but he reiterated his opposition to granting the vote to legal immigrants who are not citizens. ''I believe voting is the essence of citizenship,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Two City Council members, Bill Perkins and John C. Liu, are drafting legislation that would permit legal immigrants to vote in city elections, a notion that enjoys some support around the city. According to census figures, there are more than 10 million legal immigrants nationwide who are not citizens, some of them ineligible for citizenship because they are here on temporary visas, others who have not applied. Citizenship can take as long as 10 years because of a backlog of applications. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Sakip Sabanci, 71, Businessman
description: Sakip Sabanci, a leading philanthropist in Turkey and one of its most prominent businessmen as head of the conglomerate Sabanci Holding, died here on Saturday. He was 71.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline futures rose after the International Energy Agency increased its forecast for global petroleum demand. In New York, gasoline for May delivery rose 2.95 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $1.1803 a gallon.

description: In more than three years in office, President Bush has held precisely two news conferences on prime-time television. On Monday, he said he would hold his third, on at 8:30 Tuesday night in the East Room of the White House.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel To Introduce New Processors
description: Intel, the world's largest chipmaker, said that it would introduce two new Itanium 2 processors today that would effectively lower the price of servers based on the chip by 28 percent, while offering a 25 percent increase in performance. Prices for servers based on the new processors will cost $2,100 to $8,000, roughly half what they would have cost two years ago, the company said. As part of the announcement, Audi, the automaker, said it would adopt servers based on the new Itanium chips for their improved price/performance. The announcement was scheduled to be made at the Intel developer forum in Taipei. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Bush Welcomes Gaza Plan, Without Backing It Fully
description: President Bush said Monday that he would welcome a withdrawal of Israeli forces and settlers from the Gaza Strip but warned that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's plan for such a pullback should not replace the White House's stalled proposal for negotiations that would lead to the creation of a Palestinian state.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC TO BUY 2 TEMPLE-INLAND FACTORIES
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation agreed to buy paperboard and packaging operations of Temple-Inland Inc. in California and Delaware for an undisclosed amount. The plants, in Ontario, Calif., and Harrington, Del., will help expand sales in Mexico, Southern California and the Northeast United States, Georgia-Pacific said. The Delaware plant makes printed laminated-box packaging for beverage and telecommunications customers. The California plant makes packaging for toys, produce and electronics. Georgia-Pacific is based in Atlanta.

title: Lost Dreams in the Poconos
description: Working families who limp from paycheck to paycheck have been priced out of many housing markets. In most of New York's outlying communities, the median prices for homes begin at more than $350,000. But dreams die hard and homeownership is a powerful lure, which explains why over the last decade, thousands of New Yorkers kept their city jobs but moved with their families 100 miles away, to homes they bought with easy credit and the promise of a better life in the Poconos in Pennsylvania. That's where, for many, the nightmare began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MESSERSCHMITT, JOHN
description: MESSERSCHMITT -- John. The College of Aeronautics Board of Trustees on behalf of the students, faculty and staff, is deeply saddened by the loss of John Messerschmitt who dedicated more than 18 years to the College. He was steadfastly committed to higher education and served as Chair of the Board for seven years. Under his leadership, the College revised the degree offerings, completed a major construction project, and laid the foundation for the next 100 years for our leading-edge institution. His service to our country as a World War II combat pilot and lifetime dedication to the field of electronics contributed to his thoughtful insight on the Board, and he will be missed. The College community also extends its condolences and heartfelt support to Mrs. Betsy Messerschmitt and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIERSON, POLLY STOKES
description: PIERSON--Polly Stokes, a wonderful mother and grandmother, died peacefully at her home in Malibu on April 5, surrounded by her family. She was born to Walter and Polly Stokes in Manhattan in 1926. After attending the Chapin School, she pursued a BA, Class of '48, and Master's degree at Radcliffe. A summer resident of Cooperstown, she met Frank Romer Pierson there and they later married and moved to California in the early '50's. A generous supporter of the performing arts, Polly was a major contributor to the Glimmerglass Opera from its inception. Her son Michael and his wife Maggie, their children Colin, Emmet and Gracie and her daughter Eve and children Hannah and Ben, wish to thank the many friends for the love and concern they have always shown.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Foreigners Buying Stocks
description: Foreign investors bought a record amount of Japanese stocks in March and for the fiscal year ended in March, government data showed. Foreign investors bought a net 2.69 trillion yen worth of Japanese shares in March, more than any previous month, the finance ministry said. Cheered by a brighter outlook for Japan's economy, foreign investors have bought more Japanese shares than they sold for 18 consecutive months. The demand by foreign investors for Japanese shares has helped drive the benchmark Nikkei 225 stock average to its highest level in two and a half years. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ODIERNO, ANTHONY (LOUIS)
description: ODIERNO--Anthony (Louis). Died peacefully on April 9, 2004, with family members at his bedside. Mr. Odierno is survived by his wife Pamela Hanks Odierno, daughters: Linda, Odette and Melody; his grandchildren: Debbie, Susie, Donny, Joey and Justin; great grandchildren: Gary Michael, Chris, Kathy, Tommy, Nicole, Gina and Debbie; step-daughters: Lauren and Kati Gillis; brothers, sisters and his in-laws Jim and Ruth Hanks. Mr. Odierno was a greatly respected real estate developer and prime general contractor for the U.S. Government with extensive holdings in Florida, New York and S. Carolina. He will be missed by his family as well as his friends and business associates. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, April 13, 2004, from 2:00-4:00 PM and from 6:00-8:00 PM at Sylvan Abbey Funeral Home. Graveside services will be held on Wednesday, at 1:00 PM in Sylvan Abbey Memorial Park, Peacefield Chapel Mausoleum.

description: A Canadian citizen was sentenced to 63 months in prison for trying to board a flight in March 2003 at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport with 32 razor blades concealed in his carry-on luggage. The man, Fazal Karim, had flown into the country earlier that day. He denied any ties to terrorist organizations, but federal prosecutors said they believed he was trying to test the airport's security. Mr. Karim, 37, was also ordered deported upon completion of his sentence. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: TOYS 'R' US APPOINTS A NEW CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Toys ''R'' Us promoted Raymond Arthur to chief financial officer, succeeding Louis Lipschitz, who retired in March after 17 years with the company. Mr. Arthur, 45, joined the company in 1999 and served most recently as president of Toysrus.com, the online unit of Toys ''R'' Us, the company said. The chief executive, John H. Eyler Jr., said Mr. Arthur's first tasks would include helping to evaluate company assets. Toys ''R'' Us is based in Wayne, N.J.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Health Insurer To Refund $5 Million
description: Health Net, one of the New York metropolitan region's largest health insurers, has agreed to refund $4.99 million to policyholders for wrongly denying or underpaying some claims from 1999 to 2002 and failing to offer a proper appeals process, the state Insurance Department announced yesterday. A state report released last fall, based on data compiled by consumer groups, found that Health Net had one of the highest rates of consumer complaints in 2002. The company has agreed to run newspaper advertisements in the next 90 days telling consumers of a new process to appeal payment decisions, and to change defective forms it had used to explain consumer benefits. Health Net has more than 120,000 customers in New York City, and about 380,000 across the metropolitan region. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

The manufacturer, Nikko America Inc., announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The trucks, which were made from April 2003 to January 2004, were sold at toy stores and department stores nationwide until February. Consumers can order a free replacement by calling (866) 232-6013, toll free. John Files (NYT)

title: NORTHROP IS PLANNING TO BUILD PLANT IN MISSISSIPPI
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation will build a plant in Moss Point, Miss., to assemble and to test its new Fire Scout unmanned plane for the Army and Navy. The 39,000-square-foot plant will provide 30 manufacturing jobs, which could grow to as many as 65 as orders increase for the Fire Scout, Northrop's chief executive, Ronald D. Sugar, said in remarks during a groundbreaking. The plant will be completed by January and will begin operation by March, a Northrop spokeswoman, Cynthia Curiel, said in a telephone interview. Fire Scout, a helicopterlike vertical takeoff and landing aircraft can fly at altitudes up to 20,000 feet with a 200-pound payload for as far as 110 nautical miles.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Stake In Noodle Maker
description: Japan's top maker of instant noodles, the Nissin Food Products Company, said it would buy a one-third stake in China's No.2 noodle company, the Hebei Hualong F&N Industry Group. Nissin will pay about 20 billion yen ($187 million) to take a 33.4 percent in the Chinese company. Nissin, the maker of Cup Noodle and other instant ramen noodles, has a leading 40 percent share of Japan s instant noodle market, but only a small presence in China. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Residents Evacuated
description: Rescue workers evacuated about 120 people from buildings in Sunset Park last night after burning electrical cables caused carbon monoxide levels to shoot up in their homes, the authorities said. No one was injured. Firefighters came to the area about 6:15 p.m. to put out a fire inside a manhole on 43rd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Deputy Fire Chief James Leonard said. Fumes from the cables caused the high carbon monoxide readings, according to Chris Olert, a spokesman for Consolidated Edison, and around 7 p.m., fire officials evacuated many of the houses in the area. Residents were permitted to return to their homes by 10:40 p.m., Mr. Olert said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Anti-Cigarette Campaign To Top $45 Million
description: The State Department of Health announced a plan yesterday to spend more than $45 million on antismoking programs this year, an increase of about 45 percent from last year's spending of $31 million. The plan includes expanded telephone services and an interactive Web site at www.nysmokefree.com. The phone service handles 45,000 to 55,000 calls a year, the department said. As part of the expanded campaign, the line, 866-NYQUITS (866-697-8487), will be equipped to handle 5,000 more callers, officials said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: California Gets In on the Pinot Noir Game
description: IN the last decade, pinot noir has been a real California success story. Pinot, the great red grape of Burgundy, was long considered too exacting -- fickle is the clich -- to produce good wine in California. The climate was too warm, the soil too rich, the grape clones incorrect, the rootstocks improper, you name it. But once you have the taste of good pinot noir in your mouth, you thirst for more, and California winemakers persevered until they began to get it right.

title: Central Europe's New Demagogues
description: To the shock of many Slovaks, Vladimir Meciar, their discredited former prime minister, led the first round of balloting earlier this month for Slovakia's next president. He now faces Ivan Gasparovic -- his former top aide, who would be an even more disastrous choice -- in a runoff on Saturday. The return of Mr. Meciar, rejected six years ago by Slovakia for his thuggish behavior and incoherent economic policies, is unfortunately not an isolated event in Eastern and Central Europe.

description: Happily, President Bush finally held a prime-time news conference last night. Unhappily, he failed to address either of the questions uppermost in Americans' minds: how to move Iraq from its current chaos, and what he has learned from the 9/11 investigations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLER, WILHELMINE STEWART KIRBY
description: WALLER--Wilhelmine Stewart Kirby. The Officers and Directors of The Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former President, Wilhelmine Kirby Waller, and extend deepest sympathy to her family and friends. She served the Garden Club with great distinction and extraordinary ability as its 17th president (1965 to 1968) and in many other capacities that began with her membership in the Bedford Garden Club. Her most memorable contributions were in the area of environmental legislation on both local and national levels. She served tirelessly on many national and state commissions and held a seat on the President's Citizen Advisory Council on Environmental Quality under three presidential administrations --Nixon, Ford and George H. Bush. She is credited with the formation of the Garden Club's National Affairs and Legislation Committee, which has been active for many years in promoting sound conservation policy through legislation. Mrs Waller made considerable contributions to the Garden Club, to Westchester County, to New York State and to the Nation. She will be remembered fondly by the many people whose lives she touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, NATHAN L.
description: HALPERN--Nathan L. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Central Park Conservancy note with deep sadness the passing of Nathan L. Halpern, a member of the Board from 1984 to 1995, and esteemed counsel and Life Trustee from 1995 to present. During his tenure with the Conservancy, and throughout its formative years, Nathan's strong leadership and generosity, provided a solid foundation for Central Park's renaissance. Today, millions of New Yorkers and visitors from around the world enjoy the fruits of his commitment to the treasure that is Central Park. The progress made in revitalizing the Park will stand as a lasting tribute to a special man. We extend our sympathies to his family and friends. The Board of Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Minister's Killer Appeals
description: A 25-year-old man convicted of murdering Anna Lindh, the foreign minister, in September appealed the verdict on the ground that prosecutors failed to prove his intention to kill her. The man, Mijailo Mijailovic, was sentenced to life in prison in March. His lawyer said the murder conviction should be overturned and replaced with a charge of manslaughter, news agencies reported. He also challenged psychiatric evidence asserting that Mr. Mijailovic was fit to stand trial. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Republicans In Virginia Help Advance Tax Increase
description: Defying their party's strongly antitax leadership, a group of Republicans joined the Democratic minority in the Virginia House of Delegates on Tuesday to approve a $748 million tax increase over two years.

title: A French-Toast Menagerie For Brunchers of a Shorter Sort
description: Sunday brunch is an ideal meal to share with small children in a restaurant -- the atmosphere is usually relaxed, and except for the bloody marys, the menu is likely to be child-friendly. Dumonet in the Carlyle has a new ''Sunday best'' brunch from noon to 3 p.m. for children, with a special buffet table festooned with balloons and set up so that children can help themselves to French toast in animal shapes, little pizzas, bagels, cereals, fries, miniburgers and cookies. It is $25 for children under 10. The restaurant has also introduced an  la carte children's menu at all meals ($5 to $24). A new children's menu is also being offered at Jerry's, 101 Prince Street (Greene Street), with hamburgers, macaroni and cheese and hot dogs. It is free from 5:30 to 7 p.m. every day except Saturday for children under 8.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Soldiers Open Fire On Each Other
description: Three soldiers were killed when two army patrols hunting for right-wing paramilitaries inadvertently opened fire on each other, just a day after President lvaro Uribe apologized to relatives of a family of five who were accidentally killed by troops. The mistaken killings have prompted a wave of criticism against the army that began three weeks ago when soldiers accidentally killed seven elite policeman and four civilians in another incident that remains unexplained. Critics in Congress have charged that Mr. Uribe's hard-line efforts in Colombia's long war are leading to excesses and mistakes that are costing lives. Juan Forero (NYT)

The hourlong trio, inspired by the whirling dervishes, sets its dancers spinning in and out of formation, their torsos and arms shifting slightly. There is a bit of traditional South American dance and video. The music, live and recorded, includes drumming, Afro-Colombian cumbia and electronic Sufi music. Somehow it all worked.

description: KERLIN--Gilbert. The partners, associates and staff of Shearman & Sterling LLP mourn the passing of our partner and distinguished colleague Gilbert Kerlin, who died Thursday at the age of 94. The importance of Gil's contributions to the firm and to his partners cannot be overstated. He has also been justly praised for his philanthrophy and services to his community of Riverdale, NY. He was an exceptional partner and friend whose charm, talent, dedication and exuberance will be missed by all.

title: FOOT LOCKER WILL BUY 350 FOOTSTAR STORES
description: Foot Locker said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 350 shoe and clothing stores from Footstar for $160 million. The deal is for nearly all of Footstar's Footaction stores. Footstar, which filed for bankruptcy protection on March 2, recently said it planned to close its 88 Just For Feet stores and 75 of its 428 Footaction stores. Footstar, based in West Nyack, N.Y., said it would concentrate on its Meldisco business as it reorganizes. The division operates shoe departments at Kmart stores. Footstar received bankruptcy court approval to auction the 350 Footaction stores last week. The stores' sale to Foot Locker is subject to court approval, with a hearing scheduled for April 21. Foot Locker, based in New York, has about 3,600 stores and had fiscal 2004 revenue of $4.78 billion.

It is about how in the 1940's and 50's the food industry tried to convince American women that cooking was difficult in order to persuade them that they needed newly developed packaged and frozen foods and cake mixes. And how women fought back.

description: FEIGIN--Simeon Lubell. Died on April 13 at age 76 after a long illness. A psychiatrist in private practice for 44 years in New York City, Scarsdale and White Plains. Attending psychiatrist at NYU Medical Center and Lenox Hill Hospital. Psychiatric consultant to the Mental Health Association of Westchester County, the Rutherford House, the Hebrew Home for the Aged and the Sterling Mental Health Center in White Plains. His mother was Dorothy Lubell Feigin, an abstract painter, etcher and lithographer whose works are in numerous collections. Dr. Feigin is survived by his wife of 49 years, Annette Feigin, by four children, Cynthia A. Feigin of Scarsdale, Laura Feigin Levine of Chevy Chase, MD, Andrew S. Feigin, M.D. of Manhattan and Gerald E. Feigin of Croton-onHudson, NY and five grandchildren. title: SUNTRUST BANKS AGREES TO PURCHASE SEIX INVESTMENT
description: SunTrust Banks agreed to buy Seix Investment Advisors, a manager of fixed-income funds, to become one of the nation's five largest managers of assets for foundations and endowments. The acquisition will bring an additional $17 billion of assets to SunTrust's Trusco Capital Management unit, the company said. Seix Investment, which has 17 investment professionals, will keep its headquarters in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and operate as a division of Trusco Capital. For SunTrust, the purchase increases its funds under management to $117 billion, including more than $50 billion at Trusco Capital, the company said.

title: So, Don Juan, What's Dessert?

Lavish table settings typical of Byron's epic poem about the don will be the focus of a lecture on May 4 at Sotheby's Institute of Art, 1334 York Avenue (71st Street).

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Applied Micro To Acquire I.B.M. Microchip Line
description: The Applied Micro Circuits Corporation agreed yesterday to pay I.B.M. $227 million for a line of microprocessors and licenses that could almost double its annual revenue. The chip line is part of I.B.M.'s 400 series of embedded PowerPC products, used in network equipment like switches and routers as well as printers and digital televisions, Applied Micro said. I.B.M. will manufacture the chips for Applied Micro, which is based in San Diego. Shares of Applied Micro fell 8 cents, to $6.20. Shares of I.B.M. fell 70 cents, to $93.04.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Brewing Magnate To Run For Senate
description: Peter Coors, the chairman of Adolph Coors Company, formally announced that he would seek the Senate seat being vacated by Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Republican who is retiring. Mr. Coors, 57, left, was endorsed by Senator Campbell and Bill Owens, the Republican governor. Mr. Coors, who will retain his title but will no longer receive a salary from the brewer, will face off against a former congressman, Bob Schaffer, for the Republican nomination. Attorney General Ken Salazar is running as a Democrat. Julie Dunn (NYT)

The man, Paul Goldman, a 38-year-old immigrant from Uzbekistan who lived in Mount Laurel, N.J., was charged with killing his girlfriend, Fay Zonis, 42, of Philadelphia, in December and fled to Europe. In January, his parents committed suicide, saying in a note that they could not live with what their son had done. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

Beloved husband of Rhoda, he was born February 1, 1924 on the Lower East Side, NY, NY. Champion skater, swimmer, storyteller and much beloved by all who knew him--he served in the Navy and was a graduate of Adelphi College and the Hebrew Union College School of Sacred Music. He is survived by children, Marian, Alan (Connie), and Gail (Clifton). Adored by his grandchildren, David, Daniel and Jake. Loving brother of Bernard, Nathan, and Irving. Bestowed with an insatiable curiosity, he celebrated the small things in life. His magic inspired the child in all of us. Services will be held Wednesday, April 14, 10:30 AM at Temple Beth El, Spring Valley, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Shot By Retired Officer
description: A retired police officer shot and injured a man early yesterday morning while trying to break up a fight outside a restaurant in Queens, the police said. The former officer stepped between the two men, who had been arguing outside the Last Stop Gourmet Shop on Beach 116th Street in Rockaway Park. One of the men, Paul Friedl, 37, grabbed the retired officer's glasses and threatened him with a knife, the police said, and the former officer, who was not identified by the police, then shot Mr. Friedl, wounding him in the chin and the arm. He was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center and was in stable condition yesterday. Mr. Friedl was charged with menacing and criminal possession of a weapon. The other man, John Treanor, 36, was also arrested and was charged with disorderly conduct. The former officer was not injured, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Adopts Rule on Fund Market Timing
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered mutual funds yesterday to disclose what they do to deter rapid trades, the first rule developed to address the trading scandals that erupted last year in the $7.6 trillion fund industry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Convicted Of Knifing Death
description: A Queens man was convicted on Monday of stabbing his former girlfriend more than 140 times. Prosecutors said the man, Paul DiLeonardo, 24, attacked his former girlfriend, Katherine Guarido, 24, on June 18, 2002, as she sat with him in a parked car in the Richmond Hill section of the borough. Despite scores of stab wounds, she staggered from the car to the street, where she collapsed and later died, they said. Mr. DiLeonardo then went to his mother's residence and reported the murder, prosecutors said. Mr. DiLeonardo waived his right to a jury trial and was convicted by Justice Robert J. Hanophy of State Supreme Court. He faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison at his sentencing on May 18, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Beef Talks Set
description: The Japanese government has invited United States experts to consultations in Tokyo next week aimed at finding a way for Japan to lift its ban on beef imports from the United States, Vice President Dick Cheney said on the last day of a four-day visit to Japan. Japan has blocked the imports since December, when a case of mad cow disease was discovered in Washington State. Japan has demanded that the United States test all cattle for the disease before lifting the ban. The United States has argued that testing all cows is unnecessary because the disease occurs only in older animals. Before imposing the ban, Japan imported about $1 billion worth of beef from the United States annually. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Founder of Ermitage, Ltd., now Liberty Ermitage Jersey Ltd. and director of several companies and GAM funds. Serious collector of baroque pictures and furniture. Amateur historian, enthusiastic hiker and international gourmet. Funeral in Jersey, Channel Islands, U.K. at 2:30 on Friday, April 16 at the Grouville Parish Church. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Saviours Hospital (Queens House) or Jersey Hospice Care and sent C/O Broadlands, La Hogue Bie, Jersey JE3. 9HQ. C.I. via U.K.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Admits Murdering Wife
description: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to murdering his wife last year, cutting her head off with a handsaw and leaving her body in a suitcase on a Harlem street. The man, Oscar Pilamunga, 25, kicked, punched and strangled his wife, Beatrice Yually, 23, on May 31, 2003, after she said she might leave him, law enforcement officials said. Mr. Pilamunga could be sentenced to 15 years to life in prison at his sentencing, which is scheduled for May 12. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Testimony Before the 9/11 Commission
description: The following is the text of the April 14 hearings on law enforcement, counterterrorism and intelligence collection in the United States prior to Sept. 11, as transcribed by FDCH e-Media, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, ELDON
description: BAILEY--Eldon. The Juilliard School is deeply saddened by the death of Eldon ''Buster'' Bailey. As a distinguished member of our percussion department, he helped educate new generations of percussionists around the world. We extend our condolences to his entire family. Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: The Failed F.B.I.
description: The 9/11 investigation commission has provided a chilling, and sadly believable, account of two presidents' failures to come to grips with the catastrophic intelligence problems that preceded the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. The Clinton and Bush administrations failed in different ways, but they shared one central flaw: an inability to manage the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The myriad endemic shortcomings of the agency are at the center of what went wrong with American intelligence. The critical challenge for the commission, and the Bush administration, is to figure out what to do about it.

title: World Business Briefing | World Trade: Lumber Tariff Ruling
description: A World Trade Organization panel said that the United States was justified in imposing antidumping duties on imports of softwood lumber from Canada two years ago, but that the method used to calculate the duties was flawed. The antidumping case is one of several involving Canadian lumber exports currently before the W.T.O. and panels set up under the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Canadians have also protested against American countervailing duties, imposed to offset what the United States sees as subsidies on Canadian lumber. Negotiators from the countries have so far failed to resolve the lumber dispute. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Orders Approval Of Contract
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has ordered the city comptroller to clear a marketing contract with Snapple that the comptroller has argued was awarded improperly. In a letter sent late Monday, the mayor invoked a City Charter provision requiring the comptroller to register the contract within 10 days. The contract gives Snapple exclusive rights to market its soft drinks and snacks on municipal property throughout New York. In the mayor's letter to the comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., above, the mayor said he had found no evidence to support Mr. Thompson's concerns that the city could have made more money if other suppliers had been given a fair chance to compete for the deal. Mr. Thompson said in a statement yesterday that he remained troubled by the contract and was ''investigating legal options to ensure that the city gets the best deal.'' Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Union and Theater Agree On Use of Virtual Orchestra
description: Correction Appended

title: INVESTOR OPPOSITION THREATENS MONY SALE TO AXA
description: More than 15 percent of Mony Group's shareholders said they would oppose in a Delaware court the insurer's sale to France's AXA, enough to give AXA the right to walk away from the $1.5 billion purchase. Mony, based in New York, said 15.5 percent of investors had indicated they would prefer that a judge determine the value of their shares rather than receive the $31 offered by AXA, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The amount of dissenters exceeds a 15 percent trigger that allows AXA to cancel the purchase. AXA said it remained committed to the offer, which some Mony investors have criticized as too low and more beneficial to Mony management than to shareholders. Mony shareholders are scheduled to vote on the takeover May 18.

title: Hallmark TV Unit May Sell Foreign Assets
description: Crown Media Holdings, the parent company of the Hallmark Channel cable network, said yesterday that it was exploring the sale of its overseas operations, as well as the foreign rights to its library of 700 television programs.

title: Knicks' Playoff Position to Remain Up in the Air Until the Final Buzzer
description: The team president, the head coach, two assistant coaches and eight players who began the season with the Knicks are gone. In a season marked by change and turmoil, it is perhaps fitting that uncertainty will stalk the Knicks until the final night of the regular season.

title: Islam and Democracy: Algerians Try to Blaze a Trail
description: Algeria managed to elect a president to a second term last week with voting that was widely celebrated as free and fair. That might not sound like much, but after a decade-long civil war with radical Islamists that left as many as 150,000 dead, it seemed monumental to many Algerians. And the exercise came with a lesson for would-be Arab democracies: timing is important and participants must agree to the secular principles needed for democracy to work.

title: Police and Fire Dept. Merchandiser Is Sued
description: For years, Albert Elovitz and merchants like him have been hawking key chains, shot glasses, bobble-head dolls and even boxer shorts proudly emblazoned with the initials N.Y.P.D. or F.D.N.Y. But this week, the city filed a civil lawsuit against Mr. Elovitz and his online store, saying that all those knickknacks are knocking down the image of New York's Police and Fire Departments.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown South; A Hotel That Says 'Stay a While'
description: Construction has begun on an unusual 43-story hotel and rental apartment building on the Avenue of the Americas between 38th and 39th Streets. The project, to be known as Bryant Park Tower, will house an extended-stay hotel -- the 357-suite Marriott Residence Inn -- with 96 studio and one-bedroom rental apartments on the top 10 floors.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: SPECIAL SESSION ON SCHOOLS FINANCING The governor has called a special legislative session, which will begin April 20, to consider scrapping the state's system of public school financing, which takes money from wealthy districts and gives it to poor ones. The governor, Rick Perry, a Republican, wants to eliminate the system, which relies heavily on property taxes, and instead raise so-called sin taxes to maintain equity in school financing. Under Mr. Perry's plan, property taxes would be cut by $6 billion while taxes on cigarettes, video lottery gambling and sex-oriented entertainment would raise an estimated $2.5 billion. (AP)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Court Stays Execution
description: A federal appeals court stayed the execution of Michael F. Rosales, whose lawyers contend he is mentally retarded and thus protected from the death penalty. He was to have been executed last night. Mr. Rosales, 30, was convicted of capital murder in the death of a 67-year-old woman in Lubbock during a burglary in 1997. A state court had rejected arguments by Mr. Rosales's lawyers that his I.Q., which they said was 73, was reason to spare him. Under Texas law, an I.Q. of 70 is considered the benchmark for retardation. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Father-and-Son Quality Time Comes to the MetroStars
description: For Bob and Michael Bradley, it has always been about quality time.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And Then It Turned Out He Was My Agent

title: Is Gold Now Worth Its Weight in Lobster?
description: ''AS late as the 1880's lobster was so common that it was still being used as bait for cod and striped bass,'' states the entry on lobster in ''The Encyclopedia of Fish Cookery,'' by A. J. McClane.

title: Hynix Drops Plan to Sell Assets to Citigroup
description: Emboldened by a rise in global chip prices, Hynix Semiconductor, the large maker of memory chips, said Tuesday that it had ended talks to sell its nonmemory assets to a Citigroup unit.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 4 about the refugee population of the South Pacific island of Nauru, where Australia has been sending asylum seekers under a policy begun in 2001, misstated the reason the island's Afghan refugees fled their homeland. It was to escape Taliban persecution, not war. The article also referred incorrectly to the Tampa, a vessel that was prohibited from landing in Australia in August 2001 because it carried refugees. It was a Norwegian freighter that had rescued the refugees from a leaking boat; it was not itself leaking. ( Go to Article )

title: Kerry Recruits Votes for Today and Politicians for Tomorrow
description: Senator John Kerry was doing his best to channel John F. Kennedy again, denouncing apathy and trying to get young people excited about politics and public service.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New York State Fund to Join Californians in Dissent at Citigroup
description: In the world of heavyweight institutional investors, the California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, tilts the scales. And on Monday it leaned on Citigroup's board, citing corporate governance problems at the company, the world's biggest bank, as reasons for not supporting the re-election of Sanford I. Weill and Charles O. Prince as directors next week.

title: Political Memo; Latest Big-Money Fight, Over Fund-Raising Groups, Will Be Heard by Election Panel
description: The Bush and Kerry campaigns have already sparred over it. Now the advocacy groups will chime in. And the unions. And the trade associations. And don't forget the watchdogs.

title: Cheney Presses Beijing on North Korea
description: BEIJING, April 14  Vice President Dick Cheney presented Chinese leaders with new evidence about the scope of North Korea's nuclear program and warned that "time is not necessarily on our side" in continuing negotiations, a senior Bush administration official said today.

title: Rule Created Legal 'Wall' To Sharing Information
description: On Tuesday, witnesses and commissioners pondered the role of ''the wall'' in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: War Reports From Civilians Stir Up Iraqis Against U.S.
description: The memories were so raw that the boy's words tumbled out of his mouth on Tuesday, a day after he survived an American attack that destroyed his house outside Falluja.

title: Cruel Choices
description: I can't get the kaleidoscope of genocide out of my head since my trip last month to the Sudan-Chad border: the fresh graves, especially the extra-small mounds for children; the piles of branches on graves to keep wild animals from digging up corpses; the tales of women being first raped and then branded on the hand to stigmatize them forever; the isolated peasants, unfamiliar with electricity, who suddenly encounter the 21st century as helicopters machine-gun their children.

title: The Department Of Internal Resentment
description: For nearly 13 years, until October 2003, I was a tax collector for the Internal Revenue Service. I was a field officer, spending the majority of my time making unannounced visits to businesses and individuals who owed federal taxes. I never expected a warm reception and rarely did I receive one.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Wholesale Prices Rise
description: Japan's corporate goods price index rose 0.2 percent in March from a year earlier, for the first annual increase since July 2000, as higher prices of iron and steel offset lower prices of some agricultural goods, government data showed. The increase in the index of wholesale prices was an indication that Japan's long battle with deflation may be coming to an end, though economists and government officials cautioned against reading too much into the figures. Consumer prices are expected to continue to fall because of stagnant wage growth and weak demand. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Making a Case For a Mission
description: Facing a moment of political peril unlike any in the more than one thousand days of his presidency, George W. Bush made the case on Tuesday night for staying the course in Iraq with the language and zeal of a missionary and combined it with a stark warning that failure would embolden America's enemies around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAU, GLADYS BALOG. (WIDOW OF HERBERT H.)
description: BLAU--Gladys Balog. (Widow of Herbert H.), Larchmont, died April 11; mother of Leslie (Sarita) and Lawrence.

title: Yanks' Rotation For Red Sox Twisted by Rain
description: Mel Stottlemyre was all dressed up with nothing to do. He roamed the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium yesterday with his warm-up jersey buttoned to the top, a catcher's mitt on his left hand and a baseball in his right. Stottlemyre may have looked like a Little Leaguer dejected by the rain, but he was every bit a fretting pitching coach.

description: Kraft Foods Inc. said yesterday that its chief executive, Roger K. Deromedi, is making a complete recovery after being hospitalized about two weeks ago and plans to return to work May 10.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Executive Resigns
description: The world's largest natural gas producer, Gazprom, said Boris Yurlov, 55, resigned as chief financial officer to take a government job. Andrei Kruglov, the 35-year-old head of the corporate finance division, was appointed acting deputy chief executive and will supervise Gazprom's finances, Gazprom said. Mr. Yurlov last year oversaw the two biggest corporate bond sales in Russia's history, raising almost $3 billion for Gazprom to help the company reduce interest payments and lengthen the maturity of its debt. He also won board approval for plans to cut new borrowing by 40 percent to $3.2 billion in two years and maintain debt at no more than $15 billion.

title: 9/11 Panel Report Faults Culture of Spy Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 — American intelligence agencies failed to anticipate the Sept. 11 terror attacks in part because of their piecemeal approach to the ever-growing torrents of information they tried to process, the staff of the 9/11 commission said in a report today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRAZER, KENNETH G.
description: FRAZER--Kenneth G., 93, April 8, retired president Ludwig Mueller Co. Memorial service, Arbor Glen, Bridgewater, NJ, Sat. April 24, 2PM.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airport Use Increases
description: The world's biggest op-erator of airports, BAA, said the number of people using its seven British airports increased by 4.4 percent, to 133.4 million, a record, in the year ended March 31. The increase was most marked for the month of March -- up 10.4 percent, to 10.4 million, compared with a year ago, when air travel slowed at the start of the war in Iraq. BAA said the biggest surge came at Stansted airport, north of London, which is used mostly by low-cost airlines like Ryanair and EasyJet. The number of travelers using Stansted rose 15.9 percent, to 19.4 million passengers for the year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: D'oh! Am I Underpaid?; Negotiations Are Stalled for Voice Actors in 'The Simpsons'
description: On television Homer J. Simpson is an underachiever, the safety inspector at the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant, with the record for most years worked at an entry-level position. In real life Mr. Simpson and his family of subversives have, by the estimate of accountants employed by the actors who supply their voices, earned Fox upward of $2.5 billion as the stars of one of the longest-running prime-time series in television history.
