title: Sports of The Times; Coach's Long Journey Ends With Dream Job
description: QUEENS COLLEGE has numerous distinguished alumni: Jerry Seinfeld and Paul Simon, Marvin Hamlisch and New York State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, as well as the Manhattan psychiatrist Isaac S. Herschkopf, class of '71, who, with pride, refers to his alma mater as the Harvard of Flushing.

title: Kerry's Boldface Names
description: Democrats worry that President Bush is slumping too soon. Six months from now, with the economy surging at a 4 percent rate and peace breaking out in the Greater Middle East, today's seeming-underdog incumbent could easily come roaring back to win going away.

title: MCDONALD'S NET INCOME BEATS FIRST-QUARTER FORECASTS
description: The McDonald's Corporation said first-quarter net income rose to about 40 cents a share, beating analysts' estimates, because of strong sales in the United States. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected McDonald's to earn 37 cents a share. McDonald's had net income of $327.4 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter of 2003. Sales in the United States rose 14 percent in the quarter, the company said in its preliminary earnings statement. Sales in the United States have risen every month for a year. Sales in Europe fell 2.9 percent last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOX, MARTIN, FERLE (NEE HOFFMAN)
description: FOX - MARTIN -- Ferle (nee Hoffman). Born 1917, St. Louis, died April 10, NY. We loved you & will miss your enchanting wit and charm. Survived by niece, nephew and their children. Memorial service April 18, 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOHN, JULIUS
description: KOHN--Julius. Of Kent, CT. Formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Age 97. Husband of the late Leonore Kohn. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York, Wednesday April 14 at 1:30 PM.

title: You're Published. Now the Fun Begins? Think Again.
description: Writers just want to be humiliated. Over and over again. That's the way it seemed to Robin Robertson, a Scottish poet and editor who solicited authors' reminiscences about their most humiliating moments for a book. The stories poured in. Writers, some famous, seemed only too glad to share their humiliations. The result, ''Mortification: Writers' Stories of Their Public Shame,'' published last month by Fourth Estate, is bound to ensure their humiliations endure, on paper.

title: Lines Drawn in Fight on N.S.F. Financing
description: WHEN Vernon J. Ehlers was a young physics professor at Calvin College in Grand Rapids, Mich., in the mid-1960's, he won a National Science Foundation grant to set up a summer institute for training elementary teachers in science. ''I was surprised,'' he recalled recently. ''At the time, I had no political connections. N.S.F. just liked the proposal, I guess.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: I.B.M. Buys Schlumberger Unit
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it had acquired the disaster recovery subsidiary of Schlumberger for an undisclosed sum. The deal will add 40 business backup centers in Europe and North America to the 120 I.B.M. Global Services already operates. The deal rids Schlumberger, which is the world's largest oil services company, of one of the remnants of its expansion into business information services with the 2001 acquisition of Sema. Most of Sema was sold to Atos Origin in January in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $1.45 billion. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: U.S. Workers, Lured by Money And Idealism, Face Iraqi Reality
description: They were driven by the promise of six-figure salaries or a powerful sense of patriotism. For others, the decision to sign up for a job in the cauldron of Iraq was motivated by desire to help ordinary Iraqis improve their lives. Among the tens of thousands of American citizens working in Iraq, few could have imagined how dangerous their jobs would become.

title: Neil Upmeyer Is Dead at 57; A Researcher of Public Issues
description: Neil Upmeyer, a widely respected public-interest researcher in New Jersey who, as head of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues tackled subjects like campaign finance, lobbying and the environment, died on Friday at his home in Lambertville, N.J. He was 57.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAZARUS, ELIZABETH JUNE
description: LAZARUS--Elizabeth June. Died peacefully on Sunday, April 11th, 2004 at White Plains Hospital, at the age of 83. Mrs. Lazarus was born on June 25, 1920 in Elm Creek, Nebraska. She was the youngest, and final survivor, of the seven children of Cyrena Harper and Joseph Henry Stallbories. After attending Nebraska Wesleyan University on a full scholarship, June came to New York City and began a business career. She married Stanley Lazarus in New York City, who predeceased her in 1965. They had one child, a daughter, Marian Lewis of White Plains, who survives. Mrs. Lazarus was formerly a proprietor of both Larchmont Healthmart and Greenwich Healthmart. She was a lovely woman who will be sadly missed. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to Sarah Neuman Center for Healthcare and Rehabilitation, in Mamaroneck, or to White Plains Hospital, would be appreciated. For more information contact Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, 914-381-1809.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALLORY, BETTY G.
description: MALLORY--Betty G. On April 8, 2004. Loving wife of the late John H. Mallory. Beloved mother of Diane, Melissa and the late John H. Mallory Jr. Dear grandmother of Beth, John, Christina and Jamie. Proud great-grandmother of Mallory and sister of Nancy G. Ritter. Memorial service Saturday, April 17, 11 A.M. at St. Mark's Church, New Canaan, CT.

title: Spalding Gray Remembered In Tribute at Lincoln Center
description: The actor and monologuist Spalding Gray was remembered yesterday in a sorrowful memorial service before several hundred people at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, on the same Lincoln Center stage where he had performed three of his epic autobiographical tales.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: THE HAGUE: MILOSEVIC WANTS 1,631 WITNESSES Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president who stands accused of crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide at the United Nations tribunal, submitted a list of witnesses he hoped to summon for his defense. Zdenko Tomanovic, a lawyer assisting Mr. Milosevic, said the list included Bill Clinton and Tony Blair. The judges in his trial, scheduled to resume in June, will decide which witnesses may be called. Mr. Milosevic has been given 150 court days to complete his defense. (Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a historical biography project on African-Americans misstated the century in which Mary McLeod Bethune (1875-1955) was a noted black educator. It was the 20th, not the 19th. The article also misstated the name of one university with a major black oral history archive. It is the University of Southern Mississippi, not Southern Mississippi University.

title: No More Need To Forage for Blues
description: Blue foot mushrooms, named for the tender blue to violet tint on their stems and the tops of their beige caps, grow abundantly in North America and Europe from late summer through fall, when foragers search for them. But now cultivated blue foots from France and the Netherlands are being sold in the United States. The mushrooms, also called blewits, are not shy, tasting of earth and spice, and they never go limp in the pan. Saut them in butter, dusting with curry powder as they cook, and finish the dish with a little heavy cream. The mushrooms keep their color better if they are simmered in vegetable stock for 10 minutes, then used in a soup or cooled and tossed in a salad. They are $24 a pound at Dean & DeLuca, $23 at Agata & Valentina, and $32.50 at Manhattan Fruit Exchange.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. Adjuncts Set Strike Deadline
description: A group of part-time New York University professors voted to strike next Wednesday if the university's administration does not give them a contract they consider fair, Scott Sommer, a union representative, said last night. In a mail vote, 91.4 percent of the university's adjunct professors who voted, chose to strike for higher wages and for health insurance and job security, Mr. Sommer said. They have been negotiating with the university for 18 months but have not been able to come to an agreement, Mr. Sommer said. He said there were 2,300 adjunct professors at the university in the 2002-03 academic year. A university spokesman could not be reached for comment after the vote results were tallied late last night. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Bush's Letter to Sharon on Israeli Withdrawal
description: Text of Bush letter to Sharon on Israeli withdrawal WASHINGTON, April 14 (AFP) - Text of letter sent by US President George W. Bush to Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon following a meeting at the White House on an Israeli plan to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.

description: Domino's Pizza Inc., the world's second-biggest pizza chain, said yesterday that it planned to sell shares in an initial public offering and use the money to pay back debt.

title: Benefit Funds Owed Millions By Hospitals
description: Private hospitals in New York City have fallen more than $100 million behind on payments to employee benefit and pension funds in recent years, deepening the hospitals' money woes and threatening thousands of workers with the loss of health insurance and other benefits.

title: Consumer Prices Rise, Heightening Concern on Inflation
description: In another sign of a strengthening economy, the Government said this morning that consumer prices rose by 0.5 percent in March, led by higher energy and transportation costs.

title: A Phantom of the Kitchen Shows Up Downtown
description: WHAT'S this -- Jonathan Waxman cooking in a modest restaurant hidden away in the West Village? The chef who helped set the agenda of New York dining at Jams in the 1980's? Whose return to full-time chefdom at Washington Park, after years of phantom sightings in kitchens around the country, was the talk of New York just two years ago?

description: When Todd Zeile walks into the Mets' clubhouse, sunglasses on, shirt rumpled, hair tousled, he often looks as if he just woke up.

title: A Persian Carpet Bearing Sweets
description: The perfumed delicacy of rose, the pungency of saffron and the richness of sesame are evident in sweets imported from Iran by Pariya Food of Sydney, Australia. The company, started by a family that was in the food business in Iran before emigrating to Australia in 1987, is now selling its treats in New York.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Refugee Caucus Urges Asylum For Teenager
description: Members of the Congressional Refugee Caucus are calling for the Department of Homeland Security to grant asylum to a teenage immigrant from Guinea who was held in adult jails and other detention centers for three years in a legal struggle to remain in the United States. The youth, Malik Jarno, now 19, arrived in Virginia in 2001. The Congressional Black Caucus and members of the Human Rights Caucus have also urged that Mr. Jarno receive asylum. John Files (NYT)

title: With Rowland Panel Missing Its Deadline, Lawmakers Are Expecting More Delays
description: The first deadline slips by on Wednesday. The three-week extension until early May is all but an afterthought. Now it will be June, maybe late June, lawmakers say, before a decision will come from the special committee considering whether to recommend the impeachment of Gov. John G. Rowland.

title: The Subway That Started It All; 100 Years Later, Faded Traces of City's Original Remain
description: Amid the daily scrum of the New York City subway, few ever go looking for the past. Rushing to work or home, from one appointment to the next, riders scurry past mysterious doors that lead nowhere, walled off platforms and stairwells, faded sections of tile and other odd artifacts of history without a second glance or thought.

title: DRUG MAKER EARNS LESS IN FIRST QUARTER THAN EXPECTED
description: Pharmaceutical Resources, the holding company for the generic-drug maker Par Pharmaceutical, said yesterday that first-quarter net income rose to 80 cents a share from 67 cents, less than analysts had expected. The company also said it had agreed to buy Kali Laboratories for about $135 million. Legal and regulatory delays of products slowed earnings growth, a company spokesman, Stephen Mock, said. Pharmaceutical Resources did not disclose total net income and would report complete results April 29. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn $1.04 a share. The acquisition of Kali, which was closely held, expands Pharmaceutical Resources' ability to develop its more profitable medicines and rely less on partnerships, its chief executive, Scott Tarriff, told analysts on a conference call. Kali, based in Somerset, N.J., has filed for federal approval of 14 products and is developing 25 more. Pharmaceutical Resources is based in Spring Valley, N.Y.

description: President Bush vowed on Tuesday night that the United States would not bow to the surge of violence in Iraq, saying that to change course in the face of mounting attacks would betray the Iraqi people and embolden America's enemies around the world.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Wireless Telephone Expansion
description: China's biggest fixed-line phone operator, the China Telecom Corporation, agreed to pay its state-owned parent $3.4 billion for 10 phone networks as it tried to catch up with faster- growing cellular phone operators. The company said it would assume $4.8 billion of debt and sell as many as 7.56 billion new shares after May 3 to pay for the purchase. The acquisition will increase the number of lines it has by 43 million, to more than 160 million. China Telecom needs more users to increase profit, as new-line growth has lagged that of competitors.

title: Miso Makes A Good Fish Better
description: BLACK cod with miso was not invented by Nobu Matsuhisa, the chef at Nobu in TriBeCa, but he certainly popularized it. His time-consuming recipe, which calls for soaking the fish in a sweet miso marinade for a couple of days, is a variation on a traditional Japanese process that uses sake lees, the sweet solids that remain after making sake, to marinate fish.

title: Economic Scene; Alan Greenspan notwithstanding, a new book insists that government social spending does not stunt growth.
description: IN widely reported comments before a Congressional committee in February, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested that President Bush's tax cuts should not be even partly rescinded. Rather, Mr. Greenspan said, the nation should cut future domestic spending, including Social Security benefits, to balance the budget. Higher spending or higher taxes would deter economic growth, he warned.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: MACEDONIA: RUNOFF SEEN IN PRESIDENTIAL VOTE Prime Minister Branko Crvenkovski had the lead in an election for a new president to replace Boris Trajkovski, who was killed in a plane crash in February, unofficial preliminary results indicated, but he did not have a wide enough margin to avoid a runoff election on April 28. Mr. Crvenkovski's main rival, Sasko Kedev, a nationalist politician, was said to be in second place. Official results are not expected until tonight. Election rules require a candidate to have more than 50 percent of the vote to win on a first ballot, or face a runoff. Two Albanian candidates failed to get enough votes to qualify for the next round. Foreign observers said the election campaign was one of the most peaceful in years for the ethnically mixed Balkan country. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: S. & P. RAISES DEBT RATING FOR YUM BRANDS TO BBB-
description: The debt rating of Yum Brands Inc., the operator of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants, was raised to investment grade by Standard & Poor's, citing the company's debt reduction and improved profitability. Standard & Poor's raised the rating on Yum one level to BBB- from BB+. The company's outlook remains stable, Standard & Poor's said. Yum, based in Louisville, Ky., has paid down $2.6 billion in debt since 1998, and increased operating margins after it improved relationships with franchisees and increased staff training, Standard & Poor's said. The company's operating margins improved to 21.1 percent from 15 percent in 1997, Standard & Poor's said. Moody's Investors Service raised Yum to investment grade in February.

title: Dundee Is Championing A Swedish Heavyweight
description: When he sees things through his own eyes, Angelo Dundee has often said, he sees things. Minute, almost invisible, things.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Lindows Renames Its Software Overseas
description: Lindows, barred from using its name in three European countries after lawsuits by Microsoft, renamed its Linux software and Web site to avoid further litigation. Lindows renamed the software Linspire, the company said yesterday. It may still use the Lindows name in some instances in the United States. The decision by Lindows, which is based in San Diego, may have handed Microsoft a victory at a time when Microsoft is losing ground in a federal court battle with the company, said Matt Rosoff, an analyst at Directions on Microsoft. Microsoft had sued, claiming the Lindows.com name confused consumers and diluted the trademark for Windows, the operating system that runs about 95 percent of the world's personal computers. The federal judge in the case had questioned the validity of Windows as a trademark. Customers will not be affected and the change will not require an upgrade, Lindows said. The company's Web site will be renamed www.linspire.com. Lindows will be kept as the corporate name and used in ''certain instances'' in the United States, said a Lindows spokeswoman, Kira Lee.

title: Manhattanites Will Soon Find Depots Close to Home
description: THE Home Depot is moving into Manhattan, with plans to open at two locations before the end of the year. ''We feel the time is right,'' said John Costello, the executive vice president for merchandising and marketing at the Home Depot, citing the number of Manhattan residents and contractors who now travel to the other boroughs and beyond for renovation supplies.

title: Amid a Forest's Ashes, a Debate Over Logging Profits Is Burning On
description: For 120 days in 2002, a colossal wildfire scarred a half-million acres of Southern Oregon and Northern California, leaving behind a charred landscape that has turned into fertile soil for a conflict over how to manage the public forests.

title: When Red Wine Meets White Marble
description: THE designer Alene Workman in Hollywood, Fla., once had clients who discovered that their new $5,000 stainless steel and sandblasted-glass Brueton cocktail table was developing spots. They suspected a defect in the painted undersurface, or the humidity in South Florida. The culprit was an overzealous cleaning crew. ''Whatever the cleaning solution used was,'' Ms. Workman said, it ''was eating away at the paint.''

description: Harley-Davidson Inc. said yesterday that profit rose 9.9 percent in the first quarter on record demand in the United States for its motorcycles and higher sales of parts and accessories.

description: THERESA M. McGOVERN has never shied away from speaking her mind. But the death of her mother in the World Trade Center attack stunned her into silence. This public person became very private. Ms. McGovern is an assistant professor at the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, though she is best known as the founder of the H.I.V. Law Project, where for a decade she fought to change policies affecting women and poor people with AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINNOTT, EDWARD C., MD.
description: SINNOTT--Edward C., MD. Of Somers, NY and Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Roslyn and Old Westbury, NY died on April 9, 2004. A graduate of NY Medical College, he served in the U.S. Navy and then as an attending anesthesiologist at Meadowbrook Hospital in East Meadow, NY. He was Chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology and the Executive Committee of the Medical Staff at Nassau County Medical Center. He was past President of the New York State Society of Anesthesiologists and of the Nassau Academy of Medicine. Served as a Trustee of the National Board for Respiratory Care and was actively involved on the New York State Board for Professional Medical Conduct. He was born February 17, 1928 to the late J. Paul and Helen Cranwell Sinnott. He was predeceased by his loving wife, Lydia (Trini) Fitzpatrick Sinnott. He is survived by his son Edward, Jr. of Mt. Kisco, NY, daughter-in-law Eileen and three grandchildren, Daniel, Edward and William. Also survived by his brother, J. Paul, Jr. of Katonah, NY. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at the St. Francis Chapel at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY on Saturday, 10:30am. Interment will follow at the family mausoleum at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Brooklyn Man Faces Felony Charge After Arrest in Killing of Cat
description: A Brooklyn man who was left alone last week with his girlfriend's cat, Darwin, became so enraged at the animal that he beat him to death with his fists, the authorities said last night. Now he is charged with the state's most severe animal abuse charge and, if convicted, could face jail time, they said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Attack On An Election Rally
description: Hours before Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee was to campaign in Kashmir, suspected Islamic militants attacked another election rally in the town of Banihal, killing one person and wounding 22, according to local news accounts. The attack on the rally for the Congress Party was the second in a week. An attack last Thursday by suspected militants killed 9 people and injured 60. Indians are to go the polls in staggered national elections beginning Tuesday. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Theft Of J.F.K. Jr. Items Is Reported
description: An employee of Sotheby's, the Manhattan auction house where items that had been owned by John F. Kennedy Jr. were stored for safekeeping, has been charged with stealing dozens of the items. Among the 35 items reported stolen were a Father's Day card written by Mr. Kennedy, left, when he was a toddler in the White House, and a letter from Queen Elizabeth II to President and Mrs. Kennedy congratulating them on their son's birth. Prosecutors say that Mr. Gallagher sold the items -- which have been returned -- for $5,000. Mr. Gallagher was arraigned on Tuesday on charges of grand larceny and possession of stolen property, the Manhattan district attorney's office said. The arrest was first reported yesterday by The New York Post. Mr. Gallagher's lawyer, Martin D. Kane, did not return a call seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Kayaker Is Just Waiting For the Sock of the Bay
description: The afternoon after, fans were still buzzing. After Barry Bonds hit his 660th career home run on Monday and his 661st on Tuesday to pass Willie Mays, people at SBC Park were talking about the guy in the kayak.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telstra Chairman Resigns
description: Robert C. Mansfield, left, has quit as chairman of the Telstra Corporation, Australia's biggest phone company, saying the ''bond of trust'' he needed to work with the board had been broken. His resignation comes two months after a magazine, The Bulletin, said the board had rejected a plan backed by Mr. Mansfield and the chief executive, Zygmunt E. Switkowski, to make a bid of 3.5 billion Australian dollars ($2.6 billion) for John Fairfax Holdings, the country's second-biggest newspaper publisher. ''It has become evident to me recently that the bond of trust necessary for the board to operate effectively has been ruptured,'' Mr. Mansfield said. The deputy chairman, John Ralph, will fill in while a new chairman is sought, Telstra said.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Cellphone Contest
description: Some of the biggest names in telecommunications are vying to build a second cellphone network for Saudi Arabia, a kingdom of 25 million where cellphone use has grown more than 50 percent a year since 1997. Groups led by Vodafone of Britain, Deutsche Telekom of Germany and Orascom Telcom of Egypt are among the 11 finalists. Etisalat of the United Arab Emirates, Maxis of Malaysia, Telefnica Mviles of Spain, MTN of South Africa, MTC of Kuwait, Bouygues Tlcom of France, Telecom Italia Mobile of Italy and Mobilkom of Austria lead the other consortiums. Each must include at least five local partners. The license, to be awarded late this year, will entail a hefty fee and revenue-sharing agreement. The winner will compete against the government-controlled monopoly. Borzou Daragahi (NYT)

description: Shea Stadium was cold, wet, bleak and mostly empty last night. The fans who did show up entertained themselves by booing the Mets. It was as if a day of rain had washed away the pastel chalk drawing of optimism created by Monday's home opener.

title: U-HAUL PARENT SETTLES WITH I.R.S. FOR BIG TAX REFUND
description: Amerco Inc., parent of the U-Haul International truck-rental business, said it avoided paying as much as $93 million in additional tax by settling a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service. Amerco will get a net refund of $6.5 million as a result of the settlement, the company said. The settlement involved deductions taken for fiscal years ended March 31, 1996, and March 31, 1997, Amerco said. The dispute was over $372 million the company paid to resolve litigation with the family of the chief executive, Edward J. Shoen, that it deducted from Amerco's income taxes, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company estimated it could have been liable for $76 million to $93 million more in taxes if the case had been settled unfavorably.

title: The Price of Incuriosity
description: Americans knew George W. Bush was an incurious man when they elected him, but the hearings of the 9/11 investigating commission, which turned yesterday from the F.B.I.'s fecklessness to the C.I.A.'s blurred vision, have brought that fact home in a startling way. The president is trying hard to present himself as a hands-on manager who talked terrorism incessantly with the director of central intelligence, George Tenet. (''I wanted Tenet in the Oval Office all the time.'') But Mr. Tenet had to concede yesterday that he was not in Crawford, Tex., for the Aug. 6, 2001, briefing titled ''Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S.'' Mr. Tenet told the panel he didn't meet with Bush all that month, but the C.I.A. later said there had been two meetings. No one has been able to say whether Mr. Bush followed up in any way after he asked his intelligence agencies whether there was a domestic threat from Al Qaeda, and got a loud ''yes'' in response.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Tinton Falls: Body Parts Weren't Human
description: Body parts -- found last week at a recycling center have been determined as not human. Robert Honecker, the county's first assistant prosecutor, had said that a worker found a foot among construction debris at the Mazza and Sons recycling center on April 8, and that a search had turned up a forearm and right hand in advanced stages of decomposition. On Tuesday, a review by the Monmouth County medical examiner's office determined that the body parts belonged to an unspecified primate. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DirecTV Awarded $51.5 Million From Pegasus
description: The DirecTV Group was awarded $51.5 million from the Pegasus Communications Corporation, which markets the DirecTV satellite-television service in rural areas, in a Los Angeles jury trial over a marketing agreement. DirecTV will ask the judge to also award $11 million in interest, DirecTV said. The trial in federal district court in Los Angeles is one of several legal disputes pending between the companies. Shares of Pegasus, based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., fell $4.33, to $30.21, after the verdict was announced. In trading after the close of United States markets, Pegasus shares fell another $1.81, to $28.40. The company said it previously expensed $35 million as an accrued liability on its balance sheet in anticipation of the jury's award. ''We will be giving careful consideration to our legal options respecting the verdict, including our rights of appeal,'' Cheryl Crate, vice president for communications at Pegasus, said in a statement. Shares of DirecTV, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., rose 25 cents, to $17.15.

Nashala, who is also seeking $80,000 in damages from the school district, has been allowed to return to classes and wear her head scarf pending resolution of the case. Judge Frank H. Seay has yet to rule on a petition by the school district to dismiss the case. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Port Authority Crime Drops Sharply
description: Crime at airports, bus terminals and other sites operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey fell by 8.3 percent last year and has dropped by 44.8 percent since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, officials said. Crime is defined as robbery, larceny, or assault, said Tony Ciavolella, a Port Authority spokesman. He said the decline was attributed largely to the 550 new police officers the authority had hired since the attacks, and to a $300 million security upgrade. The agency now has more than 1,600 officers. The authority, which also operates the PATH commuter trains, has been on a heightened state of alert since 2001. The authority, which lost 37 of its officers in the attack on the World Trade Center, now has 1,600 officers. John Holl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORAN, CHARLES F.
description: MORAN--Charles F., retired business leader and civic benefactor, passed away at his home in Wheaton on Monday (April 12, 2004). He retired in 1993 as Senior Vice President and as a member of the Sears Roebuck and Co. Management Committee after a forty year career with Sears. Most recently he was Chairman of the Board of Denny's Corporation, and President of the Homan Arthington Foundation, which was responsible for redeveloping the original Sears headquarters location on Chicago's West Side into affordable housing for threehundred families in the North Lawndale neighborhood. Mr. Moran was born in Brooklyn, NY, in 1930, and developed a lifelong love for sports and humor. He starred as a catcher at Drew University in Madison, NJ, played in the Northern League on a team affiliated with the New York Yankees, and earned positions with numerous traveling All-Star baseball teams. He caught batting practice for the Brooklyn Dodgers on several occasions, including for the 1949 Major League All-Star Game held at Ebbets Field. One All-Star team appearance in 1948 led him to Mauch Chunk, PA (now Jim Thorpe, PA), where he met his wife of fifty-two years, Dolores Huber. After a short Army stint, Mr. Moran joined Sears as a trainee in its Hackensack, NJ store. In forty years and seven moves he took on increasing responsibility, ranging from spilling paint as a trainee to selling the Sears Tower, from plowing Sears parking lots to building new parking lots, and from integrating Dean Witter and Coldwell Banker into Sears to then subsequently leading the divestiture of these units. Sears retired Chairman, President and CEO Edward Brennan said ''Charley was a man of great competence and total integrity. Whenever there was a tough challenge, he could be counted on to handle it successfully.'' Mr. Moran also acted as Chairman of Thermadyne Holdings Corporation, and Prodigy Services (a joint venture between Sears and IBM that was a key precursor to the Internet). He acted on numerous corporate boards, including Discover Bank and the Morgan Stanley Trust Company, SPS Transaction Services, Inc., Advantis, Inc., DeSoto, Inc., and Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc. His other civic contributions included membership in the Sorin Society at the University of Notre Dame, and as a benefactor to many needy students. He leaves a loving family, and numerous friends and colleagues who will miss him for his many contributions. His ongoing legacy is his family--wife, Dolores; daughter, Mary (William) Deatherage; son, Charles (Dianne) Moran; daughter, Alice Moran; son, John (Laura) Moran; and eleven grandchildren. Visitation will be at 4-9 P.M on Wednesday, April 14, at Williams-Kampp Funeral Home at 430 E. Roosevelt Rd. in Wheaton. A funeral Mass will be held at 10 A.M. on Thursday, April 15, at St. Mark Catholic Church at 303 E. Parkway Drive in Wheaton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rush University Medical Center Cancer Institute, 1700 W. Van Buren, Suite 250, Chicago, IL 60612, or to the Homan Arthington Foundation, 3517 W. Arthington Street, Chicago, IL 60624.

title: Interior Design, No Appointment Necessary
description: Kevin Mancini and Payam Yazdani stumbled into the Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis architectural office while searching the hip Lower East Side for a place to open their new coffee shop, Ini Ani. ''They became our first walk-in clients,'' said Paul Lewis (far left, with his partners Marc Tsurumaki, center, and David J. Lewis, his twin brother). Challenged by a bare-bones budget of $35,000, the architects did much of the fabrication themselves. They used inexpensive construction materials like corrugated cardboard to create a screen (above) that wraps around the cafe's sitting area, delineating circulation from seating and providing acoustical dampening. Custom oak and stainless steel chairs (above left) mirror the profile of a built-in wraparound bench. The cardboard wall system's steel supports are echoed in hanging steel light fixtures. There is a decorative plaster relief (top left) of 479 individually cast coffee cup lids, gathered from the neighborhood. Paul Lewis said, ''I love the idea that these functional elements could be very repetitive, yet have incredible variation as well.'' Ini Ani serves coffee, tea, and multiethnic snacks including a Persian breakfast of feta, figs, dates, tomatoes and cucumbers. It is at 105 Stanton Street (Ludlow Street); (212) 254-9066. Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis is at (212) 505-5955. ANNA HOLTZMAN

title: National Briefing | Washington: Toys Recalled After Death And Injuries
description: Hundreds of thousands of toy automobiles -- Batman-themed cars and ride-on toy trucks -- have been recalled because more than a dozen children have been hurt and one killed while playing with them, federal officials said. The manufacturers of the toys, Mattel of El Segundo, Calif., and Tek Nek Toys International of Grapevine, Tex., announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Mattel said it had recalled more than 300,000 of its Batman cars because the sharp tips of their plastic tail wings could cause cuts, scrapes and other injuries. Tek Nek Toys said it had recalled about 70,000 of its trucks because screws attaching the steering wheels had come off, posing a choking hazard. The company said one child died after swallowing such a screw. Mattel can be reached by calling, toll free, 888-271-9891; the telephone number for Tek Nek Toys, also toll free, is (888) 661-0222. John Files (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Posts $45 Million Profit
description: Advanced Micro Devices had its second quarterly profit since 2001 as rising sales included higher demand for chips like the Opteron that are more profitable. Net income was $45 million, or 12 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $146.4 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier, Advanced Micro said yesterday. Sales grew from $714.6 million a year earlier. Under its chief executive, Hector de J. Ruiz, Advanced Micro has taken market share from Intel in so-called NOR flash-memory chips, which store programming code and software in cellphones and computers. The company, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has also introduced a range of 64-bit Opteron processors that can handle existing programs as well as newer and more-powerful software used in network servers. Last year, shipments of Opteron-based systems showed an almost tenfold increase from the second quarter, when they were introduced, to 22,244 in the fourth quarter, the market researcher Gartner has said. Advanced Micro shares rose 38 cents, to $17.50, in extended trading after the report. They fell 4 cents, to $17.12, in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNDY, JOHN HINE
description: MUNDY--John Hine. John Mundy, Professor Emeritus, died peacefully at home on April 13. Born in London in 1917, he was educated in New York at the St. Thomas Choir School, Trinity School and Columbia College and received his Ph.D. in history at Columbia University. Following military service in the U.S. Army Signal Corps in the Second World War he taught medieval and modern European history for over forty years at Columbia, where he was Chairman of the History Department in the 1960s. A specialist in the history of twelfth and thirteenth century Toulouse, he also wrote widely on modern and contemporary history. His latest book is due for publication in England this year. Over the years John Mundy taught at Barnard College, the School of General Studies, the Institute of Adv anced Study at Princeton, the University of Chicago and Fordham and Brown Universities. He also lectured at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New School of Social Research and the Aldeburgh Music Festival in England, and was Directeur d'Etudes en Sciences Sociales at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes in Paris. Professor Mundy was a Fellow of both the American Council of Learned Societies and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. A member of the Medieval Academy of America, he served as its President in 1988-89. He is survived by his wife Charlotte, son John, daughter Martha, sister Meg, granddaughters Sara and Thea and nephew Sotos Yannopoulos. In lieu of flowers, gifts in John's memory may be sent to: The Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University, New York, NY 10027.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACPHERSON, HOWARD DOBBINS
description: MacPHERSON -- Howard Dobbins. Died peacefully on April 14, 2004 at the age of 100. He lived at home in Mahwah, NJ. His three children, 10 grandchildren and 16 greatgrandchildren will remember him for his kindness and optimism. His father was a Presbyterian minister and he grew up in Virginia, graduating from Hampden-Sydney College and receiving a Master's from Princeton University. Sent to Europe by Mobil Oil, he met Mildred Snow in Rome and they were married in 1936. Howard worked at Mobil for 33 years, and then had a second career overseeing international trade for New York state. After his beloved wife died in 1980, Howard devoted himself to taking care of his neighbors and old friends, and was also a proud member of the Ramapo Reformed Church. Services will be held for him there at 11 AM, Saturday, April 17 (100 Island Road, Mahwah, NJ).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Sales Fall

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: OKLAHOMA: U.S. MAY INTERVENE IN HEAD-SCARF SUIT The Department of Justice may intervene in a lawsuit brought by an 11-year-old Muslim girl after the Muskogee public schools twice suspended her for wearing a head scarf, a federal judge ruled. A brief filed by the department said a school district policy banning head coverings in class violated the religious beliefs of the girl, Nashala Hearn, and should be amended. Nashala, who is also seeking $80,000 in damages from the school district, has been allowed to return to classes and wear her head scarf pending resolution of the case. Judge Frank H. Seay has yet to rule on a petition by the school district to dismiss the case. Steve Barnes (NYT)

Mr. Walls, 64, a former Johnson County Republican chairman, had rejected pleas from party officials to abandon his candidacy, saying that his cross-dressing was ''a small part of my personal past'' and had been resolved to his family's satisfaction. Mr. Walls received 40 percent of the vote, and his opponent, Rob Orr, a real estate broker, 60 percent. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: The Humble Hard Drive, Transformed Into a Video Grab Bag
description: Digital video and computers may go together like a horse and carriage, but getting the video out of the camera and onto the PC is where many people get tangled up in the reins -- especially those whose computers lack the FireWire connection common to digital video cameras. There is equipment that can help you burn that footage of the peewee hockey game onto a DVD, including video-capture cards that can be installed in your computer to connect the camera directly to the PC and bulky external decoder boxes that can connect it via a U.S.B. port. The new AVerMedia UltraTV USB 300 External TV Tuner gives you a pocket-size solution, and it can also play and record live television on your laptop or desktop PC.

title: Space-Age Concrete Blocks That Let You See the Light
description: Sunlight travels through LiTraCon, above, a concrete that is 5 percent fiber optic glass. In the Hungarian factory where it is made, large pieces of concrete are molded by hand with optical fibers running through them. When the concrete is crosscut into individual blocks, sections of the fibers are revealed as conduits for light, said Andreas Bittis, a German architect. Mr. Bittis is marketing the material with Aron Losonczi, 27, the Hungarian architect who invented it. ''Next year, we will think about distribution in the United States or China,'' Mr. Bittis said. The light-transmitting blocks will be displayed in ''Liquid Stone: New Architecture in Concrete,'' opening June 19 at the National Building Museum, 401 F Street NW, Washington; (202) 272-2448; www.nbm.org. Information about the blocks is available from LiTraCon: 011-49-241-533-258; www.litracon.com. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Runoff Seen In Presidential Vote
description: Prime Minister Branko Crvenkovski had the lead in an election for a new president to replace Boris Trajkovski, who was killed in a plane crash in February, unofficial preliminary results indicated, but he did not have a wide enough margin to avoid a runoff election on April 28. Mr. Crvenkovski's main rival, Sasko Kedev, a nationalist politician, was said to be in second place. Official results are not expected until tonight. Election rules require a candidate to have more than 50 percent of the vote to win on a first ballot, or face a runoff. Two Albanian candidates failed to get enough votes to qualify for the next round. Foreign observers said the election campaign was one of the most peaceful in years for the ethnically mixed Balkan country.

title: In Major Shift, Bush Endorses Sharon Plan and Backs Keeping Some Israeli Settlements
description: President Bush on Wednesday recognized Israel's right to retain some West Bank settlements as part of any peace accord with the Palestinians as he formally endorsed Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw from Gaza and parts of the West Bank. He called the plan ''historic'' and ''courageous.''

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: 10 Indicted In Gunrunning Scheme
description: Ten Oklahoma residents have been indicted by a federal grand jury in connection with a scheme in which 240 handguns were purchased from legitimate dealers in the Tulsa area and then transported to Baltimore for illegal sale on the streets. The indictment contends that three men -- Dorian B. Carr Jr., 30, and Alvin E. Edwards, 23, both of Muskogee; and Christopher D. Fields, 19, of Okmulgee -- provided money to seven other people, who then bought the weapons after providing false information to sales clerks. As convicted felons, Mr. Carr and Mr. Edwards could not lawfully buy handguns, the indictment said. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Gets A New Judge
description: A Scottish judge, Lord Bonomy, will join the three-judge panel of the international war crimes tribunal that is trying the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, the court announced. Lord Bonomy, 58, arrived at the tribunal this week to begin to familiarize himself with testimony from nearly 300 witness before the trial resumes in June. He replaces another British judge, Richard May, who was forced to step down in February because of ill health. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Cease-Fire Monitors
description: The African Union said it would send military observers to Sudan's Darfur region, where vicious fighting has sent more than 100,000 refugees pouring across the border into neighboring Chad. The monitors, from Nigeria, Ghana, Senegal and Namibia, are to ensure that government soldiers, militia groups and rebel fighters abide by a 45-day cease-fire agreement intended to allow aid workers to reach the suffering. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: STEEL DYNAMICS SAYS PROFIT WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: Steel Dynamics Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit would rise to as much as 90 cents a share, higher than analysts' estimates. The company, which is based in Fort Wayne, Ind., was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call to earn 63 cents a share. Steel Dynamics, which makes automotive and appliance steel from recycled metal, is benefiting from a surcharge imposed to cover the rising cost of raw materials, including scrap steel, which rose $93 a ton from a year earlier.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Greece Endorses Reunification
description: Greece's prime minister, Costas Caramanlis, gave a qualified endorsement to the United Nations plan to reunify Cyprus and urged the island's Greece Cypriot majority to approve it in a referendum on April 24. ''We should not allow the plan's injustices to blur our vision of the future,'' he said after a four-hour meeting of Greece's political leaders and president. ''What is important now is to calmly see how we can make the best of the plan's positive elements within the framework of the European Union.'' His remarks, televised in Greece and Cypress, came amid international pressure on Athens to come out in support of the plan. In the past week alone, President Bush placed three telephone calls to Mr. Caramanlis. In Brussels, at the opening of an international meeting to assess the needs for Cyprus, Washington pledged $400 million, conditional on acceptance of the plan by both sides on Cyprus. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

It was Gen. John P. Abizaid, the head of Central Command, who said at a news briefing in Baghdad on Monday that there would "probably end up being a uniquely Iraqi solution" to the effort to bring Mr. Sadr to justice, and that "we're applying the military force necessary to assist in that regard." Only then will he go back to living at home with his family. Frank said that his staff had prepared 35 DVD's worth of material on each of the Nets' potential opponents, although for now his attention will be on the Knicks. ''You don't put a limit on it,'' he said of the hours he will be putting in as he prepares for the first playoff games of his coaching career. ''Whatever it takes. You don't want to leave any stone unturned. You want to give your best effort.'' Coaching against Franks is the Knicks' Lenny Wilkens, the dean of N.B.A. coaches. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNDY, JOHN HINE
description: MUNDY--John Hine. John Mundy, Professor Emeritus, died peacefully at home on April 13. Born in London in 1917, he was educated in New York at the St. Thomas Choir School, Trinity School and Columbia College and received his Ph.D. in history at Columbia University. Following military service in the U.S. Army Signal Corps in the Second World War he taught medieval and modern European history for over forty years at Columbia, where he was Chairman of the History Department in the 1960s. A specialist in the history of twelfth and thirteenth century Toulouse, he also wrote widely on modern and contemporary history. His latest book is due for publication in England this year. Over the years John Mundy taught at Barnard College, the School of General Studies, the Institute of Adv anced Study at Princeton, the University of Chicago and Fordham and Brown Universities. He also lectured at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New School of Social Research and the Aldeburgh Music Festival in England, and was Directeur d'Etudes en Sciences Sociales at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes in Paris. Professor Mundy was a Fellow of both the American Council of Learned Societies and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. A member of the Medieval Academy of America, he served as its President in 1988-89. He is survived by his wife Charlotte, son John, daughter Martha, sister Meg, granddaughters Sara and Thea and nephew Sotos Yannopoulos. In lieu of flowers, gifts in John's memory may be sent to: The Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University, New York, NY 10027.

title: 36 Hours | Sonoma, Calif.
description: SONOMA, in the heart of California's oh-so-trendy wine country, is one of the few places in the region where the word ''country'' still seems appropriate. Mud-spattered pickup trucks park alongside luxury cars, roosters crow throughout the day, and four draft horses live a half block from the town square. The area's Spanish and Mexican heritage is evident in the central plaza, which is surrounded by a historic mission, whitewashed adobe buildings and the fortress barracks of Gen. Mariano Vallejo, the Mexican commander who established Sonoma in 1835. The Sonoma Valley's ideal climate and rich rocky soil also turn out an endless cornucopia of grapes and excellent produce, and award-winning local chefs use the fresh bounty to their advantage. title: WORLDCOM PLANS TO EXIT BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION TUESDAY
description: The telecommunications company WorldCom Inc., which filed the biggest bankruptcy in United States history in 2002, plans to exit court protection Tuesday, a WorldCom lawyer said. The lawyer, Marcia Goldstein, told Judge Jed Rakoff of the company's plans during a hearing yesterday in federal court in New York. The timing indicates that WorldCom will meet a federal Bankruptcy Court deadline of April 28 for exiting bankruptcy. The original Feb. 28 deadline was pushed back so the company could complete a financial restatement, which ultimately wiped out $74 billion in pretax income, including the $10.6 billion of fraudulent accounting that forced WorldCom to seek protection from creditors.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung Profit Nearly Triples
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's second-largest chip maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income almost tripled as sales of its flat-screen displays and cellphones rose. Net income was 3.1 trillion South Korean won ($2.7 billion), compared with 1.1 trillion won in the period a year earlier. Samsung, which last year generated more profit than any other Asian electronics company, is benefiting from surging demand for its memory chips and flat-panel displays.

title: A Palestinian Clings to His Dream of Going Back Home
description: Mustafa Ghwaleh, 66, has lived in the same tidy house for more than half a century, building it with his own sweat to accommodate his 8 children and 10 grandchildren, several of them still living at home. Despite a house that reflects decades of loving care, Mr. Ghwaleh still describes himself as a refugee in a temporary camp. On Thursday, he settled into his living room couch with a cup of sweetened tea and scolded President Bush for suggesting that Palestinian refugees should prepare for a future in a truncated Palestinian state and give up the notion of returning to their old land, which is now part of Israel.

title: CIT TO BUY LEASING UNIT FROM GATX FOR ABOUT $200 MILLION
description: The CIT Group, which finances purchases of items like aircraft and trains, agreed to buy the GATX Corporation's technology-leasing unit for about $200 million in cash and undisclosed debt to lease more computer equipment. GATX valued the unit's assets at about $520 million. It had $200 million in sales last year, a GATX spokesman, Robert Lyons, said. CIT, based in Livingston, N.J., expects to complete the purchase before July 31. The purchase gives CIT, which was sold to the public by Tyco International Inc. in 2002, the ability to finance more computer- network services for companies, a spokesman, Doug Donsky, said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 36 Indicted In Insurance Fraud
description: District Attorney Richard A. Brown announced the indictment of 36 people yesterday, including a reputed Bonanno crime family associate, who prosecutors say engineered a multimillion-dollar automobile insurance fraud. Those accused include five lawyers, three doctors, a dentist, a psychologist, a chiropractor, a physical therapist, an acupuncturist and an insurance company claims manager. Authorities said the scam involved staged accidents and fake victims who received unneeded treatments at a Richmond Hill medical clinic. Joseph Fratta, whom authorities identified as a reputed Bonanno associate, is accused of supervising the operation, and has been indicted on several charges, including enterprise corruption. Stacy Albin (NYT)

It will be fascinating to watch as the neighborhood discovers how to use it.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Report To China On Election Laws
description: The government sent Beijing a report seeking permission to pursue some changes to local election laws, but suggesting that further democratization should take place gradually. The report gave no hint of a timetable for achieving universal suffrage, and it angered Hong Kong's democracy movement. Jackie Hung, the financial secretary and spokeswoman for the Civil Human Rights Front, a coalition of civic groups and democracy advocates, said that Tung Chee-hwa, the Beijing-backed chief executive, should have consulted the public more before submitting the report. ''It proves he was only responsible to the Beijing government and not to the Hong Kong people,'' she said. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NORTH KOREA ETERNAL PRESIDENT North Korea celebrated the 92nd anniversary of the birth of Kim Il Sung, who almost 10 years after his death is still president of the Communist state he founded in 1948. Thousands danced in colorful costumes to the memory of the world's only deceased head of state, state television showed. King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, an old friend, was in Pyongyang to show "boundless reverence" for Kim, while the presidents of Russia, Pakistan and the Palestinian Authority sent messages or floral baskets, the official KCNA news agency said. Kim's son, Kim Jong Il, the "Dear Leader," inherited power from his father, now called "Eternal President." To celebrate his father's birthday, he promoted eight lieutenant generals and 65 major generals. (Reuters)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xerox To Report On Plastic Electronics
description: Xerox said that it would present a report today outlining what it said is major progress toward creating electronics out of inexpensive, flexible plastic. The report, which will be presented at the spring meeting of the Materials Research Society in San Francisco, will detail advances in its development of conductive, semiconductive and insulating inks. Xerox will also describe its ability to fashion them into an electronic circuit using an inkjet printer in normal atmospheric conditions, according to Beng Ong, a fellow at Xerox's Canadian research center. Organic electronics will never match silicon for processing speed, but such plastic devices would not have to be made in expensive clean rooms as today's chips are. Xerox and others are racing to develop them for less demanding applications like electronic displays and radio identification tags. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: A Lag In Clothing Sales
description: Hennes & Mauritz, Europe's largest clothing retailer, said sales in March rose half as much as analysts had forecast because colder weather eroded demand for spring fashions. Revenue climbed 7 percent; analysts had expected a gain of 14 percent. Sales growth was less than 10 percent for the first time in four months, Hennes & Mauritz said. The company, based in Stockholm, has cut prices to offset lackluster demand in Germany, the source of a third of its sales and its main market. The company is opening 51 stores and closing 3 in its second quarter, which ends May 31. The company opened its first outlets in Canada in March.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brookhaven: Official Pleads To Corruption Charge
description: A town politician embroiled in a corruption scandal pleaded guilty yesterday to extorting bribes from residential builders. The politician, Theodore Rickman, served on the Zoning Board of Appeals for the Town of Brookhaven, where he accepted $16,000 in bribes in exchange for ''yes'' votes on different builders' proposals from September 2002 to last month, according to the Suffolk County district attorney's office. Mr. Rickman, who is also the treasurer of the Brookhaven Republican Party, will now cooperate with an investigation into corruption in Suffolk County politics, the district attorney's office said. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACPHERSON, HOWARD DOBBINS
description: MacPHERSON -- Howard Dobbins. Died peacefully on April 14, 2004 at the age of 100. He lived at home in Mahwah, NJ. His three children, 10 grandchildren and 16 greatgrandchildren will remember him for his kindness and optimism. His father was a Presbyterian minister and he grew up in Virginia, graduating from Hampden-Sydney College and receiving a Master's from Princeton University. Sent to Europe by Mobil Oil, he met Mildred Snow in Rome and they were married in 1936. Howard worked at Mobil for 33 years, and then had a second career overseeing international trade for New York state. After his beloved wife died in 1980, Howard devoted himself to taking care of his neighbors and old friends, and was also a proud member of the Ramapo Reformed Church. Services will be held for him there at 11 AM, Saturday, April 17 (100 Island Road, Mahwah, NJ).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fewer Homeless On The Streets
description: The number of homeless people sleeping on the streets of Manhattan has declined slightly even as the population in city shelters has surged, city officials said yesterday in releasing the second annual census of street homelessness. In February, the Department of Homeless Services counted people sleeping on the streets, in subway cars and in doorways, and from those numbers, the city concluded that there were a total of 2,694 homeless people on the streets of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island. (Queens and the Bronx will be added to the calculations next year.) In Manhattan, the only borough surveyed in 2003, the city found 1,472 homeless people, a slight decline from the 1,560 counted last year. Officials said that in the same period, the number of adults in shelters citywide rose by more than 600, to nearly 9,000 people. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: At the Auto Show, Dreamers and Their Cars
description: ABOUT 1,000 cars and trucks are on display at the 2004 New York International Automobile Show, which ends this Sunday, but in truth there are only two types: those you can touch and those you can't. The touchable ones -- the 2004 models, that is -- are open to inspection; attendees stand in line to get behind the wheel, and the exhibition halls resonate with the pleasing thunk of trunks and doors being open and shut. The untouchables -- the concepts, the exotics, anything with an Italian name -- sit behind velvet ropes and rotate on canted stages, as distant as movie stars at the Oscars and just as photographed. Up to a million car buffs are expected to crowd into the show, potential buyers among them, but mostly those who come to gawk, to touch and to dream, perchance to drive. DANA WHITE

title: Region's Air Doesn't Meet New Standards
description: Most of the people who live in New York State and all the residents of New Jersey and Connecticut are breathing air that does not meet new federal health standards for smog, according to a report released yesterday by federal environmental officials. The pollution is a combination of dirty emissions produced in the states themselves and contaminants that float in on air coming from the Midwest and central Canada.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 605 Kidnapped In Chechnya In 2003
description: The Interior Ministry announced that 605 people had been kidnapped last year in Chechnya and that another 249 people had been kidnapped in adjacent regions affected by the long-running conflict. It said 253 of these people had been freed. Kidnapping is widely used by the Russian military, the local government and rebel fighters as a tool of terror. The human rights group Memorial has reported that 492 people were kidnapped in the 30 percent of Chechnya where it is able to operate, suggesting that the overall figure is much higher than the official count. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: A Soldier's Sacrifice
description: It was about 3 a.m. and pitch-black when the convoy of U.S. Army trucks, traveling south on Highway 1, turned right and began moving along a rutted dirt road near Bayji, a small town in the Sunni Triangle about 25 miles north of Tikrit.

description: A World Of Wings

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Bus Contracts Questioned
description: School bus contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars a year have been awarded without public bids since 1979, officials said yesterday at a hearing of the City Council's Education Committee. Unlike other city agencies, the Education Department -- which spends about $2.5 billion a year on goods and services -- is not subject to review by the comptroller. The schools chancellor's office said that almost half of the $1.36 billion in no-bid contracts this fiscal year had gone toward transportation. ''I am not convinced that taxpayers or children are getting what they are entitled to,'' said Eva S. Moskowitz, the committee chairwoman.

description: One Bankers Trust Plaza has been dressed for its own funeral since 2001. Now the time is at hand.

description: ON both sides of the river, the court is 94 feet long and 50 feet wide. The basket is 10 feet high. The ball is round, N.B.A.-approved, with between seven and a half and eight and a half pounds of pressure. Almost everything else relating to the game of professional basketball looks and feels very different, from Midtown Manhattan to East Rutherford, N.J.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 16  Ignoring South Korean voters' rejection of the impeachment of President Roh Moo Hyun, the nation's Constitutional Court said today that it would not be dissuaded by the election returns.

Without being asked about it, he brought up his turnover that jump-started the Lightning's 3-0 victory on Wednesday night that gave Tampa Bay a 3-1 lead in the four-of-seven-game first-round playoff series.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Globalstar Emerges From Bankruptcy
description: Globalstar, the $4 billion satellite phone system begun by a partnership led by Qualcomm and Loral Space and Communications, said yesterday that it had emerged from bankruptcy. Its new owners, Thermo Capital Partners, paid $43 million for 81.25 percent of its stock, with the remainder being divided among former bondholders, Qualcomm and Loral, according to a company spokesman. Thermo Capital, which is run by Jim Lynch in Denver and Jay Monroe in New Orleans, had previously focused on real estate, energy and terrestrial telecommunications investments. Globalstar, which had roughly 40,000 subscribers when it entered bankruptcy protection just over two years ago and now has 110,000 subscribers in 120 countries, is trying to follow in the footsteps of Iridium, a formerly bankrupt rival that now operates profitably. Globalstar will remain based in San Jose, Calif. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

No opponent, site, television network or specific date has been announced. Geoffrey Gray

Yet every so often a project comes along with such a grotesquely negative cost-benefit ratio that even the most cynical citizen snaps awake.

description: A labor arbitrator ruled yesterday that the City Department of Education violated the public school teachers' contract last year when it rejected sabbatical requests from hundreds of teachers in a budget-cutting move that saved $35 million.

description: The atmosphere was ideal at Senator John Kerry's rally this morning at the University of Pittsburgh . On a jacketless spring day, the sun spilled over thousands of students on an outdoor plaza surrounded by architectural gems. The sound system carried crisp notes from Jon Bon Jovi's guitar . There was a clear view of the candidate, framed by flags and homemade signs.

title: Shopping List | Bird Watching
description: SPRING means the return of birds who spent the winter elsewhere. title: A Hemisphere Shows Its Many-Cultured Glory
description: For the last few decades, the Brooklyn Museum of Art's Hall of the Americas, the display arena for objects from the museum's hallowed collections of North, Central and South American art, was a place that most visitors rushed through on their way to see other things. Painted an institutional gray-green and with its stellar exhibits half hidden in cumbersome installations, the hall had not been refurbished since the 1960's.

title: Special Day Honors Jackie Robinson
description: Rachel Robinson can recall even the mundane details of that historic day 57 years ago yesterday: her tiny Manhattan hotel room, the search for a taxicab to take her to Brooklyn, the fur coat in which she bundled her infant son at chilly Ebbets Field.

He discussed the film with conservatives like Bill O'Reilly, on Fox television, but did not ''deploy'' them to encourage their audiences to see it, and Mr. O'Reilly did not recommend it.

title: From One Commission to Another: Shut Up
description: There is a growing chorus of criticism against members of the 9/11 commission that they are behaving like partisan players in what was supposed to be an objective review of the terrorist attacks. After all, you can't turn on the television or flip through a newspaper (including to this page) without encountering panel members pontificating on the hearings. While we are confident that the commission will ultimately be able to produce a constructive and unbiased report, as members of another panel on terrorism we also know the value of silence.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Retail Sales Surge
description: Retail sales in Singapore surged 41 percent in February from a year earlier, more than twice the expected pace, suggesting that an export-led recovery in the economy is beginning to fuel domestic spending. The rise in the Statistics Department's retail sales index compared with a forecast by economists for an increase of 19 percent. Excluding vehicles, retail sales rose 16.5 percent, the most in at least six years. Adjusted for seasonal factors, overall retail sales rose 23 percent from the previous month. Excluding cars, sales rose by a seasonally adjusted 8.6 percent from January.

description: Phil Sokolof, a Nebraska industrialist whose heart attack turned him into a national evangelist of a low-cholesterol diet, died on Thursday in Omaha. He was 82.

title: JUDGE GIVES UAL MORE TIME TO FILE A RECOVERY PLAN
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, was given another extension to file its recovery plan yesterday by a federal bankruptcy judge, pushing the deadline to June 30 from May 8. The ruling by Judge Eugene R. Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court at a hearing in Chicago gives UAL the exclusive right to submit a recovery plan until June 30. Creditors are precluded during that time from submitting competing proposals. UAL's deadline for soliciting acceptances of the recovery plan from creditors was extended until August 30, from July 7.

title: Coach Unites Current Yankee Underdog With One of the Team's Former Stars
description: They have a bond that is loose yet strong. They played baseball for the same high school, a decade apart. They were deeply influenced by the same coach, who was the father of one of them. They both made it to the major leagues and played for the Yankees. One is still here, while the other is not and does not miss it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Aviation Officials Sentenced In Country's Worst Crash
description: A Milan court found four aviation officials guilty of manslaughter and negligence for their role in a runway crash at Linate Airport in Milan in 2001 that killed 118 people. The airport's director and a traffic controller received eight-year prison terms, while the former chief of Italy's air traffic control agency and a supervisor of Milan's two airports received six-and-a-half-year terms. The accident, in which a Copenhagen-bound SAS plane collided with a private Cessna in heavy fog, was Italy's worst air disaster. The airport did not have a working ground-radar system at the time. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Stake Sold
description: The South Kore-an government sold its 22 percent stake in Hana Bank for 1.07 trillion won ($920 million), removing concern that the bank, the nation's fourth-largest lender, would have to purchase the shares with its own capital. The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation, the state agency that held the stake, sold 42.7 million shares at 25,050 won each to domestic and overseas investors, a Hana spokesman, An Young Geun, said. The price was 4.9 percent lower than Wednesday's closing price. The sale frees Hana from a commitment to buy part of the stake and gives it more funds to expand into asset management and brokerage businesses to reduce its reliance on lending.

description: IMAGINE. The Celtics, the Bruins and the Red Sox all in the playoffs at the same time. What a concept.

description: The Islanders finally found a way to solve Tampa Bay goalie Nikolai Khabibulin but were eliminated by a shooting star in overtime.

title: GOODYEAR IS PURCHASING THE REMAINING 50% OF DACKIA
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company agreed to buy for an undisclosed price the 50 percent of the Swedish tire retailer Dackia that it does not already own. Dackia has more than 60 company-owned stores and annual sales of about $65 million, Goodyear said. Procuritas Partners KB, a private equity firm with offices in Stockholm and Copenhagen, and Dackia management owned the other 50 percent, said Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio. The unit will be managed by Goodyear Dunlop Tires Europe, the company said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wages Rise
description: Propelled by bankers' bonuses, British wages rose at their fastest in almost three years in the quarter that ended Feb. 29. The Office of National Statistics said the increase was 4.9 percent, the highest since August 2001. In the same period, unemployment fell slightly to the lowest rate in 29 years, the office said. The figures could add to pressure for higher interest rates in May to head off inflation, economists said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

Beloved husband of Jeanne and the late Ann Dixon Ronan. Loving father of Monica Ronan, Mark Ronan and his wife Maureen, Maura Olson and her husband Lawrence. Devoted grandfather of six. title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Bandannas Not Ruled Out
description: The new education minister, Franois Fillon, suggested that the law prohibiting the wearing of religious symbols in schools, including Islamic head scarves, could be interpreted to allow bandannas. ''It is only necessary that it not be ostentatious, because that's what the law says,'' he said. ''There were bandannas in school before the question of the head scarf issue came up.'' At a gathering of the Union of Islamic Organizations of France last weekend, the group's leader proposed that Muslim girls learn to use bandannas as ''discreet headwear.'' Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retail Stake Purchased
description: Nomura Holdings said it would invest 50 billion yen ($463 million) for a majority stake in the holding company of the Seibu Department Store group, which is undergoing a major turnaround. The investment by the Nomura Principal Finance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Nomura, Japan's biggest brokerage firm, is part of a 100 billion yen bailout of the retailer. Mizuho Corporate Bank, a major lender to Seibu, will invest 40 billion yen in the retailer in the form of a debt-for-equity swap with the remainder coming from other shareholders. Last year, Seibu, one of Japan's biggest department store chains, took over a failed department store, Sogo, and combined its operations under the holding company Millennium Retailing Group. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: 9/11 Panel Calls Policies On Immigration Ineffective
description: The commission investigating the 9/11 attacks has concluded that immigration policies promoted as essential to keeping the country safe from future attacks have been largely ineffective, producing little, if any, information leading to the identification or apprehension of terrorists.

title: Spain Says It Has Arrested 3 More Suspects in Train Bombings
description: On its last day before turning over power to the Socialists, Spain's conservative government announced it had made three more arrests of suspected Islamic militants. Interior Minister ngel Acebes, just hours from stepping down, said the new suspects were a Moroccan, an Egyptian and a Saudi citizen, all of whom had made contacts with a presumed leader of the Madrid train bombings in March.

title: Corrections

In a study by Stanley Milgram, people were asked to administer electrical shocks to strangers, but no electricity was actually used, and the recipients feigned their distress.

title: Making Nanotechnology More Than a Nanoissue
description: In the latest reflection of debate over what constitutes a nanotechnology company, Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it had dropped six companies and added three to its recently created nanotechnology stock index.

description: The Justice Department moved on Thursday to shut down what it said was a health-benefits fraud that it said allowed employers nationwide to disguise wages by listing them as nontaxable reimbursement for medical costs or by deducting health insurance premiums improperly, costing the government both income and Social Security taxes.

title: Replacing Glavine Is Mets' First Domino in Defeat
description: Tom Glavine had been at his robotic best, his black cap pulled over his forehead, his eyes staring into a tunnel, when his pitching shoulder turned stiff on a cool night at Shea Stadium.

title: Mickelson, a Hot Commodity, Visits the Stock Exchange
description: The ovation was huge as Phil Mickelson walked through the crowd, shook hands and signed autographs while accepting pats on the back and heartfelt congratulations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Trial Resumes
description: The corruption trial of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resumed, three months after the Constitutional Court ruled that a law enacted last June to shield him from prosecution violated the Constitution. The trial centers on charges that Mr. Berlusconi tried to bribe judges to influence a business deal. As the trial resumed, prosecutors charged that the lead judge was biased, called for his removal and immediately put the progress of the proceedings in doubt. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: An Isfaeli Who's Got Everybody Outraged
description: Benny Morris is used to making enemies. When his first groundbreaking book appeared in 1988, marshaling evidence that Israel's founders had deliberately -- and often violently -- forced Arabs to flee during the war for independence, Mr. Morris was reviled and called an anti-Zionist. For years he was unable to find work as a professor in Israel; when he finally landed a job at Ben-Gurion University, named for Israel's first prime minister, Ben-Gurion's son tried to have the radical young historian fired.

title: NEW YORK LOSES MAJOR LEGAL ALLY IN SUIT OVER GUNS
description: New York City is preparing for the first trial of a civil suit by an American city claiming that the gun industry fosters an illegal market in the firearms criminals use to deliver death to the city's doorsteps.

title: Bundesbank Chief Resigns Amid Scandal
description: In a development that rocked Germany's political establishment, Ernst Welteke stepped down yesterday as head of the Bundesbank, succumbing to a scandal involving a $9,335 hotel bill, a night on a corporate yacht and bad blood between the government and Germany's central bankers.

title: Editorial Observer; The Recording Industry Soldiers On Against Illegal Downloading
description: In the past few weeks there have been some mixed developments in the recording industry's battle against illegal file sharing. On the legal front, the industry began a new round of international lawsuits against foreign file sharers. A misguided new bill authorizing civil charges in file-sharing cases is making its way through the Senate, and a bill criminalizing copyright violations over peer-to-peer networks has been passed out of committee in the House. The Justice Department has established an Intellectual Property Task Force to look at ways to crack down on violations. Meanwhile, a Canadian judge has refused to force Internet providers to give up the addresses of file sharers. His ruling effectively makes the sharing of music files legal in Canada.

title: Red Sox Give Rodriguez Rude Welcome to Rivalry
description: The gentle translation of the most popular T-shirt and chant here is this: Yankees Stink. It is usually a preposterous cry, given the histories of the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox. But for one night, at least, the fans had a point.

title: National Briefing: Southwest

Paintings, pottery and sculptures have been stolen from five galleries since December. A guard has admitted stealing two Georgia O'Keeffe paintings from two galleries and one has been recovered. Still missing from the State Museum of Fine Arts is O'Keeffe's "Special 21 (Palo Duro Canyon)," valued at $1 million.   Steve Barnes (NYT)
