title: Big Auditing Firm Gets 6-Month Ban On New Business
description: Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, was barred yesterday from accepting any new audit clients in the United States for six months after a judge found that the firm acted improperly by auditing a company with which it had a highly profitable business relationship.

title: Slow to Adapt, Nokia Loses Market Share In Latest Cellphones
description: Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, paid a heavy price on Friday for missing the trend toward stylish clamshell phone handsets, denting its vaunted reputation as the arbiter of cellphone chic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEYMAN, ROSEMARIE
description: HEYMAN -- Rosemarie of Kassel, Germany. Born October 8, 1912, died April 14, 2004. Resided in Queens, NY. Mother of Joyce Kravets and Dick Heyman, grandmother of Marc, Robin, Susie, Joel, Corinne, Hilary and greatgrandmother of Melissa, Elijah and Tasia.

title: Despite Its Jersey City Tower, Goldman Sachs Commits to One in Lower Manhattan
description: Goldman Sachs is forging ahead with plans to build a billion-dollar, 40-story world headquarters at Battery Park City just as it completes construction of New Jersey's tallest building a mile away in Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, EDWARD R.
description: LEVY--Edward R. Died on April 11, 2004 at Calvary Hospital of cancer at age 74. Mr. Levy earned a Master's degree in mathematics and a Doctorate in English from the University of Illnois. He taught at the University's prestigious high school and was the senior author of a series of rhetoric textbooks published by Holt, Rhinehart, and Winston in the 1970's. He was stage manager for long running, off Broadway show ''The Fantastiks'' for more than half a decade and was the musical director of the Tony award-winning Torch Song Trilogy. For the past 20 years, he worked as a voice teacher and as a senior editor of mathematics and English textbooks. Services will be held at the Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner) on 29th St off 5th Av, Monday, April 19th at 11 AM.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Thursday about President Bush's endorsement of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw the Israelis from Gaza referred imprecisely to the number of Palestinian refugees for whom Arabs have demanded the ''right of return.'' The reference to millions encompassed not just Palestinian refugees from the Arab-Israeli war of 1948 but also their descendants.

title: The Pistons May Have The Last Playoff Laugh
description: Rasheed Wallace has one of the most profound tattoos in professional sports. Etched on his upper right arm, it is a majestic drawing of an Egyptian royal family -- a king, a queen and their children -- in the spotlight of a blazing sun.

title: A Tale of Love and Death In Afghanistan
description: Homa Safi was 21, a journalist-in-training at a French-Afghan monthly magazine in Kabul, Nouvelles de Kaboul, that I started two years ago. She was one of the innumerable women whom the fall of the Taliban seemed to have returned to life. But like so many of her Afghan sisters, she decided last month that the gap between what her world offered her and what she wanted was too great.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the addition of the @ symbol to Morse code misstated the code for the spelled-out word ''at'' and overstated its similarity to the code for the letter W. The duration of the code for ''at'' (dot-dash, dash) is 11 beats, not 9, because the pause between letters is three times the pause between dots and dashes within letters. That longer pause also distinguishes the code for ''at'' from the code for W (dot-dash-dash).

title: Study Plans To Retest Use Of Hormones In Menopause
description: Correction Appended

title: Sports of The Times; The Search for Tomorrow's Somebody
description: NOW that Lennox Lewis has retired as the accepted world heavyweight champion, the promoter Don King is shouting that ''the next era begins'' tonight at Madison Square Garden. But it begins without a marquee name.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Nuclear Waste Center Remains Open
description: Gov. Bill Richardson said a storage center for nuclear waste would continue to operate despite a warning on Thursday by his environment secretary, Ron Curry, that the state might close it. Mr. Richardson, a Democrat, said the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant near Carlsbad would accept shipments of military-related radioactive materials pending the resolution of a dispute with the federal Energy Department, which seeks to store higher-level atomic waste in the underground repository. The department is appealing a federal judge's ban on radioactive sludge at the site. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Tenet to Sell a Hospital
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the hospital chain being investigated by federal authorities, has agreed to sell a hospital in Redding, Calif., to the privately held Hospital Partners of America for about $60 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Vehicle Sales Surge
description: India's passenger vehicle sales rose by more than 30 percent in the fiscal year that ended in March and was one million for the first time. An automotive trade group, the Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers, said sales of passenger vehicles, which include cars, vans and sports utility vehicles, rose to one million from 780,000 in the prior year. Demand for new cars was heightened by low interest rates, a strong economy and new models and competitive prices from automakers. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Schumer Opposes Plan to Build A Tunnel in Lower Manhattan
description: The loudest shot to date against the idea of building a short tunnel through Lower Manhattan was fired yesterday by Senator Charles E. Schumer, who said that he opposed the plan if it would divert money from other transportation projects.

title: Son Jailed in Killings Says Another Man Admits to Crime
description: Lawyers for a Long Island man who says he is wrongly imprisoned for killing his parents now claim that another man in the case has recently admitted slashing the couple's throats.

title: A Different Kind of Intelligence Failure
description: Intelligence failures are to blame, so we are told, for the tragedy of 9/11 and the unfolding catastrophe in Iraq. If the Bush administration had heeded its intelligence agencies, say its opponents, it might have prevented the 9/11 attacks and avoided its mishaps in Iraq. Administration officials, meanwhile, say that their intelligence was either not accurate or not ''actionable.'' This finger-pointing reflects misconceptions about the nature of intelligence -- and suggests an intelligence failure of a different sort.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Rights Group Wants Inquiry On Deaths
description: The Southern Christian Leadership Conference called on the state to investigate deaths of people in police custody. The conference, a civil rights group based in Atlanta, questioned the deaths of several black men in the last year who were in custody or meeting with law enforcement officials. Representatives of the conference said the men included five killed by the members of the Cobb County police and a man found hanging in his cell in Nashville, Ga. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Ex-Judge Is Spared Prison For Lies in a Federal Inquiry
description: Correction Appended

title: Jefferson No Longer That Other Guy on Nets
description: The Nets were running a preseason drill, scampering up and down the court almost to the point of exhaustion. Most of the attention was focused on Jason Kidd and Kenyon Martin, the All-Star tandem that led the Nets to the past two N.B.A. finals, and Alonzo Mourning, who was trying to come back from a chronic kidney disease.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Final Canary Wharf Bid
description: After nearly 13 months of back-and-forth bidding and negotiations, a Morgan Stanley-led investment group may have won the battle for Canary Wharf, London's new financial district. Late yesterday afternoon, the group, which also includes the Glick and Tisch families of New York, bid 295 pence a share for the 14-million-square-foot property in an offer that analysts said was more attractive than an offer of 275 pence plus stock from Canary Wharf's founder, Paul Reichmann. Mr. Reichmann teamed up with Brascan, a Toronto property group. Under rules set by the Takeover Panel, the government agency that controls mergers, no additional bids for the property are allowed. Both offers will now be open to a vote from shareholders. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: EXIDE'S PLAN TO CUT $1.3 BILLION IN DEBT IS APPROVED
description: Exide Technologies, the world's biggest maker of car batteries, won a judge's approval for its plan to eliminate $1.3 billion in debt and exit bankruptcy protection by the end of this month. Under the company's plan, lenders will receive 90 percent of the reorganized company's stock and unsecured creditors will get the remaining 10 percent, court papers say. Shareholders will get nothing. Judge Kevin Carey of United States Bankruptcy Court in Philadelphia approved the plan at a hearing yesterday. The judge's approval of the plan will allow the 116-year-old company to exit bankruptcy protection after two years with about $540 million in debt. Exide, which is based in Princeton, N.J., filed for Chapter 11 protection in April 2002.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on April 9, about John Jeremiah Sullivan's memoir ''Blood Horses: Notes of a Sportswriter's Son,'' quoted incorrectly from a passage that the reviewer singled out for praise. Mr. Sullivan wrote, ''It is not too much to say that a person today who knows horses, really knows them, understands more about what it meant in the past to be human than the most knowledgeable historian.'' He did not write, ''One who really knows horses today knows more about the past than historians.''

title: Religion Journal; Get Me to the Church on Time? Not With New Ministries
description: Answering the call of marriage ministry, the Rev. Dr. Gerald W. Montgomery of Lakewood, Wash., has his calendar booked for officiating over ''I do's'' nearly every weekend of the spring wedding season. But that does not mean his destination is church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERMAN, DR. MURIEL
description: BERMAN--Dr. Muriel. The American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem note with profound sorrow the passing of Dr. Muriel Berman, wife of the late Philip I. Berman and beloved mother of Nancy, Nina and Steven. Committed to Israel's people, the Bermans created a meaningful legacy at Hebrew University, including: The Philip I. and Muriel M. Berman Center for Biblical Archaeology; the Muriel and Philip Berman National Medical Library; and support for scholarships and fellowships. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Berman family. AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Peter T. Willner, Exec. VP

description: JERUSALEM, April 17 - An Israeli helicopter strike on Saturday night killed the Hamas leader in the Gaza Strip, Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, hospital officials in Gaza City said. Dr. Rantisi assumed the post just last month after a similar attack killed the group's founder, Sheik Ahmed Yassin.

description: Teresa Heinz Kerry, heir to a $500 million ketchup fortune and would-be first lady, has refused to make public her tax returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURTIS, EDWARD S.
description: CURTIS--Edward S., 78, of Boynton Beach, Florida died on April 8, 2004 at his home after a long struggle with Cancer. Born May 1, 1925 in New York City, he was the son of the late David and Sadie Cohen. He was the husband of Harriet Hanft Curtis, who died in 1995. Retired, he was a dentist in private practice in Schenectady, New York. He served in the Navy in WWII, and in the Air Force National Guard thereafter. Surviving are dearest friend Renee Telsey, of Boynton Beach, Florida; sister Carol Schulman and her husband Norman Schulman, of Great Neck, New York; son Charlie Curtis and his wife Betty Curtis, and their daughter, Paige, of Winchester, Virginia; and son Doug Curtis and his wife Marjorie, of Sykesville, Maryland. A service will be held in Schenectady, New York at the Temple Gates of Heaven Cemetery on April 23, 2004 at 2PM.

title: In the City, Laps of Luxury; A Pool in the Apartment Is the Latest in Extravagance

So when he bought a multimillion-dollar home in the United States several years ago, he built a heated outdoor pool, studded with ocean-blue tiles hand-painted in Spain and ringed by a teak deck.

title: COURT APPROVES NATIONAL CENTURY'S LIQUIDATION PLAN
description: National Century Financial Enterprises a defunct health care finance company with $3.5 billion in debt, won court approval to liquidate and distribute its remaining assets to creditors after 17 months in bankruptcy. National Century gave health care providers cash for their receivables and packaged the income stream into notes it sold to investors. The company's November 2002 collapse pushed at least 30 health care companies in 13 states and the District of Columbia into bankruptcy. Judge Donald Calhoun of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the liquidation plan, which will pay secured bondholders 12 percent to 14 percent of the more than $3 billion they are owed. Remaining bond debts are grouped in a $2.64 billion pool of unsecured claims.

title: Arguments Are Refined In Retrial Of Ex-Banker
description: Opening arguments yesterday in the retrial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston banker accused of obstruction of justice, suggested just how much -- and how little -- the prosecution and defense learned from their mistakes during the first trial, which ended in a hung jury.

title: HRPT OUTBIDS FINANCIER TO BUY HALLWOOD REALTY

Icahn. HRPT, based in Newton, Mass., offered $137.91 for every unit of Hallwood, 15 percent more than Mr. Icahn's bid of $120 a unit. HRPT owns and leases 36 million square feet of office and industrial space, and Hallwood, which is based in Dallas, 5 million square feet.

description: Japan's economic recovery is continuing steadily as improvement in the corporate sector spreads to more companies, the government said in its monthly economic outlook. Despite its optimistic outlook for companies, the cabinet office refrained from raising its overall assessment of the economy, citing concern about weak job growth. Japan's gross domestic product grew at an annual pace of 6.4 percent in the last quarter of 2003 the fastest pace in more than a decade. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Wal-Mart, a Nation Unto Itself

We also know that it is maniacal about low prices. (Some economists say it has single-handedly cut inflation by 1 percent in recent years, saving consumers billions of dollars annually.) We know that its labor practices have come under attack. (It charges its workers so much for health insurance that about one-third of them do not have it.)

Visitation Sunday, April 18, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Rd, Pleasantville, NY. Services Monday, 11:00, All Saints Episcopal Church, Briarcliff. title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: 2 OFFICIALS DISMISSED FOR OBSTRUCTING SREBRENICA INQUIRY Paddy Ashdown, the Briton who administers Bosnia, removed from office Gen. Cvjetko Savic, chief of the Bosnian Serb Army, and Dejan Miletic, the head of the Bosnian Serb office for cooperation with the international war crimes tribunal, for obstructing an investigation into the killings of more than 7,500 Muslim men and boys in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995, Europe's worst single atrocity since World War II. The Bosnian Serb authorities were ordered last year to submit a report on the massacre. It was supposed to explain what happened to those missing after the fall of the Muslim town. On Wednesday, the authorities filed a report that failed to address the fate of the victims. Mr. Ashdown, above, gave the Serb authorities two weeks to produce relevant information or he will consider firing the interior and defense ministers. If a substantial report is not submitted by the first week of June, he said the president and prime minister would be held responsible. "It is unacceptable that the truth has to be pulled out as a rotten tooth," he said. (AP)

title: Talking the Talk (and Defining It, Too)

This tactic will be familiar to those who have heard Mr. Rock's 1996 litany of distinctions between black people and a subset of blacks he designated with racist slang.

Pataki's response to a request by The Associated Press for documents about a trip he took with his wife to St. Barts misidentified a part owner of the private jet they used. It is Theater Street Distributors Inc., owned by Earle I. Mack -- not the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a company in which he is a major shareholder. title: Too Close for Comfort
description: On Tuesday the nation will mark the fifth anniversary of the Columbine High School massacre. The memory of that tragedy is fresh in the minds of parents and students in the tiny community of Malcolm, Neb., where 17-year-old Josh Magee was stopped in the high school parking lot last month with 20 homemade bombs and a bolt-action rifle at the ready.

title: A Shape-Shifting Producer With Another New Pose
description: Pharrell Williams has built a career as one of pop music's cleverest and most appealing impostors. Along with Chad Hugo, his partner in the Neptunes, Mr. Williams produced deceptively simple hits for Justin Timberlake and others, full of deliberately thin synthesizer sounds and choruses that sounded even better when you sang them in the shower. Through it all, Mr. Williams played the part of the accidental mogul: he was a scruffy, trucker-hatted skateboarder who had somehow wandered into a Jay-Z video.

title: A More Humble Hawk

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Software Services
description: India's third-largest software services company, Wipro, said its fourth-quarter profit rose 42 percent, beating expectations, as outsourcing of software and back-office work by global corporations lifted its revenue by 44 percent, to $1.2 billion. Wipro, which is based in Bangalore, announced a dividend of 4 rupees (9 cents) a share, a one-time payment of 25 rupees a share and a payout of two shares for every share held. Wipro said income rose to 3.25 billion rupees ($74 million) in the quarter. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: The Perils of Cutting Medicaid
description: Medicaid, a joint state-federal health insurance program for the poor, has blossomed into the largest and most expensive public health program in the nation. For the most part, this is a blessing. Medicaid provides badly needed health care to those who can least afford it as well as badly needed financial support for the health institutions that take care of them. It is fast expanding into the nation's imperfect substitute for universal health insurance. But the states are having serious trouble carrying their share of the costs.

title: Keys to the Series
description: 1. THREE KNEES -- Allan Houston has conceded that he will most likely sit out the series because of his knee troubles. Kenyon Martin has endured setbacks with his left knee becuase of tendinitis. But the most scrutinized knee belongs to Jason Kidd, who may or may not be back at full speed.

title: Red Sox Have The Hot Ticket
description: The Red Sox set a franchise attendance record last season by drawing 2,724,162 fans to Fenway Park, averaging almost a sellout every game. They could be on their way to breaking that mark, said Charles Steinberg, the club's executive vice president for public affairs.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chairman Resigns
description: Takashi Usami, the chairman of the Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, an affiliate of DaimlerChrysler and Mitsubishi Motors, has resigned. Mr. Usami's resignation follows the company's admission last month that a design defect may have been the cause of a series of truck accidents, including a fatal one. Mitsubishi Fuso, which DaimlerChrysler controls through a 65 percent stake, is recalling 130,000 trucks and buses to fix faulty wheels. The troubles at the truckmaker have been another setback in Japan for DaimlerChrysler, which is also trying to turn around the unprofitable Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. DaimlerChrysler is also the largest shareholder of Mitsubishi Motors. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: SERGEANT DENIES GUILT IN DESERTION CASE A National Guardsman opposed to the conflict in Iraq pleaded not guilty to a military charge of desertion and will face a court-martial for refusing to rejoin his unit for five months after he had a two-week furlough. The guardsman, Staff Sgt. Camilo Mejia of the Florida National Guard, requested that a jury at Fort Stewart decide his case instead of a military judge. The jury will be made up of Army personnel, a third of them enlisted officers. Sergeant Mejia applied for conscientious objector status. The Army said it was pressing the desertion charge because he was missing for so long. (AP)

title: Pouring Great Old Wine Into Some Very Old Skins
description: Attempts to make classical music sound new often smack of forced over-interpretation. Roger Norrington's goal is to make classical music sound old. An advocate of the idea of playing music on period instruments -- which has done much to redefine contemporary understanding of what Baroque music sounded like -- at the start of his conducting career he took it one step further, by using original instruments in the music of later classical composers: Beethoven, Berlioz, Mendelssohn. Technically speaking, therefore, the music doesn't sound new. But it certainly sounds different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PILLAR, RICHARD LOUIS

He dedicated his life to raising a loving family with his late wife, Arlene, and fostering close friendships filled with happiness and laughter. Known as ''Papa D'' to more than just his grandchildren, he always had a warm smile for everyone. He will be greatly missed by his three children, Russell, Meredith, and Matthew; his wife, Ursula; his five grandchildren; his brothers, Robert and Charles; and all of those dear family members and friends whose lives he touched. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel at 175 North Long Beach Road in Rockville Centre, NY, on Sunday, April 18, 2004, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations be made in celebration of his life to the research program of the National Kidney Foundation, 30 East 33rd Street, New York, NY 10016.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: WPP Incentive Plan Accepted
description: Shareholders of WPP, an advertising company, approved an incentive plan after WPP changed the conditions that could produce bonuses for managers including the chief executive, Sir Martin Sorrell. Investors voted for the plan -- which could allow Sir Martin to earn as much as 44 million ($79 million) -- at a meeting in London. The company said 80 percent of shareholders voted in favor. WPP delayed a vote this month on its plan after investor groups protested its structure. WPP, whose plan could net top executives as much as 112 million, bowed to investor pressure and modified the performance criteria. Under WPP's original plan, executives would have been judged by how the company performed against other global advertising companies on a number of financial and performance benchmarks.

title: The Case of The Cherry Hill Cluster
description: D.T. Max's article (March 28) might lead readers to believe that there was a ''group'' or ''cluster'' of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease cases in Washington State recently. That is inaccurate or, at the very least, misleading. It is true that we have had 35 possible cases over a six-year period, but they have not been grouped or clustered in any way. In this time period, that would be a typical number of cases for any area in the country with the same population. Additionally, we track C.J.D. when it is mentioned on death certificates. In these 35, C.J.D. was often just one of several possible causes of death mentioned. Of the 35, only 14 people had autopsies, so there is no way for us to confirm the true causes of death for the other 21. We are working to encourage more autopsies in suspected C.J.D. cases so we can have a better understanding of this disease.

title: Page Two: April 11-17; One-Party Power
description: South Africa's third democratic election since apartheid's end went fairly, peacefully and predictably: the African National Congress, which won 62 percent of the vote in 1994 and 66 percent in 1999, racked up 70 percent this time. The closest challenger, the white-led Democratic Alliance, mustered but 12 percent. President Thabo Mbeki called the landslide a rejection of old racial and ethnic divisions, and experts said that under his stewardship Africa's most robust democracy would progress. But the A.N.C.'s growing dominance of electoral politics left some troubled. ''A one-party monopoly of the elections poses certain dangers,'' said Steven Friedman, a veteran analyst. ''So far, we've avoided that danger better than one might have expected. But that's not a guarantee forever.'' Michael Wines

It was composed by Yann Tiersen, a French composer who wrote the music for ''Amlie'' and who also plays accordion on the new Divine Comedy album. The ''Goodbye, Lenin!'' soundtrack includes ''Summer 78,'' sung by Claire Pichet, but mostly it's full of melancholy instrumental pieces. There's a spooky track with a vibraphone called ''Mother Will Die,'' which almost makes me want to avoid seeing the film, just to make sure it doesn't ruin the music.

Miller of the detective bureau said that the man was still in Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, listed in stable condition, after being taken there Sunday for evaluation. title: A Rush of Blood to the Head
description: I was walking the way most of us do in New York, unseeing, following the same path down Eighth Avenue I did every Saturday after my tennis lesson. It's a way of preserving the illusion of solitude in a teeming city, this sort of traveling on cruise control, oblivious to all around us. It was raining heavily that evening. I peered out from under my umbrella as I approached the crosswalk. The glare of headlights caught a small figure, clutching a polka-dot umbrella. And then a van smashed into her, throwing her forward. It rolled over her, picking her up and dragging her. I screamed for it to stop, and the van slowed. She crawled out from the wheel well and I ran to her.

title: DESIGN WITH A CAPITAL D

Those of us who care just hope that more good decisions are made than bad ones, because beauty makes our day, and ugly just brings us down.

title: Questions for Karen Armstrong
description: Karen Armstrong's emphasis on compassion is commendable (Deborah Solomon, April 4). But we should not forget that grief, rather than depression, is the usual reaction to the death of a child. While feelings of sadness and its associated symptoms of insomnia, poor appetite and weight loss are common to both conditions, it is only depression that may include pervasive feelings of worthlessness and guilt; significant loss of the ability to function socially, occupationally or in self-care; and suicidal thinking and behavior. The suffering caused by depression may be extreme but can be greatly alleviated by timely and appropriate treatment. Armstrong says that it is a ''shame'' to always block out feeling depressed. But for someone who is suffering clinical depression, medical treatment is the most compassionate response.

title: Harried Child
description: IN the fall of 2000, the New York independent filmmaker Michael Almereyda took a small crew to San Francisco to record the gestation of a Sam Shepard play. The stars were Sean Penn and Nick Nolte, as brothers uneasily reunited in the grungy desert shack of their recently deceased but still very present father (the longtime Shepard interpreter James Gammon). Woody Harrelson, Cheech Marin and Sheila Tousey had supporting roles. Mr. Shepard, who had played the ghost in Mr. Almereyda's 2000 film of ''Hamlet'' with Ethan Hawke, was directing. ''This So-Called Disaster: Sam Shepard Directs 'The Late Henry Moss' '' is distilled from Mr. Almereyda's 140 hours of videotape. It examines not just artists burrowing their way into Mr. Shepard's text, but also a writer grappling with the legacy of his ornery, alcoholic father. (''This so-called disaster'' is how Mr. Shepard's father once described their family life.) Last month Mr. Almereyda talked with Sylviane Gold about his film, which opens at Film Forum in Manhattan on Wednesday. Excerpts from their conversation follow.

title: The End of Primary Care
description: The patient shivered as she waited for the doctor to climb the stairs to the second floor. She was 6 years old, and a fever had kept her home for the past few days. Her mother, half of a working couple with four other children, called the doctor that afternoon. The child listened as her mother's voice grew closer, punctuated by an occasional low-pitched question. Fear overcame malaise, and the girl slipped quietly under the bed. The doctor, a tall, thin man with reddish-blond hair and freckles, glanced around the room and then somewhat awkwardly lowered himself onto the floor. He smiled at the girl. ''Hello, Lisa,'' he said to me. And then we talked -- right there, underneath the bed, as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Of Ray Kappe, the architecture critic Michael Webb writes in ''Themes and Variations: House Design by Ray Kappe,'' ''This undogmatic but committed modern architect has created a succession of houses that are a comfortable fit for their sites and the needs of their owners.'' In fact, Kappe has designed more than 100 houses since the 1950's, and energy conservation was in the forefront of his consciousness long before California building codes mandated such measures in 1975. Kappe also became known for his sensitive and resourceful solutions to building on steep sites -- a skill he honed with the design of his own house. The house that Kappe designed for Anne Keeler and Gordon Melcher in Pacific Palisades (a) was completed in 1990. It is a taller, narrower version of the concrete-tower-and-laminated-beam structure that Kappe had built for himself decades earlier. A skylit staircase and gallery cut through the main space (b), connecting the living areas to the bedrooms below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWATT, JOHN C.
description: HOWATT--John C., 77. Died April 12, 2004 with his sons and daughters by his side. Born in Detroit August 12, 1926, John was a graduate of Blair Academy and Princeton University, and served as an officer in the U.S. Naval Corps in WWII. An ardent Republican, he was an eloquent President of the New York Young Republican Club from 1958 to 1960. His long career as a stockbroker and brokerage office manager was distinguished by the loyalty, honesty, and integrity that characterized his entire life. He was a gentleman and a gentle man, as well as a patriot of the old school. An avid fly fisherman and football fan, John will be remembered by his many friends, colleagues and clients for his exuberance for life and generous spirit. He will always remain in our hearts. Survivors include his cherished companion, Lois Brooks; his children Shelby Todd Schultz, Laura Colangelo, and Daniel and Charles Howatt, and their mother, Shelby Moorman Howatt; his sisters Elizabeth Card and Charlotte Grant; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Big Brothers Big Sisters of NYC, 223 E. 30 St, NYC, 10016.

description: Thank you for the article about our return to unchecked air pollution. Greed, arrogance and hubris have prevented this administration and the energy industry leaders from realizing that, when mother nature decides to hit her reset button, we're all going down -- including them.

title: Mixing Colors, Blending Cultures
description: IN a cozy home-studio in Upper Montclair, Siona Benjamin has just finished a painting of a South Asian woman wearing a sari patterned with the American flag, her legs sheathed in the unmistakable striped pajamas of Nazi concentration camp victims. The figure looks at herself in a mirror, but all she sees are images of conflict and war.

title: The Art That Got Away
description: THE Whitney Museum of American Art is billing its display of ''The Arts of Life in America,'' five murals painted by Thomas Hart Benton, as ''a landmark homecoming.'' For the past 51 years, the murals have been part of the permanent collection of the New Britain Museum of American Art in Connecticut, which has lent them to the Whitney, their original owner, for nine months. But given how the paintings ended up in Connecticut in the first place, the exhibition might just as easily be seen as the story of a landmark blunder.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: STRANGE MR. SATIE

title: How Can We Know The Dancer From a Duck?
description: PHILIPPE DECOUFL likes to sleep in, but he has a good excuse. From his dreams, he says, he plucks the mythical figures, strange animals and bizarre contraptions that appear in his shows. With them in tow, he sets off on a tour of dance and circus, music and costume that has made him one of France's most popular choreographers.

title: The Socratic Shrink
description: Philosophical counseling is legitimate, but Lou Marinoff's representation of it is highly questionable (Daniel Duane, March 21). Philosophical counseling already has an impressive history in bioethics. Staff philosophers counsel physicians today in many academic hospitals. There are graduate programs in bioethics to train philosophers to function as ethicists, and philosophers have testified as expert witnesses in court cases involving ethical issues in medicine. If philosophers can help physicians and the courts resolve difficult problems in medicine, why deny that philosophers can help individuals with life's difficult moral dilemmas?

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Suburbs' Long Approval Process Upsets Developers
description: GIBBS COLLEGE, a degree-granting arm of what was originally the Katharine Gibbs School for aspiring secretaries, is creating a new campus here out of a former manufacturing plant.

title: Trying to Save the Chai Latte in Hamilton Heights
description: When a new Starbucks pops up in parts of Manhattan, some residents invariably bemoan its sterile corporate-ness, then give in and buy coffee there anyway. So Regina McRae's reaction to the Starbucks that opened two years ago in her neighborhood, Hamilton Heights, was counterintuitive: she was thrilled by its presence, but she never went there. She does not drink coffee.

title: Redbuds' 15 Minutes Are Ticking
description: IT'S April, and in the New York area, the redbuds are beginning to bloom. Their clusters of tightly packed flowers on slim branches are turning this compact tree into a trend.

title: Security Is a Human Right, Too
description: When I was a sophomore in high school, I became acquainted with a religious group that called itself Moral Rearmament. Its adherents were required to practice four virtues without compromise: absolute honesty, absolute purity, absolute unselfishness and absolute love. To a 14-year-old, this formula seemed eminently sensible, and I decided that I would become a disciple. And for a few days I was.

title: Cleaning Up In Aisle 4
description: Times are tough in the supermarket game. Everywhere you look, a $250 billion gorilla named Wal-Mart is threatening to eviscerate your margins and eat your lunch.

title: Tricky Question on Rookies: There Are 2 Right Answers
description: How can LeBron James not be the rookie of the year? At the tender age of 19, he exceeded even the rosiest expectations, making the jump from high school to the N.B.A. look like a step off the curb rather than the dive off the cliff it had been for most of his predecessors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULMAN, DR. DAVID
description: SCHULMAN--Dr. David. Died on Sunday, March 28, 2004 after a long illness from complications of Parkinsons Disease at his home in Manhattan. A memorial service will be conducted on April 27th at 3:00 PM. It will be held at Mt. Sinai Hospital, 1425 Madison Avenue between 98 and 99 Street, in the first floor seminar room. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Division of Child Psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: Page Two: April 11-17; Intelligence Takes A Beating
description: THE question in Washington is not whether the intelligence community will be overhauled, but how, after fresh evidence last week that the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. had missed major warning signs about the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGMAN, ANDREW
description: BERGMAN--Andrew. Loved and admired son of Elliot and Sybil. Brother to Clifford and Marilyn, uncle to Kuper and Asher. He was the author of ''The Will to Travel'' and an Advocate for the Handicapped. Despite severe disabilities he traveled to Europe, New Zealand, Australia and Greenland. On March 23, 2004, after a bout with pneumonia, he embarked on his final trip. He was 47 years old and he had to desperately fight for every year. He will be sorely missed.

title: Changing All The Rules
description: As an environmental attorney, I would add that since most coal-fired power plants and oil refineries are located in low-income and minority communities, those communities are most directly affected by the recent attempts to reform new-source review. Those communities have been working for years to bring about emissions reductions at these facilities, and they will only work harder to oppose the Bush administration's anti-environment initiatives.

title: From the Platonic Ideal for Cookware (It's on the Right Bank)
description: KNOCK on wood, but that brief chapter when certain souls were pouring out perfectly nice bottles of vin rouge and ordering freedom fries seems to have passed. Plenty of people will say it's a good thing, too, lest we end up at the mercy of Francophobes insisting that couture and cuisine be called dressmakin' and cookin'.

title: A County Of Squash, And Talent Homegrown
description: IT is something of a well-kept secret for those who are not members of the small world of squash, but it is manifestly true: Westchester is famous for its youth squash players.

title: Making Use of the McCain Factor
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona, a Republican, was quick to quell the kerfuffle he created last month by saying he would "entertain" an offer to run for vice president on the Democratic ticket with his good friend Senator John Kerry. But while Mr. McCain says he has ruled out such a move, a day can hardly pass without Mr. Kerry talking about his fellow Vietnam combat veteran.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOLLENDER, SELMA
description: HOLLENDER--Selma. After 10 years, we live with your warm spirit each day. Alex, Jane, Beth, Wendy, Herb and Pearl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, EDWARD R.
description: LEVY--Edward R. Died on April 11, 2004 at Calvary Hospital of cancer at age 74. Mr. Levy earned a Master's degree in mathematics and a Doctorate in English from the University of Illnois. He taught at the University's prestigious high school and was the senior author of a series of rhetoric textbooks published by Holt, Rhinehart, and Winston in the 1970's. He was stage manager for long running, off Broadway show ''The Fantastiks'' for more than half a decade and was the musical director of the Tony award-winning Torch Song Trilogy. For the past 20 years, he worked as a voice teacher and as a senior editor of mathematics and English textbooks. Services will be held at the Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner) on 29th St off 5th Av, Monday, April 19th at 11 AM.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: MY SISTER'S KEEPER

title: Strictly Provincial Battle Becoming Talk of Hockey
description: The current Ottawa-Toronto series may not determine the best team in the National Hockey League or its Eastern Conference or even among Canadian participants in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about Mark Lawrence, who decorates clothing in graffiti style, referred incorrectly to a police encounter he had as a teenager. Mr. Lawrence was not arrested. An officer suspected him of painting graffiti in a subway car and told him to clean the car. The article also misstated the ''street name'' of one of Mr. Lawrence's employees, Paul Anglin Jr. It is Devious, not Sense. A photograph with the article, of shoes with paintings of $100 bills, was published in error. It was the work of Fulton Air Brush, not of Mr. Lawrence.

title: THE ZHOOZH
description: The last stage of any decorating project is the installation. That's the time when -- after the paint is dry, the wallpaper is hung and the carpet is laid -- the furniture, lamps and accessories are brought in and arranged, and the owners' possessions are put in their proper places. But for many decorators, the installation is more than just move-in time. It's when a set of rooms becomes a home, with the addition of a certain extra something. It's what the style world calls the zhoozh. Think of a starlet being styled for the Oscars.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about competing visions of the legend of Davy Crockett misstated the title of a coming book about him and misstated the author's given name. The book is "Sleuthing the Alamo: Davy Crockett's Last Stand and Other Mysteries of the Texas Revolution,'' not "Myths of the Texas Revolution.'' The writer is James E. Crisp, not Jim Crisp.

title: Plum's Tarts
description: BERGDORF BLONDES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASSETT, IRWIN A.
description: BASSETT--Irwin A. Beloved husband of Rita. Adored father of Dr. Cliff Bassett and Debbie Rapoport. Wonderful father - in - law, cherished brother and grandfather. Exemplary son of the late Dr. and Mrs. David Bassett. A man for all seasons.

title: Mary Remuzzi, Daniel Uthman
description: Mary Margaret Remuzzi, the daughter of Rachael P. Remuzzi of Leesburg, Va., and the late Dr. Robert Remuzzi, was married last evening to Daniel Lawrence Uthman, the son of Azmi Uthman of Winchester, Va., and the late Charlotte Uthman. The Rev. James A. Wallace, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZMARTIN, KATHLEEN (NEE QUINN)
description: FITZMARTIN--Kathleen (nee Quinn). On April 16, 2004. Native of Drumdiffer, Ballinamore, Co. Leitrim, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Peter. Dear mother of Raymond and Kevin. Cherished grandmother of Erin, Kevin and Michael. Sister of Francis and Eileen in Ireland. Roseleen, Theresa and Esther in England. And the late Mary Agnes, John, Peter and Belinda. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81 St, Monday, April 19, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Avenue at 76 Street, Tuesday, April 20, at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, DR. ARTHUR, O.D.
description: SILVER--Dr. Arthur, O.D. Beloved and adored husband of Selma. Most loving and devoted father of Marsha, Helene and Karen. Cherished grandfather of Julie, Emily and Adam. Dear brother of Jerome and Martin. Graveside service private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORBALLY, THOMAS
description: CORBALLY--Thomas, April 15th, 2004, passed away at home. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. @ 81st St., Tuesday, April 20th, 5-9 PM. Mass on Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. @ 66th St.

description: 'Charlie Allen had his hair on fire,'' wrote Richard Clarke, the former counterterrorism chief, at the start of a chapter in his brilliantly promoted best seller, ''Against All Enemies.''

description: Correction Appended

title: Where Late the Jackhammers Rang
description: They might have been easy to miss, what with all the bulldozers and jackhammers and general chaos, but a group of more demure residents have recently put down roots in Columbus Circle. Eleven trees were planted in front of the new Time Warner Center late last month, signaling the start of the area's transformation from decade-long construction site to lush green space.

title: Carrie Groothuis, Howard Muhlstein
description: Carrie Rachel Groothuis, the daughter of Jane and Michael Groothuis of Lawrence, N.Y., was married last evening to Howard Adam Muhlstein, a son of Janet and Joel Muhlstein of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Martin S. Cohen performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Teenage Fiction, Adult Problems (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: TAILOR MADE
description: In 1950, three years before he closed his couture house, Marcel Rochas published ''25 Years of Elegance,'' one of the first books, according to the historian Caroline Rennolds Milbank, that chronicles the interplay between fashion, society and culture. Rochas was both a pragmatist and an innovator. He abandoned a career in law to open a couture house, according to legend, so that his young wife would always be smartly dressed, and as early as 1934, he was offering patrons a chance to customize their wardrobes, with monogrammed gloves and ID belt buckles.

title: Low-Cost Airlines
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''In the Air, on the Cheap'' (April 4): Barry Estabrook had it exactly right when he said, ''I expect a certain amount of attitude from airline employees, somewhere between sullen and downright surly.'' Many times I have seen flight attendants standing idly, chatting, while watching people struggle to get heavy bags in the overhead compartment. Flight attendants are now Safety Observers. They are standing safely, observing.

title: Backpack Trek: The Next Generation
description: Correction Appended

title: The Brooklyn Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Early Warnings; What Did He Know, and When?
description: THE president was receiving intelligence that an attack might occur imminently, probably not on the United States mainland, but abroad. Intercepted communications pointed to an adversary with a deadly history of surprise attacks. And, it did happen, the most horrific assault ever on American territory, and one that would lead to war. An investigation as to how so large a blow could have gone undetected was begun while the nation was still fighting the war. One objective was to find out what the president knew about the threat, when did he know and what did he do to counter it?

title: Public Housing, Strings Attached (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: From Gig to Gig, a Band Draws Loyal, Local Fans
description: IF some measure of success for a band working its way up in the music business is being able to inspire fans to cook and serve 450 turquoise-colored pancakes, free of charge, to a concert audience, then Gandalf Murphy and the Slambovian Circus of Dreams has hit the mark.

title: Our Sprawling, Supersize Utopia
description: Many of the smug enclaves Brooks describes are proof of a new medievalism, a way of shutting out variety, culture and risk. The awful truth is that the American middle class is moving farther and farther away from the great centers of population and culture. There's nothing out there in the exurban frontier but bulldozed land and monotonous architecture. Small-mindedness, xenophobia and a false sense of security can be its only result.

title: Israeli Rightists Support Gaza Pullout Plan
description: JERUSALEM, April 18 - As Palestinians massed in Gaza City to vent rage at Israel over its killing on Saturday night of a top militant leader, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon picked up crucial support on Sunday from right-wing leaders for his plan to withdraw from the Gaza Strip without a peace agreement.

title: The Love of His Life Is a Goat
description: ''WHO is Sylvia?'' In ''Two Gentlemen of Verona,'' Shakespeare asked that rhetorical question about a ''holy, fair and virtuous '' lady. ''Who is Sylvia?'' is the alternative title of Edward Albee's play, ''The Goat,'' now at TheaterWorks in Hartford. Here, too, the answer is self-evident. Sylvia is the goat.

title: For Lenders, A Cut Of Profits
description: WHEN Elinor M. Wolfert, then 81, took out a reverse mortgage on her Brooklyn home in February 1996, she believed that ''the idea made a lot of sense,'' she said in a later court affidavit. With such a mortgage, instead of getting a lump-sum loan and then repaying the loan with interest in monthly payments over a period of years, Mrs. Wolfert, a widow, got not only an up-front loan but also a guarantee of receiving regular monthly payments from the lender.

title: Ideas & Trends: Raise and Spend; In Politics, Too Much Money Is Never Enough
description: I have the most reliable friend you can have in American politics, and that is ready money,'' Phil Gramm, the former Republican senator from Texas, famously said, kicking off his 1996 presidential bid. Mr. Gramm spent $27 million in short order, but flopped in the primaries, once again proving the axiom that money does not guarantee political victory.

title: A Hop, Skip and a Jump to the 80's
description: THE 1980's were the heyday of gimmicky sneakers. Reebok had its inflatable Pumps. Nike outfitted its Air line with see-through soles. And Kangaroos offered a zippered pocket, emblazoned with the company's marsupial mascot. Nike and Reebok survived the decade in decent form, but Kangaroos, despite a few glorious years of sales topping $80 million, vanished from American stores, a victim of management woes and the vagaries of taste.

title: Hailing a Maven Of Yiddish
description: To the Editor:

title: New: Sunday Business
description: The New York Times today introduces a redesigned Sunday business section that combines news about business personalities and companies with advice on how to invest and spend. SundayBusiness seeks to help readers understand how the economy affects their lives.

title: Table Manners -- Footnotes
description: Lovers' quarrel: From top: Filao decanter, $500. At Baccarat, 625 Madison Avenue. Greek Column candlestick, $60, from Mottahedeh, (800) 242-3050. Madeline vase, $198, from the Waterford Crystal Georgian Collection, www.waterford.com. Massena goblet, $150. At Baccarat. Bell-top salt-and-pepper set, $125. At Barneys New York, 660 Madison Avenue. Indigo Wave dinner plate and bread plate, $225 for a five-piece place setting, from Mottahedeh. Acorn fork, $1,350 for six. At Georg Jensen Living, 683 Madison Avenue. Jean Dubost Laguiole steak knife. Bamboo embroidered linen place mat and napkin set, $225, from Nancy Stanley Waud Fine Linens, (310) 273-3690.

title: Bracing for the Battle Of the Highlands
description: George Washington saved his fledgling colonial army in the frigid winter of 1777 by marching into the heights above Morristown to avoid a battle with a larger, better-equipped British force.

title: Our Journal
description: After the actress Lynn Redgrave learned she had breast cancer in December 2002, she chose to undergo surgery, followed by a half-year regimen of chemotherapy and radiation. She also asked her daughter Annabel Clark, then a photography student at Parsons School of Design, if she would photograph the course of treatment and recovery. It was an idea that had occurred to Annabel as well: while her mother documented the experience in her journal, she would take pictures of the healing process -- and in so doing, become part of that process, for both her mother and herself.

title: MORE JOBS IN STATE
description: New Jersey gained 12,900 jobs in March, increasing the number of nonfarm payroll jobs in the state to more than four million, the highest employment level since December 2000, Labor Commissioner Albert G. Kroll announced on Wednesday. Leading this growth were professional and business services, which added 6,700 jobs, and trade, transportation, and utilities, which added 5,000 jobs. Their gains offset losses in manufacturing and construction, which shrunk by 2,000 and 1,700 jobs, respectively. The March unemployment rate was 5.2 percent, down from 5.4 percent in February. Jess Bruder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLCLOUGH, ELIZABETH SHEMPP
description: COLCLOUGH -- Elizabeth Shempp, born October 2, 1901 in Hudesville, PA. After graduating from the University of Rochester, she taught English. She married Walter Colclough, an editor of the NY Herald Tribune. Widowed in 1933, she became the first woman radio editor of the NY Herald Tribune. From 1942-1952 she was Program Director of America's Town Meeting of the Air and organized ''Round - the - World Town Meetings'' in London, Paris, Berlin, Vienna, Rome, Ankara, Cairo, Karachi, New Delhi, Manila, Tokyo and Honolulu. For 17 years, Bess was VP of the prestigious Washington PR firm, Robert Mullen & Co. Blessed with a unique wit, charm and joie de vivre, Bess was beloved by all who knew her. Deceased on April 8, 2004 at age 102, at Ozanam Hall, Bayside, NY. She leaves behind her niece and nephew, Evangeline Hachmann and William Shempp and families.

title: 'A Pirate of Exquisite Mind'
description: On 6 April 1674 the merchant ship Content sailed down the Thames, bound for the fast-growing colony of Jamaica. Onboard was a nervous, thin-faced young man on his way to work on a sugar plantation. Twenty-two-year-old William Dampier had balked at the last moment. He feared being sold as an indentured servant when the ship berthed in Jamaica. As wind filled the sails and the small vessel began to creak and roll, it was too late to change his mind. However, he had sensibly agreed with the ship's captain, John Kent, that he would work his passage as an able seaman. As such, the law required Kent to discharge him as a free man on his arrival.

title: Steinbeck, at Last, Welcomed Home
description: THE city of Salinas and the surrounding valley about 100 miles south of San Francisco are commonly known as Steinbeck Country, the consequence of an uneasy reconciliation between the Nobel laureate in the years since his death and the place where he was born and raised.

title: No Politics Are Local
description: As readers of Adult Video News and the 2005 federal budget will be aware, Attorney General John Ashcroft is staffing up the Justice Department for a prosecutorial assault on America's $10 billion pornography industry. Moderate civil libertarians have traditionally taken the side of pornographers on such matters. While a local community can make its own rules, they say, prosecuting smut at the federal level is Orwellian overkill. But this localist view makes less sense in the Internet age. It is unfair to ask bluenoses to band together to sway their city councils when most porn gets made not by some louche photographer living in a trailer across the railroad tracks but by multinational corporations with lobbyists in Washington.

title: Same Night, Same Channel, Same Giant Bummer
description: TO fans of the WB's recently canceled ''Angel,'' the writer Tim Minear is known affectionately as the Tim Reaper: the master of the fatal plot twist. But most recently, he's been on the other side of the scythe -- helming two acclaimed hourlong dramas in two seasons, only to see each canceled before it had much of a chance to win an audience. In 2002, he was an executive producer on the Fox space western ''Firefly'' along with its creator, Joss Whedon -- only to see their series scheduled in the ''Friday night death slot,'' broadcast out of order, then axed. This season, Mr. Minear took on another quirky one-hour drama for Fox: ''Wonderfalls,'' starring Caroline Dhavernas as a disaffected Niagara Falls tourist shop clerk guided by tchotchkes. ''Wonderfalls'' was dropped after only four episodes, despite being one of the best-reviewed shows of the current season. A rerun of ''The Swan'' took its place.

title: Mudhole? Don't Be Insulting; It's Protected Wetland
description: IN Tuesday night's steady rain, two men could be seen just off the turnpike in East Brunswick clomping through a wet, wooded area with flashlights, turning over logs and occasionally plunging their hands into the standing water that covered much of the site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, ELIZABETH GALLOWAY (BETSY)
description: DAVIS--Elizabeth Galloway (Betsy). On April 13, 2004. Betsy encouraged many to become involved in community outreach, and she created positive changes to the lives she touched. Preceded in death by her father John Price Davis, she is survived by her mother Virginia Davis Halladay (Eugene), brother Jeffery Wright Davis (Julia), sister Gretchen Weller Davis, brother Matthew Carver Davis (Kara), Stuart and Sarah Halladay, and Rudy. Memorial celebration Thursday, April 22, at 5 PM, at Credit Swisse First Boston, 1 Madison Ave, New York (enter on 24 St). Donations to the Betsy Davis Fund at Good Shepherd Services, c/o Good Shepherd Services, 305 7th Ave, 9th Fl, NYC 10001.

title: Spring in Trenton, Subpoenas in Bloom
description: IT is, at last, springtime here in the state capital, which means two things: the Trenton Thunder's new season is under way, and state lawmakers are conducting budget hearings. From the not-so-far corners of this compact state come busloads of advocates and other interested parties to hear legislators and commissioners discuss, often in numbing detail, the figures, projections and acronyms that are the vernacular of state government.

title: Harvesting Different Fruit
description: Steve Wozniak's rsum needs only two items to impress: Apple I and Apple II. Engineering them allowed ''Woz,'' as Mr. Wozniak is known in the computer industry, to retire from Apple after its initial public offering in 1980 made him several hundred million dollars. He gave a lot of that to education-related charities and for years donated much of his time as a volunteer, teaching computer skills to children.

title: Word for Word/Fundamental Questions; The Imperial Presidency And the Constraints of the Law
description: STARTING this week, the Supreme Court will take up three cases dealing with the Bush administration's detention of ''enemy combatants.'' The administration's lawyers argue for a view of executive authority that leaves no room for ''second-guessing'' by the federal courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, SANDY
description: VOGEL--Sandy, formerly of Manhattan, died Friday, April 2nd, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY following open heart surgery. For many years an executive producer of TV commercials, she retired in 1998 to her home in Montauk, NY. Devoted sister, beloved aunt and great-aunt, world traveler and friend to many. A celebration of her life will be held Friday, April 23rd, at the Wainwright House, Rye, NY, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to Concerned Citizens of Montauk, PO Box 915, Montauk, NY 11954.

title: Page Two: April 11-17; Some Wonders Never Cease
description: NASA has developed a high-tech insulator called Aerogel -- a solid material that is 99.9 percent air. A translucent concrete, marketed as LiTraCon, was recently developed in Hungary. And last week, Tyco Fire and Security introduced a flame-dousing ''water'' called Sapphire. The catch? It doesn't get things wet. Old-time scientific rationality seems to be teetering on the edge of obsolescence.

title: Forbidden Fur
description: The Ethicist (March 21) asked for readers' suggestions on what to do with old fur. The Black Beauty Ranch has fur on its wish list. As described on its Web site, blackbeautyranch.org, the ranch was ''founded in 1979 by Cleveland Amory and the Fund for Animals in order to provide a safe sanctuary and final home for unwanted and abused domestic and exotic animals.'' Its suggestion is to donate an old fur for the animals to use.

description: BECK--Eugene. Sutton Place Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member and benefactor. A gentle man with a kind heart, we grieve with the family and extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Esther, children and grandchildren. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Mark Wiener, President

description: THE FALL OF THE HOUSE OF ROOSEVELT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VANN, RUBY
description: VANN--Ruby, April 13. Services Woodward Home, 1 Troy Ave., Brooklyn, Sunday, 28PM, and Monday 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RITTER, MILTON
description: RITTER--Milton. 89, died peacefully on April 14, New York City. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Father of Dianne, Janice, Julia and Joseph. Devoted grandfather of eight. Companion to Florence Pushkin. Family receiving Sunday, April 18. A simple man and good father.

title: Parading It
description: A century ago, the Easter parade on Fifth Avenue was a serious display of spring finery with rigid rules about propriety. Right, a taste of that era last Sunday contrasted with today's easy ways, just below: T-shirted ticket holders for high Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Below, classic style among worshipers at St. Thomas Episcopal Church attending high service. On the avenue, bottom row, many looks and colors went by, with pink the favorite. For some, the annual promenade is a spring carnival, like the poetic explosion far right. Four women wore panoramic eggs. And, above, the doggy Easter bonnet with all the frills upon it.

title: Thai Night Life Faces A Shortened Night
description: THE law-and-order government of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra has been trying to clean up Thailand's image as a good-time sex and entertainment center since his election in 2001. The latest effort focuses on earlier closing hours for bars, discos, massage parlors and karaoke halls across the country.

title: Cases Before Supreme Court Will Test Limits of Presidential Power
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Three Supreme Court cases generated by the Bush administration's detention of those it deems "enemy combatants" will be argued over the next 10 days, framing a debate of historic dimension not only about the rights of citizens and noncitizens alike, but also  or perhaps principally  about the boundaries of presidential power.

title: How to Improve Domestic Intelligence
description: Before Sept. 11, Al Qaeda terrorists took advantage of yawning gaps between the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in order to slip into the United States. Last week, the Sept. 11 commission hearings recounted in painful detail the lapses of the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. before the attacks on New York and Washington, and helped pressure President Bush to consider reforming the way the government collects intelligence.

title: This Season Our Chef Is Offering Debt and Agita
description: IN the first season of the NBC reality series ''The Restaurant,'' America got to watch as Rocco DiSpirito, the buff, 30-something chef of the Manhattan restaurant Union Pacific, opened his dream trattoria, Rocco's on 22nd. It wasn't pretty: the six-episode summer series, created by Mark Burnett -- the producer behind ''Survivor'' and ''The Apprentice'' -- showcased the many difficulties of getting started, from construction delays to staff mutinies to kitchen fires to the demands of Mr. DiSpirito's financial backer, Jeffrey Chodorow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAMPERT, SAMUEL

title: The Ocean in the Head
description: When Marvin Bell, in his excellent new collection of poems, writes the totally characteristic line ''His spine quivers like a long quill, quite like it,'' it's worth considering what that ''quite like it'' might be doing there. Verbally and rhythmically it functions as a sort of heart murmur, a shrug or flutter after the main pulse of the line. This is Bell's territory in miniature: echo, aftermath, a looking backward through the veil of things. RAMPANT (Copper Canyon, $20) deals in negative space: ''A lit cigarette is building an ash column,'' Bell writes in ''Of a Student''; Gaud's great church in Barcelona ''remains unfinished but / people talk about it''; a wartime experience is so intense it becomes ''a glare, a deficit in memory.'' We are assured in ''The Troubling'' that ''there is an outside beyond the farthest / thing we can imagine.'' As a poet in the office of student or historian of consciousness, Bell performs beautifully, like a less sleek Wallace Stevens. One of this book's highlights is called ''Ulysses, Too, Was Sometimes Down at Heart,'' in which the hero's sea wanderings are shrunk to the size of an anxious 21st-century brain, and oceanic storms contract to a chemical flux in the skull -- the mood swing, the change of the wind, the swing of the boom beneath the sail. ''We have learned to / hear the sound of a rain cloud forming. A mast / nearly snaps. We make that promise again -/ to be steadier, to spend the highs slowly.'' This is sympathy, the real thing. James Parker

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Even among the eccentric objects and art pieces displayed in the Suzanne Slesin-Michael Steinberg household, the Tejo Remy chest of drawers in the bedroom stands out like a ham at Hanukkah. Originally commissioned in 1991 by the Dutch collective Droog Design, the unconventional storage system comprises 20 disparate wooden drawers tied together with a mover's strap, bringing to mind the bundled mess on the back of the Beverly Hillbillies' truck. ''I've always adored that piece,'' Slesin says. ''It's an idea that always makes me smile and embodies everything that appeals to me about design -- it's quirky, folksy, partly recycled, thought-provoking and not pretentious.'' Although the piece is one of a series officially called You Can't Lay Down Your Memories, the group could also be referred to as You Can't Remember Where You Put Anything. ''I love that you have to go fish for your socks because you have no idea where you put them,'' she says. ''For me, it's part of its appeal, and besides, it trains your memory.'' title: We the Characters
description: Writers have set some perversely difficult tasks for themselves: composing a novel entirely devoid of the letter ''E,'' for example, or a novel in which the chapters can be read in a number of different orders. One of the trickiest feats is to narrate a story in the first-person plural. It's so hard, in fact, that among the dispiritingly vast array of titles shelved in my local bookstore's How to Write Fiction section, few even mention the first-person plural as an option. John Gardner's classic, ''The Art of Fiction: Notes on Craft for Young Writers,'' refers to it in passing as ''the 'town' point of view, in which the voice in the story is some unnamed spokesman for all the community,'' and notes that William Faulkner's short story ''A Rose for Emily'' is the best-known example. But even in the sentence or two he devotes to the subject, Gardner assumes too much. Is the ''we'' who narrates Faulkner's Gothic tale about a reclusive spinster really ''some unnamed spokesman'' or is it the town itself?

Documentary photographs are accused of lying and documentary photographers of exploitation, condescension, pandering and related unsavory activities. Yet they continue to try to report the world as it is or as they see it, some hoping to change it, some struggling with doubts they harbored long before the critics arrived.

title: Seeing Red
description: Taking advantage of my overstuffed vulnerability on a recent weekend in New Orleans, a tiny Middle Eastern army carrying Kalashnikovs somehow broke through my epiglottis and at about 10 a.m. Saturday staged an offensive that was not only painful but also, to say the least, disruptive. The bed shook, the hotel walls realigned in a trapezoid and Red's gentle, soothing words became shrieks from a macaw. After I endured several hours of this -- accompanied by cold sweats, some woozies and the certainty that life wasn't worth living -- the remedy suddenly appeared in an almost religious vision. It took the form of that jewel of all fruits, the cranberry.

title: 'Kings of Infinite Space'
description: One brutally hot summer's morning, Paul Trilby-ex-husband, temp typist, cat murderer-slouched sweating in his t-shirt on his way to work, waiting behind the wheel of his car for the longest red light in central Texas. He was steeling himself for a confrontation with his boss, screwing up his nerve to ask for a raise, but his present circumstances were conspiring against him. His fourteen-year-old Dodge Colt rattled in place in the middle of the Travis Street Bridge, hemmed in on all sides by bulbous, purring pickup trucks and gleaming sport utility vehicles with fat, black tires. The electric blues and greens of these enormous automobiles reflected the dazzling morning glare through Paul's cracked and dirty windshield; they radiated shimmering heat through his open window. Waiting for the light, the fingers of his left hand drumming the scalding side of his car, the skin of his forearm baking to leather in the heat, Paul felt less like a man who deserved more out of life than a peasant on a mule cart trapped in the middle of an armored division.

title: Singled Out
description: It was simple enough -- or so we thought until the letter came. A local broker had suggested we consider obtaining our health insurance as individuals. We had been covered in a group plan thanks to Matt's fellowship at Occidental College, a post he held while at work on a book. But the two of us were increasingly structuring our work lives as entrepreneurs. Jody worked part time in venture capital, served as lead director of a public company and was thinking of launching her own business; Matt had added consulting to column and book writing and his weekly radio show. The agent we had spoken with had recommended getting into the individual market for health insurance while we were in our early 40's and healthy. That way, he said, we could pursue such freelance lives with the assurance that we would always have health coverage. Once you are in the system, he said, you will only be subject to the annual premium increases the insurers apply to everyone. But trying to move from group coverage into the individual market when we were older might be much harder. If you think you are headed in an entrepreneurial direction, he concluded, it's best to make the shift as soon as you can. It seemed straightforward.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SHE'S just a well-groomed elderly woman in an orange sweater talking about her old boss. When she asked him for cyanide capsules, she remembers, he said, ''I would have preferred to give you a nicer farewell gift.'' There's nothing more to Andr Heller and Othmar Schmiderer's BLIND SPOT: HITLER'S SECRETARY(2002) than the talking head of Traudl Junge, who was one of the Fuhrer's four secretaries from 1942 to 1945, but that's enough. Especially when she discusses the final days in the bunker. ''He became completely numb and apathetic, and he would just sit in the corridor,'' she recalls, ''with a puppy in his lap, staring ahead blankly.'' She also remembers that Hitler didn't like to be touched. Junge, who was eventually pardoned, died of cancer in 2002 -- Tuesday at 8:30 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: SAVING CULTURAL TREASURES
description: The looting of archaeological sites in Latin America and the smuggling of pre-Columbian and colonial-era objects has become so pervasive that the International Council of Museums issued a ''red list'' of 25 types of objects likely to be stolen. The Paris-based council's book, ''Red List of Latin-American Cultural Objects at Risk,'' is intended to help art dealers, customs and police officials identify such objects. Manus Brinkman, secretary general of the council, said that because thousands of objects stolen from churches or taken from archaeological sites often end up in North America, the red list would increase public awareness and encourage collectors to stop buying such cultural property. Among these items are Teotihuacan masks, jade Olmec figurines, Nayarit clay figures and clay Jama-Coaque figures and vessels.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Firefighter Accused Of Drunken Driving
description: A firefighter was arrested early yesterday on charges of drunken driving, the police said. The firefighter, Michael Criscitiello, smelled of alcohol when he was stopped at 4:40 a.m. after a traffic infraction at Morani Street and Richmond Avenue, two blocks north of Victory Boulevard, the police said. The firefighter's arrest came as the Fire Department has been buffeted by controversies involving alcohol use. It was the latest in a series of incidents since a New Year's Eve drinking party in a Staten Island firehouse led to a fight that left one firefighter hospitalized. A department spokesman said that Firefighter Criscitiello had been assigned to Engine Company 250 in Brooklyn and has been a firefighter for two and a half years. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Alan's memory to the Trinity Hockey Rink Fund, Trinity College, 300 Summit St, Hartford, CT 06106. title: Algerian Elections
description: The lopsided re-election victory of President Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria recently is, above all, a sign that the Algerians desperately long for an end to more than a decade of civil violence. Since taking office in 1999 in elections largely engineered by the military, Mr. Bouteflika has managed to restore a measure of peace and normalcy, assisted by high prices for the gas and oil that account for most of Algeria's national income. With so much attention focused these days on the Arab world's democratic deficit, it would make good sense for the United States and the European Union to support Mr. Bouteflika and encourage his government to start to promote real democracy. The election was not above reproach, but with 83.5 percent of the votes and a thumbs-up from international monitors, it was clear that a large majority chose Mr. Bouteflika.

title: A Citizen's Right

title: Settlements for Sale
description: The initiative by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to withdraw unilaterally from the Gaza Strip is the only promising feature on an otherwise troubled Israeli-Palestinian political landscape. However, there are still far too many unknowns about the Sharon proposal for it to qualify as a real plan. By publicly endorsing the plan last week, President Bush has given Mr. Sharon a boost domestically and has significantly reduced uncertainty about whether or not the prime minister will have the political capital needed to carry it out. But Israel's killing on Saturday of Abdel Aziz Rantisi, the leader in Gaza of the militant group Hamas, is a reminder that the withdrawal could also give rise to further unrest. Many other questions remain as well, particularly concerning what will be done with the settlements once Israel evacuates them.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: TDS To Restate Some Results
description: Telephone and Data Systems, the parent of the U.S. Cellular Corporation, said yesterday that it would restate its financial results for 2002 and 2003 because new accounting rules valued the company's mobile-phone licenses higher. That will increase the 2002 net loss by about $10 million and reduce 2003 net income by about $14 million. TDS, which is based in Chicago, said that sales would not change. After a review, the company increased the value of the wireless licenses by $230 million, TDS said. Goodwill -- an intangible asset that is the difference between the price paid for an asset and its book value -- decreased by $139 million, and related deferred income taxes rose by $91 million. Increasing the value of the wireless licenses makes them subject to larger write-downs when the market value of the asset is less than the book value, a TDS spokesman, Mark Steinkrauss, said. TDS's net income fell in 2003 and its loss increased in 2002 because the company had to write down the value of some wireless licenses, he said. TDS had reported 2003 net income of $61.1 million and a 2002 loss of $984.8 million.

title: A Haitian Journalist Was Killed, But a Film Keeps His Spirit Alive
description: Jean Lopold Dominique's craggy good looks, rapid-fire eloquence and grand gestures would have served him well on the stage or in film. He was certainly a character, though not an actor, who believed unwaveringly in his native Haiti as it stumbled toward democracy. His optimism was boundless, whether it was as an agronomist who owned no land or later as a radio journalist who challenged corruption and crime in a land where reality outdoes any fantasy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charges Against Lawyer Remain
description: A federal judge in Manhattan denied motions yesterday to dismiss the most recent charges against a prominent defense lawyer who has been accused of supporting terrorism by helping her client, an imprisoned sheik, direct terrorist operations. The lawyer, Lynne F. Stewart, left, contended that the charges were vague, overly broad, irrelevant and prejudicial, but Judge John G. Koeltl did not agree. The charges were part of a revised indictment filed against Ms. Stewart and a co-defendant in November after the most serious charges in the original indictment were dismissed on constitutional grounds. If convicted, the defendants could each face 5 to 15 years in prison. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Willingboro: Nurses On Strike
description: Nearly 290 nurses went out on strike yesterday at Lourdes Medical Center of Burlington County. Temporary workers filled their shifts. The nurses began picketing after another failed attempt at contract negotiations on Friday. The unions' central concern in the proposed contract is an existing clause that grants the hospital, according to the union, too much discretion in determining when and where nurses work. Management disputes that description. Union officials said that hospital administrators had used that language recently to abuse nurses' rights, pointing to last October, when management reorganized three hospital units. The resulting shift and assignment changes disrupted the nurses' lives and lessened time with patients, the union said. There were no plans yesterday to resume negotiations. Jason George (NYT)

description: Sony Ericsson, the world's sixth-largest mobile phone maker, posted its third consecutive quarterly profit with net income of 82 million euros ($98.7 million) compared with a loss of 104 million euros a year earlier. In marked contrast to the market leader, Nokia, whose cellphone business is in the doldrums, Sony Ericsson, a joint venture of Sony and Ericsson, said sales surged to 1.34 billion euros ($1.6 billion) from 806 million euros a year ago. Like some rivals, Sony Ericsson is making gains with cellphones featuring trendy clamshell designs and miniature digital cameras. Alan Cowell (NYT)
