title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Grocer Reports Loss
description: Royal Ahold said that it lost 1 million euros ($1.2 million) last year, a sliver of the 1.2 billion euros ($1.4 billion) it lost in 2002, when an accounting scandal at its U.S. Foodservice subsidiary hurt its results. Foodservice, one of the largest food distributors in the United States, reported a $218 million operating loss last year. It recorded a $148 million profit in 2002. Ahold executives attributed the Foodservice loss in part on difficulties with suppliers after the accounting scandal. Several of Ahold's supermarket chains in the United States, including Giant-Landover, reported significant declines in operating income because of a weak dollar and retail margin pressures. Ahold's total 2003 sales were down 10.6 percent, to 56.1 billion euros ($67.4 billion). Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Paramilitary Chief Missing After Attack
description: Carlos Castao, Colombia's most infamous warlord, narrowly escaped assassination by a rival faction of the paramilitary group he leads and he is now in hiding, probably along the northern border region with Panama, said his Miami-based lawyer, Joaquin Perez. His disappearance threatens demobilization talks President lvaro Uribe's government has been holding with Mr. Castao and his paramilitary force. Mr. Castao has expressed a reluctance to cement a deal with the government unless he is assured that he will not be extradited to the United States, where he is wanted on cocaine trafficking charges. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Dredging Plan Criticized
description: The Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, and several environmental groups said yesterday that they planned to sue to stop dredge waste from being deposited into Long Island Sound. Under an Environmental Protection Agency plan, about 21 million cubic yards of sediment would be deposited in the two sites -- one between Huntington and Stamford, Conn., the other between Shoreham Beach and East Haven, Conn. Mr. Levy said the plan permitted sediment from polluted Connecticut waterways to be deposited at the sites, which could harm cleanup efforts in the Sound. Mel Cot, manager of the water quality unit for the environmental agency's office in Boston, said that the sediment was tested for toxins and that regulations prohibited the deposit of waste testing positive for contamination. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: MG TECHNOLOGIES SELLS 4 CHEMICAL UNITS FOR $2.7 BILLION
description: A German engineering group, MG Technologies, sold the majority of its Dynamit Nobel chemical businesses for 2.25 billion euros ($2.7 billion) to a consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and CSFB Private Equity, MG Technologies said yesterday. The four Dynamit units with 7,400 employees and combined sales of about 1.5 billion euros ($1.8 billion) are to be incorporated into Kohlberg Kravis's subsidiary, Rockwood Specialties, a chemicals company less than half the size of the acquisition. Rockwood is based in Princeton, N.J. MG Technologies, which is based in Frankfurt, had said earlier that it would focus on engineering and divest all Dynamit businesses plus another chemicals unit. Dynamit's plastics business is not part of the deal, which requires approval by MG Technologies' supervisory board and cartel authorities. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULTZ, CHAD
description: SCHULTZ--Chad. A Chicago investment banker, died at home on Thursday, after a long illness. He was 50. Mr. Schultz was a Managing Director of Credit Suisse First Boston, and Group Co-Head of the Private Fund Group, an industry leading placement agent for private equity investment funds. He joined CSFB in November, 2000, when the firm merged with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, where he was a Managing Director, Founder and CoHead of the Private Fund Group. He joined DLJ in 1994 from Merrill Lynch in Chicago, whre he was a Vice President with responsibility for raising institutional private equity for various investment partnerships. Prior to that, Mr. Schultz spent six years with Morgan Stanley in the Fixed Income and Financial Services Group. He received a BA from Trinity College. Mr. Schultz was known for the energy and enthusiasm he brought to his many interests. His avid love of music flowed from his skill at the piano to an encyclopedic knowledge of both popular and classical music. No less a student of the arts and literature, Mr. Schultz brought the intensity and intelligence that drove his business success to bear in these areas as well, providing him with an engaging charm born of his easy familiarity with so many facets of culture. He founded Bordigera Vineyards in 1999, the culmination of his interest in wine, encompassing with typical thoroughness the soil, the vines, and their combination in the wine making process. His daughters' love of horses translated into the establishment of Bordigera Stables, yet another example of the passion Mr. Schultz brought to all of his accomplishments. Mr. Schultz is survived by his wife Noreen McGuire Schultz; his daughters, Claire and Elizabeth Schultz and Lauren Besser; his parents Sigrid and Gerhard Schultz; and his sisters, Dawn Bandolik and Beth Walsh. A Memorial Service was held Monday, April 19, at 10 am, at Fourth Presbyterian Church, Michigan Ave and Delaware Place, Chicago. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Chad Schultz Cancer Research Fund, C/O the Greater Milwaukee Foundation, 1020 North Broadway, Milwaukee, WI. 53202.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHSCHILD, TIRZAH
description: ROTHSCHILD -- Tirzah. Passed away peacefully in her own apartment in Upper Manhattan on Sunday, April 18, 2004, after a short illness. Beloved daughter of the late Dr. Leo and Paula Rothschild, sister of Dr. Karlo Rothschild and the late Hilde Straus and sister-in-law of Walter Straus and Frances Rothschild. She was buried in Jerusalem. For over 50 years she was teacher/principal at Yeshiva Rabbi S.R. Hirsch in New York City & was respected and admired as a ''Teacher's Teacher.'' She devoted much time and boundless energy to volunteer work, charity and to helping others. Her family, friends and countless students will always be grateful to her.

title: Byzantine Chant, Rich Challenge To Its Gregorian Counterpart
description: Most New Yorkers, conditioned as we are to the modes and key systems of Western European music, know the sound of Byzantine chant more by reputation than by direct acquaintance. We hear it indirectly, through the Russian Orthodox sacred music that in recent years has found a concert following, or in the music of the contemporary English composer John Tavener. A curious listener could also pop into a Greek Orthodox church to hear it in its natural setting.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Annual Results Delayed
description: Adecco, a Swiss company that provides temporary workers, said it was delaying the release the full results of 2003 for a second time. Adecco, which already postponed 2003 results after disclosing accounting problems at its North American unit in January, said in a statement that ''significant progress'' had been made in completing group accounts and reiterated that no evidence to date had been found of ''major misappropriations or irregularities.'' The results for 2003 and the first quarter of 2004 had been scheduled for release today. The latest delay set off a 4 percent decline in its share price, less than the 35 percent decline when it announced the first delay in January. Adecco, based in Glattbrugg, Switzerland, said the audit had to be reviewed by a New York law firm and cited slow communications for the delay. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

description: At the start, in rural Hopkinton, the temperature was 83 degrees. At the finish, in the upscale Back Bay section of Boston, it was up to 85, making it the warmest day here since August. But unwanted heat or not, the 108th annual Boston Marathon would go on.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadcom To Buy Widcomm For $49 Million
description: The Broadcom Corporation, which makes computer chips and has announced three acquisitions in the last year, has agreed to acquire Widcomm Inc., which is closely held, for $49 million in cash and stock, adding software that runs wireless devices. Broadcom said yesterday that it might issue about 1.23 million shares of Class A common stock for the transaction and pay as much as $3 million in cash. Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., is buying Widcomm to add software for Bluetooth wireless technology to its hardware products, the company said. Broadcom shares fell 32 cents, to $39.44.

title: Balanchine's '34 Ballet, Staged at Its Original Site
description: The first ballet that George Balanchine choreographed in the United States was ''Serenade,'' and its first public performance, in 1934 at Woodlands, the Westchester estate of Felix Warburg, is an oft-told tale in ballet history.

description: The index of leading economic indicators rose 0.3 percent in March, the Conference Board reported yesterday, and posted its greatest 12-month increase in two decades.

description: After days of talks and threats of a military showdown, American officials agreed Monday to call off an offensive in the flash point city of Falluja if civic leaders can persuade insurgents there to turn in their heavy weapons.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Suit Filed Over Power Plant
description: A group of Democratic elected officials filed a lawsuit in federal court yesterday to try to block the use of $400 million in tax-exempt Liberty Bonds for a 1,000-megawatt power plant in Astoria. Congress voted in 2002 to allow up to $8 billion in Liberty Bonds to provide tax-free financing to help New York City rebuild after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. The lead plaintiff in the suit, Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris, said that the plant was not in Lower Manhattan and did not fit the definition of nonresidential real property required by the federal statute, and that local residents were opposed to another plant in the area. Lynn Rasic, a spokeswoman for Gov. George E. Pataki, who is a defendant in the lawsuit, said the project met the criteria for the program because it allowed up to $2 billion in bonds to be used outside Lower Manhattan for projects benefiting the entire city. She called the lawsuit ''frivolous'' and said that when completed, the plant would provide up to 10 percent of the city's energy. Al Baker (NYT)

title: White House Revises Rules on Overtime Pay
description: Facing a deluge of criticism in an election year, the Bush administration scaled back today its plans to deny overtime coverage to hundreds of thousands of American workers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark Reports 28% Profit Increase
description: Lexmark International, the nation's second-biggest maker of computer printers, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 28 percent on demand for new machines that combine printing, faxing and copying. Net income increased to $121 million, or 91 cents a share, from $94.6 million, or 73 cents, a year earlier. Sales grew 13 percent, to $1.26 billion, from $1.11 billion, the company said on its Web site. Lexmark's multifunction copiers are more profitable. Sales of such devices grew to more than 40 percent of the American ink-jet printer market in 2003, the market researcher Gartner has said. First-quarter results exceeded forecasts of analysts, who had expected profit of 87 cents a share and sales of $1.22 billion, the average of 16 estimates in Thomson Financial surveys. Lexmark shares rose $2.31, to $96.16.

title: Reining In Painkillers
description: Worried that millions of Americans are using prescription opiate painkillers to get high rather than to ease severe chronic pain, drug makers are working with the government and pain specialists on ways to prevent abuse. The effort includes tracking and reformulating pills.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cendant's chief is taking a pay cut, but some say that it's hard to determine how much of one.
description: BOWING to shareholder pressure, Henry R. Silverman, the chairman and chief executive of the Cendant Corporation and recipient of one of the richest executive compensation packages in the United States, took a bit of a pay cut yesterday as the company announced changes to his employment contract. The move came the day that jury selection began in the securities fraud case of two former Cendant officers in federal court in Hartford, and the day before Cendant's annual meeting with shareholders in New York.

title: Layups for Love In the Heart Of an Arena
description: How do you create a spell? With words. We all know the incantations of fairy tales, the language writers invent to make the dead rise and the gods appear, to send ordinary people past the boundaries of the natural world. From the first words of ''Three Seconds in the Key,'' a New Georges production at the Baruch Performing Arts center through May 9, the playwright Deb Margolin creates a spell.

Its goal is not to shock, amaze or even entertain, but to inform the people who influence or will someday influence science policy.

Khalidi as the Edward Said Professor of Arab Studies at Columbia University last fall brought to the campus not only a noted Middle Eastern scholar, but also a man who, like Dr. Said, has been assailed by conservatives and many supporters of Israel for being critical of United States policy on the Middle East.

description: South America's biggest economies moved a step closer on Monday to sealing a long-sought trade deal with the European Union, a shift that could complicate efforts to forge a free trade area stretching from Alaska to Argentina by the end of the year.

description: Islanders goalie Rick DiPietro will have arthroscopic surgery tomorrow on his right knee, General Manager Mike Milbury said yesterday in a conference call that otherwise indicated little of the Islanders' postseason plans.

title: Chief Executive Of US Airways Quits Amid Strife
description: The chief executive of US Airways, David N. Siegel, who vowed last month that he would not run from the airline's deepening financial problems but had reached a logjam with its unions, resigned yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pier Renovation Planned
description: Norwegian Cruise Lines and Carnival Corporation have signed letters of intent with the city to pay a minimum of $200 million in port charges through 2017 to help pay for improvements to the main cruise ship terminal on the West Side of Manhattan and to create a pier for cruise liners in Brooklyn. Under the unusual agreement, the city will spend $150 million to renovate the terminal on Manhattan's West Side, which has not had a major renovation since the 1970's. The agreements call for the two cruise lines to bring at least 13 million passengers to the city through 2017 and in return to get the best berths. The city will also reduce the cruise lines' fees in exchange for volume and revenue guarantees. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: In Rare U.S. Race, Armstrong Is Wary
description: Lance Armstrong does not race often in the United States in stage races, so there is an eagerness to see him at his best for the Tour de Georgia. Officials expect Armstrong's appearance in the six-day event to draw one million spectators, but Armstrong said people could be disappointed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stagecoach Payout
description: The Stagecoach Group, the British bus and rail operator, said it would return as much as 250 million ($451 million) to shareholders and that fiscal 2004 earnings would be higher than analysts' forecasts. Income in the 2004 fiscal year, which ends April 30, will be helped by its rail business, a lower than expected tax charge and profit from its Virgin Rail Group joint venture, Stagecoach said.

title: Worldcom Changes Its Name and Emerges From Bankruptcy
description: Worldcom Inc. emerged from federal bankruptcy protection this morning with the new name of MCI, about 21 months after the scandal-tainted company sought protection from creditors in the wake of an $11 billion accounting fraud.

title: 5 Suffolk Teenagers Charged In BB Shooting Spree
description: Five Suffolk County teenagers went on a BB gun shooting spree late last week, damaged close to 50 cars, and, when confronted by an outraged car owner, shot him in the forehead, the police said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Nauru: Help For A Neighbor
description: Threatened with bankruptcy by the financing company GE Capital, the Pacific island nation of Nauru is seeking help from Australia, which promised to have senior financial officials help Nauru devise a plan to stave off financial ruin. Nauru, with a population of slightly more than 12,000, has been hurt by poor investments and declining reserves of phosphate and is struggling to repay 235 million Australian dollars ($176 million) it owes GE Capital. Last Friday, GE Capital repossessed several of Nauru's properties in Australia to recover its loan. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Israeli Tanks Enter Gaza; 4 Palestinians Die in Fighting
description: JERUSALEM, April 20  Israeli soldiers killed at least four Palestinians today as tanks entered the northern Gaza Strip in an attempt to halt repeated Palestinian rocket fire coming from the tense territory, according to security officials on both sides.

title: JONES APPAREL EXTENDS BID FOR MAXWELL SHOE COMPANY
description: The Jones Apparel Group said yesterday that it had extended its $20-a-share tender offer for the Maxwell Shoe Company's shares from April 19 until May 17. Maxwell's board continues to recommend that its holders reject the hostile bid, which is worth about $300 million. Shares of Readville, Mass.-based Maxwell closed at $22.11, down 22 cents, on the Nasdaq. Jones Apparel, of Bristol, Pa., said 236,834 Maxwell shares, or about 1.6 percent of the total outstanding, were tendered and not withdrawn as of Sunday. Maxwell said its shareholders have sent a message that they believe Jones Apparel's offer is inadequate.

title: One More Reason to Join a Gym
description: Overweight older women can reduce unhealthy estrogen levels, and perhaps reduce their risk of breast cancer, by taking off fat through exercise, a new study has found.

description: It is Florence, the year 2000. Sarah Dunant, a writer and moderator of cultural programs for the BBC, sits miserably in a restaurant opposite her estranged lover, staring at the bloody steak on the table between them.

description: For the second time in three weeks, hundreds of police officers were deployed in Britain on Monday in a major sweep of suspected terrorists. The police said nine men and one woman had been arrested.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Man Is Charged In 12 Killings
description: A Kansas City man has been charged with 10 counts of first-degree murder and 2 counts of capital murder in a dozen strangling deaths spanning almost two decades. Prosecutors, citing DNA evidence collected 17 years ago, say the man, Lorenzo J. Gilyard, 53, strangled and sexually assaulted 12 women -- 11 prostitutes and a woman who might have been mentally ill -- from 1977 to 1993. Mr. Gilyard, the supervisor of a trash collecting company, is being held without bail. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: American and allied forces have choked the flow of foreign fighters coming into Iraq from Syria and Iran, curbing a small but persistent source of combatants that has fueled the insurgency, especially in the Sunni Muslim heartland, American military officers said Monday.

title: FLEMING CONSIDERS CHANGING REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: The grocery distributor Fleming Companies said yesterday that it had a tentative deal with some major creditors that might require it to redraft its plan for leaving bankruptcy. James Sprayregen, a lawyer for Fleming, which is based in Lewisville, Tex., said at a court hearing that by May 4, Fleming would know whether it faced a contest with large vendors over its reorganization plan or whether they would accept a settlement negotiated by an official committee representing their interests. The so-called ''reclamation claimants,'' which sold to Fleming just before its bankruptcy, include the H.J. Heinz Company, ConAgra Foods, the Hershey Foods Corporation and dozens of others. They are normally entitled to claiming their products back, and have confronted Fleming over its proposed Chapter 11 plan. They have said they are owed hundreds of millions of dollars in priority payments and that special bankruptcy court rules entitle them to collect from Fleming before other vendors do. Dow Jones/AP

title: Corrections

title: ETHAN ALLEN WILL CLOSE PLANTS IN NEW YORK AND VIRGINIA
description: Ethan Allen Interiors, which sells furniture at more than 300 stores, said yesterday that it would close plants in New York and Virginia and lay off about 500 workers to make its manufacturing base more efficient. Ethan Allen, based in Danbury, Conn., said in a regulatory filing that it would close plants in Boonville, N.Y., and Bridgewater, Va., and record costs of 20 cents to 22 cents a share. Most of the effect on earnings is expected to occur in the company's fiscal fourth quarter, ending June 30. Ethan Allen will have 12 plants and about 4,000 employees after the closings.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Fire Leaves 2 Children Seriously Hurt
description: Two children suffered serious injuries in a fire that broke out last night on the top floor of a three-story building at 417 East 146th Street in the Mott Haven section, the authorities said. Relatives identified the victims early this morning as Tanisha Narvaez and Jeremy Delgado, both 1 year old. They said that Tanisha was being treated at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and that Jeremy had been transferred from there to Jacobi Medical Center. Claribel Mercado, Jeremy's godmother, said the children had been playing with other children on the third floor when an explosion occurred about 10:30 p.m. The fire was brought under control by 11 p.m. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Sunken Boat To Be Removed
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had begun to remove the Cartigan, a former Coast Guard boat that has been partly submerged for nearly a year in Sheepshead Bay. ''This 125-foot eyesore is a detriment to the community and a navigational hazard,'' Mr. Bloomberg said in a statement. ''In instances like this, it is only appropriate that the city take action to correct the situation and remove the Cartigan.'' Removing the vessel, now privately owned, from the bay requires divers to deploy a boom to contain any discharge. As it is raised, water will be pumped from the boat to make it lighter, and then the boat will be hoisted out of the water and onto a barge. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPHAEL, ALAN H.

Devoted husband of the late Rita S. Raphael. Whether a quip, a pun or a joke, he shared his gift of laughter with family and many friends. Donations to Cornell School of Engineering or Horace Mann will be appreciated.

title: Coffee, Tea and Fatigue: Airline Job Loses Its Allure
description: Long, long gone are the good old days, when flight attendants with indelible smiles donned white gloves to serve dinner on fine china. Today, as airlines battle furiously over fares while desperately cutting costs, the flight attendant's job on major airlines has gone from glamour to grind.

description: The commander of American-led forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David Barno, said Monday that Pakistan had successfully disrupted the Qaeda network in the tribal areas bordering Afghanistan and had significantly affected its ability to support a suspected Taliban insurgency across the border in Afghanistan.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Hundreds Arrested At Bird And Dog Fights
description: More than 200 men, women and children were arrested Sunday at a rural property in Barrow County where rooster and pit bull fights were held, said Larry Schnall, a state trooper. The detainees, who came from across the country, were charged with gambling and cruelty to animals. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NIEMEYER, JACK
description: NIEMEYER -- Jack. The Trustees, administration, staff, students, and alumni of Bank Street College of Education deeply mourn the passing of John H. Niemeyer, President Emeritus. His presidency of Bank Street, from 1956-1973, ushered the College onto the national stage, and laid the groundwork for its significant influence on American education. As President Emeritus and Life Trustee, Jack continued to play a central role in the shaping of the College and its pursuit of its mission, in a commitment that spanned nearly 50 years. Children in public schools across the nation, especially those in urban schools, have lost a passionate friend and advocate. And as for Bank Street, a long and pivotal chapter in our history has come to an end. We are the poorer for its closing, but will always be the richer for all the years that Jack devoted to the College. Augusta Souza Kappner, President Sue A. Kaplan, Chair Board of Trustees

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: DIAMOND HUNTERS KILLED IN AMAZON The police began retrieving the bodies of 26 diamond prospectors killed in a clash with Indians in the Amazon jungle. The bodies of 30 more prospectors could still be inside the remote Roosevelt reserve in northwestern Rondônia, also apparently victims of a massacre by Cinta Larga Indians on April 7, a state official said. A police official in Espigão d'Oeste, 60 miles from the reservation, home to some 1,300 Indians and South America's largest diamond reserves, said the miners were all shot to death. Tensions between prospectors and Indians have flared often in recent years, but little was known about the reasons for the latest violence.    (AP)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Court Affirms Genocide In Bosnia
description: In a landmark decision, the appeals chamber of the United Nations war crimes tribunal ruled that genocide took place in Bosnia during the war in the 1990's. The five appeals judges, whose decision is final, settled a question much debated by legal scholars: was the persecution and killing of Bosnian Muslims by Serbs and others, known as ethnic cleansing. a deliberate genocidal campaign? Referring to the massacre of more than 7,000 Muslim men and boys in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995, the court said the crime ''should be called by its proper name: genocide.'' The ruling came in an appeal by Radislav Krstic, above, a Bosnian Serb general and the only person yet convicted of genocide in the former Yugoslavia. The judges reduced his sentence to 35 years from 46 because he had ''aided and abetted genocide'' in Srebrenica but had not taken part in it. Legal scholars said the ruling on genocide, the most serious of war crimes, was likely to have an important effect on the trial of Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, and on other cases. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAYN, BENJAMIN ROBERT
description: PAYN -- Benjamin Robert. Born on December 24, 1913 in Swir, then Russia, today Lithuania. At the time of the Communist Revolution in 1918 the family escaped to Berlin where he lived until Hitler came to power. He moved to Paris in 1934 and served in the French Army during WWII until the collapse of the French Army. He arrived in New York in June of 1944 where he lived until his death. A committed Zionist since adolescence, he was a faithful disciple of Vladimir Jabotinsky, the Zionist leader, and while in France, he worked tirelessly with Aliya Beth to obtain exit visas and transport for European Jewish refugees to travel to what was then Palestine. He worked closely with Edmond de Rothschild on the financing and construction of the oil pipeline which was the beginning of the Israeli oil and gas industry and he was cited for this work by the American-Israel Chamber of Commerce and Industry. He received a PhD in Political Science from la Sorbonne and in 1961 was decorated by the French Government as a Chevalier de La Legion d'Honneur for his services to France and to Franco-American relations. He was a man of commitment and integrity, a loyal and involved friend and a loving and responsible family member. He was married to Amalia Tellez and the father of Dr. Nadine Payn and Deanne Payn and the grandfather of Danielle Carter and Ana Maria Dragin. Services will be held on Friday, April 23, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Police Building in Saudi Capital Is Wrecked by Car Bomb
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 21  A deadly game of cat and mouse between the security services and a group of anti-government extremists that has been unrolling for the past 10 days across central Saudi Arabia culminated today in a car bombing here that official sources said killed four people and wounded 148.

title: Sports of The Times; It's About Finding a Zone, Not Zen, for Rodriguez
description: HE'S the back door to Alex Rodriguez's inner sanctum. His name is Jim Fannin, who describes himself as a performance coach. Once a touring tennis pro, he's now a 54-year-old sports savant who turned his psychology and marketing degree at East Tennessee State into a career, since 1977, as a motivational consultant for professional athletes and corporate executives.

title: Privatizing Warfare
description: It's one thing for the military to outsource food and laundry services to private firms, as it started doing aggressively in the 1990's, but it's quite another to outsource the actual fighting. That is what the Pentagon is perilously close to doing in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHMAN, JOAN F.
description: RICHMAN--Joan F., 64. Died April 3 at her home in Bucks County, PA. Beloved sister of Judith R. Saidel (Peter). Loving aunt of Andrew (Toshiko), Lisa and Jonathan. Join her family to celebrate her life with joy at The Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East 65 St. on April 22, 6:30-8:30PM. Contributions may be made to Opera Theatre of Saint Louis, PO Box 191910, St Louis MO 63119

title: Police in Jordan Kill 4 It Says Plotted Against It and the U.S.
description: At least four militants were killed in a firefight yesterday as the Jordanian police continued to round up suspects in what authorities have described as a major plot to bomb American and Jordanian government targets, according to officials in Amman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOKE, ELWOOD
description: COOKE--Elwood. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Elwood Cooke. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Richard J. Bronstein, Secy

title: The Nicest Terrorist I Ever Met
description: When I interviewed Abdel Aziz Rantisi a year and a half ago in Gaza, the interpreter who accompanied me made one request: that our cab remain parked conspicuously in front of his apartment, in a quiet and pleasant residential neighborhood there. That way, she figured, the pilots of any Israeli helicopters hovering nearby would see there were journalists visiting, and would hold off killing Dr. Rantisi, then the chief spokesman for the militant group Hamas, at least until we'd left.

title: Ford's First-Quarter Earnings Up More Than 100%
description: DETROIT, April 21  The Ford Motor Company more than doubled its first-quarter earnings, driven by cost cuts and favorable pricing trends.

title: Belfour Makes the Difference for the Leafs
description: In terms of health, the Toronto Maple Leafs did not match up well against the Ottawa Senators, whom they eliminated Tuesday night from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, C. VIRGIL
description: MARTIN--C. Virgil. The Board and staff of the Mertz Gilmore Foundation note with sadness the passing of their friend, colleague, and mentor, Virgil Martin. His wisdom, integrity, and standard of responsible trusteeship helped set the course of the Foundation in its early years. His good cheer, encouragement, and counsel will be sorely missed.

title: Railroad Officials Blame Human Error in Crash of 2 Trains at Pennsylvania Station
description: The arithmetic underlying Pennsylvania Station is mind-bending: 1,005 trains a day, from three different railroads, barreling through seven tunnels, converging on just 21 tracks in one aging station, bursting at the seams.

title: G.M. Tops Expectations, but Profits Decline
description: General Motors reported a decline in first-quarter profit on Tuesday, but the results were better than expected, driven by a record performance in its financing business, surging Asian auto sales and a shrinking tax bill in the United States.

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TO BUY PANAMSAT FROM DIRECTV
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company agreed to buy the satellite operator PanAmSat Corporation from Rupert Murdoch's DirecTV Group and other investors for $3.53 billion, or $23.50 a share, the companies said yesterday. PanAmSat mainly leases satellites to TV networks that use them to deliver programming to local cable TV systems and broadcast stations. Kohlberg Kravis, which is based in New York, outbid competitors including the Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group. Kohlberg Kravis will also assume PanAmSat's $750 million in net debt. DirecTV's chief executive, Chase Carey, said in February that he might sell PanAmSat, based in Wilton, Conn., to focus on DirecTV's consumer pay-television business.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Archbishop Rebukes Seton Hall Students
description: The Archbishop of Newark, the Rev. John J. Myers, criticized law students at Seton Hall, a Roman Catholic institution, for honoring a Supreme Court justice and a federal judge, both of whom the archbishop said favor abortion. It was the latest in a series of rebukes by Catholic clerics, including some against Catholic officeholders, including Senator John Kerry. In a statement to appear today on the front page of the archdiocesan newspaper, Archbishop Myers criticized the students' invitation to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, and an award in her name to Judge Maryanne Trump Barry. A Seton Hall spokeswoman, Natalie M. Thigpen, said the award was ''a serious lapse.'' Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: SUMMER JAZZ
description: Correction Appended

title: STARWOOD CAPITAL OFFERS TO BUY RACETRACK OWNER
description: Investors led by the Starwood Capital Group, the hotel operator, said they would offer 308.6 million ($558.1 million) for the racetrack owner Wembley, edging out a bid made earlier this month by a casino group, MGM Mirage. Wembley, which owns dog tracks in England and in the United States, and a horse track in Colorado, is attracting attention because of a proposal by British lawmakers to ease rules for gambling sites. Starwood, along with the casino developers Kerzner International and the Waterford Group, have offered 2.4 percent more than MGM. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Merrill Lynch Firm Is Told It Must Pay In Sexual Bias Case
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, discriminated against women who worked as stockbrokers, according to a panel of arbitrators that has awarded $2.2 million to one of them.

title: From Out of the West, A Wok Slinger, Searing the Beef
description: SLANTED DOOR, Charles Phan's immensely popular Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco, which recently reopened in new quarters in the Ferry Building, has featured a dish called shaking beef ''since Day 1,'' Mr. Phan said. It is clearly the restaurant's most popular dish: ''There are nights we sell 60 orders of it,'' he said.

title: Schilling's Interlocking Letters Are More Than They Seem
description: At first glance, it appeared that Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, left, was wearing a Yankees hat, of all things, while watching the Bruins play the Montreal Canadiens in Game 7 of their National Hockey League playoff series on Monday night. But a closer examination of the cap logo reveals that the logo is not ''NY'' as in New York, but ''YH'' as in Yankees hater. And the colors of the hat are red and blue, Red Sox colors.

title: Chief Executive of Janus Capital Steps Down
description: The Janus Capital Group said yesterday that its chief executive, Mark B. Whiston, was resigning and that he would be succeeded by the chairman as the company struggles to stanch billions of dollars in redemptions by investors in its mutual funds.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2nd Man Enters Plea In Missile Scheme
description: A man arrested in an investigation of what prosecutors call a conspiracy to smuggle shoulder-fired missiles that can down commercial aircraft has pleaded guilty to a lesser charge and plans to testify against the central figure in the conspiracy, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Moinuddeen Ahmed Hameed, an Indian citizen living in the United States illegally, was arrested in August. Yesterday he pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiracy to operate an unlicensed money-transmitting business. Matthew C. McCue (NYT)

description: OSBORNE--Stanley deJongh. A service to celebrate the life of Stanley deJongh Osborne will be held at St. James, 865 Madison Ave, Saturday, April 24, at 10:00 A.M. Donations instead of flowers to: NY-Presbyterian Hospital, Development Office, Box 123, 525 East 68th Street, NY, NY 10021.

title: THE VIRTUAL ORCHESTRA (CONTINUED)
description: The Opera Company of Brooklyn has formally withdrawn from a recent agreement with the Broadway musicians union that would have prevented the opera from using a so-called virtual orchestra machine, a sophisticated synthesizer that closely approximates the sound of real musicians. Jay D. Meetze, the company's founder and principal conductor, said in a statement that he objected to efforts by the union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, to dictate which instruments he could use. ''The union has gone too far by trying to take away my choices for artistic expression,'' Mr. Meetze said. In response, David Lennon, the president of Local 802, said his union had filed an unfair labor practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board against the opera company. ''We stand firm that this machine is not a musical instrument,'' he said. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPHAEL, ALAN H.
description: RAPHAEL--Alan H. The Board and staff of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged (JASA) express their profound sorrow at the passing of Alan H. Raphael. Mr. Raphael has been a supporter of JASA for many years and his children have followed in his footsteps. We extend our condolences to his daughter, Cathy Raphael, and her brother, John Raphael-who has provided key support to assist our most vulnerable clients for many years. David M. Warren, President Aileen Gitelson, CEO

title: Bush, Powell and the Rush to War
description: To the Editor:

title: Why They Hate Us, Really
description: For the last five weeks I have been traveling through the Middle East, meeting diplomats, officials, policy experts, military leaders, students and ordinary citizens. I learned something very important: the greatest single cause of anti-Americanism in the Middle East today is not the war in Iraq; more surprisingly, it is not even American support for Israel, per se. Rather, it is a widespread belief that the United States simply does not care about the rights or needs of the Palestinian people.

title: Russia to Run 2,500-Mile Oil Pipeline In East Asia
description: A planned pipeline would stretch from Tayshet in the Irkutsk region, a former gulag hub in Russia's Siberian expanse, to Nakhodka, a port on the Sea of Japan, bringing much-needed oil to countries in East Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENBERG, HERMAN
description: ROSENBERG--Herman. April 21, 1902 - April 1, 1998 Missing you today, as I do every day. Happy birthday. Carla

title: Modified-Food Labeling Begins in Europe
description: ALL food sold in the European Union with genetically modified ingredients must now say so on the label, under rules that went into effect on Sunday. Any restaurant serving genetically engineered food must identify it on the menu.

title: Miscellany
description: The Miss Universe Organization, New York, a partnership between Donald J. Trump and the NBC network, named JAMI Charity Brands in New York, which helps match nonprofit groups with corporate benefactors, to help secure sponsors for causes supported by the Miss Universe, Miss USA and Miss Teen USA competitions. NBC is part of General Electric.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMAN, HAROLD, ESQ.
description: NEWMAN--Harold, Esq. Loving husband of Racia ''Roni'' Jame, devoted father of Laurie Cortez and son-in-law Michael Cortez, adoring grandfather of Robert, Carli, Bobby and Abby. Died April 18, 2004.

title: To Deal, Bloomberg Had to Retreat on Pay, Productivity
description: The three-year deal that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached yesterday with the city's largest municipal union, District Council 37, fell far short of giving him everything he had sought, but it did give him one important victory.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: WEAPONS BOUND FOR U.S. ARE SEIZED Customs officials said they intercepted a ship carrying 8,000 Kalashnikov assault rifles and other machine guns headed for New York. The customs agency said the weapons belonged to a large unidentified American company in Georgia and had an estimated worth of more than $7 million. Officials found the weapons packed into three containers on a ship from Romania that docked at the port of Gioia Tauro. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: After a career that took him from kitchen to kitchen -- Scarabee, Layla and the Tonic, among them -- JOEY FORTUNATO , right, has found a home of his own. With MICHELE GATON , who was the manager of Coffee Shop, he has opened EXTRA VIRGIN , 259 West Fourth Street (Perry Street), an already busy little trattoria that fits the neighborhood like a glove. The menu roams the Mediterranean, as do the olive oils, a different one poured each evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHILL, RABBI ABRAHAM
description: CHILL--Rabbi Abraham. Age 92. Resident of Jerusalem, Israel. Husband of the late Libbie. Survived by children Daniel (Vivian), Deanne Shapiro (Leonard), sister Teme Goldman, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Torah scholar, author of numerous books on Torah, musmach of Lomza Yeshiva, Petach Tikva, first Jewish chaplain at West Point Military Academy, served in US Army during WWII, Rabbi in Nashville, TN and Providence, RI. Shiva will be observed in Israel.

title: Norris McWhirter, 78, Dies; A Matchless Record Keeper
description: Norris D. McWhirter, one of the founders of Guinness World Records, the ubiquitous reference work that keeps track of superlatives both serious and frivolous, from sports records and tall buildings to the oldest licensed driver (104) and the farthest a person has walked with a milk bottle balanced on his head (80.96 miles), died yesterday at his home in Wiltshire in southern England. He was 78.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the popularity of hot dogs and other quick foods in Chicago incorrectly described the all-beef hot dogs served in New York by Katz's Delicatessen and the Gray's Papaya chain. Their hot dogs are not kosher.

title: It Helps To Distress The Noodles
description: SEAFOOD and bean combinations can be found all over Italy, but rarely elsewhere -- why so few others have caught on to this wonderful pairing is beyond me. The dishes have much in common with cassoulet and myriad other meat and bean combinations, not only in the core marriage but also in the strength of the garlic and the abundance of good olive oil, which more than makes up for the absence of the duck fat in cassoulet.

title: Editorial Observer; Where the Wide Benches of Southwestern Montana Spill Into the Rivers
description: As a description of landscape, the word ''bench'' doesn't mean much in the Northeast. The terrain is simply too tangled and wooded, the views too short. But the word comes into its own in Montana, especially in the southwestern part of the state. The mountains there dominate the view, of course, their ranges rising almost navely against the sky: the Madison, the Gravelly, the Tobacco Root. They seem, at first, like the largest part of the landscape. But where the mountains stop, the benches begin, great alluvial fans that shelve outward from the base of the mountains to the middle of a broad shallow valley. There, a river is trenching its way between the benches.

title: Editor of USA Today Resigns; Cites Failure Over Fabrications
description: Karen Jurgensen, the top editor of USA Today since 1999, resigned abruptly Tuesday evening, citing her failure to intercept what were apparently fabrications in articles by Jack Kelley, who was the newspaper's star foreign correspondent.

title: Breaking Molds, and Then Designing New Ones
description: NOT long before he graduated from Harvard with a master's degree in architecture, J. Max Bond Jr., whose firm Davis Brody Bond was named associate architect for the ground zero memorial last week, recalls being chummily taken aside by one of the gurus of Harvard's architecture program and receiving an unfriendly shock. The professor advised him to exit the architect business before he'd even dipped his toe in it. Talent and intelligence weren't his liability; toe color was.

title: NextWave Pact With F.C.C. Ends Airwave Dispute
description: The government forged an agreement with NextWave Telecom Inc. on Tuesday that will free valuable airwave licenses vital to improving the nation's cellphone system.

title: VETERANS AS WRITERS
description: Americans who have seen military service in Iraq and Afghanistan will have the opportunity to describe their war experiences through a new program financed by the National Endowment for the Arts. The program, ''Operation Homecoming,'' will provide writing workshops led by well-known authors like Tom Clancy, above, and Jeff Shaara, including some who are veterans, at seven military installations around the country, Dana Gioia, the chairman of the endowment, said yesterday. In partnership with the Department of Defense, and sponsored by the Boeing Company, the workshops to help turn stories and reflections of returning troops into fiction, verse, letters, essays, memoirs or personal journals. Some workshops will be held at bases overseas, but they have not been announced. To provide guidance, the endowment will distribute an ''Operation Homecoming'' CD, including interviews and readings by noted authors, including Shelby Foote, who have dealt with war in their writings. The best examples will be published in 2005 in an anthology to be made available at military installations, schools and libraries and sold in bookstores. The project will accept submissions through Dec. 31. ELIZABETH OLSON

title: Actors' Alchemy, From Raw Script To Final Bow
description: Creative people of all kinds, but perhaps especially those involved in performing, love to talk about process, that mystery-shrouded road between the raw material of experience and the high finish of a work of art. Process is so fascinating, to insiders and outsiders, because it is hard to convey. Interviews with actors, directors and writers tend to devolve into truisms and abstractions, while attempts to dramatize artists at work often suffer from melodrama and foreshortening, missing the small details, the trial and error, and the sheer tedium of artistic labor.

description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Supreme Court appeared distinctly unreceptive Tuesday to the Bush administration's argument that the federal courthouse doors must remain closed to the foreign detainees at the Guantanamo Bay naval base in Cuba.

description: O'NEILL--Leo. The Board of Directors and staff of the Alliance for Downtown New York mourn the loss of our Director, colleague and friend, Leo C. O'Neill. As the President of Standard & Poor's, a member of the Downtown Alliance and a Downtown resident, Leo was an intelligent, thoughtful and committed advocate for Downtown New York. His tireless dedication and sincere devotion to our community will always be remembered. We will miss him dearly and send our heartfelt condolences to the entire O'Neill family. Robert R. Douglass Chairman Carl Weisbrod, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit At Akzo
description: The pharmaceutical and chemicals company Akzo Nobel said increased paint sales helped to offset a slowdown in its medical division and reported a first-quarter profit of 133 million euros ($159.9 million), down 4.3 percent from the period a year earlier. First-quarter sales fell 4.5 percent, to 3.14 billion euros. Akzo Nobel has been struggling to stabilize its pharmaceutical unit after the release in the United States of generic competitors to its best-selling anti-depressant Remeron. Its pharmaceutical sales fell 7.1 percent, to 821 million euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Delay of Gay Marriage Is Sought
description: Seeking to keep same-sex marriages from taking place as scheduled on May 17, the head of a conservative Roman Catholic group filed a petition on Tuesday asking the state's highest court to keep gay marriages from occurring for at least two and a half years.

title: Bush-Cheney Interview on 9/11 Is Set
description: President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney will appear together on April 29 before the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, an official said Tuesday.

title: Italy Considers Tax Breaks as Way to Help Ailing Alitalia
description: As it hovered near bankruptcy, Alitalia, Italy's flagship air carrier, gave some hints on Tuesday of a turnaround plan that it referred to as a ''hypothesis,'' as the government considered offering tax breaks to the entire airline industry.

title: Kennedys Without Tears
description: A stunning new history coming in May about the relationship between Jacqueline and John F. Kennedy came floating into my office. I immediately flipped though ''Grace and Power: The Private World of the Kennedy White House'' by Sally Bedell Smith to see if it included ''the lunch'' of March 22, 1962.

description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston announced plans on Tuesday to sell much of its headquarters complex, including the ornate archbishop's residence, to adjacent Boston College for more than $100 million.

title: Malone Has Starring Role in 'As the Lakers' World Turns'
description: When someone turns this Los Angeles Lakers season into a book or, even more fitting, a mini-series, Karl Malone will be the most likable character, the wise old man in the corner of the locker room who has tried to keep things from getting out of hand. He has pulled aside players for talks, picked up the slack with reporters when teammates have run away and smiled at the distractions when no one else has.

title: Bundesbank Likely to Get A Professor At the Helm
description: The German government, moving swiftly to get past a scandal at one of its most revered institutions, is expected to nominate an academic economist with no party ties or central banking experience to succeed Ernst Welteke as the president of the Bundesbank.

description: John Kerry's renewed emphasis on criticizing President Bush for his push to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling has attracted some criticism of its own  from a fellow Democrat.

title: Corner Bistro With Backbone
description: SOME restaurants begin with large ambitions and ride the wave of ''can't get a reservation for a month'' novelty for a while before they figure out that their most reliable business comes from people in the neighborhood, who need to be cultivated. Cafe Luxembourg and Ouest both made this transition well. Many more places failed to adapt and, when all the publicity faded away, went out of business.

title: Parents Agree to Cooperate in Fatal Accident
description: The parents of an elementary school teacher who has admitted involvement in a hit-and-run crash on March 31 that killed two young brothers avoided jail on Tuesday by vowing in court that they would tell prosecutors what they knew about the accident.

title: EYEGLASSES GIANTS VIE TO BUY OWNER OF PEARLE VISION
description: The Cole National Corporation, owner of Pearle Vision optical stores, said yesterday that it would negotiate with Moulin International Holdings Ltd., which made an unsolicited offer on Monday to buy Cole for $451 million, or $25 a share. Moulin's bid exceeds the offer of $401 million, or $22.50 a share, from another maker of eyeglasses, Luxottica Group. Moulin, based in Hong Kong, makes eyewear under the Enrico Coveri, Elizabeth Arden and Giordano brand names. Cole shareholders had been slated to vote on the Luxottica deal yesterday but the meeting was postponed to an unspecified date. Luxottica is based in Milan.

title: Poetry and Money
description: To the Editor:

title: A Coffee Shop With Sweet Ancestry
description: Michael and Ann Warren, the owners of Cupcake Cafe, have opened Casa Cupcake, 545 Ninth Avenue (40th Street) an oasis for coffee. But they do not serve cupcakes. ''You can get them at Cupcake Cafe across the street,'' Mr. Warren said. ''We have biscotti and doughnuts, things we like better with coffee.'' A generous $3 cappuccino, right, is topped with a head of creamy froth that would do a glass of Guinness proud. La Colombe Torrefaction supplies the espresso beans. Right now the cafe's look suggests an archaeological dig, with patches of exposed brick and marble slabs as counters and tables.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Two Children Stabbed To Death
description: Two children, 10 years old and 15 months old, were stabbed to death early yesterday when an argument in a public housing complex flared into a knife attack, the police said. Five adults, including three police officers, were also injured. The police said the attacks followed a dispute between Robert Swain, 23, of New London and his former girlfriend, Jennifer Turner, 20. Mr. Swain was charged with fatally stabbing Josiah Swain, his son with Ms. Turner, and Ms. Turner's sister, Emmaline, the 10-year-old. The police said that Mr. Swain also stabbed Ms. Turner and a neighbor, Rita Whitehead, who attempted to aid Ms. Turner. Both women were hospitalized with serious injuries. Three officers were hurt when Mr. Swain resisted arrest, the police said. The charges against Mr. Swain include capital murder, which is punishable by the death penalty. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: The Lost Father
description: As the daughter of a soldier killed in action, I'm worried sick about this generation of war-torn families. I read the growing casualty list from Iraq and think about the number of children who are being left fatherless -- or motherless. I consider the fourth grader who stands alone at recess trying to recall her father's voice; the weeping bride who walks the aisle alone, wishing with every step that her father was there to escort her; and all those babies not yet born, their memories not yet formed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about the decision by the new government of Spain to withdraw its troops from Iraq misstated the name of the television program on which Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, said she was concerned that terrorists could ''draw the wrong lesson from Spain.'' It is ''Fox News Sunday,'' not ''Fox News.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, SR. MARY ELIZABETH
description: KELLY--Sr. Mary Elizabeth (Sister Dolores Mary), beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mount St. Vincent, died Tuesday, April 20, 2004. Sister Mary Elizabeth was President of Elizabeth Seton College from 1966 to 1974. From 1977 to 1993, she held various administrative positions at the College, and after the merger with Iona College, until Elizabeth Seton closed in 1993. She is survived by a niece, several nephews and cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mount Saint Vincent, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY, on Wednesday, 1-8 P.M. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10 A.M., at the Immaculate Conception Chapel at Mount Saint Vincent. Interment to follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, New York 10471.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: JUDGE ORDERS ARREST OF EX-PRESIDENT A federal judge issued an international arrest order for former President Carlos Menem, who failed to return from Chile to appear in court in connection with a graft case, a court spokesman said. The authorities want to question him in connection with the alleged embezzlement of up to $60 million in the construction of two prisons. Mr. Menem's 1989-1999 presidency was marred by allegations of corruption, and he is the subject of several investigations. He has also been summoned to appear in court this week for allegedly failing to declare a Swiss bank account. (Reuters)

description: The Pentagon has drawn up plans to send fresh troops quickly to Iraq in case it decides it must keep 135,000 or more American soldiers deployed beyond July, senior officials said Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column yesterday about the departure of the president of the Burberry Group, Thomas J. O'Neill, misstated the name of the company he is joining. It is Harry Winston, not Henry Winston.

title: Commercials have expanded into short films with the story as the focus rather than the product.
description: THE steamroller called branded entertainment, in which advertisers show their wares in longer-form narrative films instead of commercials, is barreling ahead with new productions from marketers like Visa and Sears, Roebuck & Company. New entries into what some call ''advertainment'' moreover, are pushing the genre beyond its early home online and onto television, movie screens and DVD's.

title: North Atlantic Storms Delay Arrival of the Queen Mary 2
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAUB, REVEREND ARMIN
description: TRAUB -- Reverend Armin. On April 19, 2004. Former assistant Rabbi at Shore Park Jewish Center, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn for over 30 years. Beloved husband of Yetti for over 55 years. Devoted father of Marcel, Pepi Yakirevich and Elisa. Cherished grandfather of Yonathan, Yael, Noah, Michael and Naomi. Loving brother of Irene Weiss, David Karmi, Menachem Karmi and the late William, Moshe, Hannah Fuchs and Rose. Services Wednesday 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: EL PASO GETS BETTER DEAL FOR SALE OF GULFTERRA INTEREST
description: The El Paso Corporation, the natural gas pipeline owner, would get an additional $370 million for the sale of its investment in GulfTerra Energy Partners under a new agreement with the buyer, Enterprise Products Partners. El Paso, which is based in Houston, agreed to accept a 9.9 percent stake in the general partner that manages the combined company, rather than the 50 percent stake announced in December, El Paso said. El Paso's cash proceeds from the sale would rise to $1.35 billion under the new agreement. Enterprise Products, also based in Houston, agreed on Dec. 15 to buy GulfTerra for $3.23 billion in cash and units and assume $1.7 billion in debt.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: New Operations Chief For Ferry
description: Seven months after a deadly accident claimed the lives of 11 passengers aboard a Staten Island ferry, the Department of Transportation announced the appointment of a chief operations officer. Capt. James C. DeSimone, a Bronx native and vice president of operations for New York Water Taxi, will assume the post in early May. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Slips
description: German investor confidence fell for a fourth month in April, reflecting concern over the sluggish economic recovery. The ZEW Center for European Economic Research reported the decline in its index measuring the sentiment of institutional investors and analysts. The index has fallen every month since hitting a three-and-a-half year high in December. According to Germany's central bank, the economy grew 0.25 percent in the first quarter, at about the same level as in the two previous quarters. In reaction to the ZEW report, the euro fell nearly 1 percent against the dollar. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Arguments on Detainees at Guantnamo
description: Following are excerpts from arguments yesterday before the Supreme Court on whether the detainees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, are entitled to access to federal court, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. John J. Gibbons, a retired federal judge, argued for the detainees and Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson for the government. For a full transcript click here .

title: Rookie Can't Hold Lead, But Yankees Pull Away
description: The starting pitcher is often the last player to arrive in the clubhouse, but Alex Graman came to U.S. Cellular Field before most of his new teammates Tuesday, more than three and a half hours before the game. Batting practice was canceled because of rain, and Graman paced the clubhouse, looking calm but understanding what he was about to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASKY, IRVING (UNCLE SONNY)
description: LASKY--Irving (Uncle Sonny). Age 95. Beloved and cherished Uncle. A quiet, thoughtful man with a great facility to ''fix'' things with his Golden Hands. Active on a daily basis. Anxious, willing and able to help others in need. A rare, sweet human being who will be missed by his nephews and niece and their families and friends. Jerome and Maxine Belson Victor and Arlene Belson Janet Lipsky Joel and Lois Heller

title: Bush Firm on Iraq Policy as Senators Question the Costs
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  President Bush said today that the latest carnage in Iraq would not lessen the United States' commitment to bring peace and freedom to that country. But some lawmakers questioned whether he had been forthright about the costs of that mission.

title: Bush Visit Buoys Pataki On Antiterror Legislation
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who has been battling for two years to get the State Legislature to pass a set of laws that he says will help combat terrorism, sought to bolster his case on Tuesday in the refracted light of a presidential visit.

title: Attacks on Basra Extend Violence to a Calm Region
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 21  The suicide attacks in Basra on Wednesday shattered a week of relative calm in Iraq, bringing anger, mourning and upheaval to a mostly Shiite southern city that has been spared the worst of the violence in the yearlong American occupation.

title: The Real Nuclear Danger
description: In the summer of 2001, there was a spike in Al Qaeda ''chatter'' and mounting evidence that a terror strike was imminent. But without precise details, it was difficult to get the attention of top policy makers or the public -- until it was too late.

title: Martin Answers Mutombo's Elbow
description: Kenyon Martin was never very interested in the back-and-forth talk that floated across the Hudson River the past three days.

title: Israeli Who Revealed Nuclear Secrets Is Freed
description: ASHKELON, Israel, April 21  After 18 years behind bars for revealing Israeli nuclear secrets, a defiant Mordechai Vanunu headed out of prison today a partly free man, flashing the victory sign and declaring he was proud of what he had done.

title: INTERPUBLIC PAYS $93 MILLION TO QUIT RACING ACCOUNT
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, the advertising company, will pay $93 million to end a contract to promote the British Grand Prix, another step toward exiting its unprofitable auto-racing business. The company, which was bound under the contract until 2015, will be released after July's Formula One race, Interpublic said. Interpublic, based in New York, is trying to withdraw from motor sports in a bid to return to profitability. The company has not posted a profit since 2002, and its accounting is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Real Barbecue, but It's Not From Kansas
description: FORGET Pearson's Texas BBQ and Daisy May's BBQ USA and all the rest of the pretenders. New Yorkers can fuss and rage all they want about why they cannot find real barbecue in the city, but it has been here all the time, its smoky aroma wafting up right past closed noses.

title: Washington Memo; In the Real Reality TV, the C.I.A.'s Chief Is the Survivor
description: As director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet has spent much of the last six weeks being sharply questioned on Capitol Hill and before the Sept. 11 commission about failures on his watch.

title: A Fashion Idol's Odyssey From Punk to Prosperity; Museum Celebrates a Designer Who Shocked Britons
description: In each of her major roles, Vivienne Westwood has matched the mood of the times. When she was punk symbol in the angry 1970's, wearing clothes festooned with spikes and safety pins and T-shirts emblazoned with ''Destroy,'' Britons delighted in being shocked by her. Now, as fashion idol of a prosperous new millennium, her energy given over to lavish historical designs, she is celebrated as a pillar of the creative establishment.

title: After Tree Kills Couple, A Search For Answers
description: Officials with the New York State Department of Transportation were still trying on Tuesday to find out why a tree fell onto the Saw Mill River Parkway here in calm weather on Monday evening, killing a couple as they were driving home with their infant daughter.

title: Bush Gives Kerry a Free Lunch, Sort Of
description: The new polls must have President Bush feeling pretty confident. There he was this afternoon, speaking before hundreds of editors and publishers of the nation's newspapers  people with ready access to printing presses and barrels of ink  and he passed up the opportunity to get in a few licks at John Kerry .

title: Judge Blocks Navy's Plan For Airfield Near Flyway
description: A federal judge in North Carolina has ordered the Navy to halt its efforts to create a new landing field for training pilots five miles from a large migratory bird refuge, pending further court rulings.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Weapons Bound For U.S. Are Seized
description: Customs officials said they intercepted a ship carrying 8,000 Kalashnikov assault rifles and other machine guns headed for New York. The customs agency said the weapons belonged to a large unidentified American company in Georgia and had an estimated worth of more than $7 million. Officials found the weapons packed into three containers on a ship from Romania that docked at the port of Gioia Tauro. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MITCHELL, CAROL SPENCER
description: MITCHELL--Carol Spencer. 50, passed away at her home in Croton-on-Hudson on April 15, 2004, following a long courageous battle with breast cancer. A photojournalist, writer, and multi-media producer, she spent over 17 years as a member of the foreign press corps, covering the Middle East, North Africa and the Caribbean, as well as Central and South America. Her photographs have appeared on the covers of Time and Newsweek; she worked extensively for both publications. She also traveled on special assignments for U.S. News and World Reports, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, Newsday, The Philadelphia Enquirer and numerous European publications. She is survived by her beloved husband, Brian Mitchell, their son Sam; her sisters: Ellen Susman, of Houston, and Susan Spencer Goldstein, of Montclair; and her parents Babette Williams of Gainesville, FL and Gordon Spencer of Belle Mead, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations in Carol's name be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Breast Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, NY NY 10087, Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam Inc., 100 South Bedford Rd, Mt Kisco NY 10549 or the Caring Committee of Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glendale Rd, Croton-onHudson, New York 10520.

title: A Texas Bid to Shift School Financing to 'Sin Taxes'
description: How much money Texas spends to teach children reading, writing and arithmetic may soon depend in part on how successful women like Vanity, Destiny and Rio of the Yellow Rose, a topless bar in this state capital, are in attracting customers.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Judge Halts Same-Sex Marriage Licenses
description: A judge ordered Multnomah County to stop issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples, but at the same time ordered the state to recognize the 3,000 licenses that have been issued. The county, which includes Portland, starting issuing the licenses March 3 and was the last jurisdiction in the country still issuing them. The, judge, Frank L. Bearden of Circuit Court, said a state law that limits marriage to a man and a woman could violate the State Constitution, but he said only the Legislature and the State Supreme Court could settle the issue. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Cheney Addresses Anti-Abortion Group
description: Five days before a major march for abortion rights is expected in the nation's capital to protest the Bush administration's actions, Vice President Dick Cheney rallied the administration's allies in the anti-abortion movement Tuesday night.

title: Big Talk, No Action as Knicks Go Quietly
description: The Knicks, models of softness and figures of sympathy after Sunday's embarrassing loss to the Nets, vowed to show up for Game 2 Tuesday night with clinched fists. It took them less than three minutes to show that they were not all talk.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Eurotunnel's Revenue Falls
description: Eurotunnel, which owns the Channel Tunnel and whose shareholders voted out board members this month, said operating revenue fell in the first quarter, the fifth consecutive quarterly decline. Sales fell 3.5 percent, to $227 million. The French-British company has lowered prices as it faces competition from ferries and discount airlines. Eurotunnel said the number of cars and coaches using the tunnel fell while lower prices offset a 7 percent rise in truck traffic. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Arguments on Detainees at Guantnamo
description: Following are excerpts from arguments yesterday before the Supreme Court on whether the detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, are entitled to access to federal court, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. John J. Gibbons, a retired federal judge, argued for the detainees and Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson for the government. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/washington.

title: Chronicler Of Juicy Details Of Officialdom
description: For months on end, he moves in the shadows, leaving no fingerprints, making no noise. Then, every couple of years or so, Bob Woodward produces a book that sets official Washington abuzz over juicy details of recent history that his competitors might have killed to know at the time.

title: Campaign Plans to Release All of Kerry's Available Military Records From Vietnam
description: Aides to Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign said on Tuesday that they would release all of his military records, including evaluations by his Navy commanders, a day after the campaign had refused to make the documents public.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Ratings Cut
description: Two credit rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's, cut their debt ratings on the Russian oil company Yukos, citing concerns that the company may be forced into insolvency if the company has to pay a $3.5 billion tax penalty. The downgrade reflects ''concerns about the increasing risk of Yukos losing ownership rights over its crucial cash-generating subsidiaries and uncertainties regarding liquidity,'' an S.&P. analyst, Elena Anankina, said. ''If Yukos loses the tax case, the company may find itself under the threat of forced sale of core assets, insolvency procedures or effective nationalization of its assets,'' she said. The Russian tax ministry sued Yukos in December for back taxes, but Yukos has challenged the claim. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Columbia Buys Sites and Assures Neighbors
description: Columbia University has aggressively moved to buy the brick warehouses and industrial buildings near the Hudson River in West Harlem where it wants to build a new campus, even as it does a delicate dance with community groups that view the school's real estate ambitions warily.

title: Mayor Reaches Accord With Largest City Union
description: The Bloomberg administration and the city's largest municipal union reached a tentative contract last night that would increase the wages of 121,000 city workers by roughly 5 percent over three years while requiring newly hired workers to accept lower starting salaries.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Voting Begins
description: India began the world's largest democratic exercise, carrying out the first round of voting in national elections that will involve 675 million voters and take three weeks to complete. Surveys of voters leaving the polls indicated a victory for a coalition headed by Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, the leader of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party. Officials reported scattered violence with at least four people killed in five states. For the first time, electronic voting machines will be used by all voters across India. Final results will be declared on May 13. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Rodriguez's Dry Spells Never Last
description: Alex Rodriguez has been through worse, when he was 24 and playing out the string of a losing season with Seattle. In September 1999, Rodriguez had 5 hits in a stretch of 58 at-bats, finally breaking loose with a grand slam against Tampa Bay, in front of his mother.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review last Wednesday about BLT Steak, on East 57th Street in New York, incorrectly described the hanger steaks sold to the restaurant by the meat supplier DeBragga & Spitler. They are sold fresh, not dry aged.

title: A Magnificent Obsession That Starts With Rice and Fish
description: Correction Appended

title: There's a Price to Pay for Kidnapping Little Girls
description: ''Man on Fire,'' a new child-endangerment thriller starring Denzel Washington, was originally scheduled to open nationwide on Friday, but 20th Century Fox decided, rather suddenly, to push its New York and Los Angeles debut forward by two days. Perhaps the studio reasoned that it would be unfair to make moviegoers in the nation's two largest cities, their blood lust aroused by ''Kill Bill: Vol. 2'' and ''The Punisher,'' wait an entire week for the next round of righteous killing.

title: Security System At Hospitals Draws Scrutiny
description: New York City's 11 public hospitals have no common security system, no uniform method of screening visitors or restricting their access to certain wards of a hospital building. Background checks on new employees can vary widely from one institution to another.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Party Linked To I.R.A.
description: An international panel found that Northern Irish paramilitaries continue to carry out violent attacks and are heavily involved in criminal activities, including racketeering and smuggling. Because the panel, the Independent Monitoring Commission, also found that prominent politicians hold top positions in both the Irish Republican Army and its political wing, Sinn Fein, Britain will likely withhold $215,000 paid to Sinn Fein elected representatives. The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, called the commission report a sham. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; No Place for the War of Words
description: THIS was late in the second quarter last night, the Knicks desperately trying to hang with the Nets but falling behind, slip sliding away. Dikembe Mutombo, who had been the toughest of off-day talkers, was trying to power his way to the rim, backing up, dribbling once, twice, a third time.

title: Martins Suggests Modern Dance Troupe for Lincoln Center
description: Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, has suggested creating a modern dance company at Lincoln Center that would be the first new cultural organization there since Jazz at Lincoln Center was established in 1996. The company would replace New York City Opera as the ballet's co-tenant at the New York State Theater, if the opera troupe succeeds in building a new home at the World Trade Center site or elsewhere.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; Offices Rising Across From Library's Lions
description: Construction of a 27-story glass and concrete building has begun at the northeast corner of 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue -- on a lot vacant for more than a decade that once held the mansion in which Edith Wharton made her society debut in 1879.

title: No Yearlong Crews For Space Station
description: NASA has turned down Russia's request to extend the stay of the next International Space Station crew to a full year from six months but is open to the idea for later missions, the agency said Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINER, EARL ROY, PHD
description: MINER -- Earl Roy, PhD, passed away on April 17, 2004 at Meadow Lakes in Hightstown, NJ after a long illness. Earl was Townsend Martin, Class of 1917, Professor of English and Comparative Literature until his retirement from Princeton University in 2000. He specialized in early modern English literature, classical Japanese literature and comparative poetics. Adding to Earl's many publications and numerous books will be a recently completed new edition of Milton's Paradise Lost which will be published in the summer of 2004. He was President of the Milton Society of America, the American Society for 18th Century Studies and the International Comparative Literature Association. He was honored with Princeton's Behrman Award for distinguished achievement in the humanities in 1993. In 1994 he received the Order of the Rising Sun from the government of Japan in recognition of his ''special commitment'' to Japanese literature. Earl is survived by Jinny, his loving wife of 53 years, their children, Erik and Lisa, and grandson, Bryan. Also surviving are four brothers, Eldon, Arthur and David in Arizona and Norman in California. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Earl Miner Memorial Fund can be sent to the Comparative Literature Department, 133 East Pyne, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544. At Earl's request, there will be no service.

title: Top Managers Dismissed At ABC Entertainment
description: Just a month before ABC must present its fall lineup of programs to advertisers, the Walt Disney Company yesterday fired the entire top management structure at the entertainment division of the struggling network.
