title: Bush Draws Terrorism Law Into Campaign
description: The banner behind President Bush proclaimed, ''Protecting the Homeland.'' At his side were five law enforcement officials, including the United States attorney who prosecuted six terrorism suspects here last year. And for nearly an hour on Tuesday, Mr. Bush and the White House-picked group sharing a stage with him hailed the antiterrorism law enacted in the wake of the Sept. 11 acts, declaring that it was vital to protecting the nation.

title: Paramilitary Chief's Disappearance Clouds Colombian Talks
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 21 — Days after an assassination attempt on Carlos Castaño, the driving force of Colombia's right-wing paramilitary army, his disappearance has thrown peace talks between the paramilitaries and the government into a state of turmoil and threaten a cornerstone of President Álvaro Uribe's strategy to pacify the country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 22 Accused Of Mob Influence
description: In a quiet corner of the construction trade, mobsters created an elaborate structure of illegal influence, controlling unions and using violence and extortion to generate millions of dollars for themselves from building projects, federal officials charged yesterday. The mob, prosecutors charged, controlled part of the drywall industry, an essential part of nearly every major construction job. In a 225-page indictment unsealed yesterday, 22 people described as members and associates of the Genovese crime family were accused of racketeering, mail fraud, tax evasion, extortion and other offenses. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Sony Raises Profit Estimate for Year
description: The Sony Corporation on Tuesday raised its estimate of net profit by 60 percent for the fiscal year that just ended, citing favorable currency swings, a lower tax bill in the United States and a strong performance for its movie and finance businesses.

description: Judge Baltasar Garzn, who indicted Osama bin Laden and 34 others in September, has charged five more people with belonging to or supporting a Qaeda cell in Spain.

title: A Wry Outsider Determined to Endure, Against the Odds
description: The stage is a rectangle of camel-colored sand. A man stands before us in an orange cotton uniform, standard issue for prison inmates in the United States. But his voice, melodic yet percussive like a vibraphone, marks him as a foreigner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKAN, ROBERTA MAY
description: BARKAN--Roberta May, in Stanford, CA, April 18, 2004. Beloved wife of Paul Barkan of Palo Alto, CA. Loving mother of Jeremy Barkan (Lisa) of Jerusalem and David Barkan (Wendy) of Los Altos, CA. Devoted grandmother of Shachar, Haim, Rachel and Naomi Barkan. An inspiration to countless students. A recognized scholar, lecturer and author in Jewish Studies and Hebrew Literature, she served as Professor at SUNY, Purchase College. A recipient of an M.A. and Ph.D. from Columbia University and the SUNY Chancellor's Award for Excellence in Teaching. Funeral services were held in San Jose, CA and burial took place in Jerusalem, Israel.

description: SUTTER--Meyer. April 21, 1997. Always remembered with love

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Speedy Monarch
description: King Carl Gustav capped a day of go-carting by driving his yellow Porsche across southern Sweden at speeds up to 100 miles per hour, according to the newspaper Aftonbladet. With Queen Silvia at his side, the king sped 150 miles from Karlskoga to Stockholm as a convoy of security officers and Prince Carl Philip, in his own Porsche, struggled to keep up, witnesses said. A royal spokeswoman denied that the king's driving was ''insane,'' as Aftonbladet claimed in a front-page headline. In any case, the constitution prevents prosecution of the king. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: SBC Proposes a Higher but Uniform Rate for Rivals Using Its Lines
description: SBC Communications, the regional telephone giant, proposed yesterday that it permit its competitors to use its local phone network at a set, uniform price through the remainder of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VIESER, SUSAN S. (NEE: STOLP)
description: VIESER -- Susan S. (nee: Stolp). Long time resident of Larchmont on April 20, 2004. Beloved wife of William, loving mother of David and Evan, dear sister of David and Loren. Visiting at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. in Larchmont, NY on Wednesday 7-9 P.M. and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Memorial service Friday 1:30 P.M. at Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUGENSTEIN, WILLIAM C.
description: AUGENSTEIN--William C. It is with great sadness that Royal Pet Supplies announces the sudden passing of William (Billy) C. Augenstein, president and owner, on Sunday, April 18, 2004. Billy was born in New York on May 29, 1952. Billy is survived by his mother, Irene, brother Stephen, nieces Jennifer and Sara, and nephew Ryan. A memorial celebration of Billy's life will be held at the Huntington Hilton on Sunday, April 25, 2004, at 12:30 PM. There will be an opportunity for anyone wanting to ''say a few words'' or ''tell a brief story'' to help all of us come to grips with Billy's tragic passing. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the BideA-Wee Foundation, 410 East 38 St., New York, NY 10016, Attn: Donations. Billy Augenstein was bigger than life, a man of great vision, a remarkable leader, a true motivator and a close friend to all.

title: How to Navigate the Produce Aisle
description: Nearly 150 fruits and vegetables are explored in the ''Field Guide to Produce'' by Aliza Green (Quirk Books, $14.95), which is like a bird book in that it manages to be both fat and yet small enough to take on the hunt. It has color photographs and considers history, the seasons, storage and serving suggestions. I loved the tips. One was to trim the cores of radicchio and serve them like radishes. Another was to soak peeled baby carrots in water if they have dried out and whitened in the refrigerator.

description: Game and Drink

title: Memory Play: A Cathartic Can of Worms
description: When Martin Moran set out to write ''The Tricky Part,'' a one-man show playing Off Broadway, he knew he was going to disturb some people. The play is a true story about three years in his life, between the ages of 12 to 15, when Mr. Moran had a sexual relationship with an older man.

title: Clarett Turns to Supreme Court for Help
description: Maurice Clarett, the former Ohio State running back, asked the Supreme Court yesterday to lift an appeals court ruling that bars him from the N.F.L. draft this weekend.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Cellphone Profit
description: The country's largest cellphone operator, Telekomunikasi Selular, said that its net profit rose 52 percent to 4.24 trillion rupiah ($492 million) last year. The company, known as Telkomsel, said the number of subscribers increased 60 percent last year to 9.6 million, helping push revenue up 47 percent, to 11.15 trillion rupiah. Indonesia's largest operator, Telekomunikasi Indonesia, owns 65 percent of Telkomsel, with the remainder held by Singapore Telecommunications. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: US Airways Said to Be Seeking More Concessions
description: A day after the resignation of the chief executive of US Airways, the airline's board approved a framework yesterday for a streamlining program that includes labor concessions, people briefed on the board's action said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Whistle-Blower Bill Planned
description: Councilman David Yassky said yesterday that he would introduce a bill today that would allow people to sue businesses and individuals who defraud the New York City government. The bill, known as the False Claims Act, is based on a federal law that seeks to offer a financial incentive to so-called whistle-blowers by allowing them to keep part of any civil court judgment award. He said that the city currently paid millions of dollars a year in false claims for payroll, medical and construction expenses. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Bush, Powell and the Rush to War
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics and the Patriot Act
description: President Bush campaigned in Buffalo yesterday, wrapping himself in the Patriot Act and urging Congress to extend parts of the law that do not expire until the end of next year. The Patriot Act has always been a tempting bit of election-year politics, an easy way to seem tough on terrorism. But it also is bad law, and the president should be heeding calls from conservatives and liberals to remove provisions that trample on civil liberties.

title: Queenly Menus and Royal Views
description: On Sunday evening between 7:15 and 8:30 p.m., both the Queen Elizabeth 2 and the Queen Mary 2 are to sail down the Hudson and out to sea. It will be the QE2's farewell crossing, and the QM2's first transatlantic voyage to Southampton. At Steamer's Landing, a restaurant on the Hudson River just south of the World Financial Center at Liberty Street, Jan Fried, far left, one of the owners, has come up with a three-course dinner ($60 including a glass of wine but not tax or tip) featuring dishes from the QE2's menu. Reservations, from 6 to 8:15, (212) 432-1451.

title: Testimony in Williams Case Ends With Focus on Shotgun
description: Testimony in the Jayson Williams manslaughter trial ended on Tuesday after a gun expert called by the defense criticized prosecutors for letting a Browning Arms Company executive inspect Mr. Williams's 12-gauge shotgun in private.

title: 3 Car Bombings Kill 20 People In an Iraqi City
description: Three car bombs exploded in front of Iraqi police stations in the southern city of Basra on Wednesday morning, killing about 20 people and wounding more than 60, according to the police and witnesses.

title: Restrictions Possible On Beluga Caviar Trade
description: THE Fish and Wildlife Service yesterday declared the beluga sturgeon a threatened, but not endangered, species. The decision means that conservation measures must be enacted for the fish but does not require a ban on the import, export or sale of beluga caviar in this country.

title: Truce Lets Families Return To Falluja, a Few at a Time
description: A tenuous peace deal between the American occupation forces and the embattled city of Falluja got off to a slow and sometimes chaotic start on Tuesday. A handful of families managed to return home, hundreds of people trying to were stranded along the road and Iraqi security forces whose loyalty was suspect only days ago lined up to return to patrol.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Imam Arrested For Wife-Beating Remarks
description: The Interior Ministry said an Algerian-born Muslim cleric, Chirane Abdelkader Bouziane, was arrested and served with an expulsion order after he told the monthly Lyon Mag that the Koran authorized men to beat unfaithful wives as long as they were not struck in the face. His remarks provoked an uproar, including protests from French Muslim leaders. Mr. Bouziane, 52, who has lived in France since 1979 and is imam of a mosque in Venissieux, a Lyon suburb, was charged with violating a French law protecting human dignity. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: Crispin Porter Shines At Award Ceremonies
description: Agencies were recognized last night at two big awards presentations.

title: Thinking Out Loud at MGM
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald was working as a screenwriter for MGM when he sent a memo to the producer Hunt Stromberg on June 27, 1938, about the script for ''Infidelity,'' a movie that was to star Clark Gable, Gary Cooper, Joan Crawford and Franchot Tone. The film was later canceled because of its theme, adultery. Following is an excerpt from the memo, part of a cache of Fitzgerald papers recently acquired by the University of South Carolina.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about a sale of furniture designed by Wendell Castle misstated the price for an armchair that was pictured. It is $8,500; $2,500 is the price of a side chair in the sale.

title: Losing Our Edge?
description: I was just out in Silicon Valley, checking in with high-tech entrepreneurs about the state of their business. I wouldn't say they were universally gloomy, but I did detect something I hadn't detected before: a real undertow of concern that America is losing its competitive edge vis--vis China, India, Japan and other Asian tigers, and that the Bush team is deaf, dumb and blind to this situation.

title: Unhappy Tim Thomas Speaks
description: In his first public statements since bruising his back and ankle in a collision with the Nets' Jason Collins on Saturday, Tim Thomas on Wednesday accused Collins of hurting him on purpose, challenged his teammates and called the Nets' Kenyon Martin a fraud.

title: Arts Patron of Rare Violins Vanishes Before Arraignment
description: He is an inveterate raconteur, known to spin lush, if dubious, tales of chatting up Albert Einstein, discussing tropical fish with Emperor Hirohito and exchanging correspondence with Winston Churchill. And about the only thing more outsize than the stories he told was his generosity: this millionaire philanthropist, Herbert R. Axelrod, sold a collection of rare violins to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra last year at a substantial discount -- a gesture that prompted one headline writer to call him and his wife the Medici of the Meadowlands.

title: Higher Earnings Ease Fears of Increase in Interest Rates
description: The major stock indicators rose as higher-than-forecast earnings from companies including Motorola and Ford helped the market rebound from losses tied to concern that interest rates may increase.

title: High Point Market Opens on Nervous Note
description: AS the spring furniture market opens here today, furniture manufacturers are making contingency plans to reassure retail buyers in case the federal government decides to impose steep duties on Chinese-made wood bedroom furniture later this spring.

title: An Indecent Crackdown
description: As if the feds weren't already hounding Tony Soprano enough, Congress may soon try to clean up his language. The idea of extending broadcast TV's decency standards to cable channels like HBO is the worst -- and certainly the most constitutionally flawed -- of many censorial proposals being floated in Washington these days.

title: L.I. Driver, 82, Was Drunk, The Police Say
description: An 82-year-old Nassau County man whose sport utility vehicle collided on Tuesday with a minivan full of young soccer players on a Long Island highway, killing him and two of the children, had a level of alcohol in his system that was more than twice the legal limit, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Panel Toughening Stance On Impeachment Delays
description: Over in the Senate, away from the constant calculations about how long the House impeachment inquiry of Gov. John G. Rowland will last, how broad it will be and how much it will cost, Kevin B. Sullivan, the president pro tempore, has been doing some math of his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, TALIA
description: ROSENBERG--Talia. Born in Israel, late of New York City and East Hampton, suddenly passed away at the age of 60 on April 20, 2004. She will be profoundly missed by her numerous and international family of friends and Mooshie. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday, 11:15AM. Contributions may be made to Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons.

title: Suffolk County Police Find Body Of Woman Missing Since Feb. 27
description: A body believed to be that of a 23-year-old Long Island woman who disappeared nearly two months ago was found yesterday in a wooded area in Westhampton, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; Queens Is Better Than Manhattan for Jets-Olympics Facility
description: PLOPPING the Olympics in New York sounded like a bad idea, right from the start. Even when the Jets promised to subsidize part of the cost of the Olympic stadium, it still brought out my inner Nimby.

title: Establishment Candidates Defeat Challengers in Sierra Club Voting
description: After weeks of highly publicized warnings that anti-immigration outsiders were trying to take over the venerable Sierra Club, the club's members on Wednesday overwhelmingly supported all five candidates put forward by the group's formal nominating committee.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DANNENBERG, ELI MERCER
description: DANNENBERG--Eli Mercer. April 22, 1991 So wise, so sweet, so funny. A man of science who loved art. A man of integrity, courage and honor. Remembered today, and every day, with so much love. Janice, Linda, Paul and Bruce

title: Libraries Wired, and Reborn
description: THE low point came in 1997, a year before personal computers and the Internet came to the libraries of Terrebonne Parish, a swatch of bayou country in South Louisiana, where people make their living on the water, harvesting shrimp and crabs or servicing oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico. Four of the nine branch libraries had been shut down for lack of funds, and the main library, a dreary concrete-slab building that locals nicknamed ''the bomb shelter,'' needed repairs and books.

title: INSIDE
description: Kerry Heightens Attack

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASKER, BETTY ANN
description: LASKER--Betty Ann, 63, died in Burlington, VT April 20, 2004. Born in the Bronx, NY May 6, 1940. Daughter of Max and Gertrude Wasserman. Survived by her husband, Milton, two children, Seth and Cynthia, two grandchildren, Moriah and Alex, all of Burlington, sister, Bobby Minsky of Floral Park, NY, many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by a daughter, Abby Lasker, and a sister, Judith Katz. Services today in VT.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Cubans Sentenced In Hijacking
description: Six Cubans were sentenced to 20 to 24 years in federal prison for hijacking a passenger flight in Cuba in March 2003. The men were convicted of using knives and a hatchet to take control of a flight with 37 people on board from the Isle of Youth, off Cuba's southern coast, and divert it toward Florida. United States fighter jets intercepted the plane and escorted it to Key West. Alexis Norneilla Morales, whom the prosecution painted as the ringleader, received a 24-year sentence, as did his brother, Miakel Guerra Morales. Eduardo Javir Meja Morales, Yainer Olivares Samn, Neudis Infantes Hernndez and Alvens Aras-Izquierdo received 20 years, the minimum sentence for air piracy. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Better Pricing And Cost Cuts Raise Profit At Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said on Wednesday that its first-quarter earnings more than doubled, in large part because of cost cuts and favorable pricing trends.

title: At Fujitsu's Request, Japan Bars Samsung Screens
description: Responding to a request by Fujitsu, Japanese customs authorities on Wednesday began blocking imports of plasma display panels made by a Samsung Group affiliate in an escalating battle over patent rights between the world's top two makers of displays for flat-panel televisions.

title: If Brendel Were a Bagel, He Would Be an Everything
description: The question was, What kind of bagel would the author of ''Cursing Bagels,'' a new book of poems that casts Beethoven as a baker throwing a fresh batch of guess what into the oven, like? Cinnamon raisin? Sun-dried tomato? Pumpernickel? Plain?

title: Four Killed and 148 Wounded In a Suicide Bombing in Riyadh
description: A suicide bomber detonated a Chevrolet Blazer loaded with explosives in central Riyadh on Wednesday, shattering the facade of a police building, killing at least four people and wounding 148.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO., Stamford, Conn., said it had agreed to buy the closely held Box USA Holdings, Northbrook, Ill., as prices and demand for boxes rise. Analysts estimated the deal's worth at $300 million to $325 million.

title: Lieber Won't Be Rushed To Face the Red Sox
description: The Yankees' best option to face the Boston Red Sox on Sunday will pitch that day, but he will do it in Tampa, Fla., against the Class A Fort Myers Miracle. No matter how badly the Yankees would like Jon Lieber to face Pedro Martnez that day, they will not rush his comeback from a strained right groin muscle.

title: Michael Jackson Is Indicted On Child-Molesting Charges
description: A grand jury in Santa Barbara indicted Michael Jackson on Wednesday on charges of child molesting, making it a virtual certainty he will stand trial in a case brought by prosecutors in December, officials said.

title: Fighting Resumes in Falluja; Return of Families Is Halted
description: The fragile peace effort here threatened to collapse Wednesday as insurgents fired mortars and battled with the marines, forcing the American military to stop the return of families who had fled the fighting. At the same time, a crucial part of the peace deal -- the insurgents' promise to surrender their heavy weapons -- got off to an almost comically slow start.

title: Details; With a Tweak Here and There, a Custom Machine
description: WANT a bigger hard drive, more memory, a different monitor or a more robust video card in that new rig you're ordering? Most major computer makers offer a variety of components and configurations. You can also find special deals and promotions that change from time to time and extended technical support plans.

title: 9 Palestinians Killed by Israelis In Second Day of Gaza Fighting
description: Israeli troops in armored vehicles killed 9 Palestinians and wounded about 25 on Wednesday in a second day of running clashes in the northern Gaza Strip, officials from the two sides said.

description: Christa Giesecke noticed welcome signs of construction nearly two weeks ago inside a boarded-up town house a few doors east of the house in West Harlem where she has lived for four years.

description: A statewide Muslim civil rights group has called for a bias-crime investigation into vandalism at a mosque being built in Toms River.

title: Bush Isn't Surprised Americans Expect Attack
description: President Bush expressed no surprise on Wednesday that the majority of Americans think it is somewhat likely that there will be a terrorist attack in the United States before the November election, and he suggested that they had a reason to be concerned.

title: UTILITY OWNER SELLS STAKE IN FIBER OPTIC VENTURE
description: The Exelon Corporation, a utility owner, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its stake in a Philadelphia-area fiber optic system for $49 million to its partner in the venture, TelCove, which emerged from bankruptcy protection this month. The sale to TelCove, which is closely held and based in Cannonsburg, Pa., is expected to close in this quarter, Exelon said. The joint venture, Peco TelCove, provides local and long-distance calling and data services in southeastern Pennsylvania. Exelon is based in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMILOWITZ, MARTIN
description: SMILOWITZ--Martin, on April 21, 2004. Beloved husband of Marilyn Getzoff. Loving stepfather of Steven & Lisa and Barry & Cindy. Devoted grandfather of Corey, Eric, Marc, Matthew and Sara. Caring uncle of Debra, cousin and dear friend to many. Services Friday 10am at ''Gutterman's Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Loses Bid On Part-Internet Calls
description: The Federal Communications Commission rejected AT&T's bid to pay lower fees to local telephone companies for completing calls routed partially over the Internet, a victory for SBC Communications. By a 5-to-0 vote yesterday , the F.C.C. turned down AT&T's October 2002 request. The agency did not decide whether AT&T owes payments it has withheld from local phone carriers while the agency reviewed the matter. Any such claims will be decided on a case-by-case basis, an F.C.C. spokesman, David Fiske, said. The F.C.C. chairman, Michael K. Powell, who has said Internet phone service should be subject to few regulations, decided the AT&T calls are not different enough from conventional circuit-switched phone service. AT&T, trying to pare some of its $10.8 billion in annual access costs, has said the ''arcane'' fees discourage investment in Internet-based technology that benefits consumers.

title: Burlington Resources' Plans for Ecuador Run Into Opposition
description: Burlington Resources, a large independent energy company, has been seeking to drill for oil in a remote part of the Ecuadorean Amazon since the late 1990's, when it acquired an exploration property there. Pablo Tsere, an Indian leader from the same area, has been opposing the company's efforts for just as long.

title: Keep the Sounds to Yourself With Game Boy Headphones
description: Now there are headphones available for Nintendo's Game Boy Advance SP, the popular hand-held game console that looks like a laptop for Tom Thumb. Millions of the portable game players, which were introduced in North America in January 2003, have been sold. Until now, anyone using one in public had to pay for an adapter to plug standard headphones into the little $100 boxes, or impose their noises and tunes on everyone within earshot.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Court Lifts 2 Death Sentences
description: The Court of Criminal Appeals reversed the death sentences of two convicts. The court said that one, Willie M. Modden, was retarded, precluding his execution. Mr. Modden, who was twice convicted and sentenced to death for a murder committed in 1984, had his sentence reduced to life imprisonment. The court held that evidence at trial did not support the death sentence given the other inmate, Kenneth Vodochodsky, in a case involving the murders of two police officers in 1999. The court ordered that Mr. Vodochodsky be resentenced. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: When Loved Ones Are Lost in War
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tamale Vendor Arrested And Food Checked For Human Remains
description: The police in the central state of Michoacn arrested a tamale vendor after finding a mutilated body in his home. The police suspect the vendor killed a friend after a fight and may have put his flesh into a batch of tamales, a popular dish of chopped meat wrapped in a softened corn husk. Investigators were conducting tests on the tamales and on pots of boiled meat found in the vendor's home. The case was front-page news, prompting headlines like ''Tamales of Death!'' Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Hope Intermingles With Grief Among Halliburton Workers
description: The fates of four Halliburton contract workers missing in Iraq remained unclear Wednesday, a day after the announcement that the bodies of three others ambushed in the same attack, on April 9, had been identified.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chip Maker Posts Profit
description: The chip maker Infineon Technologies posted a net profit of 39 million euros ($46 million) for the second quarter ended March 31, in contrast to a loss of 328 million euros a year earlier. Cost cuts and greater demand for chips contributed to the gain. Sales rose 13 percent, to 1.67 billion euros ($1.98 billion). Max Dietrich Kley, above, the interim chief executive since Ulrich Schumacher was ousted by the supervisory board last month, said he expected annual sales to climb to 7 billion euros as the worldwide semiconductor market grows 22 percent this year. Infineon, based in Munich, said it had two candidates for chief executive. The company did not identify them but said both were German. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Simple Ideas For Around The House, Straight Out Of Brooklyn
description: ''Brooklyn Designs 2004,'' a showcase for 45 furniture designers sponsored by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, will open April 30 at two locations in the Dumbo neighborhood. Some of the best ideas shown will be the simplest. Top-and-bottom poster frames, above, sandwich art between magnetized walnut strips and steel strips in six lengths, 8 1/2 inches ($14) to 32 inches ($30). The inventors, Paul Galli and Todd Seidman, owners of 54 Dean, will be at Booth 24 in St. Ann's Warehouse (38 Water Street). Birch plywood boxes, below, with anodized aluminum frames, which double as handles, can carry books and serve as shelves. Designed by Manche Mitchell, they come in four sizes, the largest 18 by 18 by 13 inches, and are $350 each (Booth 27, St. Ann's Warehouse). Other designers will be at the Brooklyn Designs Gallery, 37 Main Street (Water Street). Open daily through May 2. Admission, $10; (718) 875-1000, extension 146. Architects and designers can attend the first day free, with prior registration at www.brooklyndesigns.net.

description: WHAT is so great about Internet commerce?

description: PAYN -- Benjamin Robert. The Pieniek family acknowledges with profound sorrow the passing of our friend. We extend our deepest condolences to Amalia and the family. Love, Toby & Ellen

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page picture caption on Saturday about the renovation of a school in Afghanistan misstated the date of the renovation work shown in the picture. It was in April 2003, not last week. ( Go to Article )

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Most School Budgets Approved
description: Despite New Jersey's rising property taxes, voters approved 70 percent of the state's school budgets on Tuesday. The gesture of confidence surprised school board officials, who have seen a steady decline in budget approvals over the last three years. Last year, only 62 percent of the budgets were approved, down from 88 percent in 2000. With property taxes rising 15 percent in the last two years, many school administrators had braced for the worst. The vote covered 550 districts seeking a total of more than $9.5 billion. Of the proposed budgets, 383 were approved and 166 were defeated. Jessica Bruder (NYT)

title: Connecticut Auto Emission Test Is Stopped for as Long as 90 Days
description: The state is suspending its auto emissions testing program for as long as 90 days, Gov. John G. Rowland said on Wednesday, after a preliminary audit revealed a range of technical problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNALLY, EDWARD M.
description: McNALLY--Edward M., 91, of Red Hook, NY died April 7, 2004. He was president of Voorhis-Tiebout Co., He attended Lehigh University and graduated from New York University in 1934. He was a lieutenant in U.S. Navy in WW II. He was president of the Red Hook Library a director of the local bank. He is survived by Margery, his wife of 64 years, sons Edward A. McNally of Ridgefield, CT, and Mark J. McNally of Lake Katrine, NY, a sister, Sandra Smith, of Darien, CT, a granddaughter and three stepgrandchildren. Donations may be made to Northern Dutchess Hospital Foundation, PO Box 5002, Rhinebeck, NY 12572.

title: Panel Says Internal Flaws at USA Today Aided in Deceptions
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 — A panel of outside journalists retained by USA Today to investigate the repeated fabrications of its former star foreign correspondent has concluded that sloppy editing, poor newsroom communication and a deeply embedded culture of fear contributed to those deceptions being published in the newspaper's pages.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 3 Madrid Suspects Freed
description: A judge has released three suspects -- a Moroccan, an Egyptian and a Saudi -- arrested in Madrid last week in connection with the March 11 train bombings, leaving a total of 18 suspects still charged in the case, including 15 Moroccans. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Adding Some Color to Make Children's Days Brighter
description: Little Sisters of the Assumption Family Health Service, a nonprofit social-services organization, has a colorful new home in East Harlem designed by Peter L. Gluck, a Manhattan architect, right. The building, at 23,000 square feet, cost $4.5 million.

description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Kurdish Lawmakers Convicted In Retrial
description: In a decision that drew immediate censure from European Union officials, a state security court in upheld the 15-year prison sentences of four Kurdish members of Parliament convicted in 1994 of having links to the outlawed Kurdistan Workers Party. Rights groups had campaigned for the release of the defendants; one, Leyla Zana, left, had been awarded the European Parliament's Sakharov Peace Prize for her outspoken advocacy for Kurdish rights. While Turkey has since eased restrictions on Kurds, a European Commission spokesman in Brussels called Mrs. Zana a ''political prisoner'' and said Turkey's bid for membership in the bloc could be hurt by the verdict. Susan Sachs (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: U.S. Reports Flaw In Cisco Equipment
description: A flaw in equipment from Cisco Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of computer networking gear, may let hackers knock out the company's machines that help run the Internet, the Department of Homeland Security said yesterday. The operating system software for Cisco's routers and switches for directing Internet traffic has a fault that may let a hacker send erroneous data that causes the machines to restart, making them unavailable, the department said on its Web site. Cisco has made a software patch available on its Web site. The flaw in Cisco's SNMP software is separate from a problem disclosed yesterday that affects the underlying technology of the Internet, called TCP. The latter affects gear from all Internet vendors. The Cisco flaw is more serious, by making it easier for a hacker to exploit, Shawn Hernan, of the technical staff of the United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team, said. Shares of Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., rose 23 cents, to $22.34, but lost their gains in after-hours trading, falling to 22.05.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a settlement allowing several Connecticut inmates to collect royalties from a book of personal essays provided an incorrect summary from the state Attorney General's Office of a law covering convicts who profit from books about their crimes. Although that law was not the one cited in the settlement, Connecticut does indeed have a ''Son of Sam'' law requiring that such profits be held in escrow for crime victims. A picture caption with the article misspelled the surname of one of the writers in some editions. She is Brenda Medina, not Madina.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: 13 Accused In Insurance Fraud Case
description: The Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon, announced yesterday that 13 people had been arrested and accused of workers' compensation and similar fraud. One of the accused, Edward Abrams, a Long Island debt-collection lawyer, had submitted $46,000 in claims for a hip and shoulder injury in an auto accident, but continued to work out of his home, the authorities said. They said the insurance company learned his doctors' files did not match Mr. Abrams's submitted claims. Mr. Abrams was charged with grand larceny, insurance fraud and falsifying business records. If convicted, he faces up to seven years in prison. His lawyer, Charles Hochbaum, declined to comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

title: Freedom Summer, 2004
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Who Sought Haven From Tornado Die as Building Is Struck
description: Eight people who sought protection from a tornado in the basement of a neighborhood bar were killed on Tuesday when the building collapsed, sending thousands of pounds of debris crashing onto them, officials said on Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Monoxide Detector Bill Advances
description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday that would require carbon monoxide detectors to be installed in apartments, single-family homes, hotels and schools across the city. The bill would require owners or landlords to install at least one detector within 15 feet of a bedroom or sleeping area, and allow them to pass along a one-time $25 fee to tenants. City officials would have the authority to determine the number and location of detectors to be placed in hotels and schools. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Sorry, I Can't Talk Now. They're Ready for My Root Canal.
description: Gone are the days when sound effects for your phone calls had to be homemade, like holding your nose when you called in sick. Now owners of selected Nokia and Sony Ericsson cellphones can use a utility called Soundercover to add recorded background sounds to their phoned-in alibis. If you are lingering over a latte but want to say that a traffic jam is holding you up, for example, Soundercover can add the sounds of honking horns and screeching tires to your call.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Clinton Aide A Harvard Dean
description: David T. Ellwood, an expert on poverty and the family, who helped overhaul welfare during the Clinton administration, has been named dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Dr. Ellwood, a professor of political economy there, will succeed Joseph S. Nye Jr., who is stepping down on June 30. Dr. Ellwood has been on the faculty since 1980 as a professor and academic dean. He took a leave from 1993 to 1995 to work for the Department of Health and Human Services. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHANE, RABBI SOLOMON
description: KAHANE--Rabbi Solomon. Beloved rabbi of the West Side Jewish Center for 38 years. A teacher and role model to the entire Jewish people. Rarely does one man possess such a combination of compassion and intellect. He was a best friend to all of us. His memory is an inspiration to us all. May G-d, blessed be He, grant him the eternal reward he so richly deserves. The officers and members of the West Side Jewish Center mourn his loss together with his family and friends.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: NEW MEXICO: CENSURE OVER GAY-MARRIAGE LICENSES The Republican Central Committee of Sandoval County adopted a resolution censuring a clerk for issuing marriage licenses to gays. The committee had tried to mount a recall campaign against the clerk, Victoria S. Dunlap, a Republican. Ms. Dunlap, who contends that state law does not prohibit gay marriage, issued 66 licenses before a state judge stopped her. A hearing is pending. The resolution said Ms. Dunlap had "brought disgrace to the party." Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Koi Flashing in a Mud Pond, Making Everything Clear
description: SCOTT PURDIN says he was miserable as a writer, even though he loved his graduate work with John Hawkes at Brown University. He made a few independent films from his screenplays, and taught writing and filmmaking at Louisiana State University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLMAN GILROD, BER NICE
description: MILLMAN GILROD -- Ber nice, born October 19, 1916, in Far Rockaway, NY, died April 13 in San Francisco, CA. She graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Brooklyn College and had a respected 50-year career as a women's merchandise executive in the Garment Center. She will be greatly loved and missed by her entire family--Susana Millman, daughter by first husband, Hyman Millman; Susan Dechnik, daughter of second husband, Harry Gilrod; granddaughters, Season Korchin and Jill Loxterman; grandson, Steven Dechnik, and two great-grandchildren.

title: Film Legend Bothered by Use of Name in Stunt at Princeton
description: Paul Newman has attached his name to salad dressing, popcorn and salsa. But he has drawn the line at a Princeton tradition known as Newman's Day, in which students strive to drink 24 beers in 24 hours.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Comptroller Sues Over Snapple Deal
description: The city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., has filed a lawsuit to block the Bloomberg administration's $126 million contract giving Snapple exclusive rights to sell beverages from vending machines on city property. Last week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ordered Mr. Thompson to approve the contract, invoking a City Charter provision requiring the comptroller to register the contract within 10 days. Mr. Thompson has charged that the contract was awarded improperly. In the suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Thompson called the contract ''a backroom deal.'' Snapple, in a statement, said it would help the Bloomberg administration fight the suit. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSO, TINA AND LUCIO LOU
description: RUSSO--Tina and Lucio Lou. The Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of the March of Dimes extend our deepest sympathy to our esteemed board members Thomas and Anthony Russo on the passing of their parents, Tina and Lucio Lou Russo. For over 50 years, the Russos dedicated themselves to our original mission to fight polio and our new mission, to improve the health of babies by preventing birth defects, prematurity and infant death. They will be deeply missed. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D, President Gary D. Forsee, Chairman, National Board of Trustees

title: A Workshop to Give Tips on Making Old Books New Again
description: A free workshop on Saturday at the New York Public Library will explain how to protect, repair and clean books using household products. The instructors, Margot Rosenberg and Bern Marcowitz, wrote ''The Care and Feeding of Books Old and New'' (Thomas Dunne, 2002). Participants can bring in their broken bindings and stained pages. The workshop is at 2 p.m. in the library shop, 455 Fifth Avenue (40th Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Dying Mother Tries to Get Her Son Home From Iraq
description: As she sat in the grandstand of the lovely little ballpark here on Tuesday evening, Patrice Confer should have been reveling in the rewards of motherhood. Her 15-year-old daughter was playing right field for the Altoona High School softball team, and on an adjacent diamond one of her sons was behind the plate for the school's baseball team.

title: Fund for Asbestos Victims Seems Headed for Setback Today
description: Though negotiations continue, a bill that would settle hundreds of thousands of asbestos lawsuits by creating a trust fund to compensate victims appears headed for a procedural defeat in the Senate, where a vote is scheduled for Thursday.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: The Trixie Code

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. Avoids Faculty Strike
description: New York University's part-time professors reached a tentative contract agreement with the university early yesterday and called off a threatened strike. Neither side would disclose the details, but the union said the contract, which must be approved by its members, was ''groundbreaking.'' The agreement was the first reached by the part-time professors since they unionized in 2002 and affiliated with the United Automobile Workers. The adjuncts make less than $4,000 per course. (The union says the average payment is about $2,700; the university says the average pay is about $3,700 for a three-credit course.) U.A.W. officials said the union, A.C.T.-U.A.W. Local 7902, is the largest adjunct-only union at a private university in the United States; N.Y.U. says it includes about 2,300 professors. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

The men were convicted of using knives and a hatchet to take control of a flight with 37 people on board from the Isle of Youth, off Cuba's southern coast, and divert it toward Florida. United States fighter jets intercepted the plane and escorted it to Key West. Alexis Norneilla Morales, whom the prosecution painted as the ringleader, received a 24-year sentence, as did his brother, Miakel Guerra Morales. Eduardo Javier Mejia Morales, Yainer Olivares Samon, Neudis Infantes Hernandez and Alvenis Arias-Izquierdo received 20 years, the minimum sentence for air piracy. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: The Body Politic
description: Not since Jane Goodall lived with chimps in Tanzania has there been such a vivid study of the nonverbal patterns of primates engaged in a dominance display.

title: Disappearance of Rightist Unsettles Colombian Peace Talks
description: Days after an assassination attempt on Carlos Castao, the driving force of Colombia's right-wing paramilitary army, his disappearance has thrown peace talks between the paramilitaries and the government into a state of turmoil. It has also threatened a cornerstone of President lvaro Uribe's strategy to pacify the country.

title: An Arbiter of Cool Has a New Owner
description: LAST week's announcement in Milan that the famously dashing Italian furniture company, Cappellini, had been sold to Poltrona Frau, a more conservative brand known for its leather upholstery, sent ripples through the world of international design.

title: Two Pharmaceutical Giants to Start Merger Talks
description: Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceuticals group, said it would begin merger talks with France's Aventis, which faces a $53.2 billion hostile takeover bid from Sanofi-Synthelabo.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: CLINTON AIDE A HARVARD DEAN David T. Ellwood, an expert on poverty and the family, who helped overhaul welfare during the Clinton administration, has been named dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Dr. Ellwood, a professor of political economy there, will succeed Joseph S. Nye Jr., who is stepping down on June 30. Dr. Ellwood has been on the faculty since 1980 as a professor and academic dean. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Making City Pay Raises Count
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg drew a line in the sand on giving retroactive pay raises to city workers shortly after he took office and inherited a fiscal crisis. That line shifted recently with an improving budget outlook and the need to take care of certain matters before the 2005 re-election campaign. This week City Hall gave in on the point altogether, agreeing to pay members of the city's largest municipal workers' union additional money for the two years they have worked without a contract.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: N.B.A. Analysis; Playoffs Are Past Before They Begin At Garden
description: If the Knicks ran fast breaks as fast as they make reckless comments, if they were as committed to playing defense as they are to sounding off, there might be a reason to believe that a competitive playoff game will break out Thursday at Madison Square Garden.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Revenue Falls At Reuters
description: The Reuters Group said revenue at its main unit declined 8.4 percent in the first quarter as businesses canceled subscriptions in Europe. Revenue at the unit, which sells financial information to businesses like banks, dropped to 556 million ($991 million). The rate of decline slowed from 9.1 percent in the year-earlier period. Revenue on that basis may fall 6 percent to 6.5 percent in the second quarter, the chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, said on a conference call. Sales in the United States and in Asia, which together account for 43 percent of the main unit's sales, were not enough to offset cancellations in Europe, Mr. Glocer said.

title: High Court Denies Stay for Clarett Days Before N.F.L. Draft
description: The last-gasp attempt by Maurice Clarett and Mike Williams to be included in this weekend's National Football League draft ended today when the United States Supreme Court denied Clarett's request to overturn a lower court's stay that prevents them from entering the draft.

title: Sharon May Pursue Gaza Withdrawal Even If Party Objects
description: JERUSALEM, April 22  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon could still pursue his proposal for an Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip even if his own party rejects the plan in a May 2 referendum, a senior government official said today.

title: Ready, Aim, Sing: 'Assassins' Hits Broadway
description: It has taken 13 years for the Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman musical ''Assassins,'' which opens tonight, to make its way to Broadway. And while some of the delay can be attributed to the usual theatrical gremlins -- like scheduling problems -- the greatest obstacle has been the strange intersection of its dark subject matter and world events, including two Persian Gulf wars and the terrorist attacks of 9/11.

title: Nets' Defense Has Had Marbury Up in Arms
description: Try to put yourself in Stephon Marbury's sneakers. You are having a difficult night. With the burden on your shoulders, your short-handed Knicks team is futilely chasing the Nets around the court as the score soars as if on a pinball machine.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Says Antismoking Plan Succeeds
description: City officials said yesterday that a nicotine patch program to stop smoking has been far more successful than they expected, with one in three smokers quitting and staying tobacco-free for six months. The health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, said 11,000 people quit smoking using patches given out free last year. ''Of all the programs my agency did last year, this was by far the most effective in terms of saving lives,'' he said. The city gave patches to 34,000 smokers. He said at least 1,700 people who quit extended their lives by doing so. The city mailed a six-week supply of patches to anyone who requested them by phone and answered a few questions, and interviewed participants six months later. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMUELSON, CARL
description: SAMUELSON -- Carl. Al though we mourn the death of our Founder, Carl Samuelson, we celebrate his life and remember the joy he brought to all. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 25 at 10AM at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, N.Y. The Stagedoor Manor Family

title: Ex-Ranger Kovalev Regains Luster
description: Aleksei Kovalev of the Montreal Canadiens pilots his own airplane and wants to fly helicopters. This is appropriate for a talented athlete whose career has had many ups and downs amid its dips and dives.

title: From Shared Resources, Your Personal History
description: LARS LUNDIN and his database are matchmakers of a sort, trading in information about matches made long ago. Genealogists send him family trees, and his computer compares them with other family trees in a database of more than two million current and former Danish citizens. Each month, he estimates, his computer finds more than 1,000 connections between cousins.

title: COMPUTER SERVICES COMPANY SAYS S.E.C. ENDED INQUIRY
description: The Carreker Corporation, which sells software and computer services to banks, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had ended an informal investigation into the company's accounting without recommending any enforcement action. The S.E.C. began investigating Carreker in December 2002, its general counsel, Tod V. Mongan, said. Carreker, based in Dallas, has restated its earnings for four fiscal years, ending Jan. 31, 2002, and for the first two quarters of the year ended Jan. 31, 2003.

title: Mercury and the E.P.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMRAH, COL. GEORGE ALEXANDER
description: HAMRAH--Col. George Alexander, USA (Ret.) on April 18, 2004 in San Diego, CA. Beloved son of the late Alexander J. Hamrah and Labiby Hamrah. He was born in Brooklyn NY, attended Penn State University and received his B.S. from NYU. He was awarded a Ph.D. in Economics. Col. Hamrah enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1941, rose to the rank of Colonel in the Quartermaster Corps and served With Distinction for 35 years. He is survived by his sister-in-law Mary E. Hamrah of Tenafly NJ, eight nieces and one nephew, and many grandnephews and grandnieces. He was preceded in death by his brother, Elias Hamrah of Englewood NJ and by his four sisters, Adma Ganim of Cincinnati OH, Alice Hamrah of Bowie MD, Claire Lian of Beechwood NJ, Louise Hamrah of Brooklyn NY. Family and friends may call Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 at the Herbst-Traska-Waldeck Chapels, 7614 4th Ave, Brooklyn NY 11209 (valet parking). Funeral liturgy Saturday, 10AM at Church of the Virgin Mary, 8th Ave and 2nd St, Brooklyn NY. Interment St. John's Cemetery. For information, 718-745-1600

title: Officers Get List of Names Of Actors In Sex Films
description: Investigators for the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services obtained on Wednesday a list of the legal names of 53 adult-movie actors who were known to have had sexual contact with two actors infected with the AIDS virus or with someone else who had sex with the two.

title: Expect Much Scrambling of the Top 10 Draft Positions
description: The order among the first 10 teams in the National Football League draft remains intact, but few involved believe that will last. Movement -- and plenty of it -- is expected among the teams in these final hours preceding Saturday's selections.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a new study of hormone therapy in menopausal women misstated the role of a researcher, Dr. JoAnn E. Manson of Harvard Medical School. She will be one of eight principal investigators in the study, not the director. (The director will be Dr. S. Mitchell Harman, president of the Kronos Longevity Research Institute in Phoenix, which is paying for the study.)

title: Neglect and the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Phone Sales Miss Goal
description: The Telstra Corporation, Australia's biggest phone company, said third-quarter sales rose 1 percent, to 5 billion Australian dollars, short of its goal, as growth at its fixed-line business stalled. The company, based in Melbourne, had a goal of 4 percent to 5 percent growth.

title: The Fine Print on the Trade Center Site
description: WORLD trade was not exactly the lifeblood of the World Trade Center, and the twin towers were not really twins. The proposed Wedge of Light will be in shadow, the 1,776-foot Freedom Tower will be a 1,500-foot building (not counting spire) and the memorial ''footprints'' may not correspond exactly to the original building outlines.

title: Voter Scan: 'This Is Your Brain on Politics . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: Arsenal; 'You've Got Spyware!' AOL Update Will Scan for Sneaky Programs
description: America Online is fighting fire with fire.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose to 1.13 trillion yen ($10.4 billion) in March, a gain of 18 percent from a year earlier, as exports increased to China and other Asian countries. A 13 percent increase in exports, including a 20 percent increase in shipments to Asia, powered the ninth consecutive monthly expansion in the surplus. Imports expanded 12 percent from the year, helped by growing consumption in Japan. Japan's trade surplus with the United States fell 3.6 percent, largely because of an increase in orders by Japanese companies for airplanes made in the Untied States. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRADEN, ADELAIDE
description: BRADEN--Adelaide Weld of Lloyd Harbor, NY died April 20, 2004 in her 85th year. Beloved wife of William Braden, and the late Robert Bacon Whitney and James Knott. She is survived by her daughter, Hope Whitney Lapsley and her son, Robert Bacon Whitney Jr. and seven stepchildren, Lilias K. Bostwick, David H. Knott, Catherine K. Welch, Susan K. Childs, Nora K. Cushing, William Braden Jr. and Maria Clark and daughter-in-law, Susan Jardine-Paterson. She is also survived by her two sisters, Rose Weld Baldwin and Katharine Weld Bacon. She was predeceased by her sons, Michael Whitney, Stephen Weld Whitney and James Knott Jr. She was a devoted grandmother of 26 grandchildren and great-grandmother of 33 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday April 24 at 12pm at the Church of the Advent, Westbury, LI. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Family and Children's Association, 100 East Old Country Rd, Mineola, NY 11501 or Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, 540 Fulton Ave, Hempstead, NY 11550.

title: Final Curtain to Fall on 'Gypsy' May 30
description: The producers of the Broadway revival of ''Gypsy,'' which struggled to stay open last winter but rallied this spring, have finally decided to give up the fight. They announced yesterday that the $8 million production would close on May 30 after a 14-month run.

title: Neglect and the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: For $45, a Digital Camera With Frills
description: Up to now, inexpensive digital cameras have generally been stripped of special features like display screens, meaning the photographer had no way to see what sort of image had been captured until the picture was downloaded to a PC. Now the cost-conscious user can point, shoot and review with the Argus DC-1730, the first under-$50 digital camera with a liquid crystal display.

title: Investor's Pullout Stirs Doubts About SCO Group
description: The SCO Group received a large dose of cash and a vote of confidence for its anti-Linux campaign last October when BayStar Capital arranged a $50 million investment in the company.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Tribesmen Get Extension
description: A 2,000-strong tribal militia hunting down remnants of Al Qaeda and its sympathizers in the rugged semi-autonomous tribal region of South Waziristan alongside the Afghan border was given until May 1 by Pakistani officials to show concrete and tangible results. The military has threatened tough action if the tribal militia fails to cooperate and hand over terror suspects. A deadline passed on Tuesday, but tribal leaders asked for an extension. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Voter Scan: 'This Is Your Brain on Politics . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking for Europe, Chirac Warns Iran on Inspections
description: In a hardening of Europe's position toward Iran's nuclear activities, President Jacques Chirac of France criticized Iran on Wednesday for failing to comply fully with international inspections of its nuclear sites, and suggested that Iran had violated the spirit of an agreement with France, Germany and Britain to curtail its nuclear programs, senior French officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Drug Courier Loses Hospital Suit
description: In an unusual lawsuit, a federal jury found yesterday that there was no malpractice when doctors at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens, surgically removed bags of heroin from a drug courier. The admitted courier, William Meequaye Kanyi, filed the lawsuit. Mr. Kanyi, who is from Ghana, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport in 1998. The jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn rejected claims that the surgery was unnecessary and that doctors had improperly found Mr. Kanyi psychologically incompetent to refuse permission. ''The hospital should be commended,'' said a juror, who refused to be named. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Voter Scan: 'This Is Your Brain on Politics . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Piece of Business On a Pre-election List
description: Like a bride preparing for the big day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appears to have a giant to-do list that he is checking off, week by week, getting himself ready for what could be a bruising re-election campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOBER, ARNOLD
description: BOBER--Arnold. Born August 4, 1917 in The Hague, Holland. Died peacefully on April 21, 2004. Beloved husband of Senta and loving father of Franklin and the late Jack. Loving grandfather of Suzanne, Sara, David, Gabrielle, Bronwen and Jenia. Greatgrandfather of Ted. Brotherin-law of Henry Solan. An intellectual, investor, linguist and businessman. He was loved and he will be missed. Services at 9AM Friday, April 23 at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City.

title: A Call to Arms by Abortion Rights Groups
description: For the first time in 12 years, a coalition of abortion rights advocates will hold what they hope will be a major march in Washington on Sunday, trying to return the issue to the forefront of American politics -- and to highlight what they contend is the Bush administration's extremism.

title: Disclosure by the Kerrys
description: Senator John Kerry's two tours of combat duty in Vietnam should have prepared him well for the political firefight that is part of the daily slog in a presidential campaign. Yet his team seemed caught off guard in delivering on his promise of full disclosure of his war records. Detailed documents have finally been released, but only after the Bush campaign began questioning whether Mr. Kerry might somehow be hiding something in his war record. It should have been no surprise to Mr. Kerry that the Republicans took advantage of the news vacuum he created by withholding his records -- not after President Bush's recent discomfort over questions about his own Vietnam-era service at home in the Texas Air National Guard.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Censure Over Gay-Marriage Licenses
description: The Republican Central Committee of Sandoval County adopted a resolution censuring a clerk for issuing marriage licenses to gays. The committee had tried to mount a recall campaign against the clerk, Victoria S. Dunlap, a Republican. Ms. Dunlap, who contends that state law does not prohibit gay marriage, issued 66 licenses before a state judge stopped her. A hearing is pending. The resolution said Ms. Dunlap had ''brought disgrace to the party.'' Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Used Cellphones Find a Market Among Bare-Bones Users
description: EVEN as the latest cellphone models arrive in showcases, a new breed of shopper is scouring online ads and dark corners of stores for a bargain phone with a little mileage on it. As cellphones become routine for even the cash-strapped and the very young, more Americans are willing to pay for handsets previously used by other hands.

title: A Briton in Brooklyn Capitalizes on a Misunderstanding
description: Several British experts have settled on this side of the Atlantic in the last half century, adding flavor to the tournament world. Two, including me, have been primarily writers, two have been players, and one was a teacher; four of them wound up in Florida. The teacher, Ronald Crown, died this month in Boca Raton after instructing large classes in that area for 28 years.

title: U.S. Orders Further Cuts in Air Traffic at O'Hare
description: Despite an order by the Federal Aviation Administration to reduce traffic at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, delays became worse there in March. As a result, the agency will order deeper cuts, the transportation secretary announced on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIMPFHEIMER, HANNA
description: WIMPFHEIMER -- Hanna (Putti). We mourn the passing of our beloved wife, mother, sister, grandmother, great grandmother and friend. She will be remembered for her dignity, elegance and intellect.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: WEINSTEIN--Joseph. With loving memories. Norma, Children and Grandchildre

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: Correction Appended

title: Consistent Vazquez And Posada Carry Yanks
description: Javier Vazquez came to the Yankees with command of his fastball, changeup and curve, the widespread adoration of scouts and no idea about the American League. He struggled against A.L. teams before joining the Yankees, so he made what has been a wise decision. Vazquez put his trust in Jorge Posada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMANN, ARTHUR M.
description: KAUFMANN--Arthur M. Of Ft. Lee, NJ. Husband of Christiane, father of Allan, Mark and Michael. Brother of Martha Laub. Grandfather of Maximillian, Nicholas and Angelica. Graveside service Thursday 10:30 AM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions to N.J. Veterans Home, Paramus, NJ. For info ''Gutterman-Musicant''.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Senegal: Prime Minister Out
description: President Abdoulaye Wade removed his prime minister, Idrissa Seck. Mr. Seck is considered a rival to the 77-year-old president. Fatou Diakhat (NYT)

title: No Escaping Bush for Kerry, Even in Backwoods Louisiana
description: SHELL BEACH, La., April 21  Political backdrops can be as important as what's on stage, a maxim the Kerry campaign's advance team always keeps in mind. Its giant-sized American flags have bisected whole gymnasiums and eclipsed small buildings in a single drape. And it usually tries to place a none-too-subtle message where cameras will have a hard time missing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLD, DEENA
description: GOLD--Deena. Beloved wife of Gilbert and mother of David, Susan and Bill. Sister of George Israel and Carol Kuller. Her grandchildren, Nathan, Joshua, Sophia, Daniel, Zachary and Chloe were the joy of her life. She will be dearly missed. Contributions in her memory can be sent to Temple Emanuel Nursery School & Kindergarten, 1 Saperstein Plaza, Lynbrook, NY 11563, or any children's charity.

title: COURT APPROVES SALE OF 353 STORES TO FOOT LOCKER
description: Foot Locker, the athletic shoe retailer, won court approval yesterday to buy the bankrupt Footstar's 353 Footaction stores for $225 million after increasing its bid to beat an offer from Finish Line. The transaction was approved by Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains. Foot Locker, based in New York, has about 3,600 stores. Footstar, based in West Nyack, N.Y., is closing another 163 Footaction and Just for Feet stores as it sheds its retail operations to run shoe sections in department stores.

title: North Korean Leader Tells China He's Committed to Nuclear Talks
description: The Chinese government on Wednesday finally acknowledged the secretive visit of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, and announced that he would continue with the six-nation talks organized by China to defuse North Korea's nuclear standoff with the United States.

title: In Bright Light, an E-Book That's Easy on the Eyes
description: While hand-held electronic books have been around for years, such gadgets have never really taken off. One reason is that their small display screens are simply not as easy to read as an ordinary paperback.

title: As Wealthy Fill Top Colleges, Concerns Grow Over Fairness
description: At prestigious universities around the country, from flagship state colleges to the Ivy League, more and more students from upper-income families are edging out those from the middle class, according to university data.

title: Judge Agrees to Defense Request on Instructions to Williams Jury
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., April 21 - Before the jurors hearing the case against Jayson Williams begin deliberations, they will be told that they cannot convict him of manslaughter if they believe that he merely acted negligently, but not recklessly, in the fatal shooting of Costas Christofi in February 2002.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Kills One At Police Station
description: A bomb exploded outside a police station in a border town of southern Afghanistan, killing one person and wounding two, a government official said. The bomb, attached to a motorcycle, may have been aimed at the governor of Kandahar, who was visiting the police station. A second bomb, placed in a pressure cooker, was found on a street in Kabul. The bomb was defused, and a man carrying a remote-control device was arrested. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Voter Scan: 'This Is Your Brain on Politics . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dub Generation: Gearheads Go Hip-Hop
description: ON a forthcoming cover, the actors Owen Wilson, Ben Stiller and Snoop Dogg preen in their "Starsky & Hutch" best, while for a previous issue the basketball player Kobe Bryant posed sitting on the bumper of his canary-yellow Lamborghini Murcielago. Then there's the rapper Lil' Kim, who modeled for her cover in a minidress zipped down to her navel, her Mercedes-Benz G500 peeking through in the background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLEASON, FRANCIS J.
description: GLEASON--Francis J. of Montclair NJ on April 20, 2004. Husband of Patricia A. Gleason. Father of Owen Gleason, Mary Dannemiller, Mark Gleason, Hugh Gleason, Angela Gleason and Nora Leary. Brother of Thomas, James, Paul, the late Benedict and the late John Gleason. Also survived by 13 grandchildren. A Funeral Mass will be offered in Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair NJ on Saturday April 24 at 10 AM. Visiting in the Prout Funeral Home, 370 Bloomfield Ave, Verona NJ on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Immaculate Conception Church, 30 North Fullerton Ave, Montclair NJ 07042 or to the Montclair Art Museum, 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair, New Jersey 07042, would be appreciated.

title: Group of Senators Agree on Drug Imports
description: A bipartisan group of senators announced Wednesday that they had reached agreement on a bill to allow imports of lower-cost prescription drugs from Canada and some other countries.

title: Attack of the Killer Political Books
description: Aroundup of forums highlights, including readers' opinions on the new Bob Woodward book and a proposed solution for plagiarism.

title: Metro Matters; Museum Stop: Lots of Light And Gargoyles
description: TO the untrained eye, they look like basic fluorescent lights, but Michael Moss does not have an untrained eye. He's the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's lighting superintendent for Brooklyn, and he is an expert like few others when it comes to lights in the subway system. He has been for a long time.

title: A Place to Bed Down When Living Is Lazy
description: SUMMER is approaching, so it is time to get the guest room ready. For those who do not have a separate room or a convertible sofa, options for overnighters include a bed in a suitcase and handsome sleeping bags for children dropping in. And don't forget a night light to help guests find their way in the dark.

title: Mormon Church Gets Ready to Open Its Newest Temple, Near Lincoln Center
description: A legacy of misunderstanding and persecution has bred a keen instinct for public relations in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. And so, in what has become something of a ritual itself, the Mormon church opens every newly built temple to the public. Then it shuts the doors.

title: Europe Asks Court to Rule on Air Security Pact
description: In a bid to protect Europeans' rights to privacy, the European Parliament on Wednesday voted 276 to 260 to refer a draft agreement between the European Commission and the United States on the use of air passenger data to the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.

title: Sony Group Said to Be in Talks to Buy MGM
description: A consortium led by the Sony Corporation of America is in talks to acquire Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the Hollywood studio famous for ''The Wizard of Oz,'' James Bond and the Pink Panther, for as much as $5 billion, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Amish Man's U.S. Stay Hangs on a Photo
description: For nearly two years, Daniel Zehr, an Amish man from Canada who wants to become an American citizen, has resisted what to others might seem a simple requirement: that he submit his photograph to immigration officials. Doing that, Mr. Zehr argues in a lawsuit, would violate his religious belief that the Bible prohibits posing for photographs.

title: PC Mission: Big Value, Small Price
description: PRODUCTS that are tagged as ''high value'' or ''value-priced'' bring to mind things that are faded copies of something else, like store-brand sandwich cookies that don't taste like real Oreos or an imported $75 guitar that can't begin to approach the warmth and tone of a Martin steel-string wonder costing several thousand dollars. Sure, these lower-priced items may perform the same function as the big-ticket goods, but not nearly as well, nor for as long, before falling apart.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Apprentic'd: A Cautionary Tale

title: Eccentric? Sure, but His Students Succeed
description: AH, let's just go ahead and say it. Stanley Bosworth, the departing founding headmaster of St. Ann's School, is peculiar. He even refers to himself as ''this old wizard.'' He calls himself a few other things that are too salty for a family paper.

title: Nazis and Jews: Insights From Old Diary
description: James G. McDonald was an American diplomat who knew every major public figure in the 1930's as Europe and later the rest of the world rushed to war. He was also, it turns out, a dedicated and precise diarist, recording his meetings with Hitler, Mussolini and Roosevelt and detailing his own impressions of Nazi intentions.

title: Ex-Broker Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
description: Theodore C. Sihpol III, a former broker for the Bank of America Corporation, pleaded not guilty to fraud yesterday after being indicted this month in New York Supreme Court in Manhattan on 40 counts of fraud, grand larceny and falsifying statements.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: CLINTON AIDE A HARVARD DEAN David T. Ellwood, an expert on poverty and the family, who helped overhaul welfare during the Clinton administration, has been named dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Dr. Ellwood, a professor of political economy there, will succeed Joseph S. Nye Jr., who is stepping down on June 30. Dr. Ellwood has been on the faculty since 1980 as a professor and academic dean. He took a leave from 1993 to 1995 to work for the Department of Health and Human Services. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Foraging for the Right Goop and Goggles
description: AS we arrived poolside, I checked the second hand on my watch.

title: THERMO ELECTRON ACQUIRES U.S. COUNSELING SERVICES
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation, a maker of analytical instruments for medical laboratories, said yesterday that it had acquired U.S. Counseling Services for $77.9 million to add services to help its customers manage their equipment. U.S. Counseling, which is closely held and based in Brookfield, Wis., provides products for health care and pharmaceutical companies, Thermo Electron said. Thermo Electron is based in Waltham, Mass. The acquisition is the company's second in a recent emphasis on service. Thermo Electron acquired Laboratory Management Services in November to add services for ensuring that equipment complies with federal regulations, the chief executive, Marijn E. Dekkers, said.

title: Fitzgerald as Screenwriter: No Hollywood Ending
description: In the summer of 1937, broke, in debt and trying desperately to dry out, F. Scott Fitzgerald moved to Hollywood, where he joined the legions of jerks with Underwoods, to paraphrase the studio chief Jack Warner's famous put-down of screenwriters.

title: Makeup Exam Is Canceled After a TV Close-Up
description: New York City education officials yesterday canceled makeup exams for third-grade public school students who missed Tuesday's citywide reading test because at least one television station showed a close-up of test questions, compromising the security of the exam.

title: Bright Spots in the Rain Forest
description: The rallying cry, ''Save the Amazon!'' rang out again this month when the Brazilian government reported that clearing of the rain forest had reached near-record levels -- with an area bigger than the state of New Jersey disappearing last year. This Earth Day, global environmental groups are covering their Web sites with the usual predictions of how long it will take for all the trees there to vanish (20 to 50 years). Recently, the Brazilian government announced yet another initiative to get serious about the problem.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Judge Rules Against Terry Nichols
description: A state judge denied a motion to dismiss the murder case against Terry L. Nichols, whose lawyers had argued that prosecutors failed to provide exculpatory evidence. The judge, Steven W. Taylor, said the claims were ''laced with melodrama but no substance.'' Mr. Nichols is charged with 161 counts of murder involving the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building in 1995. The state is seeking the death penalty against Mr. Nichols, who is serving a life prison sentence for his conviction on federal charges. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Battle for Falluja Rouses The Anger of Iraqis Weary Of the U.S. Occupation
description: After suicide car bombs ripped into the relative calm of the southern city of Basra on Wednesday, merchants in a middle-class neighborhood here directed words dripping with venom at the American occupiers.

title: Vanunu, Disdaining Israel, Is Freed to Chants vs. Cheers
description: Angry Israelis chanted, ''Shut up, atomic spy!'' and ''Death to traitors!'' as a defiant Mordechai Vanunu headed out of prison on Wednesday after 18 years, flashing the victory sign and declaring he was proud of what he had done.

title: Justice Seeks N.F.L. Response
description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg asked the National Football League yesterday to reply by this morning to Maurice Clarett's appeal to the Supreme Court to be allowed into this weekend's draft. An answer from the court is expected later in the day.

title: To Outsmart Intruders, Enlist a Counterspy
description: IF your computer seems sluggish or your Web browser suddenly begins to act as if it is possessed by ads, there is a good chance that stealthy programs known as spyware or adware have slipped onboard.

title: In Brazil, Iconoclast Is Bearded In His Den; A Controversial Sculptor Revels in His Menagerie
description: As both a sculptor and a painter, Francisco Brennand has always been regarded as a maverick who prefers to work far from the mainstream of Brazilian art. So it seems appropriate that the large estate where he lives, labors and displays his controversial work lies at the end of a long dirt road on the outskirts of his native city, in northeast Brazil.

title: Frank Schiff Is Dead at 83; Headed Big Insurance Broker

description: THE familiar electrocardiograms of yearly medical checkups are the routine way to record electrical activity of the heart and detect disorders in its rhythms. But the test is relatively insensitive at pinpointing small areas where there may be problems, since a standard EKG machine samples electrical potential only at a handful of points on the body's surface.

description: EBay Inc., the world's largest Internet auction company, said first-quarter earnings surged 92 percent, the most in a year, as more people listed items for sale on its sites.

title: Straight to DVD
description: The idea of chronological generations may have to be set aside. The world we live in now is really measured in technological periods, which have no fixed length and overlap in wildly unpredictable ways. Each of our tools, each of our toys, seems to be rushing us into the future or holding us back. Consider the DVD.

But the Tar Heels' best runner, Shalane Flanagan, is redshirting to prepare for the Olympic trials, and they were up against Tennessee, which won the N.C.A.A. indoor title.
