title: World Briefing | United Nations: Volcker Begins Inquiry
description: The Security Council unanimously backed an independent inquiry into the United Nations oil-for-food program, and the former Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, took charge of it, pledging ''a full, fair investigation, as conclusive as we can make it.'' After meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan, Mr. Volcker, left, said the most important task was seeing if there was substance to charges of corruption involving United Nations officials. ''If there is substance, get it out there, get it out in a hurry and cauterize the wound,'' he said. Saddam Hussein is said to have pocketed more than $10 billion from the $67 billion program, created to devote Iraqi oil revenues to the purchase of food and other aid. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARK, ROSEMARY
description: PARK -- Rosemary. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Barnard College are saddened by the death of Rosemary Park, who provided inspiring leadership as President of Barnard from 19621967. A vital figure in higher education and a leading advocate for women's advancement, she was a wise and thoughtful administrator and scholar who devoted her life to students at Barnard and at Connecticut College, where she was professor and president, and at the University of California at Los Angeles, where she served as vice chancellor until her retirement in 1970. Barnard expresses its deep sympathy to her family, friends and colleagues. Judith Shapiro, President Barnard College

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Electrolux Profit Falls
description: Electrolux, a maker of household appliances, said first-quarter profit fell 57 percent because of a $127 million charge to close an American factory and as sales declined for a ninth quarter. Net income fell to 532 million kronor ($69 million) from 1.25 billion kronor a year earlier. Sales fell 4.9 percent, to 30.5 billion. Electrolux, based in Stockholm, has said it will shut the plant, in Greenville, Mich., and move its work to Mexico.

The current offering at Juilliard lies somewhere between: Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex'' and ''Nightingale'' are hardly war horses, but they were seen earlier this season as part of the Metropolitan Opera's Stravinsky triple bill, along with the ballet ''Le Sacre du Printemps.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Rivals Offered Higher Rate-Leasing Plans
description: Verizon Communications, the telecommunications giant based in New York, introduced a contractual framework yesterday for leasing its lines to competing telephone companies. Verizon said that it would lease its lines in customized three-year deals to competitors. Verizon, which operates in 30 states, said the price would vary by state but would typically range from $20 to $24 per telephone line a month, with the cost rising each subsequent year. The offer from Verizon follows similar proposals by other regional telephone giants, like SBC and BellSouth. Generally, the offers come after a recent appeals court decision that threw out federal rules forcing the dominant local phone companies, like Verizon, to lease their networks to competitors at low rates set by state regulators.

title: On Wheels; Everybody Buckled? Start the Movie

title: Reports of Massive Blast Emerge From Secretive North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, April 23  Hundreds of people were killed and injured when two trains loaded with fuel collided and exploded in a North Korean railroad station on Thursday, only hours after North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, had passed by, according to reports in South Korean news media.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Chip Contracts Reviewed
description: The European Commission is investigating Germany and Italy for reportedly favoring Intel chips in bids for computers by government agencies. Local authorities and utility companies in these countries have demanded that successful bids for large technology contracts must propose equipment using Intel chips, the commission said. ''Procurement bodies can't specify a brand in a tender. If you do mention a brand name, then you must consider bids that use equivalent equipment to that brand,'' Jonathan Todd, a European Commission spokesman, said. The commission is also reviewing contracts in Austria, Belgium, France, Finland and the Netherlands. Paul Meller (NYT)

Milk has spilled and spattered; food is smeared across the floor; pages from a medical report are strewn everywhere. When the cast members come out to take their bows, they look battered and disheveled, as if they, too, had been hit by a storm.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Recall Dates Set
description: Elections authorities said Venezuelans would have four days, starting May 27, to validate up to 1.2 million signatures on petitions seeking a recall referendum to remove President Hugo Chvez from office. If about 600,000 pro-referendum signatures are verified, an opposition movement determined to remove Mr. Chvez from office would have the 2.4 million signatures required to prompt a referendum for Aug. 8. This is the opposition's last chance to legally remove Mr. Chvez's left-leaning government before his term ends at the end of 2006, because a successful referendum after Aug. 19 would hand power over to the vice president, Jos Vicente Rangel, a close Chvez ally. Juan Forero (NYT)

The companies said on April 1 that they would jointly develop the four drugs . Solvay will also help Wyeth sell its antidepressant Effexor. Wyeth is based in Madison, N.J.

The movie is awesome, not in the sense of ''See ya tomorrow, dude'' awesome, but as in gasps inspired by the Grand Canyon, Yosemite National Park and other natural wonders. Filmed by Jon Long in the large-screen Imax format, it wraps and lulls you in its splendor while transporting you to the farthest reaches of the earth in search of pictorial perfection.

description: A 146-year-old oak tree in Guernica, long a symbol of Basque identity, has died, a victim of last summer's heat wave. It had survived the bombing of Guernica by Nazi planes in 1937 that flattened the city in a day and inspired Picasso's antiwar masterpiece ''Guernica.'' It was the third in a line of ceremonial oaks on the spot dating back to medieval times. Its predecessor was the namesake of an 1810 poem by Wordsworth. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

''Clients are interested in the topic, and spa professionals are interested.'' In response, her company's Web site (www.spafinder.com) soon will include the term ''eco-spa'' among its searchable spa categories, alongside other terms like ''weight loss,'' ''romantic/honeymoon'' and ''mineral springs.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Kills Himself After Shootings
description: A man forced his way into his ex-girlfriend's apartment in Jackson Heights last night, shot and wounded her and her friend, and then fatally shot himself, the police and neighbors said. The man, identified as Oscar Cano, fired a .38 caliber pistol at the woman, identified by the landlord as Zorayda D'Alejandro, 32, about 8:30 p.m., injuring her hand. He then shot the man who was with her, and then shot himself in the head. Ms. D'Alejandro's friend was in critical condition last night at Elmhurst Hospital Center. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: In Case of Recycling, Beware: Black Humor Can Fade to Gray
description: One generation's groundbreaker becomes another generation's formula. The original is cut down and remade in cheaper material. Joe Hortua's second play, ''Between Us,'' which opened on Tuesday at the Manhattan Theater Club and runs through May 30, has this made-over look and feel. The first act, directed with a heavy hand by Christopher Ashley, is a sitcom take on ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' Characters keep walking meaningfully across the stage to confront one another or to pick up a significant prop. The direction doesn't change in the second act, but the playwright tries harder to be himself.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Turmeric Benefits Tied To Cystic Fibrosis
description: A substance in turmeric, the principal ingredient of curry, may help correct a cellular malfunction that lies behind the deadly disease cystic fibrosis, according to a study published in the journal Science today. Nine out of 10 mice with the disease survived at least 10 weeks when fed large amounts of the compound, called curcumin. Only 4 out of 10 mice lived that long when left untreated, said Dr. Michael J. Caplan of the Yale medical school, who led the research. Clinical trials, set to begin this summer, will determine whether curcumin works in humans and has any side effects, he said. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Maine Takes A Cautious Path On Its Pensions
description: After being hammered in the financial markets for the last few years, many pension funds are turning to riskier investments, hoping that hedge funds, venture capital and the like will fuel returns and cover recent losses. But Maine has drawn a different lesson from the recent pension woes. Instead of shooting high, it is deliberately aiming for low, but guaranteed, investment income to pay for the retirement benefits of its workers.

description: Mets third baseman Ty Wigginton, who has been hospitalized twice this week after fainting once and nearly fainting again, was placed on the disabled list yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Explodes In Kandahar
description: Signs were growing of an urban bombing campaign by the Taliban as another bomb exploded overnight in the bazaar of the southern city of Kandahar. A man was killed and may have been setting the explosive at the time, the local military commander said. International peacekeeping forces, meanwhile, said they had arrested 17 people in Kabul, some of them with explosives. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: The One Constant in the N.F.L. Draft Is ESPN
description: Is it the National Football League draft or ESPN's N.F.L. draft? Is the league simply a character in the ESPN empire -- James Bond to MGM, Roger Rabbit in Toontown? Commissioner Paul Tagliabue appears at regular intervals with a jersey, a smile and a draft pick to establish league involvement. But the constant faces tomorrow at noon Eastern time and Sunday at 11 a.m. will be the ESPN troops in Madison Square Garden, Bristol, Conn., the ''Cold Pizza'' studio and the draft headquarters of each team.

title: Washington Approves 5-State Pool to Buy Drugs for 900,000 Medicaid Recipients
description: The Bush administration on Thursday approved plans by five states to pool their purchasing power and seek deeper discounts on prescription drugs for more than 900,000 Medicaid recipients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIRTES, DAVID
description: SPIRTES--David. The officers, directors and members of the Fire Island Association record, with deep sorrow, the untimely passing, on April 15, of David W. Spirtes, Superintendent of the Fire Island National Seashore. In less than a year on Fire Island, he changed the atmosphere from one of distrust and contention to one of open communication and cooperation. To his family and colleagues in the National Park Service, we extend our most sincere condolences.

title: A Muscular Idealism
description: Sargent Shriver is 88 years old, which is all the proof we need that time is flying. That he is not better known is a scandal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Found Dead
description: A woman was found dead in her apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, apparently strangled by someone she knew, law enforcement officials said. Her children, 5 and 3, were in the apartment, on McDonough Street, at the time of the killing, though it was not clear whether they had witnessed it, the officials said. The woman's body was found in her bed about noon, the police said. Neighbors said she had lived with her children in the building for about two years. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: British tabloids, so famous for their restraint and decorum, are waxing indignant that on ''48 Hours'' on Wednesday night CBS showed a grainy, indistinct black-and-white photograph of Diana, Princess of Wales, moments after her fatal 1997 car crash. So are some relatives of the victims: Diana's younger brother, Earl Spencer, said the family was ''shocked and sickened'' by CBS's decision.

title: Buried in a World of Props, A Young Man Comes to Life
description: Deep inside the clammy, weird-for-weird's sake world of ''Rhinoceros Eyes,'' set mostly in the bowels of a cluttered store for movie props, Chep (Michael Pitt), a pathologically reclusive young clerk, sleeps among a pile of mannequins when he's not scavenging through the junk for his boss, Bundy (Matt Servitto). Swallowing his words in ''ers'' and ''ums,'' his wide, rabbity eyes surveying the world with an expression of perpetual alarm, Chep might be a geeky young cousin of James Dean wrestling with some unspecified trauma. And Mr. Pitt, the movies' arty male ingnue of the moment, plays his character's cowering intensity for all it's worth.

description: One of the gyroscopes that keeps the International Space Station in the right position has failed, a development that will require an extra spacewalk for astronauts to fix, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Thursday.

title: A Concert Opera With Moments of Parody
description: Christopher Guest, the director of pseudo-documentary films on dog shows, folk music, and other quirky areas of human endeavor, probably wouldn't make one about opera, which is too specific and limited in appeal even for him. Yet the Opera Orchestra of New York's concert performance of "La Gioconda" on April 20 bore strong resemblances to one of Mr. Guest's movies, treading a fine line between high seriousness and blatant parody.

title: Rumsfeld Era at Pentagon May Be Prolonged
description: WASHINGTON -- One of the most intriguing questions during this very political year is what President Bush's national security team will look like if the president manages to defeat his Democratic challenger in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEILL, LEO C.

The communities in the Valley and those of us who worked with him will long benefit from the clarity of his thinking and the warmth that informed his guidance. title: Police Say Couple's Deaths May Be Tied to Earlier Threat
description: Last month, Colin Myles, 24, and his girlfriend, Nicole Wheeler, 19, were threatened after Mr. Myles identified three people who had attacked him in what law enforcement officials say may have been a drug-related robbery. Now, the authorities are investigating whether their deaths this week were connected to that threat.

description: Aformer Suffolk County legislator and a Suffolk Off-Track Betting Corporation official, both onetime advisers to County Executive Steve Levy, were charged yesterday with taking bribes in exchange for inside information on county contracts, the district attorney's office said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Growth
description: The core industrial sector of India's economy, which includes the refining, electrical and coal sectors, grew 7.1 percent in the fiscal year ended in March, according to a government report. The sector also includes the crude oil, cement and steel industries and accounts for more than a fourth of the country's industrial output. It is generally seen as an advance indicator of industrial growth. Saritha Rai (NYT)

The higher price, which has been approved by MCI's board, comes in response to a bid by Calais, a consortium of three Brazilian phone companies. Although MCI has emerged from bankruptcy, the deal must still be approved by a bankruptcy court in New York. The hearing to approve Embratel's sale is scheduled for April 27. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

description: The New York City Fire Department, while retaining a strong esprit de corps after the Sept. 11 attack, is nonetheless hurt by an inability to communicate during fires and other emergencies, a new workplace study reports.

title: Mixing It Up Brazilian-Style, With Capoeira and Flying Feet
description: DanceBrazil opened its two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a clear and mostly exhilarating lesson in the fusion of disparate dance styles and traditions. Modern dance seemed at times to be pushing up like a volcanic eruption through a baseline of capoeira, the Afro-Brazilian kickboxing form, with limbs and air-stabbing flexed feet flying out from cantilevering bodies.

title: Mussina Lasts Longer but Comes Up Short
description: Derek Jeter stood by his locker before Thursday's game against the Chicago White Sox, speaking with a group of reporters about the Yankees' coming series with the Boston Red Sox. Jason Giambi, who had just given an interview on the same topic, tossed Jeter a line.

title: Grand Jury to Examine Shooting Of Unarmed Teenager by Officer
description: Prosecutors will present to a grand jury the case of an unarmed 16-year-old boy who was shot on Wednesday by an off-duty court officer being attacked by a group of people, a spokesman for Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney, said yesterday.

title: House Sets Up Quick Elections If Its Members Die in Attack
description: Fearing that a terrorist attack on the Capitol could decimate the legislative branch, the House overwhelmingly approved a measure on Thursday that would provide for quick special elections if 100 or more of its members were killed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Manslaughter Conviction In Crash
description: A jury convicted a man of manslaughter yesterday, 18 months after he fled from the police while driving a stolen car and struck another driver, who later died. The jury deliberated for four hours before finding Robert Pearson, 24, guilty of second-degree manslaughter after a one-week trial. He will be sentenced on May 10 by Supreme Court Justice Mark H. Spires, and faces up to 15 years in prison. The crime took place on October 22, 2002, when Mr. Pearson was pulled over by police while driving a Lexus that had been reported stolen in Haverstraw, N.Y. He fled with the vehicle, running stop signs and a red light at high speeds, until he struck a car driven by Kevin Fisher, 25, a barber on his way home from work.

title: F.D.A. Seeks Reports of Stent Problems
description: The Food and Drug Administration is actively seeking reports of possible problems with a stent that came on the market last month, saying it has heard of serious medical complications in some cases.

title: Share Prices Rise on Higher Forecasts for 2004 Earnings
description: Stocks rose yesterday after companies like eBay and Caterpillar raised their 2004 earnings forecasts, fueling optimism that profit will increase enough this year to warrant further gains in share prices.

title: U.N. Moves to Disassociate Itself From Remarks by Envoy to Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 23  United Nations officials moved today to disassociate the organization from damning remarks about Israel and American policy in the Middle East made by its special envoy to Iraq, Lakhdar Brahimi.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Western Digital Posts 12% Profit Decline
description: Western Digital, the company that makes the disk drives that are used in Microsoft's Xbox video game console, said yesterday that profit in the third quarter fell 12 percent as prices declined during a seasonally slow time of the year. Net income dropped to $47.9 million, or 22 cents a share, from $54.5 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the quarter ended March 26 rose 6.1 percent, to $748.9 million from $705.8 million. The company said it was seeing benefits from its acquisition last year of Read-Rite. The shares rose 22 cents, to $9.20, in extended trading after the report. They fell $1.27, or 12 percent, to $8.98, in regular trading.

title: Summer Tenants, Both the Fickle and the Faithful
description: SOMETIME in the next week or so, Gladys Bender, 85, will pack up her 1999 Mazda Proteg and head north from her home in Delray, Fla., to Columbia County, N.Y., and the house she has rented for the last 11 years. The sheets stocked by the landlord don't quite fit the beds; the towels, frankly, are getting a bit threadbare, and the oven's stated temperature is frequently more than a few degrees removed from reality. ''You could be fussy,'' Ms. Bender said, but why bother? ''It's so nice to go there each May and know where everything is. You walk in and you're very much at home.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 'Green Buildings' Bill Introduced
description: In recognition of Earth Day yesterday, the City Council introduced a bill that would require the use of environmentally friendly designs in new buildings, and major renovations of existing ones that are owned and funded by the city. Speaker Gifford Miller, left, and Councilman James F. Gennaro said that the legislation -- known as the ''Green Buildings Bill'' -- will substantially reduce the city's electricity consumption, air pollution and water use. ''How we construct our buildings can have a major effect on our health and the environment,'' Mr. Miller said. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 8 about an apology by the state of Illinois for expelling Mormons in 1846 misstated the relationship between Anne Burke, an Illinois appellate justice, and Representative Daniel J. Burke, who were instrumental in bringing about the apology. They are sister-in-law and brother-in-law, not sister and brother.

title: Families Chasing Dream in U.S. Mourn Sons Killed in Crash
description: On the outskirts of Romero de Guzman, a small town in the Mexican state of Michoacan, Macario Bravo worked fields of potato and corn, dreaming of a new life for his family. He had heard of a place up north where anything seemed possible: a town on the edge of a racetrack where men were paid hundreds of dollars a week -- a windfall, by Romero de Guzman standards -- to keep horses clean and fed.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton
description: The senator from New York answered readers' questions on health care.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Freed Man Files Claim
description: A man who was released after serving 24 years in prison on a murder charge that was dismissed has filed a claim for damages against the city of Long Beach and Los Angeles County. The man, Thomas Lee Goldstein, 55, left, was freed April 2 after prosecutors conceded that they lacked sufficient evidence to retry him for the 1979 shotgun killing of John McGinest. The Long Beach city attorney, Robert Shannon, said the city would not consider the claim because Mr. Goldstein never followed up on a $2 million claim he filed against the city in 1998. Mr. Shannon denied any wrongdoing by Long Beach police who investigated the case. Five federal judges have said Mr. Goldstein's constitutional rights were violated at his 1980 trial. The key witness recanted his testimony before dying last year. Ben Bergman (NYT)

title: Even Free Music May Not Get The Audience It Deserves
description: The summer performances in Central Park by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic remain the classic classical freebies in town, but you hardly have to wait until summer to hear high-quality music on the cheap. For chamber music fans, or simply curious listeners, several series offer free or deeply discounted tickets to worthy performances. Two such concerts took place over the weekend: the Shanghai String Quartet performed free on Saturday night at the City University Graduate Center, and the Orion String Quartet played for a song at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Pakistan-Born Architect Arrested In Terror Plan
description: The police arrested a man in Sydney who they said was a member of a cell plotting terrorist attacks in Australia. The man, Faheem Khalid Lodhi, 34, a Pakistani-born architect, had been under surveillance for several months. Among the group's targets was Australia's electricity grid, they said. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda In Russia
description: Saying it expects strong growth in Russian auto sales, the Honda Motor Company said that it had established a subsidiary in Russia to sell its cars, motorcycles and other products. The move is the latest by Honda to increase sales in markets outside of North America and Japan. A cut in Russia's consumption tax and the country's expected entry into the World Trade Organization in a few years will help sales of cars, Honda said. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Mideast Investment In Volkswagen
description: The Persian Gulf state of Abu Dhabi could emerge as the second-largest shareholder in Volkswagen in a deal under which Volkswagen and two Middle Eastern partners would buy a Dutch fleet management company from ABN Amro bank for 2 billion euros ($2.3 billion). The fleet company, LeasePlan, manages 1.2 million vehicles, which would expand Volkswagen's presence in a profitable business. Volkswagen may finance the acquisition by selling shares to an Abu Dhabi-linked investment company. Volkswagen's largest shareholder, the German state of Lower Saxony, which owns 18 percent, said it supported the plan. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Policy Barring Ex-Baathists From Key Iraq Posts Is Eased
description: The American administration here said Thursday that it was loosening a policy aimed at purging the Iraqi government of members of the former governing Baath Party.

title: Elegy for the Unflinching Conscience of Haiti
description: In recent months, between grim bulletins from the Middle East, Haiti has periodically found its way back into the headlines. As has so often been the case over the last 30 years, the news has been confusing, dispiriting and sad. The turbulence that led to the removal of Jean-Bertrand Aristide from Haiti's presidency gives ''The Agronomist,'' a superb new documentary by Jonathan Demme, a melancholy timeliness. Its hero, Jean Dominique, embodies the fragile, perpetual hope that Haiti, so long tormented by foreign meddlers and domestic dictators, might someday nurture a just and decent political order.

description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon could still pursue his proposal for an Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip even if his own party rejects the plan in a referendum on May 2, a senior government official said Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, GREG (ALLEN G.)
description: HARRIS--Greg (Allen G.). April 19, 2004 in New York. Age 78. WWII Tuskegee Airman. Longtime journalist: Chicago Defender, Amsterdam News, Time, Newsweek, Life, CBS Radio, NBC News. First black television correspondent in Vietnam. Former National Vice President and New York State President, Air Force Association. Born: Chicago. Loved by his wife of 39 years, Jo Ann Harris. Adoring father and grandfather to daughter Liz Harris, her husband Edward Dugger III, of Boston, and their children Cyrus, Langston and Chloe Dugger; and to son David Harris, his wife Janet Walton of Medford, MA, and their son Quentin Walton Harris. Family requests no flowers. Donations to honor his lifelong passion and dedication to education may be made to the CMA Bronzeville Foundation, c/o Earl E. Strayhorn, Trustee, 3519 S. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
description: The country's top drug maker Ranbaxy Laboratories said its net profit rose 10.4 percent in the quarter, helped by sales of newer drugs. Ranbaxy, based in New Delhi, said its profit rose to 1.91 billion rupees ($43.9 million) from 1.73 billion rupees ($39.7 million) a year earlier. Ranbaxy receives 80 percent of its revenue by exporting generic versions of drugs, mainly to the United States. The company said it had applied for 38 generic equivalents with the Food and Drug Administration. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Senior Port Officials Re-Elected
description: The 12-member board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday unanimously re-elected Anthony R. Coscia as chairman and Charles A. Gargano as vice chairman at the bistate agency that operates the region's airports, bridge and tunnel crossings and marine port operations. Both men will serve one-year terms. In their regular monthly meeting at the agency's Manhattan headquarters, the board also appointed Michael F. O'Connor, a former chief of the New York City Transit Police, to the newly created post of chief of public safety and emergency management. Mr. O'Connor will bring together the operations of the agency's 1,600-member police force and its emergency management operations.They also named Samuel J. Plumeri Jr., 57, superintendent of the police force. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

description: Two trains loaded with fuel collided and exploded in a North Korean railroad station Thursday, killing or injuring an estimated 3,000 people, according to South Korean government officials and news reports.

title: A Singer Keeps Embellishment to a Minimum
description: The gravity that the Brazilian contralto Virginia Rodrigues projects in concert is not the sort of sexy, free-spirited passion traditionally associated with Brazilian pop singers. Nor does it spring directly from the rhythmically dense Afro-Brazilian chant she absorbed as a child growing up on the streets of Salvador de Bahia. Her signature style is a transcendent plainness.

title: WellChoice Ends an Attempt To Acquire Oxford Health Plans
description: WellChoice, the parent of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, announced yesterday that it had ended talks to acquire Oxford Health Plans. The collapse of the talks revived speculation that WellChoice, along with Empire, the largest health insurer in New York state, might become a target for an acquisition attempt by a bigger national managed care company.

title: On Eve of Draft, Giants Have A Hand to Play
description: Their dismal, coach-killing 4-12 season last year landed them the No. 4 pick in the N.F.L. draft, but until recently the Giants had no idea it would catapult them into the middle of all the drama on the eve of the draft.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Class-Action On Behalf Of Inmates
description: Lawyers in Atlanta filed a federal class-action lawsuit against Sheriff Jacquelyn H. Barrett of Fulton County on behalf of county jail inmates who they said were regularly incarcerated for days or weeks beyond their release dates because of bureaucratic delays. The inmates were also subjected to strip searches after charges were dismissed or bond granted, said one of the lawyers filing the suit, Charles B. Pekor. Until 2002 the jail was under the supervision of a federal judge because of overcrowding, partly because of bureaucratic delays in handling inmates, said Tamara Serwer of the Southern Center for Human Rights, which represented inmates in that suit. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Earnings Drop As Costs Rise
description: PeopleSoft, the business-software maker fighting a hostile takeover bid by Oracle, said yesterday that earnings fell 37 percent as costs grew faster than sales. The company's shares declined as much as 7.1 percent. Net income fell to $24.2 million, or 7 cents a share, from $38.5 million, or 12 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 40 percent, to $643.1 million, from $460.3 million, outpaced by a 49 percent increase in total expenses.

title: China Reports Suspected Case Of SARS In Beijing
description: The Chinese government announced Thursday that a nurse in Beijing had been hospitalized with a suspected case of SARS and that five other people had been isolated with fevers. The authorities in Hong Kong also said a second suspected SARS patient had been discovered in eastern China.

title: You Are Feeling Sleepy. Don't Worry About Clues.
description: So much mumbo jumbo flutters around the subject of hypnosis that filmmakers have traditionally taken the license to fly it straight into the ozone with no regard for scientific accuracy. From the spirals and spooky aural squiggles of ''Spellbound'' through the paranoid, assassin-as-mental-robot politics of ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' hypnotism's supposed path to instant catharsis or calamity makes it the perfect glue for plugging up plot holes and spinning out fantasies.

title: AON IS SUBPOENAED BY NEW YORK'S ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: The Aon Corporation, the insurance brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, as part of an investigation into payments between insurance companies and brokers. Other insurance brokers are also being subpoenaed, Aon said. A company spokesman, Gary Sullivan, said that such compensation agreements were common and that the company disclosed any payments to clients. The investigation involved commissions and fees paid by an insurer based on services performed and the volume of business placed with the insurer, Sullivan said, citing the disclosure on Aon's Web site. A spokeswoman for Spitzer declined to comment.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Syndicate Suspected Of Looting Linen
description: The Western Cape government suspects that organized crime has stolen more than $3.5 million in hospital linens since 2001, including $1 million last year, and has asked the national government's investigative agency, the Scorpions, to find the miscreants. The provincial health minister suggested that entire truckloads had disappeared, noting that some pieces had turned up in a Barcelona flea market. But a lower-level official, noting that each patient receives an average of two visitors a day, suggested that petty theft alone could cause 100,000 pieces of linen to disappear annually. Whether criminals laundered the booty was unclear. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: It's a Boat! It'a Plane! It's a . . . Hovercraft!
description: PHIL WHITNEY and a few friends had just glided over a mass of lily pads, up a boat ramp and across a parking lot at Lake Osborne in South Florida when a freckle-nosed boy ran up to them. ''Can I see you fly?'' he asked.

title: Depressing News on Depression
description: Antidepressant drugs are being widely administered to children and adolescents despite increasing concern that the benefits have been oversold and some potentially dangerous side effects minimized. The jury is still out on whether the modest benefits of some of these drugs outweigh the small risks they impose. But the escalating debate makes us wonder, uneasily, whether doctors have been dispensing the pills far too cavalierly despite a dearth of evidence to support their value.

title: Mary McGrory, 85, Longtime Washington Columnist, Dies
description: Mary McGrory, an unapologetic liberal who chronicled 50 years of scandal, war, Congressional turmoil and political heartbreak as a columnist for The Washington Star and The Washington Post, died on Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital. She was 85.

title: Saudis Support A Jihad in Iraq, Not Back Home
description: On Wednesday morning, just hours before a suicide bomber demolished a Saudi police building in downtown Riyadh, the family of a young man was accepting congratulations for his death in the jihad over the border in Iraq, the one that enjoys no small support here.

title: Couple Takes Protest Up Tree In Central Park
description: Two people took off most of their clothes and climbed to the top of a tree in Central Park yesterday, drawing hundreds of onlookers and keeping dozens of police officers and rescue workers busy for four hours.

title: Freaky Future: An Awkward Teenager Finds Herself Fast-Forwarded to Adulthood
description: ''We need to remember what used to be good,'' says a character in the director Gary Winick's new comedy, ''13 Going on 30.'' That's not exactly the smartest remark to include in a movie that is essentially a retread of the Tom Hanks body-switch comedy ''Big.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Setback For Bill On Asbestos Lawsuits
description: A bill that would settle hundreds of thousands of lawsuits over asbestos exposure by creating a trust fund to compensate victims suffered a procedural defeat in the Senate when Republican backers of the measure failed to muster the 60 votes necessary to bring it up for consideration. The outcome was expected. But the vote, 50 to 47 in favor of taking up the bill, does not necessarily mean the measure is dead for this year. A senior judge on the federal appeals court in Philadelphia, Edward R. Becker, has been brokering talks between business groups and insurers, who will contribute to the fund, and labor unions, who represent workers injured by asbestos. Those talks will continue, and the Senate Republican and Democratic leaders, Bill Frist and Tom Daschle, have now agreed to join them personally. ''What we need to do is build on that momentum,'' Dr. Frist said. Sheryl Gay Stolberg (NYT)

title: Wigginton Is Hospitalized and Put on Disabled List
description: Mets third baseman Ty Wigginton, who has been hospitalized twice this week after fainting once and nearly fainting again, was placed on the disabled list yesterday.

Eight pitches, eight balls, two more walks for the San Francisco slugger. The announcers' point was that the Padres had such a big lead, Peavy could afford to throw a strike or two and risk another Bonds home run.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Real Estate Merger
description: The country's largest listed retail property group, Westfield Holdings, said it planned to acquire two associated trusts to create a global real estate company. Westfield, which is controlled by Frank Lowy, left, will acquire the Westfield Trust and the Westfield America Trust. His sons run the two trusts being acquired. The combined entity, which will be called the Westfield Group, will control 123 shopping centers in four countries. In the United States, Westfield has 66 malls in 14 states. John Shaw (NYT)

description: SAP Group, the world's leading business software maker, said licensing revenue rose 5 percent, to 370 million euros ($439 million) in the first quarter, helped by strong demand in the United States. While the increase of license sales, being the first in nearly three years, and net profit of 229 million euros ($272 million) were in line with analysts' expectations, SAP's total revenue fell short of it with only 2 percent growth, up to 1.56 billion euros ($1.86 billion). Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Suspected Car Thief Killled By Police
description: A Newark man died last night, several hours after he was shot by a police detective, the Newark police said. The man, Fernando Cruz, 32, was spotted by two plainclothes detectives from the department's vehicle theft unit driving a stolen Lexus at 1:15 p.m. They approached the car, but he sped away, dragging one of the detectives, James Arroyo, a short distance. The other detective, Anthony Brown, fired at Mr. Cruz and struck him in the torso. Mr. Cruz died at 7:45 p.m. at University Hospital, the police said. Mr. Cruz was on parole and had been convicted of seven felonies, the authorities said. The detectives, who were treated for minor injuries, will be placed on modified duty pending the outcome of an investigation, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Hong Kong's Democratic Yearning
description: China's Communist leaders aren't holding up their end of the ''one country, two systems'' deal on Hong Kong. A recent ruling by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress that Hong Kong cannot reform its political processes without Beijing's approval violates the spirit, and probably the letter, of the admittedly vague Basic Law, which has provided the constitutional framework for Hong Kong, a former British colony, since its return to China in 1997.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Bribe Charges In Suffolk
description: A former Suffolk County legislator and a Suffolk Off-Track Betting Corporation official, both onetime advisers to County Executive Steve Levy, were charged yesterday with taking bribes in exchange for inside information on county contracts, the district attorney's office said. The former legislator, Wayne Prospect, and the OTB official, Stephen Baranello, are accused of working together to take a bribe of more than $10,000 earlier this week from an undercover detective posing as a contractor, said the district attorney, Thomas Spota. They were charged with second-degree bribe receiving, a felony punishable by up to 15 years in prison; both pleaded not guilty at their arraignment yesterday. Vivian S. Toy (NYT)

title: Time Cuts 2 Top Positions
description: Time Inc. said yesterday in an internal memorandum that it had eliminated the positions of the presidents of two divisions, People and Sports Illustrated, in a measure that company executives said was meant to remove a layer of management.

title: Oh, Sure: Her Best Friend Is Mom
description: There is nothing more satisfying on television than snobbery -- scenes in which the main character is humiliated by haughty, mean-spirited authority figures.

title: All of European Antitrust Ruling Made Public
description: The European Commission released the full text of its antitrust ruling against Microsoft on Thursday, prompting a strong rebuttal from the company in a widely disseminated internal memorandum.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Van Drivers' Strike Strands Disabled Riders
description: About a thousand drivers who provide van service for disabled riders in New York City Transit's Access-a-Ride program walked off their jobs yesterday in a wage dispute. The walkout, by drivers who work for four private companies, stranded about 1,500 disabled people, a spokeswoman for the companies said. The four companies provide about half of the 6,000 rides a day in the program, according to transit officials, who are trying to shift most of the riders to the four remaining carriers. Others will be directed to livery cabs and ambulette services, and will be reimbursed. The striking drivers are members of Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union. Contract negotiations with the companies -- Maggie's Paratransit, Atlantic Paratrans, Transit Facility Management and MV Transportation -- have gone on since September. Calls to the union and its lawyers were not returned yesterday. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: An International Night of Dance
description: Dancers from several nations offered a lively program on April 16 at the Mulberry Street Theater as part of the Newsteps choreographers' series.

title: Furniture That Echoes Palazzo Walls
description: Painted furniture has been popular since the ancient Egyptians perfected the art of painting on wood. It goes in and out of fashion but never out of style. ''All you have to do is go to Versailles or any Italian palazzo to see how well painted furniture goes with everything else,'' said the veteran New York interior designer Tom Britt. ''The grander the palace, the more you see.''

title: What Went Wrong?
description: On April 11 of last year, just after U.S. forces took Baghdad, I warned that the Bush administration had a ''pattern of conquest followed by malign neglect,'' and that the same was likely to happen in Iraq. I'm sorry to say those worries proved justified.

title: City May Sue Over Showing Of Tests on TV
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, furious that questions from Tuesday's third-grade citywide reading test were broadcast on television, threatened yesterday to pursue legal action against the advocates who had made the test public and the media organizations that aired close-up images of it.

title: Saudis Report 5 Terror Suspects Killed in Clash in Jidda
description: RIYADH, April 23  An overnight gun battle between Saudi security services and a small enclave of the country's most wanted terrorists that erupted in the Red Sea port of Jidda ended with five suspects dead, including one who blew himself up rather than face capture, the Interior Ministry said today.

title: Pentagon Ban on Pictures Of Dead Troops Is Broken
description: The Pentagon's ban on making images of dead soldiers' homecomings at military bases public was briefly relaxed yesterday, as hundreds of photographs of flag-draped coffins at Dover Air Force Base were released on the Internet by a Web site dedicated to combating government secrecy.

title: Bush Administration Eases Economic Sanctions on Libya
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 — President Bush eased economic sanctions on Libya today, rewarding Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for renouncing weapons of mass destruction and opening opportunities for American companies to do business in his nation.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Sect Leader Sentenced
description: A federal judge sentenced Dwight York, a sect leader who goes by the names Malachi York and Maku: Chief Black Thunderbird Eagle, to 135 years in prison for child molesting and financial crimes. The victims were members of his sect, which he moved from a mosque in Brooklyn to an Egyptian-themed compound in Putnam County, Ga., in 1993 and called the United Nuwaubian Nation of Moors. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Employees Able To Cash Checks At Chase
description: The New York City Department of Finance said yesterday that it had taken steps to allow city employees to cash their checks at selected Chase Manhattan Bank branches today after the state suspended the license of a check-cashing service that many employees use. The New York State Banking Department issued a 30-day suspension order to Cashpoint Network Services Inc. on Wednesday, citing its failure to pay creditors and maintain its books and records, among other things. City finance officials said the suspension was expected to affect about 4,700 city employees who do not have checking accounts and regularly use the service to cash their paychecks. Cashpoint, which operates or oversees more than 400 neighborhood payment centers, was also used by residents to pay their parking tickets and their real estate and water and sewer bills. Hundreds of other Cashpoint centers across the state were also shut down. City finance officials urged people to pay their bills by mail, over the Internet or at the department's business centers. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Summer Romance, With a Lease
description: IT seems there are two kinds of summer renters: the monogamists for whom familiarity breeds content and who rent the same house year after year, and those with a more promiscuous bent -- restless souls whose attitude each summer seems to be ''so many houses, so little time.'' Page 2.

title: Infusing Mystical, New Age Lyrics With a Sense of Gravitas
description: Lizz Wright, a young jazz singer and songwriter of astonishing maturity and poise, proves what might be called the Stevie Wonder Rule of popular music: song lyrics with a mystical, new age bent register strongly only when infused with purpose and spirit by a powerful voice. Then they come to life, assume a weight and a complexity not found on the page and never seem quite the same again.

title: The Real War
description: Fans of the cartoon strip ''Doonesbury'' have been following the travails of B. D., the football-helmeted Vietnam vet who somehow wound up back under fire in Iraq. In a series of strips that one Colorado paper decried as unnecessarily ''graphic violent battlefield depictions,'' B. D. was wounded and lost his lower leg. Most of the response has apparently been far more positive than the Colorado newspaper's, but the strip's creator, Garry Trudeau, is lucky that he works with ink rather than film. In the real Middle East, an American worker in Kuwait was fired this week when a newspaper printed a photo she had taken of a cargo plane full of coffins draped in American flags.

title: Sales Abroad Help Amazon Post a Profit In 1st Quarter
description: Amazon.com reported first-quarter earnings of $111 million on Thursday, its first profit in a nonholiday quarter, led by lower prices and surging international sales.

title: Smaller Unions Handcuffed By City Pact, Leaders Say
description: Leaders of several New York City municipal unions criticized District Council 37 yesterday over the tentative three-year contract it reached this week with the Bloomberg administration, saying its reductions in benefits for new workers would apply to members of other civilian unions as well. The deal would reduce vacation, sick leave and other benefits for newly hired workers. Under the city's labor laws, District Council 37, as the largest municipal union, has the authority to bind most other civilian unions on benefits when it negotiates contracts.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Angolan Troops Abuse Congolese Miners
description: Congolese diamond miners working for years in Angola have been beaten, raped and driven out by Angolan forces, the aid group Doctors Without Borders reported. A team of doctors in southwestern Congo has been treating the Congolese victims, who fled a contested, remote mining area called Kaninda. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Court Ruling Backs Powers Of Governor In Budgeting
description: The State Legislature on Wednesday lost the latest round in a bitter and protracted legal battle over how much power the governor should have over New York's budget-making process.

title: St. John's Working With N.C.A.A.
description: St. John's is cooperating with N.C.A.A. investigators looking into charges made by Abe Keita, one of the Red Storm players dropped from the team last season, who said he had received payments of nearly $300 a month to play at the university since arriving in 1999. On March 3, Keita was also suspended from classes for a year for his role in a sex scandal. ''We're cooperating fully,'' St. John's athletics director, David Wegrzyn, said yesterday. ''We're working to respond to their requests for whatever information that can be of assistance.'' Joe Drape

title: Science Group Says U.S. Budget Plan Would Harm Research
description: The nation's largest general science group said Thursday that the Bush administration's proposed budget for the next five years could cut research financing at 21 of the 24 federal agencies that engage in it.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Sunday about the popularity of college admission prep camps misstated the number of companies offering such programs this summer and how long they have been available. There are at least four such companies, not three. The programs are not new; a company that was not mentioned in the article, Education Unlimited, based in Berkeley, Calif., says it has offered such a program for a decade. ( Go to Article )

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STANGOS, NIKOS

title: Bush, Campaigning in Florida, Promotes the Environment
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  President Bush sought to burnish his environmental credentials again today, this time in the state that was the most bitterly contested of all in 2000, Florida.

title: Top Rebel, a Convicted Killer, Surrenders to Police in Haiti
description: A rebel leader who is also a convicted murderer gave himself up to the police on Thursday in an elaborately choreographed surrender.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Had A Great Fall
description: Hospital officials in Cape Town said a man was ''in a relatively good condition, considering his ordeal'' after falling 19 stories from a hotel window in Sea Point, a fashionable suburb. The man, Nicholas Du Plooy, suffered two broken arms, a broken leg and an injured neck after falling at the Ritz Hotel but was otherwise uninjured. The police said they did not know why he fell, but did not suspect foul play. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Postseason Is Progress For Knicks
description: THE tough talk this week between the Nets and the Knicks created an interesting distraction to a one-sided rivalry: Tim Thomas of the Knicks insulted the Nets' Kenyon Martin, and Martin walked around practice yesterday wearing a tabloid back page taped to his jersey and called Thomas a career underachiever.

description: JACOBS--William B. Esq. Devoted husband of Sondra. Beloved father of Laura Levine (Kevin) & Andrew M. Jacobs (Amy). Loving brother of Jane Ross (Barry). The Yeshiva University family is grieved by the passing, in Jerusalem, of this kind, greatly beloved, and distinguished rabbinic leader, scholar, and author, the beloved father of Daniel (and Vivian) Chill, Deanne (and Dr. Leonard Z.) Shapiro, and Teme Goldman, whose family established the Libbie Chill Memorial Scholarship at Stern College for Women in memory of their mother, among their other benefactions. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Two Days That Live In Punditry
description: NATIONAL COLUMNISTS DAY came and went this week, and did anyone notice? The kids didn't call. There was no breakfast in bed. Nobody sent a card or flowers or, more appropriate for the occasion, a fruitcake.

title: Tennessee Wins Distance Medley
description: North Carolina had won the women's distance medley, one of the signature races at the Penn Relays, for three straight years. But the Tar Heels' best runner, Shalane Flanagan, is redshirting to prepare for the Olympic trials, and they were up against Tennessee, which won the N.C.A.A. indoor title.

title: 36 Hours | Charleston, S.C.
description: WITH its well-groomed streets lined with Colonial and antebellum mansions, gardens of magnolias and hibiscus and top-drawer antiques stores, Charleston can seem more like a series of postcards than the center of a metropolitan area with a half-million people. But as host to local events that have had grave national ramifications -- the first shots of the Civil War were fired in its harbor -- the city also has a layered and turbulent history. Not all of it is attractive. For almost two centuries Charleston thrived as a central port in the slave trade. Still, with walker-friendly dimensions, dozens of bed-and-breakfasts, upscale shopping and maybe the South's best restaurants outside New Orleans, it reveals itself as more than a pretty place. RICHARD B. WOODWARD

title: Lottery Numbers
Follow The Leader
description: In this year's presidential campaign, no wisdom is more conventional than the assumption that George W. Bush's re-election effort will succeed or fail along with the American mission in Iraq. If Iraq collapses, the reasoning goes, the Bush presidency will soon follow. And yet here was the president gaining ground, in several polls released this week, in the face of what were certainly the worst three weeks in Iraq since the United States deposed Saddam Hussein a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YEARDYE, TOM
description: YEARDYE--Tom. Suddenly, on April 21, age 73. Devoted husband to Anne and brother to June, much loved father of Gregory, Tamara and Daniel, and grandfather of Araminta. Funeral private. Flowers JH Kenyon Funeral Directors, 011 44 207 834 4624. Inquiries 011 44 207 591 7006.

title: Exuding Balanchine's Essence
description: After 18 years dancing at the New York State Theater, Wendy Whelan has the spirit and pacing of George Balanchine's ballets in her body -- the languid intensity of ''Episodes,'' the exuberant rapidity of the ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet,'' the elegance of ''Liebeslieder Walzer.'' Her muscles remember them. All they need is to be reminded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAYNE, FRANK A.
description: BAYNE -- Frank A. Died peacefully on April 18, 2004. Beloved husband of Maya, brother of Susan, father of Ian, Helen and Cornelia, grandfather of Michael, Bradley, Caitlyn, Alex and Addia. In his memory, donations may be made to the American Red Cross.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker Posts Profit
description: Helped by sales of its multiple sclerosis drug, Ribif, the biotechnology company Serono said its profit was up 76 percent in the first quarter. Analysts said Serono's profit of $106 million, up from $60 million in 2003, was better than expected. Serono, based in Geneva, said revenue rose 26 percent, to $557 million, and it raised its profit outlook for the current year. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Somber About War, but Giggling in 'Satyric Festival Song'
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company is letting audiences glimpse many periods of its founder's choreographic development in its engagement at City Center. Some bold works from the 1930's have proved especially exciting. Three were shown on Wednesday night.

description: SHLISKY -- Rose. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Theodore, Frederick and Louise, Susan and Howard Goldstein. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Dear sister. Funeral services Friday 2:30pm at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: A.I.G. PROFIT INCREASES ON HIGHER INSURANCE PRICES
description: The American International Group, the large insurer, said its first-quarter profit rose 36 percent after it raised property and casualty prices and expanded its life insurance and annuities business in Asia. Net income climbed to $2.66 billion, or $1.01 a share, from $1.95 billion, or 74 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose 25 percent, to $23.64 billion. Shares of the company, based in New York, rose 50 cents, to $73.70. The shares have risen 34 percent in the last year, beating the 29 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock insurance index.

title: Viacom's First-Quarter Profit Surged 60%, Topping Estimates
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit, fueled by a strong performance from its television and cable units, surged 60 percent, handily beating estimates.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LANDI, RUTH
description: LANDI--Ruth. April 23, 1905May 3, 2001. Dearest Mama, ''In life we loved you dearly, in death we do the same.'' Happy Birthday, Ruthie. Always, Googie & Ion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAIZEN, NANCY
description: RAIZEN--Nancy. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member Nancy Raizen and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alex C. Solowey, President

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Nets Shake Off Knicks' Best Shots
description: The Knicks hoped that Madison Square Garden possessed magical powers, that the spirit of playoff victories past would eliminate a sizable disparity in talent and athleticism. And if the Garden, home to its first playoff game in three years, could not change the tenor of their first-round Eastern Conference series with the Nets, then perhaps Tim Thomas's explosive remarks on Wednesday could.

title: EUROPE ASKS GLAXOSMITHKLINE TO STRENGTHEN WARNINGS
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the drug maker, should strengthen warnings about severe withdrawal symptoms when patients stop taking its depression medicine Paxil, a European Union advisory panel said. ''Patients must not stop their treatment abruptly, except on medical advice,'' the Union's Committee for Proprietary Medicinal Products said. It also recommended that Paxil not be given to children and adolescents because of the potential for increased suicidal behavior. Glaxo, based in Britain, will have to include symptoms related to withdrawals in greater detail on Paxil's label, Glaxo European's medical director said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Cement Business's Profit Rises
description: The cement company Cemex said that sales and profits rose in the first quarter as a result of economic growth in its major markets. Overall sales rose 13 percent, to $1.8 billion, and income nearly quadrupled to $311 million. The company said the rise in income was a result of a better operating performance, the peso's strength against the dollar and better results for its securities trading. Sales increased 10 percent in Mexico, Cemex's largest market, and 14 percent in the United States, its No.2 market. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: New York
description: VAN DRIVERS' STRIKE STRANDS DISABLED RIDERS About a thousand drivers who provide van service for disabled riders in New York City Transit's Access-a-Ride program walked off their jobs yesterday in a wage dispute. The walkout, by drivers who work for four private companies, stranded about 1,500 disabled people, a spokeswoman for the companies said. The four companies provide about half of the 6,000 rides a day in the program, according to transit officials, who are trying to shift most of the riders to the four remaining carriers. Others will be directed to livery cabs and ambulette services, and will be reimbursed. The striking drivers are members of Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union. Contract negotiations with the companies - Maggie's Paratransit, Atlantic Paratrans, Transit Facility Management and MV Transportation - have gone on since September. Calls to the union and its lawyers were not returned yesterday.Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Shopping List | Weekend Office
description: WE would be the last to encourage a summer of working weekends. But what about those mini-vacations, three- or four-day second home stays? The guilt is far more palatable if you bring your laptop and have a space to use it. We're especially partial to portable office components that look as appealing as the climate outside. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: A Singular Voice From Washington
description: It was always a treat to watch Mary McGrory buttonhole a lawmaker or cabinet secretary in a Washington corridor and present a punishing question or two in her disarmingly sweet way. Across five decades as a singular journalist, Mary tracked and hounded the political class -- ''Capitol strivers and pretenders,'' she called them -- with a crackling mix of insight and affection. She died on Wednesday at the age of 85, a year after a stroke put a stop to her lyrical prose.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS IRAQ SOVEREIGNTY COULD BE LIMITED
description: The Bush administration's plans for a new caretaker government in Iraq would place severe limits on its sovereignty, including only partial command over its armed forces and no authority to enact new laws, administration officials said Thursday.

title: Former N.F.L. Player Killed in Afghanistan
description: Pat Tillman, whose decision to give up a lucrative N.F.L. career to join the Army Rangers made him one of the most public examples of patriotism in the aftermath of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was killed Thursday in fighting in Afghanistan, a United States military official said yesterday.

description: Eli Manning is too young to remember the bruises his father, Archie, brought home as a quarterback with the New Orleans Saints. The stories have been passed down in anecdotes. Although some are funny, others serve as cautionary tales.

description: Can a carved and painted Native American mask from the 19th century provide the same aesthetic frisson as, say, a 20th-century Modernist work? By the standards of Charles and Valerie Diker, longtime collectors, yes indeed. In their Manhattan apartment they prove the point by setting out top-flight historical Native American objects with works by Joan Mir, Mark Rothko, Louise Nevelson and others of the Modernist persuasion.

title: The Bad Boys Who Burned Out but Never Faded Away
description: As you watch the riveting, all-elbows-and-knuckles documentary ''MC5: A True Testimonial,'' you may wonder how long it can gingerly bypass the piles of syringes, resentment and bad karma that mark the path to ''Behind the Music,'' VH1's video tribute to rock 'n' roll wreckage. For most of its running time, the director David C. Thomas actually manages to keep the film charging ahead of the wastrel clichs that dot those VH1 burn-out chronicles, because we're not just using one eye to catch a cobbled-together archive about Milli Vanilli or some band that beat the odds to one-hit wonderland.

title: Residential Real Estate; A Rare Condo Conversion For a West Side Building
description: An Upper West Side landlord is in the process, rare in recent years, of converting a rental building to a condominium. Two weeks ago, the first 15 of the 98 apartments in the 20-story prewar building at 172 West 79th Street, which is now called the Hopkins, were offered for sale.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Authorities Crack Down On Piracy
description: Law enforcement officials in the United States and 10 other countries conducted more than 120 searches around the world this week in an effort to disrupt Internet groups pirating illegal computer software, games, movies and music, federal officials said yesterday. No arrests were made, but officials said they have identified nearly 100 people whom they suspect of trafficking in tens of millions of dollars worth of pirated Internet products. American investigators conducted searches in 27 states, seizing computers and computer servers in some cases, with foreign searches executed in Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Israel, the Netherlands, Singapore and Sweden. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

Then there's the rapper Lil' Kim, who modeled for her cover in a minidress zipped down to her navel, her Mercedes-Benz G500 peeking through in the background.

title: Blair's Shift In Agenda Puts Euro In Question
description: At a news conference on Thursday, Prime Minister Tony Blair devoted much time to defending his contentious about-face decision to hold a referendum on a new European constitution. But behind the furor over his abrupt change of course lay a less obvious but equally far-reaching question: has the prospect of Britain joining the euro single currency receded so far as to be unthinkable?

title: A Shift in Testimony in Ex-Banker's Trial
description: The retrial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston investment banker accused of obstruction of justice, may have tipped in his favor yesterday as the prosecution's strongest witness appeared to temper some of the most damaging testimony he had offered during the first trial.

title: U.S. Charges Defense Lawyer With Fraud and Obstruction
description: A Manhattan defense lawyer known for feistiness and a touch of drama was charged yesterday with fraud, obstruction of justice and other crimes. Prosecutors suggested that she was a drug abuser who was romantically involved with a client who has turned on her and is cooperating with them.

title: WEYERHAEUSER TO PAY $14 MILLION TO SETTLE CLAIMS
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company agreed to pay $14 million to settle claims it monopolized the market for alder-saw log, a wood used to make furniture, flooring and finished lumber, the company said yesterday. The claims, made in a suit filed by Coast Mountain Hardwoods in United States District Court in Portland, Ore., originally sought $820 million in damages. Weyerhaeuser, which admitted no liability in the settlement, said it would take a charge of about $9 million, or 4 cents a share, in the first quarter. Weyerhaeuser acquired Coast Mountain in late 2000, leaving rights to the alder-saw suit with the previous owners.

title: He's a Meek Bookkeeper, but Don't Get Him Riled
description: The title of the director Yoji Yamada's minor character drama, the initially slow-going ''Twilight Samurai,'' may evoke an image of duels between volatile warriors as the setting sun silhouettes their early-evening battles. But the film's name actually refers to a taciturn, devoted -- and impoverished -- widower in the Edo period, Seibei Iguchi (Hiroyuki Sanada), who dashes home at dusk to spend time with his young daughters and ailing mother.

title: All the President's Numbers
description: Polls are to Washington what box scores are to cities that have a baseball team: they are scrutinized obsessively by partisans. This week the news has been especially startling. After weeks of accusations of Bush administration negligence (or worse) before the 9/11 commission and bloody unrest in Iraq, George W. Bush has ticked past John Kerry in three new national polls.

A generous and gentle man, he was a loyal and trustworthy friend. Funeral services will be held at Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY on Sunday, April 25 at 12:30PM. In lieu of floral tributes, please send donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Charities Surprise Donor Foundations With Bluntness
description: The world of charities, the world of soliciting and spending other people's money, is governed by a principle so obvious that it has inspired at least three clichs: Beggars can't be choosers. Silence is golden. Don't bite the hand that feeds you.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Parmalat USA Corp., New York, a bankrupt subsidiary of Parmalat Finanziaria S.p.A., Milan, Italy's largest food company, reached an agreement with the lender General Electric Capital, a unit of General Electric, Fairfield, Conn., that buys more time to find a buyer for its assets without defaulting on a $35 million loan.

title: A Demon Gallery of Glory Hounds
description: THIS is what they always wanted, isn't it? A clear shot at the big time, where people would have to pay attention to them? More than a decade after they first surfaced to critical shudders and head-scratching, the unhappy have-nots of ''Assassins'' -- the glitteringly dark musical by Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman about Americans who dream of killing their country's presidents -- have finally made it to Broadway.

title: Work Restarts On Projects Hurt by Strife, Officials Say
description: Work on rebuilding Iraq's infrastructure is recovering from a near halt at the height of the violence earlier this month, project officials said on Thursday, though 10 percent of the foreign workers remain out of Iraq for safety and little is being done at 10 percent of the projects.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Oh, they're gearing up for success down on Downing Street, all right.

title: At Eco-Spas, It's Nature And Nurture
description: WATER is everywhere at El Monte Sagrado resort in Taos, N.M. It pours over small, rocky waterfalls on the leafy grounds. It trickles through a trough at the base of a curving wall in the resort's luxurious spa. It fills a rough-hewn artificial ''swimming hole'' outside, where back-to-nature bathers blithely commune with goldfish and trout, while children staying at the resort dip in borrowed fishing poles, and with a little barefoot perseverance, try to catch a trout for dinner. (Goldfish are strictly catch and release.) The constant gurgling is intoxicating in the high, dry desert of Taos. It whispers of life, growth and renewal.

title: Allies Suspect Al Qaeda Link to Bombings in Basra; Death Toll Is Reduced
description: As the authorities scoured the sites of five nearly simultaneous car bombings that killed dozens of people here on Wednesday, allied military officials said the attacks bore the hallmarks of the Qaeda terrorist network but said they did not have proof.

description: Two years ago, shopping for a sporty Chevrolet Cavalier, Jessica Coutsonikas took the route of many a first-time car-buyer short on cash but long on desire: she decided to lease.

description: When questions were raised last month about whether a 27-year-old John Kerry had attended a Kansas City meeting of Vietnam Veterans Against the War where the assassination of senators was discussed, the Kerry presidential campaign went into action.

title: Congressional Memo; A Longtime Courtesy Loses In the Closely Split Senate
description: As leaders of the Senate, Bill Frist, a Republican, and Tom Daschle, a Democrat, already spend a lot of time together. Now, Dr. Frist is even planning to visit South Dakota, the home state of his opposite number.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: A SETBACK FOR GOV. BUSH A state appeals court panel rejected two efforts by Gov. Jeb Bush to dismiss a challenge to his intervention in the case of a brain-damaged woman, Terri Schiavo. Mrs. Schiavo's husband, Michael, filed the suit last fall after the Legislature approved a measure letting Mr. Bush order reinsertion of Mrs. Schiavo's feeding tube. Several courts had given Mr. Schiavo permission to remove the tube. Mrs. Schiavo's parents fought the removal, and Mr. Bush, a Republican, joined them. Mr. Schiavo contended that the new law was unconstitutional. Mr. Bush's legal objections have stalled the case. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: A Beer Company Responds to the Low-Carb Crowd, Saying Its Product Isn't at Fault
description: As if dieting were not complicated enough -- picky eaters who just scraped through high school chemistry are expected to nod knowingly about net carbohydrates as a percentage of glycemic load -- a beer company has now loudly attacked the South Beach diet over a chemical that may or may not lurk in beer and may or may not make any difference if it does.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Firm Sues Connecticut Over Suspension of Auto Emissions Tests
description: One day after Connecticut announced that it was suspending auto emissions testing because a preliminary audit revealed flaws in the program that caused false readings, the company hired to do the testing filed suit against the state.

title: Soldier Is Granted Permission To See Terminally Ill Mother
description: A soldier serving in Iraq whose mother has been found to have terminal cancer will be allowed to return home to Wisconsin, an Army spokesman said Friday.

title: Corrections

More than twice as many gave that response in the latest poll, not ''almost'' twice as many.

title: A Compromised Voting System
description: California's secretary of state, Kevin Shelley, is expected to decide in the next week whether the state's electronic voting machines can be used in November. His office has just issued two disturbing studies -- one on machine malfunctions in last month's primary, another on misconduct by one of the nation's leading voting machine manufacturers -- that make a strong case against the current system. Refusing to certify the state's electronic voting machines at this late date is a serious step, but there are compelling reasons for Mr. Shelley to decertify some, and perhaps all, of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRITSCH, PETER H.
description: FRITSCH--Peter H. 85, on April 22, 2004 from complications of emphysema. Austrian born, but a New Yorker to the core, he is mourned by his wife Theresa, his children Erica Bell, Peter Nicholas Fritsch, and Christina Fritsch, and granddaughters, Nora and Callie.

title: A 'Bone Woman' Chronicles the World's Massacres
description: CLEA KOFF was present at the big events of the 1990's: Rwanda, Bosnia, Kosovo. Just out of graduate school, she was not a fledgling diplomat, nor a journalist. She was wearing overalls, protective gloves and boots.

title: Jackson's Indictment Clouds Future Deals
description: Michael Jackson's indictment on Wednesday by a grand jury in Santa Barbara on charges of child molestation will only intensify Mr. Jackson's difficulties in continuing his career as a recording artist and businessman, his former advisers say.

In lieu of floral tributes, please send donations to American Cancer Society.

description: In traditions dating from Orson Welles's movie ''Citizen Kane'' or Evelyn Waugh's novel ''Scoop,'' the dealings between rival newspaper bosses might be presumed to be robust, not to say bare-knuckled.

title: For Abortion Rights Cause, a New Diversity
description: When Kalpana Krishnamurthy rallies supporters here this weekend at a march for abortion rights, the first such national gathering in 12 years, she will be doing so as director of the Third Wave Foundation, a nationwide feminist group.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Executive Named
description: Adecco, the world's largest employment services company, said it had named Jim Fredholm, left an executive at Deutsche Post, as chief financial officer to succeed Felix Weber, who stepped down in January after disclosing an accounting scandal at a division, Adecco Staffing North America. Mr. Fredholm, 51, managed a cost-cutting program at Deutsche Post World Net, where he oversaw a merger with the global delivery company DSL last year, Addeco said. He previously worked as the chief financial officer of Danza, a Deutsche Post unit. He will assume his new post on June 1. Mr. Weber resigned in January. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: McDonald's Reprimanded
description: The authorities have reprimanded the McDonald's Corporation for illegal working conditions found at 39 of its 54 fast-food restaurants in Switzerland during an investigation, according to a published report. Executives from McDonald's and officials from the Swiss state secretariat for economic affairs in Bern are scheduled to meet next week to resolve the matter, a spokeswoman for the secretariat said. The report found that McDonald's had violated labor laws by making staff members work more than six days in a row, without breaks during some shifts, and by putting 18-year-olds on night shifts. McDonald did not contest the facts in the report but said that the country's regulations were becoming too restrictive and some were obsolete. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture with an entry in the National Briefing column on Thursday about an appeals court ruling upholding the murder conviction of Ernest Avants in the 1966 killing of a sharecropper, Ben Chester White, was published in error. It showed Peter H. Coors, who is seeking the Republican nomination for Senate in Colorado, not Mr. Avants.

title: Boston's Bellhorn Makes Most of Opportunity
description: Mark Bellhorn, the second baseman for the Boston Red Sox, drew notice when he hit 27 home runs for the Chicago Cubs in 2002. But he had only nine other homers before this season in his seven-year major league career.

title: Vazquez to Start on Short Rest
description: Javier Vazquez will start tomorrow against the Red Sox, four days after throwing 113 pitches in eight innings in a victory in Chicago.

title: A Boat With a History Is Taken on Its Final Voyage
description: Most of New York's finite maritime attention has been focused this week on the comings and goings of some extremely large cruise ships. But in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, the big story yesterday was the farewell voyage of the former Coast Guard cutter Cartigan, battered, waterlogged and hanging limply in the arms of a 100-ton crane.
