description: The top United States commander in the Middle East suggested in an interview on Friday that he was likely to ask for another extension in the current troop levels in Iraq, now at 135,000, and might even ask for more troops beyond that.

title: Carmaker Looks Inward In a Search for Cash
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation began a scramble for new cash on Friday, huddling first with its siblings in the Mitsubishi Group a day after its largest shareholder, DaimlerChrysler, said that it would not be providing any more money.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: In Poll, Chvez Wins Recall
description: President Hugo Chvez would win if a recall referendum were held, one of the country's top pollsters, Alfredo Keller & Associates, reported. With voters disenchanted and the opposition fractured, Mr. Chvez would win the backing of 35 percent of the registered voters questioned, while 31 percent would vote against him and the rest would abstain, said Alfredo Keller, the president of the polling company. Electoral authorities said a recall could be held on Aug. 8, but the opposition remains split over whether to recheck more than 500,000 petition signatures they need to initiate the vote. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: This Manning Brother Lets Arm Do the Talking
description: It started in kindergarten.

title: Ageless Maddux, the Same Old Mets
description: Some of the best contact the Mets made this week came after the final pitch was thrown Friday.

title: A Galactic Warrior, With Hypothetical Enemies
description: When NASA's Spirit and Opportunity probes landed on Mars recently, they were carrying some of the most sophisticated technology ever sent to that planet. But they might also have been carrying some illicit stowaways: microbes.

title: Aventis Plan Is Rejected
description: A plan by Aventis to issue warrants as part of the drugmaker's efforts to thwart Sanofi-Synthlabo's hostile takeover bid was rejected by France's market regulator.

title: GLAXO'S ATTEMPT TO STOP SALES OF GENERIC DRUG FAILS
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the drug maker, lost a bid to stop generic drug maker Apotex from selling a version of the antidepressant Paxil. Sales of Paxil, which reached $1.9 billion in the United States last year, fell 40 percent in the fourth quarter because of generic competition. After Apotex started selling its generic drug in September, Glaxo reached an agreement with Pharmaceutical Resources's Par Pharmaceutical to sell an ''authorized generic'' version. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit said Glaxo's patent was invalid because the invention was publicly used more than a year before the patent application. Apotex is based in Toronto. Glaxo is based in Brentford, England.

description: Long before anyone even mused about making a musical of ''Les Misrables,'' 19th-century choreographers created a spate of ballets based on another novel by Victor Hugo, ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame.''

title: Other Athletes Who Died in Service
description: Many athletes who served in the military during wartime were assigned to servicemen's ball clubs to entertain fellow soldiers and sailors. But a number served in combat, and the death of Pat Tillman in Afghanistan is a reminder. A look at some of those who died while serving.

title: Big Medical Research Prize Goes to 2 Pioneers in Genetics Work
description: Two California researchers who in the 1970's pioneered ways to splice and recombine genes, paving the way for the modern biotechnology industry, have received the Albany Medical Center Prize in Medicine and Biomedical Research, the nation's largest award in the field.

The intelligence cited surveillance of federal buildings in New York  not specifically Lower Manhattan  in connection with an attack. ( Go to Article )

He was going to a luncheon, to be honored for the charity he's done, the sacrifices he's made, when the voice on the radio said that Pat Tillman had given his life.

His last job was Sr. Vice President of strategic planning for the Federal Reserve Bank of NY. He retired in 1984. He is survived by his wife Betty. description: The black-turbaned imam sounded ready for martyrdom.

description: President Bush made a highly lucrative visit on Friday to the state that made him president, coupling a promotion of his environmental policies in Naples with two fund-raisers for the Republican National Committee that brought in $4.4 million.

description: Correction Appended

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Navajos Keep One-Fourth Blood Rule
description: The Navajo Nation Council rejected a proposal to lower the minimum blood requirement for tribal membership. The Navajos, the largest American tribe, have 310,000 members who qualify by having at least one-quarter Navajo blood. Reducing the threshold to one-eighth would double the size of the tribe, advocates of the change had said. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: John Joseph Ryan, 92, Assemblyman and Judge
description: John Joseph Ryan, formerly a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn and a judge in the criminal and claims courts, died on April 16 at a nursing home in Hinsdale, Ill. He was 92 and formerly a resident of Brooklyn as well as Breezy Point, N.Y., and Westfield, N.J.

title: Sharon Says His Pledge Not to Harm Arafat No Longer Holds
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said Friday that he no longer considered himself bound by his pledge not to harm Yasir Arafat, his most explicit statement yet that he might take action against the Palestinian leader.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 3 about the transfer of control of the Bronx Terminal Market misstated an aspect of the 1970's investigation into the granting of a 99-year lease to David Buntzman after he made a $30,000 contribution to the presidential campaign of Mayor John V. Lindsay. Richard Aurelio, Mr. Lindsay's campaign manager, says he was never subpoenaed in the case, and prosecutors also say they have no recollection or record of any such subpoena, although they investigated Mr. Aurelio's role at the time.

title: Conflicted Desires, Refracted in Amber Haze
description: Like so many melancholic television movies, ''Plainsong'' has been bronzed. Out under the Colorado sky, where an actor who resembles George Bush 41 puts up hay, the light looks suntanned; it's the same in the farmhouses lined with hook rugs. Maybe a study has found that this color induces tears, the pleasurable kind with the endorphins and nostalgia.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shell Investigation
description: Britain's market regulator, the Financial Services Authority, is investigating Shell Transport and Trading, the British half of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the agency said. The announcement follows mid-March reports that the regulator is taking an informal look at the company, after Shell cut 20 percent from its proven reserve estimates in January. It is unusual for the agency to comment publicly on an investigation, and the regulator is speaking out because of the ''high levels of public interest and concern'' about Shell, an agency spokeswoman, Kate Burns, said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: U.S. Lifts Bans on Libyan Trade, But Limits on Diplomacy Remain
description: President Bush lifted most of the remaining restrictions on doing business with Libya on Friday, and for the first time in decades authorized the establishment of an American diplomatic mission in Tripoli.

title: Vatican Cardinal Signals Backing for Sanctions on Kerry
description: Addressing a question about Senator John Kerry's support for abortion rights, a high-ranking Vatican cardinal said in a news conference in Rome yesterday that a Roman Catholic politician who supports abortion ''is not fit'' to receive communion.

title: WINE GROUP BUYS GOLDEN STATE FOR $82 MILLION
description: Golden State Vintners, which supplies wine and grapes to California wineries, accepted an increased offer from Wine Group to buy the company for about $82 million, topping a bid by Golden State's chief executive. Wine Group, which produces and sells wines under such brand names as Glen Ellen and Franzia, raised its offer Tuesday to $8.25 a share from a bid of $74 million, or $7.75 a share, earlier this month. A group led by Jeffrey O'Neill, Golden State's chief executive, offered $7.25 a share on March 23. The offer is 2.4 percent less than Golden State's closing share price on Thursday. Wine Group, which is closely held, will assume about $29 million of Golden States' debt, the company said. Stock in Golden State, based in Napa, Calif., has gained 42 percent since Feb. 23, the day before it disclosed the competing takeover bids.

title: Latest Chapter of Rivalry Is Laugher for the Red Sox
description: For the Yankees, it descended from one pitcher's embarrassment to all-out farce in about three innings. It was bad enough when Jos Contreras imploded again, new delivery and all, for another early exit. It was worse when the fans at Yankee Stadium booed the marquee hitters -- Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and Jason Giambi -- after successive weak outs in the sixth inning.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 23  The American authorities increased the pressure on besieged insurgents in the Sunni Muslim stronghold of Falluja on Friday with a series of blunt warnings that if they did not lay down their arms, United States soldiers would attack within days.

title: A Moment of Naked Reality As Response to a City Critic
description: In his role as chief advocate for the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has sought to defend its eight million residents from terrorist threats, parking scofflaws and the dangers of secondhand smoke in restaurants.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Journalist Held Without Charges
description: A 27-year-old Saudi journalist, Faris Hizam al-Harbi, was arrested in Eastern Province on Wednesday and is being held without charges, according to a statement from the Washington-based Saudi Institute, a pro-democracy organization. Mr. Harbi has not been able to contact a lawyer or his family, the statement said. He used to work for the pan-Arab daily Al Sharq Al Awsat, but was barred by the Saudi government from working as journalist last month. No one in the Saudi government could immediately be reached for comment.

title: N.F.L. Draft Will Go On, But Williams Won't Watch
description: Mike Williams, the receiver who was expected to be a first-round pick in this weekend's N.F.L. draft, will be out of the country instead, sent away by his agent to avoid the spotlight of an event they feel should have included him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, RABBI PAUL
description: KATZ--Rabbi Paul. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague in Israel. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: A Setback For Gov. Bush
description: A state appeals court panel rejected two efforts by Gov. Jeb Bush to dismiss a challenge to his intervention in the case of a brain-damaged woman, Terri Schiavo. Mrs. Schiavo's husband, Michael, filed the suit last fall after the Legislature approved a measure letting Mr. Bush order reinsertion of Mrs. Schiavo's feeding tube. Several courts had given Mr. Schiavo permission to remove the tube. Mrs. Schiavo's parents fought the removal, and Mr. Bush, a Republican, joined them. Mr. Schiavo contended that the new law was unconstitutional. Mr. Bush's legal objections have stalled the case. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Plea In Computer Harassment Case
description: A South Carolina man pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Seattle to 26 counts of using a computer across state lines to harass a former girlfriend who lived in Seattle. An assistant United States attorney in Seattle, Kathryn A. Warma, said that to her knowledge the man, James R. Murphy, 38, was the first person prosecuted under a 1996 law that equates harassing e-mail messages with telephone calls. Mr. Murphy could face up to two years in prison and a $250,000 fine for each count, Ms. Warma said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: About New York; War Veteran's Homecoming Is Spent in Homeless Shelters
description: THIS is how Nicole Goodwin travels these days: with her 1-year-old daughter pressed to her chest in a Snugli, a heavy backpack strapped across her shoulders, and a baby stroller crammed with as many bags of clothes and diapers as it can hold. When you are a homeless young mother, these are the things you carry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRACHTMAN, HYMAN
description: TRACHTMAN--Hyman. A beloved friend of true character and kindness. We will sorely miss him and remember him always. Our sincerest condolences to his entire family. Eric and Lauren, Mike and Caroline Bates

title: Going Early Into That Good Night
description: What is it about poets? Even in the pantheon of troubled artists, poets tend to be perceived as singularly despairing and subject to bad ends. Sylvia Plath turned on the gas and stuck her head in an oven when she was 30. Hart Crane leaped from the deck of a ship at 32. Paul Laurence Dunbar succumbed to tuberculosis at 33. As if that weren't bad enough, now one of the largest studies of its kind shows that poets tend to die younger than other types of writers.

title: FANNIE MAE ADDS ERNST & YOUNG DESPITE SUSPENSION
description: Fannie Mae recently added Ernst &Young to its roster of consultants in a fight with regulators over its accounting practices -- even though the Securities and Exchange Commission barred the auditing firm from taking on new clients. An S.E.C. administrative law judge suspended the firm last week from accepting new public-company audit clients for six months and forced it to relinquish $1.7 million in fees as punishment for participating in a lucrative business venture with an audit client.

title: Peter Prescott, 68, Author And Newsweek Book Critic
description: Peter S. Prescott, an author and a longtime book critic for Newsweek, died on Friday at Tisch Hospital at the New York University Medical Center. He was 68.

title: Cartoon On Holocaust Draws Fire At Rutgers
description: The president of Rutgers University condemned a weekly campus publication on Friday for printing a front-page cartoon that ridiculed victims of the Holocaust. But, citing legal precedents protecting student publications, he said he could not take away its university funds as some critics had urged.

title: Senate Beckons a Coors From Beer to Political Ads
description: New York has its Rockefellers, Chicago its McCormicks, San Francisco its Hearsts and Stanfords. Here the name is Coors.

title: Guard Gives Sisters More Time To Decide on Returning to Iraq
description: Rachel and Charity Witmer, members of the Wisconsin National Guard serving in Iraq, have been granted another 15 days of leave to decide whether to seek reassignment after their sister, Michelle, was killed in Baghdad.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Troublesome Questions Rain Down on the Yanks
description: Jos Contreras was fortunate that the Yankees pumped some music through their public address system while he was trudging off the mound in the fourth inning because that muffled some of the incessant booing. But Contreras still absorbed enough of the verbal abuse, a long, loud chorus of displeasure for a job not well done.

title: From a Sound Explorer, Serenades for Laptop
description: In 1967, when the electronic composer Morton Subotnick released ''Silver Apples of the Moon,'' he seemed to be exploring a limitless world. Four decades later, his pioneering compositions are appealing in part because they evoke an earlier era: a time when electronic music sounded, well, electronic; when the future was all blips and gurgles.

description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC WILL BUY BANCSHARES FOR $420 MILLION
description: The Central Pacific Financial Corporation, Hawaii's second-biggest publicly traded bank, said it would buy CB Bancshares for about $420 million in cash and stock, capping a yearlong hostile pursuit of Hawaii's No.3 lender. Central Pacific will pay $91.83 a share in cash and stock for CB Bancshares, the parent of City Bank, the companies said. The price is 7.4 percent higher than CB Bancshares' closing price on Thursday and $21.83 higher than Central Pacfic's initial bid last April. The purchase will create a bank with $4 billion in assets, second only to the Bank of Hawaii Corporation, and 46 branches in the state. Central Pacific will pay $20 in cash and 2.6752 shares for each share of CB Bancshares. Both companies are based in Honolulu.

title: Google Flirts; Investors Wonder About Date
description: Google, the Web search company that has developed a huge following around the world, is expected to take a tentative first step next week toward a public stock offering, a person close to the company said Friday. But it is likely to stop short of filing a formal registration to sell shares, the person said.

title: March Orders For Factories Top Forecast, Rising 3.4%
description: Orders for long-lasting factory goods rose 3.4 percent in March, more than many economists had forecast, as corporate spending accelerated on machinery, metals and computers.

title: Leo O'Neill, 64, Executive Who Helped Expand S.&P.
description: Leo C. O'Neill, who guided Standard & Poor's as it expanded from an American bond rating firm into an international concern whose opinion could be critical to the terms on which companies and governments could borrow money, died on Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONALDSON, ADELAIDE R. CHAQUENEAU, ''FIFI,''
description: DONALDSON--Adelaide R. Chaqueneau, ''Fifi,'' of New York and Palm Beach, died April 20 in NYC. Wonderful and true friend, beloved wife of the late Robert M. Donaldson II of Lloyd Neck, NY; dear stepmother of Dr. Sally Donaldson, mother-in-law of Peter Hassinger and devoted grandmother of Laurel of Brooklyn, NY. Also survived by much loved first cousin, Helen Rhinelander Schreuer, of France. A service will be held Monday, April 26, at 4:00 PM at L'Eglise Francaise du Saint Esprit, 109 East 60th St. (bet. Lexington and Park) NYC 10022. In lieu of flowers a donation can be made to Saint Esprit or to the Properties Preservation Trust of the Church Of The Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th St., NYC, 10128.

title: DELTA IS PRESSING PILOTS' UNION FOR 30% CUT IN PAY
description: The chief executive of Delta Air Lines, Gerald Grinstein, said that concessions from the pilots' union were inadequate and that the company was still seeking a pay cut of 30 percent from the group. Pilots have offered to accept a 9 percent reduction and forgo a 4.5 percent increase scheduled to take effect next month. ''It doesn't come near enough to close the gap,'' Mr. Grinstein told reporters after the airline's annual shareholders meeting. The union for Delta's 7,500 pilots rejected a company proposal for the second time in January. Mr. Grinstein said he thought that the airline would survive without filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 699 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Return of Japanese to prominence at exhibits and sales
description: NEW YORK  The Japanese are back. On the museum scene, they are everywhere. In the art market, their presence is once again making itself felt and in both cases, the lead part is played by collectors.

title: Check From Sprinter's Account Sent to Balco
description: A check for $7,350, previously mentioned in a government affidavit in the Balco steroids case, was written to the founder of Balco from the bank account of the Olympic sprint champion Marion Jones, according to two people familiar with bank records in the case.

title: North Korea Appeals for Help After Railway Explosion
description: Correction Appended

title: Riding on the River
description: BOSTON, April 24 - How many people does it take to ride a bicycle along the Charles River on a sunny Saturday?

title: Top Rowland Aide Quits; 2 Will Replace Him
description: The spokesman and chief of staff for Gov. John G. Rowland left the administration on Friday, and the embattled governor immediately announced that two people, including a former assistant who has decided to return to the Capitol, would jointly fill the vacancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROOK, SUSAN
description: BROOK--Susan, 63, died on April 22, 2004 following a recent accident. She is survived by devoted husband Michael, loving daughter Kira, stepchildren Mandy Shear and Scott Brook and Julie and Daniel Brook; adoring grandchildren Zev and Isaiah, mother-in-law Anne Brook and special friend Kelwin Coleman. Susan was a multifaceted woman, an occupational therapist, clinical social worker, psychoanalyst, artist and craftsperson. She touched many lives with her persistence and courage in the face of physical obstacles. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue on Monday, April 26 at 11:15 AM.

title: Files Show Kerry Earned Medals for Wounds From Shrapnel, Which Is Still in His Leg
description: Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign offered a brief glimpse at his military medical file on Friday. The file showed that Mr. Kerry requested that his relatives not be notified after he was wounded in action and that he retains a piece of shrapnel in his left thigh.

title: This Time, Arkansas Hangs On in Medley
description: For Alistair Cragg of Arkansas, it was a bad dream that really happened. Last April, leading in the distance medley of the Penn Relays, he was running the anchor leg when Nate Brannen of Michigan ran him down and beat him by an eyelash.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: New Embratel Stake Bid
description: Brazil's top three phone companies made a fourth offer to buy MCI's controlling stake in Embratel Participaes in a bid to thwart the sale of the Brazilian long-distance carrier to Telfonos de Mxico. The new offer by Calais Participaes -- a consortium of Spanish companies -- raised the nonrefundable amount MCI would receive immediately to $470 million from $396 million, but kept the final price tag unchanged at $550 million. The move by Calais came one day after Telmex raised its bid for Embratel to $400 million from $360 million, an offer that has already been approved by MCI's board. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Golf Anyone? The Movable Feast Called 'Judicial Education'
description: Amid the uproar over Justice Antonin Scalia's duck-hunting trip with Vice President Dick Cheney, I phoned a federal judge I know to get his take on the matter. Speaking off the record, the judge, a seasoned court veteran, sharply criticized Mr. Scalia's judgment, first in going on the trip, and accepting free rides on Air Force Two for himself and two relatives, and then in refusing to step aside when the case challenging the secrecy of Mr. Cheney's energy task force is heard next Tuesday by the Supreme Court.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Prime Minister's Aide Caught With Underage Prostitute
description: The director of communications for Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin resigned after he was found with a 17-year-old Romanian prostitute in his car. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAUMSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: BAUMSTEIN--Dorothy, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was born in Ostrowietz, Poland. She and her husband Bernard survived the Nazis and helped others do the same. In 1946 they were brought to New York by Bernard's older brothers and made a new life in the Bronx with their daughter Bina. Music and movies became Dorothy's passion, and she and Bernard won many dance contests together. In retirement they spent summers in Sag Harbor, near their beloved daughter, son-in-law Walter and granddaughter Sarah. Last May Dorothy fulfilled a wish by walking down the aisle at Sarah's wedding to Hugo Lindgren. In her last years, Dorothy was lovingly cared for by Bibi and Reuben Ledra. Funeral services will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, Long Island, Sunday, April 25, at 11 AM.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Bomb Threat Turns Back Ship
description: A high-speed Greek passenger ferry an hour into its journey to Italy was forced to return to the port of Patras after an anonymous bomb threat. Officers and sniffer dogs swept over the ship, called Superfast. They found no bomb, but the scare tested the readiness of security forces already on high alert ahead of the Athens Olympics this summer. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Latvia: Russian Diplomat Expelled
description: Latvia announced that it was expelling a Russian diplomat within 72 hours, prompting an unusually pointed response from Russian officials, who called the decision a provocation based on Latvia's anti-Russian policies. The diplomat, accused of trying to collect information on NATO and other security matters, is the sixth Russian diplomat expelled for espionage this year, after expulsions by Lithuania and Estonia in February and March. In each case Russia has retaliated tit for tat. Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia joined NATO last month and will join the European Union a week from today. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Photos of Soldiers' Coffins Spark a Debate Over Access
description: A White House spokesman, Trent Duffy, said on Friday that President Bush had seen photographs of the coffins of service members killed in Iraq arriving at Dover Air Force Base that were made public on Thursday and agreed with the Pentagon that releasing the photographs was wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIGMAN, JOSEPH, PHD
description: STEIGMAN -- Joseph, PhD, died April 17, 2004, age 91. Emeritus Professor of Chemistry in Nuclear Medicine, State University of NY, Downstate Medical Center at Brooklyn, NY. A graduate of Columbia College, he received his PhD in Chemistry from Columbia University in 1937. He taught at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and was an outstanding teacher and researcher in many fields including Analytical Chemistry and Nuclear Medicine. He is survived by his wife Margot of 63 years, nephew David, niece Rose and cousin Evelyn Baar of Rome, NY.

title: Ex-Schwab Officer Held in Fund Inquiry

title: Set That Apricot Free
description: Shoppers at farmers markets in cities around the country might feel virtuous because they're filling their baskets with eggs and chard and apples offered by farmers within driving distance. Same goes for the city subscribers in community supported agriculture programs, who buy shares in the production of a nearby farm. And they're justified: they are helping change American agriculture by supporting local farmers instead of agribusiness. Small family farms are essential to guaranteeing the diversity and safety of our food supply.

title: INAMED AND GENZYME WIN APPROVAL FOR WRINKLE FILLER
description: The Inamed Corporation and its partner the Genzyme Corporation won Food and Drug Administration approval of the Hylaform gel to treat wrinkles around the eyes and mouth. Inamed, which already sells other wrinkle fillers, will compete with the Medicis Pharmaceutical Corporation's Restylane, which was approved in December. Both treatments include an ingredient already found in the body called hyaluronic acid. Stock in Inamed, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., rose $2, or 3.7 percent, to $55.50 a share. Inamed is also developing a product similar to Allergan Inc.'s Botox for wrinkles.

They sailed together until the doctors took his boat away. They went to concerts together. He wrote her poems and letters bedecked with jokes and kisses. And he called her several times a week to chat about the day.

title: Look, No Hands: Pixar's Killer App

Like many recent hand-drawn cartoons, ''Home on the Range'' didn't take a lesson from Pixar: ''It's all about presence, and how you enter the room,'' as one of the creatures in ''Monsters, Inc.'' says. Although the statement is meant as parody -- especially as uttered by James Coburn, in the portentous, velveteen tones of an ''Inside the Actors Studio'' interview -- it could also refer to the way Pixar bestrides the cartooniverse these days.

title: A Condo Selling Its Air Rights
description: Q. I am a board member and unit owner in a condominium complex in the East Village. The complex comprises several four-story brownstones that are lower than the law allows. The board is considering selling the remaining development rights to a developer of a nearby building. The developer intends to use these rights to construct a building higher than zoning regulations would otherwise allow. Does the board's possible transfer of air rights require the consent of all unit owners or would two-thirds suffice? . . . William Ramos, Manhattan.

She was brave to take on Rachel Carson and the consequences of the DDT ban brought about by well-meaning and powerful pressure groups. Environmentalism has become a latter-day religion for these individuals.

Organized by Nancy Cohen and Denise Call, the center's staff curators, this fine, gutsy little show pairs artwork by emerging multicultural women artists with those who have achieved wider recognition.

Ms. Jeffery, who lives in the nearby Gowanus Houses, recalls cracked sidewalks, unsavory characters and empty storefronts.

title: 18th-Century Crib Notes
description: Because the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute has become so influential in fashion -- its ''Goddess'' show brought forth flou, and ''Jacqueline Kennedy'' inspired a return to ladylike lines -- get ready for a French revolution. When ''Dangerous Liaisons: Fashion and Furniture in the 18th Century,'' convenes this Thursday in the museum's legendary French period rooms in the Wrightsman Galleries, we will be treated, as the organizers explain, to an exploration of ''the body's spatial negotiation of the 18th-century interior as a choreography of seduction and erotic play.'' Is it getting hot in here? Well, lest anyone wander naked into the esprit de l'ge, here's a glossary of terms, francophiles and objets, to render you comme il faut.

description: ON a recent Saturday morning at Yoga Haven in Tuckahoe, 15 pregnant women settled onto rubber mats and greeted one another with questions about how they were feeling and when their babies were due. Then the instructor, Reyna Gonzalez, guided them through a prenatal yoga routine.

title: A Silver Sugar Bowl With a Story to Tell
description: IN the late 18th century, Louis Bolduc, an entrepreneur engaged in agriculture and the mining and sale of lead and salt in Sainte Genevieve, Mo., owned a silver sugar bowl with a stylized flower finial on its cover. These days, the bowl is on display in New Haven at Yale University Art Gallery. Acquired in October of last year, it is an important addition to the gallery's collection of American silver, thousands of pieces ranging from the earliest examples made in this country to contemporary creations.

description: At entrances to Tokyo's sleekest hotels and high-rises this spring, visitors may find orange emergency tape blocking access to the revolving doors.

title: POSTINGS: Adjacent Westchester Developments; Housing Aims To Mix Ages
description: Sterling Glen of Rye Brook, a 166-unit luxury rental housing development for independent older residents in Westchester, has opened next door to BelleFair, a for-sale development completed several years ago by Spectrum Skanska. Because Sterling Glen is coordinating many recreational activities with those offered at the 250-unit BelleFair, which was built in a ''new urbanism'' style intended to evoke an old-fashioned small-town way of life and encourage interaction among neighbors of various ages, it is being billed as multigenerational housing for those over 62.

title: Changes in Design Preceded Collapse of Casino Garage
description: The garage collapse that killed four construction workers and injured 20 others last October during a $245 million expansion of the Tropicana Casino and Resort was caused by the faulty installation of concrete floors after changes were made to the design to speed the job and save money, according to engineers for the contractors and others who have studied the design plans and the debris.

title: The Very Model Of a Modern Satirist
description: HOW can a writer be at once so famous and so little known? With Arthur Sullivan, William S. Gilbert wrote some of the most popular stage works of all time, operettas like ''The Mikado,'' ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' Yet even after ''Topsy-Turvy,'' Mike Leigh's recent film about their partnership, many Gilbert and Sullivan devotees know little about the man, or the range and brilliance of his work: truly, a most ingenious paradox.

title: A Different Course
description: You've seen the ads on billboards and the bus. They make the process of getting a degree online look almost cozy: earn an M.B.A. in your pajamas and fuzzy slippers. The reality is a little, well, blearier.

title: 'Alexander Hamilton'
description: On the night of April 18, 1775, 800 British troops marched out of Boston to capture Samuel Adams and John Hancock and seize a stockpile of patriot munitions in Concord, Massachusetts. As they passed Lexington, they encountered a motley battalion of militia farmers known as Minutemen, and in the ensuing exchange of gunfire the British killed 8 colonists and then 2 more in Concord. As the redcoats retreated helter-skelter to Boston, they were riddled by sniper fire that erupted from behind hedges, stone walls, and fences, leaving a bloody trail of 273 British casualties versus 95 dead or wounded for the patriots.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Hayley Westenra; Almost a Diva
description: SHE is just like any teenage girl, but taller, thinner, prettier and she spends her spare time writing notes to the opera singer Kiri Te Kanawa. Like Dame Kiri, the teenager, Hayley Westenra, is from New Zealand and a singer, but not just any singer. She has sold more than a million copies of her classical album, ''Pure,'' and worries that turning 17 ''sounds old.''

title: Living Off the Land, From Farm to Table
description: THE revolutionary new culinary center opening here next week may be creating an uproar in the greater foodie universe, but managers of the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture say they are actually hoping to start off by attracting residents of Westchester County, not just the great gourmands of the world.

title: On the Art Trail In Rural Japan
description: MY friend Lilla flourished a blue sheet of paper headed ''Artists' Walking Tour of Southern Rural Japan.'' It promised Buddhist pilgrimage routes, picnics assembled in local supermarkets, hot-springs baths, contemporary art collections, traditional houses, ancient crafts and modern potters, hiking and tatami mats, ferry rides across the Inland Sea. I had never been to Japan. But I had reached the age when ''I want to do that when I have time'' has become ''I better do that while I still can.'' So I signed up.

description: SPRING, and once again the air is filled with flying things that leave a painful welt. Not hornets or horseflies -- high season for paintball has arrived, and on Long Island it's bigger than ever.

title: A Grown-Up Grand Cherokee
description: IN the early 1990's, when large numbers of Americans switched from sedans and minivans to sport utility vehicles, the Jeep Grand Cherokee -- along with the Ford Explorer -- became a fixture in the nation's driveways and parking lots.

title: The Wrong Debate on Terrorism
description: The last month has seen a remarkable series of events that focused the public and news media on America's shortcomings in dealing with terrorism from radical Islamists. This catharsis, which is not yet over, is necessary for our national psyche. If we learn the right lessons, it may also prove to be an essential part of our future victory over those who now threaten us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRITSCH, PETER H.
description: FRITSCH--Peter H. 85, on April 22, 2004 from complications of emphysema. Austrian born, but a New Yorker to the core, he is mourned by his wife Theresa, his children Erica Bell, Peter Nicholas Fritsch, and Christina Fritsch, and granddaughters, Nora and Callie.

title: BackTalk; Bannister's Milestone Recalls A Different Era in Sport
description: Few events are powerful enough to raise the human spirit worldwide. The moon landing comes to mind. The discovery of the polio vaccine. Reaching the summit of the earth's highest peak. In my lifetime, one athletic feat reached this level: the breaking of the four-minute-mile barrier. I can still remember May 6, 1954, as if it were yesterday. And I contend that Roger Bannister's achievement matters more to us now than ever.

title: Foreigners in the Land of Their Birth
description: MY daughters watched in fascination as old men in thickly quilted jackets wielded three-foot-long brushes that looked like giant Q-Tips. The men dipped the padded ends in water, and then swished beautiful calligraphy onto the dark slabs of sidewalk stone. The characters shone brightly for a few moments, then began to evaporate and fade away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONSTHER, BURTON, MD
description: BRONSTHER--Burton, MD. The Staff Society of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center mourn the passing of our esteemed and beloved colleague, Burton Bronsther, MD. Dr. Bronsther was a member of the staff of Long Island Jewish Medical Center for 40 years and was a Founder of the Children's Medical Center of New York, now Schneider Children's Hospital, as well as Founder and President of Surgical Aid to Children of the World (SACOW). Dr. Bronsther was renowned ''worldwide'' for his great surgical skills, teaching ability, philanthropic work and his many publications that advanced the field of Pediatric Surgery. Dr. Bronsther possessed a keen intellect that was imbued with charm and humanity and his loss will be immeasurable. Eugene Friedman, M.D., Pres Randall Feingold, M.D. VP Glenn Faust, M.D., Secretary Angelo Reppucci, M.D. Treas

Except for their devotional lyrics, the band sounds indistinguishable from a secular rock group. And the audience, in turn, has responded like fans of other musical genres: downloading the songs free from unauthorized file-sharing services.

Take my left fielder and his massive contract, please, they begged, after placing Ramirez on irrevocable waivers. No one bit.

This block of East Fifth Street would hardly seem to nurture culinary ambition -- let alone a small empire. But thanks to Jack and Grace Lamb, diners happily assemble here for exquisite sushi in one of their tiny restaurants and for shellfish extravaganzas in another.

title: Yankees Continue To Go Meekly
description: He was booed at Yankee Stadium the night before, but Derek Jeter kept insisting there was nothing really wrong. He trusted his approach and believed that he was hitting the ball well, no matter the results. He was, as ever, the cool captain of the Yankees.

The ground floor of the eight-story, warehouse-like building on 11th Avenue and 54th Street was given over to a greasy garage, while heavyset guys named Louis and Uncle Bobby paced the second-floor showroom. A get-'em-in, get-'em-out vibe prevailed.

She is survived by devoted husband Michael, loving daughter Kira, stepchildren Mandy Shear and Scott Brook and Julie and Daniel Brook; adoring grandchildren Zev and Isaiah, mother-in-law Anne Brook and special friend Kelwin Coleman. Susan was a multifaceted woman, an occupational therapist, clinical social worker, psychoanalyst, artist and craftsperson. She touched many lives with her persistence and courage in the face of physical obstacles. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue on Monday, April 26 at 11:15 AM.

description: OVER the last 15 months, ''End of the Century,'' a documentary about punk rock's founding fathers, the Ramones, has been shown at major film festivals in New York, Toronto and Berlin. It has attracted a following among influential figures like Nicolas Cage and the director Jim Jarmusch. It has been praised in Variety, Entertainment Weekly and The Los Angeles Times for its unflinching portrayal of the dysfunction that both fueled and undermined the Ramones.

description: CHEZ STPHANE in Westport is so unselfconsciously retro it is a real delight in both looks and menu. I was first charmed by the old-fashioned provenal look of the tiny, crowded dining room.

title: Ignorance Is No Excuse
description: ''The bar exam is not the fondest experience of a new law graduate,'' says Erica Moeser, president of the National Conference of Bar Examiners. To prove the point beyond a reasonable doubt: 73 percent passed the bar in 1972; with more rigorous standards, 63 percent passed in 2002. The bar takes a nail-biting two to three days, depending on a state's requirements. One nearly universal component is an exam developed by the bar examiners to demonstrate broad knowledge of the law. Below, sample questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAUMAN, SIDNEY
description: BAUMAN--Sidney. March 25, 1914-April 21, 2004. Grew up alone to master the ways of NY and win the woman of his dreams. The wounded W.W. II Vet returned to raise his children and worship his wife in a blazing romance that burns still. From the race tracks to the night clubs he was ''Bub'' to his wife ''Red'' as they embodied the city's style and glamour of their time. Proud, knowing and always gracious, he was the host wherever he went. Worldly wise and tough, except when leading the band in ''You're Nobody 'Til Somebody Loves You.'' He is survived by his infatuated wife Florence, children Steven and Fern, grandchildren Beau, Spencer, Sean and Ben. We love you more. Services Monday, April 26, 11:00 AM. Lang Tobia Dipalma Funeral Home, 406 Deerpark Ave, Babylon, NY 11702. 631-669-4040.

title: Culinary Delights Laid Out to Tempt Japan's Commuters
description: PHENOMENAL food halls are not news in Japan. They have been found in the basement level of Japanese department stores since the 1920's. Nevertheless, your first visit to a depachika, as they are known, will probably leave you speechless. Typically, it houses more than 50 independent merchants. And there are about 20 in Tokyo.

title: Cracking the Code Of 'Alias'
description: THE master plot lines of the serial spy drama ''Alias'' are kept on a corkboard in the writers' room, on index cards that track the progress of every character at each point in the season. The show, broadcast on Sundays at 9 p.m. on ABC, is the soap opera of spy series, tangling international espionage with tortured familial relationships. Sydney Bristow, for example, the C.I.A. agent played by the show's star, Jennifer Garner, began the third season by waking up two years after the second season ended. She had been presumed dead, she learned, and had no memory of how she had spent the lost time. Sydney spent many of the ensuing episodes caught in a love triangle with her ex-boyfriend (a fellow spy named Michael Vaughn) and the woman he married while Bristow was gone. Her emotionally distant father (Victor Garber) is a colleague, her mother is a threat to national security, and she may or may not be the subject of a doomsday prophecy by a 16th-century sage named Milo Rambaldi. One could see why it might be helpful to map things out on paper.

title: Pindar Offers Dining Wines In Magnums
description: Pindar Vineyards, Long Island's largest-volume producer, has released two oversize bottles of food-oriented wines that cost-conscious hosts may find economically appealing, especially with large-scale, warm-weather entertaining starting.

title: Making Sense of The Mission
description: It was refreshing to see James Traub's article (April 11) on the difficult but critical role of peacekeeping and nation-building in today's military operations. The foundations of democracy can't truly begin to be implemented in their absence. And it's the only way to prevent chaotic, war-torn countries from turning into breeding grounds for inflamed fundamentalism and terrorists.

title: Attacked, Expelled, Ignored
description: The Darfur region of western Sudan is one of the most remote and inhospitable places on earth, which makes it an ideal place to get away with ethnic cleansing. Since late last year, an Arab militia called the Janjaweed has killed thousands of darker-skinned non-Arabs and driven about one million from their homes. Most of the refugees are still in Sudan, many of them in squalid camps, the children dying of malnutrition and measles. An additional 110,000 refugees have crossed into Chad. Even there they are not safe: the Janjaweed regularly raid across the border.

title: Charges Filed Against Two Men Who Climbed Tree in Central Park
description: Two nearly naked men who drew crowds and kept rescue workers at bay for hours on Thursday when they climbed a tree in Central Park were charged yesterday with a series of misdemeanors, the police said.

title: 'Belle': Breakthrough Roles, 8 of Them
description: ''Belle'' is a short film that is set in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, but it was filmed largely in Chelsea, where most of its cast lives. That cast would be eight elderly women, all non-actors, who were recruited en masse for this production from a senior citizens' art program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORRIS, JOHN D.

description: District Attorney Jeanine Pirro, a Republican, called on Washington last week to set politics aside and extend the federal ban on assault weapons that is scheduled to expire Sept. 13.

title: Civil War Dog Tags Were on Wrong Soldier
description: THE mystery surrounding a medallion with the name and unit of Union Army Pvt. Ezra Chamberlin of Killingly, found aboard a sunken Confederate submarine when it was raised from the waters off Charleston, S.C., in 2001, has been solved. Two scientists have determined that although his dog tag was on the submarine, Private Chamberlin wasn't.

title: The World; An Israeli Pullout Won't Create a Nation in Gaza
description: PRIME MINISTER ARIEL SHARON may want to withdraw Israeli troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip, but that does not mean it will be easy for Palestinians to build a state here. Although the date proposed for Israel's unilateral exit is not until late 2005, details of the plan have been emerging in the week since Mr. Sharon met with a supportive President Bush. And Palestinian leaders have grown increasingly critical.

title: He Parked Your Car. She Retrieved It. Who Gets a Tip?
description: MICHAEL LYNN was more than a little surprised to learn the number of Americans who evidently don't know that it is customary to tip a waiter 15 to 20 percent of the bill.

title: For Some Politicians, a Losing Race Isn't Always a Total Loss
description: Tony Avella, a city councilman from the northern shores of Queens, speaks passionately about running for mayor next year. Having won his seat in a competitive race in 2001, he acknowledges that he is a long shot in the 2005 Democratic primary, since he is barely known outside his district.

title: P. Diddy's Boradway Crash Course
description: AT the beginning of this year, Sean Combs, who is not only one of the biggest, but also one of the most frequently changed, names in hip-hop, underwent another one of his famous transformations. He had already gone by Puffy (starting in high school), Puff Daddy (in his early days as an impresario) and P. Diddy (after he was acquitted of charges of bribery and gun possession). But after prolonged consultation with Susan Batson, the woman he calls ''my guru, coach, hero,'' he quietly started asking friends to refer to him as Walter Lee.

title: As the War Turns: A New Soap Opera
description: ON Feb. 27, 1968, America's most trusted anchor, CBS's Walter Cronkite, concluded a special report from Vietnam by saying that the ''only rational way out'' was a negotiated end to the war. To L. B. J., this pronouncement was a political death sentence. ''If I've lost Walter Cronkite, I've lost Mr. Average Citizen,'' he confided to his press secretary. A month later he decided not to seek re-election.

title: Had Enough Of Emo? Try R & B-mo
description: MARIO WINANS -- This R & B singer and producer has a huge hit with ''I Don't Wanna Know,'' which uses an airy Enya sample (previously used by the Fugees) to make a heartfelt -- but short-sighted -- plea: ''I don't wanna know/ If you're playing me, keep it on the low/ 'Cause my heart can't take it anymore.'' The song comes from his new CD, ''Hurt No More'' (Bad Boy/Universal), one of the year's best R & B albums so far. Mr. Winans shamelessly and winningly plays up his vulnerability (could it be that emo has given way to R & B-mo?), and his minimalist beats give him plenty of space to sing the hooks: on ''This Is the Thanks I Get,'' the music consists mainly of three digitized flute notes.

title: Nuts and Bolts
description: THE timeline for online Ph.D. programs is roughly the same as at a traditional university, four to six years, with a typical workload of 20 hours a week. Tuition averages $15,000 a year -- midway between most public and private university tuitions (but without the income that doctoral candidates count on as teaching assistants at bricks-and-mortar universities). Ph.D. studies fall into three categories of distance education.

Also survived by grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Family will receive friends Monday, April 26th from 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, Inc. 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx.

description: BERDOE -- Claire. 95, of Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully on April 23, 2004. Devoted wife of the late Arthur. Loved and adored mother of Natalie, Greta and Dr. Franklin Berdoe. title: The Nanny Nightmare
description: FOR months, the bizarre story of Cherin Perelman and her Hungarian nanny, Lady Anne Elizabeth Toth, was the talk of the Upper West Side. Always, the story elicited small gasps and unimaginable questions: Did the nanny really have five aliases? Was she a small-time thief with dashed dreams or an expert con artist?

title: Simplicity as the Mother of Invention
description: In their simple, uncluttered world, Peep, Quack and Chirp have just about everything three young birds could ever want: a big, leafy tree to perch on, an alluring blue pond, a green hill or two to explore. Like their surroundings, the animated stars of ''Peep and the Big Wide World,'' a children's series shown weekday mornings on the Learning Channel and Discovery Kids, are also decidedly uncomplicated, at least visually speaking. Quack looks more like a big purple egg than a duck; Chirp, an analytically minded robin, resembles a plump cherry that happens to have a beak; and Peep, a recently hatched chick with an inquisitive mind, is little more than a yellow ball with two spindly legs.

title: A New Queen Bows With Greater Ease
description: THE 1,132 foot, 151,400-ton Queen Mary 2 glided into Pier 92 on the West Side of Manhattan on Thursday morning after its six-day voyage from Southampton, England. Three thrusters, which work like great water jets, enable the ship to turn in its own length and allowed it to dock without the aid of tugboats.

title: Can Drug-Free Baseball Stars Smash Records?
description: On the day that Barry Bonds eventually tied his godfather, Willie Mays, for third place on baseball's all-time home-run list, a portion of his hometown crowd booed him during a pregame ceremony. Why the catcalls? Bonds is thoughtful, outspoken, African-American and male, a combination that has, historically, affronted a certain type of fan. He also has a well-earned reputation for being a total pill. The principal reason he was booed, though, is that many people suspect that he cheated. They believe that his eye-popping home-run totals of the past few years were ''artificially encouraged,'' as Hemingway once said of doped-up racehorses. Despite his denials, they assume he is now surpassing the sport's most hallowed names in the record books on something other than his own merits.

title: Lies That Can Change the World
description: DECEPTION and longing shape the lives of the characters in ''Since Otar Left,'' the French director Julie Bertuccelli's remarkably poignant debut feature (opening on Friday). Based on a true story, this bittersweet film focuses on a household of three women who dream of Paris while living in Tbilisi, Georgia. The elderly Eka (Esther Gorintin) worships her absent son, Otar, who went to France in search of work. Her daughter (Nino Khomassouridze) and granddaughter (Dinara Droukarova) live in uneasy complicity with this cult. But when Otar suddenly dies, the younger women fabricate his letters, to keep him alive for his mother.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) The bones in this audacious first novel, which is narrated by a 14-year-old girl looking down from heaven after her abduction and murder, refer not to the victim but to the connections forged among her family members as they emerge from the grief and dysfunction that follow her death. The book, which became a surprise best seller, ''deals with almost unthinkable subjects with humor and intelligence and a kind of mysterious grace,'' Katherine Bouton wrote in the Book Review in 2002.

The F.M.A., as written, would be used to deny federal benefits and could be used to deny state-sanctioned benefits for gay and lesbian couples. While my own recent unearthing of Golden Rod was only slightly less dramatic, the neighborhood clientele that often fills the place to bursting has known about the place since it opened three years ago. At that time it must have been the first in Westchester to offer Chinese cuisine and sushi as well as pleasing dishes rooted in Thailand, Malay and Indonesia.

title: 'Seaport'
description: Between 1830 and 1960 the Port of New York was the busiest in the world. It was also the largest in terms of available waterfront: The Greater New York area, including Yonkers, Jersey City, Newark, and Long Island, had a waterfront extending 771 miles, of which 362 were developed with piers. Manhattan alone had a direct waterfront of 43 miles, with its developed waterfront (measuring along the piers and the heads of slips) totaling about 76 miles. On Manhattan's West Side, a continuous line of finger piers extended up the Hudson River to accommodate all the ships in port, while on the other side of the island, the East River teemed with every kind of vessel-tugboats, liners, sailboats, steamboats, freighters, tankers, barges, and fishing trawlers-passing to and from the ocean.

title: Rarefied Perch by a Sacred Mountain in Bhutan
description: Living up to its reputation for luxurious lodging in exclusive locations, Amanresorts will open the first of six planned resorts in the hermetic Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan at the end of this week. The 24-suite Amanrila Paro is 20 minutes from Bhutan's only international airport, in Paro, in the shadow of a 17th-century fortress monastery and Chomo Lhari, a 24,000-foot peak and one of the kingdom's most sacred mountains.

title: JUMPERS
description: ANALYTIC philosophy is many things, but hilarious is not one of them. So it is yet another of Tom Stoppard's singular triumphs that he earns sincere laughs during dense lectures about, among other things, Bertrand Russell's theory of descriptions. The protagonist of Mr. Stoppard's 1972 farce ''Jumpers'' (published by Grove Press), which opens in a revival at the Brooks Atkinson Theater today, is a rumpled logician named George Moore -- named, no doubt, after the early-20th-century British philosopher who worked at Trinity College, Cambridge, along with Russell and Ludwig Wittgenstein. Simon Russell Beale plays the professor, just as he did in the Royal National Theater production in London, which, before transferring to Broadway, won rave reviews and moved to the West End.

I cannot register a complaint or a lament, for any man who chooses to place himself in public sight has no reason to regret such attentions. Rather, he must be grateful if the public chooses to cast its fickle gaze in his direction, a truth to which the countless volumes languishing in the scribbler's perdition of obscurity can testify.

title: 'The Shadow of the Wind'
description: Asecret's worth depends on the people from whom it must be kept. My first thought on waking was to tell my best friend about the Cemetery of Forgotten Books. Tomas Aguilar was a classmate who devoted his free time and his talent to the invention of wonderfully ingenious contraptions of dubious practicality, like the aerostatic dart or the dynamo spinning top. I pictured us both, equipped with flashlights and compasses, uncovering the mysteries of those bibliographic catacombs. Who better than Tomas to share my secret? Then, remembering my promise, I decided that circumstances advised me to adopt what in detective novels is termed a different modus operandi. At noon I approached my father to quiz him about the book and about Julian Carax-both world famous, I assumed. My plan was to get my hands on his complete works and read them all by the end of the week. To my surprise, I discovered that my father, a natural-born librarian and a walking lexicon of publishers' catalogs and oddities, had never heard of The Shadow of the Wind or Julian Carax. Intrigued, he examined the printing history on the back of the title page for clues.

title: Diversity's False Solace

Or are there remedies we haven't debated yet, like school days and calendars that match work schedules (say, 8 to 6 and two weeks off a year), with supervised breaks in the early years for play and homework and time in later grades for extracurricular or nonacademic activities like band, school paper, shop and sports? Not a change local property taxes can be expected to cover, but an ''education President'' might manage it.

title: Correction

title: What the World Needs Now Is DDT
description: Thanks to Tina Rosenberg for exposing the developed world's complicity in malaria mortality and for missing none of the nuances of global politics by which the principle of sparing the environment from DDT is disconnected from the fact of two million malaria deaths a year. It's easy to imagine that public health officials are paralyzed by indecisiveness between the environmentalists' precautionary principle and the practical matter of controlling communicable disease with antibiotics, vaccines and insecticides. Rosenberg reveals the truth that principles can be reconciled with practice.

title: When Time Runs Out

title: Sydney
description: A love of the sea and the surf never quite leaves the people of Sydney. But this far into the Southern Hemisphere autumn, only the hardiest souls are still catching waves on the ocean beaches or swimming in outdoor pools. Most have stored their boards and swimsuits and replaced their skimpy beach gear with fall wardrobes of sweaters and jackets.

title: DISTRICT BUDGETS
description: Voters last week approved almost 70 percent of 550 school budgets, an increase over last year's 62 percent approval rate, according to the New Jersey School Boards Association. The budgets under consideration totaled more than $9.5 billion. The results were seen as an indication that residents by and large supported increases as state aid remains stagnant. ''I think voters understood the situation boards were in,'' said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the association. ''They have had inadequate state aid and rising costs not in their control.'' Voters supported increases in 39 of the 75 districts where the increases exceeded the state-imposed cap of more than 3 percent. Last year, one-third of those increases were approved. The election was by no means a rubber stamp. In one closely contested district, Fairfield, Essex County, the vote was tied 201 to 201 and is considered a defeat; the budget must now be decided by the town council. In Moorestown, Burlington County, in another close vote, the budget was defeated 1,056 to 1,037. Debra Nussbaum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAUMSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: BAUMSTEIN--Dorothy, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was born in Ostrowietz, Poland. She and her husband Bernard survived the Nazis and helped others do the same. In 1946 they were brought to New York by Bernard's older brothers and made a new life in the Bronx with their daughter Bina. Music and movies became Dorothy's passion, and she and Bernard won many dance contests together. In retirement they spent summers in Sag Harbor, near their beloved daughter, son-in-law Walter and granddaughter Sarah. Last May Dorothy fulfilled a wish by walking down the aisle at Sarah's wedding to Hugo Lindgren. In her last years, Dorothy was lovingly cared for by Bibi and Reuben Ledra. Funeral services will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, Long Island, Sunday, April 25, at 11 AM.

title: The New Queen of Mean
description: WITH her curves subdued by a dark blazer and her lovely face obscured by comp-lit glasses, Tina Fey may be America's most powerful antidote to the Barbie Doll. She's the first female co-anchor of ''Weekend Update'' on ''Saturday Night Live'' since Jane Curtin, who worked with Dan Aykroyd back in the 70's, and she's the first female head writer in the show's 29-year history. Two years ago, after reading Rosalind Wiseman's ''Queen Bees and Wannabes,'' a pop-ethnography that details the unfathomably cruel folkways of adolescent girls, Ms. Fey decided it was the perfect raw material for her first screenplay. The comedy, opening on Friday nationwide, is ''Mean Girls,'' a 97-minute orgy of wish fulfillment about a lonesome newcomer (Lindsay Lohan) who embeds herself in the popular crowd. On a recent spring afternoon, the writer Jennifer Senior had coffee with Ms. Fey, who also has a small role in the movie, to discuss screenwriting, news gathering and the mythological role of hot dogs in girl-world byzantium.

He leaves behind his devoted wife Camilla Samuelson, two children Debra Samuelson of NY, Cynthia Samuelson of Lexington, MA and son-inlaw, Jonathan Samen. title: Close Encounters

And for every one of these unopened books about the mysteries of our faith, there were 10 about the mysteries of our universe: U.F.O.'s, extrasensory perception, reincarnation and other subjects tiptoeing into blasphemy.

title: Cats, Like Us
description: ''After years of observation, I can confirm that love between cats exists,'' Hans Silvester writes in his captivating collection of photographs, CATS IN LOVE (Chronicle, $29.95). As in his previous book, ''The Complete Cats in the Sun,'' Silvester focuses on the stray cat population on the Greek island group called the Cyclades. Photograph after photograph debunks the myth that cats are aloof loners. There are glorious images of cats playing together, lying languorously in the sun, even mating. ''It's surprising to what degree cats' relationships resemble our own,'' Silvester writes. His images capture cats on the hoods of cars and on motorcycle seats, hiding under chairs, and walking with tails draped over each other  the embodiments of affection. There is a breathtaking series of photographs of two cats jumping together (almost gleefully, it appears) from ledge to ledge. ''Cats are an element of the island landscape,'' Silvester writes, ''like the wind, the sun, and the sea; they are a constant, like the coming of day and night.'' Carolyn T. Hughes

But in Miami, Florida, on 20 February 1927, he was born small and sickly. A premature baby of seven months, he weighed less than three pounds, and he seemed closer to death than life.

Throughout her life, Ms. Worsley generously shared her vast and extraordinary knowledge of the theatre with countless appreciative students. From 1970-1975, Ms. Worsley served as the Director of AMDA. Her courage, warmth and tireless dedication during those years are fondly remembered and highly treasured. We send our heartfelt sympathy and deepest condolences to her family.

The news was surprising and not a little deflating. The mutation that lifted us above the other apes had nothing directly to do with our brain. Rather, it had to do with our jaw. What led to the emergence of modern humans, in all of our culture-creating, science-discovering, globe-dominating glory, was a chance defect in a gene responsible for the formation of our jaw muscles. So, at least, the scientists speculated.

title: GOVERNOR WEIGHS TAX INCREASE
description: Governor McGreevey met with legislative leaders last week to negotiate details of a plan that would provide property tax rebates to elderly and middle-income homeowners by enacting a steep income tax increase for the state's wealthiest residents. After balking at the idea for months, Mr. McGreevey indicated that he would be willing to call a joint legislative session to propose the tax increase, provided that the proceeds go to property tax relief. The plan would raise the levy on households with a taxable income of more than $500,000 to about 9 percent from the current rate of 6.37 percent, legislative and administrative officials said. The $700 million raised by such an increase would pay for homestead rebates, which offer refunds to homeowners 65 and older, and would restore rebates to middle-income households. David Kocieniewski

title: 'The President of Good and Evil'
description: George W. Bush is not only America's president, but also its most prominent moralist. No other president in living memory has spoken so often about good and evil, right and wrong. His inaugural address was a call to build "a single nation of justice and opportunity." A year later, he famously proclaimed North Korea, Iran and Iraq to be an "axis of evil," and in contrast, he called the United States "a moral nation." He defends his tax policy in moral terms, saying that it is fair, and gives back to taxpayers what is rightfully theirs. The case he makes for free trade is "not just monetary, but moral." Open trade is a "moral imperative." Another "moral imperative," he says, is alleviating hunger and poverty throughout the world. He has said that "America's greatest economic need is higher ethical standards." In setting out the "Bush doctrine," which defends preemptive strikes against those who might threaten America with weapons of mass destruction, he asserted: "Moral truth is the same in every culture, in every time, and in every place." But in what moral truths does the president believe? Considering how much the president says about ethics, it is surprising how little serious discussion there has been of the moral philosophy of George W. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINER, EARL ROY, PHD
description: MINER -- Earl Roy, PhD, passed away on April 17, 2004 at Meadow Lakes in Hightstown, NJ after a long illness. Earl was Townsend Martin, Class of 1917, Professor of English and Comparative Literature until his retirement from Princeton University in 2000. He specialized in early modern English literature, classical Japanese literature and comparative poetics. Adding to Earl's many publications and numerous books will be a recently completed new edition of Milton's Paradise Lost which will be published in the summer of 2004. He was President of the Milton Society of America, the American Society for 18th Century Studies and the International Comparative Literature Association. He was honored with Princeton's Behrman Award for distinguished achievement in the humanities in 1993. In 1994 he received the Order of the Rising Sun from the government of Japan in recognition of his ''special commitment'' to Japanese literature. Earl is survived by Jinny, his loving wife of 53 years, their children, Erik and Lisa, and grandson, Bryan. Also surviving are four brothers, Eldon, Arthur and David in Arizona and Norman in California. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Earl Miner Memorial Fund can be sent to the Comparative Literature Department, 133 East Pyne, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544. At Earl's request, there will be no service.

The first thing I noticed was the eagerness to sign me up for just one master's course. I received quick, detailed replies and follow-up phone calls. E-Cornell had a good course, but turned out not to be offering it when I wanted to start. Cardean won out over Phoenix because it was willing to provide information on the instructors; the norm is to tell you about the professor who planned the course, not the professor who is actually teaching it. title: The Essence of the Dust Bowl, at 40 Below

Mr. Maddin, a Canadian, has an affinity for the early German Expressionist films of Fritz Lang, as well as the nightmarish surreality of David Lynch. '' 'Eraserhead' gave me the courage to make movies,'' he once said. '' 'Wow,' I thought, when I saw it. 'This is my biography. How did someone read my mind and project it onto the screen?' '' Mr. Maddin's new film, ''The Saddest Music in the World,'' is filled with imagery that seems projected directly from his psyche. Set in Winnipeg, Manitoba, during the Depression, this stark fantasia is about a ruthless beer baroness (Isabella Rossellini), who in an effort to encourage alcohol consumption, sponsors a global contest to find the most mournful music possible.

title: Alexander Hamilton, City Boy

The first treasury secretary prided himself on his broad, continental perspective, and even fervid admirers have been loath to cast him as a New Yorker, lest this tarnish his gleaming national vision. Yet in five years of research, I have found that Hamilton, loaded with brash charm, bottomless energy and worldly cunning, was in fact the classic New Yorker and a quintessential urbanite.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSEMAN, MILL
description: ROSEMAN--Mill. August 14, 1921-September 27, 2003. Son of Pearl and Mischa, died at home in Center Moriches, with his adoring wife at his side. Loving father of Paul, Jane, Robin and John (Hinchcliff). Doting grandfather of Kate, Abby, and Emily. Graduate CCNY; MA, NYU. Worked at PM newspaper with his good friend George Nelson. Served in the Army Air Corps in WWII. A lifelong ad man and marketing consultant, early on Mill worked for the American Jewish Committee and did publicity for Nathan's of Coney Island. He worked with James Beard and other notables in the food world. In the 1950's, Mill became a partner in The Lampert Agency. He had a long association with Strathmore Paper, and later in life was VP of Marketing at Impressions of Roslyn. He was a regular contributor to ''Communication Arts.'' Mill was a fine writer --precise, elegant language was his to command. He was an accomplished sculptor, working in various media. He loved music & art, across a heroically eclectic spectrum, but what truly defined Mill was his passionate, immutable belief that everyone was entitled to social justice, to be able to work with dignity at a fair wage, and to be able to live their lives unburdened by oppression and fear. Mill marched for civil rights and for the rights of women to choose their reproductive destinies. He found war and aggression and imperialism abhorrent. He was a wonderful husband, and is sorely missed by those who loved him. Linda S. Miller-Roseman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDELMAN, WILLIAM
description: EDELMAN--William. 82, died April 23, surrounded by his beloved family. At his side were his children, Norma Penn, Neil Edelman, Terry Tannenbaum, son-in-law David Penn, daughter-in-law Shelley Edelman and his grandchildren Jonathan, Ricki, Jeremy, Jessica, Jillian, Ryanne and Evan. William's beloved wife Esther had passed away suddenly in 1991. Both of them, Holocaust survivors, had endured so many difficult years of devastating experiences and the annihilation of most of their families. Yet, together they persevered, overcame their tragedies and created a wonderful and loving life for them and their children here, in America. William was a man of slight build, but a ''Giant of a Man'' as he towered among everyone with his kindness, generosity, intellect, warmth and love. For he was truly ''over 10 feet tall.'' He leaves a legacy to those who knew and loved him as a relative, friend and business associate, of a human being who knew how to live, how to survive, how to deal with life's adversities. There was always a warm greeting, a kind word, and a true interest in your well-being when you were with William. You knew he cared about you and you respected him and loved him for it. William was born on December 27, 1921 in BiallerPodliask, Poland, one of five children. At the age of 19, he left for Russia as the Nazis entered Poland. He joined the Russian army and fought in a Polish division. He and one other member of his division were the sole survivors of a brutal onslaught by the Nazis. At the end of the war he returned to his hometown to see if anyone else had survived. His entire famlily with the exception of one sister had been slaughtered. It was upon his return that he met Esther, who, with one of her sisters, were the sole survivors of their family. He eventually married Esther and lived in a Displaced Persons Camp, where their first child Norma was born. Soon thereafter in 1950, the family left for America, where they first settled in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. William was a butcher, struggling and working to support and feed three children, which now included Neil and Terry. At the same time, he attended Brooklyn College in an effort to educate himself with the hope and expectation of being able to create a better life for his family. He managed, in spite of the financial difficulties, to save money and miraculously became a Real Estate Builder and Developer. He actually had to leave college a few credits short of a Bachelor of Science Degree because the business had grown to such an extent that it required 100% of his time. In the late 1950s William became a major developer of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn and in Staten Island. In the 1970s he built The Georgetowne hi-rise on Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn. Eventually his son Neil and son-inlaw David joined the business. Throughout the 1950s and even today, he and his firm, Forest View, and the Georgetowne are well-regarded and respected in the building construction industry. William was a member of the Board of Directors of the Israeli Humanitarian Foundation and Secretary of the Bialler Society (an organization of survivors of the Holocaust from the area surrounding his birthplace). William will truly be missed by all those whose paths he crossed, but the experience of life took on a unique meaning for each of them because of the richness of what he had imparted, for William was truly a ''Gentleman.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOLLINI, CHARLES F.
description: FOLLINI--Charles F. The beloved husband of Maria, the adored father of Christina and CJ and the cherished grandfather to Charles and Jeremiah Reen, died peacefully of natural causes on Sunday, April 25. He was 91. The son of immigrant parents and born in the Tremont section of the Bronx, Charles' abundant life was the quintessential American success story. At a young age, Charles formed the values and character that made him legendary to friends and strangers alike throughout his life. He placed utmost importance on integrity, loyalty and commitment, so much that he altered his driver's license by two years in order to join the New York Fire Department. As a Fireman 1st Class with Ladder Company 13, Charles was awarded the Walter Scott Medal for Exceptional Valor by Mayor O'Dwyer on June 3, 1946. To rescue a trapped man, Charles forced his way into a blazing building even before other firemen could put a hose to the flames or clear the place of smoke or gas. He carried the man to safety. After retiring from the NYFD, Charles and his brothers founded what became Edenwald Contracting Co, Inc. of Whitestone, Queens. By the 1980's, Edenwald had grown to become one of the largest municipal and utility contractors in New York. During his time, Charles with his brother George were the Chief Executives of the firm which performed hundreds of millions of dollars of construction projects prior to 1994. Edenwald was also responsible for such notable projects as the US Open Tennis Center in Flushing, NY, and the award-winning Washington Market Park in Tribeca. First Lady Nancy Reagan honored Charles and his company's contributions to its design and construction. In later years, Charles became a successful developer in association with the Rockefeller Group in Mount Olive, NJ, and also throughout Whitestone, Queens. Charles spent these later years devoted to his family, especially his grandsons, Charlie and Jeremiah, whose presence for a man so advanced in age was the greatest gift God could bestow. Family, friends and acquaintances honor and treasure the memory of someone so trusted that his word was his bond, and truly a man among men. Services will be held on Wednesday, April 28, at Coxe & Graziano, 767 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, NY 10543, and a Mass will be held at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, in Pelham, NY, on Thursday, April 29, at 10 am.

The ring, dubbed the Codwise Crew after the Corona street where one of their robberies took place, often sought out Asian or Indian immigrants, believing them more likely to keep cash at home, the police said. The suspects come from Cali, Colombia, and nearly all of them entered the country illegally, Deputy Chief Hall said. The arrests were first reported yesterday in The Daily News. Shaila K. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANASTOS, ROSEMARY PARK
description: ANASTOS--Rosemary Park. Prominent educator, passed away quietly in her home in Los Angeles, CA, on Saturday, April 17, at the age of 97. She earned her doctorate in German literature at the University of Cologne in 1934 with a dissertation on Richard Wagner. She was a Professor of German and Academic Dean at Connecticut College from 1943 to 1947 and served as President of the college from 1947 to 1962. In 1962 she accepted an appointment as President of Barnard College, moving in 1967 to UCLA, where she was a Vice-Chancellor from 1967 to 1970, and Professor of Higher Education from 1967 until her retirement in 1974. She received numerous recognitions and honors, including honorary degrees from 25 universities and colleges. She was the widow of Milton V. Anastos, distinguished Professor of Byzantine Greek and History at UCLA, who died in 1997. She supervised the publication of a portion of her late husband's unfinished survey of Byzantine intellectual history. She is survived by her stepson Milton V. Anastos Jr., and by several nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the UCLA Faculty Center at 4 pm, Wednesday, May 5.
