title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMERON, DONALD JOHN, M.D.
description: CAMERON -- Donald John, M.D., 74, of Bronxville and Point O' Woods, NY died on April 23 at home of complications from cancer. Dr. Cameron, son of the late Gertrude and James K. Cameron was born in Rochester, NY, raised in Scarsdale, NY, graduated from Scarsdale High School, Amherst College, and Cornell University Medical College. After serving as a Captain in the U.S. Medical Corps, 195658, 10th Field Hospital, Wurzburg, Germany, he became a resident on the 2nd Cornell Medical Division of Bellevue Hospital. In the private practice of internal medicine for over 40 years, Dr. Cameron was Clinical Associate Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, a respected clinician and revered teacher. He was Attending Physician at Doctor's Hospital from 1970-95 and Attending Physician at New York Hospital. Upon retirement, he became an associate at the Rogisin Lipid Center. A Fellow of the American College of Physicians and the New York Academy of Medicine, he was also a Director of the Griffis Faculty Club, a member of the Physicians Scientific Society, the Medical Strollers and a Physician of The St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York. Beloved husband of Alison for 48 years, loving father of son Douglas W. and his wife Tara, of Tiburon, CA and daughter Laura C. Hale and her husband Tyler, of Manhattan and devoted grandfather of Douglas W. Jr. He is also survived by sisters Gail C. Wescott of Atlanta and Jean C. Phleger of San Francisco as well as many nephews and nieces. Donald was a 20 year Director of the Point O' Woods Association, a member of Siwanoy Country Club, The University Club and The Hillsboro Club of Florida. An enthusiastic skier, golfer, ocean swimmer, bridge, backgammon and croquet player, he will be dearly missed by family, friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be held Friday, April 30 at 11AM at The Reformed Church, Pondfield Road, Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Reformed Church, The Church at Point O' Woods, or The Fund for Research, Department of Medicine, New York Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Changes Rules On Some Carrier Fees
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it would not bill other carriers fees of about a half-cent a minute to connect callers who use a high-speed Internet connection to reach Qwest local-telephone customers. Qwest, the nation's fourth-largest local telephone company, said that it was urging the Federal Communications Commission to adopt similar rules nationally. Denver-based Qwest is using the policy in its local-service territory, which covers 14 Western states. Qwest said it was the only one of the four regional phone carriers known as Baby Bells to adopt such a stance. The move comes as Internet-phone start-ups like Vonage Holdings increasingly take customers from local carriers, which are also starting to offer similar services, as Qwest has done. The move will not have a big financial effect on the company, because less than 1 percent of Qwest's call-connection fees comes from Internet-phone services, Qwest's senior vice president, R. Steven Davis, said. The company collects several hundred million dollars annually in total fees, said Mr. Davis, who could not immediately provide a precise number. The policy would speed the spread of so-called voice-over-Internet protocol, or VoIP services, and would benefit customers, the industry and Qwest, the company said. Qwest shares rose 4 cents, to $4.29.

description: The Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, a poultry processor, said yesterday that it would shed a processing plant and its 1,300 workers in a bid to end losses in the fresh turkey business. The cost to close or sell the turkey plant, which is in Hinton, Va., will result in expenses of $46 million, or 69 cents a share, for the six months ended Oct. 2, the company said. The turkey business will have a loss of as much as $8 million in the next two quarters and will be profitable in 2005, the company said. Shedding the plant will reduce production of turkey meat and strengthen the company's focus on value-added turkey products, O.B. Goolsby, the company's chief operating officer, said in a statement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Homeless Man's Death a Homicide
description: After more than a year in which the cause of death of a homeless man imprisoned at Riker's Island was undetermined, the police on Sunday reclassified his death as a homicide. The man, Philip Generoso, 47, developed an acute case of pneumonia while serving a one-and-a-half- to two-year sentence, and died on Feb. 4, 2003. An autopsy revealed that he had no spleen, and that because the spleen plays an important role in the body's immune system, its absence had probably contributed to his getting pneumonia. The police located Mr. Generoso's sister this month, and last week she told them that on Feb. 17, 2002, Mr. Generoso was assaulted, and so badly injured that his spleen was surgically removed. The police said they were now investigating the assault, which contributed to his death. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Electronic Data Posts Loss On Navy Contract
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the world's second-largest seller of computer services, yesterday posted a first-quarter loss from continuing operations of $38 million on costs connected with a contract to build a data network for the United States Navy. The loss from continuing operations was 7 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $1.43 billion, or $3 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $5.2 billion from $5.02 billion. Electronic Data had a $145 million operating loss from its $6.9 billion Navy contract, adding to more than $1 billion in losses since 2000. The task to merge about 1,000 computer systems has been besieged by testing delays and software problems. I.B.M. and other rivals have taken advantage of the problems to steal clients. The company said it expected results this quarter of break-even to a loss of 6 cents a share, on sales of $5.1 billion to $5.2 billion. Analysts expected sales of $5.16 billion, according to the average forecast in a survey by Thomson Financial. Excluding a gain of 8 cents a share from the sale of its automotive group, and 10 cents a share in costs associated with laying off 5,200 workers, Electronic Data had a loss of 1 cent a share, in line with the average analyst forecast. The shares fell to $18.56 in extended trading. They declined 16 cents, to $19.23, in regular trading.

title: A Destructive Vote in Cyprus
description: The overwhelming vote by Greek Cypriots on Saturday to reject the United Nations' reunification plan for their divided island was destructive but hardly a surprise. The Greek majority on Cyprus had made no secret of its distaste for the plan, largely because of limits on the number of Greeks who would be able to reclaim the property they lost when Turkey invaded the northern part of the island in 1974. The United States and the European Union had hoped they could overcome that resistance through political pressure. But the hard fact is that the Greek Cypriots knew their government would be joining the E.U. on May 1 as ''Cyprus,'' with or without a deal with the Turkish north. The only way to restore any chance for reunification now is for the E.U. and the United States to get tough, by lifting economic sanctions on the Turkish north and sharply limiting aid to the Greek south.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Sunny Budget
description: Having led New York out of two years of multibillion-dollar budget shortfalls, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has brought the city to something like an oasis. The improved economy and the current surplus of about $800 million demonstrate how wise Mr. Bloomberg was when he decided to raise taxes to protect the city's quality-of-life services during the recession. The turnaround is an enormous fiscal achievement for Mr. Bloomberg, but it's a tenuous one. Politicians with their eyes on the next election could ruin everything with too many ill-targeted tax breaks, too soon. That includes Mr. Bloomberg's own plan to give a $400 property tax rebate to each homeowner in the city.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Testimony On Accuser's History
description: Witnesses testified behind closed doors in the rape case of Kobe Bryant, the Los Angeles Lakers basketball star, and some documents were made public as the two sides continued to disagree over several issues, including whether the accuser can be called a victim. In the first of three days of closed hearings this week in Eagle, Judge W. Terry Ruckriegle heard arguments about the relevance of the 19-year-old accuser's sexual history and whether the police improperly obtained statements and other evidence last summer from Mr. Bryant, 25. He is accused of raping the woman, a hotel employee but has said that the sex was consensual. The judge gave the two sides 15 days to submit briefs on the issue of whether to refer to the accuser as a victim, which the defense says implies Mr. Bryant's guilt. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: No Small Price to Pay for Denim Perfection
description: In the beginning there was Levi's. And Levi's begat Wrangler and Lee. And Wrangler and Lee begat Jordache and Calvin Klein and Sergio Valente. And then, moved by the mystical and inexorable forces of the American marketplace, the jeans makers all went forth and multiplied. By now every parent of a teenager is aware of this reality. The days when the crucial decision in purchasing a pair of blue jeans was as simple as predicting the degree of inseam shrinkage are as remote as the Gold Rush.

description: The latest shocking numbers from the states' hard-pressed child welfare programs confirm the ongoing national tragedy in which 1,400 children died from abuse and neglect in 2002. This intolerable toll looms darkly in a federal study that counted 896,000 abused and neglected foster children in the same year. Even the state officials now threatened with penalties candidly admit to widespread shortcomings in tracking and protecting society's most vulnerable members.

title: A Clearer Path to Reading Fluency
description: Remedial programs for students with dyslexia often succeed only in making bad readers into slightly better bad readers. Now a new study shows that more aggressive treatment can make dyslexic brains work the way normal brains do, activating a region that plays a vital role in reading fluency.

title: Learning the Risks of Looking Good
description: Any medical procedure poses some risks, and that includes surgery performed simply to look good. By definition, in elective surgery any risk is unnecessary. But people take a variety of unnecessary risks -- riding horses, scuba diving -- for a variety of reasons. Depending on the point of view, jowls or bags under the eyes may be a very good reason.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: A Curb On Grade Inflation
description: The Princeton faculty approved a plan yesterday to reduce the number of A's, including A-pluses and A-minuses, from almost 50 percent of all grades to 35 percent, the level in the late 1980's and early 1990's. The vote, after 90 minutes of discussion, was 156 to 84, according to the university's Web site. Nancy Weiss Malkiel, dean of the undergraduate college, called the vote a ''strong affirmation'' and said the focus now would be on implementing the plan and being sensitive to concerns raised by both faculty and students. Some critics had charged that Princeton students would be at a disadvantage in the job market and in graduate schools if Princeton gave fewer A's than other colleges. But Dr. Malkiel said that graduate school directors and employers had applauded the move, saying it would help them distinguish the students' abilities. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: A Night of Living Art at the Metropolitan Museum
description: The term Este Lauder liked to use was ''elegant achievers,'' a cosmetic and certainly a polite way of saying people on the make. No town appreciates an elegant achiever as much as this one, and few better opportunities come about for such types to disport themselves than the annual Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which, true to the rules of the game, is advertised as the Party of the Year.

Mr. Summerford has been vice president, international, since March 2003. He will start working from Britain on June 1.

title: Claude (Fiddler) Williams, 96, Jazz Violinist
description: Claude (Fiddler) Williams, who began swinging on string instruments before the word jazz was commonly used, went on to become Count Basie's first recorded guitarist and continued playing violin with other jazz greats into his 90's, died on Sunday in Kansas City. He was 96.

title: Justices Won't Hear Military-College Appeal on Dinner Prayer
description: The Supreme Court refused on Monday to consider an appeal by the State of Virginia to permit the state-sponsored Virginia Military Institute to return to the practice of dinner-hour prayers. Two lower federal courts had declared the cadet-led prayers unconstitutional.

title: Mr. Cheney's Day in Court
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today on Vice President Dick Cheney's attempt to keep the public from knowing who met with him behind closed doors three years ago to draft the administration's energy policy. The case is best known for the controversy over Justice Antonin Scalia's decision to go duck hunting with Mr. Cheney while it was pending. But it raises important issues in its own right. The court should affirm the decisions of the lower courts and order Mr. Cheney to disclose the names of the participants. It should also be mindful of the role Justice Scalia plays. There is a real danger that his participation will damage the court's reputation.

title: Plea Deal Reported Near in Patients' Deaths
description: Prosecutors in New Jersey and Pennsylvania are nearing a plea agreement with a former nurse, Charles Cullen, under which he would be spared the death penalty, plead guilty in 14 patients' deaths and help investigators identify his other victims, law enforcement officials said. Mr. Cullen has claimed to have killed more than 30 patients.

title: Every Passenger Is a Potential Case Study
description: An airplane cabin is a fertile laboratory for the study of social interaction. One time, the man next to me was drooling and snoring. As usual, in my direction. I let my tray fall with a clunk. I tried adjusting my seat. One passenger gave me that ''I feel bad for you'' pout. Finally when the drool on his chin reached high tide, I nudged him. If I were in bed and this were my husband, I would have my routine perfected. But if I know him only as the guy sitting in 13B, do I have the right to wake him?

title: Of Smoking Bans and Heart Attacks
description: A six-month ban on smoking in public places and workplaces in Helena, Mont., appears to have sharply reduced the number of heart attacks. For the six months that the ban was in effect in 2002, there were only 24 heart attack admissions for Helena residents at the hospital serving all cardiac patients in the area. That was a 40 percent reduction from the 40 heart attacks recorded for the same six-month period, on average, in the four years before the ban and in the year after it. There was no similar drop for people living outside Helena, where the ban was not in effect.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Bottler's Earnings Rise
description: The brewer and bottler Femsa, Latin America's largest beverage company, said first-quarter income rose 95.9 percent, to $73 million, on sales of $1.82 billion, up 55.4 percent. Driving the increase was the acquisition of Panamerican Beverages last year by Femsa's subsidiary Coca-Cola Femsa. Sales at Coca-Cola Femsa rose 140 percent, to $935 million, and profit increased 77 percent, to $78 million. The purchase of Panamerican Beverages for $2.7 billion added operations in Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela and Central America. Revenue rose for Femsa's brewing unit -- the maker of the Dos Equis, Sol and Tecate brands -- helped by stronger sales in Mexico and rising exports to the United States. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: MEMO PAD
description: GENERAL AVIATION SAGGED IN 2003 -- Shipments of general aviation aircraft of all types fell 3.2 percent in 2003, though strength was seen in the fourth quarter largely because of a surge in the sale of piston-engine planes, according to the General Aviation Manufacturers Association. More than 211,000 general aviation aircraft operate in the United States, ranging from single-engine propeller planes to so-called heavy metal corporate jets capable of long-distance flight. About 70 percent of the 29 million flight hours logged by general aviation planes last year was for business.

title: Many in Dance World Give Backing to a Smaller Theater at Ground Zero
description: Many in the New York dance world are rallying behind the Joyce Theater's proposal to build a 900-seat home for dance as a cultural anchor for the World Trade Center site, favoring it over the New York City Opera's proposal to build a 2,200-seat opera house that would be used in part for dance in the off-season.

title: Mort Sahl, Still Simmering After All These Years
description: Mort Sahl was riffing on the military record of President Bush the other night from the stage at the Village Theater, where he performed many times in the 1950's and 1960's, when the place was known as the Village Gate. He could only imagine, he said, the version of the conversation Mr. Bush had with his daughter Jenna that so many fathers have had with their children.

title: Hotels, Again Profitable, Are Adding Surcharges
description: The brochure of the Comfort Inn Oceanfront in Miami Beach, is awash in caveats about extra charges: a daily parking fee of $9.50, a pet surcharge of $25 a stay and $10 a night, a visitor parking fee of $6 for every four hours. But there is no mention of a $1.50-a-night fee for a safe in the room, payable whether you use it or not.

title: MGM'S DIRECTORS APPROVE A ONE-TIME DIVIDEND
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the movie studio controlled by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, said its directors had approved a one-time dividend of $8 a share. The dividend will be payable May 17 to shareholders of record May 7, the company said. Mr. Kerkorian and his closely held Tracinda Corporation, which together own more than 174 million MGM shares, will receive about $1.39 billion. ''Our strong cash flow and our confidence in our ability to continue to generate strong cash flow are the principal reasons why we decided to reward our shareholders,'' Alex Yemenidjian, MGM's chief executive, said. Shares fell 10 cents, to $20.17 a share.

title: CPI DISMISSES ITS CHIEF AND NAMES AN ACTING SUCCESSOR
description: The CPI Corporation, which operates photography studios in Sears, Roebuck & Company department stores, said yesterday that it had dismissed J. David Pierson as chief executive and chairman. Jack Krings was named acting chief executive, chief operating officer and president, CPI said. Mr. Krings joined CPI in October 2001 and has served as president of the portrait studio division, the company said. CPI, based in St. Louis, has not yet begun a search for a permanent successor, a spokeswoman, Jane Nelson, said. She declined to comment on why Pierson was removed. The management change follows a campaign by shareholders led by Knightspoint Partners, an investment firm in New York, to oust most of CPI's board. The group complained the company was not doing enough to stop a three-year decline in its portrait sittings.

description: FRELINGHUYSEN -- George Griswold died at the age of 92, after a long illness, on Sunday, April 25, 2004 at his home in West Palm Beach, Florida. He was the son of Mr. & Mrs. Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J. and was named for his grandfather, G.G. Frelinghuysen, also of Morristown. His maternal grandparents were Mr. & Mrs. H.O. Havermeyer, of New York, N.Y. At an early age Mr. Frelinghuysen was employed at John Wanamaker's in New York, where he developed solid talent as an interior designer. He later went into business for himself. During a long and active life, he lived for many years in Morristown. Later he moved to Bel Air and Santa Barbara, California and then to Santa Fe, New Mexico. Next he lived for years in Honolulu, Hawaii before his final move to Florida. Mr. Frelinghuysen is survived by a younger brother, Peter, of Morristown, and by six nephews and two nieces.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Crackdown On Drag Racing
description: Less than three weeks after two pedestrians were seriously injured in a hit-and-run accident that the authorities linked to drag-racing, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, left, has renewed efforts to prosecute such drivers. Three men -- Vitaliy Zaytsev, 21, of Bayside; Brian Kessler, 23, of Middle Village; and Stephen Montalbano, 19, of Jamaica -- who the police said were driving at high speeds have been charged with reckless endangerment and other violations. They are not suspects in the hit-and-run accident. Mr. Brown began a crackdown on drag-racing along public streets after the hit-and-run, in which two high school students were struck on April 8. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: 'Jerry Springer' Approaches
description: Producers of ''Jerry Springer -- The Opera'' announced yesterday that the critically acclaimed West End musical would open on Broadway on Oct. 20, 2005. The theater is yet to be determined. Based on Mr. Springer's infamously vulgar daytime talk show and starring Michael Brandon, above, the Olivier Award-winning musical, which balances high- and lowbrow culture, features a crew of characters that includes two-timing bisexuals and lesbian dwarfs, singing chorales and anthems that evoke Bach and Handel. The score is by Richard Thomas, and the book and lyrics are by Stewart Lee and Mr. Thomas. Before the show moves to New York, it will have a six-week tryout at the Orpheum Theater in San Francisco during the spring of 2005. The much-traveled musical had its premiere at the 2002 Edinburgh Fringe Festival. It transferred to London's Royal National Theater in April 2003 and moved to the West End for a commercial run in the fall. JASON ZINOMAN

title: FEDEX CHANGING KINKO'S BRAND NAME TO FEDEX KINKO'S

title: 'Plan of Attack': All the President's Mentors
description: On April 19 - the day the American Revolution began in 1775 - Bob Woodward released ''Plan of Attack'' with a fusillade of publicity that will not soon be equaled. The shot heard round Washington benefited from several factors, including its timing. Stirred up by the recent revelations of Richard Clarke and Paul O'Neill, the turmoil over the 9/11 commission and the dawning sense that our Iraq problems are not going away soon, the news media rolled out the red carpet for a book that was rumored to be more critical of the Bush administration - and therefore important - than Woodward's previous reporting. The result has been a little difficult to decipher amid the cacophony of television chatter and White House denials (to say nothing of the ka-ching of cash registers). But a serious book it is, instantly essential, matching America's most celebrated political reporter against the most secretive administration in our history. For once, a hyped product has lived up to its billing.

title: Looking Past Town Borders To Bridge the Snowplow Gap
description: A peculiar ritual occurs across Long Island during winter storms. Snowplow trucks rumble along roads clearing the way -- but then every so often they suddenly lift their plows, leaving the snow on the next stretch of pavement untouched.

title: Knicks Have Little and Need to Do a Lot
description: When Isiah Thomas took over as the Knicks' president of basketball operations earlier this season, he was faced with an immediate choice. He could strip salary from the roster, dealing away contracts as quickly as possible, and let expiring contracts run their course to begin building for the future. Or he could do what he did during the season, adding contracts that most other teams would avoid, pushing the Knicks higher above the salary cap and the luxury-tax threshold and patching together a team with some hope of contending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHULTZ, SEYMOUR
description: SHULTZ--Seymour, 95, of NYC on April 26, 2004. Beloved brother of the late Ethel Cooper, and Lillian and George Blumenson. Loving uncle of Shiela and Joel Pollack, and Lester and Genia Blumenson. Grand uncle of Ellen and Bonnie, Craig, Stacey, Jeffrey, and Carolyn and their respective spouses and nine great grand nieces and nephews. Seymour worked for Paramount Pictures for over 55 years. A kind, loving, giving, and generous man he will be sorely missed by all who loved him. Services April 28, at 1 P.M. Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ. Info Gutterman-Musicant 1-800522-0588

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: L-3 Profit Rises 45% On Acquisitions
description: L-3 Communications Holdings, a maker of bomb detectors and military electronics, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 45 percent on acquisitions and demand for wartime maintenance. Sales climbed to $1.52 billion, from $1.09 billion. Shares rose $1.21 to $62.05.

title: Suburban Retailing for the New Brooklyn
description: In Dumbo, a high-concept exercise in nesting lust called Hadco, a demonstration center where customers can try out luxe appliances for purchase elsewhere, has opened near outposts of ABC Carpet and Home and West Elm. In Gowanus, within eyeshot of a fuel-oil depot and a bustling scrap-metal business, a gleaming new 136,000-square-foot Lowe's, the chain's first foray into New York City's urban market, is set to open this Friday. And in Red Hook, if Ikea has its way, an enormous yellow and blue box will draw shoppers to the Erie Basin.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Altering Stock Symbols
description: Seeking to address one of the chief criticisms of corporate governance standards in Canada, the Toronto Stock Exchange said that, starting in October, a two-letter suffix would be added to the stock symbols of listed companies to identify nonvoting, multiple-voting or subordinated-voting share structures. Several of Canada's most prominent companies have dual-voting structures, usually put in place in an attempt to entrench the control of family shareholders. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Bush Issues Directive to Bolster Defense Against Bioterrorism
description: President Bush has approved a series of initiatives intended to enhance the nation's defenses against a catastrophic biological weapons attack, senior administration officials said Tuesday. The steps include creation of a common surveillance system to collect and analyze information about bioterrorist threats.

title: Regional Orchestra Flounders In Troubled Financial Waters
description: Long Island seems to possess an artistic Bermuda triangle into which entire theater troupes, dance companies and chamber groups have vanished. The Long Island Philharmonic, faced with the area's diffuse geography and with an aging, shrinking audience base -- a problem that has plagued regional orchestras across the country -- is trying to avoid a similar fate.

description: To some viewers and at least one interview subject of this Friday's edition of the newsmagazine ''20/20'' on ABC, the promotions for an hourlong special about open adoption have made it come across as the newest, and perhaps most outrageous, reality show yet.

description: An article on Friday about the internal investigation of fabrications by the former USA Today reporter Jack Kelley referred imprecisely to the departure of Brian Gallagher from the executive editor's position and misstated the timing of his announcement. Mr. Gallagher, the paper's No. 2 editor, said that he would give up the post soon after the appointment of a new top editor and that his future at the paper had yet to be resolved. He did not say he was resigning. Mr. Gallagher made the announcement at a meeting of editors Thursday morning, not at a larger gathering of the newsroom staff later in the day. ( Go to Article )

title: Israelis March In Gaza Strip, 70,000 Strong
description: Tens of thousands of Israelis descended on this seaside settlement bloc on Tuesday in the largest public expression yet of opposition to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw settlers and soldiers from the Gaza Strip.

title: Thai Security Forces Kill Scores of Rebels
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 28 — In the worst outbreak of violence in years of turmoil in Thailand's Muslim southern provinces, the government said 112 people were killed today when armed men staged a series of raids before dawn on police stations and security outposts.

title: Damascus Hit By a Bombing And a Gunfight
description: Heavily armed assailants detonated a bomb near a cluster of foreign embassies in Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Tuesday, setting off an intense gun battle with state security forces that maintain exceptionally tight control over the society.

title: 2nd Attacker Pleads Guilty In Community Leader's Death
description: Five years after a prominent East Village community leader was beaten to death on a street in Queens, a New Jersey man pleaded guilty yesterday to manslaughter, bringing a case that had galvanized the victim's friends and family close to a resolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OBEL, DAVID
description: OBEL--David. Adoring husband of Susan. Most loving and proud father of Karen and Kenneth (Jennifer). Devoted brother of Max (Ellen). A kind, generous man whom we will lovingly remember and terribly miss. Services Wednesday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: G.M. Has Way to Go on Road to Recall Redemption
description: General Motors called it the Road to Redemption campaign: After years of problems with quality, the company started proclaiming in an unusual series of newspaper and magazine ads beginning last year that it had rededicated itself to fixing its past problems.

title: Korean Automaker Passes U.S. and Europeans in Quality Survey
description: DETROIT, April 28  Hyundai, the Korean automaker, surpassed domestic and European manufacturers for the first time in J. D. Power's closely watched initial quality rankings.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about sushi referred incorrectly to the wasabi plant, the source of the condiment traditionally served with raw fish. As a member of the mustard family, it is indeed related to horseradish.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: N.Y.U. Student Faces Drug-Dealing Charges
description: Following a six-month undercover investigation, a New York University student was arrested yesterday on felony drug-dealing charges, the police said. The student, Julia Diaco, 18, of Rumson, N.J., sold marijuana, psychedelic mushrooms, acid, ecstasy and cocaine to undercover detectives on at least eight occasions in her dormitory, Hayden Hall, and at other West Village locations, said Lt. Phillip A. Spinella of the Manhattan South Narcotics Bureau said. The sales ranged from $60 to $650, he said. ''It's an area where we have a lot of problems, it's a high-profile area,'' he said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

Plaza, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations to HIAS, 333 7th Ave., NY NY. 10001.

title: Those Illegal Farm Subsidies
description: America's lavish handouts to its farmers harvest poverty throughout the developing world. And they are illegal as well. That's the conclusion of a World Trade Organization panel that heard Brazil's challenge to the cotton subsidies that belie this nation's commitment to free and fair trade.

title: The City Life; A Tree Trimmed in Brooklyn
description: The tree surgeon spoke in whispers, as if to keep the nearby trees from overhearing. ''You've gotta be careful about how you cut these trees,'' he said. ''If you take off too big a piece and leave too big a wound, rot seeps in and the tree dies.'' This would be very bad. The 65-foot locust trees in question are surrounded by Brooklyn rowhouses and would cause a great deal of damage -- not to mention lawsuits -- if they fell.

title: Lawmakers Voice Doom and Gloom On W.T.O. Ruling
description: Lawmakers from major farm states, shaken by a preliminary World Trade Organization ruling against the government's multibillion-dollar subsidies to the cotton industry, warned on Tuesday that the action could deal a severe blow to agribusinesses and farmers nationwide.

title: After a Two-Year Absence, Zito Is Back in the Race
description: It is hard to pick the lowest moment of the winter or spring for the trainer Nick Zito. There are just too many things to choose from.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, MAURICE
description: FRIEDMAN -- Maurice, 95, died April 27 after a brief illness. Loving and beloved husband for 67 years of Hilda; father and father-in-law of Steve and Barbara, Phyllis and Brad Perkins, Rich and Joanna; grandfather of Suzy and David Cohen, Caroline and David Levy, David Benioff Friedman, Rachael and Moshe Arenstein, Judith and Scott Schiamberg, Rebecca Perkins and Rebecca, Daniel and Julia Friedman; greatgrandfather of Sam and Zeke Cohen and Tea and Evelina Levy; Brother and brother-inlaw of Martha, Harry and Bea, Ed and Selma Kaufman, and the late Alex and Hilda Weinig, Seymour and Claire, Ed, and Milton and Gert Kaufman. The many people whom he touched knew him to be one of a kind, a person of extraordinary warmth, heart and cheer who took enormous joy from other people and who gave it in return. He was a successful insurance broker but his real accomplishments in life were to add measurably to the store of human love and to set the standard for those around him as a son, sibling, spouse, parent, grandparent, great - grandparent and friend. Services Thursday, April 29, 10am, ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, NY.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Having just opened BLT STEAK in Midtown with JIMMY HABER, LAURENT TOURONDEL plans to add a little Vietnamese spot in TriBeCa. His casual VIET CAFE, 345 Greenwich Street (Jay Street) is expected to open by the summer.

title: $5 Billion in Antiterror Aid Is Reported Stuck in Pipeline
description: More than $5 billion in federal money to help communities brace for terrorist attacks has not yet reached the local authorities and remains stuck in the administrative pipeline, Congressional officials said Tuesday.

title: With Skeptical Eye, Marines Train Iraqis for Falluja Patrols
description: A dozen Iraqi troops practiced storming a building for about an hour here on Tuesday under the watchful, if dubious, eyes of the American marines they are expected to join for patrols inside this violent city.

title: Derby Drug For All But One Contestant
description: Smarty Jones has already outrun his pedigree in winning all six of his races on the way to the Kentucky Derby. He will be the only undefeated colt when what is expected to be a full field of 20 horses is loaded into the starting gate for the Derby late Saturday afternoon, and he will be one of the favorites in the 130th running of the race.

title: New Armored Vehicles Being Rushed to Iraq as Fights Rage
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  The Army and Marine Corps are rushing dozens of 70-ton battle tanks and armored personnel carriers to Iraq to help meet the escalating security threat to American troops, military officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Adecco Seeks To Delay Report
description: Adecco, the Swiss employment services giant, said yesterday that it was trying to persuade its lenders to extend a deadline of Monday set for the release of its audited financial statements for 2003. The company delayed reporting the 2003 results in January after disclosing that it had uncovered accounting problems at a unit, Adecco Staffing North America. The company ordered a complete reauditing of group accounts, which it planned to release last week. At the last minute, however, Adecco said that the reaudited results could not be released until they had been reviewed by its independent law firm, Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. It said the process had been delayed by slow processing of e-mail messages. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the internal investigation of fabrications by the former USA Today reporter Jack Kelley referred imprecisely to the departure of Brian Gallagher from the executive editor's position and misstated the timing of his announcement. Mr. Gallagher, the paper's No. 2 editor, said that he would give up the post soon after the appointment of a new top editor and that his future at the paper had yet to be resolved. He did not say he was resigning. Mr. Gallagher made the announcement at a meeting of editors Thursday morning, not at a larger gathering of the newsroom staff later in the day.

title: The Velella Code
description: New Yorkers who have been asked to give financial support to the re-election campaign of a local state legislator may want to ponder the question of what, exactly, the money is needed for when almost all the lawmakers have districts that guarantee re-election to even the most sluggish incumbent. The answer, thanks to the expansive interpretations of state elections law, is that the money can be used to underwrite anything from veterinarian bills for the office cat to ''fact-finding'' vacations. But the case of State Senator Guy Velella gives a whole new dimension to both the improper use of campaign funds and the ability of the members of the Senate's Republican majority to think with one mind.

title: After Bombing in Damascus, Syria Has Little to Say
description: ISTANBUL, April 28  Retreating into characteristic silence on the topic of security threats, Syrian officials disclosed no further information on today about the identities or possible motives of the gunmen who set off a bomb near the center of Damascus, Syria's capital, on Tuesday evening.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronics Concerns Post Profits
description: Demand for flat-panel televisions, digital cameras and DVD recorders raised profits for the Sharp Corporation and Canon Inc. Sharp said its net profit rose 86 percent for the fiscal year ended March 31, to 60.7 billion yen ($558.5 million). Canon earned 84.3 billion yen for the three months ended March 31, up 18 percent from a year earlier, on brisk sales of digital cameras and printers. Pioneer and Sanyo Electric also reported solid profit growth. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Siege Defined On Stones Set in Haste In the Dirt
description: The place where the new dead lie in this city west of Baghdad was once a soccer stadium called the Falluja Sports Club.

title: Sisters of Dead Soldier Decide To Finish Service Outside Iraq
description: At the urging of their military commanders, two sisters of a soldier killed in Baghdad this month have chosen not to return to their Army National Guard units in Iraq, a spokesman for the Guard said in Wisconsin yesterday.

title: Specter Wins Senate Primary in Close Vote
description: Senator Arlen Specter, a four-term Republican known for his centrist stands, turned back a ferocious challenge from his party's right wing on Tuesday, barely defeating Representative Patrick J. Toomey in the Senate primary in Pennsylvania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUDER, ESTEE
description: LAUDER--Estee. The faculty members and staff of The Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (IDC) in Israel and the members of the board of directors and staff of The American Friends of IDC are saddened by the passing of Mrs. Estee Lauder, beloved mother of Mr. Ronald S. Lauder, a member of the Board of the American Friends of IDC and the founder of the Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy at the IDC Herzliya. Mrs. Estee Lauder, a pioneer of her industry and an accomplished businesswoman ahead of her time committed much of her energy and resources to public service and to public causes. She has left a legacy of charitable activism that has continued and perpetuated by her sons. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Ronald S. Lauder and the entire family. Professor Uriel Reichman, President, IDC Sam Zell, Chairman of the Board, AFIDC

title: Other Shoe Drops in Deal For Aventis: Severance
description: This week, executives from the French drug company Sanofi-Synthlabo earned a surprising victory with a takeover of the larger rival Aventis. But in clinching the $65.5 billion deal, they may have also inherited a headache -- the distinction of paying out some of the highest severance packages awarded in Europe in recent years.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN SAYS EARNINGS ROSE 16%
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said first-quarter profit climbed 16 percent, helped by spending on Patriot missiles used in Iraq and financing to develop new jets. Net income rose to $291 million, or 65 cents a share, from $250 million, or 55 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 18 percent, to $8.35 billion from $7.06 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expected Lockheed to earn 53 cents a share on sales of $7.73 billion. Sales at Lockheed's largest business, aeronautics, rose 38 percent, the chief financial officer, Christopher Kubasik, said. Lockheed also raised its 2004 sales forecast, to as much as $34.8 billion from $34.5 billion.

title: Time to Shine For Students And Stars
description: Dance students shared the stage with dance stars on Monday night when Youth America Grand Prix staged its fifth-anniversary gala at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center. The event concluded a five-day competition involving 321 students, ages 9 to 19, who were judged by a panel of dancers and teachers.

title: Bush-Cheney 9/11 Interview Won't Be Formally Recorded
description: The White House said on Tuesday that there would be no recording or formal transcription of the historic joint interview of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney by the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: Nortel Fires 3 Executives Amid Accounting Inquiry
description: Nortel Networks, North America's largest telecommunications equipment maker, fired its chief executive officer, chief financial officer and its controller today, and may halve its 2003 earnings as part of a sweeping review of the company's accounts.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Taliban Attack In Center Of Country
description: Forty Taliban fighters attacked district offices near Kandahar, killing three people. It was the first such attack on a centrally located town, a reminder of the continuing threat the Taliban pose to stability. The district chief, Niaz Mohammad Sarhadi, said there was no doubt the Taliban were responsible for the attack. The attackers left a Chinese-made Kalashnikov of the kind used by the police in Pakistan, said Saadullah Mashuzai, the police chief. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Sony Narrowed Loss in Quarter
description: The Sony Corporation said on Tuesday that it narrowed its net loss in its fourth quarter as profit from its mobile phone operation and a lower tax bill partly offset charges from overhauling its electronics division and declines in its game business.

title: Fund for Hussein Victims
description: American officials announced Tuesday that they would establish a special compensation fund for Iraqis who were imprisoned or executed for political reasons under Saddam Hussein. The fund, to be administered by a commission controlled by Iraqis and financed by a ''substantial'' contribution from the United States, would also look at compensating Iraqis who lost their jobs because they opposed Mr. Hussein, the officials said.

title: A Task of Moderation
description: A thin but resistant line of moderate Republicans is reported to be still holding out for some budget responsibility in the Senate. We can only offer them encouragement, and congratulations for sensing voters' rising concern over the red ink being generated across the decade by President Bush's tax-cut mania. At issue is a resolution of differences between rival budget plans. House Republicans are pressing for an open-ended acceptance of the president's deficit-stoking approach, which fails to raise revenue to the level of the nation's rising expenditures. In the Senate, on the other hand, Democrats and four G.O.P. moderates have passed a proposal that demands the return of pay-as-you-go discipline.

description: FREELANDER--Aviva. 75, born Tel Aviv, died April 27, Worcester, MA. Deeply mourned by I. Robert (Sonny); Rabbi Daniel, Michael; Rabbi Elyse Frishman, Susan; beloved grandchildren, Adam, Jonah, Devra, David, Raphael, Jessie. Funeral Thursday at Temple Emanuel in Worcester.

description: The Yonkers police received several tips yesterday from witnesses who may have seen a group of boys throwing debris off a highway overpass on Saturday, just before a woman was killed when a chunk of asphalt crashed through her windshield.

description: PERRONE--Cindy. To the Gladsteins, may your memories be an everlasting source of comfort. Michael Nierenberg, Chairman Tamar Spilo, Ph.D., President Samuel Waxman, M.D., Scientific Director Ann Jackowitz, Exec. description: Kerry Collins has begun shopping his talents -- Pittsburgh was among the teams that received a call yesterday -- and the likelihood that he will again play for the Giants is less than slim.

title: Sales of Existing Homes Climb
description: Sales of existing homes showed a healthy increase in March amid job and income growth, and consumer confidence rose in April to a three-month high, according to separate reports released yesterday.

title: Images of Coffins Bring War Home to America
description: WASHINGTON -- For several years, American generals have referred to "the Dover test" of a military operation. It consists of trying to estimate how many coffins arriving at Dover Air Force Base the American public will tolerate before turning against a war. This month of April, true to its reputation for cruelty, has seen more than 110 U.S. soldiers killed in Iraq. The test has begun to be applied in earnest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRELINGHUYSEN, GEORGE GRISWOLD
description: FRELINGHUYSEN -- George Griswold died at the age of 92, after a long illness, on Sunday, April 25, 2004 at his home in West Palm Beach, Florida. He was the son of Mr. & Mrs. Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J. and was named for his grandfather, G.G. Frelinghuysen, also of Morristown. His maternal grandparents were Mr. & Mrs. H.O. Havermeyer, of New York, N.Y. At an early age Mr. Frelinghuysen was employed at John Wanamaker's in New York, where he developed solid talent as an interior designer. He later went into business for himself. During a long and active life, he lived for many years in Morristown. Later he moved to Bel Air and Santa Barbara, California and then to Santa Fe, New Mexico. Next he lived for years in Honolulu, Hawaii before his final move to Florida. Mr. Frelinghuysen is survived by a younger brother, Peter, of Morristown, and by six nephews and two nieces.

description: CAMERON--Donald J., M.D. An outstanding physician and educator at Weill Cornell Medical Center, died on April 23, 2004. After obtaining his M.D. from Cornell University Medical College in 1955, he continued to serve at Cornell for many years becoming a Senior Attending Physician with expertise in internal medicine, cardiovascular and renal disease, and geriatrics. He was a superb teacher and enthusiastic supporter of the Department of Medicine. Beloved by patients, medical students and residents, his passing is acknowledged with deepest sadness. Ralph L. Nachman, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Weill Medical College of Cornell University Physician-in-Chief New York-Presbyterian Hospital

title: MCI IS SELLING STAKE IN BRAZILIAN PHONE COMPANY
description: MCI Inc. won court approval last night to sell its controlling stake in the Brazilian phone company Embratel Participaes to Telfonos de Mexico for $400 million, putting an end to a two-month bidding war for Brazil's biggest long-distance carrier. Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York rejected a claim by a consortium of Brazil's top three fixed-line operators, which had sought to block the sale of Embratel to Telmex by arguing that the bidding process was unfair. The deal, which must still be approved by Brazilian regulators, is the latest foray into South America by Carlos Slim Hel, the Mexican billionaire who controls Telmex and its wireless sister company, America Mvil. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: OVERTURNED CONVICTION IN ACTOR'S KILLING A federal judge overturned the conviction of one of three men found guilty of killing Haing S. Ngor, the Oscar-winning actor in "The Killing Fields." The man, Tak Sun Tan, left, was convicted of first-degree murder and robbery in the 1996 killing of Mr. Ngor. In court papers filed Monday, the judge, Margaret M. Morrow of Federal District Court, approved the recommendation of a federal magistrate judge, who found that the prosecutor in Mr. Tan's trial misrepresented evidence and played on jurors' emotions by emphasizing the hardships Mr. Ngor had faced living under the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.    (AP)

description: SEASONAL menus usually show up only in white-tablecloth restaurants. But in the Pacific Northwest, customers can dine on a changing selection of local ingredients at a fast-food chain called Burgerville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLAUS, ROBERT
description: CLAUS--Robert, 90, on April 24, 2004, in Madison, WI of lymphoma. A retired archivist and longtime resident of Great Neck, NY, he is survived by his wife Jean Christie and their son and grandson. A memorial meeting will be held at 2PM on Saturday, May 22nd, at the Friends (Quaker) Meeting House, 1704 Roberts Court, Madison.

description: GOLDSMITH--Peter D., died on April 23, 2004 in Oberlin, OH at age 51. Dean of Students at Oberlin College; loving father of Joanna and Ben; adoring husband of Julie Kalish; and beloved son and brother of George, Sonia, Robert and Laurie Goldsmith and Lynn Goldberg. He will be remembered for his kindness, his intellect, his moral convictions and his profound humanism. He will be dearly missed. Interment private; memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Peter Goldsmith Memorial Fund at Oberlin College, Office of Development, 50 W. Lorain Street, Oberlin, Ohio 44074.

title: Strong Criminal Penalties Sought For Violations That Kill Workers
description: For at least 15 years, Democrats in Congress have tried in vain to increase criminal penalties against employers who commit safety violations that result in the deaths of workers. These willful violations leave about 100 workers dead each year, yet prosecutions are almost unheard of and only a handful of executives have ever been sentenced to more than a few months in jail.

title: Blair Promises Middle Road On European Immigration
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said Tuesday that Britain had reached a ''crunch point'' in its dealing with outsiders and promised a ''top to bottom'' review of immigration policies, just four days before the expansion of the European Union removes obstacles to Continental migration.

description: INSIDE a packed hotel conference room in Sydney, Australia, with the 2000 Summer Games under way, Marion Jones held the thick hand of her husband, C. J. Hunter, a gruff Bluto in a black T-shirt, before he puddled up in tears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSTON, GLENN W.
description: JOHNSTON--Glenn W. Funeral services for Glenn W. Johnston, retired president of Sterling Drug Co. will be held at 3 P.M. Friday April 30, at the First United Methodist Church of Pocahontas, Ark. Mr. Johnston died Tuesday, April 27, at the age of 84 in Vero Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He lived for many years in Greenwich Conn., and worked in New York City. He retired in 1983, and in recent years divided his time between homes in Ivoryton, Conn., and Vero Beach. Mr. Johnston grew up in Pocahontas. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance, and served in the Eighth Air Force in England during World War II. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Gleason Johnston; two sons, Scott, of Bentonville, Ark., and James, of Greenwich, Conn; one daughter, Patricia Johnston Mullen of Andover, Mass; a stepson, John Mockeridge of Stuart, Fla; a stepdaughter, Nancy Miner of Bridgeport, Conn; a sister, Mary Ann Johnston Harwell of Port Orange, FL; and four grandsons. His first wife, mother of his three children, was Aldean Spikes Johnston, also a native of Pocahontas, who died in 1971.

title: Chile, the Rich Kid on the Block (It Starts to Feel Lonely)
description: Achieving a free trade agreement with the United States was supposed to be the magic moment that certified Chile's entry into the elite club of stable, democratic and prosperous nations. Instead, the new accord, signed in January, has reignited a sometimes anguished debate here about what it means to be Latin American and whether Chile has somehow lost those essential characteristics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERNER, LAWRENCE A.

Chapel Service Thursday, April 29, 3:30 P.M. at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 North Federal Hwy, Boca Raton, FL. title: Lieber Ready for Saturday Start
description: Jon Lieber has been in the major leagues for a decade, but yesterday he did something he had never done: he walked into Yankee Stadium. After so many false steps on his way there, Lieber kept his eyes on the painted stripe on the floor guiding guests to the clubhouse.

description: The special United Nations envoy for Iraq, offering a speeded-up timetable for the selection of a caretaker government in Baghdad, said Tuesday that the new government should be chosen a full month before sovereignty is transferred on June 30 to give it time to define its authority.

description: The ABC News program ''Nightline'' will broadcast on Friday night the names and faces of every member of the armed forces killed in action in Iraq.

But now the protesters are talking about infiltrating the convention to undermine the event itself.

title: Training Called Inadequate For Emergency Technicians
description: More than two years after 9/11 and nine years after a Japanese cult released a toxic gas on the Tokyo subway system, the majority of New York City's emergency medical technicians are not properly trained to enter a contaminated zone and treat victims, officials said Tuesday.

title: Proposal Bars Banks From Using Medical Data to Decide Loans
description: New federal rules being proposed this week would expand the individual right to medical privacy by stipulating that banks cannot consider information about a person's medical condition when deciding whether to lend money.

title: Taiwan Casts U.S. as China Intermediary
description: President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan is pressing the Bush administration to approve his plans to change the island's Constitution, casting the United States as an intermediary in the most delicate issue dividing China and Taiwan, Taiwanese officials said Tuesday.

description: The European Union and Russia agreed Tuesday to extend their economic and political relationship to the union's 10 new members, most of them former Soviet republics or satellites.

title: Libyan Leader, in Europe, Makes His Case for Peace
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi paraded into the heart of Europe on Tuesday to announce Libya's official return from the diplomatic outback of ''liberation struggles'' to the center stage of international cooperation.

title: Specter Is Survivor In G.O.P. Primary
description: Senator Arlen Specter, a four-term Republican known for his centrist stands, turned back a challenge in a Senate primary from his party's right wing, barely defeating Representative Patrick J. Toomey.

title: U.S. Forces Keep Pressure on Rebels in Falluja and Najaf
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 28  The American military made an aggressive push in its two-front war in Iraq today, continuing an aerial bombardment of guerilla positions in the volatile city of Falluja while tightening its grip on roads surrounding the southern holy city of Najaf, where a rebel Shiite cleric has sought refuge.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NORTH KOREA: ASSESSING TRAIN DISASTER North Korea rejected medical assistance from South Korea to aid victims of the explosion last week at the Ryongchon train station, the Seoul government said. But the North is accepting cement and diesel fuel from the South. The official North Korean news agency estimated property damage at $356 million and said the explosion had destroyed at least 8,100 homes and more than 30 public buildings. The death toll stands at 161; more than 1,300 people were injured. (AP)

title: Justices Hear Challenges to Post-9/11 Presidential Powers
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 — The lawyers for two American citizens held in a Navy brig in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks told the Supreme Court today that the treatment of their clients was contrary to America's law and heritage.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Saturday about the outbreak of a mysterious rash at a Brooklyn school that sent 19 fifth graders to emergency rooms misidentified the neighborhood. It was Bensonhurst, not Midwood.

title: JEANS MAKER TO PAY $396 MILLION FOR CLOTHING COMPANY
description: The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee and Wrangler jeans, agreed to acquire Vans Inc. for $396 million to add sneakers and apparel that appeal to teenagers. VF, based in Greensboro, N.C., will pay $20.55 for each share of Vans, a 30 percent premium to its closing price Monday. VF, which also reported higher first-quarter results yesterday, said the Vans purchase would not add to 2004 earnings. VF is buying outdoor clothing and sportswear companies after sales of jeans dropped last year. Vans, based in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., had sales of $330 million in the year ended in May 2003.

Flowers are welcome or memorial contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

description: The Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, reorganized its executive ranks yesterday as part of plans to open a Chicago office of a Toronto agency, Downtown Partners DDB.

description: Last week, the Genzyme Corporation officially opened its $140 million, 300,000-square-foot headquarters here. Last week, in Boston, construction started on a $53 million, 160,000-square-foot science laboratory, the Biosquare Research Building D.

title: Coconut Shrimp? Ambition Can Wait
description: WHEN Atoosa Rubenstein, the editor in chief of Seventeen magazine, gets to choose the location for a lunch meeting, she simply descends from her 13th-floor office on Broadway and does a quick diagonal across Times Square to her favorite restaurant. One of New York's youngest and most sought-after editors, Ms. Rubenstein gets a big welcome from the matre d'htel and then steps into a huge chrome and glass elevator to the second-floor dining area, where she is framed by a tasteful mobile of fish seeming to swim in the air. Just last week, she settled into a big cushy booth there a little after noon.

title: Boy, 4, Dies After Falling Four Stories From Roof of Apartment Building
description: A 4-year-old boy died last night after he fell from the roof of a four-story apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: An Inquiry Into Insurance Payments and Conflicts
description: The latest financial investigation undertaken by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has some familiar themes: conflicts of interest, inadequate disclosure and companies that are said to be taking advantage of their customers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Relief For Alstom
description: The French power and engineering company Alstom said that its lenders suspended the company's obligations to meet some of its debt requirements for five months. The company said that the conditions of its loans were unchanged and that the postponement would imply no penalty. Under its restructuring agreement, Alstom signed a 1.56 billion euro ($1.85 billion) five-year loan last year, with the obligation to meet certain targets after one year. The financial situation of the company will be re-examined with its lenders before Sept. 30, Alstom said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

description: STONE -- Allen. Dearest Brother, Happy Birthday. Loved and remembered forever. Cynthi

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Tax Incentives
description: The finance minister, Somkid Jatusripitak, said that the cabinet approved tax incentives that it hoped would steady Thailand's stock market by attracting longer-term investments. Among the measures was an extension on tax privileges for companies that list shares on the Thai stock exchange, as well as tax breaks for investments in mutual and pension funds. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: ImClone Reports First Profit In 8 Years
description: ImClone Systems, which began selling its cancer drug Erbitux in the United States this year, had net income of $62.7 million, its first quarterly profit in more than eight years, the company said yesterday. Revenue jumped more than fivefold to $109.6 million, helped by a payment from Bristol-Myers Squibb tied to federal approval of Erbitux. Shares fell $3.15, or 4.3 percent, to $69.94.

title: In This Fish Story, the Money Keeps Getting Bigger
description: Like many athletes, Michael Iaconelli likes to celebrate. But when he pumps his fist and points at the television cameras, he is usually brandishing a hefty large-mouth bass and standing on the deck of his customized boat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Profit Rises
description: The oil company BP reported $4.7 billion in profit for the first quarter, a 17 percent increase from the period a year earlier. The results included asset sales and credits of $1.18 billion. The company said it would split off more than half of its underperforming chemicals business in 2005, and might sell it in an initial public offering. Lord Browne, the chief executive, said that the book value of the business was about $7 billion. The company's revenue from petrochemicals was $16.1 billion in 2003, 7 percent of its total. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Strong Yen and Drop in U.S. Sales Hurt Profit at Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company said Tuesday that profit fell more than a third in the latest quarter, hurt by unfavorable currency swings and a decline in sales in the crucial North American market.

title: The Aromas Deserve a Place on the Menu
description: LIKE a beautiful morning, a restaurant that smells good can make just about anybody happy. The scent of warm yeasty bread, of freshly cooked basmati rice, of pungent nuoc mam and mint in a Vietnamese place or of horseradish and lemon at an oyster bar -- for starters -- sharpens the appetite and opens the mind to awaiting pleasures. Yet few restaurants understand that simple equation. Instead, you are welcomed by the smell of cleanser, the receptionist's perfume or old coffee. Astounding.

title: I.B.M. Plans to Build Servers That Act Like Mainframes
description: I.B.M. plans today to announce new server computers that behave more like mainframes and are priced as low as $1,500. The servers will be able to run as many as 10 operating systems on a single machine. One processor can divvy up the workload -- packing the capability of several machines into one -- by building several virtual machines that run on the underlying hardware. It is a technology that has existed for decades in the mainframe market long ruled by I.B.M.

title: Perky Leaves, Perfect for Wilting
description: Now, when their leaves are tender, is the best time to use dandelion greens. At the Union Square Greenmarket there are several kinds this season, both wild and cultivated. Windfall Farms, at the market on Wednesdays and Saturdays, has Italian cultivated red-ribbed and plain, $3 to $8 a quarter-pound depending on the size of the leaves. On Saturdays Paffenroth Gardens has wild leaves, and will soon have cultivated, $1 a bunch. John Gorzynski has wild dandelion for $1.50 a bunch, also on Saturdays. Cultivated smooth-leaf dandelion is sold on Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays by Hydrogarden Farm, $4 for four ounces.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 5 More Warrants In March Attack
description: International arrest warrants have been issued for five more suspects in the March 11 rail bombings. One of the five was captured in suburban Madrid. The warrants said the five men provided logistic and financial support to the leaders of the militant cell responsible for the attacks, which killed 191 people. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Frank Gehry: From Bilbao To Bottles
description: ''Why would a critter like me do a thing like this?'' Frank Gehry asked rhetorically about the vodka bottle he has designed. The short answer is that the architect's son Alejandro, an illustrator, asked him to, at the request of a friend who was working with the brand, Wyborowa (pronounced vee-BROH-vah), from Poland.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Safety Chief Quits
description: The top city education official in charge of school safety has resigned, officials said yesterday. The official, Benjamin B. Tucker, left, was chief executive of the Office of School Safety and Planning, created in September 2002 by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who intended it to tamp down on disruptive students. Like Joel I. Klein, the schools chancellor, Mr. Tucker is a former Justice Department official. No reason has been given for Mr. Tucker's resignation, but the mayor's sweeping reorganization of the school system has caused long delays in suspending or removing such students. And over the last few months, Mr. Tucker has been at the center of an intense effort by the Bloomberg administration to flood the city's most dangerous schools with police officers and new security measures. Officials said those measures had been effective in reducing violence at the so-called ''impact schools.'' Mr. Tucker's responsibilities will be taken over by Rose Albanese-DePinto, a veteran educator who has been supervising the impact schools. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOBERMAN, ROBERT J., M.D.
description: SOBERMAN--Robert J., M.D., The faculty and staff of the New York University School of Medicine express their deep sadness over the death of our friend and colleague, Robert J. Soberman, M.D., Professor of Medicine and Associate Dean for Post-Graduate Programs at the NYU Post - Graduate Medical School. Dr. Soberman was a respected faculty member whose career at NYU spanned more than 50 years. A graduate of NYU School of Medicine, he completed his internship and residency at Bellevue Hospital. After joining the faculty in 1951, he became a prominent figure in the field of nephrology, especially in kidney and pancreas transplantation, and helped develop national regulations for fair organ procurement and distribution. Through his enduring commitment to medical education, Dr. Soberman played an important role in strengthening programs for physicians to gain new skills throughout their careers. We will always remember Dr. Soberman for his skills as a physician, his concern for his patients, and his tireless dedication to NYU School of Medicine. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Beatrice, his children, Roy, Diane, and Nina, and the entire Soberman family on this sad occasion. Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine Richard I. Levin, M.D. Vice Dean for Education, Faculty & Academic Affairs NYU School of Medicine

title: A Tale of Ireland Forever, or at Least 1,100 Years
description: Edward Rutherfurd's new novel, ''The Princes of Ireland: the Dublin Saga,'' is 776 pages long, with hundreds of characters; it spans 1,100 years of Irish history, complete with maps and a family tree. Readers who have reveled in Mr. Rutherfurd's previous historical novels have again been undeterred by the weight or the detail. With almost 200,000 copies in print, the book is rising on best-seller lists throughout the United States, and it is No. 4 in Dublin.

title: White House Memo; Second Time Around, Bush Is Forgoing a Visionary Agenda
description: George W. Bush ran for president four years ago on a platform of meaty domestic policy ideas, including tax cuts of historic proportions, the creation of Social Security investment accounts and a demand that school systems document their performance through increased testing of children.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Vermont Requires Labels On Biotech Seeds
description: Vermont is requiring that genetically modified seeds be labeled, becoming the first state to do so. Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican, signed the measure into law on Monday. ''It showed that state legislatures can stand up to the biotech industry,'' said Ben Davis, environmental advocate for the Vermont Public Interest Research Group. Lisa Dry of the Biotechnology Industry Organization said farmers already knew when they were buying genetically engineered seeds because they had to sign agreements covering their use of the seeds. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWYER, JANE ESTELLE BROADUS (HUDSON)
description: DWYER--Jane Estelle Broadus (Hudson). Dancer, actress, teacher, garden grower, wife, lover, mother, grandmother, and creative force extraordinaire. Died of cancer in Pittsfield, MA on Monday morning, April 26, 2004, two days short of her sixtyfifth birthday. Her loss is mourned and her life celebrated by her husband, Jim, of Stephentown, NY; her daughters, Peri and Karli; their husbands, Michael Luse, and Paul-Hector Gannon; her grandchildren, Kyrie, Amanda, Maya, Benjamin, and Orion; her brother, John Broadus, and his family, of Daphne, AL; and innumerable others whose lives she touched and enriched. ''Out, out, brief candle.''

title: National Briefing | West: California: Accusation Of Faking Racist Attack
description: A psychology professor is to be arraigned on May 19 on charges that she lied to the police and committed insurance fraud in claiming that someone had vandalized her car with anti-Semitic and racist slurs. Witnesses told the police they had seen the professor, Kerri Dunn, of Claremont McKenna College, painting and damaging the car. Ms. Dunn, 39, was attending a campus seminar on racism on March 9, the day she said the vandalism occurred. Ms. Dunn, who is on paid leave from the college, says she is innocent. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Ex-Congressman Charged In Fatal Accident
description: Wes Watkins, a former United States representative, was charged in a state court with two counts of negligent homicide involving a traffic accident on April 19 in Stillwater that killed two adults and injured two children. A highway patrolman's report cited inattentive driving by Mr. Watkins in the deaths of Brian Cullen, 32, and his wife, Ardith, 34. Mr. Watkins's vehicle struck the rear of the Cullens' car. The charges against Mr. Watkins, a Republican, are misdemeanors and carry a potential sentence of a year in jail, but a state prosecutor said he expected to negotiate a lesser sentence. Mr. Watkins, 65, served 18 years in Congress, ending in 2001. Steve Barnes (NYT)

He wears $15 reading glasses, off the rack at CVS. Before bedtime, he starts but rarely finishes movies like ''Seabiscuit'' and ''The Blues Brothers'' in his hotel suite. title: Bring Back the Baathists

But that's precisely the point -- the history of the last 50 years shows that countries trying to make transitions to democracy must inevitably bring back at least some members of the ousted regime.

title: DISNEY BOARD REITERATES SUPPORT FOR EISNER

The statement came at the end of a two-day retreat by the board in which it reviewed the operating divisions and the performance of the top 8 to 12 executives. The board also outlined the duties of George J. Mitchell, who succeeded Mr. Eisner as chairman after shareholders withheld 45 percent of their votes from him during the board election at the annual meeting in March. The duties include presiding over executive sessions where management is not present; coordinating feedback to the chief executive; establishing the board agenda with the chief executive; delivering any necessary information to board members; and reviewing succession plans for the chief executive as well as top executives. Mr. Eisner's authority in company operation will not change. Laura M. Holson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HESS, JOHN D.
description: HESS--John D., a pioneering writer for television and a 50 year resident of Bucks County, PA., died peacefully at his home on Thursday, April 15, 2004, two days short of his 86th birthday. Mr. Hess was the husband of Mary Ann Van Hess and the late Jane Vosper Hess who died in 1996. Mr. Hess was born in Chicago. His father Carl died when John was three years old. He was raised by his mother, Ollie, and stepfather, Dr. J.P. Greenhill. He graduated from the University of Chicago Lab School in 1935, and-with distinction-from Dartmouth in 1939, where he pursued his lifelong ambition to be a writer. After a post-graduate year at Yale Drama School, he began his professional career as a staff writer for WGN radio in Chicago. His work was interrupted when he enlisted in the army in July 1942. Mr. Hess trained at the army's Advanced Tank Officers School, and joined his unit, the 743rd Armored Battalion, in Europe as a second lieutenant in September 1944. He served as the 743rd's transportation officer, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge and other major engagements in Belgium, Holland and Germany. After the defeat of Germany, he assisted victims of concentration camps and helped relocate refugees throughout Europe. Prior to his repatriation to the U.S., in September 1945, he authored Move Out, Verify The Combat Story of the 743rd Tank Battalion, a history of tank combat in WWII. He was honorably discharged as a captain in January 1946. After the war, he returned to Chicago, resuming his position at WGN as a contributing writer for the station's nationally broadcast radio programs. He also authored short stories for magazines such as Esquire, The Saturday Evening Post and Colliers. In 1950, Mr. Hess originated and wrote a live-broadcast television soap opera called ''Love of Life'', which ran for thirty years. He also wrote other leading daytime soaps, including ''Secret Storm'' and ''General Hospital''. He supplemented this with concurrent work in the theatre, his first love. In 1953, his controversial play, ''The Gray Eyed People'' was produced on Broadway, starring Walter Matthau, with direction by Morton Da Costa. He also was deeply involved with Mike Ellis' Bucks County Playhouse in the 1950's and 1960's where his plays ''The Facts of Life'', ''The Better Mousetrap,'' and ''A Perfect Frenzy'' premiered. In 1959, his original feature-length television mystery ''The Wicked Scheme of Jebal Deeks'' was broadcast by Ford Startime to critical acclaim. Starring Alec Guiness in his American television debut, it was directed by Franklin Schaffner. In 1961, he wrote and produced a feature movie thriller '' Matter of Morals'' starring Patrick O'Neal and Maj-Britt Nillson. Directed by Hollywood veteran John Cromwell, the film was released by Twentieth Century Fox. Over the next two and a half decades, Mr. Hess wrote for a virtual who's who of major nighttime television series. His work included episodes of comedies, ''MASH'', ''Alice'' and ''One Day At A Time'', and dramas, ''Streets of San Francisco'', ''The Rockford Files'', and ''Ben Casey''. Mr. Hess' principal home was New Hope, PA, where he was active in community affairs. Following the death of his first wife, he married Mary Ann Van. They lived together in Bucks County from 1997 to his death. In addition to his wife, Mr. Hess is survived by sons Anthony G. Hess of New Hope and Oliver G. Hess of Ojai, CA, his brother Carl B. Hess of New York, and grandsons John T. and Carl T. Hess of Ojai. Services private. Memorial donations in Mr. Hess's name may be made to the John D. Hess 1939 Fund at Dartmouth College (c/o Elizabeth Spencer, Hanover, NH 03755-3525), to The Nature Conservancy or to charities of one's choice.

title: After 40 Years, A Waiter Is the Boss
description: BACK in the days when a waiter was a waiter, not an actor who serves up his audition woes with the entre, Wolfgang Zwiener came to New York from Bremen, Germany, fully prepared: he had completed a three-year apprenticeship for the job. After a stint at Lchow's on East 14th Street in the early 1960's, he went to work at Peter Luger Steak House in Brooklyn, where he stayed for 40 years, becoming the headwaiter in 1968. He married and put his two sons through college (Steven at the University of Chicago and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, where he received an M.B.A., and Peter at Columbia University, then the University of Chicago for his M.B.A). With Mr. Zwiener approaching retirement -- he'll be 65 in June -- he considered moving to Marco Island, Fla., where he has a vacation home.
