title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HESS, JOHN D.
description: HESS--John D., a pioneering writer for television and a 50 year resident of Bucks County, PA., died peacefully at his home on Thursday, April 15, 2004, two days short of his 86th birthday. Mr. Hess was the husband of Mary Ann Van Hess and the late Jane Vosper Hess who died in 1996. Mr. Hess was born in Chicago. His father Carl died when John was three years old. He was raised by his mother, Ollie, and stepfather, Dr. J.P. Greenhill. He graduated from the University of Chicago Lab School in 1935, and-with distinction-from Dartmouth in 1939, where he pursued his lifelong ambition to be a writer. After a post-graduate year at Yale Drama School, he began his professional career as a staff writer for WGN radio in Chicago. His work was interrupted when he enlisted in the army in July 1942. Mr. Hess trained at the army's Advanced Tank Officers School, and joined his unit, the 743rd Armored Battalion, in Europe as a second lieutenant in September 1944. He served as the 743rd's transportation officer, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge and other major engagements in Belgium, Holland and Germany. After the defeat of Germany, he assisted victims of concentration camps and helped relocate refugees throughout Europe. Prior to his repatriation to the U.S., in September 1945, he authored Move Out, Verify The Combat Story of the 743rd Tank Battalion, a history of tank combat in WWII. He was honorably discharged as a captain in January 1946. After the war, he returned to Chicago, resuming his position at WGN as a contributing writer for the station's nationally broadcast radio programs. He also authored short stories for magazines such as Esquire, The Saturday Evening Post and Colliers. In 1950, Mr. Hess originated and wrote a live-broadcast television soap opera called ''Love of Life'', which ran for thirty years. He also wrote other leading daytime soaps, including ''Secret Storm'' and ''General Hospital''. He supplemented this with concurrent work in the theatre, his first love. In 1953, his controversial play, ''The Gray Eyed People'' was produced on Broadway, starring Walter Matthau, with direction by Morton Da Costa. He also was deeply involved with Mike Ellis' Bucks County Playhouse in the 1950's and 1960's where his plays ''The Facts of Life'', ''The Better Mousetrap,'' and ''A Perfect Frenzy'' premiered. In 1959, his original feature-length television mystery ''The Wicked Scheme of Jebal Deeks'' was broadcast by Ford Startime to critical acclaim. Starring Alec Guiness in his American television debut, it was directed by Franklin Schaffner. In 1961, he wrote and produced a feature movie thriller '' Matter of Morals'' starring Patrick O'Neal and Maj-Britt Nillson. Directed by Hollywood veteran John Cromwell, the film was released by Twentieth Century Fox. Over the next two and a half decades, Mr. Hess wrote for a virtual who's who of major nighttime television series. His work included episodes of comedies, ''MASH'', ''Alice'' and ''One Day At A Time'', and dramas, ''Streets of San Francisco'', ''The Rockford Files'', and ''Ben Casey''. Mr. Hess' principal home was New Hope, PA, where he was active in community affairs. Following the death of his first wife, he married Mary Ann Van. They lived together in Bucks County from 1997 to his death. In addition to his wife, Mr. Hess is survived by sons Anthony G. Hess of New Hope and Oliver G. Hess of Ojai, CA, his brother Carl B. Hess of New York, and grandsons John T. and Carl T. Hess of Ojai. Services private. Memorial donations in Mr. Hess's name may be made to the John D. Hess 1939 Fund at Dartmouth College (c/o Elizabeth Spencer, Hanover, NH 03755-3525), to The Nature Conservancy or to charities of one's choice.

Bloomberg has declared tomorrow the second annual Poem in Your Pocket Day, an initiative intended to promote literacy and poetry at schools, libraries and cultural organizations. title: ASSOCIATED BANC-CORP IS BUYING RIVAL WISCONSIN BANK
description: Associated Banc-Corp, one of Wisconsin's biggest banks, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the First Federal Capital Corporation for $613 million. The move will allow Associated, based in Green Bay, to expand in Wisconsin, Illinois and Minnesota. Associated will pay 0.635 share or an equivalent amount of cash for each share of First Federal, based in LaCrosse, Wis. The deal values First Federal's shares at $26.79 each, 27 percent higher than their closing price Tuesday. Associated will gain 91 branches and $3.7 billion in assets. The combined bank will have about $19 billion of assets.

Investors will receive $7.10 for each MedSource share they hold at the deal's close, which is expected in June or July, MedSource's chief financial officer, William J. Kullback, said. With the purchase, UTI, a closely held company based in Collegeville, Pa., will gain products like components for pacemakers, UTI's chief executive, Ron Sparks, said. UTI, which is assuming MedSource debt, also makes medical supplies. Stock in MedSource rose 95 cents, or 16 percent, to $6.91 a share.

Not only does the U.S. economy appear to be headed for at least a burst of recovery around election time, but so does the world's second-largest economy, Japan, which should also help buoy the U.S. recovery. It's more evidence, to me, that Mr. Kerry may have to run in the most difficult of all environments, and exactly the opposite of the one Democrats had hoped for: an environment where the U.S. economy is rebounding, and Iraq is reeling.

Some may transfer, some may leave for the pros, but if the athletes are in good academic standing, the programs won't be penalized.

description: NEW YORK: An agreement has been reached between the major aviation units of the United States to carry out the peaceful conquests of the commercial airway systems of the western hemisphere, exclusive of Canada, in one united movement. Operation of the agreement, which is effective immediately, will lead to abandonment of plans for air lines in Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America by the United Aircraft and Transport group and the consolidation of these projected efforts under the aegis of the Aviation Corporation of the Americas, holding company of Pan-American Airways, which operates extensive international lines south of the American border as far as the Canal Zone and plans operations in South America.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Robbed and Fatally Stabbed
description: A Bronx man died yesterday from stab wounds he received in a struggle with a man who demanded his jewelry, the police said. The victim, Rafael Lara, 43, of Fordham, was walking at 188th Street and Elm Place at 4:35 a.m. when he was approached by a man in his 20's who demanded Mr. Lara's neck chain, investigators said. In the ensuing struggle, Mr. Lara was stabbed in the stomach and left arm, and the assailant fled with the chain. Mr. Lara was pronounced dead at St. Barnabas Hospital shortly after 9 a.m.. The police had made no arrests as of last night. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: RealNetworks Posts Wider First-Quarter Loss
description: RealNetworks, which sells Internet media software and subscriptions, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss widened to $10.4 million because of legal costs and subscription costs. In a separate development, the company president, Lawrence Jacobson, quit after three years. The company has no plans to replace Mr. Jacobson at this time, the chief executive, Rob Glaser, said. The net loss equaled 6 cents a share, increasing from $2.84 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier, the Seattle-based company said in a statement. Analysts had estimated that the loss would be 4 cents a share. Sales rose 29 percent, to $60.4 million, exceeding the $57.1 million estimate of 10 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. The loss reflects costs of $2.32 million for an antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft and expenses to remove golf programming from RealNetworks' subscription service. The company said sales this quarter would be $63 million to $65 million, above analyst estimates of $59.3 million. The company forecast a loss of 3 cents or 4 cents a share, including 1 cent or 2 cents a share for legal costs. The shares fell 51 cents, to $6.09. The stock rose to $6.15 in after-hours trading.

They are: Fort Edward, Washington County; Schaghticoke in Rensselaer County; and Bethlehem in Albany County. The agency is expected to choose one site and announce it in the fall. In the proposed cleanup, expected to begin in 2006, about 2.65 million cubic yards of river-bottom mud, contaminated with PCB's, will be removed and taken by barge to the processing site. title: In Iraq, Flag Design, Too, Comes Under Fire
description: WHEN the government of Qatar, the tiny, oil-rich emirate, asked Tariq Atrissi last year to design a logo for it, the mandate was clear: to communicate to investors and tourists the country's ornate past and modern aspirations. ''How much can you represent a country by a logo and some colors?'' Mr. Atrissi, a graphic artist of Lebanese origin, recalled thinking. The symbol he designed combines blue for hospitality; gold for sand, sun and luxury; and burgundy, Qatar's national color.

Shares of Compuware, which is based in Detroit, fell 30 cents, or 3.6 percent, to $7.99.

title: Democracy Takes a Hit
description: ''It is unfortunate,'' Justice Anthony Kennedy lamented yesterday, ''that our legislators have reached the point of declaring that, when it comes to apportionment, 'We are in the business of rigging elections.' '' Despite that trenchant analysis of the state of our democracy, Justice Kennedy joined four of his colleagues in rejecting a challenge to Pennsylvania's thoroughly biased Congressional redistricting plan. Yesterday's 5-to-4 ruling was an enormous missed opportunity, one we can only hope the court revisits another day. Until it does, the public must challenge the growing trend of treating reapportionment as an opportunity to rig elections.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: JDS Uniphase Loss Narrows To $7.3 Million
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, the maker of parts for fiber optic networks, said yesterday that its third-quarter net loss narrowed to $7.3 million on cost cuts. The net loss was 1 cent a share, compared with $136.8 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier, said the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif. Sales for the period that ended March 31 fell 2.6 percent, to $161.4 million. JDS Uniphase has closed dozens of operations in the last three years and cut its work force more than 80 percent, to 5,300, as demand for optical components plummeted. Operating expenses fell 44 percent from a year earlier, to $77.3 million, the company said. Revenue in the fourth quarter will rise to as much as $169.5 million with a loss, excluding certain items, of 1 cent a share, the company said. On that basis, the company was expected to break even on a per-share basis, according to the average estimate of 18 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Shares of JDS Uniphase fell 17 cents, to $3.86.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Wireless Earnings Up
description: Amrica Mvil, the largest wireless telecommunications company in Latin America, reported that revenue and profit rose in the first quarter, helped by growth in Mexico and South America. Sales rose 55.8 percent over the first quarter of last year, to $2.5 billion. Profit increased 35.5 percent, to $376 million. The company added 2.9 million subscribers in the quarter to reach a total of 48.3 million. The quarterly figures included operations that the company acquired in Brazil last year. In Mexico, the company's subsidiary, Telcel, signed up 1.13 million subscribers. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

description: Two centuries ago a person who migrated to another continent was likely to be out of touch permanently with the friends of his youth. A century ago such a person could rely on slow mail or perhaps expensive telephones and telegrams. Today there is e-mail and videoconferencing, and for bridge players there is also the chance to play electronically.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Study: 3 Million At Risk From Pollution
description: Nearly three million people living in Manhattan and the Bronx breathe air contaminated with unhealthy levels of soot that can aggravate asthma and cause strokes and heart attacks, according to the annual air-quality report of the American Lung Association. The tiny soot particles, from diesel exhaust and power-plant emissions, can become lodged in the lungs, causing respiratory problems, especially when combined with high levels of ozone in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANE, BOB
description: KANE--Bob. Of Great Neck died on April 27, 2004 at age 96. Born in NYC on May 21, 1907. Beloved ''Daddy'' of Michael Kane and Riki Kane Larimer, known to him as ''Baby.'' Beloved son-in-law of Bob Larimer, known to him as ''Robby.'' Married to the woman he adored, Ginger Weiner Kane, for 57 years until her death in 1992. Co-owner, with his brother Bill, of Metropolitan Plumbing Supply for more than 60 years. Bob was an avid storyteller, dedicated gourmand, aspiring comedian, ardent golfer, patient fisherman, parlor magician, crafty card player, champion kibitzer and above all, super salesman. He loved sunshine, jokes, steaks, cigars, lobsters, baseball, plump oysters, old songs, animals and kids. He lived all of his 35,406 days to the hilt.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Rise In Deaths On The Road
description: More people were killed in motor vehicle accidents last year than in any other year since 1990, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said. Deaths in 2003 rose to 43,200, up 405 from 2002. The agency's administrator, Dr. Jeffrey Runge, said the number could reach 50,000 by 2008. The best hope for reducing the number is stronger state seat-belt laws, he said. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SUPPORT FOR STEM-CELL RESEARCH A letter signed by 206 members of the House asks President Bush to expand his August 2001 executive order that limits federal money for embryonic stem-cell research, a controversial subject because some people believe that any experiments on human embryos are unethical. Mr. Bush's policy restricted the use of federal money to batches of embryonic stem cells, called cell lines, that existed at the time of his announcement. While there were 78 stem-cell lines in August 2001, supporters of more research said the National Institutes of Health now estimated there were only 15 to 19 cell lines available.    (Reuters)

title: Excerpts From Arguments Before Supreme Court on Detention of U.S. Citizens
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court arguments yesterday about the Bush administration's detention of two United States citizens, Yaser Esam Hamdi and Jose Padilla, whom it has classified as enemy combatants. Paul D. Clement, a deputy solicitor general, argued for the government in both cases. Mr. Hamdi was represented by Frank W. Dunham Jr. and Mr. Padilla by Jennifer Martinez. The transcript was provided by the Alderson Reporting Company.

title: More Angry Than Ever at the U.S., the Iraqis Crave Security
description: The tension of these last hard weeks had eased enough that it did not seem completely insane to drink a big midday beer and eat potato chips on one of Baghdad's bridges across the Tigris River. American helicopters chopped across a panorama of reeds, minarets, water and sky. There was faint gunfire, but nothing for the beer drinkers, Uday Saleh, 28, and Muhammad Hussein, 30, to worry about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMENFELD, ADRIAN
description: BLUMENFELD -- Adrian, passed away Monday, April 26, two days short of his 88th birthday. He was a man of brilliant intellect, an avid reader, and a great devotee of classical music and opera. A true Renaissance man, he had a passionate interest in cooking, sailing, jokes and story telling, woodworking, origami, camping, macrame and life itself. We all loved him dearly, admired him inordinately and will miss him grievously; his wife Beatrice, two daughters Joan Blumenfeld and Susan Lisagor and four grandchildren, Jessica and Sara Lisagor, and Robert and Max Krone.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Security Funds From M.T.A.
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board awarded about $100 million to four companies yesterday for greater security against possible terrorist attacks. Officials declined to identify the companies' projects, citing security concerns. A staff summary, however, listed general possibilities, including perimeter security, surveillance systems, command and communications centers and physical-asset hardening. The money comes from $591 million in state and federal funds, including $143 million from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Also yesterday, the board approved the issuing of a request for proposals for the Second Avenue subway. The first phase is expected to be completed in 2011 and cost $3.8 billion. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Madrid Suspect Once Arrested In Turkey
description: Nearly four years before the Madrid rail bombings on March 11, one suspect in the attacks was arrested in Turkey, but the police released him, according to an indictment by Judge Baltasar Garzn. The suspect, Said Berraj, traveled from Madrid to Istanbul on Sept. 25, 2000, with Amer el-Azizi, whom the indictment calls a leader of a Spanish Qaeda cell, and Salaheddin Benyaich, who has been jailed in Morocco as a terrorist. Two weeks later, the Turkish authorities arrested the three men, Judge Garzn wrote, for failing to produce identification papers, but his report does not say why they were released. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Fairness for Ex-Offenders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRELINGHUYSEN, GEORGE GRISWOLD
description: FRELINGHUYSEN -- George Griswold died at the age of 92, after a long illness, on Sunday, April 25, 2004 at his home in West Palm Beach, Florida. He was the son of Mr. & Mrs. Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J. and was named for his grandfather, G.G. Frelinghuysen, also of Morristown. His maternal grandparents were Mr. & Mrs. H.O. Havermeyer, of New York, N.Y. At an early age Mr. Frelinghuysen was employed at John Wanamaker's in New York, where he developed solid talent as an interior designer. He later went into business for himself. During a long and active life, he lived for many years in Morristown. Later he moved to Bel Air and Santa Barbara, California and then to Santa Fe, New Mexico. Next he lived for years in Honolulu, Hawaii before his final move to Florida. Mr. Frelinghuysen is survived by a younger brother, Peter, of Morristown, and by six nephews and two nieces.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Somerville: Reread For Williams Jury
description: On the second day of deliberations, the jury in the Jayson Williams manslaughter trial asked for a rereading of testimony dealing with charges that Mr. Williams tried to cover up his role in the fatal shooting of a chauffeur, Costas Christofi, in February 2002. In the sections the jury requested, two Harlem Globetrotters, Howard Paul Gaffney and Chris Morris, said that Mr. Williams had asked them and others to tell detectives they were playing pool in his recreation room when Mr. Christofi went upstairs and shot himself. Mr. Gaffney also said that Mr. Williams dove toward Mr. Christofi as he lay dying and asked, ''Are you O.K.?, are you O.K.?'' and moments later said that he had ruined his life. Mr. Morris said Mr. Williams wiped the shotgun with a towel and seemed in a panic. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Picasso's Giant Shadow; Star of Spring Auctions May Fetch $100 Million
description: Every few years a collection comes up for sale that eclipses all the other art being offered during the two heady weeks in spring and fall when the New York auction houses sell important Impressionist, modern and contemporary works. This season it is the fabled paintings that are now part of the Greentree Foundation, the star of which is Picasso's ''Boy With a Pipe.'' Dealers and experts are betting that it could fetch as much as $100 million next week, eclipsing the world record set in 1990 when van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' sold at Christie's in New York for $82.5 million.

Far beyond his accomplishments on and off the football field, Michael will be remembered for his devotion to his family, and in particular to his wife of 38 years, Bernadette, his greatest love and enduring passion. Michael's legacy will live forever as will his memory in the hearts of those who loved him. The family will receive friends on Thursday, April 29, between 7-9 pm and on Friday, April 30, between 2-4 pm and 7-9 pm at the Rosar-Morrison Funeral Home, 467 Sherbourne Street, Toronto. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Misses Profit Forecast
description: The German electronics and engineering company Siemens posted a smaller-than-expected second-quarter profit as a result of losses at its transportation systems and logistics units. Profit rose to 1.2 billion euros ($1.43 billion) from 568 billion euros a year earlier but fell short of the 1.47 billion euros expected by analysts. The company posted a one-time gain of 836 million euros from the sale of a stake in the chipmaker Infineon Technologies. Sales in the period, which ended March 31, fell 2 percent. Hit by charges for defective trams, Siemens's transportation systems reported a loss of 289 million euros, while the logistics unit booked 433 million euros of one-time charges and lost 30 million euros. The chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, above, reiterated the company's target for profit growth of more than 10 percent for the full year, ''even if they will be harder to reach.'' title: Taking High-End Furniture Down Just a Notch
description: Tomorrow, Sills Huniford Associates, the decorating firm, will open Dwellings, a Manhattan shop offering to the public lower-end versions of the firm's famously expensive couture furniture for private clients. The venture could be seen as one of several recent efforts by the partners, Stephen Sills (on left, inset) and James Huniford (right), to redeem their reputations after a 2000 New York magazine article detailed complaints from clients who thought they had wildly overpaid for antiques and other furnishings (charges the partners have denied). Mr. Sills said the store would attract ''a young, upwardly mobile'' customer with ''a lot of money'' -- though not necessarily as much as his clients usually spend. Mr. Huniford said he envisioned customers who dress in Stella McCartney ready-to-wear and have never decorated before. They said they were not worried about diverting clients who typically pay twice as much for similarly styled pieces, custom-made with somewhat better materials. The store, with dead-simple dcor, offers the firm's Southampton Cube armchair ($2,650), Plaster Column lamp ($1,400) and Tufted Back sofa ($5,800), above the inset; and vintage pieces, including a $14,500 pair of painted dressers and an abandoned beehive ($3,800), top right. Mr. Huniford described Dwellings as a converted floor-through on the second floor of a town house, although the location might better be described as occupying the third floor, above a celebrity dermatologist. The address is 30 East 67th Street (Madison Avenue); www.dwellingshome.com or (800) 953-3267. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: HUMANITIES GRANTS
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced it will give $9.9 million for 42 projects across the country to preserve humanities collections, increase public access and create humanities research tools and reference works. Six New York institutions were awarded money for projects, including the New York Public Library, which is to preserve and make available works by the playwright and screenwriter Paddy Chayefsky (1923-81). Also awarded financing was the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx for a display of archival records on the history of horticulture, gardening and landscape design between 1818 and 1990. Columbia University received money for two projects: an online version of a multivolume reference work on the Near East and Central Asia, and for a catalog of medieval manuscripts. ELIZABETH OLSON

The purchase will add 19 cents a share to 2005 net income, Eaton said. Eaton, based in Cleveland, has made 19 acquisitions since 2000. Powerware, based in Raleigh, N.C., had revenue of about $775 million in the year that ended in March, Eaton said.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Midway Loss Widens On Decline In Sales

The net loss increased to $14.2 million, or 27 cents a share, from $9.32 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier, said Midway, which is based in Chicago. Sales dropped 56 percent, to $20.1 million, from $45.8 million. Sales declined from last year's first quarter, when Midway introduced ''Mortal Kombat'' in Europe, the chief financial officer, Thomas E. Powell, told analysts on a conference call. First-quarter revenue exceeded the $18 million forecast on April 6 because of higher-than-expected sales of ''The Suffering,'' the chief executive, David F. Zucker, said. Shares of Midway rose 21 cents, to $8.95, in extended trading after results were announced. The shares had dropped 95 cents, or 9.8 percent, to $8.74 in regular trading.

title: Economic Scene; A growing number of men are not working, so what are they doing?

title: Reality TV, With a Grill as Its Star

The Discovery Channel commissioned Michael Hoff Productions to track the design of a barbecue from conceptual sketches to production of a prototype and a rooftop cookout. The result, ''The Launch,'' introduces Robert Brunner (shown on right), a Pentagram partner, as the ''boss'' and Rob Forbes (on the left), the founder of the retailer Design Within Reach, as the ''client.'' Tension mounts as designers, prototype makers and engineers battle to meet a five-week deadline. Truth is, Mr. Forbes did not ''commission'' the barbecue and has no plans to sell it -- at least not yet. Some viewers may be disappointed. The Fuego has different surfaces for grilling meat, vegetables and fish; a stainless steel body; adjustable ceramic shelves; drawers; and a light for grilling after dark. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TELSON, HOWARD
description: TELSON--Howard. On April 5, 2004 from cancer at age 49. Dr. Telson of New York City obtained his B.A. at Princeton and his M.D. at Yale. He was a Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at NYU School of Medicine where he trained as a psychiatrist and was on the faculty for 20 years. He developed several innovative programs at Bellevue Hospital that improved the mental health system, including the New York State outpatient commitment pilot program at Bellevue Hospital that was expanded statewide by Kendra's Law. He educated the nation about this program through interviews with many leading newspapers and appearances on CNN and ''60 Minutes''. Dr. Telson contributed to the medical and legal literature on forensic psychiatry, the history of psychiatry and the treatment of the homeless mentally ill. He was a Distinguished Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and served on the board of directors of the National Alliance of the Mentally Ill (NAMI) of NYC Metro. Dr. Telson's gift for healing improved the lives of innumerable patients. His broad knowledge of history, geography, politics, literature, architecture and art, and extensive world travels, informed his practice of psychiatry enriching countless psychiatrists, case managers and other mental health professionals whom he taught. All those who knew him were touched by his warmth and the profound humanity of his relationship with others. Dr. Telson is survived by his partner, Anand Pandya, M.D., his sister, Lynne Barsky, brother-inlaw, Michael Barsky, and nieces, Danielle and Sara. Donations can be made in his name to NAMI (www.nami. org). A memorial service will be held on Saturday May 8 at 11 A.M. at Farkas Auditorium, NYU Medical Center, 450 First Avenue near 30th Street in Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Lawmaker Faces Arrest Warrant
description: A judge signed a bench warrant yesterday for the arrest of Assemblyman Roger L. Green after he failed to pay a $2,000 fine stemming from his guilty plea for submitting false travel expenses. Mr. Green pleaded guilty in February to stealing money from the Legislature by submitting papers listing false travel expenses. He was sentenced to three years' probation and ordered to pay a $2,000 fine by Monday. The deadline passed with no payment made, and Judge William A. Carter of Albany City Court signed the warrant for the Albany police to execute. Mr. Green's lawyer, Gerald Shargel, called the failure to pay ''an oversight,'' and said the fine was being paid immediately. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Charged In Woman's Murder
description: Jacob Cecil, 57, sought for questioning in the killing of his companion in her home in the Bronx, has surrendered to the police and has been charged with second-degree murder, the police said yesterday. The woman, Waheeda Khan, 37, a nurse, was found dead by her son when he returned home early Tuesday from an errand, the police said. The woman initially appeared to have been shot in the head, but it was later determined that she had died of blunt trauma, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office said yesterday. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Antiterror Overtime Pay Multiplies
description: Spending on overtime pay for police officers involved in antiterrorism operations rose to $32 million last year, 160 times higher than the $200,000 spent on such pay in 2000, according to a nonpartisan fiscal monitor. In the first half of this fiscal year, such overtime totaled $46 million, or 230 times the 2000 level. The report by the Independent Budget Office said that antiterrorism programs were helping to push total police overtime to $346 million this year, almost twice the sum originally budgeted. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the increase, while worrisome, was necessary. ''My first commitment is to make this city as safe as I can,'' he said. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: New York's Greenmarkets
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Help Promised For Bronx Terminal
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would work with the vendors at the Bronx Terminal Market to keep them from going out of business when the lease for the property changes hands. The market, built in the 1920's, was once one of the largest wholesale operations for Hispanic foods in the country, with more than 100 tenants. There are now about 30 fruit and vegetable wholesalers there. Related Companies, the developer completing the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, recently bought out the Terminal Market's city lease. Related Companies plans to build a multilevel retail complex and garage, with an esplanade and park. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: De Kooning From Z to A: Meetings and Convergences
description: There are two ways to traverse the thrilling survey of Willem de Kooning's paintings at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea: forward and backward. Both are rewarding, but backward is encouraged. Several examples of the artist's late work, visible from the front door, make the case. Painted between 1984 and 1988, just before de Kooning descended into the oblivion of Alzheimer's disease, they fill the gallery's majestic central space and will in all likelihood draw you like a magnet.

title: Coloring By the Numbers
description: COLORS don't come any juicier than those that saturate ''Bombay Dreams,'' the $14 million musical about movie love Bollywood-style, which opened last night at the Broadway Theater. Scarcely a scene goes by that isn't splashed with gorgeous heaping helpings of oranges, golds, greens, purples, yellows and more shades of pink than even Este Lauder had names for.

title: Judge Lets Jockeys Wear Ads In Derby
description: A federal judge in Louisville, Ky., issued a temporary injunction yesterday against Kentucky that will let jockeys wear advertising on their pants and turtlenecks tomorrow at the Kentucky Derby, as they have in Florida, New York, Maryland and California.

title: Their long slump over, airlines are battling for a busy summer market.
description: AS summer approaches and the air travel business recovers from its long doldrums, Madison Avenue has produced a crop of campaigns talking up its airline clients. The advertising varies widely in style and content, but all of it aims to fill seats in what could be the busiest travel season in several years.

title: On Gay Circuit, The Party Never Ends
description: IT was one in the morning on Easter Sunday. Inside the Palm Springs, Calif., convention center, which had been transformed into an elfish forest, with chiffon drapery and cherry blossoms, 4,500 men dressed -- partially at least -- in white were dancing to ear-shattering techno. Suddenly, the D.J. stopped the music, and the curtain on the stage rose to reveal a symphony orchestra playing a dance version of Annie Lennox's ''Into the West'' from ''The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.'' A silver-painted drag queen in a 20-foot headdress lip-synched the song from a dais while a small troupe of modern ballet dancers pirouetted onstage.

title: Into the Future, Without a Map?
description: SATELLITE navigation systems, now installed in nearly 30 percent of all new car models, are all but making the road map obsolete -- and with it the serendipity that can occur on a road trip when you are led astray by human error. After all, what better way to get off the beaten path? Page 2.

title: Blow to Builder Over Insurance At Ground Zero
description: A federal jury in Manhattan handed the developer Larry A. Silverstein a major setback yesterday in his bitter legal battle with two dozen insurers over how much money will be available for rebuilding the sprawling World Trade Center site. The panel ruled that many of the insurers were not liable for the double payments he had sought.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Detective Shoots Armed Man
description: An undercover narcotics detective shot and wounded a man while trying to buy drugs in Brooklyn last night, the police said. The detective, whom the police would not identify, was with a partner when he tried to buy drugs from a man on the corner of Starr Street and Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick about 6:15 p.m. They were approached by a man armed with a kitchen knife, and one of the detectives shot him once in the torso, the police said. The wounded man was in stable condition last night at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens. The other man, whose identity was not released by the police, was in custody last night, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Europe Lifts the Curtain
description: Born amid the devastation wrought by Hitler, the European Coal and Steel Community has come a long way, and it is about to take another giant leap forward tomorrow. Ten nations, and their 75 million people, are joining the European Union in that club's most ambitious enlargement ever. For much of Central and Eastern Europe, severed from the West by the Nazi blitzkrieg and Stalin's subsequent ''liberation,'' this amounts to the lifting of the Iron Curtain.

description: Why this particular fishing village, among the hundreds along the East African coast, may soon receive a new well, courtesy of the Pentagon, is no secret.

description: Yogi Berra has forgotten some details, but he knew the length of his worst hitless streak, the way he broke out of it and the opponent when he did. Decades later, Derek Jeter provided the historical symmetry to an epic slump.

title: Jury in Williams Trial Has Decided 6 Counts, but Is Split on 2 Others
description: The jurors in the Jayson Williams manslaughter trial disclosed on Thursday that they had reached verdicts in six of the charges and were deeply divided on the two other counts.

title: Op-Chart; Will a Bigger Europe Be a Better Europe?
description: Tomorrow the European Union will grow to 25 members from 15, including 8 new countries from formerly Communist Eastern Europe: the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia. (The other two new members are Malta and the southern part of Cyprus.) This will have a profound effect on an organization whose institutions were designed for six members in the 1950's and have been only tinkered with since. And, as the chart below shows, the differences between West and East are striking.

title: A Full Range of Technology Is Applied to Bomb Falluja
description: The airstrikes in Falluja in the past three days by American warplanes and helicopter gunships have been the most intense aerial bombardment in Iraq since major combat ended nearly a year ago, military officials said Thursday.

title: Oriental Dance as a Theatrical Form
description: There were no allusions to striptease-style belly dancing when the Elena Lentini Dance Theater presented "The Garden of Abraham: Myth, Ritual & Folklore" on April 24 at the Washington Square United Methodist Church in Greenwich Village. There were few glimpses of lurching abdomens, bare or clothed. There was also little sense of the origins of Oriental dance, as practitioners call it, as healthy exercise to strengthen women's muscles for labor. Instead, Ms. Lentini, the doyenne of Middle Eastern dancing at the August Fazil's Rehearsal Studios in the Theater District, made a strong case for Oriental dance as a theatrical form.

Her lifelong dedication to women and their health and beauty inspires our work. Our sincere condolences to Leonard and Evelyn, Ronald and Jo Carole and their families. Myra J. description: Deputy Chief Bruce H. Smolka Jr., left, has been promoted to commanding officer of Patrol Borough Manhattan South, a major Police Department post. He succeeds Assistant Chief Michael Esposito, who retired as commander last week after two years in the post and 37 years in the department. Manhattan South covers the area south of 59th street, including the Empire State Building, the United Nations and Wall Street. Chief Smolka, 51, will be promoted to the rank of assistant chief at a ceremony today. Michael Wilson (NYT)

It's the relatively cheap help on the horizon, however, that may keep the Angels among the league's premier teams for several years.

description: Coherence is not necessarily a virtue of film festivals. Since the third annual TriBeCa Film Festival, which starts tomorrow, will stuff more than 150 features into a little more than a week, coherence may not even be a possibility. Like last year's TriBeCa Festival and other, similar events sprouting like toadstools in every resort town and urban center in North America, a degree of chaos will surely be part of what makes this festival festive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANE, BOB
description: KANE--Bob. Of Great Neck died on April 27, 2004 at age 96. Born in NYC on May 21, 1907. Beloved ''Daddy'' of Michael Kane and Riki Kane Larimer, known to him as ''Baby.'' Beloved son-in-law of Bob Larimer, known to him as ''Robby.'' Married to the woman he adored, Ginger Weiner Kane, for 57 years until her death in 1992. Co-owner, with his brother Bill, of Metropolitan Plumbing Supply for more than 60 years. Bob was an avid storyteller, dedicated gourmand, aspiring comedian, ardent golfer, patient fisherman, parlor magician, crafty card player, champion kibitzer and above all, super salesman. He loved sunshine, jokes, steaks, cigars, lobsters, baseball, plump oysters, old songs, animals and kids. He lived all of his 35,406 days to the hilt.

title: U.N. Struggles to Find Troops to Police Haiti
description: Just a month before its deadline, the United Nations finds itself hard-pressed to sign up peacekeeping troops and French-speaking police officers to take over security in Haiti from an American-led interim force, United Nations officials and diplomats say.

title: Former Envoy Talks in Book About Source Of C.I.A. Leak
description: Former Ambassador Joseph C. Wilson IV says in a new book that he believes the White House official behind the disclosure of his wife's identity as an undercover C.I.A. officer was ''quite possibly'' I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff. But Mr. Wilson offers no firm evidence to support his assertion, and the White House has denied it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Pro-Westerner Elected President
description: The center-left prime minister, Branko Crvenkovski, was declared the winner of the presidential elections held Wednesday, in spite of apparent irregularities. Mr. Crvenkovski had about 62 percent of the vote; his conservative rival, Sasko Kedev, won 39 percent. International observers said the ballot, called after the death of President Boris Trajkovski in a plane crash in February, was broadly democratic but had been marred by incidents of ballot-stuffing and proxy voting. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Two Suspended for THG Test Results
description: Two track and field athletes who had tested positive for the steroid THG were suspended for two years yesterday by the United States Anti-Doping Agency. They are the first suspensions of American athletes since the drug, tetrahydrogestrinone, was discovered last summer.

title: DELPHI AND VISTEON REACH A PACT WITH U.A.W.
description: The Delphi Corporation and the Visteon Corporation, the auto-parts makers, said yesterday that they had reached seven-year agreements with the United Automobile Workers that let the companies pay lower wages and offer fewer benefits to new employees. Delphi said its agreement provided a $14-an-hour starting wage for new hires, about half the rate for current union-represented workers. A Visteon spokesman, Jim Fisher, would not comment on wages and said the two sides still had ''operational issues'' to resolve. He declined to be more specific. The U.A.W. said Delphi would make ''significant investments'' at union plants and did not comment on the Visteon accord. ''Both the U.A.W. and Delphi faced many hard choices during these negotiations,'' the union's president, Ron Gettelfinger, said in a statement.

title: Shell Tries A Buyback To Pacify Its Investors
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said on Thursday that it would buy back $2 billion of its shares this year, the latest sign that the company is trying to placate shareholders after months of criticism.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Ruling On Diluted Votes
description: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld a lower court's ruling that Charleston County had illegally diluted minority voting by electing all nine council members in countywide voting. The county is 34.5 percent black. Since 1970, 3 of the 41 members elected in the at-large system have been from racial minorities. The judges affirmed the decision by Judge Michael Duffy of Federal District that the system discriminated because it was ''not clearly erroneous,'' though they said it was ''certainly disputable.'' Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Judge Is Assailed Over Holocaust Fund
description: The raw emotions and memories brought to life by a 1998 settlement of a lawsuit against Swiss banks for their handling of Nazi-era accounts filled a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, as a federal judge heard what one witness described as a ''dog-eat-dog'' battle between Holocaust survivors over how to distribute what could be hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Go Off the Beaten Path? Not Likely With G.P.S.
description: THE term ''road trip'' used to mean piling into the family station wagon and waiting for the fireworks to begin. There was the familiar ritual of watching Mom open the pale blue map -- creased and worn, splattered with coffee stains -- while Dad took the wheel. There was the leisurely interlude when the trip was on course and everyone took turns measuring distances and noting points of interest. Then there was the panicked moment when someone realized Interstate 95 had become Interstate 195 and the next exit was 30 miles away.

Beloved wife of the late Irving; devoted mother to Sandra, Cindy, Michael and the late David; adored grandmother of Daniel, Brian, Ian and Josh. Cherished sister of Shirley. Always a smile, loved her family, loved life. Will be missed forever. Funeral services Sunday May 2, 9am, Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens, NY.

This is too bad, because the two principal actors in this watery romantic comedy, which opens nationwide today, make you wish it were better.

title: John W. Kirklin Is Dead at 86; Innovator in Cardiac Surgery
description: Dr. John W. Kirklin, a cardiovascular surgeon whose refinements of the heart-lung machine in the 1950's helped make open heart surgery safer and more predictable, died on April 21 at his home in Birmingham, Ala. He was 86.

title: And the Rich Get Smarter
description: Yet another string of studies confirms what any high school senior or parent who has just weathered the college admissions mating dance already knew -- it's a cutthroat competition where money matters more than ever. Teenagers from wealthy families are beating out middle- and working-class youngsters, both at top private colleges and flagship state universities whose historic mission of broad access is receding into memory. The trend means that ''smart poor kids,'' as the educator Terry Hartle bluntly puts it, ''go to college at the same rate as stupid rich kids.''

A co-founder of East End Hospice, she founded the Hospice Thrift Shop. She leaves her children, Linda, Nancy, and Bill Cahan and two grandchildren. A unique, vibrant and true original, she is deeply missed. Memorial service May 8, 2-4 PM, WHB Free Library. Donations preferred to East End Hospice or Bide-A-Wee in Westhampton.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Posts Profit
description: Buoyed by a strong demand in Asia, the Swiss-Swedish engineering group ABB reported a net profit of $4 million for the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $45 million in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts said the quarterly profit figure fell far short of an expected $46 million, but noted that ABB had nearly eliminated losses in noncore units, had improved cash flow and had increased sales. The chief executive, Jrgen Dormann, above, said it was the sixth consecutive quarterly rise and that the trend underscored a gradual recovery of the troubled Swiss engineering giant after years of losses.

title: AETNA SAYS PROFIT ROSE 11%, AIDED BY NEW CUSTOMERS
description: Aetna, the health insurer, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 11 percent as the company added more than 300,000 customers. Net income rose to $365.8 million, or $2.28 a share, from $330 million, or $2.12, a year earlier, the company, based in Hartford, said. For the first time since 1999, Aetna is signing up more members as competitors are turning to acquisitions to fuel growth. Aetna said profit was $1.75 a share excluding adjustments to reserves, capital gains and completion of tax audits for discontinued operations. On that basis, the company was expected to earn $1.72 a share, the average estimate of 20 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Shares of the company fell $4.03, or 4.5 percent, to $83.72 yesterday. They had risen 30 percent this year.

title: U.S. Is Seeking Return of Funds From Schools
description: The federal government is moving to recover hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicaid payments it maintains have been improperly claimed by school districts throughout New York, according to federal officials and state school administrators.

title: Daimler Board Blocks Protg Of Troubled Chief
description: DaimlerChrysler's chief executive, Jrgen E. Schrempp, survived a critical board meeting yesterday, a week after the board rejected his proposal that the company bail out its struggling Japanese partner, Mitsubishi Motors.

title: An Egalitarian Auction? Bankers Are Not Amused
description: For months, investment banks vied to win the job of underwriting Google's much-anticipated initial public offering. But as details emerged yesterday about the unusual auction process that Google's founders have chosen, questions have arisen about whether the scramble for a piece of the action was worth the trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUGENES, OTTAR
description: HAUGENES--Ottar. Of Huntington. On April 28, 2004. Beloved husband of Gisela and cherished father of Scott Erik (Claudine) and Steven Tor (Susan), devoted grandfather of Skylar, Hannah, Dylan, Jackson, and Tor. Loving uncle of Linnea Osth-Wrage (George). Visitation Sunday 10-11AM at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc. 1380 New York Ave, Huntington Station. Service 11AM. Cremation private. Donations may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROONEY, MARGUERITE
description: ROONEY--Marguerite. The Directors, Trustees and Staff of the Edmund Niles Huyck Preserve mourn the loss of our Chairman, Marge Rooney. Marge was an extraordinary woman and inspired us all with her selfless commitment to the Preserve and our community. Her humor and generous heart will always be with us. We extend our most sincere condolences to the Rooney family. Laura Carter, President

title: Militant Mullah Meets Match In Comic at Norway Nightclub
description: How much weight does a bearded mullah carry in a freewheeling liberal society like Norway's?

title: A Brancusi Trio Becomes a Quartet
description: When ''Constantin Brancusi: The Essence of Things'' opens at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on June 11, the exhibition will include several works not seen at the Tate Modern in London, where the exhibition is on view through May 23. One in particular will stand out, especially to art historians and scholars well versed in this Romanian-born artist's work. Curators at the Guggenheim call the sculpture a discovery and say it has never been publicly exhibited before.

title: Civil Rights of Sikh Violated, Judge Says
description: The New York Police Department violated the civil rights of a Sikh traffic enforcement agent when it threatened to fire him if he did not cut his hair and remove his turban, an administrative law judge has found.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

title: Sharon's Gaza Pullout Plan May Face His Party's Rebuff
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon faced the prospect of a major political setback on Thursday as three separate polls all showed that members of his own party were likely to vote down his proposal for pulling Israel out of the Gaza Strip.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about arson at the home of a Hmong community leader in Maplewood, Minn., referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of Hmong refugees who are expected to settle in the St. Paul area this summer. The number is unknown, not necessarily in the thousands. (About 15,000 Hmong will move to the United States this summer.)

description: Events

title: Strong Growth Rate Seen in First Quarter
description: The American economy grew at a vigorous annual rate of 4.2 percent in the first quarter, with military spending making a significant contribution to economic growth for the first time since the early days of the war in Iraq.

title: 36 Hours | Jacksonville, Fla.
description: WITH its working-city image and nebulous locale -- on the brink of northeast Florida, whistling distance from Georgia -- Jacksonville has never been a serious vacation spot. Now it should be. Along the sleek-blue St. Johns River, neighborhoods are sliding into style. Artists and designers have turned up the vogue volume, opening galleries, cafes and shops among the ancient maples and magnolias. Elegant new inns and jazz bars beckon from spectacularly restored 100-year-old mansions. Cruise ships visit, and millions are being poured into museums. Momentum builds for the 2005 Super Bowl, which will be played in the downtown stadium. Meantime, travelers can slip in for savvy weekends, knowing that the place long called ''the biggest city in South Georgia'' is fast becoming Florida's next jewel. CATHERINE O'NEAL

title: Key Witness Tells of Deception at Adelphia
description: James Brown, the government's star witness against members of the Rigas family, which ran the Adelphia Communications Corporation, offered blistering testimony yesterday that implicated them in a variety of financial frauds.

title: McGreevey Looks to Wealthy To Fix New Jersey Property Tax
description: In a rare special session of the Legislature, Gov. James E. McGreevey on Thursday urged an increase in the income taxes of New Jersey's wealthiest residents to finance bigger property tax rebates for more than 90 percent of the state's homeowners.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the return of Western archaeologists to Iran after a quarter-century absence misstated the affiliation of Dr. Holly Pittman, who is investigating Bronze Age remains there. She is from the University of Pennsylvania, not Penn State.

title: Alternate Side Of Reality Parking Rules
description: LET us suppose you have a chest of drawers that you sorely need for storage space but cannot fit into your small apartment. What to do?

title: Serving a Celestial Banquet
description: Olivier Messiaen was an intensely committed Catholic who wrote music inspired by his love of God, his love of nature and his love of birdsong. For much of his creative life, Messiaen was also the organist at the Church of the Trinity in Paris. Not surprisingly, he left behind a rich collection of 11 works for that instrument that together offer a remarkable panoramic view of his twinned musical and spiritual worlds.

title: Olympic Trials: Who Needs Athens?
description: FANS of the Summer Olympics who have neither the time nor the money to make it to Athens this year -- or who are skittish about security -- can see the top American hopefuls right here at home in the coming months. Here are some of the sports that are holding Olympic trials to determine the national team. Tickets are still available for each, at far below Olympic prices. J. R. ROMANKO

title: Nets Are Going to Detroit To Resume Word Game
description: When the Nets limped off the court on March 18, the last time they saw the Detroit Pistons, they showed more fire after the game than they had during it. One by one, the Nets took their turns spewing at the Pistons for the words that the team had thrown at them before the game and later, with even Jason Kidd, who rarely shows a glimpse of a temper, ripping into the Pistons in his postgame interview.

title: 'People Say I'm Crazy'
description: Directed by John Cadigan

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Stephen Hanson opened the elegant Fiamma Osteria in SoHo back in the spring of 2002. It was a bid for critical legitmacy from a man best known for opening populist food mills; Mr. Hanson's company, B. R. Guest Inc., owns Ruby Foo's Dim Sum and Sushi Palace, Blue Water Grill and Blue Fin, among more than a dozen other feed lots in Manhattan, Las Vegas and, lately, Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Just How 'Historic' Can an Oval Office Interview Be if It's Not Recorded?
description: If an important meeting takes place in the Oval Office and there are no television cameras to record it, did the meeting matter?

description: BROWN--Themis Anastasia. Always missed, remembered and always loved. Mom and Dad

title: Ex-Editor at Gannett Chain Is to Lead USA Today
description: USA Today, the Gannett Company flagship jolted by revelations of fabrications and plagiarism, yesterday named as its new editor Kenneth A. Paulson, the executive director of the First Amendment Center and a former top editor at the chain.

title: Citing Pullback, Antigraft Team Quits Teamsters
description: The former federal prosecutor who heads the Teamsters' internal anticorruption program resigned yesterday, along with 20 other investigators and lawyers involved in that effort, saying the union's president was not fully committed to fighting corruption.

title: DOW CHEMICAL TO CUT 3,000 JOBS, CITING RISING COSTS
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,000 jobs this year amid rising costs. The company, based in Midland, Mich., also reported a sixfold increase in first-quarter profit on growing demand from manufacturers. Net income rose to $469 million, or 50 cents a share, from $76 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue climbed 15 percent, to $9.31 billion, from $8.08 billion. The average estimate of 14 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial climbed to 43 cents a share from 39 cents in the last month.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: RULING ON DILUTED VOTES A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld a lower court's ruling that Charleston County had illegally diluted minority voting by electing all nine council members in countywide voting. The county is 34.5 percent black. Since 1970, 3 of the 41 members elected in the at-large system have been from racial minorities. The judges affirmed the decision by Judge Michael Duffy of Federal District that the system discriminated because it was "not clearly erroneous," though they said it was "certainly disputable." Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Residential Real Estate; Sale of Luxury Condos Is Brisk as Building Rises in Hudson Square
description: Two blocks from the Hudson River, in the western portion of SoHo known as Hudson Square, the site where an abandoned warehouse once stood is now well along toward becoming a sleek 14-story building with 104 condominium apartments.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Misses 4th-Quarter Forecast
description: BMC Software, whose programs manage computer networks and corporate call centers, missed its quarterly profit forecast yesterday and agreed to pay a 69 percent premium to buy Marimba Inc. BMC shares declined $1.45, or 7.4 percent, to $18.05. Marimba rose $3.20, or 66 percent, to $8.07. BMC, based in Houston, said it would pay $8.25 a share for Marimba, based in Mountain View, Calif. The quarter, BMC's fourth, ended March 31. Net income increased 79 percent, to $36.9 million, or 16 cents a share, from $20.6 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier, BMC said. Sales gained 5.1 percent, to $400.2 million from $380.7 million, BMC said. Excluding some costs, profit would have been 18 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOVACH, LILLIAN MITZI
description: KOVACH--Lillian Mitzi, age 85, on April 29th, 2004. Beloved wife of Leslie. Loving mother of Hildi. Devoted sister of Pearl and Sylvia. Graveside service Salem Field Cemetery, Monday, May 3rd, 3 PM.

title: Troops Without Armor in Iraq
description: It's hard to imagine what the Pentagon was thinking when it told the American Army and Marine replacement divisions bound for Iraq earlier this year to leave their tanks and other heavily armored vehicles behind. American military planners seem to have ignored evidence that armed resistance to the occupation was far from suppressed. As a result, they failed to anticipate the kinds of ambushes and urban firefights these troops are now caught up in and against which tanks and armored personnel carriers afford the best protection.

title: `Enemy Combatants' and the Court (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Promoter of U.S. Image Quits for Wall St. Job
description: Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department veteran who was summoned from abroad to overhaul the public diplomacy effort, said Thursday that she was resigning to take a position at the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RATLIFF, JENNIE
description: RATLIFF--Jennie. Died April 25, at age 65, of ALS, at her home in Norwich, VT. Here's to a life well lived, from her husband, Marcus Ratliff, and sons Marcus and Ben; her four grandsons will remember her love, intelligence, elegance, generosity, and Christmas crackers.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Chief Justice To Move To Teaching
description: Chief Justice Thomas R. Phillips of the State Supreme Court said he would resign effective Sept. 3 and teach at the South Texas School of Law at Houston. Justice Phillips, 54, was a strong advocate to reorganize the judiciary, which he described as ''a relic of the 19th century.'' In particular, Justice Phillips, a Republican who has been chief judge since he was first appointed in 1988, argued for abolishing judicial elections and granting governors the power to appoint judges, subject to periodic reaffirmation by a public vote. Opposition in the House doomed the proposal last year. Gov. Rick Perry, also a Republican, will appoint a successor. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, FLORENCE (NEE MESSER)
description: BROWN--Florence (nee Messer), April 29, 2004. Devoted wife of the late Reuben. Mother of Daniel Brown and Donald (Helaine) Brown. Cherished grandmother of Shari (Paul) Isserles, Shira, Aaron and Jeffrey Brown. Loving sister of Gwen Levinson and the late Blanche McSorley. Graveside services Sunday, 11am at Mount Ararat Cemetery (section 72), Farmingdale. For more information, Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks, 800622-6410.

title: It's Home, Without Anything Pretty About It
description: Almost immediately, ''The Book of Ruth,'' which appears Sunday night on CBS, shakes off the trusting television viewer, as if rejecting a friendly advance. A slow series of still lifes and drab interiors, set to gentle piano music, are interrupted at intervals by poltergeisty action -- crashing plates and insinuations of violence -- until all the stuff in the house, from the dismal dcor to the rake teeth in the front yard, becomes dangerous, disloyal.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Police Informants Linked To Attack
description: The Interior Ministry said it would investigate whether two key suspects in the March 11 train bombings were police informants. The men, one a retired mine worker, are believed to have helped obtain the explosives used in the bombings, court officials said. The announcement was in response to an article in El Mundo saying that Rafa Zuher of Morocco and Emilio Surez Trashorras of Spain habitually informed the police about drug shipments. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: 'The Clay Bird'
description: Directed by Tareque Masud

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, PAUL N.
description: SIEGEL--Paul N., 87, April 26, 2004. Shakespearean professor emeritus, Marxist scholar and political activist. Well loved and revered father of Rosalind Robertson and grandfather of Christie, Jenni, Noah and Jessica Robertson and Halle Tecco. Truly a uniquely principled, generous and dedicated man. Memorial service May 22. For details call his granddaughter Jenni 212-873-7523.

title: A Fresh Look at Beethoven and the I Ching
description: With its third stage, Zankel Hall, up and running, Carnegie Hall has felt busier than ever this season. Last weekend alone there was a visiting orchestra, a Perspectives series event, a conducting workshop, a pops concert and a high-powered chat on the creative process. With all this activity, it can be easy to lose sight of a simple string quartet concert, and yet there it was: the Brentano Quartet performed works by Beethoven, Mozart and the Chinese composer Chou Wen-chung on April 23 in Weill Recital Hall.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Monday about BestLife, a new magazine published by Rodale Inc., misidentified the readership the publisher is pursuing. It consists of middle-aged men, not young men.

title: World Briefings
description: EUROPE

title: Jackson Pleads Not Guilty to 10 Felony Counts
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif., April 30  Facing new charges and flanked by a new lawyer, Michael Jackson pleaded not guilty today to 10 felony counts arising from accusations that he sexually abused a 13-year-old boy last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Serono Executive Leaves
description: Serono, Europe's largest biotechnology company, said that Allan Shaw had resigned as chief financial officer and a member of the board for personal reasons. Serono, which is based in Geneva, said that Jacques Theurillat, deputy chief executive, would step in until a successor is found. Mr. Theurillat, who is also president of European and international sales and marketing, held the post of chief financial officer from 1996 to 2002. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Record Fine For Pollution
description: A unit of Tyco International has agreed to pay the largest fine ever levied in New England for environmental crimes. The offenses include illegally dumping lead-laced wastewater into the Manchester, Stafford and Staffordville sewer systems and falsifying water samples sent to state regulators for examination. Tyco Printed Circuit Group is a limited partnership that is part of the company once headed by Dennis Kozlowski, whose financial misconduct trial recently ended in mistrial. The Tyco unit pleaded guilty in federal court yesterday and agreed to pay $10 million for violations of the federal Clean Water Act between 1999 and 2001. Earlier, three employees pleaded guilty to felonies in connection with the Clean Water Act. They are awaiting sentencing. Brian E. Spears, the assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the case, said that $4 million of the fine would go to improvement projects, including $500,000 each for sewer and wastewater treatment systems in the towns. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: A Pianist's Hands Encompass Two Sides of Central Park
description: He dashed out of Avery Fisher Hall last night sounding like a guy who needed fast wheels, or maybe a rocket. The pianist Louis Lortie was late.
