description: To the Editor:

title: The French Get Their Drug Company. Will Foreign Investors Retaliate?
description: WILL foreign investors punish France?

title: MCI EXPECTS 2004 LOSS AND SALES AT LOW END OF ESTIMATES
description: MCI Inc., which exited bankruptcy protection last week, said yesterday that it would have an unspecified loss this year, with sales at the low end of its estimates, as prices for telephone and data service decline. The company, formerly known as WorldCom Inc., separately reported 2003 net income of $22.2 billion because of a gain on the $35 billion of debt it wiped away as part of the restructuring, compared with a loss of $9.2 billion in 2002. Excluding a Brazilian unit, sales last year fell 14.7 percent, to $24.4 billion, MCI said in a statement. MCI, the second-biggest long-distance phone company after AT&T, said sales this year would be at the low end of the $21 billion to $22 billion range it forecast in January.

title: Genetic Link Seen in Cancer Drug's Power
description: As one treatment after another failed to beat back her lung cancer, Kate Robbins began writing her thoughts and feelings in journals to leave her children ''something tangible that they could read and refer back to'' after she died.

title: Reyes Has Another Setback With Hamstring
description: Jos Reyes, out almost seven weeks with a strained right hamstring, suffered another setback Thursday.

title: BUSH AND CHENEY TELL 9/11 PANEL OF '01 WARNINGS
description: President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney were questioned in the Oval Office for more than three hours on Thursday by the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks. They said intelligence warnings they received throughout 2001 suggested that Al Qaeda was poised to strike overseas, not on American soil, according to accounts of commission and administration officials.

title: Google's Sale of Its Shares Will Defy Wall St. Tradition
description: Correction Appended

title: Joe Ovelman
description: Oliver Kamm/5BE Gallery

title: Freedom for a Terror Suspect in Indonesia
description: Abu Bakar Bashir, who just finished an 18-month jail term in Indonesia on immigration charges, was immediately arrested yesterday in Jakarta. He has been accused of leading Jamaah Islamiyah, which is associated with Al Qaeda, but putting him on trial again carries heavy political risks for the Indonesian government.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Finisar To Buy Infineon Unit
description: Finisar will acquire the fiber optic components division of Infineon Technologies, Europe's second-largest semiconductor producer, in a stock swap that will give Infineon a 38 percent stake in Finisar, the two companies said yesterday. The deal is valued at about $244 million based on Finisar's closing price of $1.81 in trading yesterday on the Nasdaq. Finisar is based in Sunnyvale, Calif. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: With Child Kidnappings on Rise, Afghans Seek Help From Public
description: The Afghan interior minister, Ali Ahmad Jalali, made an unusual appeal to the public on Thursday to watch out for child kidnappers and traffickers, after the police uncovered widespread cases of child kidnapping across the country.

title: Ex-Nurse Pleads Guilty to Killing Patients
description: It took less than 10 minutes in the county courthouse for Charles Cullen, the former nurse, to confirm committing the most recent murders in a quiet rampage through hospitals in New Jersey and Pennsylvania over the past decade. Answering with a simple, emotionless ''Yes,'' Mr. Cullen again and again admitted intentionally killing a total of at least 14 patients.

title: A Dog-Maintenance Miracle And the Shaky Empire It Built
description: The only grotesque extravagance missing from the estate of Nick Vanderpark (Jack Black), the overnight zillionaire who bounces through ''Envy'' like a big gurgling baby, is a statue of Michelangelo's David urinating vodka. Nick has acquired everything else imaginable: an ugly, out-of-place mansion in the San Fernando Valley surrounded by power lines; a white horse named Corky that gobbles up the neighbors' apples; an indoor bowling alley next to the dining room; a glittering carousel that malfunctions; an elaborate archery range; and a bed so enormous it makes him look like the Incredible Shrinking Man.

title: What's on Your Playlist?
description: When a corporation misses its projections by 30 percent, you're entitled to think that something has gone wrong. Apple -- once just a computer company -- had hoped to sell 100 million songs in the first year of its iTunes Music Store. Instead it sold 70 million songs. But nobody seems to be complaining. At 99 cents per song, iTunes has generated nearly $70 million in legal Internet music sales that didn't exist before, and it is hoping to double that figure in the second year.

title: 'Italy: Spaces and Places'
description: Robert Mann Gallery

title: Walters Defends Show On Adoption
description: Barbara Walters, the co-anchor of the ABC News program ''20/20,'' said yesterday that its segment on adoption, which will be broadcast tonight, is a ''straightforward news report.'' She was responding to widespread criticism of the network's promotion of the program, which many complained made it sound like a ''Win the Baby'' reality show.

title: Federal Investigators Seized Vials From Bonds's Trainer
description: Federal investigators found vials containing what are believed to be human growth hormone and anabolic steroids in the apartment and vehicle of Greg Anderson, Barry Bonds's personal trainer, during a search last September.

title: From Dream to Nightmare
description: At least 10 more American soldiers died yesterday in George W. Bush's senseless war in Iraq.

title: UNION PACIFIC SAYS FIRST-QUARTER REVENUE FELL 62%
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, owner of the largest United States railroad, said yesterday that first-quarter profit fell 62 percent, in part because train delays increased fuel and wage costs. Results benefited from a $41 million drop in income tax payments. Net income declined to $165 million, or 63 cents a share, from $429 million, or $1.67, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue declined 6.1 percent, to $2.89 billion, as the 2003 quarter included $343 million from Overnite, a trucking unit sold last year. Costs rose 9 percent, to $2.58 billion. The company was expected to earn 59 cents a share, the average estimate in a Thomson Financial poll of 12 analysts.

title: Jeter Lights Yanks' Fire as Early as Possible
description: Derek Jeter did not do everything for the Yankees last night. He speared a rising line drive at shortstop and he ended his 0-for-32 slump with a towering home run, but those plays came on back-to-back pitches in the first inning.

title: OSHA Cites 4 Companies in Parking Garage Collapse
description: Intentional disregard or plain indifference by one of the main subcontractors at the Tropicana Casino and Resort expansion project, as well as serious violations by three other companies, caused the death of four workers and the injury of 20 others when the garage they were erecting collapsed last October, federal investigators concluded yesterday.

title: Picking a Jury for a Case in the Headlines
description: Testimony has finished in the retrial of former Credit Suisse First Boston banker Frank P. Quattrone but the publicity surrounding his and other prominent white-collar criminal cases may make life a little harder for the corporate defendants who follow.

title: Kerry Challenges Bush to Internationalize Iraqi Operation
description: FULTON, Mo., April 30  One year after President Bush celebrated success in Iraq by landing on an aircraft carrier decorated with a "Mission Accomplished" banner, Senator John Kerry today challenged him to immediately internationalize the operation, urging the appointment of a high commissioner to oversee Iraq's reconstruction and political transformation.

title: Let Them Wear Silk: Decadence Before the Fall
description: ''DANGEROUS LIAISONS,'' a sumptuous display of 18th-century fashion and furniture on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, recasts the museum exhibition as a double-entendre. The show is more than a presentation of fancy dress and dcor. It is a shock. A scandal. A deluge!

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Van Strike Settlement Unravels
description: The settlement of the strike by van drivers for the disabled that was announced on Wednesday unraveled yesterday when union leaders examined the terms more closely. The weeklong strike by 1,000 drivers will therefore continue. According to management, the agreement would have provided drivers a 2 percent retroactive pay increase and a minimum 4.6 percent increase a year over the next three years. But Ron Straci, a lawyer for the union, said that strike leaders discovered that the yearly increases would be divided into two installments, one in September, the other on workers' anniversary dates, meaning that some workers would benefit long before others. The four companies provide half of the program's 6,000 daily rides. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: False Spin on Retirees
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Doctor Accused Of Sexual Abuse
description: The police arrested a Metropolitan Hospital Center medical resident, Walter Calderon, 34, on Wednesday night and charged him with sexually abusing two female patients during medical examinations, the police said. The Health and Hospitals Corporation issued a statement saying that Dr. Calderon had resigned, and that he had been accused of performing an improper examination on a female patient in September. He was suspended then, but was eventually cleared. He was reinstated on the condition that any examination of a female patient be chaperoned, the statement said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Excerpts From 'Owner's Manual' Included With Offering
description: The founders of Google, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, included in the offering statement a letter -- or, in their words, ''An Owner's Manual'' -- patterned after the annual letters that Warren E. Buffett writes to shareholders at Berkshire Hathaway. Following are excerpts from the Google founders' letter:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Look, if we had something to hide, we wouldn't have met with them in the first place. We answered all of their questions.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Posts Profit
description: The HVB Group, Germany's second-largest bank, reported first-quarter profit and revenue that fell short of market forecasts and the company's own goals. Profit rose to 53 million euros ($62.7 million), compared with a 9 million euro loss a year ago, and revenue slipped to 2.32 billion euros ($2.74 billion) from 2.36 billion euros, 2 percent below HVB's forecast. Interest income dropped 120 million euros, to 1.29 billion euros. Business shrank as the bank sold assets worth about $4 billion to increase its capital.

title: A Golf Hero Who Suffers In Silence
description: The most pertinent question posed by ''Bobby Jones: Stroke of Genius,'' a high-minded, lethally dull biography of the legendary golfer Bobby Jones, is whether a smidgen of the box-office magic of ''The Passion of the Christ'' has rubbed off on its star, Jim Caviezel. If Hollywood's biblical past tells us anything, my guess would be no.

title: READER'S DIGEST POSTS $2.2 MILLION IN EARNINGS
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc., publisher of the magazine, posted a third-quarter profit yesterday of $2.2 million, in contrast to a loss a year earlier, helped by higher earnings at its international unit. Net income for the period ended March 31 was 2 cents a share, compared with a loss of $4.6 million, or 5 cents, a year earlier, the company, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., said.

title: Romancing the Mirror, to Debussy
description: The New York City Ballet's European Festival at the New York State Theater continued on Wednesday night with works choreographed by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins to music of Debussy, Ravel, Hindemith and Brahms, as orchestrated by Schoenberg.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Proposes Lower Rates For Some Local Access
description: AT&T, making a counteroffer yesterday in talks to end a dispute over what it pays to use networks of local-telephone companies, proposed spending less to lease lines if it uses its own equipment to route calls on those wires. Federal Communications Commission rules allowing discounts in leasing regional carriers' equipment and lines, which AT&T uses to resell local-phone service, may expire June 15 unless the Supreme Court intervenes.

title: Boundaries and Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: As Terrorists Strike Arab Targets, Escalation Fears Arise
description: A string of significant terrorist actions, all within days of one another, in major Arab capitals, may signal that the war in Iraq is fueling the very kind of extremism it was supposed to curtail, Arab officials and analysts said Thursday.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Rape Inquiry Ends
description: The Miami Beach police have ended an investigation of a rape accusation against the creator of the ''Girls Gone Wild'' video series, Joe Francis. A Texan, 21, had told the police that she had gone to Mr. Francis's hotel suite on March 12 and that she believed she had been drugged because she woke up the next day in his bed and did not remember what had occurred. Mr. Francis, 31, said he and the woman had consensual sex. Spokesmen said that state attorney's office had decided there was insufficient evidence to bring charges and that a blood test did not show the woman had been drugged. Mireya Navarro (NYT)

title: Older Giants Redrawing Game Plans
description: Although none of the Giants were ready to use the word rebuilding on Thursday to describe their coming season, the absences of their starting quarterback and their not-yet-arrived wunderkind have changed the atmosphere inside the locker room of a team that did not see this big a shake-up coming.

title: Hospital Where 13 Were Killed Prepares to Face Lawsuits
description: It was the hospital that finally stopped Charles Cullen, but now Somerset Medical Center is in the eye of a legal storm.

title: Senate Extends Until 2007 Ban on Internet Access Tax

title: Bush Expresses 'Deep Disgust' Over Abuse of Iraqi Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  President Bush expressed revulsion today over photographs strengthening reports that some United States soldiers had abused and humiliated Iraqi prisoners. He said that the soldiers responsible would be punished, and that such conduct did not reflect the values of the American military or the American people.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Probation In Caesarean Death
description: A Utah woman who resisted her doctor's urging to have a Caesarean section and was charged with murder when one of her twins was stillborn received a sentence of 18 months probation after pleading guilty to two lesser charges of child endangerment. Judge Dennis M. Fuchs of Third District Court ordered that the woman, Melissa Ann Rowland, 28, receive mental health treatment. The conviction for child endangerment stems from the drugs that she admitted taking in her pregnancy and not her decision about the Caesarean. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: China Cools Lending, and Markets Shiver
description: Asian stock markets and currencies dipped on Thursday and prices for oil and other commodities slipped as world markets responded to news that Chinese authorities ordered banks to stop their rapid increase in lending at least until the weeklong May Day holiday begins on Saturday.

title: EXXON MOBIL'S REFINING EARNINGS HIT A 13-YEAR HIGH
description: Exxon Mobil Corporation posted a $5.44 billion profit yesterday as record United States gasoline prices resulted in the highest first-quarter refining earnings in 13 years. Net income fell to 83 cents a share from $7.04 billion, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier, Exxon said. In the period a year earlier, Exxon, based in Irving, Tex., had $2.2 billion in gains from an accounting change and the sale of its stake in Ruhrgas. First-quarter sales rose 6 percent, to $67.6 billion. ''Earnings on the refining and marketing side of the business were significantly above expectations,'' said Tim Ghriskey, chief investment officer at Solaris Asset Management. ''Anybody who goes to the gas pump these days shouldn't be surprised.'' Earnings were 3 cents a share higher than the highest estimate from 19 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Reliance Profit Up 29%
description: One of India's largest private enterprises, Reliance Industries, the oil exploration, refining and petrochemicals company, announced a 29 percent rise in quarterly profit. Reliance Industries, the flagship of the oil-to-wireless service company, the Reliance Group, said quarterly profit rose to 14.19 billion rupees ($322 million) in the quarter ended in March, from 11.01 billion rupees a year earlier. But the better-than-expected results failed to excite a bearish stock market, where the Reliance Group's stock price fell more than 2 percent, to 528.15 rupees ($12).

title: Preserve Performance Art? Can You Preserve the Wind?
description: One photo on the postcard and the program showed a naked, paint-besmeared man dragging a naked woman through more paint, all solemnly observed by dimly lighted musicians and art fans sitting in the background. There was a second photo on the postcard, of a naked woman (presumably the same naked woman) posing demurely in profile, her right breast dark with paint and hence obscured, standing next to a wall covered with butcher-paper on which she had pressed herself, leaving the predictable marks.

title: Thailand Sends Troops To Counter New Attacks
description: Thailand flooded its predominantly Muslim south with about 1,000 soldiers on Thursday as local residents and human rights groups questioned the overwhelming force used to kill more than 100 lightly armed attackers on Wednesday.

title: Williams Is Acquitted on Manslaughter Charge
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., April 30 — A jury today found the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams not guilty of manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a limousine driver at Mr. William's mansion. The jury could not reach a verdict on a charge of reckless manslaughter, but did convict Mr. Williams of four charges involving efforts to hinder the investigation.

title: In Front of Your Nose
description: ''We are all capable of believing things which we know to be untrue, and then, when we are finally proved wrong, impudently twisting the facts so as to show that we were right. Intellectually, it is possible to carry on this process for an indefinite time: the only check on it is that sooner or later a false belief bumps up against solid reality, usually on a battlefield.'' That's from George Orwell's 1946 essay ''In Front of Your Nose.'' It seems especially relevant right now, as we survey the wreckage of America's Iraq adventure.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Suspected Mercenaries To Be Deported
description: Zimbabwe agreed to send 70 suspected mercenaries to Equatorial Guinea. With 15 others already in jail there, the men are likely to be charged with plotting to overthrow that nation's ruler, Todoro Obiang Nguema. The transfer was arranged under a hastily drawn extradition treaty between the nations. The 70 men, who were arrested when a jet carrying most of them stopped at Harare in early March, claim that they were bound to guard miners in Congo, not to overthrow a government. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: . . . And Bulldozing It
description: ''IT was a horrendous scene, so many brave boys,'' Thomas Cartwright said haltingly as he stood on the porch of the Carter House. The two-story brick building was at the center of a battle here that was among the bloodiest of the Civil War. Mr. Cartwright, executive director and resident historian of the Carter House Museum, spoke in a voice tight with emotion about the 8,000 soldiers, Union and Confederate, who had died within a span of five hours on Nov. 30, 1864, in a battle that rivaled Pickett's Charge in terms of carnage.

description: The Riggs National Corporation, mired in a wide-ranging federal investigation into possible money laundering and terrorist financing through accounts held at its Riggs Bank subsidiary, said yesterday that it planned to sell or exit most of its venerable embassy and international banking operations.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Suspects In Killing Of Aid Workers
description: The police arrested 18 suspects in the killing of two Afghan aid workers and a policeman Monday night in the Panjwai District, Kandahar, in southern Afghanistan. The suspects were found with weapons and explosives, satellite telephones and a number of vehicles and motorbikes. They are also suspected of destroying road construction equipment last week in the same area, the interior minister, Ali Ahmad Jalali, said. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

description: United States military commanders here moved to loosen their siege of this city on Thursday, proposing to turn over the task of ending a fierce anti-American insurgency to a new force of Iraqi soldiers, led by officers once loyal to Saddam Hussein.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: LookSmart Buys Net Nanny For $5 Million
description: LookSmart, an Internet search service, said yesterday that it had acquired the Net Nanny business and assets for about $5 million in cash and stock from the software company BioNet Systems, which is closely held. The acquisition will help San Francisco-based LookSmart add more consumer online filtering services to its software products and services. Shares of LookSmart rose 8 cents, to $2.44.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Hindustan Lever Profit Falls
description: One of India's top consumer goods makers, Hindustan Lever, announced a 20.9 percent decline in profit for the quarter ended in March, after price cuts for best-selling products hurt profit margins. Hindustan Lever, the Indian unit of the Anglo-Dutch Unilever, which makes Lux soap, Surf detergent and Fair and Lovely skin-lightening cream, said that its net profit fell to 2.94 billion rupees ($65 million) in the quarter from 3.82 billion rupees ($86 million) in the period a year earlier. Hindustan Lever and multinational rival Proctor & Gamble India have been waging a fierce price war on detergents and shampoos.
